1 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


WASHINGTON'S AFRICA POLICY: WHO'S MAKING IT?


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

At the top levels, the Clinton foreign policy team probably has more experience with Africa than that of any previous administration.

* * *

Anthony Lake, the president's national security adviser, has researched and written about African issues and was deeply involved in formulating Africa policy for the Carter administration.

"Southern Africa was one of his primary areas of interests," says Marianne Spiegel, who was the Africa specialist on the State Department's Policy Planning Staff that Lake headed throughout the Carter years.

Lake wrote his Ph.D. dissertation at Princeton on South Africa and also authored The Tar-Baby Option, a study of Africa policy in the Nixon presidency. As a young foreign service officer, Lake served on the staff of Nixon's national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, but resigned to protest the 1970 bombing of Cambodia. 

Before joining the Carter administration, Lake headed International Voluntary Services, which sent Americans to assist grass-roots development efforts abroad. In recent years, he has taught international relations at Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts.

* * *

Secretary of State Warren Christopher also shaped Carter's policy as deputy secretary of state. Although less intensely involved in African issues than Lake, Christopher, in his role as chief negotiator for the release of American hostages in Iran, developed a close association with Algeria, a key intermediary in the negotiations.

* * *

Christopher's chief Africa aide will be the assistant secretary for Africa, George Moose, who was a junior member of the Carter Africa team, first as a desk officer and later as deputy director for southern Africa during the negotiations to end white rule in Rhodesia. In the early years of the Reagan administration, Moose served under Ambassador Jeanne Kirkpatrick at the United States Mission to the United Nations in New York.

He was named U.S. ambassador to the West African nation of Benin in 1983 and, in 1986, ambassador to Senegal. Like the current assistant secretary, Herman Cohen, who is also a former ambassador to Senegal, Moose is fluent in French.

* * *

At the Pentagon, a key post with significance for Africa policy is slated to go to Frank Wisner, who most recently has been undersecretary of State for security affairs, with major responsibility for coordinating the Bush administration's Somalia policy. Wisner's official involvement with Africa dates to 1976, when he was chosen to direct southern African affairs just as then-Secretary of State Kissinger embarked on a round of shuttle diplomacy in southern Africa.

Wisner was a player in various facets of Carter Africa policy, serving as ambassador to Zambia for part of the period. He then helped coordinate the Reagan administration's negotiations with Angola, Mozambique, Namibia and South Africa, before leaving Washington to become U.S. ambassador to Egypt during the late 1980s.

Wisner now moves to undersecretary for policy, under Secretary of Defense Les Aspin, for the Pentagon. One of the six or seven assistant secretaries serving Wisner is likely to be Jock Covey, a former Wisner aide at State, who is to head the newly renamed Bureau of Regional Affairs. The post of deputy secretary for Africa in that bureau is currently James Woods, an experienced Africa hand who has held the job since the Carter years. Slated for another assistant secretary post is Morton Halperin, until recently head of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union, who will head up a Defense Department bureau dealing with democracy and human rights issues.

* * *

Lawrence Summers, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's choice as undersecretary for international affairs, is a former professor of political economy at Harvard, who has dealt extensively with Africa as chief economist at the World Bank. Summers' appointment may be the most controversial of those that will deal significantly with Africa. His nomination, and earlier indications that he was being considered to head the Council of Economic Advisors, were criticized by environmental and other non-governmental groups. A statement issued by the Development Gap for Alternative Policies in Washington charges that Summers "aggressively promoted" World Bank policies "that have caused social, economic and environmental devastation across the southern hemisphere."

* * *

A number of key lower level posts are still unfilled. In the Africa Bureau at the State Department, three deputy assistant secretaries who are career officials remain in their posts. Decisions about those posts await Senate confirmation of George Moose, who is expected to name his own aides.

Principal deputy in the interim is Jeffrey Davidow, a former U.S. ambassador to Zambia, who is responsible for southern Africa. He will complete a three-year appointment to that post in March or April. Robert Houdek, who is in charge of east Africa and Zaire, and John Byerley, a lawyer recently named to handle economic matters, may or may not be retained by Moose.

* * *

At the National Security Council (NSC), Lake has chosen Jennifer Ward, the U.S. ambassador in Niger, to handle African affairs. Ward, who will complete her current tour in May, is a career foreign service officer who served a brief tenure in the 1970s as staff director of the House Africa subcommittee and as a Pentagon consultant. Her title is slated to be senior director for Africa, which is an elevation of the classification the position had in the Bush administration.

Ernest Wilson, a specialist on African economic issues, is coordinating global economic policy matters for the NSC. Wilson, who left a teaching post at the University of Michigan last fall to become a Council on Foreign Relations fellow and teach at the University of Maryland, will handle such issues as foreign aid reform.

* * *

On Capitol Hill, the House Africa subcommittee has a new chairman and the Senate Africa subcommittee a new ranking Republican. Paul Simon of Illinois continues to chair the Senate panel, but the ranking minority member is now James R. Jeffords of Vermont. He replaces Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, who retains membership on the Foreign Affairs Committee but relinquished her subcommittee spot in order to become the ranking minority member of the Labor Committee.

Harry Johnston from Florida succeeds Mervyn Dymally, who retired at the end of the last Congress, as head of the Africa subcommittee in the House. Democratic members also include Donald Payne and Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, Alcee Hastings from Florida and Don Edwards from California, along with Republicans Dan Burton (IN), Lincoln Diaz- Balart (FL) and Edward Royce (CA).

The subcommittee itself was almost eliminated in a restructuring design proposed by House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Lee Hamilton. The move would have combined the Africa and Inter-American Affairs subcommittees, but the plan was abandoned after strong opposition from the Congressional Black Caucus and Africa interest groups, including Africare, TransAfrica and the Washington Office on Africa. *


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 8, 1993


VIEWPOINT
The Clinton Administration Should Back the Democratic Forces in Zaire


BYLINE: William Close


LENGTH: 707 words


DATELINE: Big Piney, Wyoming


 

The killing and destruction in Zaire is further evidence of the total breakdown of government in that central African nation, presided over by a man who has been one of Washington's closest allies in Africa. President Mobutu Sese Seko appears, once again, to have hammered the process of democratization to a standstill in his starving and bleeding country.

The fact that most of the dead were soldiers, in three days of violence that began January 28, points up the cynicism of Mobutu's misrule. 

Troops of the regular army are given little or no ammunition and are paid poorly, if at all. They have become thugs to survive, but they are as hungry and as alienated from the president as the people they beat and loot in Kinshasa's sprawling slums. No one who knew Zaire was surprised that the army rioted after being paid with the new banknotes that Mobutu had printed and which most shopkeepers refuse to accept.

In contrast, Mobutu's Special Presidential Detachment is a well- armed elite, using tanks and trucks to raid the homes of wealthy foreigners or members of the opposition and haul away the booty. Mobutu's method of restoring order after the riots was to send the special detachment on a killing orgy against members of the army and their families, leaving hundreds of dead and wounded in a city lacking both medical care and food.

Yet Mobutu stays in power.

Backed by the detachment, he blocks every move of the transition government that was chosen by a pro-democracy coalition. Robbed of the power of the purse, Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi is stymied. Meetings of the High Council of the Republic, the democratic parliament headed by Roman Catholic Archbishop Laurent Pasinya Monsengwo, have been barred by Mobutu. Gatherings of more than five people have been banned. The press is muzzled. In the resulting power vacuum, Mobutu skillfully exploits the rivalries and tensions among opposition forces.

Neither Tshisekedi nor any other opposition leader can function as head of a transitional government as long as the president controls the special detachment and the central bank.

Provoking the army to violence appears to have been an intentional maneuver by the president. It has frightened away Europeans who could have been witnesses to further crackdowns against the democracy process. It has provided an excuse for Mobutu to move against the transition government, which he blames for promoting instability.

Despite the mounting evidence of corruption, incompetence and repression in Zaire, the Bush administration failed to oppose Mobutu openly and vigorously.

President Clinton has said that his administration will not coddle dictators. To make that commitment meaningful in Zaire, he should reverse the policy that has allowed Mobutu to pillage his own country and people.

The Clinton administration should signal, in the strongest possible terms, that leniency toward Mobutu is at an end. In the name of U.S. taxpayers, whose money has funded Mobutu's lavish lifestyle and swollen his foreign bank accounts, the American government should work to freeze Mobutu's financial assets, as well as those of his cronies, and encourage European countries to do the same. Washington should also support imposition of a fuel embargo to pressure the president to yield to the demands of his people. *

Dr. William Close, lived for 16 years in Zaire where he served as personal physician to President Mobutu Sese Seko. He now practices medicine in Wyoming.


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


VIEWPOINT
Black Rhinos are Nearly Extinct


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

One of Africa's grandest beasts will disappear unless saving the rhino can be made more profitable than killing it.

Harare, Zimbabwe

by Nick O'Connor

In 1961, the British naturalist Sir Peter Scott warned that the black rhinoceros, a species found only in Africa, would be extinct within 30 years. He was too pessimistic, but not by much.

Today, there are fewer than 2,000 of the animals left, scattered in a handful of African countries. (There are thought to be about 5,000 African white rhino, mainly in South Africa, and fewer than 3,000 of other species in Asia.) 

I am a tobacco farmer, a third-generation Zimbabwean, but like many farmers here, I am in the front line of the fight to save our rhinos. Sadly, it is a fight that we are losing.

The 1989 rhino census recorded about 2,000 in the country, with 130 in commercial conservancies and the rest in our national parks. Zimbabwe was home to 50% of all the remaining rhino in Africa. Perhaps this news alerted the poachers, because reports of shootings started coming in from all over.

Three years later, the most recent census shows that we are left with a maximum of 450 rhinos, and probably no more than 300. In other words, on average, more than one rhino has been shot every day. Births in the conservancies increased numbers there to 149 in 1992, despite 15 having been poached.

For years, conservationists have warned of poachers crossing our borders, prompting our government to initiate a "shoot-to-kill" policy against poachers from neighboring Zambia. We have even used trackers disguised as peasant fishermen along the Zambezi river boundary between the two countries, resulting in lethal games of cat-and-mouse.

While the Zambians continue to poach, it is now obvious that most of the current poaching is by fellow Zimbabweans, and this really hurts. Realizing that the Zambians could not be stopped, local poachers apparently decided to get in on the action. Starting in the national parks, using inside information, they have quietly and systematically killed our rhino.

In the past two months, the poachers have changed tactics. With rhino so scarce in the national parks, there has been a full-scale attack on the conservancies. These refuges, varying in size from 100,000 to 500,000 acres, were formed by groups of commercial farmers who joined large tracts of land to create mini-parks.

There are five such parks in Zimbabwe. We were determined to pool our resources and provide the security needed to end the killing. Until late last year we were succeeding, but fate has been unkind. The 1992 drought that devastated Zimbabwe's agriculture has financially crippled many of the farmers involved in the conservancies and it coincided with an increase in the poachers' attacks.

Last month one conservancy lost all 12 of its black rhino. We called a "council of war," and two weeks ago we just managed to stop four poachers, armed with AK47s and driving a high-speed vehicle, from entering the Midlands Black Rhino Conservancy of which I am a member.

Now we too have had our first loss. We can only do our best, and we are in desperate need of help. But whatever we do will not remove my sense of guilt for failing.

What a world we live in, where a few individuals in the African bush must shoulder the responsibility of protecting a species for all our children and are forced to make constant appeals to the developed nations for money. This cannot be the long-term solution.

The crisis of the rhino is fueled by the demand for its horn from nations of the Far East. The resulting scarcity of animals drives prices higher, prompting more killings. Extinction is the inevitable result.

Because supply and demand will always prevail in a capitalist world, there seems no point in appealing for decency from the Yemenis, Japanese or Chinese, who erroneously believe that a pinch of horn will cure them of anything.

Fifteen years ago, the International Convention on Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) made all trade in horn illegal. We have been losing the battle ever since. The black rhino population of Africa has fallen from 65,000 to fewer than 2,000 in the same period.

In my opinion, the answer to the rhino's survival lies in private ownership. Currently, because the rhino is an endangered species, it is protected by the state. Individuals are not allowed to sell rhinos, and yet there is a massive potential market for them. In theory, profits from rhino sales could be used to pay for all the necessary conservation work and would encourage every farmer in Africa to set up breeding programs.

As things now stand, even if poaching could be eliminated, the encroachment of people would still threaten not only the rhino, but all Africa's wildlife. In the constant struggle for scarce resources, with ever- increasing human populations, wildlife will always lose out unless it can be used to make money. This has happened in every single industrial nation, and it is naive to assume that Third World countries will follow a different path to development.

The rhino is a dangerous beast, as welcome to most African farmers as wolves were in Scotland or bears in the New Forest of England, before hunting eradicated them. Until rural people see wild animals as a vital source of revenue as important to their financial well being as farming or cattle the rhino, the elephant and many other species are doomed.

We in the conservancies will fight on, but we need help. Zimbabwe's rhino may only have 18 months left. After that, all arguments will be academic. *

INSIGHT/Guardian News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


February 8, 1993


ZAIRE
Fast Facts


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Size: 905,405 square miles (2,344,999 square kilometers), Zaire is the second largest country in sub-Saharan Africa and is larger than a quarter the size of the United States.

Capital: Kinshasa

Date of Independence: June 30, 1960

Flag: A raised fist holding a torch encircled by a light green rectangle. 

Gross National Product: $220 dollars per capita (1990 dollars)

Population: 37.3 million

Zaire's population is ethnically diverse with more than 200 different groups.

Religion: Half the population is Christian, and Zaire has developed independent, indigenous churches alongside the Roman Catholic Church and Protestant denominations. About half of Zaire's people practice traditional animist beliefs.

Language: While the official language is French, most Zaireans speak one or more of numerous local or regional languages, the largest of which are Tshiluba and Kikongo.

Economy: The country is rich in natural resources but suffers from depressed international prices and domestic instability. Major exports include copper, tin, silver and diamonds.

Government: Zaire has been ruled for 27 years by President Mobutu Sese Seko, long considered one of Africa's most corrupt and authoritarian leaders.


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


5 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


PRESSURES FOR CHANGE BUILD AMID ZAIRE VIOLENCE
Will the recent clashes break the deadlock between pro-democracy forces and a dictator who appears to be losing his grip?


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1027 words


DATELINE: Kinshasa, Zaire


 

More than a year of military tension and political power struggles exploded in Zaire's capital at the end of January, when soldiers went on a looting and killing rampage after being paid with worthless currency printed by the besieged regime of President Mobutu Sese Seko. Pro- democracy officials say at least 1,000 people were killed and scores of others injured when troops in Zaire's regular army began rioting on the streets of Kinshasa, the capital.

Most of the dead were soldiers killed by Mobutu Sese Seko's elite presidential guard unit. "There were lots of soldiers missing at role call" after the clashes, says Jean Joseph Mukendi, a close aide to Prime Minister Etianne Tshisekedi who was chosen by the pro-democracy coalition to head a transition government. The current conflict recalls similar violence 16 months ago when unpaid soldiers went on a looting spree across the country, leaving more than 100 dead and forcing the evacuation of some 20,000 foreigners. 

Transportation is almost at a halt. The military has sealed off the Gombe area of Kinshasa, where most of the foreigners who have chosen to stay in Zaire reside. Soldiers also have been shooting outside the Intercontinental Hotel, an oasis of privilege in the impoverished and looted capital.

Opposition leaders accuse Mobutu of instigating the revolt to give the appearance that he is the only person who can keep Zaire under control. The president's critics say the frustration of the soldiers was predictable, because both shopkeepers and the democracy movement had publicized their refusal to accept Mobutu's new bank notes. "It's just cinema," says Buana Kabue, leader of Zaire's Human Rights League. "If the international community doesn't intervene, the dictatorship is going to enforce itself and continue to kill to stay in power."

Three years ago, Mobutu promised to cede power to a growing democracy movement. A national democracy conference last summer chose Tshisekedi to head the transition government, but Mobutu hired and fired him within a span of two weeks.

About 600 Belgian troops have been standing by in Brazzaville across the Congo River from Zaire's capital, but Brussels said that all but 120 of those forces would be withdrawn. The troops were flown in to help evacuate more than 1,000 Belgian, French and other foreign nationals from Kinshasa. Expatriates say they feel more threatened by the latest violence than by previous clashes because the soldiers appear to be targeting foreigners. At least seven have been killed in the melee, including France's ambassador to Zaire, Philipe Brenard, who died in a machine-gun attack on the French embassy.

Prime Minister Tshisekedi appealed for foreign assistance to halt the killings, but Mobutu vowed to bar the Belgians from intervening in their former colony. Then, in a conciliatory move, the president made his personal riverboat available to help evacuate Belgians and other foreigners.

Although Mobutu seized power in Zaire in 1965 with CIA backing, his attitude toward his foreign allies has been ambivalent. In the 1970s, he began an "authenticity" campaign to shake off colonial cultural residues. He prohibited the wearing of ties, ruled that Zairean names must replace "Christian" names, and changed the name of the country and adjacent river from the Congo to Zaire.

Mobutu retains power now by keeping a tight grip on the nation's purse strings, maintaining the loyalty of his armed presidential guards through gifts and money. But regular army units are out of control, and the chain of command has crumbled, leaving Zaire in a complete state of lawlessness. The country has become a sweltering haven for mercenaries, counterfeiters and diamond smugglers.

Mobutu rules the central bank. Bank-note paper often is flown to Zaire from Germany, where it is printed, and then rushed to Mobutu's boat. He spends most of his time on the river, apparently to avoid the wrath of the hungry and desperate citizenry in the capital.

Zaire's latest military and political crisis revolves around currency worth about two U.S. dollars. When Mobutu ordered distribution of the new 5-million-zaire notes, his arch rival, Prime Minister Tshisekedi declared the bills nonlegal tender. Merchants and street vendors refused to accept them.

Although payday for Zaire's army falls at the end of the month, soldiers often wait months to receive even part of their wages. Mobutu's decision to meet the army payroll with 5-million-zaire notes prompted immediate revolt.

A U.S. dollar that bought 50,000 zaires a year ago now buys almost 3 million, reflecting Zaire's economic collapse. Mobutu says a new bill of 10 million zaires will be put into circulation soon. But the conflict over currency is a symbol of the country's ongoing power struggle. Last week, Mobutu implicitly accused Tshisekedi of high treason for rejecting the new currency. At the same time, the president announced that "democracy remains on course." *


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 8, 1993


SUDAN
Fast Facts


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Size: Sudan is the largest country in Africa. At 967,568 square miles (2,506,001 square kilometers), the east African country is larger than the United States east of the Mississippi river. 

Capital: Khartoum

Date of Independence: January 1, 1956

Flag: A green triangle over bars of red, white and black.

Gross National Product: $480 per capita (1989 dollars)

Population: 25.1 million

Some 70% of the people are of Arab origin, living largely in northern areas, while 30% are blacks of diverse ethnic backgrounds who live in the south.

Religion: Most northerners are Sunni Muslims The south is largely a Christian and animist area.

Language: Arabic is the official language of the government and is spoken by more than 50% of Sudanese; English is also widely spoken throughout the country. In southern Sudan there are more than 120 languages and dialects.

Economy: Sudan has an agriculture-based economy. Major exports include cotton, sorghum, livestock and petroleum.

Government: Sudan has endured a succession of dictators since independence in 1956. The present military government has been headed by Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmad El Bashir since he seized power in a 1989 coup.


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


7 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


WAR CREATES FAMINE IN SOUTHERN SUDAN
Starvation in Somalia finally caught our attention. But in nearby Sudan, at least 600,000 people have died in a bloody civil war that attracts little notice.


BYLINE: Francois Vinsot


LENGTH: 1640 words


DATELINE: Waat, Sudan


 

What strikes you when you come to Waat is the smell of death and the vultures watching for corpses, says Lisa, an American aid worker at one of the few spots in southern Sudan where international relief agencies are allowed to operate. Tonight the buzzards won't hover in vain.

N'deng's five-year-old body, shriveled and covered with flies, will be left to rot outside the camp. N'deng can't be buried because dying of starvation is ignominious, explains his emaciated father, who has just arrived here with his family after a three-week walk.

The plight of this town highlights the tragedy of the entire civilian population of southern Sudan, which is trapped in a web of wars. Fighting has raged since 1983, when long-simmering animosities erupted into open warfare between an authoritarian Islamic government in the north and rebels fighting for autonomy of the Christian and animist south. The spark that reignited the three-decade conflict was the government's attempt to impose Sharia, a strict Islamic code, throughout the country. But racial factors are also behind the years of suspicion and periodic warfare, with black southerners charging that the policies of their Arab rulers are racist and discriminatory. 

International power politics have further fueled the civil war. The government is supported by Islamic Iran and Libya, while rebels find refuge in Kenya and Uganda, across Sudan's southern borders.

N'deng's family is among the thousands who had to flee their homes when government forces swept through southern Sudan early this year in a new offensive against the rebels. Roaming the desert, the family followed the sounds of United Nations relief planes, vaguely hoping to find food, peace and shelter before eventually wandering into Waat, a rebel- controlled village in the Upper Nile region.

Until last summer, Waat's 3,000 semi-nomadic inhabitants managed to survive on their meager livestock and an unreliable well pump. In late August, with war-induced famine sweeping the region, the Khartoum authorities allowed the United Nations to fly emergency aid from Kenya to the airstrip here. Since then, the town has become an open camp, swollen by more than 15,000 civilians who have converged on it from all parts of southern Sudan.

Life in Waat is punctuated by a succession of sounds, some homely, some ominous. Morning begins with the cock's crow. During the day, the murmur of voices is broken by occasional bursts of distant gunfire.

People also listen warily for the characteristic burr of bombers. Each time one approaches, the crowd falls silent until after the noise overhead has died down.

At nightfall there are cries of children playing in puddles and the chanting of adults. As the night wears on, only the thud of tom-toms remains.

The rumble of an incoming relief plane is probably the most welcome sound of all. Whenever it is heard, all activity stops and hundreds flock toward the runway where the white Buffalo aircraft will deliver the food on which the lives of everyone here depend. Nothing grows in Waat, and the grazing is too scant to support enough livestock for 20,000 people.

A Slender Thread. The vital air link, however, is tenuous. Permission to land must be obtained from Khartoum each month. Even if permission is granted, the overused aircraft can break down at any moment. Four months ago, scores of people died when the plane was grounded for 10 days of repairs. Many more starved to death over the next three weeks, when relief operations were suspended temporarily after five aid workers in southern Sudan were killed.

According to a French doctor on a fact-finding mission in Waat, this is a place of survivors and of immense will power. Only those who were strong enough to walk for weeks have made it here. Typical of those is a 45-year-old grandmother in charge of six children. Their father had been killed in combat and their mother had died on the way to the camp. Bad as the situation is, Waat is a humanitarian oasis.

But even in this oasis, two-thirds of the children face starvation.

The crisis is made worse by a severe shortage of drinkable water. Even if the balky well pump became fully operational, it could not produce nearly enough water. Latrines are few and far between. Diseased cattle and dogs roam freely about the camp.

People are forced to drink and wash from polluted puddles. The food is also contaminated, because the "dry aid'' supplied by the United Nations must be mixed with water.

Can't Cope. The three UN aid workers now based in Waat are completely unequipped to deal with a crisis of this magnitude. Exhausted and grieving, they can only express their frustration by sending report after report. But they feel that nobody is listening.

"The people out there don't have a clue about what's happening here,'' says one. "We see the vultures, we watch people die. What are they doing?''

Lisa was the only UN staff member in Waat when there were no flights for 10 days. "I had to tell the mother of a dying child that the plane had broken down,'' she says. "Sometimes when I send my reports by radio I burst into tears.''

As long as the southern Sudanese were successfully resisting the government's offensive, the SPLA remained united. But since the beginning of 1992, when one rebel-held town after another fell into the hands of government forces, the latent tension within the southern camps has degenerated into open conflict.

Now that Khartoum controls about 90% of southern Sudan, the rebels have split mainly along ethnic lines. Longtime SPLA leader John Garang still resists in the southwest with the backing of the Dinka people. A breakaway group called the Nasir faction, which charges Garang with undemocratic practices, holds out in the east where the Nuer people predominate. Elders belonging to other ethnic groups play a complex game of shifting alliances. The region's people, as always, are caught in the middle.

But the famine, like the war, has thrown the groups together again. Although Waat is in a Nuer area, many of those who have traveled the farthest across the desert to get here, and whose children show the red tinted hair characteristic of malnutrition, are from Dinka areas.

As long as the fighting continues, the plight of the southern Sudanese is sure to worsen. Crops sown during the wet season are plundered by armies at the start of the dry season. Cattle that have not been decimated by hunger and disease are often stolen. Millions of people wander the countryside, at the mercy of emergency aid and those who control it.

Tip of the Iceberg. In the immediate future, the best hope for many of the region's starving people would appear to be the already crowded refugee camps in neighboring Uganda and Kenya, where they could become internationally recognized refugees and not mere "displaced persons" inside Sudan.

But United Nations officials and field workers have become hamstrung by political factors.

Three years ago, the world body launched Operation Lifeline Sudan to deliver relief to the starving south, exerting strong pressure on a weak Sudanese government to secure its cooperation. But since Islamic hard- liners seized power in Khartoum in 1989, Lifeline has become a shadow of itself. Every month Khartoum rejects some of the relief flights attempted by the United Nations. Much of the aid doesn't reach Sudan, let alone get distributed.

The government in Khartoum claims there is no famine. Official success in limiting the entry and movements of foreigners, including journalists, is one reason the plight of Sudan's people is so little known.

So when visiting Waat, it is easy to be haunted by a niggling question. Why has the government now allowed a foreign reporter into a place where aid workers can't cope and where only soldiers look well-fed? Could it be that Waat is the most presentable spot in southern Sudan? * INSIGHT/Guardian News Service

Francois Vinsot reports for the French division of the BBC World Service. This article was co-written with Henri Astier of the BBC World Service.


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


8 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


GOLD PRICE DROP IDLES MINERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
The economic downturn could threaten delicate political negotiations.


BYLINE: Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 867 words


DATELINE: Johannesburg, South Africa


 

At a time when South Africa is desperately trying to break out of a four-year recession, the all-important gold price has hit a seven-year low, sending shock waves through the economy and throwing thousands of blacks out of work. There is concern that the continuing recession may blunt the prospects for a smooth transition to democratic rule.

South Africa's 33 mines still produce over 600 tons of the glittering metal each year, making the country the world's largest gold producer. But South Africa also has the deepest and some of the most expensive mines on earth, and they require a gold price of about $400 per ounce in order to be profitable. 

Gold recently dipped to $326.50 per ounce its lowest level since the mid-1980s. Analysts say there is little hope of improvement in the near future.

"As long as world inflation is low, gold is really not going to perform well," says Mike Daly, a South African economist.

Recent global crises such as the Gulf War have shown that investors no longer turn to gold in times of trouble. But gold still brings in more than $5 billion annually for South Africa more than a quarter of the country's export earnings.

The worsening state of South Africa's gold mines spells trouble for the entire region.

Forty percent of mineworkers come from South Africa's neighbors, who depend heavily on miners' remittances. In Lesotho, for example, 45% of the gross domestic product comes from this remitted pay, according to Francois Viruly, senior economist for the South African Chamber of Mines, the umbrella group for the country's six major mining houses.

South Africa's gold mines currently employ over 380,000 miners, but 150,000 jobs have been lost since 1987, and more cutbacks are in the works.

The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM), the country's largest union, has won hard-fought victories in recent years for miners who spend their working days a mile or more underground in a humid inferno, drilling and blasting holes in a wall of gray rock to expose a thin seam of ore. Several hundred workers are killed every year, but lack of jobs in the region is so severe that there is never a shortage of replacements.

The painful irony of South Africa's gold industry is that it was built on cheap labor. Now labor accounts for 50% of total costs, and South Africa's old mines have moved from being the lowest-cost producers in the world to being among the highest.

Because of the crisis, NUM accepted a wage increase of only six percent (inflation is 12%) in order to avoid layoffs. The union, which has about 300,000 members, also has asked the government to subsidize marginal mines where over 80,000 people remain employed, but the government has not agreed.

"The answer we got was to let the free market take care of it," says Jerry Majatlagi, a spokesman for NUM.

However, the market has not been helping South Africa's gold mining industry for the past decade.

The gold price has fallen steadily since early 1980 when it reached an all-time high of $875 per ounce. The recent tumble results primarily from the strength of the U.S. dollar, many analysts believe.

Increasing supplies of gold on the world market have also pushed down the price. Since the Gulf War, some analysts suspect that Iraq has sold off large amounts of its gold to meet foreign exchange needs. The failed economy of the former Soviet Union sparked sales of gold by Russia to finance the move to a free-market economy.

"If we're going to grow in the years to come we're going to need foreign exchange to get the economy moving," Viruly warns. "The mining industry will have to play an important role so we have the foreign exchange to grow."

The low gold price should be a warning that South Africa must restructure and diversify its economy, strengthening particularly its manufacturing sector, economists say. South Africa needs to produce more value-added goods that can take over from gold as major foreign exchange earners. *


LOAD-DATE: March 17, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


9 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 8, 1993


ANGOLA AND ZAIRE EDGE ONTO CROWDED FOREIGN POLICY AGENDA
Two of Africa's longest-simmering conflicts are hot again, presenting President Clinton with an early test of his response to crises in areas where the United States has had significant Cold War interests.


BYLINE: Reed Kramer * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1747 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

With the new Africa policy team not yet complete, Clinton administration officials are scrambling to react to a resumption of Angola's bloody civil war and to fighting in Zaire. The Angolan strife pits a formerly U.S.-backed rebel group against a government that won a United Nations-monitored election last year. In Zaire, where an estimated 1,000 people died in rioting late last month, a democracy movement is trying to oust a ruler who is one of Washington's oldest allies in Africa.

Both Angola and Zaire have posed prickly issues for previous presidents, and several of President Clinton's foreign policy experts grappled with the problems while serving in the Carter administration. The latest difficulties have prompted the State Department to dispatch a five- person delegation to the first round of United Nations-sponsored peace talks on Angola that began late last month and to send a senior official to Brussels for consultations on Zaire with the Belgian and French governments in early February.

A bipartisan group from both houses of Congress has appealed to Secretary of State Warren Christopher for an aggressive U.S. peacemaking role in Angola. "The U.S. can make a positive difference in one of the major crisis areas of the world," a letter from a number of members says. 

The current Angolan conflict has some of the elements of fighting that raged throughout the 1980s, when the Soviet and Cuban-backed government battled to a virtual draw against the rebel group Unita, led by Jonas Savimbi, who had the support of the United States and South Africa. While Washington and Moscow are no longer waging a proxy war in Angola, and South African soldiers have withdrawn from Angolan territory, Angola says South Africa is still active in the conflict.

"We know that the Pretoria regime is trying to save Savimbi," Angolan Foreign Minister Venancio de Moura said in a telephone interview earlier this month during a visit to New York. De Moura charges that neighboring Zaire also is aiding Unita.

Prior to Clinton's inauguration, Africa watchers expected him to respond to last September's Angolan voting by extending diplomatic recognition to the government headed by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. Although Angola won independence from Portugal in 1975, previous American administrations have refused to establish formal ties with the Marxist-oriented regime.

On Zaire, Clinton was thought likely to distance the American government from President Mobutu Sese Seko, who traded on his long- standing ties with the CIA to make Zaire the third largest recipient of U.S. aid to sub-Saharan Africa over the past three decades.

But worsening violence in both countries has narrowed Clinton's options. Although sentiment favoring recognition of the Angolan government is strong within the administration, some officials are advocating a delay while the United Nations sponsors peace talks. Another argument on the go-slow side is the Angolan government's recent loss of territorial control. Unita now holds an estimated 70% or more of the country, which is about the size of California and Texas combined.

In recent combat, Unita rebels beat back an all-out assault on its headquarters at Huambo, Angola's second largest city, although fighting in the area continues. Unita troops also seized the town of Soyo, a key oil- producing center, and they have advanced to the outskirts of the capital, Luanda, where they blew up a pumping station, leaving the city's 2.5 million people facing a spreading cholera outbreak without water. Rebel units also are reported to be active in the enclave of Cabinda, where a U.S.-owned subsidiary pumps most of the country's oil, the government's main revenue earner.

The State Department has warned Unita not to attack U.S. oil facilities in Cabinda and has deplored indications that both Angolan sides are rearming for further war.

The fighting that resumed in October has claimed as many as 15,000 lives. More than one million people, a tenth of the population, face imminent starvation, according to the World Food Program. Experts calculate that the damage to Angola's infrastructure, including buildings, roads, bridges and communications facilities, has been greater in recent months than in years of earlier fighting.

The UN-sponsored elections, the result of a 1991 peace agreement ending 16 years of fighting, were judged generally free and fair by outside observers. But Savimbi's rejection of the official results, which gave him 40.97% of the total to 49.57% for dos Santos, has stalled the electoral process. With the country now returned to a war footing, the runoff required to give one candidate a majority cannot be held.

Peace talks are focusing on forging a cease-fire agreement and an interim arrangement to share power until a runoff can be held.

The congressional letter to Secretary of State Christopher calls for an expanded UN presence in Angola to help ensure the success of any negotiated agreement. The letter's signers advocate recognizing the dos Santos government, on condition that it accept an expanded UN mandate.

Other members of Congress, including Senate Africa subcommittee chair Paul Simon, are urging Christopher to recognize the Luanda government without delay, arguing that it already has met U.S. conditions by holding internationally supervised elections.

Both members of Congress and administration officials say the United Nations should demobilize the rival armies and create a unified Angolan defense force. Doing so before the September vote might have averted the current troubles, many observers believe.

But the dos Santos government has been wary of allowing the world body to assume functions that might infringe Angolan sovereignty. In the government's view, it is Unita's refusal to accept the election results, plus interference by South Africa and Zaire, that has revived the war.

As evidence of what it says is an illegal South African supply operation into Unita territory, the government published a list of four- engine cargo planes and small aircraft with registration numbers, as well as the names of air crew members said to have taken part in the ferry flights.

South African Foreign Minister Roelof "Pik" Botha has denied the charges, saying in a letter to UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali that his government is not supporting Unita "militarily or in any other way."

Luanda also complains that Zaire has been serving as a rear base for Unita forces and a conduit for the shipment of fuel and other essentials to Savimbi. The CIA used Zaire to supply Unita during the six years of active American support in the Reagan and Bush years, and Mobutu and Savimbi are old confederates.

However, Mobutu has his hands full with troubles at home, after the rioting in late January by army troops.

"I've got to think this is the beginning of the end for Mo," says one government strategist, using the moniker for the Zaire president favored in official Washington. "We've got to face up to what that means for us."

Over the past year, the Bush administration repeatedly pressed Mobutu to cede powers to a transitional government chosen last August by a national conference of the country's political, religious and professional organizations. But appeals from members of Congress and Mobutu's critics to apply firm pressure on Mobutu to step aside were not heeded.

"Every time we got to that point, we were rebuffed by word from on- high at the White House," says one frustrated government official who is among those who have advocated a more active U.S. diplomatic stance to promote democracy.

Although Mobutu has been criticized by successive U.S. administrations, when faced with a crisis he has been able to count on Washington's support. During the late 1970s, the Carter administration twice backed interventions by the French and Belgians to rescue Mobutu from domestic upheaval.

U.S. involvement in the recent effort to evacuate foreign nationals from Zaire was minimal. A U.S. Army C-130 cargo plane was sent to carry supplies for the Belgians who sent troops to stand by in neighboring Congo. But officials with experience in the region know that bigger decisions about Zaire lie just ahead.

Following the meetings in Brussels with French and Belgian officials, the hold-over assistant secretary of State for Africa, Herman Cohen, is participating in the Clinton administration's deliberations on policy options for handling the crisis. "We knew we would have to deal with Zaire," says one new appointee. "But now it has moved to the top of the list." *

MARCH 8, 1993


SECTION: LETTERS


LENGTH: 869 words


 

We cherish letters from our readers. And we hope that these pages will encourage debate on the issues raised.

To send a letter or to submit a Viewpoint for consideration, write:

The Editor

Box 3851

Durham, NC 27702

fax (919) 286-2614

To the editor:

I wish to thank you and your staff sincerely for your informative newspaper, AfricaNews. We have seized the opportunity to reprint your highly enlightening article on American policy toward Africa in the 1990s. We are hoping that our readers will pay keen attention in an effort to further their understanding of some of the thinking about Africa going on in Washington. 

Kenneth Y. Best

Managing Director

The Observer Co. (Gambia) Ltd.

To the editor:

Thank you very much for the Special Report on Somalia in the December 21, 1992 - January 3, 1993, issue of AfricaNews. This issue provides the beginning of the kind of in-depth and integrated coverage that I have been frustrated to not find in mainstream newspapers. It is extremely important for the public of the United States (and elsewhere) to see and appreciate the richness and diversity that is being trampled by violence and starvation in Somalia.

There is one aspect of life in Somalia, however, that still needs to be discussed. That is the social, psychological and physical foundation that is

given to 98 percent of all females in Somalia: the tradition of infibulation, or female genital mutilation.

This (practice) will have a profound effect on the recovery of the men, women, children and infrastructure of Somalia. In particular, there are even more obstacles than usual to the birthing of the next generation of Somali babies, who will have to be formed in wombs devastated by hunger and sickness and cross a threshold into the world that has been complicated and diseased by infibulation.

I urge you to break the media silence on the lives and concerns of the women and girls who will produce and bring up the next generation.

Kristen R. Barney

Arlington, Virginia

Reply: A report on female circumcision is already in progress.

To the editor:

You're hitting the African agenda right on target! I've just about reached the point where I would like to lift almost the entire newspaper onto the pages of our magazine.

Jan Burgess, Editor

Review of African Political Economy

Sheffield, England Editor's Desk

With this issue, we welcome 9,000 new subscribers who responded to our recent promotional mailing. We hope that you, along with our valued old subscribers, will help us celebrate our upcoming 20th anniversary by telling us what you find commendable or objectionable in our coverage, by sharing your views with other readers through letters to our Viewpoint section, and by telling us what you'd like to see in future issues.

In turn, we'll try you keep you posted -- on the major challenges facing Africa, on how African developments will affect you, and from time to time, on how our other media work is going. At the moment, we have a television crew in Zaire, documenting the struggle between old and new political and economic orders -- important work, we think, in this era when global interdependence is acknowledged in policy discussions, even if not yet taken into account in policy decisions.

Journalism, to us, is the chance to make a difference by providing the most accurate, reliable information to the largest number of people possible. We thank you for joining us and helping to make that effort possible. * OK

11 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


DATELINE: AFRICA


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

SAVE THE RHINO

The World Wildlife Fund said last week that Africa's black rhinos are at the top of its list of endangered species needing protection, along with the Siberian tiger. The Washington, D-based group said that only the southern African nation of Zimbabwe has a significant number of rhinos, whose horn is prized as an aphrodisiac in parts of Asia and the Middle East. In the last two decades, the animal's numbers have declined by 90 percent to about 2,000. In part of an energetic effort by Zimbabwe to protect the species, a member of parliament, Benjamin Moyo, was jailed last month after being convicted of unlawful possession of rhino horns. The white rhinoceros, although more numerous, is threatened as well. Botswana, to Zimbabwe's south, has moved two white rhinos to a sanctuary, in what is the first step of a drive to capture and guard what are believed to be the country's last 10 examples of the species.

EMERGING WOMEN

The United States was not the only country to experience the "year of the woman" in 1992. Women in the East African nation of Kenya have been busy carving out a spot for themselves in the once all-male political arena. In December, six women won seats in the national assembly, and several women were elected to town and county councils. 

With the emergence of numerous women's organizations following President Daniel arap Moi's decision to legalize opposition parties in 1991, women began to organize on a broad front and to develop a political agenda. Women candidates raised concerns about shortages of food products, increasing costs of education, and the lack of sufficient health facilities. Their campaigns pushed these traditional "women's issues" into the discussions about political priorities.

The newly elected members of parliament and local councils say they are hopeful that increasing educational opportunities for women will lead to a greater representation of women at every level of government. Like their American counterparts, Kenyan women are pledging to create a legacy for generations of women to come.

PAYING THE PRICE

It has been two years since the army of Mali's ex-President Moussa Traore turned their guns on him, refusing to carry out his orders to shoot anti-government protesters. Now, in the wake of Mali's first free elections since independence from France in 1960, the former head of state has been convicted and sentenced to death for the mass killing of 106 pro-democracy demonstrators in the weeks before the soldiers joined the rebellion and ousted him. Three of Traore's senior officers also received death sentences for their part in the killings.

International observers credit Mali's military-led transitional government with setting the pace for democracy in the West African country. Traore's successor as head of state, Lt. Col. Amadou Toiumani Toure joined with interim Prime Minister Soumana Sacko to organize multiparty elections. A former opposition leader, Alpha Oumar Konare, took over as the newly elected president last June.

In a speech at the inauguration, Toure cautioned that reconciliation would serve better than revenge. However, he said Mali's democracy had been bought with a price, and "the country cannot forget those who died while fighting for freedom." Government officials argue that the deposed leaders' convictions will allow Malians to put the past behind them and get on with the business of implementing the democratic reforms they have long sought.

UNSANCTIONED?

The lifting of diplomatic and economic sanctions against the South African government may be on the horizon, signaling relief for the country's recession stricken economy. In late February, leaders of the African National Congress (ANC) joined efforts to encourage the international community to remove trade limitations, once a date for the nation's first nonracial elections is set.

In 1991, the United States and the European Community lifted government bans on trade with South Africa. However, a number of major U.S. cities, including Chicago, Los Angeles and New York, have maintained local laws barring city business with firms that have ties in South Africa.

Tough sanctions, imposed during the height of the anti-apartheid movement, have had a strong impact on the South African economy. The nation's gross domestic product has continued to decline over the past several years, and economists estimate that over 250,000 jobs have been lost in the past three years.

ANC leaders argue that it is time to make efforts to stabilize the economy, starting with fighting the current recession and creating jobs, as a base for democratic developments.

Following the anti-apartheid group's announcement, the United Nations Human Rights Commission called for international support for South Africa's transition process. The world body cited the need to reward positive change, while issuing notice to F.W. de Klerk's National Party government that arms and oil embargoes will be maintained until the installation of democratic rule.

TO GO OR NOT TO GO?

President Gnassingbe Eyadema and his supporters may be home alone if the recent mass exodus from Togo continues. An estimated 250,000 Togolese have fled to neighboring Benin and Ghana, creating a refugee problem that has focused international attention on the continuing political crisis in the small West African country.

Mounting violence against pro-democracy supporters by the army has created a climate of fear. Eyadema, who took power in a 1967 coup, was forced by public protests in 1991 to agree to formation of a transition government to lead the country to multiparty elections. But Togo's military has remained loyal to the president and has resisted the reforms. Opposition members maintain that troops are using the threat of force to keep the president in power.

Peace talks in France last month deadlocked over the issue of ensuring the army's neutrality. Opposition leader, Messan Gnininvi has appealed to France and the United States to mediate to ensure a resumption of peace talks.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


WORLD BANK REMEDIES CAUSE MISERY IN AFRICA


BYLINE: Victoria Brittain INSIGHT/Guardian News Service


LENGTH: 1254 words


DATELINE: London


 

In a serious challenge to the prime position of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in African policy-making, two new books examine the continent's dramatic decline over a dozen years and challenge the orthodoxies of these, the two most powerful institutions on the continent.

Alternative Development Strategies in Sub-Saharan Africa, edited by Frances Stewart, Sanjaya Lall and Samuel Wangwe, and Africa's Recovery in the 1990s, edited by Giovanni Andrea Cornia, Rolf van der Hoeven and Thandika Mkandawire, both are published by Macmillan in Britain. The studies are published against the background of Africa's deep economic crisis, which worsened in the 1980s and has continued into the 1990s with little or no sign of improvement.

Richard Jolly, deputy executive director of the United Nations children's agency, Unicef, says Africa remains the highest priority for Unicef's aid because it is the one continent where the health and education status of children has deteriorated in recent years and is projected to worsen further in the 1990s. However, other donors are becoming more inclined to cut their losses and target their aid to places with less record of failure. 

The grim economic situation in three-quarters of African countries is disputed by no one, but a bitter intellectual battle rages over the recipes for improvement. Some long-term goals such as industrialization have disappeared almost entirely from current thinking, preoccupied as it is with crisis management.

For over a decade, Structural Adjustment Programs (SAPs) drawn up by the World Bank and the IMF have been the key policies for Africa. They have focused on the stabilization of macroeconomic imbalances, removal of structural bottlenecks, and economic growth.

Although SAPs have been judged successful in Chile and Indonesia, the programs have had little success in Africa beyond middle-income countries such as Cameroon and Mauritius. And, while bank officials claim at least fragile achievements across the continent, other analysts -- particularly Africans -- blame the harsh regime of SAPs for cuts in employment and in health and education budgets, which have put the entire social fabric at risk.

In the past few years, under pressure from Unicef, SAPs have been modified to include the social dimension -- particularly the protection of the poorest, most vulnerable groups. But the decline in per capita Gross Domestic Product (GDP) continues, and social service cuts mean new generations of less educated, less healthy citizens for the next century.

"There is a greater consensus about the importance of the social dimension, but total consensus certainly has not been achieved,'' says Dr. Giovanni Andrea Cornia, an economist at Unicef and one of the editors of the optimistically titled Africa's Recovery in the 1990s.

Frances Stewart introduces Alternative Development Strategies by looking at the contradiction between current policies and long-term

objectives. She cites three long-term objectives for Africa: industrial development, increasing food production and human resources development. She then asks how the well-known effects of current policy -- falling employment figures, declining school rolls and shrinking investment in infrastructure -- can be reconciled with those objectives.

The bank and the fund are responsible for the policy advice that has brought about these effects.

In addition, the same advisers encouraged increased production of the primary products that make up 90 percent of Africa's exports, so that their prices have fallen disastrously. Coffee, copper and cotton all have dropped by about 25 percent over the past 30 years. Ten of the continent's 13 major export commodities fell still further last year, including losses of ten percent to 30 percent or more from 1991 levels for cocoa, coffee, cotton and peanut oil.

These price trends are not going to be reversed. What could be, Stewart says, is the structure of exports. Her book shows that, compared with South Asia -- where between 1965 and 1987 primary products fell from 63 percent of exports to 36 percent -- in low-income African countries the proportion rose from 92 percent to 94 percent.

Among other major problems Stewart identifies is the reduced local control that is a result of the privatization encouraged by SAPs, and the excessive liberalization of imports, which has led, in Ghana for instance, to de-industrialization as the textile industry has collapsed under the impact of imported second-hand clothes from Europe. "African countries basically lost control of their policies in the 1980s,'' she comments.

Both books emphasize new strategies that the authors -- who include

distinguished African economists -- believe could work. These include:

* encouragement of indigenous food crops by such policies as subsidies on fertilizers and other inputs, while halting lending to traditional export areas such as coffee;

* commodity price support schemes;

* support for rural non-agricultural development;

* a serious bid for industrialization; and

* boosting human resources by increasing the proportion of aid to education and health.

Most importantly, these strategists propose outright cancellation of at least part of Africa's debt, as well as conversion of what Africa owes the World Bank and the IMF into low-interest, long-term loans. This could reduce such anomalies as the fact that poor African countries paid nearly $200 million more in loan repayments to the IMF last year than they received in assistance.

The measures could free more than $1 billion for African development each year.

Many of these ideas have been put forward repeatedly by Unicef, the United Nations Development Program and the Economic Commission for Africa. But this approach has a long way to go before being accepted as a real alternative to the unsuccessful World Bank/IMF prescriptions for Africa's desperate situation. *

Victoria Brittain is an editor of the London newspaper the Guardian.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


ECONOMIC PREMISES NEED RE-THINKING


BYLINE: Winifred Armstrong


LENGTH: 854 words


DATELINE: New York


 

Will more outside aid, trade and investment help the nations of Africa to overcome poverty and develop economically? It is unlikely.

Most African economies have deteriorated over the past decade, partly because of the policies that underlie the infusions of loans and aid. Trying harder using the same flawed premises won't help.

The major element missing from current economic policies is sustainability. 

The ability of people to engage in productive economic activities through which they can make a living and build a life is not a goal of the global economic order. Neither is the sustainability of the earth's resources. Rather, the primary aim of international economic policies is an ever-greater output of products that can be sold for cash.

The "new global economic order" stresses comparative competitive advantage and export growth. The underlying assumption is that every country will have a comparative advantage in producing and selling something -- and that more production will mean more wealth for more people. But that is not what is happening. In both Africa and the United States, the standard of living of the majority of people is dropping. Only the richest are getting richer.

Using the concept of comparative advantage, Western governments and international agencies have often urged African nations to produce export crops instead of food. The assumption is that with the money earned from export sales, cheaper imported food can be substituted for that which had been grown locally. Outside aid, investment and trade are often conditional on Africans' acceptance of the switch from local to export production.

Such recommendations conceivably might lead to increased prosperity if the former food producers became instead the producers of exports -- and if they could sell those exports at prices that would enable them to purchase the food and other goods they need. Neither assumption has been borne out in the marketplace. Local producers often find there is no alternative product that they can successfully grow on the same land. Imported food is not "cheaper" if you have nothing with which to buy it.

Our current policies are further skewed by the limitations of economic policy formulation, such as economists' failure to value the food produced for the family table or for local trade. Food or informal trade that does not become part of the cash economy is not "valued" nor included in calculations of a country's gross national product. In Africa, subsistence agriculture and informal trade have accounted for perhaps 50 percent to 90 percent of what people live from; not to count it surely distorts the policies affecting those people. In addition, a community's state of health, level of education and a host of other quality-of-life factors may be the stuff of political conversation, but they are regarded as "externalities" and omitted from what is "counted" in economic policy decisions. Africans and Americans alike suffer the logic of these limited premises.

Most African countries cannot survive using a global model of comparative advantage, in my opinion. Can African countries be economically viable from their own resources? "Yes," said almost everyone with whom I talked in 17 African countries during a recent trip. But there was general agreement that that won't happen as long as Africa remains bound by an economic model that fails to place a premium on people and their environments, on education, health and community, and on building their future within available resources.

The dominant world economic models do not include these values, but they could. The recent U.S. election reflected a popular recognition that the current economic model is not working to meet the needs of people within a sustainable ecology -- and that change is possible. There is important work taking place at academic and grassroots levels in both Africa and the Americas that supports a wider conceptual framework. We should join forces to bring it into the mainstream. *

Winifred Armstrong is an international economist and a principal organizer of The Other Economic Summit (TOES)/North America. She is currently working on a book, Getting to an Economics That Will Work for

People: Something New Out of Africa.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT SPURS AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT


BYLINE: Edward V.K. Jaycox


SECTION: VIEWPOINT:


LENGTH: 1534 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

The past ten years could be described as the era of structural adjustment in sub-Saharan Africa.

Under structural adjustment programs, the countries of the region have achieved significant progress. Growth has resumed. Economies have become more responsive to market signals. Boosting agricultural productivity has reoccupied center stage. And rhetoric has been turned into policy on critical issues such as population, the environment and the role of women in development. 

The process began in response to the economic crisis facing Africa at the beginning of the 1980s. The oil shocks of the preceding decade had placed a heavy burden of debt on African countries, whose economic structures and capacities were already weak. The region had no industrial base; its management capacity was thin; its infrastructure was meager and aging; and it was rapidly losing competitiveness to other developing countries.

These conditions would not necessarily have presented Africa with a crisis had they not been compounded by misguided policies on the part of

African governments: exchange rates were grossly overvalued; exports were excessively taxed; price controls and subsidies were rampant; the state interfered in commerce and trade; and revenues from earlier commodity price booms were poorly managed.

In May 1986, at the United Nations Special Session on Africa, African leaders took responsibility for their policy mistakes and committed to undertake the necessary reforms. Today the reform effort has gained widespread acceptance, and 28 countries have adjustment policies in place.

Statistics from a core group of 15 currently adjusting countries that comprise the bulk of Africa's population and income show the following

results:

* Movements in real producer prices have been favorable for farmers, despite the decline in international prices of primary export commodities.

* The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate increased considerably, averaging almost four percent from 1986 to 1990 and three percent in 1991 -- and the positive response is likely much greater than demonstrated by conventional GDP data, which tend to exaggerate the relative importance of the official, public economy and underestimate that of the unofficial, private economy.

In 23 currently adjusting countries, average inflation rates halved, deficits declined, military expenditures have been slashed and exports are up.

The overriding mission of the World Bank is to alleviate poverty, and its adjustment programs aim first and foremost to improve the quality of life for the majority of Africans who live in abject poverty. There is no doubt that, over time, reform measures will succeed in stimulating economic growth, and the poor will gain from the opportunities available in a more vibrant economy.

However, even in the short run, most of Africa's poor have benefited from reforms. Eighty percent to 90 percent of the continent's poor are small- holder farmers who are net producers of tradable goods. Adjustment policies -- which usually include elimination of agricultural marketing monopolies, higher crop prices and lower taxation of agriculture -- have increased the income of this group. This, in turn, has led to greater food production, greater production of export crops and higher rural employment.

Contrary to some claims, the increase in the production of cash crops has not come at the expense of food production. In Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Mali and Burkina Faso, for example, per capita food production is much higher today than in the pre-adjustment period, while the volume of agricultural exports has risen at the same time.

Africa's urban poor, who number between four percent and 20 percent of the poor in counties in the region, have suffered in some cases, especially as a result of higher food prices. In the medium to long term, however, the urban poor will benefit from accelerated growth spurred by adjustment, because most of the demand for goods and services they produce and trade originates from the rural poor whose incomes rise under adjustment. It is no accident, for example, that where adjustment has been consistently pursued and growth is being restored, as in Ghana, urban wages have begun to recover as well.

Another clear indication of the benefits of adjustment for the poor is that, with only a few exceptions, real levels of government expenditures for education and health increased in adjusting countries. In recent years the bank has been paying increasing attention to such spending. In 1989-90, a third of adjustment loans mandated social sector spending, up sharply from seven percent in the first half of the 1980s. The restructuring of social expenditures to favor primary education and health services, as well as safety nets, offers substantial scope both for mitigating the short-term costs of adjustment and for improving the poor's human capital and earning potential in the long run. The bank is also intensifying its collaboration with governments to design and support social-action programs aimed at protecting the poor who might otherwise be adversely affected by structural adjustment programs.

Overall, the bank can claim a number of achievements in promoting economic reform in sub-Saharan Africa. It has succeeded in creating a group of economic managers on the continent who are knowledgeable and confident about what has gone wrong and what is required to fix it; it has encouraged a revitalization of economic activity, as domestic actors in the economy have responded to new market opportunities; and through the reform effort, it has been instrumental in rejuvenating the donor commitment to Africa, ensuring that African countries receive enough external funding to sustain progress.

Notwithstanding these achievements, there are a number of important lessons which the bank, the donor community and African governments must consider if the reform effort is to be successfully consolidated and deepened. The most important of these is the realization that changing the structure of an economy is a long-term process. Many of the mistakes made by governments and donors over the last 30 years were caused by an unrealistic view of the time required to create the necessary conditions for development in Africa, resulting in programs which were overly ambitious. This is why it is absolutely critical in the coming years for donors and African governments to maintain the commitment and the stamina for reform, even where progress is only modest.

Another important lesson is that ownership of reforms, not only by the government, but by the incipient economic actors in the country, is crucial to their success. No amount of externally imposed conditionalities, however benign and beneficial, will turn an economy around. The bank is actively seeking to increase the number of private sector, non-governmental, labor and other groups in its projects and programs.

The 1990s will be a critical decade for the region. Those countries that have recovered must do so fully in order to sustain progress into the next century, and those that have not must recover in order to avoid economic and social chaos.

While the challenges are enormous, this is not an insurmountable task. The dialogue among and between governments, international organizations and beneficiaries has vastly improved. The lessons of experience have been powerful. The strategic agenda has by and large been set. And the mechanisms for achieving Africa's development objectives are in place. The task now is to strengthen what has been accomplished and to ensure that future investments work with maximum efficiency. *

Edward V.K. Jaycox is vice president, Africa Region, World Bank.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


Recipes for an African Meal


LENGTH: 1894 words


 

Mozambique

Squash Soup

The Mozambican who inspired this recipe cooks it differently each time he makes it, depending on what is fresh in the market and what spices he can get. The squash most frequently available in Mozambique is similar to the giant West Indian or Caribbean variety that can be found in parts of Canada and the United States. Butternut is another good choice, but any winter squash will do. It's the method that's important here.

Serves 6 as a first course or 4 as a light meal.

1-2 lbs. squash, peeled and cubed 

1 bay leaf

4 or 5 large garlic cloves, crushed

1 tblsp. onion, minced

1 tblsp. oil or butter 1 tsp. salt

1/8 tsp. black pepper 1 tsp. fresh ginger, grated

1/4 tsp. curry powder

1/8 tsp. paprika

1-3 tblsp. lemon juice

Boil squash in just enough water to cover. (If the squash is extremely hard, you might want to boil it whole or in large chunks until it becomes soft enough to peel and chop more easily.) When the pieces are very soft, lift them out, leaving the water in the pan. Mash the squash with a fork, or put it through a sieve. Return squash to cooking water, add the bay leaf and simmer gently. Meanwhile, saute the crushed garlic and the onion in the oil or butter. Combine the remaining spices and then add them to the butter mixture. Saute over low heat for five to ten minutes until the flavors are well blended. Spoon a little of the squash liquid into the skillet with the butter mixture; stir and then pour the mixture into the soup pan. Add water to make

about 6 cups, and stir in lemon juice to taste. Variations: Chicken stock may be used instead of water, and other vegetables may be added. Among other spices that work well in this soup are coriander, fennel, celery seed, rosemary and cayenne pepper.

Ghana

Hkatenkwan (Peanut Stew)

Serves 4-6

Across much of Africa, soups and stews made with peanuts -- usually called "groundnuts" -- are staple main-meal foods. Depending on the hotness of your chilies or your cayenne, this version may be uncomfortably spicy. Unless you relish very hot foods, begin with no more than half the pepper specified here.

3-lb chicken, cut into pieces

1/2 of a whole onion

2 tblsp. tomato paste

1 tblsp. peanut oil or other light cooking oil

1 cup onion, well chopped

1 cup tomatoes, chopped

2/3 cup peanut butter

2 tsp. salt

2 tsp. grated fresh ginger,

2 hot chilies, crushed,

or 1 tsp. ground ginger

or 1 tsp. cayenne powder

2 cups fresh or frozen okra

1 medium-size eggplant, peeled and cubed

Boil chicken with ginger and the onion half, using about 2 cups water. Meanwhile, in a separate large pot, fry tomato paste in the oil over low heat for about five minutes. Add to the paste the chopped onions and tomatoes, stirring occasionally until the onions are clear. Remove the partially cooked chicken pieces and put them, along with about half the broth, in the large pot. Add the peanut butter, salt and peppers. Cook for five minutes before stirring in the eggplant and okra. Continue cooking until chicken and vegetables are tender. Add more broth as needed to maintain a thick, stewy consistency.

To make this a vegetarian dish, substitute 2 vegetable bouillon cubes for the chicken. Or make fewer pieces of chicken go farther by removing meat from the bone.

Like many West African foods, this stew is rather peppery. If mild foods are more your style, reduce the amount of peppers or cayenne. Serve over rice.

Algeria

Chlada Felfel (Tomato and Green Pepper Salad)

Serves 4

This North African salad is similar to salads found on many African tables.

2 large green bell peppers 2 cloves garlic, minced and crushed

4 tblsp. olive oil 1/2 tblsp. wine vinegar

1/2 tsp. salt handful of green olives

1/4 tsp. pepper handful of black olives

several anchovies (optional) 2 large ripe tomatoes, peeled and thinly sliced

Broil the green peppers in an oven for several minutes, turning them three or four times, until the skin blisters. When they're cool enought to handle, peel, seed and chop them. Pile in the center of a serving plate, and arrange tomato slices around them.

Prepare a vinaigrette by mixing olive oil, vinegar, garlic, salt and pepper. Pour over the vegetables. Decorate with olives and anchovies.

Cape Verde

Banana Enrolada (Banana Rolled in Pastry)

Serves 4

This elegant dessert is fun to make, especially when children are involved, and is universally popular. It's tasty hot or cold, alone or with ice cream.

1 1/2 cups flour
