2 tblsp. sugar (optional)

1/2 tsp. salt 4 very ripe bananas

oil for frying 6 tblsp. butter, softened,

cinnamon or 6 tblsp. vegetable oil

Combine flour, sugar and salt in a mixing bowl. With your fingertips, work the butter into the flour mixture until it is well distributed. Add water, a tablespoon at a time, until you have a dough that will hold together in a ball. (If you have time, cover the pastry and refrigerate it for 30 minutes at this point.)

Turn the ball out onto a lightly floured surface and divide it into four parts. Roll each part into an oblong that is an inch or so longer than your bananas and wide enough to wrap around one. Lay a banana on each oblong, and roll it up in the pastry, sealing the edges and ends by pinching with your fingertips. For smaller servings, or if your bananas are large, cut each banana in half before rolling the pieces in pastry.

Deep fry the pastry-wrapped bananas, or fry them in an inch or so of hot oil in a large, heavy skillet for three or four minutes on each side. When done, they should be crisp and golden brown outside and soft and moist inside. Drain on clean, absorbent cloths to absorb excess oil, and sprinkle with cinnamon before serving.

Africa

Ginger Beer

Homemade soft drinks brewed from fresh ginger can be found all across sub-Saharan Africa. They are made at varying ratios of water to ginger, and fruits of many varieties -- such as pineapples and guavas -- may be substituted for the citrus. This recipe produces a strong concentrate that can be diluted with equal parts water for drinking, but many people like it just as it is, over ice.

16 ounces (or a couple of large

handfuls) fresh ginger

juice of 1 or 2 limes 1 stick cinnamon (optional)

1 tsp. whole cloves (optional)

sugar to taste

Wash the ginger and peel it, being careful to remove only the outer layer of skin. Grind or pound to a pulp, and place in a large, heat-proof container that is enameled or made of glass or stainless steel. Cover with 1/2 gallon (8 cups) of boiling water. Set the mixture aside in a warm place. (You may want to protect it from dust by covering the container loosely with a cloth.)

After an hour or so, strain the liquid through a cloth, squeezing the pulp to extract all the flavor. Stir in lime juice, cinnamon, half the cloves and 1/2 gallon of cold water. Let the liquid sit for another hour, in the sun if possible, which allows the starch from the ginger to settle.

Pour the mixture gently through a cloth to strain it, trying not to disturb any sediment at the bottom. Strain again if necessary. Stir in the remaining cloves, add sugar if desired, then transfer the ginger beer to a jar and refrigerate.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


THE UNDISCOVERED DELIGHT OF AFRICAN CUISINE


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Elegant cuisine may not be the first image that springs to mind when African food is mentioned, but more and more people are discovering an Africa whose culinary riches rival those of any continent.

From the spicy, savory stews of North and West Africa to the soothing porridges and fiery curries of the east and south, African foods are a feast of color and aroma as well as taste. An African marketplace is a kaleidoscope of milky coconut, amber palm oil, and pyramidal mounds of spices in hues of ocher, rust and saffron. The brash greens and vibrant yellows of avocados and bananas complement the wrinkled browns of fresh lychees and grenadillas, which hide their intensity under cloaks of drabness. 

Somehow, no other food is quite so tasty as the smoky beef brochettes in a Moroccan souk or the tangy slices of guava and mango sold on a Mozambican roadside.

By tradition -- and in rural areas by necessity -- African cooks

employ the ingredients used by fine chefs everywhere: minimally processed grains, fresh, vine-ripened fruits and vegetables, just-snipped herbs and hand-pounded spices. The locally grown produce is less likely to be laced with toxic chemicals than the foods in Western supermarkets. Chicken, meat, eggs and milk are likely to come from free-range animals, and the seafood served at an evening meal was probably in the ocean when the day dawned.

Such descriptions may be surprising to those who think of Africa as a continent of food shortages, and it is tragically true that many Africans today face famine. But that reality is more a by-product of 20th-century geopolitics -- exacerbated periodically by unfavorable weather -- than it is representative of Africa's past or its customs.

African meals traditionally have been no less varied -- and often more healthful -- than the high-protein, high-fat diets of the Western world. Travelers in previous centuries marveled at the abundance of Africa's berries and nuts, domestic animals and wild game, dates, and honey.

And in accounts of their journeys, the earliest European voyagers exulted over the spices they found. For hundreds of years, Alexandria, Egypt, was the world's leading spice trading center, and the romantic scenes evoked by names such as Zanzibar, Marrakech and Timbuktu date from their importance as points of exchange for spices.

It would be a mistake to generalize about Africa's ways of eating. The continent is larger and more diverse than most Americans realize. Its 54 countries span a vast area; the nation of Sudan alone is larger than the United States east of the Mississippi River. Topography ranging from lush rain forests to snowy pinnacles -- as well as climates from arid to tropical -- have spawned distinct cuisines as different from one another as, for example, those of Turkey and Sweden.

But many Americans, particularly those who live in the southern United States, are more familiar with some of Africa's foods than they realize. Peanuts and rice, okra and yams, sesame and cumin are all among the foods and flavorings brought to colonial America from Africa. African influences are pervasive, from the jumbalayas and gumbos of Louisiana bayous to the hoe cakes and corn breads of Georgia. Indeed, "gumbo" is the West African word for okra, and "yam" is derived from the West African verb nyami, which means "to eat." Even our word "banana" came to America from Africa, by way of Portuguese explorers, with its spelling intact.

The increasing numbers of Americans who have lived in or traveled extensively in Africa -- such as more than 80,000 former Peace Corps volunteers -- have contributed to a growing awareness of Africa's ways of eating. And the popularity of African restaurants in major cities testifies to a widening appreciation of the continent's culinary delights.

Still, the only way for most Americans to eat African dishes is to cook them. That process is not as strange or difficult as might be imagined, although it is true that Africans, like all good chefs, don't cook "by the book." Getting a recipe from an accomplished African cook often requires following someone around for a day, carefully measuring the ingredients used and noting the procedures. And even then, the resulting recipe is more a benchmark than a formula; it is designed to be changed and adapted according to what is on hand and the mood of the cook.

The following recipes, adapted from The Africa News Cookbook: African Cooking for Western Kitchens, can easily accommodate substitutions and innovations. Although drawn from countries far from one another, these foods work together to make a meal fit to serve to the most discriminating connoisseurs. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


AFRICAN JAZZ: FAMILIAR BUT UNIQUE


BYLINE: Harry Amana for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

More than anything else, the creative and extremely listenable "Jazz in Africa" volumes are about the rediscovery of the late Kippie Moeketsi, the legendary South African alto saxophone player who mentored Hugh Masekela, Abdullah Ibrahim and Jonas Gwangwa in the late 1950s, created outstanding music in spite of apartheid, and who is known as "the father of South African music."

As the liner notes explain, Moeketsi, Masekela, Ibrahim, then called Dollar Brand, and Gwangwa formed the nucleus of The Jazz Epistles, a township group that folded around 1959, after it had become the first black South African group to release an album -- a very limited distribution record of less than 500 copies. Seeking creative freedom from a racist white record industry and a chance to have their music heard, Masekela and Ibrahim left the country soon after the recording and lived in exile for three decades, astonishing Europe and the United States with their new "Township Jazz" sounds. Gwangwa would also leave and become a member of Masekela's Union of South Africa group of the early 1970s. 

But Moeketsi stayed in country, playing in the townships, recording another album during the 1970s and building on his growing legend. By the time of his death in May 1983, he was an almost mythical figure, whose first record with the Epistles was a collector's item.

Now, with Volume I of the remastered "lost tracks," we hear the entire 1959, 14-song recording, featuring the young Masekela, Gwangwa and Ibrahim, with their trailblazing mentor playing masterfully in sextet ensembles the hip and swinging classical jazz of that era.

On Volume II, we are treated to six tunes cut in the 1970s, four of which feature the Township Jazz of Moeketsi in some dynamic, completely original, mind-blowing solos. Together, the two volumes explain why Moeketsi's playing is mentioned by knowledgeable insiders in the same breath as Charlie Parker and John Coltrane and why his arrangements and original pieces are compared favorably with Thelonius Monk and Dizzy Gillespie.

Volume I includes 14 songs: five standards ("Delilah," "Yardbird Suite," "Body & Soul," "Lover Come Back to Me" and "Old Devil Moon"), two South African traditional songs ("Twelve to Twelve" and "Cosmic Ray") and seven originals, including three each by Moeketsi and Ibrahim, and one by Masekela. Accompanying them in the sextet are Gwangwa on trombone; Claude Shange, bass; and Gene Latimore, drums. On six tracks, John Mehegan replaces Ibrahim on keyboard and Christopher Joseph plays keyboard on "Delilah."

What this volume reveals is the technical virtuosity of the young musicians and the confidence and originality of Moeketsi. In a four-minute solo on "Body & Soul," he overpowers his instrument in the manner of Coltrane, Pharaoh Sanders or Rahsaan Roland Kirk. Then in a cut of his own entitled "Scullery Department," he and the sextet create a seven-minute whimsical, sardonic, subversive tune reminiscent of Dizzy or Monk.

Other highlights of this volume include Moeketsi's rhythmically complex "Carols Drive," the almost angry, or maybe just pissed off, "Blues for Hughie" and Ibrahim's "Gafsa," a four-and-a-half- minute piano solo. Masekela and Gwangwa are strong on all pieces, and Shange performs an exceptional penny whistle solo on the nine-and-a-half-minute "Cosmic Ray," a traditional African song.

Volume II is a six-song tour de force of the Township Jazz made popular in the United States in the '60s and '70s, especially by Miriam Makeba and Masekela.

Three of the four Moeketsi-featured songs are quintets with Basil Coetzee on tenor; Pat Matshikiza, piano; Alec Khaoli, bass; and Sipho Mabuse, drums. Dennis Phillips, also on alto, is added for the first cut, "Tshona," a Matshikiza creation arranged by Moeketsi. "Tshona" is a brilliant 12-minute laid-back arrangement whose three saxes sometimes come in so strong that they create, for sustained intervals, a big-band feeling.

Also significant is Moeketsi's "Umgababa," an 11-minute call-and- response arrangement of saxes answering a pulsating, insistent rhythm section."Africa Day" is a sextet performance with Coetzee, Barney Rachabane and Duke Makasi on tenors; Tete Mbambisa, piano; Sipho Gumede, bass; and Gilbert Matthews, drums. All of the saxes perform innovative solos, grounded, again, by a solid driving rhythm section.

The last piece, "Kalahari," is a 23-minute masterpiece by Ibrahim. With Ibrahim and Coetzee are Robbie Jansen on alto; Arthur Jacobs, tenor; Lionel Beukes, bass; and Nazier Kapdi, drums. This is an exotic, funky, percussion-driven -- almost Afro-Cuban -- ceremony that includes chanting

male voices and the recitation of a poem by Ibrahim:

Behold the night and day

Gently they give way to each other

Dear brother.

In the darkness, I met him of the night

With arms full of love light.

"Carry one," said he, "Into the vast night."

"All right," I said. "Just guide me;

Just guide me with your light."

The two volumes are a must-buy for any collector who wants to fill in the gaps on the so-called "Modern Jazz" era or who wants to add to her collection some seminal sounds of the Township Jazz or Afro-Pop movements. They're also a good buy for anyone who loves the music and wants exposure to Kippie Moeketsi, a musical genius whose sounds apartheid almost took from us forever. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


AFRICA'S BIANNUAL BOW TO FILM KEEPS GROWING


BYLINE: David Turecamo for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 667 words


DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso


 

As long as the 13th Pan African Film Festival is in town, all life in "Ouaga" centers around the pool at the Hotel Independence. It is here that every filmmaker, distributor, producer and phony will gather in search of a deal. From eight in the morning to well past midnight they meet over soft drinks or cognac. Internationally acclaimed director Ousmane Sembene hops from one interview to the next, while a first-time filmmaker must hand out posters and press kits personally. 

Fespaco, as it is known, is less a festival than a trade show -- a sprawling African market with buyers and sellers and thousands of onlookers from all over the world who descend on this town for one week every two years in hopes of scoring the big prize.

This year's winner of the Yennenga Stallion, the top award, goes to Roger Mbala of Cote d'Ivoire for his film "Au Nom du Christ" ("In the Name of Christ"), a last-minute entry that was still being edited in mid- February.

It is impossible to see more than a small portion of the festival's movies; more than 200 are screened at theaters scattered all over town -- the capital of this country that used to be called Dahomey. Among the hottest films are "Malcolm X," dubbed to French, "Gito L'Ingrat," the first feature film produced in the tiny East African nation of Burundi, and "Thomas Sankara," a documentary about the assassinated leader of this country that drew raves and tears from the audience.

But to an observer, what emerges at Fespaco is more than just good films and bad. Questions about the future of Africa -- both it's dreams and its delusions -- seem embodied in the proceedings. The films are like the continent in microcosm. Most are heavily funded by French and German television, international aid organizations or the governments of their countries of origin. So when banners around the city proclaim the theme of this year's Fespaco as "Cinema and Liberties," a certain sense of irony is inevitable.

The sad fact is that African films are not only struggling to be free, they're having a hard time being seen. "Africa is the worst place to see African films," says Simon Bright, a filmmaker from Zimbabwe and chairman of the filmmakers' congress here.

The screens on this continent are dominated by movies from Hollywood and Bombay, and theater owners are reluctant to book anything that doesn't feature Arnold Schwarzenegger smashing a truck. Though one film from Zimbabwe outgrossed "Terminator 2" in Southern Africa, the film's producer is struggling just to get it booked into Nigeria.

Even the directors themselves seem to have their sights set on broader horizons. Because the Cannes Film Festival won't accept films that have competed elsewhere, the directors of several major films would not enter their works into competition here. The result is that most competitors at Fespaco represent a kind of second-string of African films.

Yet, like Africa, the atmosphere in Ouagadougou is electric and full of hope. There is sincerity and determination among the participants. They all seem to recognize the importance of creating and sustaining a cinema that is uniquely African so that the world can see what Africa thinks of itself. Or, as Sembene himself agreed, "To be an African filmmaker is not only a right, it is a responsibility." *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


GETTING AROUND


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Entry requirements: North American tourists staying less than three months need no visas. Requirements for nationals of other countries differ. You must bring proof of a valid yellow fever inoculation.

Arrival: A visit to Yamoussoukro begins in Abidjan, a seaside city of lagoons and peninsulas. There are direct flights to Abidjan from New York via Air Afrique, from Paris via Air France and from Zurich via Swissair. Abidjan has numerous attractions and plentiful hotels and restaurants. Accommodations at nearby beaches range from exclusive resorts, including a Club Med, to quiet coastal hideaways. Air Ivoire flies to Yamoussoukro, or you can rent a car and drive there. 

Packing: May to October in Abidjan tends to be rainy, with a dry spell in August. Temperatures are often moderate, occasionally chilly and rarely rise above the high 80's Fahrenheit. Yamoussoukro is slightly hotter and drier. Small appliances with dual voltage work, but you'll need a French-style converter plug. Batteries, film and almost anything you're likely to need are available in Abidjan shops. At night, socks and long sleeves are advisable, because malaria-carrying mosquitoes bite only after dusk.

Health Tips: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) advises that the two most important precautions before leaving home are having an immune globulin shot, also known as gamma globulin, to reduce the risks of hepatitis, and beginning a course of anti-malaria medication. CDC's 24-hour hotline, (404) 332-4559, gives information on malaria prevention as well as other health advice. As in any developing country, it's safest not to eat uncooked vegetables and fruits unless you can peel them.

Currency: The Central African Franc, or CFA, is a convertible currency used throughout French-speaking West Africa. It can be changed at banks and airports in Cote d'Ivoire, but also in major cities such as Paris and New York.

Accommodations: In Yamoussoukro, the President Hotel is pricey, about $120 and up, and is the only truly international hotel. Discounts are sometimes available for the asking. Several other hotels offer varying prices and amenities. It's best to check them out in person.

Food: In addition to the costly rooftop restaurant at the President and its more moderate poolside dining room and terrace, Yamoussoukro has restaurants serving Chinese and Italian food and a French-style creperie. For authentic African cuisine, Chez Valentine is fairly expensive but good. Local musicians often play for diners at the open-air pavilions. Outside the small downtown area, in residential neighborhoods, streetside restaurants called maquis serve such fare as grilled chicken for modest prices.

The Presidential House: The residence and grounds are off-limits unless you're an invited guest, but outside the wall is one of Yamoussoukro's few regularly scheduled attractions. Twice a day, staff members preside over the feeding of live chickens to crocodiles that lurk in a cement moat by the gates. Adopted by Houphou t-Boigny as a symbol of his family and his rule, the crocodiles function as a kind of live coat of arms.

The Basilica: The church is open regularly; check the bulletin at the President Hotel, or ask at the desk, for precise hours of tours and worship services.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


YAMOUSSOUKRO OFFERS SIGHTS WITHOUT SIGHTSEERS For the traveler who'd rather see than be seen, the town is worth a trip.


SECTION: CULTURE/LIFESTYLE


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Approaching the capital of Cote d'Ivoire, where the narrow route from the coast broadens into a six-lane divided highway, is like traveling the yellow brick road. In the distance, across the scrubby West African landscape, a storybook dome seems suspended in midair, ghostly in the shimmering afternoon heat, its gilded ribs catching slanting shafts of sun.

Over 150 miles from the metropolis of Abidjan, with its skyscrapers and 3 million people, the world's largest church sits at the end of a broad boulevard in a town of 30,000 residents.

The Basilica of Our Lady of Peace has been controversial since it was built at an estimated cost of $200 million to $250 million. Cote d'Ivoire's aging president, Felix Houphou t-Boigny, says he paid for the majestic structure from his personal fortune, siting it at his birthplace in the village of Yamoussoukro, which he named the nation's capital in 1983. But a few months before the basilica was consecrated by Pope John Paul II in 1990, protests and strikes in the streets of Abidjan called attention to the widespread public view that the building represents the excesses of many of Africa's post-colonial rulers. 

After the demonstrations forced the president to agree to legalize opposition political parties and to tolerate independent newspapers, the charges that Houphou t-Boigny had diverted government funds to the basilica died down. And although the church still is ridiculed by critics, some now say that the country should reap what benefits it can from visitors to the structure.

Certainly, the building is imposing -- its soaring structure appearing strangely at home in its unusual setting. Perhaps only an edifice of such magnitude can compete with the majesty of vast African spaces. The silvered patina of marble and stone looks less like a mirage close-up, but the earth tones harmonize with the setting.

The inside is more dissonant, with its panels of imported stained glass in 4,000 shades and its ornate painted surfaces. State-of-the-art climate and acoustic systems reduce echoes and keep the towering sanctuary evenly cooled for as many as 18,000 worshippers. Another 300,000 people can be accommodated on the marble plaza outside or stroll in the 88 acres of French-style formal gardens.

On a typical day, though, there are more guides than visitors. Helpful, friendly staff will whisk you in a soundless elevator for a rooftop view across the 40-room adjoining mansion reserved for papal visits. Openly proud of the church, the guides and guards point out that the great cathedrals of Europe, now revered by throngs of tourists as well as locals, were built alongside poverty as desperate as anything in Cote d'Ivoire.

It's hard to imagine throngs anywhere in Yamoussoukro, though. The luxury President Hotel, with sprawling swimming pools, tennis and squash courts and one of West Africa's finest golf courses, has an occupancy rate of about 15 percent. Except when a meeting or conference crowds the facility, giving it the air of a plush tropical resort, the President seems like a private mansion, its staff of servants the relic of a large family whose members have dwindled and moved away.

Normally, no reservations are needed at the rooftop restaurant, where the Parisian cuisine seems mildly surprising as an accompaniment to the 23rd-floor vista over African forest and grassland. From that vantage point, the town reveals itself as still a village, making scarcely a dent in the surrounding countryside.

The perspective from street level is even more bemusing. The drive to build a capital city seems to have lacked only people. Two institutions of higher learning, a ruling party headquarters reminiscent of Lincoln Center, and a foundation named after the president sit virtually unoccupied.

From time to time, though, the bucolic atmosphere is disrupted by the arrival of a prominent international visitor. Near the basilica, Houphou t-Boigny has built a French-modern style presidential palace, surrounded by a half-mile-long wall of granite, where he likes to receive prominent guests. Often he flies ahead, ready to greet them when they arrive from Abidjan. A typical welcome involves hundreds of dancers and drummers in traditional dress, lining what appear to be miles of red carpet.

The palace itself, with its sleek balconies, hushed corridors and gold faucets, is like a generic luxury hotel -- the modern kind that holds itself aloof from local architecture or ambiance. It could be anywhere, or at least anywhere where money is no object.

In contrast to the stark order of church and state, the town's residential areas are alive and colorful. Where the broad boulevards boast miles of high wattage street lights, the small cafes and shops of Yamoussoukro's neighborhoods use kerosene lamps and candles to supplement dim bare bulbs.

At dusk, especially during Ramadan, the month of daylight fasting observed by Muslims, vendors wheel out carts of freshly roasted plantains, grilled meats and other foods to break the fast. The flickering lights, the clink of glasses and the convivial atmosphere suggest a street party at which all passers-by are welcome.

Yamoussoukro sits on a rough dividing line between the Muslim north and the Christian south. Almost twice as many Ivorians are Muslim -- about 30 percent of the population -- as Christian. During the basilica's construction, the French site manager told a reporter for the Christian Science Monitor that the church is a symbol that the southward spread of Islam from North Africa must stop at the town.

About a half mile from the Our Lady of Peace, the minaret of a mosque also gleams in the afternoon sunlight. Although not nearly as grand as the basilica, it too is intricate and beautiful and built, it is said, with financial help from the president. Echoing from its tower, the call of the faithful to prayer can be heard each day in the gardens and plazas of the church, where Muslim workers and visitors pause in their affairs to kneel toward Mecca and pray. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


REFUGEES AND RIGOLETTO Lyric soprano finds human rights work rounds out a demanding career.


BYLINE: Tami Hultman * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

On stage, Barbara Hendricks sparkles. Off stage, too. With the singer from Stephens, Arkansas, what you see is apparently what you get.

Rehearsing for a performance with the New York Philharmonic, she is casual, flexible, ready to sing at conductor Gerard Schwarz's signal or to wait patiently while he works with the musicians, even though the hall is drafty and she is nursing a cold. There's no hint of temperament, no air of a diva -- a role she figuratively rejected when offered the part of an opera star in the 1982 French film of that name (which went on to become an international hit with an unknown actress).

What there is with Barbara Hendricks is a quick, concentrated seriousness when it's time to sing; then a sudden joyous cascade of apparently effortless sound. Afterward, appreciative orchestra members tap their bows against their instruments in the rehearsal hall's refined version of resounding applause. 

New York Times music critic Edward Rothstein called her performance the following evening "exquisite." Her voice, he said, has "a ringing ... that gives it both a porcelain fragility and an edginess." The legendary former music director of the Vienna and Berlin Philharmonic orchestras, Herbert von Karajan, compared her to Maria Callas in "passion and interpretative possibility." If there is criticism of her work, it tends to be a matter of personal preference. Her voice is described as "pretty" rather than "big." Her fans say it is her unforced naturalness that gives her such charm.

In person, she exhibits the same quality. Between rehearsal and performance, postponing a visit to the doctor in order to talk about refugees, she is warm, funny, passionate and very definitely pretty. Glamorous, even, in an understated elegant way.

"I'm real lucky and I know it," she says about her musical gifts. "I try to make it possible for the music to touch us in that place where we're alike."

So in addition to singing before affluent audiences in fabled opera houses, she sings to, and with, some of the world's most destitute people. Not performances, just a cappella songs "to give an idea of what I do for a living," she says. For the last six years she has been a Goodwill Ambassador with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, a volunteer job that berths her in primitive shelters in remote locations in Africa, Asia and other parts of the globe for days at a time.

Refugee officials say she makes no demands and expects no special treatment, perhaps because in the refugee camps she believes she is with her constituency. "I'm not an ambassador to refugees," she insists, making a distinction she clearly feels is crucial. "I'm their ambassador. My purpose is to tell their story. And part of that story is that they're just like us. Any of us could find ourselves in the same situation."

Africa is of special interest to her because of its high percentage of refugees. A third of the world's 17 million displaced people are African. But where many visitors to crisis areas become discouraged, Barbara Hendricks finds reason for hope. "Another part of the refugee story, which is very important to me," she says, "is to take away, a little bit, this image refugees have of having their hands out." Instead of dependence, Hendricks sees resilience, grit and spirit.

And she says that she is astonished, always, by the generosity of the poor. She mentions a visit to camps for Mozambican refugees in the southern African nation of Zambia, where she saw an outpouring of assistance and sharing from Zambia's people -- themselves impoverished -- toward the victims of war in their midst. "The Zambians had given 300 square kilometers of land, and on that land they had built 40 villages, 18 of which, after two years, were self-sufficient."

Between performances and UN work, Hendricks returns to her home in Switzerland, to her husband and manager, Martin Engstrom, and their young children, Jamie and Sebastien. It's "really tough," she says, speaking both of leaving her own children while she travels and of her compassion, as a mother, for the children she sees in her refugee work.

The pleasures of her own homecomings give her a heightened appreciation of the need for refugees to return to their homes or to make new ones. She is especially glad to be able to tell refugee success stories, like the repatriation of refugees to Namibia, the southwest African nation that celebrates its third anniversary of independence this month. "People see so much on television," she says, referring to the population of wealthy countries. "It's really hard to keep seeing suffering, so people just sort of become immune to it. But I think we must find in ourselves this feeling, which I believe is inherent in every human being, to know that we are somehow connected to everything that happens in the world, to everyone in the world. And we must find some way of contributing to humanity and contributing to that connection."

She comes to such thoughts as naturally as to her music. The daughter of a schoolteacher and a Methodist minister, she sang in church choirs before becoming a chemistry and mathematics major in college. Singing professionally came about by chance or by providence, depending on your viewpoint, when a trustee of the Aspen Institute in Colorado heard her perform at a community event and invited her to Aspen's summer institute.

There she met Jennie Tourel, a Russian-born music teacher who persuaded Hendricks to come study with her at Julliard. The influence of Tourel on her life is a reason Hendricks cites for her feeling of kinship to refugees.

"She was a Russian Jew," she says. "She left France during the Second World War in the last boat that was allowed to come out to America. Without that suffering she had to go through and without the fact that she was a refugee, I don't see how I would be where I am today." Hendricks says she regularly sees ways that refugees enrich the lives of the people they encounter.

Although she comes on so gently that her passions are disarming rather than off-putting, Hendricks is not uncomfortable being labeled a crusader. "I suppose I got on this wave as a student at university," she says, "because I sort of missed the active part of the civil rights movement and became very active in the women's movement. (I was) one of the original feminists, I like to say."

It was partly the struggles that swirled around her and those she participated in that led her to work with Amnesty International and then with the UN refugee program. "I realized," she says, "that there had to be some set of rights that included everyone and excluded no one -- men and women, blacks and whites. And whatever differences we wanted to have between us, there had to be a foundation for being able to resolve those differences without resorting to war, barbarism, destruction."

The election of Bill Clinton has given Barbara Hendricks new avenues to promote those ideals. She was invited to sing at the inaugural gala on January 19, where she received a sustained ovation from the festive crowd. Tom Shales, writing in the Washington Post, called her performance "stunning."

"It was thrilling." she said the next morning, en route to the swearing-in ceremony. Was she nervous? No, she said. "I was excited. I wanted to meet the occasion, to be up to the occasion."

Before she left for Washington, her son asked if she had gone to school with the new president, if she had known him. "I said, 'No. If he and I had been living in the same neighborhood, we couldn't have gone to the same school.' Living in an integrated community, it took him a while to grasp the fact. I don't think he really did."

But in true Hendricks style, singing for the president served a larger purpose. "I promised him that I'll visit him in April," she says. She plans to bring her family with her for an Easter-time concert in Miami. She'll take the children to Disney World and she'll talk to Bill Clinton about refugees.

"I will convince him to go to Africa," she says confidently. "It's so low on the totem pole. I want him to experience the richness of the people, to know who they are, so he can't forget them. I'll tell him about my experiences and where I feel he can help unlock doors that have been closed." She'll trade on their common Arkansas background, if she needs to, but she believes that Clinton is open to ideas and ready to listen.

The chance to have him listen to her talk is as satisfying as having people listen to her sing. When she thinks she can alleviate pain and injustice, she is both compelled to act and grateful for the chance to make a difference. "The post that I have at the UNHCR," she says, "is really a gift for me." *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


22 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


ENDLESS WAR


LENGTH: 227 words


 

For 26 of the last 37 years, successive Sudanese governments, all dominated by Muslim Arabs, have fought to crush an autonomy movement of black southerners who are largely Christian and animist. The current government, which seized power in a 1989 coup, has stepped up both the number and the brutality of its attacks, as have the rebels on their side. Over half a million people, mostly southerners, have died in the last ten years alone, and 4.5 million are homeless. Aid officials say the plight of southern Sudan is the world's most ignored large-scale disaster.

In December, the UN General Assembly voted overwhelmingly to condemn Sudan's militant Islamic government for human rights abuses. Last month Amnesty International issued a report charging Sudan with gross abuses, including killing or otherwise silencing critics and conducting "ethnic cleansing" operations in areas of the country outside the scrutiny of international observers. The report said the rebels, too, are rights violators. Amnesty urged the international community to take "decisive action on behalf of human rights in Sudan." *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


HASSAN AL TURABI'S ISLAMIC DREAM FOR SUDAN The most powerful man in Africa's largest nation wants to create an ideal state based on Muslim principles.


BYLINE: Joyce M. Davis for Africa News Service


SECTION: AFRICANEWS PROFILE


LENGTH: 2147 words


DATELINE: KHARTOUM, Sudan


 

As reports of disease and starvation continue to emerge from war- ravaged southern Sudan, the Islamic-backed government in the north continues to consolidate its hold on power. Gen. Omar Hassan Amad El Bashir, who seized power three years ago, has succeeded in maintaining control with the backing of the country's most influential religious leader, Hassan Al Turabi.

While Turabi says he has no official role in the Sudanese government -- identifying himself only as a spiritual advisor -- it is clear that he is very much involved in an effort to turn his country into the world's ideal Islamic state, free of corruption, of hunger and, most of all, of dependence on foreign money.

Turabi has been described as the power behind the Khartoum government. He has long been associated with Sudan's Popular Islamic Front, which helped to unseat the former regime, and with the Muslim Brotherhood and its branches around the world. Turabi's religious credentials give the government the moral authority it needs to hold onto power, and his acclaim as a progressive Islamic intellectual has made Sudan a focal point in the Muslim world. 

"I'm trying to propose an original model," he says, "taking advantage of the Western model, taking advantage of other human values from the West, Islam, Christianity to try to develop my own model -- socially, politically and economically."

Southerners say no. The major stumbling block to Turabi's Islamic experiment has been the war in the south, where Christians and animists make up the majority of the population and have opposed Turabi's dream. As the horror of southern Sudan becomes known more widely, the Khartoum government is finding itself roundly criticized for preaching religion while allowing children to starve. From Turabi's perspective, that is not the fault of the Khartoum government but of those who have chosen to oppose it.

"We are trying to build up the country now," Turabi said in recent interviews at his home and office in Khartoum. "Since independence we have had many governments and unfortunately the latest government was very corrupt, so the country developed civil war in the south, tribal war in the west, complete poverty in the west, east and south."

Turabi says he wants to see the current government bring Sudan's people together "and not allow a Somalia-like situation." Already, reports coming out of southern Sudan have likened it to Somalia. But in Sudan, the fight is over religion.

Turabi insists that such comparisons are invalid and that the Khartoum government wants to establish a society based on democracy and moral principles. He prides himself on being a rational, well-educated man, well-steeped in Western thought and culture. He says he is open to dialogue with the West but not to Western domination.

At a dinner party in his home in a residential section of Khartoum, Turabi enters the harem, where his wife is entertaining, and lays a bunch of fresh dates on the table.

"Where do you think these come from?" he beams, with his characteristic throaty laugh. "Please, try to guess." As it turns out, the dates were sent to him from Iraq. "They were gifts to us from the people of Iraq for delivering them cattle."

Turabi was behind the Sudanese government's shipment of cattle to Iraq in October as a humanitarian gesture. "Of course you know the American government was opposed to us sending the cattle," he says, "But the United Nations finally agreed to allow us to do it."

Internationalism. Sudan was criticized in Western circles for not feeding its own starving people with the exported cattle. But in much of the Muslim world, Sudan was applauded for standing up to the United States on behalf of Iraq's suffering people. And Turabi, at least for now, appears most interested in strengthening his influence in his own region. He has organized the Popular Arabic and Islamic Conference, a group that he says includes representatives of both the Arab and Islamic worlds. "It convenes not only Muslims, but Arabs, even Christians, and not only Islamic attitudes, but nationalist attitudes," he says.

Turabi is secretary-general of the organization, which he said was established after the Gulf War, when existing organizations proved too weak to prevent the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait or the war against Iraq. As the group stretches its feelers throughout Asia, Africa and Arabia, he is involved in testing new theories of Islamic governance in Sudan, melding what he considers the best of Western economic and business practices with his vision of the moral superiority of Islamic thought.

It all begins with improving the standard of living.

"People have to be relatively free economically to enjoy political freedom," he says. "And I think the government is now liberating the country. It is liberating the economy from the public to the private sector, removing laws on trade, removing most agriculture trade from the government to the private sector."

Turabi dismisses reports of human rights abuses by the government, which has been accused of detaining opponents without charges. Turabi sees detentions as a temporary but necessary aberration to protect his embryonic Islamic state.

"You know in case of war, you can not apply a fair, stable system of law," he argues. "You can apply some emergency measures. So in this government, because it is unstable economically and politically, emergency law becomes necessary." To Turabi, this is no different from the actions of Western governments during times of war or crisis. "When you conducted your civil war, were they fair in managing their enemies? Even during the last war, you took Americans of Japanese origin, took hundreds of thousands and put them in camps until the end of the war."

Turabi concedes that Sudan's emergency laws are being used to justify the arrests of hundreds of people, from university professors to doctors. But he said such practices will end as soon as the government gains stability and the war in the south ends.

Not everyone is convinced. Many people in Sudan are worried that their country is heading toward another dictatorial regime, imposed this time by religion. It was resistance to the imposition of Islamic law in the south that has fueled Sudan's civil war.

Turabi insists that the government has no intention of forcing Islamic law on non-Muslims. Even in the mostly Muslim north, the civil and family codes of Sharia law apply only to Muslims, he says. But the criminal code

applies to all: the punishment for drinking is beating; the penalty for serious crimes such as armed robbery is maiming; and murder brings a death penalty.

In the south, Turabi says, non-Muslims would be free to develop their own system of laws, in keeping with their religious principles. "Religion must be spread freely," he says. "The Quran itself prohibits anyone from becoming Muslim through force."

Turabi says Western diplomats have accused him of fomenting militant Islam in many parts of the world, from encouraging unrest in North Africa to training terrorists for operations in Egypt and Europe.

"Wherever I went in the West, I don't know whether they were told about me or whether they just branded me. They thought I was a dangerous subversive revolutionary. And that's why I think someone tried to kill me."

He was attacked physically last year in Canada, after a visit to the United States where he met with U.S. lawmakers and addressed several American Muslim organizations. He is convinced that the Sudanese exile who almost killed him did not act alone but was part of a Western conspiracy aimed at Islam.

"They say I am responsible for all the Islamic revolutions around the world, for the changes in government," he says. "I told them it's not true. This is a historical phenomenon. It just happens I speak English and can have dialogue with you."

Despite such denials, Turabi is connected through his Popular Arabic and Islamic Conference to Islamists throughout the world. Sudan has developed close ties with Iran, though Turabi seems ambivalent about the kind of Islamic state that has evolved there. And he is unyielding in his attacks on Saudi Arabia, which he says offers only the facade of an Islamic state.

"Like all religious communities, you have a traditional religious establishment, analogous to the church in Christian societies, and that is particularly so about Saudi Arabia and Iran, both Muslim communities where scholars, the mullahs, are very important, where they are very old book, very conservative -- where they never renew religious spirit."

Turabi says religious leaders in both countries should rethink their attitudes toward the role of women in society. He points to a recently passed Sudanese law setting aside ten percent of elected offices for women. "Women are represented on a big scale in parliament," he says.

Actually, only about 35 of the more than 300 lawmakers are women, but Turabi says their power and number are growing. A women's unit has been established in the Sudanese army, and women are competing equally with men in higher education and the professions, he says. "But still there is work to be done. We have a legacy, a customary attitude to women that is very conservative, that would rather isolate women from the public scene and life. What I look forward to is not only liberation of women in Muslim society, but perfecting the model itself. I want to reform society politically so that it is completely free, not just formally free. And I want a country that is not corrupt, that is morally and not just legally controlled."

Turabi is convinced that reform is well underway in Sudan. He says he expects rapid progress in the standard of living as soon as peace is achieved. "This year, the Sudan is going to export more than 1,000 tons of sorghum," he says. "Most Sudanese are growing their own food in all parts of the country, except the south."

And Turabi says the government soon will begin exporting sugar, meat, seeds and oil. But he says the biggest success is in loosening the shackles of dependence on foreign aid.

"The Sudan is now a much more equal place than before and much freer than before," he says.

Muslims and non-Muslims alike are watching Turabi's experiment to see if the world's newest Islamic government will bring stability to Sudan and end the massive suffering in the south. For even Turabi concedes that his ideal Islamic state can only succeed if it achieves peace and nourishes the principles of democracy, equality for women and respect for basic human rights. *

Joyce Davis is a foreign editor at National Public Radio.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


BRIEFING


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

RIGHTS AND WRONGS

Prospects for a new public television series have been boosted by the recruitment of Charlayne Hunter-Gault as host. The weekly program, called "Rights and Wrongs," will focus on human rights issues around the world. Hunter-Gault, who will remain national correspondent of the "MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour" on PBS, says she sees the new show as a way to bring serious journalistic attention to little-known situations that affect the lives of hundreds of millions of people. At least 70 public television stations are expected to begin airing the show on April 9. The series, produced by the folks at Global Vision, who also produced "South Africa Now," is funded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the Body Shop Foundation and the Aaron Diamond Foundation.

PAYING HIS DUES

World heavyweight boxing champion, Riddick Bowe, who has been visiting Africa, says that African Americans need to do more to aid the continent of their ancestry. On a visit to Somalia sponsored by the U.S. relief agency Americare, Bowe took food and medicine and said he is earmarking for Somalia the potential proceeds from a possible rematch with former boxing champion Evander Holyfield. Bowe, who also visited refugee camps in Kenya, was accompanied by his wife, Julie, who wept when she stepped onto African soil, saying that the experience was "overwhelming." 

LAID TO REST

The casket was draped in the African National Congress flag of green, black and gold. ANC leader Nelson Mandela gave a eulogy before thousands of mourners who included his estranged wife, Winnie Mandela, ANC President Oliver Tambo, legendary anti-apartheid campaigners Walter and Albertina Sisulu, and Chris Hani, head of the ANC's armed wing Umkhonto weSizwe ("Spear of the Nation"). The person they came to honor was not a prominent black activist from South Africa's convulsed townships, but a British-born white women, Helen Joseph.

Mandela recalled Joseph as the first person banned by the South African government, as well as the woman who helped raise his daughters Zinzi and Zenani while he was jailed. She was, he said, "my friend, my sister and comrade." In an energetic sermon at the overcrowded St. Mary's Anglican Church in downtown Johannesburg, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said, "The fact that Helen was white and that most of us here to pay tribute to her are black shows that the struggle is for all of us together -- black and white in South Africa." Joseph, who was 87 when she died, is the first white person to be buried in Soweto's Avalon Cemetery, where she lies next to her longtime friend, Lillian Ngoyi, with whom she worked to organize the 1956 march of 20,000 African women to protest the requirement that they carry passbooks.

-- Jennifer Griffin, Johannesburg

RESISTING ARREST

African newspaper publisher Pius Njawe has been awarded the Golden Pen press freedom prize by the International Federation of Newspaper Publishers, headquartered in Paris. The publisher of Le Messager is printing and distributing his pro-democracy newspaper clandestinely after receiving death threats against himself and his family. "With courage, determination and ingenuity, Mr. Njawe has stood his ground and kept his newspaper coming out," the publishers' group said, noting that the government of President Paul Biya has used censorship, seizure of issues and arrests of staff to try to prevent the newspaper's distribution.

The Cameroon government has stepped up a crackdown in recent months against critics who charge that elections held in October were fraudulent.

THE TOUGHEST JOB

Ghanaian diplomat Kofi Annan assumed the post of undersecretary- general for peacekeeping last week at the United Nations. It won't be an easy assignment. UN peacekeeping operations are overextended and underfunded and are running into difficulties from various warring factions to conflicts who aren't sure they want to transfer that fight to a negotiating table or ballot box. The world body currently is overseeing peacekeeping missions in Angola, Western Sahara, Somalia and Mozambique. Responsibility for two UN observer missions, in Eritrea and South Africa, falls to another UN department.

TRAVELING SHOES

Senegalese historian and linguist Pathe Diagne, who believes that Africans reached the Americas more than a century before Columbus, will set sail to prove the feasibility of his theory. The governments of Senegal and Nigeria are backing the trip, which -- like voyages by Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl -- aims less at establishing proof than at demonstrating that small boats piloted by skilled seafarers could have made the journey. "Our aim is not to show who got there first," Diagne told the Associated Press, "but to teach the world about West Africa's historical knowledge of navigation." Diagne, who plans to launch his four boats in May or June, bases his theory on old Spanish maps and archaeological evidence in Mexico.

HE'LL BE MISSED

Episcopal Archbishop George D. Browne of Liberia died last month at the age of 59 during a visit to Milwaukee. His archdiocese, which he was elected to head in 1982, covered six West African countries. In 1970, the cleric was the first African to become Bishop of Liberia, a country founded by freed American slaves in 1847. He was known and admired by Liberians and other West Africans for his personal courage, both in the last years of a tottering dictatorship and during the civil way that has wracked Liberia since 1989. Ignoring death threats, he served on a commission that proposed democratic reforms, and during the worst of the fighting he opened churches in Monrovia, the capital, to shelter refugees.

SKELETONS IN THE CLOSET

Last week in Paris, a mercenary's luck ran out. Bob Denard, who was a model for the main character in such books and films as "The Dogs of War," was arrested on his arrival from South Africa. He is charged with complicity in the 1989 murder of President Ahmed Abdallah of the Comoros Islands, an archipelago nation off Africa's southeast coast. Denard, who said he was ready to leave behind a life of subterfuge, is reported by the French press to have told aides that he will testify that the French secret service encouraged and aided his actions.

MUSICAL TRIBUTE

"The Song of Jacob Zulu," a play premiered by Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company last year, is coming to Broadway after a run in Perth, Australia. Although not a conventional musical where the main characters break into song, the play by Tug Yergra depends heavily on the performance of Ladysmith Black Mambazo, the South African singers who gained U.S. attention when Paul Simon included them for his Grammy- winning "Graceland" release in 1986. The group won its own Grammy the next year. Audiences attending "Jacob Zulu" have been enthusiastic about the seamless interweaving of spoken word and music to tell a powerful story -- "like a Greek tragedy with a chorus," said one theatergoer. Lead Ladysmith vocalist Joseph Shabalala says he does the play as a loving memorial to all those South Africans who fought apartheid but didn't live to see it fall.

The play previews in New York on March 17 at the Plymouth Theatre on 47th and Broadway (212-239-6200). A grand opening is scheduled for March 24.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


WINDING THE WAY TO POST-APARTHEID ELECTIONS


LENGTH: 480 words


 

As the African National Congress (ANC) and the South African government move closer to agreement on power sharing, both sides are scrambling to shore up political support. The outlines of the agreement are

now clear: a multiparty government will rule the country for five years following an election that is likely to take place in about 12 months.

The ANC must sell the deal to its constituency, including militant youth and others still distrustful of the ruling National Party headed by President F.W. de Klerk. 

The government faces pressures not only from right-wing whites but also from groups of blacks. Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, for example, and his Inkatha Freedom Party have rejected the ANC/government arrangement, insisting instead on a federal system with guaranteed autonomy for each of four regions. A federation would maximize Buthelezi's influence, since most of his political support is concentrated in the Indian Ocean province of Natal.

Under the plan accepted by the ANC and the government, Nelson Mandela and the ANC are expected to gain enough votes to lead a government in which de Klerk and his party would hold several important posts, and other, smaller groups would hold a few Cabinet seats.

Alongside the political discussions, ANC and government negotiators have been crafting a deal to merge the ANC's guerrilla wing, Umkhonto weSizwe ("Spear of the Nation") into the national army. Since power sharing talks began, following Mandela's release from prison in 1989, the ANC has suspended guerrilla activity but has maintained its military wing and some of its training bases outside the country. The merger agreement would require dissolution of Umkhonto, a move some guerrillas are resisting.

Last month several ANC members were arrested and charged with smuggling arms into the country. Mandela called the actions a violation of ANC policy, but some of his colleagues reject the idea of giving up their weapons until a new government is installed. The ANC now must convince skeptics in its ranks that the power sharing deal is the fastest and surest route to majority rule.

For its part, the government has been reaching out to potential new

backers, including two sizable minorities: Asians and Coloureds (people of racially mixed ancestry). Last month, de Klerk named two Coloureds and one Indian to relatively minor posts in his Cabinet. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


LOYALTY OF MIXED-RACE SOUTH AFRICANS UP FOR GRABS The government aims to win the support of the Coloured community away from the African National Congress, despite decades of discrimination against racially mixed people.


BYLINE: Allister Sparks * INSIGHT/Observer News Service


LENGTH: 1467 words


DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, South Africa


 

South Africa's mixed-race Coloured community, arguably the most cruelly humiliated of all apartheid's victims, is about to commit an astonishing act of contrariness by voting in droves for its persecutors.

Recent opinion polls indicate that up to 53 percent of the 3 million Coloured people support the ruling National Party, the creators of apartheid, while between three and 4.8 percent support the African National Congress (ANC). Support for President F.W. de Klerk as a leader is even more overwhelming, with a massive 74 percent favoring him against only five percent for Nelson Mandela.

Given what has been done to the Coloured people over the past 45 years -- from the forced removal of 60,000 of them from their historic home settlement in Cape Town's District Six, to race classification officials running pencils through their hair to test its crinkliness, to a law prohibiting interracial sex, which implied that their very existence was a crime -- the response seems almost as irrational as Jews lining up to support a neo-Nazi party.

Of course, as de Klerk and his Ministers hasten to point out, the National Party has reformed. It has abandoned apartheid. It has welcomed into its ranks 45 Coloured and 27 Indian members of parliament, who have crossed the floor of their respective Houses to make de Klerk's party the most multiracial in South Africa's clumsy tricameral parliament. 

But the party has not renounced its past. Only the other day de Klerk sprang to the defense of the chief architects of apartheid -- predecessors Daniel Malan, Hans Strijdom and Hendrik Verwoerd -- describing them as "men of great personal integrity" who were "sincere in their belief that separate development could bring justice to black South Africans."

There appear to be three main reasons why the Coloureds are supporting their old oppressors -- fear of communism, fear of the black African majority, and a failure of leadership by the ANC.

Religious factors sway many. "It is not so much the socialist element of communism as the atheist factor," says Vernon Rose, an American- educated Coloured pastor who heads a regional development agency. South Africa's Coloureds are a deeply religious people; nearly all are members of the Calvinist Dutch Reformed Church, and the ANC's alliance with the South African Communist Party disturbs them mightily.

Aware of this, Mandela used his personal influence to have the Reverend Allan Boesak, the charismatic Coloured preacher who with Archbishop Desmond Tutu spearheaded the great anti-apartheid revolt of the 1980s, elected chairman of the ANC branch in the Western Cape Province, where most of the Coloured people live. But Boesak's image has been tarnished by his involvement in an extramarital affair. He has seemed not to have his heart in the job, and his two senior lieutenants, Vice Chairman Lerumo Kalako and Secretary Tony Yengeni, are both prominent members of the Communist Party. Many Coloureds see the dispirited Boesak as a captive of those subordinates.

What some observers here call the "God factor" also gives de Klerk his biggest advantage over Mandela. A devout Christian and regular church- goer, de Klerk proclaims his faith in almost every speech he makes, which is something Mandela never does. "If only Mandela would use the word 'God' occasionally," lamented a senior ANC member who is himself a Muslim.

But Mandela won't. He has stated publicly that while he is not an atheist, he regards religious belief as a private matter and abhors the flaunting of it in political speeches.

Race rears its head. Racism is a more delicate issue that few want to discuss openly. "Please don't use my name," said a white ANC supporter, "but I think there is a deep-seated racism in the Coloured community. Many Coloureds have got an inborn desire to be white, and they look down on blacks."

Rose puts it more obliquely. "The Coloureds' perception of black

people is exactly what the apartheid policy wanted it to be: that black is inferior," he says. Random conversations in the Coloured townships outside Cape Town quickly reveal that the derogatory term "kaffir," the South African equivalent of "nigger," is in far greater usage there than in the white community, where it is now taboo in all but far rightist circles.

Several Coloureds I spoke to used it freely and made little attempt to hide their contempt for blacks. People who know the community well say lightness of skin has long been a status symbol among Coloureds, and darkness a stigma. "We used to have jobs advertised here in Cape Town for people who were 'slightly Coloured,'" says Allan Hendrickse, leader of the Coloured Labour Party, which hopes to form an alliance with the ANC but is also losing support to the National Party. Allen Boesak tells how community leaders came to his light-skinned mother when he was small and told her that if she gave her dark-skinned children away they could get her reclassified as white.

Taking too much for granted. Compounding these problems is what Franklin Sonn, a leading Coloured educator and ANC supporter, describes as a failure of the ANC leadership to understand the nature of the Coloured community, its special fears and needs, and to devise a strategy to win its support.

"What is happening here is more a failure on the ANC's part than a success by the National Party," says Sonn. "The young African leaders live in separate townships. They don't come face to face with the Coloured community but just take it for granted that the steam of the liberation struggle will bring them along." Rose agrees with that critique. "The ANC must become more community friendly," he says.

Prominent community leaders like these are distressed by this failure. "It is enough to make you cry," says Sonn. The thought of the Coloured people voting for the National Party is so painful to me that I can't contemplate it. It's like voting for the slave-owner."

Some think it is not too late to turn the situation around. Jannie Momberg and Jan van Eck, two white Afrikaner ministers of parliament who joined the ANC last year and spend a lot of time campaigning in the Coloured townships where the dominant language is Afrikaans, are among them. "I think there is a latent base of support that the ANC will be able to tap when it comes to the election," says Momberg. Van Eck contends that rural and working-class Coloureds are slower to join the National Party than the growing middle class, which now sees a chance at last to join the white community. Middle-class Coloureds, like the whites, feel threatened by the African majority, while many working-class Coloureds belong to trade unions, which are allied to the ANC.

"Also, life in the cities has changed," says Van Eck, "but out on the farms and in the country towns it hasn't. There the Coloured workers are still being badly treated by Afrikaner farmers, and the ANC is drawing crowds of up to 2,500 to its meetings."

This presents more ironies. Historically, the Coloureds of Cape Town have been the radicals and the country folk the conservatives. Now that may be reversing. Even more ironic is that if the Coloured community, who constitute 60 percent of the population of the Western Cape Province, do indeed swing to de Klerk in the numbers the polls suggest, this region, which is historically the most liberal in the country, may be the only one the National Party wins in South Africa's first one-person, one-vote election. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


IN TEST WITH DEMOCRACY, AFRICAN LEADERS LOSE SOME, WIN SOME Wave of democracy rocks incumbents, but some survive to reign another day.


BYLINE: Africa News Service


LENGTH: 2680 words


 

Since Africa's spreading democracy movements started gathering steam in 1990, over half the continent's 54 countries have begun the transition from autocratic political systems to multiparty governments.

Late last month, President Didier Ratsiraka of Madagascar became the fifth African leader in just over three years to go down to defeat at the polls. Five other heads of state have been forced from office by popular uprisings or coups, and several more strongmen have been compelled to adopt significant political reforms.

The dramatic changes have prompted a palpable sense of euphoria in many parts of the vast region, which is more than three times the size of the United States. In some countries, the reforms have been more cosmetic than real, and everywhere the challenge of creating governments that are truly accountable to their people is daunting. But the pressure for a new political order continues. 

In Madagascar, the Indian Ocean island nation off Africa's southeastern coast, the winner by a margin of two-to-one was Albert Zafy. A 65-year-old medical professor, Zafy emerged as the leader of a broad-based democracy campaign in 1991 that drew as many as half a million people to near-daily protests and forced Ratsiraka, who has been in office since 1975, to abandon one-party rule and agree to a competitive vote.

A transitional government that included both government and opposition members organized the presidential balloting. In the first round last November, Zafy emerged from a field of eight candidates with 45 percent of the votes. A new parliament, which will name the prime minister and key government officials, is to be elected in April.

In the West African nation of Senegal, the outcome of elections, while different, was not unexpected. Abdou Diouf, who has been president since 1981, won another term in voting on February 21. Preliminary results showed him defeating his long-time rival, Abdoulaye Wade, and six other candidates.

Senegal, whose first president was the internationally known poet Leopold Senghor, is one of the few African countries that has held regular multiparty elections throughout its post-independence history. Diouf's assumption of the presidency when Senghor retired is cited as a model of peaceful transition on an often turbulent continent.

Like Senghor, Diouf has made a name for himself beyond Senegal. He currently chairs both the Organization of African Unity and the Organization of the Islamic Conference, a worldwide grouping of Islamic nations.

But the Senegalese leader has been criticized for failing to resolve economic woes and internal divisions at home. The former French colony is deep in debt and heavily dependent on outside aid, due in part to plummeting world commodity prices since the mid-1980s. Last year alone, the country's leading export product, peanut oil, dropped in price by nearly 35 percent.

The most serious political crisis is a serious separatist rebellion in the southern region of Casamance. During the recent election, several dozen people were reported killed in attacks attributed to a Casamance rebel group, and thousands have been forced by the violence to flee their homes.

Diouf's margin in the last presidential vote, in 1988, was widely disputed, and protests over the results prompted the government to impose a state of emergency and arrest leading opposition figures.

This year's election has been criticized as well. Observers from the United States and France said the polling was generally fair, although hampered by shortages of voting equipment and personnel. But the seven opposition parties charge Diouf's party with widespread electoral fraud.

A new test for Diouf and his ruling Socialist Party lies just ahead. Parliamentary elections later this month will provide Wade's Democratic Party and several of the smaller opposition movements the opportunity to garner enough representation to pose a significant challenge to government policies in legislative deliberations.

First elected president for Niger. Another African nation in the process of choosing a new leader is Niger, where the final round of presidential voting is scheduled to take place on March 20. Eight candidates were on the ballot for round one on February 27.

Niger has spent most of its post-independence history as a one-party state with an authoritarian military leader at the helm. No previous president has been chosen in a contested vote. Widespread popular protests in 1991 forced the military leadership to yield to an interim administration that has been guiding the country toward the ballot box. Ali Sa bou, a military officer who has been head-of-state since 1987, is barred from running but remains in office as figurehead leader.

In last month's vote, a coalition of nine political parties -- the Alliance of Forces for Change -- won a combined majority in the one- chamber national assembly. However, the largest bloc of seats for a single party went to the former ruling party, the National Movement for a Developing Society, which won 28 out of a total of 83 places in the assembly.

Obstacles Along Election Road. None of the countries making the transition to multiparty government are finding the changeover to be uncomplicated, and some have encountered major pitfalls. Electoral plans have been delayed in a number of countries, including Angola, where civil war has resumed, Mozambique, where a United Nations observer team has been slow in arriving, and Togo, where an entrenched military regime has blocked democratic reforms from being implemented.

Nigeria, the continent's most populous nation, is currently in the process of beginning its presidential election process again, after an embarrassing false start in 1992.

Last month, the country took the first of a series of steps to nominate new presidential candidates. President Ibrahim Babangida, the military leader who has pledged to hand power to an elected civilian regime later this year, nullified last September's presidential primaries, saying the process was characterized by large-scale fraud, including vote buying. The two legally recognized political parties have been directed to choose their presidential nominees through a process that begins with wards and moves up through local and state organizations to the national level.

At state party congresses this week, one candidate from each of the country's 30 states and the federal capital territory, Abuja, will be chosen to stand for the nomination of the Social Democratic Party and the National Republican Convention, as the two parties are called. The presidential election is now scheduled to take place on June 11.

Another country that canceled a 1992 vote is the Central African Republic. With the assent of the opposition, Gen. Andre Kolingba, the head of state, "disallowed" the results of last October's elections because of widely reported irregularities. After a delay, new presidential and parliamentary balloting is set for April 18 and May 2.

Congo, too, will be holding new parliamentary elections soon, although a parliament and president were chosen last July and August. In November, President Pascal Lissouba dissolved the assembly after the prime minister lost a no-confidence vote. The ensuing political crisis, which brought the country to the brink of political instability and raised the specter of a return to military rule, was eased by the formation of a coalition government. But deep divisions remain, and final agreement on a new election is still to be announced.

Political contests unresolved. Two African rulers who won hotly contested votes late last year have had their victories challenged by distrustful opponents. Ghana's Jerry Rawlings and Kenya's Daniel arap Moi have been accused of using their positions as incumbents to manipulate the voting in their favor.

Opposition parties in Ghana boycotted legislative elections in December to protest the outcome of the November 3 presidential balloting. Rawlings, a former air force flight lieutenant, who won with 58 percent of the votes, has led Ghana since staging a widely popular military coup that ousted a corrupt civilian administration in 1981.

If unresolved, the election dispute could jeopardize the country's continued access to sizable assistance from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and from a number of Western countries. Efforts to encourage a workable compromise between Rawlings and his leading opponents have begun, involving, among others, the Carter Center in Atlanta. An election observer team from the center was among those international monitors who found the November poll to be generally fair.

In Kenya, Moi's win was a bitter pill for political reformers. After forcing the president to back away from an insistence on continued one- party rule, his opponents failed to unify to defeat him at the polls. With the opposition splintered, Moi was able to cling to office by winning 36 percent of the votes. Opposition parties won 88 out of 188 elected parliamentary seats.

Observers from Commonwealth countries concluded that the elections "cannot be given an unqualified rating as free and fair," but they also called the voting "an important turning point in Kenya's history."

Since the election, Moi has been criticized for failing to take any conciliatory steps to heal the political divisions. Using his constitutional prerogative to appoint 12 members of parliament, he named 11 senior members of his ruling Kanu Party who had been defeated at the polls. And on the day after parliament, convened last month with its first opposition membership in over 25 years, Moi used another constitutional provision to suspend the proceedings and send legislators home.

The political situation is further clouded by court challenges to election results in 90 parliamentary districts, according to the Nairobi-based news-magazine Weekly Review.

Despite the problems, the government has declared the elections a success and has begun campaigning to have international aid suspended in late 1991 restored.

An even more serious stand-off between a besieged ruler and his opponents resulted from last October's election in Cameroon. The incumbent president, Paul Biya, claimed victory with a reported 40 percent of the vote, compared to 36 percent for John Fru Ndi, his chief rival. Biya, who quickly organized elections after being forced into political concessions by popular pressure, won financial backing from France after the vote and was sworn in for a new five-year term. Fru Ndi, however, continues to dispute the results and to call for an election monitored by outside observers.

Learning the ropes. In many other countries, preparations for upcoming votes are actively underway. The East African nation of Burundi has scheduled parliamentary and presidential elections for June.

National elections are set to take place at about the same time in Lesotho, the tiny mountain kingdom surrounded by South Africa. The country's last election was aborted by then-president Leabua Jonathan 23 years ago with backing from South Africa after it became clear the opposition would win.

In neighboring Malawi, voters will have the chance to decide on whether to end one-party rule in a referendum scheduled for June 14. The country's "president for life," Hastings Kamuzu Banda, who has ruled with an iron grip since independence in 1964, agreed to a referendum on the issue after popular protests last year and a cut-off in international aid.

Although the government has rejected secret balloting, Banda has agreed to international observers and to the inclusion of opposition politicians on the commission that will oversee the vote. Meanwhile, Malawi authorities retain a tight reign on political opponents. In a continuation of the regime's traditional hard-line approach to dissent, police arrested two exiled politicians on their arrival in the country last month to participate in the referendum. And the country's leading opposition figure, Chakufwa Chihana, was sentenced in December to two years in prison for sedition.

Voters in Eritrea will cast ballots in April to decide on independence for the former Italian colony, annexed by Ethiopia in 1962. Across the continent, a referendum on independence for Western Sahara, which was occupied by Morocco in 1975, has been delayed by disagreement over the voters roll.

The most active voter preparation effort anywhere in Africa -- and the one attracting the greatest outside funding -- may be in South Africa. No date has been set, but the country is likely to hold its first one-person, one- vote poll sometime in early 1994.

South Africans don't have to look far for an example of successful elections. Neighboring Namibia, which until 1990 was controlled by South Africa, held its first national vote in late 1989 under United Nations supervision. Swapo, the independence movement that fought South African rule, chalked up a 57 percent majority, giving it control of the government, although a large and lively opposition has acted as a watchdog.

In regional and local elections three months ago, however, Swapo won a landslide. The party was victorious in ten out of 13 regional constituencies and in most of the 50 local councils. The rout of the official opposition was complete enough to threaten its future political viability.

"How can we maintain a healthy multiparty system if our party's platform wins such wide public acceptance that we trounce the opposition at the polls?" asked one bemused government official following release of the December results. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 306 DOCUMENTS
