Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


WHAT'S IN A TITLE?


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Even by the rules he himself established, Mobutu Sese Seko technically is no longer the president of Zaire. His latest term ended on December 4, 1991, and elections to either extend his 27-year tenure or to replace him have not been set.

That anomaly poses a dilemma for news organizations seeking to make a neutral presentation of facts. Although many reports still refer to Mobutu as Zaire's president, the Washington Post, in a recent article did not. The Associated Press, after debating the issue, has dropped the title, as has Africa News Service.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


TIES THAT BIND Pressure points considered to back change in Zaire.


BYLINE: Reed Kramer * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1214 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

Unrest over recent days in the Zairean capital, Kinshasa, during which soldiers surrounded the residence of Roman Catholic Archbishop Monsengwo Pasinya, prompted a senior American official in Washington to convey the Clinton admin-istration's concern for the cleric's safety.

Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of State for Africa in the Bush administration, who has remained at his post pending confirmation of his successor, gave what U.S. officials describe as an unequivocal message in a phone call to France. The archbishop, who chairs the interim pro-democracy parliament that is trying to end three decades of dictatorship in the country, must not be harmed, Cohen told Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's entrenched ruler, who was reached at one of his mansions on the French Riviera.

Since seizing power in a 1965 coup, Mobutu has enjoyed high-level access to American officials and close ties to the United States government. Throughout the period, Zaire has been a leading recipient of U.S. aid and, in turn, has been a diplomatic ally and a strategic staging area for CIA operations in neighboring Angola and other parts of Africa. 

But Mobutu's well-documented excesses and dogged resistance to persistent domestic pressure for change is prodding Zaire's major backers into promoting reform, although critics believe they could do more. The United States, Belgium and France, both publicly and through diplomatic channels, have insisted that Mobutu yield all effective authority to the interim parliament the archbishop heads.

There has been little tangible pressure backing up the government statements. But last month Belgium announced restrictions on visas for members of Mobutu's family and some of his closest aides.

Visa restrictions already are being applied by the other two Benelux nations, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, and are under consideration by

five other members of an eight-nation visa pact: France, Germany, Italy, Portugal and Spain.

Last week, Belgian authorities raided the Brussels home of one of Mobutu's closest associates, Bemba Salona, a wealthy Zaire entrepreneur. According to press accounts in Europe and Zaire, police found $650,000 in cash and paper that they suspect could be used to make counterfeit bills.

Belgium, France and the United States are exploring other avenues of pressure on Mobutu that might extend to a freeze of his sizable investments overseas. His holdings have been estimated to total $5 billion or more. He is believed to own luxury apartments and villas in Belgium and France, additional estates in Portugal, Spain, Italy and several African countries, as well as extensive ranch land in Brazil.

Lee Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee in the U.S. Congress, has asked the Clinton administration for a "much tougher stance" against Mobutu. Hamilton advocates the freezing of bank accounts, denial of visas to Mobutu's associates, suspension of Zaire from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and an embargo on both arms sales to Zaire and imports of Zairean copper and cobalt.

A letter to President Clinton from three dozen House members

suggests a further step if other actions fail: U.S. logistical support for a United Nations peacekeeping intervention.

Journalist Steve Askin, co-author of a forthcoming book on Zaire and Mobutu's finances, says that the form pressures take will determine their effectiveness. "Freezing Mobutu's assets could freeze him in place," Askin says. Mobutu is unlikely to give up power and flee Zaire voluntarily -- as his critics would like -- if he does not believe he can continue to live in opulent style, Askin says.

He believes a double-track approach would have the greatest impact: legal proceedings in various countries to seize key assets, along with a promise of limited legal immunity in exchange for permanent exile.

The key to Mobutu authority is the income generated from sales of Zaire's smuggled diamonds. Although little diamond revenue ends up in state coffers, an estimated $25 million a month moves through "irregular" channels to fund Mobutu and his entourage, Askin says.

As a result, the government is spending more than ten times as much as it is taking in, confidential IMF statistics indicate. Total foreign debt has risen to about $11 billion, amounting to $300 for every person in Zaire.

Copper and cobalt production, once the engine driving the economy, has plummeted. Copper exports, which averaged 500,000 tons in the mid 1980s, may fall below 150,000 tons this year.

Zaire has fallen into such serious arrears with the IMF that it faces the immediate loss of membership rights, a drastic status for a country in an era when IMF acceptability is the key to attracting other finance and investment, both public and private.

Last November, the IMF declared Zaire "non-cooperating" and gave the government three months to adopt serious reform measures. When the deadline passed on February 14, the IMF board used a technicality to postpone action. The regulations governing such severe action against a member country have not been completed, IMF officials said. Zaire's situation will be reviewed when the regulations are ready or within four months -- whichever comes first, Fund officials say.

The Clinton administration has completed a National Security Council study of policy options for Zaire, and a presidential order implementing most of the options under discussion could be prepared quickly.

But Washington wants to act in concert with Brussels and Paris, and those governments face more serious legal obstacles, diplomats say. In addition, France has indicated a reluctance to take some of the proposed steps, such as IMF expulsion.

"The French have a lot of turf in Africa," says an American official, referring to the former French colonies where Paris retains extensive influence. "They are leery about setting a precedent that they might be pressured to follow somewhere else." *

-- with William Acworth


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


CRISIS GROWS AS ZAIRE DEADLOCK CONTINUES Democracy campaign presses for ouster of longtime ruler.


BYLINE: Tony Avirgan and Livia Montana * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 854 words


DATELINE: Kinshasa, Zaire


 

Political deadlock in Zaire, traditionally one of the United States' closest allies in Africa, has already wrecked the economy and hiked tensions here to a permanent state of alert. Now the standoff is worsening, due to deepening distrust among the principal political actors.

Recent actions by troops loyal to Mobutu Sese Seko, the country's authoritarian ruler, have convinced opposition leaders that their personal safety is threatened. This "new element" has "undermined the confidence of those who are trying to find a solution," says Roman Catholic Archbishop Laurent Monsengwo Pasinya, chairman of the interim parliament, chosen last year by a national democracy conference, whose authority is resisted by Mobutu. 

Interviewed last week in his heavily guarded residence in the center of the capital, Monsengwo demanded that Mobutu explain why soldiers invaded the meeting hall where the interim assembly was meeting late last month, holding members hostage for three days without food, water or medical care.

Monsengwo, who was presiding over the deliberations when the soldiers arrived, was quickly hidden by his armed bodyguards and spirited out a back door and over a fence.

The archbishop and the parliament, known as the High Council of the Republic, have been seeking a compromise between Mobutu and interim Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi, whom Mobutu tried to dismiss from his post last month. The High Council rejected Mobutu's action, saying sole authority over the post rests with the council itself. Tshisekedi says he will not accept Mobutu's attempt to fire him.

Mobutu, who has ruled the country since seizing power in a 1965 coup, has relied on control of the army and the treasury to reward allies and manipulate the political and economic system in his favor. Without access to the national funds, Tshisekedi's government has been stymied.

"We must have fiscal authority," Tshisekedi said in an interview. "Mobutu wants to keep the financial system as before, but it is the High Council now that must decide expenditures."

The council has appealed to Mobutu to "scrupulously" respect the transitional arrangements drawn up by a national democracy conference last year. Instead, the 62-year-old leader has continued to assert his own supremacy. He is expected to make another effort to oust Tshisekedi by naming as prime minister a prominent figure like Cleophas Kamitatu Masamba.

Up to now, Tshisekedi has won the contest for public backing. His appeal for a boycott of large-denomination currency bills that Mobutu ordered minted has been widely adopted. Soldiers paid in the new 5-million- zaire notes in late January were unable to use them in the markets or stores.

When soldiers rioted and looted, Mobutu's crack guard unit, the 10,000-strong special presidential division, or DSP, opened fire to quell the mutiny, killings hundreds of troops.

The houses of opposition figures were also targeted for attack by the Israeli-trained DSP. Troops are said to have gone in search of Tshisekedi, who was hiding. An assault on the home of Frederick Kibassa Maliba, a veteran anti-Mobutu campaigner, left one of his sons dead and left two other children injured, although Kibassa himself escaped.

The soldiers who held High Council members prisoner in late February did not resort to violence. Instead, they said they were acting to dramatize the need to be paid in money they can spend. But the protest failed to resolve the issue.

The council was released, probably on orders from Mobutu, who was in France for what was announced as dental treatment. The Zaire ruler received strong diplomatic pressure from the French, Belgian and U.S. governments to intercede in the crisis. Immediately after the soldiers withdrew, the military chief of staff, Gen. Eluki Monga, announced that unless the currency issue was settled promptly, the army would take "appropriate" measures.

The council has invited Mobutu to come to Kinshasa to discuss the stalemate. Although he was reported to be holding talks last week with top aides at his mansion at Nsele, 30 miles (48 kilometers) outside the capital, he spends most of his time at his palatial residence in Gbadolite, near his birthplace in northern Zaire. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 1798 words


 

ROUGH SLEDDING

In 1991, Zambia was heralded as a promising democracy when Kenneth Kaunda's 27-year reign was ended at the ballot box. But his successor, President Frederick Chiluba, has found the challenges of democratic governance daunting.

Earlier this month, Chiluba declared a 90-day state of emergency, charging that members of the main opposition group, Kaunda's United National Independence Party (Unip) were organizing a coup. The government also severed diplomatic ties with Iran and Iraq, accusing them of funding the plot.

But opposition members are denouncing the move against Unip as an effort to bolster Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD), and Kaunda says there was no plot. More than 20 Unip members have been detained at least briefly since the emergency order went into effect, including three of Kaunda's sons. 

According to the government, the coup was planned by a radical faction of Unip, which has been at odds with other party members over policy. These tensions and the government crackdown have raised the prospect that Unip might collapse, making Zambia effectively a one-party state again.

DIOUF AGAIN

The process wasn't flawless, but last month's presidential election in Senegal produced a winner -- the incumbent, Abdou Diouf. Official results show Diouf winning a third term, receiving 58 percent of the vote, compared to 32 percent for his chief rival, Abdoulaye Wade. Opposition parties have denounced the vote, charging widespread cheating by the ruling party.

Many observers had expected that the tally would be close enough to require a second round of balloting.

A 38-member multinational observer team, organized by the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs in Washington, DC, called the election "a positive step in the conciliation of Senegal's multiparty political system." In a preliminary report, the NDI delegation also listed a number of shortcomings and irregularities. Among them, it said, were difficulties with voting cards and the ineffective use of indelible ink, which was supposed to prevent the casting of duplicate ballots. "While these problems were cause for concern, the delegation received no evidence they materially affected the election," the report concludes.

COMIC RELIEF

The government of Malawi has come up with an innovative method of addressing the problem of teenage pregnancy. A comic book, entitled Sugar Daddy, is being distributed to schools throughout the southern African nation.

The comic depicts the story of Chiphetsa, a young girl who becomes involved with an older man, attracted by the promise of financial and emotional security. Like thousands of other Malawian teens, she becomes pregnant and is expelled from school.

The country's high birth rate contributes not only to poverty but also to serious health problems for women, government officials report.

CORPS RETREAT

The Peace Corps has halted operations in Equatorial Guinea following a series of security incidents apparently aimed at foreigners. The program's last nine volunteers and three staff members were evacuated to Yaounde, Cameroon, on February 24 by charter airplane, after several volunteers were subjected to harassment by people associated with the government,

"We've spent a very, very tense time," said Sabina Dunton, the Peace Corps director for Equatorial Guinea, on her arrival in Yaounde.

The Peace Corps withdrawal follows a decision by the State Department early this month to recall U.S. Ambassador John Bennett to Washington. In February, Bennett received a death threat, which U.S. officials believe was instigated by the government of President Obiang Nguema Mbasogo. Also last month, a French development official who worked in the Ministry of Finance was found dead in his bed with his throat slit.

Other less serious incidents -- including the theft of Spanish Embassy diplomatic pouches from the airport and the holding of a Spanish diplomat at gunpoint -- also have been reported.

Diplomats in Yaounde say the harassment of foreigners may be a reaction to recent pressure from Western nations, especially the U.S. and Spain, to introduce democratic reforms in a country dominated by dictatorships since its independence in 1968.

During the past year, the Obiang government has allowed the formation of ten opposition political parties, but government opponents still face harassment. "The government doesn't like dissenters and it doesn't like dissent," says a foreign aid worker who recently left Malabo, the capital.

The death threat against Bennett "raised a lot of alarm bells," one diplomatic source says. A statement issued by the State Department announcing the ambassador's recall warned the government "that it will be held responsible for the safety of all Americans in the country." "The ambassador's recall was only temporary and was meant to signal high- level concern," one official says. Bennett is expected to return to Malabo before the end of March. (by Derald Everhart

TO THE DEATH

In an effort to develop a transition plan for the country's derailed democracy process, talks began in mid-March between Algerian government officials and opposition leaders. However, the largest opposition group, the outlawed Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) is not included.

Since a state of emergency was declared in Algeria in early 1992, the country has been ruled by a council of state with support from the military. The crackdown came in the midst of a national election campaign which the fundamentalist FIS seemed certain to win. Over 600 Islamic fundamentalists reportedly have been killed by government special forces during the past year.

Some opposition leaders taking part in the latest discussions have expressed skepticism that negotiations can succeed without representation from moderate elements within the FIS.

OUT OF GAS

A distress call from a ship off Africa's east coast early this month has led the ship's crew into troubled waters. Coast guard personnel from the island nation of Seychelles went to the aid of the Greek-flagged ship, Maria, which broadcast signals for help after running out of fuel. Once onboard, Seychelles officials discovered a sizable cargo of arms and ammunition.

The ship had aroused suspicion already because the crew apparently renamed the vessel more than once while at sea. Now the U.S. State Department in Washington says the shipment contains Serbian arms that were destined for Somalia. If true, the venture would violate two United Nations embargoes.

The ship's crew has been detained pending further investigation.

VINTAGE MOBUTU

Zaire's Mobutu Sese Seko is up to the old tricks that have kept him in power for 28 years. Last week, he engineered the selection of a new political figure to serve as the country's prime minister. But his choice has been rejected by the interim parliament and by Zaire's major international backers.

Last month, Mobutu tried to fire Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi, who was chosen for the post last year by a national democracy conference representing Zaire's political, religious and civic organizations. However, the dismissal was vetoed by the High Council of the Republic, the interim parliament elected by the national conference to steer the country toward democratic elections.

In an attempt to bypass the High Council, Mobutu convened his own conclave of hand-picked political figures in mid-March to come up with a new candidate for prime minister. The sessions were boycotted by both Archbishop Laurent Monsengwo Pasinya, chairman of the interim parliament, and the opposition coalition, known as the Sacred Union. But the meeting continued for nearly two weeks, ending with the selection of Faustin Birindwa, who was one of four co-presidents of Tshisekedi's party before resigning this month.

Mobutu also has stymied the democratic process by refusing to yield control over the country's finances and military to the interim government. But the political stalemate and deteriorating economy have prompted reaction from the countries Mobutu has previously relied upon for principal support -- the United States, Belgium and France. The three governments have been considering measures to pressure Mobutu to give up his authority, and they have said they will do business only with a prime minister chosen by the High Council.

In what may be a sign of a toughening stance, Mobutu was refused his request for a visa to enter France this week to stay in one of his luxurious estates on the French Riviera. And Clinton administration officials say Ambassador to Zaire Melissa Wells, who is moving to a senior UN position, will not be replaced in Kinshasa.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


AN AFRICAN MUSEUM IN NEW YORK


LENGTH: 640 words


 

The Museum for African Art opened its doors last month in the area of lower Manhattan known as SoHo. An outgrowth of the eight-year- old Center for African Art on New York's upper east side, the new

museum preserves the center's founding inspiration: "the belief that African art, an eloquent testimony to the richness of black culture, is one of humankind's highest achievements."

In its SoHo quarters, the museum shares a block with the New Museum of Contemporary Art and the Guggenheim Museum SoHo to create a "museum row" designed to attract a diversity of art lovers. The African museum's space is triple the size of the former Center for African Art and was the object of much exploratory planning. Last May, Museum Director Susan Vogel convened a symposium of African and American experts to discuss how to design an African art museum to meet 21st century needs. The renovation of the SoHo building reflects those conversations. 

Maya Lin, the 34-year-old artist whose earlier work includes the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial in Washington and the Civil Rights Memorial in Montgomery, Alabama, was selected to design the museum. "I think of the space as lyrical and spiritual," she says, "full of mystery and shadows -- a place that is dark, safe, welcoming and protective." In a museum, she says, the journey through the physical space should be integral to the experience. "On this journey, the descent and ascent are central, so I have spent a lot of time on the staircases that connect the street and lower levels, where the two main galleries are located. One staircase is narrow in the descent and wide, asymmetrical and spiraling in the ascent. You move into the darkness and emerge into the light."

To inject what she calls "invisible dynamics" and "musical rhythms" into the space, Lin has used textural details such as green glass, copper screens, pinpoints of light and indigo fabric.

In addition to the collections and special exhibits displayed by the museum, the nonprofit institution will operate several special projects, including an education program for New York City schools; regular presentations of film, video, music, dance and performance art; Saturday afternoon family workshops; and study tours for travelers interested in African art, history and culture. This year the museum is sponsoring six tours to east, west and southern Africa. Limited to 12 participants each, the trips are designed to allow intensive interaction with local people and traditions.

A portion of the museum's expanded space is devoted to a shop featuring African crafts, including clothes and jewelry. Director Vogel says the store's wares provide a link with living African craftspeople. "We are not selling any reproductions," she says. "Everything here is made in Africa so purchases help support craftspeople and keep their ancient arts alive." *

The Museum for African Art is located at 593 Broadway. It is open Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. and on Fridays and Saturdays from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., Tuesdays are reserved for school groups by appointment. Suggested admission is $3.00 for adults and $1.50 for seniors, students and children. For more information call (212) 966-1313.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


THE POWER AND THE GLORY OF AFRICAN ART A conversation with Susan Vogel, executive director of the Manhattan's new Museum for African Art.


SECTION: CULTURE/LIFESTYLE


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

Why do African art and culture matter to Americans?

Vogel: Traditional African art is one of the great artistic traditions -- one of humankind's highest achievements. African art and culture matter to us, here and now, because a very big part of our population is African in origin, a piece of American culture is African in origin. The African ingredients in our culture make us distinctive as Americans, so they should be of interest to everyone.

What does African art offer to us now at the end of the 20th century? 

Vogel: African art is a rich source of ideas. The painter Maillol said, "African art embodies more ideas than French art," speaking, I think, about the inventive forms that were so important to artists early in the century. Today the forms of African art have become familiar, giving it virtually the status of old master works. But the spiritual ideas it expresses, the complex insights it can offer into the human condition, the solutions that African civilizations have invented to problems that still vex us -- problems of the environment, of healing, of social and spiritual strength and cohesion -- these African ideas now attract and surprise with the power that African sculptural forms did before.

Fifty years ago, the West was more certain about its religious beliefs and political and economic systems. Now doubt pervades all these areas and has left openings, even a hunger, to look elsewhere. On a spiritual level there's a renewed interest in African religion, and there is an explosion of interest in African music. African art lies at the intersection of all these things. I think people see in it a new relevance to their lives.

Traditional African art sits at the center of African religion, healing, politics, social relations, gender relations and communal life, and it expresses all those values. Clearly, as one of the great, great art traditions, it will always have value to us. The fact that we know a lot about what the art means simply makes it more attractive and produces a new impetus to look more closely.

Haven't people turned to Africa before for ideas and inspiration?

Vogel: At the beginning of this century, the West's interest in African art came from the fact that contemporary Western artists were looking for formal solutions that they happened to see in African art. The now famous encounter of Picasso and his circle with African art was driven entirely by a search for new plastic forms. He didn't care what things meant, exactly who made them, or why -- he only cared about the way they looked. Many people still feel that way.

What about contemporary African art?

Vogel: Contemporary Africa is acting out of something the rest of us are also struggling with -- the marriage, or confrontation of cultures. African cities, like all of the major cities of the West, are polyglot and cacophonous. Africa has taken another route but independently arrived at the same point. Contemporary African art, invisible in the West until recently, is emerging as part of the critical nexus of art currents as the century closes. The melding of completely disparate cultural elements in contemporary Africa with cultural modes from Africa's ancient traditions has resulted in the independent creation of a transnational, postmodern aesthetic that continuously produces ideas and inspirations that are interesting to others. Where better to reflect on the relationships between cultures, between the inherited and the newly invented, between the colonized and the colonizers, in the postmodern era?

Where does the museum stand on the form vs. meaning question?

Vogel: Clearly, the forms are transcendent and have merit on their own, but they are more satisfying with information. We have to make -- and we have always made -- information available to our audience, but in discrete ways, so that if they don't want it, they don't have to read it. We like our exhibitions to be comprehensible, coherent even without the labels; it's very important that the ideas be visual. Ideally a visitor who reads only the room title will be able to see why objects are in that room. But extensive labels, catalogs and books are available if people want to know more.

But can that solve all the dilemmas involved in presenting art that wasn't created to be viewed in a museum?

Vogel: We have to accept that we are trying to present an aesthetic system that is African through a medium that is not African. A medium that is in many ways quite alien to Africa -- Western aesthetic systems, in Western exhibitions, and in Western architecture. We are trying to explain a whole other system of knowledge, using our system of knowledge to talk about it.

There is a kind of built-in tension and paradox that no museum really solves. As soon as you exhibit African art in a museum, you're doing something anomalous, because none of it was meant to be in museums. This sort of tension is one of the things that our shows have examined and will continue to examine. We can only attempt to create exhibition spaces in which objects have some of the animate presence they have in Africa, where objects were intended to be seen in performance, surrounded by dense crowds, singing, dancing or feasting.

Where, then, does meaning reside when we view African art in the West?

Vogel: Not all in one place. There are three participants in the life

of an African artwork transposed to the West: the art object itself, the African artists and users, with their ideas and meanings, and the Western audience and presenters, with theirs.

Because we are dealing with an art that is generally unfamiliar, whose specific references are unknown to most visitors, people may feel freer to give their own readings, to have their own take, since the maker's authoritative voice isn't present telling them what to think or feel. But of course the information we make available can increase the audience's enjoyment of the art work a great deal.

What do you want your audience to come away with after a visit to the museum?

Vogel: Hunger. I want them to come away hungry. I want them to come away satisfied -- but not completely, eager to see more, to read more, to come back, to go to another museum. I want them to leave feeling they've had the appetizer to a sumptuous meal. But I also want them to leave comfortable. We want the galleries to feel luxurious. We have very little money to do it with, but we will use textures, colors, lights and the availability of seating to make people feel comfortable while they're here. We hope that the design of the museum will speak to a very broad range of people and be so inviting that even non-museum-goers will come by to investigate and return.

Why all this comfort?

Vogel: I think that, after all, museum-going is about pleasure. It's a hedonistic business. What we really are presenting is just sheer pleasure, and if we don't do that, we've failed. Even the information has to be pleasurable. It has to give you a little tingle that comes from looking at something and saying, 'Oh, wow, that's what they meant.' So the space itself has to be physically comfortable, beautiful, welcoming and enjoyable.

Why did you choose Maya Lin to design the interior and renovate your new building?

Vogel: Her sympathy for non-Western culture was very important. Her interest in economy and recycling was quite important given our $1 million budget, but also because those are issues we are very much in sympathy with. Her interest in using African colors and fabrics was very welcome. We engaged this brilliant young architect to design our new museum because more than almost any other artist, her work has been embraced by all generations and by elite and non-elite audiences with equal fervor. We want a museum for the future, and she represents it.

Besides traditional museum-goers, tourists, artists, connoisseurs and scholars, what other audiences do you hope to attract?

Vogel: Our museum has something that belongs very specially to all African Americans in this city and peoples of the African Diaspora everywhere. We are presenting their cultural heritage, a particularly brilliant one, and we are eager to make it available to Africa's descendants in America. We also want to introduce Americans of every stripe to African art and culture, but especially children, so they will grow up with a deeper appreciation and fuller respect for Africa and for what Africa has given to the world.

What are you most looking forward to in the new museum?

Vogel: Getting to know the audience. Any exhibition is a dialogue with a space and with an audience. We're only guessing at this audience right now. As we get to know them a little better, we'll become better at talking to them. It will take us a little time to get the right tone, the vocabulary, the subjects and the questions. We can only begin to formulate what people want to see, want to learn and what they want to hear. It is the adventure we've been waiting for. *


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


BRIEFING


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

ON THE JOB -- OFFICIALLY

After two months in diplomatic limbo, the Clinton administration's principal African policy maker is about to assume his appointed role. George Moose, whose nomination as assistant secretary of State for African Affairs was announced on January 18, is expected to be confirmed by the Senate this week. Herman Cohen, President Bush's assistant secretary for Africa, remained in the post until March 19.

Moose, who was deputy director of the Clinton transition team at the State Department, has been ambassador to Senegal and to Benin, both in West Africa. He also served in the U.S. Mission to the United Nations.

Moose plans to name his own team to head key posts in the Africa bureau, beginning with the three deputy assistant secretaries. His choice for principal deputy is said to be Edward P. Brynn, the current U.S. ambassador to Burkina Faso. A second deputy slot is to go to Prudence Bushnell, who until recently was the second ranking official in the U.S. embassy in Senegal. 

Another U.S. ambassador with extensive Africa experience, Melissa Wells, has been appointed to a senior United Nations post. Prior to her selection this month, Wells was the American ambassador to Zaire. Her new job, which she assumes on April 5, is under-secretary-general for administration and management. She succeeds former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who served in the post after losing a U.S. Senate election race in Pennsylvania in 1992 (check).

ALL-STAR MOVIE

Arsenio Hall is making his first venture into film production with a South African-based drama set for release in the fall. The picture also will be the directing debut of award-winning actor Morgan Freeman.

Called "Bopha!" the movie is a story about black police in South Africa, drawn from experiences of township life. Danny Glover stars as a South African policeman who is forced into painful choices between responsibilities to his job and the welfare of his family. The tale is an account of one man's life, played against the backdrop of the larger political struggle in South Africa.

Alfre Woodard has the part of the policeman's wife. Also starring are Marius Weyers, Malcolm McDowell, Malik Bowens and Maynard Eziashi.

The Paramount Pictures film was shot on location in Harare, Zimbabwe, South Africa's neighbor to the north.

GOING FOR THE GOLD

You have my support and prayers," former Atlanta mayor and United Nations ambassador Andrew Young told officials of South Africa's Olympic Committee, who hope to bring the Olympic Games to South Africa in 2004. Young called the dream of the country's sports leaders "incredible optimism."

"That says that all of your political problems will be solved, that your economy will be on an even keel" by 1998, when bidding for the '04 games begins, Young said during his visit this month to South Africa, where he presented Atlanta's Olympic flag to South Africa's Olympic Committee chairman.

Young was in South Africa to open a three-day conference on "Free and Fair Elections" in Cape Town. "If justice prevails in South Africa," he told conferees, "it will spread not only throughout the African continent but also help cut back on the resurgence of racism in Western Europe."

DOUBLE TROUBLE

Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo Kuti was rearrested this month in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, only minutes after being freed on bail following his arrest on January 21. The charismatic and controversial star is known for blunt talk against government corruption that has stirred the ire of successive Nigerian governments, resulting in frequent imprisonment. In 1986 he appeared with an Amnesty International tour starring U2 and Sting, after being released from 20 months in jail.

Fela, as he is called, faces a murder charge in the case of an electrician allegedly beaten to death by the performer's bodyguards during a dispute over payment. Fela's brother Beka Ransome Kuti, who presides over the Nigerian Human Rights Committee, said he expects charges of kidnapping and assault to replace the original one of murder. The release on bail came after a judge ruled that the government had insufficient evidence for the murder accusation.

Besides having made a name for himself internationally as a pioneer of Afro-beat music, the 55-year-old musician has received attention for his eclectic philosophy that combines support for human rights with diatribes against equality for women. "To call me a sexist ... for me it's not a negative name," he says in a new book Breakout, published by the University of Chicago Press. He once had 28 wives, although he says now that he is not married and does not believe in the institution.

Fela comes from a prominent Nigerian family of clerics and government officials. His mother was a leading advocate for women's rights and served as a cabinet minister before being killed in a bloody government raid on Fela's compound in 1977. His brother is a former Nigerian minister of health.

STANDING TALL

Manute Bol, the tallest player in National Basketball Association (NBA) history, is a giant of a man in other ways as well, according to those who work with him. "He cares about everyone everywhere," says Anna Michael, who works for the Sudan Relief Fund, Bol's humanitarian assistance foundation. Michael says the Sudanese ballplayer feels a special responsibility for his home continent, recently visiting Somalia, Mozambique and Ethiopia, as well as Sudan, to explore how he might help the victims of conflict there.

Bol's latest project has been sponsoring a March 27 gala to raise money for southern Sudan, where an estimated 700,000 people face immediate starvation and a further 800,000 are threatened by severe food shortages. The dinner and fashion show in Washington, DC, is co-chaired by Jesse Jackson and endorsed by Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly. A choir of five dozen African youngsters, mostly the children of diplomats, is performing.

Bol says the evening's proceeds will provide food, clothing and medicine for Sudanese children. "I am feeling more and more," he says, "that a concentrated effort on behalf of the children of Sudan is sorely needed. He says he has been heartened by support from NBA friends such as Charles Barkley of the Phoenix Suns, Chris Mullen of the Golden State Warriors, as well as Hakeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets, who was expected to attend the fund-raiser.

A new book about Bol's life, Manute: The Center of Two Worlds, has just been published by Simon & Schuster.

Gala information: (703) 823-0400.

WHEW!

An eight-volume, 6,000-page work by 300 scholars over 28 years is about to be completed with publication of the eighth and final volume. The General History of Africa, commissioned by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, begins with the prehistorical period and goes through the 1980s. The project attracted funding from sources as diverse as the Vatican and the government of Libya.

French historian Jean Devisse, who serves on the project's oversight committee, told the Associated Press that sharply different points of view prompted initial disputes among the international scholars who did the research and writing. But he said discussions led to "a certain transformation of spirit, after which we began to work together." Devisse characterized the final product as a "bilateral" approach that is told from neither an African nor an outsider's perspective but is a synthesis of the two.

In its entirety, the collection is expected to fill a gap, since most previous histories have been written by historians from ex-colonial powers. Already, however, there have been criticisms that the work minimizes the flaws of African societies, while being unfailingly critical of the excesses of slavery and the colonial era.

Ali Mazrui, a Kenyan who edited the final volume, concedes that the project is imperfect. As an example, he cites the supervisory committee's rejection of a proposal to picture an African woman on the final volume's cover -- a decision he suggests is symbolic of the fact that women's role in modern Africa has been neglected by the authors.

SHE'S GOT A NERVE

Supporters of the African National Congress hissed and booed the wife of South African President F.W. de Klerk when she visited a mixed- race town in the Cape province recently. About 400 protesters greeted Marike de Klerk with revolutionary songs and derogatory posters.

The president's wife normally avoids publicity, but she has been unable to live down a statement she was quoted as making four years ago when her son was involved in a relationship with a fellow student of mixed racial ancestry. According to the Johannesburg Sunday Times, she said that a mixed race person, known in South Africa as coloured, is "someone that is not black and is not white and is also not an Indian, in other words, a non-person. They are the leftovers."

LANGUAGE: English

35 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


ZIMBABWE SAYS NO TO WHITES WHO WANT THE GOOD LIFE BACK


BYLINE: Jan Raath * INSIGHT/Observer News Service


LENGTH: 720 words


DATELINE: Harare, Zimbabwe


 

Zimbabwe's Supreme Court has slammed the door on the prospects of thousands of former white Rhodesians, who have been longing to reclaim the privileges many of them abandoned because they opposed or dreaded a black majority government.

A judgment by the court has ruled that people born in the country have no automatic right to live and work there if they hold foreign citizenship. This reverses a series of high court rulings last year, in cases fought between the Department of Immigration and white families who were trying to return to their former homes. 

The new ruling appears to shut off the last chance for a reprieve for an estimated 70,000 locally born whites who opted for foreign rather than Zimbabwean citizenship when President Robert Mugabe's government outlawed dual citizenship in 1984.

Lawyers say there are probably 50 families currently in Zimbabwe on short-term alien permits and fighting to stay. About 2,000 more families are hoping to return from abroad.

Hugh Bisset, a lawyer representing several of the petitioners in Zimbabwe is pessimistic. "I am in no doubt whatsoever they will be deported," he says.

Many of the families, nicknamed "Rhodies," left before independence in 1980 to escape what they feared would become a communist tyranny as well as a black government they believed would take revenge for nearly a century of oppression by white settlers.

But Mugabe did not live up to the predictions that he would mistreat whites, and the violence in neighboring South Africa, the high cost of living in Britain and the blandness of Australia -- the three most popular destinations for the exodus -- has made life in Zimbabwe seem more appealing than it did earlier.

Even in the absence of racist laws, being white still seems to confer special privilege. Life in the suburbs and farms of Zimbabwe has changed little, except that there is now a sizable minority of blacks sharing the easy-going lifestyle.

Graham Young, 48, a farmer, and his wife, Cilla, left Zimbabwe in 1983, because they were anxious about their children's schooling. They went to the small town of Lydenburg in South Africa. "It was just different," says Graham. "In South Africa you haven't got the bush and the open space. In Lydenburg, it was very right wing, everything was so narrow. So, after ten years, we just thought, 'What a dump, let's go back home.' It was never really not home, even while we were away."

The Youngs took the Immigration Department to court and won the right to stay. But lawyers say last week's Supreme Court ruling means that immigration officials will go looking for the Youngs at the safari farm near Victoria Falls where Graham Young works.

It will be the same for Zimbabwe-born Barney O'Hara, a former game warden. He says he left in 1987 because he needed a specialist helicopter pilot's license for wildlife operations, and he could get it only in South Africa.

But he, too, opted for foreign citizenship and was refused the right to stay when he returned to Zimbabwe in 1991. He successfully challenged the Immigration Department in a lower court. Now, the high court says the $190,000 he spent on a house in Bulawayo, the $75,000 of goods he brought back, and the job he has as a helicopter pilot helping in the campaign against rhino poachers are not tickets to residency. *


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


RURAL SOUTH AFRICA SEES THE LIGHT The government and the ANC agree on the need to electrify vast, neglected areas of the country.


BYLINE: Jennifer Griffin for Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1440 words


DATELINE: Orange Farm, South Africa


 

A brand new mini-van kicks up a cloud of red dust as it bounces along the uneven dirt road that winds its way through Orange Farm -- one of South Africa's largest shack communities. Johan du Plessis, an Afrikaner who speaks fluent Zulu, travels this route several times a week to survey the massive electrification project being carried out by the state- owned Electricity Supply Commission, or Eskom, South Africa's only electric company.

Du Plessis, a tall, friendly person, is an Eskom public affairs executive. He regularly meets with residents whose lives have been transformed by the Orange Farm project, which has provided power to more than 70,000 self-built homes in the past two years. 

Eskom's campaign to electrify South Africa includes 245 projects throughout the country. Orange Farm, where Eskom has invested R28 million (about $9.3 million) is the largest. The utility company expects to recover these costs within 15 years.

New billboards line the road and advertise the many uses of electricity in Orange Farm, which du Plessis predicts will accommodate more than 250,000 homes in the next two years. One Eskom billboard shows a young black student studying late at night next to an electric

lamp. "Electricity gives you a light to learn by," it says. Another reads: "Instant smokeless and smell-free cooking," and shows a frying pan sitting on an electric stove.

Nearly seven million of South Africa's 30 million blacks live in informal or self-built housing and virtually none of those have access to electricity. For years the government neglected such settlements and failed to provide them with basic services. But with the dawning of a "new South Africa," Eskom is moving into black townships and to places like Orange Farm, working to create a demand for its product.

"Previously, the perception had been that the people of Orange Farm hadn't wanted electricity and couldn't afford it," says du Plessis, who has worked for Eskom for over 18 years.

In 1990, as apartheid began to disintegrate, Eskom realized that it had an opportunity to negotiate the right of electric supply with black local authorities. The utility began a massive public relations campaign for a nationwide electrification scheme with the motto, "Electricity for All."

Although the company began the campaign as a means to make money, the extension of electricity to more black households is seen as crucial to energizing South Africa's moribund economy and giving its industrial expansion a boost. Many shack dwellers have decent jobs and would like to buy electrical goods such as televisions, stoves and radios. All they need is a way to power them.

"It's much better since we have electricity," says Gloria Khumalo, 32, whose tin shelter now has a bright light hanging from its rafters. "We had to use candles before."

Orange Farm shack number 2531 now supports a large television aerial on its roof. Emma Nkutha stands inside her kitchen wearing a housecoat and tennis shoes. "I am very happy with the whole setup," she says, "but my grandchildren are now watching too much television." The family recently bought a television set, a large hi-fi system, an electric stove and numerous lamps.

Phumula Mqashi, an Orange Farm convenience store that used to be run from inside a shack, has expanded into three sturdy buildings. It now sells light bulbs and offers video games, an electric popcorn machine and a refrigerator full of cold drinks.

The African National Congress (ANC), which has led the fight for political reform in South Africa, supports the need for widespread electrification. "How do you start a business with a (kerosene) lamp?" asks William Cobbett, the ANC's representative on the National Electrification Forum, a transitional body in which Eskom participates.

The metering system that Eskom has installed in each newly electrified home is a fairly simple process. Each family buys a certain amount of electricity at the beginning of the month and is issued a card to insert in home meters. The system "puts the customer in control of consumption," says du Plessis.

Who's in charge here? It also puts Eskom in control of its customer. Since 1984, Soweto's residents have resorted to nonpayment boycotts to protest apartheid and the township's sub-standard services. Eskom has reduced the risk of nonpayment by having its customers pay for electricity before they use it.

"With the card system, people aren't able to boycott Eskom if they think the rates are unfair, " says Mashupye Matlala, a planner for the Transvaal Rural Action Committee. "People are concerned about losing their bargaining power because of the new metering system."

But Eskom has its own bargaining chips in its campaign to convince more township residents to switch to electricity. Electricity costs less than the low-grade coal whose smoke previously filled each home and caused lung disease. "When I buy electricity for R10 (about $3), it lasts the whole month," says Emma Nkutha. "Before, I used to buy a bag of coal for R12, and it would last only two weeks." A deterrent to many families, however, is that the customer is required to pay a R90 deposit for the meter.

As a state-protected monopoly, whose board of directors is appointed by the government, Eskom's management has had guaranteed investment, says Frank Vorhies, an American economist who runs Eco Plus, an independent environmental and economic consultancy in Johannesburg. "They built huge power plants that the country didn't need, and now they need to create demand, so they've begun a huge public relations campaign. It's a new ploy on the part of Eskom to gather subsidies from the government."

In 1990, due to a lack of demand, Eskom closed about $260 million worth of power plants. "Now they are lobbying to say that electricity is a right and again the taxpayer is asked to pay it," says Vorhies.

The ANC, however, supports the rapid electrification of South Africa and is unconcerned about Eskom's status.

"We view it as an appropriate monopoly. We would want to retain it as a national asset and not privatize it, as was attempted in the late 1980s," says Cobbett. Although the utility should work within a legislative framework established by parliament, Cobett says, "I don't think there should be political or governmental interference with the day-to-day running of Eskom."

As part of its expansion program, Eskom has initiated negotiations to create a regional grid, or electrical network, that would connect all of the countries in southern Africa, including Tanzania, as well as the central African giant Zaire. While Zaire has tremendous power-generating potential, most countries in the region desperately need greater supplies of electricity. Many worry that Eskom, by controlling the grid, will dominate the sub-region and dictate choices about development and industrialization.

The ANC appears to be mindful of those suspicions and eager not to be seen as insensitive as it moves nearer to political power.

"We have to treat our neighboring states as partners and not simply markets," says the ANC's Cobbett. *


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK FORTITUDE REQUIRED FOR ZAIRE REPORTING


BYLINE: Tony Avirgan * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1454 words


DATELINE: Kinshasa, Zaire


 

Zaire: getting here is half the challenge.

First stop for my colleague Livia Montana and me is Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, where, we've heard, there is one of the few Zairean embassies willing to give instant visas to journalists. With no functioning government in Kinshasa, many Zairean diplomatic missions have received no money from home for up to a year. Several are desperate. We hear that the Ambassador to Japan sold the embassy building in Tokyo, pocketed the money and split. Here in Abidjan, the embassy staff apparently is eating with the proceeds from visa sales. The official who needs to sign our visa forms is three hours late getting to work. However, once he shows up and $80 per person is paid, the visas are issued in ten minutes.

There are no more international airline flights to Kinshasa, at least not for the moment. They were all suspended after the Army rampage in January when troops were paid with newly printed, valueless currency. We have to fly to Brazzaville, capital of neighboring Congo and then 

make our way across the river to Kinshasa. There are two ways to do this: one of the ferries that ply the river crossing or a six-passenger plane. We hear that we're less likely to get hassled about our six cases of video equipment at the small airport, so we opt for the five-minute flight. Fortunately, an "expediter" arranged through the U.S. Embassy is waiting to ease us through Customs and Immigration. No hassles. But an argument breaks out when the lone customs officer asks to inspect the bags of a returning Zairean businessman. The businessman refuses and is supported by all the other officials present. The Customs officer storms off in a rage.

In downtown Kinshasa, businesses have rooms stacked from floor to ceiling with cash. Dozens of people work full-time counting money, storing it in metal foot lockers. Prices are regularly quoted by knocking off the last three zeroes. Numbers are easier to handle that way.

Other stacks in other rooms provide additional mute testimony to the breakdown of Zaire's political and economic culture. We saw rooms crammed floor to ceiling with condoms. One organization alone has 27 million condoms piled up in Kinshasa and no money to pay people to package and distribute them. The cutback in international aid and the evacuation of aid workers mean that some of Africa's most successful AIDS education and prevention programs are suspended.

Zaire is private enterprise run amok.

Almost all state institutions have ceased to function and the private sector, small and large, has stepped in to fill the void. There is no government to repair deteriorating roads, so poor people fill potholes and try to collect donations from passing motorists.

With the telephone system dysfunctional, a private company is doing a brisk business with a cellular phone network. Because we must make contact with many people in Kinshasa, as well as stay in touch with home, one of the first things we do is to rent a "cellphone" at $50 a day. Despite the expense, there is an advantage for journalists in this cellphone culture. With the old phone system, any "important" person would have a secretary answering the phone, screening calls. But today's important people want to be seen with a cellphone sticking out of their pocket. When we dial, more often than not, the politician or general will be the one answering.

We quickly find, contrary to all we've been told before coming, that there is no problem shooting video, even with a big camera, away from the main streets. The only problem is trying to get some tape of real life. Every time we pick up the camera, dozens of people run in front of it to express their hatred for Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's ruler for 28 years. They hold up big wads of money and point to their stomachs, saying they have plenty of nearly worthless cash but are still hungry.

Shooting video near any major thoroughfare is quite a different story; it means almost certain arrest. There are police and military people in plain clothes all over the place. The site of a foreigner with a video camera enrages them. They ask to see our "permission." We explain that since the Ministry of Information isn't working, there is no one to issue permission. That is not considered a satisfactory response.

The first time we are picked up, it's by the "gendarmes" or police. They take us to their nearby office for questioning. After 45 minutes, they decide that this problem has to be dealt with by higher authorities. We are taken, under armed guard, to district headquarters, where the commander listens to both sides of the story. He throws his hands in the air and says, "Look, I'm supposed to deal with traffic problems for all of Kinshasa. But I don't even have a car. How am I supposed to deal with something like this?" He decrees that we should be taken to the regional headquarters.

We're first interrogated by a captain who is very rude and talks about foreign journalists defaming Zaire. Finally, he takes us upstairs to see the boss, a colonel who is a cousin of Mobutu. There are pictures of Mobutu all over the walls. The colonel listens to the arresting officer and then to us. Finally, he declares that we were doing nothing wrong and tells us to carry on with our work.

We explain that while we appreciate his attitude, it is not a position shared by the police and soldiers on the street. We ask if he can write a note saying we have his permission to go on with our work. He refuses, arguing that we don't need permission from anyone in Zaire to work as journalists.

Forty-eight hours later, we are under arrest again.

This time we are picked up in a poor neighborhood. A very agitated young man with an ID card identifying him as a member of the Civil Guard harangues us for not having permission to work as journalists. A crowd of several hundred gathers. Most of them are sympathetic to us. An army Jeep arrives and we are taken away to an army base. There, we discover that in the melee, as we were being arrested, our cellphone was lifted from Livia's shoulder bag. "Don't worry," the soldiers -- suddenly accommodating -- say. "We'll help you get it back."

The base commander orders that we be taken to Civil Guard headquarters. On the way, we stop by the place where we were arrested. Soldiers jump out of the Jeep, run across the road, grab the first young man they come to, and throw him in the back of the Jeep. We speed off to another army base. This is the headquarters of the notorious Leopard Battalion of the Civil Guard. The compound is full of vehicles equipped to control civil unrest. There are large trucks fitted with turrets and water cannons.

While we wait to be questioned, the soldiers begin interrogating the young man they picked up. He says he doesn't know anything about the stolen cellphone. That answer, too, is unsatisfactory. Our captors strip off the man's shirt and begin whipping him with his three-inch-wide leather belt decorated with metal studs, while we are forced to watch. The beating is so severe that the belt finally breaks. When they release us -- and the innocent young man -- eight hours later, they ask us to pay for the broken belt. Livia uses her crudest street French to tell them what we think of that idea. *

Tony Avirgan is a camera operator and reporter and Livia Montana is a producer for Africa News Service. We sent them to Zaire to do television coverage of the mounting crisis there.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English
