38 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


BYLINE: Jim Cason for Africa News Service


SECTION: (hd AFRICANEWS PROFILE AFRICA'S TOP STATESMAN MINCES NO WORDS Salim Salim urges Africans to put their own houses in order and says Americans can help most by working at home.


LENGTH: 2294 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

When asked if he is hopeful about his continent's future, Salim Ahmed Salim is characteristically blunt. "If I were cynical," says Africa's top statesman, "I would say we can't go any lower from where we are." Hardly a diplomatic response coming, as it does, from the secretary- general of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the regional body that represents 51 African countries.

But having conceded the scope of the problem, Salim is quick to point to more positive possibilities. "If I were to give you a balanced reaction I would say 'yes,'" he says. "There is a lot of optimism in (Africa) precisely because the things that we should have done ten years ago or 15 years ago -- and would have made a difference for our continent -- our people and our leaders realize they must be done today."

That sort of plain-spokenness has won the 51-year-old diplomat high praise from many of his colleagues. "He has managed to bring the questions of pluralism and democratization into the mainstream of the OAU," says Salim Lone, who edits the United Nations journal Africa Recovery. 

Overhaul. Salim Salim's reputation for straight talk and energetic action has put him at the center of a drive to overhaul the OAU and develop African responses to African problems. But Salim is also a strong champion of Africa's successes, and he remains a vocal critic of the international community's weak response to African crises. In a talk earlier this month, he began by reminding his audience that one of the principal agendas of the OAU, the decolonization of the continent, has been fulfilled. "This is no mean achievement," he said. "Now we even dare to think of a free South Africa -- and we dare to do so not simply as idealists, but as realists."

Salim acknowledges that Africa has experienced declining living standards and expanding conflicts in the last decade. But he insists that there is a new African willingness to address issues of peacekeeping, democratization and economic development.

To insert the OAU into that process will not be easy. The organization that so effectively rallied Africa to banish colonialism is having a much tougher time addressing internal problems and wars.

Today, the organization is largely on the sidelines in efforts to restore peace to Somalia, Zaire, Angola and Mozambique, and the OAU's efforts to develop an African economic community have been stymied. But diplomats and other observers say that if anyone can push the OAU into a leadership role, Salim can.

Born on the island of Zanzibar, which united with mainland Tanganyika in 1964 to become the new state of Tanzania, Salim has been an activist since his student days. His friends say he was influenced by his travels to revolutionary Cuba and Mao Tse Tung's China. His first diplomatic posts -- followed by many others -- was as ambassador to Egypt. At the age of 28, the already-polished young diplomat was posted to New York as Tanzania's representative to the United Nations.

Although he was one of the youngest members of the diplomatic corps, Salim quickly became known as a forceful advocate of decolonization and an outspoken opponent of apartheid. People close to Salim say that his subsequent views were shaped by those experiences and by his advocacy of the admission of the People's Republic of China to the United Nations, at a time when Taiwan was still occupying China's seat at the world body.

Although those early positions won him a year-long term as president of the General Assembly, where developing nations wield a majority of the votes, his reputation worked against him a decade later when both the United States and the Soviet Union opposed a bid to elect him secretary-general.

In 1980, Salim left the United Nations to become Tanzania's minister of foreign affairs and then briefly prime minister, before being passed over to succeed President Julius Nyerere. But Salim stayed in government, serving as Tanzania's defense minister until he won election as secretary-general of the OAU.

Today, Salim works out of the OAU headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where he lives with his wife, Amne, and their seven-year-old son, Ahmed. Their other son, Ali, is a medical student at Howard University, and they also have a daughter, Maryam, who works at the World Bank.

Push for African peacekeeping. Salim describes his number-one priority as spearheading the drive to form an African peacekeeping force. At the OAU's annual meeting last July in Senegal, Salim pushed a "Proposal for an OAU Mechanism for Conflict Prevention and Resolution." Although the proposal was actively opposed at the time by several African governments, a revised draft was debated again last month at a meeting of the OAU Council of Ministers, where the response was dramatically different. All but one of the 29 cabinet ministers attending spoke in favor. Sudan, itself gripped by civil war and the object of UN criticism for widespread human rights abuses, was the lone opponent.

Several diplomats and observers say that the U.S. action in Somalia accounts in part for Africa's new willingness to confront the challenges raised by Salim's plan. African leaders have been noticeably concerned at a situation which forces the continent to accept military expeditions by Western powers. But Salim says that, under the circumstances, U.S. involvement was a welcome development. "You cannot stand with your hands folded, in a situation like Somalia, and say the sanctity of the principle of noninterference does not allow for intervention."

Salim appears to have swayed African governments with his argument that if Africa is to achieve meaningful independence, it will have to save itself. "If we have a mechanism in the OAU," he says, "it will be possible in many of these crises that the first course of intervention will be from Africa itself, rather than from the outside."

As a model, Salim offers the OAU's peacekeeping force in the East African nation of Rwanda. For more than a year, the OAU has been working with Tanzanian diplomats to facilitate the off-and-on negotiations between the government and the rebel Rwandese Patriotic Front. Late last year a 55-person OAU military observer group -- composed of troops from Senegal, Nigeria, Mali and Zimbabwe -- was put in place to supervise a cease-fire. Although the pact broke down earlier this year, a new agreement has been signed this month. U.S. diplomats have praised the OAU peace effort, and last year the Bush administration provided $500,000 to help fund the Rwanda operation.

But even if the intervention, which remains delicate, proves successful, Salim still must persuade African heads of state to establish a permanent peacekeeping mechanism -- a campaign he is pursuing aggressively in preparation for the OAU's next summit meeting in Cairo three months from now.

International observers expect a peacekeeping plan of some sort to emerge from the June meeting, but there is less optimism about whether it will be implemented. "It is one thing to agree on paper," says Africa Recovery's Lone. "But it's another to see what can be done in practice. The second battle will be implementation."

Common market. Salim Salim acknowledges the distinction. "One of our major problems in the continent," he says, "has been the tremendous hiatus between declarations of intentions and implementation." He notes that the idea of continent-wide cooperation and economic integration have been debated at the OAU almost since its inception. The group's 1980 annual summit in Lagos, Nigeria, voted to begin a process of continental economic integration that would remove trade barriers between countries and create larger markets for African product.

"It didn't work because the commitment wasn't there," says Salim. But he says that the economic crisis of the last decade has reordered priorities. "I think right now there is a real sense of recognition on the continent that economic integration is not an option; it is the only option in town."

At the annual OAU meeting in 1991, African leaders signed an African Economic Community treaty. Salim is hopeful that by the time the OAU convenes in Cairo this year, the member countries will have ratified the document so that the structures to make it a reality can be put into place. Questioned about why Africa is not moving more quickly toward economic integration, Salim bristles slightly. "It took four or five years to create the European Economic Community," he protests. "It takes time."

Although Salim has focused his primary energy on remaking the OAU, he continues to be an outspoken critic of inequalities in the world economic system, which he sees as especially disadvantageous to Africa. "Our people work harder today, produce more, but get less for what they produce," he says, referring to the decline in commodity prices that has ravaged African economies since the 1980s. "We've been talking about democratization in individual African countries, but also there is a need for international democratization."

Support from Americans. In a recent speech on Capitol Hill during a visit organized by the New York-based African American Institute, Salim appealed to his audience to halt Africa's slide to "the periphery of the periphery" of world concerns. "My fear is that because Africa is no longer considered to be of geopolitical importance," he told his audience, "there is a danger that the world will not take seriously some of the problems on the continent." A bank for reconstruction has been formed with more than $10 billion in initial capital to assist the countries of what used to be called Eastern Europe, Salim said, but very little new assistance has been forthcoming for Africa.

Acknowledging the historical and cultural links between African Americans and Africa, Salim said he saw nothing wrong with organizing a black constituency to raise the interests and concerns of Africa with the new Clinton administration.

Salim returned to that theme when a young African American graduate student from Howard University stood up at a forum sponsored by the Washington Office on Africa, a church and trade union lobby group. After encouraging him to finish his studies, Salim responded to the student's appeal for advice on how people like himself could help Africa. "We do not want Americans to do things which Africans can do for themselves," he said. "But it is absolutely essential that our friends -- and we certainly consider the Americans our friends -- understand what we are doing and assist us in areas where they can."

Salim pointed to the issue of Africa's crippling foreign debt as an example of how Americans who care about Africa can be most helpful. "There are no financial arguments about debt relief," he said, insisting that wealthy nations and international financial institutions respond primarily to political pressures. Africa bears the heaviest proportional burden of the world's debt crisis; most African countries find their development plans foundering against the implacable drain of debt repayments. Salim and other African diplomats argue that Africa's people should not shoulder the entire burden of poor economic decisions made by the continent's past generation of leaders and the Western governments and institutions that advised them and provided the loans.

Political considerations, Salim says, are what have propelled debt relief for other regions, such as Latin America and Eastern Europe. There have been, he says, constituencies for those measures. To Americans who want to make a difference in Africa, Salim offers a challenge to domestic political organizing. "Why don't you build a constituency for Africa?" he asks. *


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


AFRICATREK PEDDLERS REACH CENTRAL AFRICA Riders for international understanding are still going strong.


BYLINE: Derald Everhart for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 907 words


DATELINE: Yaounde, Cameroon


 

The four-man AfricaTrek bicycle team spent four days in Yaounde, Cameroon, for repairs and recuperation before heading out for Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, where they expected to cross the Oubangui River into Zaire this week.

The expedition is traveling overland from Bizerte, Tunisia, to Cape Agulhas, South Africa, a grueling 12,000-mile-trip, which should take the group through 14 countries. Averaging about 47 miles a day so far, the three American cyclists and one African, who left Tunisia November 28, will traverse the continent twice before reaching the southernmost tip of Africa sometime around August 15. The team aims to set a world record, stir international interest in Africa and gather scientific data. Students in 25,000 schools across the United States are following the trip through curriculum materials, newsletters and a telephone update line. 

The main reason for the Yaounde stop was to find a new back wheel rim for team leader Dan Buettner's Cannondale mountain bike. Buettner, from Minneapolis, MN, cracked his aluminum rim while traveling between Mamfe and Dschang, Cameroon, on a rugged dirt road with "softball-sized rocks."

Steve Buettner, Dan's brother and the team's designated repairman, fashioned a replacement with the only size rim available locally -- which was one inch too large -- cutting a section out of the rim and welding it back to fit the 26-inch tires carried by the team.

The repair gave team member Mobolaji Odouyoye, from Lagos, Nigeria, the chance to recover from a bout of malaria, which hit him in western Cameroon. Running a high fever and unable to continue the ten- hour cycling days, Odouyoye, accompanied by team doctor Chip Thomas, who was recovering form malaria himself, took a bush taxi the last 194 miles to the capital city of Yaounde and rejoined the Buettner brothers there.

The ride through Cameroon followed nearly a week in Odouyoye's hometown of Lagos, where they were feted by the minister of sport and put up in a four-star hotel. The revitalized cyclists made up lost time by averaging 80 miles a day after leaving Lagos, despite harsh road conditions in western Cameroon.

Along the way, in Ogoday, a small Nigerian village, the team members were declared princes of the Mbembe people by the village chief during their overnight stay.

"There was a fair amount of palm wine drinking prior to the initiation," said Dan Buettner, the 32-year-old expedition organizer. After the ceremony, which was held in a mud structure jammed with people where "lizards ran across our feet," Buettner asked for a show of hands of others who were princes, and "half of those in the room raised their hands.

"Well, it sounds impressive," he said whimsically, about having been installed as African royalty.

Between Yaounde and Mangui, three members of the AfricaTrek team have been celebrating birthdays. Thomas, who hails from Durham, NC, but practices medicine on a Navaho Indian reservation in northern Arizona, turned 30 on March 6, while Odouyoye was 32 on March 18. Steve Buettner, from Saint Paul, MN, became 28 on February 28.

On the 800 miles of mostly dirt road separating the two cities, the group still managed over 70 miles a day. En route, the terrain changes from tropical rain forest to grassy savannah. On the next leg, through northern Zaire, the bicyclists expect to encounter the upcoming rainy season, known as the "mango rains" because they coincide with the ripening of those tropical fruits.

Although the mud will slow their progress to about 20 miles a day, team members, who each have lost several pounds sharing rice, tomato sauce and bananas with villagers along the way, say they will be looking forward to the mangoes.

The expedition will be out of touch for about a month while navigating the rain forest of Zaire. Dan Buettner says the four riders are a bit uneasy about the possibility of encountering violence in Zaire, which is in severe political and economic crisis. But he believes they will be safe by sticking to a route through northern villages.

The cyclists expect to arrive about April 20 in Kampala, Uganda, where Odouyoye will say farewell and a Ugandan rider will join the team for the remaining distance. *

For information about tracking the trekkers, call the AfricaTrek office at (612) 349-6606.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


ANGOLA: PLAYING FOR PEACE WITH TOO FEW CARDS


LENGTH: 1134 words


DATELINE: Africa News Service


 

In Angola, although the United Nations has been charged with overseeing a peaceful transition to democracy, it has had few resources to employ. Only about 220 UN personnel are in the country, which is three times the size of California and racked by war between government forces and the opposition movement known as Unita, or Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

A 1991 peace accord ending 16 years of fighting between the Soviet-supported government and U.S. and South Africa-backed rebels gave the UN responsibility for supervising the cease-fire and for verifying the outcome of the country's first free elections. But proposals for a monitoring mission modeled on the successful 1989 operation in neighboring Namibia were rejected as too costly by the major powers, who foot the largest share of UN bills. 

Instead, the Security Council agreed to dispatch 476 military observers and police monitors plus 400 election monitors to Angola, compared with the 6,000 sent to Namibia, which has one-tenth of Angola's 10 million people. The Angolan elections of last September were judged generally free and fair by the observers. But the planned disarming of the combatants and formation of a unified national army never took place.

Unita leader Jonas Savimbi rejected the results of the balloting and charged fraud after official results showed him losing to President Eduardo dos Santos in the presidential race. In mid-October, before a peaceful resolution could be found, the two sides were back at war, with both apparently guilty of atrocities and provocations.

UN efforts to organize a run-off election between dos Santos, who got 49.57 percent of the vote in September, and Savimbi, who won 40.07 percent, have been thwarted by the fighting.

Earlier this month, Savimbi condemned the United Nations and called for replacement of its envoy in Angola, British diplomat Margaret Anstee. In a speech broadcast by the Unita radio station, Savimbi said Anstee "has no experience in African affairs" and "is no longer useful" to the negotiating process. He accused her of "rigging" the election and said "she has all her friends" in Luanda, the government-controlled capital.

"We want a person of prestige and, if possible, an African," Savimbi said.

For the past several weeks, a fierce battle has been waged for control of Huambo, Angola's second largest city and Unita's headquarters. Most observers believe the fighting is the most intense Angola has experienced in over three decades of pre-independence and post- independence warfare. In his speech, Savimbi said that the ferocity of the 55 days and nights of violent clashes "has never been seen before in African military theaters."

After being forced by Unita to withdraw from the city earlier this month, government troops began moving reinforcements into the area, signaling a continuation of a three-month-long seesaw contest that has claimed an estimated 15,000 lives already. No outside food or medical assistance has reached the city's residents since early January.

Negotiations convened last month by Anstee to end the fighting were adjourned when the Unita delegation failed to appear. Unita said it was unable to make use of the UN offer to airlift its negotiating team from Huambo because of intensified shelling of the city's airport by government forces.

A March 15 Security Council resolution condemns Unita for not attending the talks and for "persistent violation" of the 1991 peace agreement. The resolution notes "with satisfaction" the government's willingness to take part in negotiations. The council called for a meeting "at the highest possible level" between the two sides prior to April 30, when the mandate for the UN operation in Angola expires.

Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has recommended a complete UN pull-out from Angola if progress toward peace is not achieved by that date.

But the council rebuffed Anstee's request for a peacekeeping force of 8,000 or more to strengthen the UN's hand in restoring peace. The call for troops was opposed by the United States, which is pursuing agreement from both sides for a truce and disarmament leading to a runoff presidential vote. State Department officials got the nod to their proposals from Angolan government representatives in a meeting on February 23 in Lisbon. Efforts are underway to hold talks on the plan with a high-level team from Unita that is making a ten-nation tour of Africa, Europe and the United States this month to explain Unita's positions.

In the Security Council deliberations, the United States also opposed an Angolan government request for permission to make purchases of arms and ammunition. The 1991 accord bars arms transfers to either party by the three countries making up a trilateral observer team -- the United States, Portugal and Russia. But the Angolan government argues that the provision should not be interpreted as preventing a member state of the UN from defending itself against attack.

Diplomatic sources report that U.S. pressure has been applied to persuade countries such as Brazil and Argentina not to provide Angola with weaponry.

Meanwhile, two South African newspapers have reported that weapons, food and other supplies are being shipped to Unita from South Africa. The Weekly Mail in Johannesburg said arms are being sent from Mmabatho airport in the nominally independent territory of Bophuthatswana in Soviet-made aircraft. The Pretoria News quoted sources in the Foreign Ministry saying it is "more than likely" that shipments are taking place, with indirect official acquiescence. *


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 22, 1993


UNITED NATIONS WAGES PEACE ON A TIGHT BUDGET Africa has the world's hottest conflicts, but peace has come at long last to tortured corners of the continent.


BYLINE: Reed Kramer * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1974 words


DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS


 

Most of the wars that shattered various parts of Africa over the past decade have been brought to an end, often with the United Nations cast in the part of peacemaker. It is a role that seems ripe for revival.

There are four current UN peacekeeping operations in Africa, with another in the proposal stage, and appeals for help from several other quarters.

But budget restrictions and a variety of other constraints have hampered UN efforts, and one of the African operations -- in Angola -- is in complete disarray.

Months of increasingly intense fighting have elevated Angola to the largest-scale war in the world today, even though the United Nations has been playing an intermediary role since 1988, alongside major world powers. In a March 12 resolution, the UN Security Council warned that "a humanitarian tragedy of grave proportions is developing" in Angola and demanded an "immediate cease-fire throughout the country." 

The UN's troubled roadshow in Angola is reflective of shortcomings elsewhere, particularly when the setting is Africa. In Somalia, the world body seemed powerless to prevent an increasingly chaotic situation from developing into a major disaster last year.

A UN plan for an independence referendum in Western Sahara, stymied by disagreements over voter eligibility, has been left in the wings for more than a year. UN troops slated for deployment to Mozambique last October, to oversee the end of a long-running civil war, only began arriving last month.

A fair share? Active conflicts in Africa are affecting more people and threatening more lives than all the fighting in other parts of the world today. But only 15 percent of UN military and civilian peacekeeping personnel are posted to Africa, and less than 12 percent of the UN's current annual $2.8 billion peacekeeping budget is allocated for African operations.

Those percentages will rise beginning in May when UN troops take over the relief and protection role that a U.S.-led coalition force has been playing in Somalia since December. The Somali operation is expected to cost about $1.5 billion during its first year and involve 20,000 troops, 8,000 logistics personnel and 2,800 civilians.

If the projection is accurate, Somalia will become the most costly peacekeeping effort anywhere, surpassing Cambodia and straining an already overextended UN peacekeeping fund.

"Restore Hope is a potluck affair," says one U.S. official, referring to the current coalition effort in Somalia. Each country is paying its own way, except for a few smaller nations, like Botswana, which has 300 troops in Somalia. Their presence is being subsidized by monies from contributors like Japan and Saudi Arabia.

Funding for the reconstituted United Nations Operation in Somalia, known as Unosom, will come through the United Nations, which is already owed over a billion dollars in outstanding members' contributions. Last week's resurgence of fighting in Kismayu underscores the possibility that the level of engagement in Somlia -- and the costs -- could escalate still further.

In addition to peacekeeping expenditures, Somalia needs an estimated $166 million in outside assistance for food, health programs, refugee resettlement, education and reconstruction. Most of the amount needed was pledged at a UN-sponsored donors conference earlier this month in Ethiopia.

A subsequent UN-convened meeting, also in Ethiopia, brought together some 250 Somali participants to debate an agenda for national reconciliation. The conference was the broadest-based effort so far to forge a political consensus, involving not only the leaders of warring factions, but intellectuals, clan elders, and the heads of civic, religious and women's organizations as well as leaders of warring factions, but it was suspended when fighting resumed.

Speaking to the gathering, the UN secretary-general's newly appointed deputy special representative, Lansana Kouyate, warned delegates that world patience with continued strife in Somalia is wearing thin. "Peace is Somalia's only salvation," he said.

Big move. In Mozambique, a massive refugee repatriation is set to begin next month, although over 100,000 people already have returned on foot. About 1.3 million Mozambicans fled the southwest African nation, most of them to next-door Malawi, during 16 years of civil war. The United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Sadako Ogata, says the resettlement will be the largest ever undertaken by her agency in Africa and will cost more than $30 million for the first year. The return of all the refugees is expected to take three years.

The bitter conflict, which claimed an unusually high number of civilian casualties, ended with a peace accord last October. The cease-fire between government forces and the rebel movement known as Renamo has had relatively few violations, despite the delayed arrival of the UN monitoring force.

With the delay, elections slated to take place in October are expected to be postponed until next year. UN officials have emphasized a determination to avoid a repetition of the violent post-election period in Angola, which like Mozambique has been at war since its independence from Portugal in the mid-1970s.

During a visit to the United States last month for talks with UN and American officials, Angola's Roman Catholic Archbishop Jaime Goncalves, the chief mediator in three years of peace talks, called for a rapid increase in the UN presence.

Waiting and waiting. In Western Sahara, the problem has not been late deployment of UN troops. Some 300 soldiers from 26 nations have been in place in the territory for the past 18 months, but the referendum they are there to monitor has not been held.

A UN plan calls for voters to choose between independence and incorporation into Morocco, which took control when Spain pulled out in 1975 and asserts a historical claim. The independence movement Polisario wants to use the last Spanish census as the starting point for establishing voter eligibility, while Morocco has moved in tens of thousands of people it says have Saharan ancestry and ought to be allowed to cast ballots.

In a March 2 resolution, the Security Council called for implementation of the UN settlement plan "without further delay" and asked the secretary-general to "intensify" negotiations and to report back on his progress by May. The council said the referendum should be held before the end of this year.

More on the way. Despite the problems UN activities are encountering, other problem spots are likely to wind up on the world body's agenda soon. The Security Council last week agreed to consider sending a peacekeeping force to the East African nation of Rwanda, to augment a monitoring force provided by the Organization of African Unity.

Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana has called for UN action to help end a civil war and restore a cease-fire that broke down early this year. The Rwandan Patriotic Front, fighting to oust Habyarimana, said it launched new attacks after several hundred minority Tutsi people were killed by supporters of the Hutu-dominated government.

More than a million of Rwanda's seven million people have been uprooted by the fighting.

In the West African nation of Liberia, where a civil war that began in late 1989 uprooted over a million people out of a population of 2.6 million, UN peacekeeping help is being sought.

Liberia was founded by freed American slaves in 1847, and like Somalia has been one of the largest U.S. aid recipients in sub-Saharan Africa. So Liberians expected the United States to intervene promptly to stop the carnage. Instead, after the country disintegrated into chaos, a multinational West African peacekeeping force stepped in to restore order.

After two years of negotiations, fighting resumed last October, sparked by an assault on the West Africans by the country's largest armed group, the National Patriotic Front led by Charles Taylor. In recent weeks, West African troops have driven the rebels from long-held positions west, south and east of the capital, Monrovia. The Nigerian-led force seems intent on forcing Taylor to abide by the terms of a previously accepted peace plan, calling for disarming troops, opening the country's roads and holding nationwide elections.

The UN secretary-general, in a report to the Security Council this month, endorses the West African peace effort and says a UN role in the crisis should support the regional initiative. A decision to commit UN observers to the peace process should await a "cessation of hostilities," the secretary-general says, but his special representative, Trevor Gordon- Somers, will return to Monrovia to explore possibilities.

In South Africa, where negotiations on a transition to majority rule continue, a 50-person UN monitoring team has arrived to assist efforts to end political violence.

There also are calls for United Nations intervention in Sudan, where hundres of thousands of people have died and 1.5 million are at risk as a result of continuing conflict between Islamic fundamentalist government forces and an insurgency movement seeking autonomy for the Christian and animist southern region of the country. A UN relief operation is charged with getting food and other emergency assistance to the afflicted population, but no plans for sending a peacekeeping force have been advanced.

Amidst the agony of continuing conflict, Africans find some solace in the ending of several long-running wars in recent years. Besides the fragile peace pacts in Somalia, Mozambique and Western Sahara, armed struggles in Namibia, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Chad and Uganda have wound down or been halted through negotiations or elections. *

Jean KENNEDY, New Currents, Ancient Rivers: Contemporary African Artists in a Generation of Change. Blue

Ridge Summit: Smithsonian Institution Press (Department 900, Blue Ridge Summit, PA 17214), 1992. $49.95 (cloth). 204 pp. Surveys African art over the last 40 years and discusses the influence of the oral and literary tradition.

Life: A South African Autobiography. New York: Routledge, Chapman and Hall, Inc. (29 West 35th Street, New York, NY 10001), 1991. $39.95 (cloth). $13.95 (paper). 42 pp. The author, former secretary of the Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers Union of South Africa, recounts her politicization and the development of the black labor movement.

Taffy Gould MCCALLUM, White Woman Witchdoctor.

Tulsa: Council Oak Books (1350 East Fifteenth Street, Tulsa, OK 74120), 1993. $29.95 (cloth). 247 pp. Biography of Rae Graham, a British nurse who became an honorary member of the Venda tribe.
