LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


DATELINE: AFRICA


LENGTH: 2547 words


 

OFF AND RUNNING

After several false starts, Nigeria's presidential campaign is moving into high gear. Two candidates, both of them rich businessmen, have emerged from the throng of aspirants -- Moshood Abiola of the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and Bashir Tofa from the National Republican Convention (NRC).

Abiola is a Muslim from the Christian-dominated south who became wealthy while heading ITT-Nigeria. He now chairs the Nigerian Stock Exchange and owns a media conglomerate, which includes the Concord newspapers and the London-based magazine, Africa Economic Digest. Tofa, a northern Muslim from Kano state, is a millionaire banker. He served as finance secretary during the previous civilian administration, which was overthrown in a 1983 coup.

Both men have close ties with the current president and military leader Ibrahim Babangida. In 1990, Tofa called for Babangida to stay in power until the year 2000. With Nigerians clamoring for a break with the past, many observers believe that Tofa's ties to former regimes makes Abiola the more likely winner of the scheduled June 12 contest. 

Babangida's administration nullified presidential primaries held last September, saying that the process was tainted by widespread fraud. He directed the two parties to restart the nomination process, beginning at the local level and culminating in the national party conventions that last month nominated Abiola and Tofa.

DYING FOR ATTENTION

Charles Taylor, head of the largest armed faction in Liberia, says he will never surrender to West African peacekeeping troops in his country. He wants a United Nations force to intervene to stop the fighting.

But the UN Security Council, in a resolution adopted on March 26, endorsed a continuation of the regional initiative by members of the Economic Community of West African States. A seven-nation West African force, known as Ecomog, has been in Liberia since late 1990, in an effort to keep the factions apart and hold elections.

Ernest Shonekan, the head of Nigeria's transitional government, appealed for American backing for the West African effort during a visit to Washington last month. Without Ecomog, Shonekan said, "Liberia would undoubtedly have degenerated to the unfortunate state now being witnessed in Yugoslavia and Somalia." He said Nigeria has no intention of dictating an outcome in Liberia and is interested only in ensuring that Liberians be allowed to choose a democratic government.

But Taylor views Nigeria as his enemy, and since his troops attacked Ecomog positions last October, war has raged through much of the country. "Ecomog is a warring faction," Taylor said in an interview late last month with journalists from the BBC, Radio France International and Reuters at his headquarters in Gbarnga. "We will never negotiate with Ecomog, ever."

AIDS COSTS

One of the largest AIDS information and health centers in Uganda is introducing cost-sharing for tests.

Beginning this month, the AIDS Information Center (AIC), a semi-official body, will ask clients and patients to pay an as yet unspecified percentage of the cost for tests. For the last three years, an average of about 180 clients have received AIDS testing services free from the center, located in the Ugandan capital, Kampala.

Each test costs about $18. The annual budget of AIC is $1.2 million, 90 percent of which is provided by a grant from the U.S. Agency for International Development. The executive director of AIC, Frank Nabwiso, says the center can no longer afford free tests.

Uganda has one of the highest incidents of AIDS in Africa, with figures in some towns suggesting that up to 30 percent of sexually active adults could be HIV carriers. The country simply cannot cope. The annual per capita income in Uganda is $238, and its expenditure on health is only $1 per person.

A report released March 12 by the AIDS Control Program, the government's main research and advisory body on AIDS, had more gloomy news about the disease. The rate of HIV infection has risen sharply among girls aged 15 to 19 in the last half of 1992, the report says.

Out of about 2,000 teenage hospital patients who turned out to be HIV positive or to have full-blown AIDS, 300 were males while 1,700 were females.

Doctors here blame those statistics on female dependence on men in Uganda's male-dominated society and on what is called here the "Sugar Daddy Phenomenon." Wealthy male adults are "raiding" this age group, apparently believing that younger females are less likely to be infected.

In 1990, as cases of rape and defilement of girls in their lower teens rose, the law was tightened to raise the consenting age for sex from 14 to 18. The penalty was increased to life imprisonment for attempted rape, and the maximum penalty for rape and defilement was raised from life imprisonment to death.

None of this seems to have helped much, and a proposal to castrate men who rape or have affairs with underage girls was shouted out of the legislature when it was proposed by a radical feminist parliamentarian.

-- Charles Onyango-Obbo in Kampala

TWO GOVERNMENTS

In Zaire, two sets of Cabinet ministers have been chosen, but neither is able to govern. And with political tensions rising, there are fears of a crackdown by the country's long-serving ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko.

Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi presented his list of selections last month to the High Council of the Republic, the interim legislative body chosen last year by a national democracy conference to lead the country to elections. The council endorsed Tshisekedi's choices, although there was some dissatisfaction expressed that the prime minister had not acted earlier.

In an attempt to outmaneuver pro-democracy forces, Mobutu, ignoring the High Council, has moved to establish his own new administration, naming Faustin Birindwa, a former Tshisekedi ally, to the prime ministership. Mobutu also convened the national assembly, the former one-party parliament that rubber stamped his programs before domestic and international pressure forced the recognition of opposition parties.

The United States, Belgium and France -- Zaire's principal financial backers -- have called on Mobutu to cede all effective authority to the High Council and to allow elections to be held. Last week, France for the second time in a month refused to give Mobutu a visa to visit one of his luxurious residences on the French Riviera.

At home, Mobutu has continued to make life difficult for his opponents. Human rights and political leaders report the harassment of several opposition figures, and Tshisekedi's residence came under fire from troops believed to be loyal to Mobutu.

ANOTHER BOMBSHELL

South Africa may have destroyed its nuclear weapons, but the government still wants to press ahead with an advanced non- nuclear missile program, amid concerns that South Africa's nuclear capacity is larger than has been disclosed.

Pretoria has developed a sophisticated long-range ballistic rocket, based on the Israeli Jericho missile, with an estimated range of nearly 500 miles. During discussions in Washington last month with South African Foreign Minister Roelof 'Pik' Botha, U.S. officials called for cancellation of the rocket program. Although Botha offered assurances that the missile technology is being converted from possible military application to peaceful purposes, Clinton administration officials say they are not satisfied and may consider using economic leverage to underline their concern.

Vital World Bank and International Monetary Fund backing for South Africa, which is expected once a nonracial interim government takes power, could be withheld if a costly missile development effort is continued, official sources say.

Last month's announcement by President F.W. de Klerk said South Africa had built six nuclear weapons after launching a clandestine production program in 1974. The bombs were dismantled in 1989, he said. Many experts believe Pretoria decided to destroy the nuclear devices in order to keep them out of the hands of a black-led government that may come to power in South Africa.

But there are concerns that the public disclosure may be covering up a far more advanced program involving battlefield nuclear weapons. A Cape Town academic, Renfrew Christie, who was jailed in 1980 for passing nuclear secrets to the African National Congress, says South Africa almost certainly developed a two-kiloton nuclear shell. He believes a 10-kiloton bomb may have been produced, as well.

-- Eddie Koch, Inter Press Service, and David Beresford, Insight/Guardian News Service, in Johannesburg

TANZANIA TENSIONS

Racial and religious tension in Tanzania is on the rise, as the East African nation prepares for its first multiparty election after 30 years of one-party rule.

The ruling Chama Cha Mapunduzi, or CCM, which means Revolutionary Party in Swahili, is facing opposition from a new crop of politicians.

The most serious challenge comes from the Democratic Party (DP), led by the controversial and charismatic Christopher Mitikila, a Protestant pastor. The DP slogan, Saa Ya Ukombozi Ni Sasa, which translates in English as "The time for liberation is now," has cast Mitikila as a radical.

Mitikila has been criticizing CCM's handling of the democratization process and has rejected newly issued party registration procedures as "undemocratic." To prove that they are national organizations, parties are required to provide a list of up to 200 supporters from each region, including the island of Zanzibar, which in 1964 was joined with the mainland -- then called Tanganyika -- to form the present United Republic of Tanzania. The ruling CCM was formed as a merger of the mainland Tanganyikan National Union and the Zanzibari Afro-Shirazi Party following a 1964 revolution on the island, ending Arab domination there.

Mitikila is portraying the 19-year union with Zanzibar as disadvantageous for the mainlanders. Tanzania's President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, himself a Zanzibari, is being cast as an "expatriate" president. Such rhetoric has heightened racial consciousness. Zanzibaris, as well as Tanzanians of Asian and Arab origin, are now being labeled with a word that suggests sexual perversion.

There is criticism of the union on Zanzibar as well. Last year, the island took up membership in the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC), a grouping of Islamic nations, stirring criticism from non-Muslims throughout Tanzania and raising question about the future of the union's status.

Religion also has become an issue at the University of Dar es Salaam, the country's oldest and principal university. When new fees were introduced last October, students united in protest. But now there are indications that Muslim students will receive financial assistance through the OIC, creating divisions within student ranks.

-- Oloya Aliker Tebere in Dar es Salaam

CAMPUS CLASHES

The University of Ghana has closed its doors indefinitely following two days of clashes between students and police that left two students critically injured and wounded at least 20 others. The worst violence occurred when police forces invaded the campus to disperse students protesting government refusal to increase financial assistance for education.

The conflict complicates an already difficult political climate. Jerry Rawlings, who took power in a 1981 military coup, was elected president last October. But the results were rejected by leading opposition parties.

University students began boycotting classes on March 17 to demand an increase in education loans from $145 to $320 a year. The Ministry of Education, according to student leaders, has rebuffed their calls for negotiation. Leaders of the National Union of Ghana Students maintain that the demonstrations were calm until heavily armed police intervened. Students and teachers say one of the police contingents involved belongs to a special commando unit, called the "Panthers," set up a few years ago to take orders directly from Rawlings.

The last time police fired on students was in 1978, when units invaded the university with tanks and armored vehicles to quell student protests against military rule.

-- Kwame Karikari in Accra


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


NEW APPROACH NEEDED IN SOMALIA


BYLINE: John Prendergast


LENGTH: 1307 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

As the United Nations prepares to take charge of the humanitarian mission in Somalia, precedents for future interventions are being set. It is therefore particularly important that structural problems in the Somali operation be examined.

International response to famines tends to follow a common formula. Food aid comes first, while such considerations as the provision of health care and the resettlement of displaced people are factored in later, if at all. 

In Somalia, such an approach introduces serious problems for the recovery effort. The focus of "Operation Restore Hope" has been the protection of food relief efforts. That priority must be changed. The goal now should be to protect the local production of food supplies, rather than to guard the distribution of imported food.

Continuing to distribute relief through feeding centers and refugee camps simplifies the task of foreign aid workers, but it also promotes dependence and erodes self-reliance. In addition, centralized food distribution centers like those set up in Somalia are breeding grounds for disease and magnets for armed militias. The key to the success of Unosom, the United Nations Operation in Somalia, is a redirection of the aid effort. The country's traditional subsistence economy must be supported, not undermined. Food aid should supplement, not replace, local agriculture and other forms of economic activity.

The first test for Unosom is speedy and efficient restoration of the country's agricultural and pastoral ways of life. Resettlement areas must be militarily secured. Productive farms and pastoral areas should be designated as safe havens and protected by troop deployments and air reconnaissance. Rather than being spread throughout the country, Unosom troops should be concentrated in areas where the most vulnerable groups need protection.

Of Somalia's six major clan groups, the Rahanwayn people probably have suffered the most. Living in a fertile region between the country's two major rivers, the Jubba and the Shabeelle, the Rahanwayn produce much of Somalia's food during normal times. But they and other nearby farming communities long have been politically and culturally subordinated in Somalia's pastoral society. During the civil war they have been subjected to vicious attacks by various militias.

In Somalia last month, I visited half a dozen camps for displaced Rahanwayn. Not one family to whom I spoke had been consulted or contacted about resettlement, although many are eager to return home once security is assured.

Overflights of these farmers' lands reveal an excellent crop in the fields -- but no one is there to harvest it. This guarantees that food relief will be required for at least an additional year.

Livestock, another potential source of food and foreign exchange, is also being neglected. Somalia's population has a higher proportion of pastoralists than any country in Africa, and livestock raising makes good sense in a country of frequent drought and semi-arid terrain. A relatively minor investment could revive the country's herds, but aid advisors generally undervalue this sector and little animal restocking has begun.

In more densely populated southern Somalia, U.S. Army Engineers and Navy Seabees are rebuilding roads, schools and hospitals throughout the area. Money goes fast when it is spent this way. Longer-term benefits could be achieved with locally planned, labor-intensive efforts. More funds should be spent on teaching materials, teachers' salaries and primary health care networks and less on new buildings.

If outside consultants and contractors sponge up the bulk of donated resources, a golden opportunity will be lost. Rehabilitation efforts could play the dual role of creating employment for Somalis while promoting disarmament. Jobs should be offered to Somalis who turn in their guns, providing an attractive alternative to militia membership for the many who joined as a way to survive.

In addition, an emphasis on local reconstruction initiatives and restoration of the subsistence economy could play an important role in political reconciliation. The recent round of peace talks in Ethiopia, which drew representatives from a cross section of Somali groups, resulted in tentative agreement on a government structure based on strong regional representation.

An attempt to build on that process could counter the tendency of international aid efforts to strengthen the richest in society more than protecting the neediest. In Somalia, the rich have gotten richer in several ways. The militias have used their armed might to strip the country of all assets. They have stolen livestock from the defenseless, extracted payoffs from the non-governmental relief organizations, and contracted with aid providers at usurious rates to provide a multitude of services.

The wealthy elite has reaped a harvest of money through currency transactions, illegal trade, transport and construction contracts, and the provision of supplies to troops from the United States and other nations.

In such a situation, a political solution must be built from the local level up -- not from the national level down. Where the U.S. operation initially concentrated on cultivating convenants between the militarily powerful militias, the UN should pursue a vigorous, broader-based diplomatic initiative involving clan elders, women's and community organizations, politicians, and professionals.

Any real progress toward reconstruction also requires drastic reductions in the stock of weapons in Somalia. Allied military forces should be seizing and destroying all guns they can find. They should work with Ethiopian and Kenyan authorities to stop militias from preying upon refugee camps on Somalia's borders. The United Nations should identify arms dealers and prosecute them for violating the UN arms embargo.

A reorientation of Unosom's approach to relief, restoration and reconciliation could yield enhanced prospects for a successful mission in war-weary Somalia. And positive results would demonstrate that humanitarian intervention can successfully save populations at risk of starvation or genocide elsewhere. n

John Prendergast is a research associate at the Center of Concern in Washington, DC, and co-convener of the Coalition for Peace in the Horn of Africa. He recently returned from a five-week trip to Somalia, Sudan and Eritrea.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


WHAT THE WORLD NEEDS NOW...


BYLINE: James P. Grant


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 827 words


DATELINE: Washington, DC


 

In spite of the gravity of the problems we face, I would venture to say that we have made more global human progress in the last 50 years than in the previous 2,000, to the point that three- quarters of the world's population now enjoy the basics of a life of dignity, productivity and health -- progress achieved while much of the world freed itself from colonialism and while respect for human and political rights expanded dramatically.

What we have not seen, however, is the automatic trickling down of economic and technological advances to the world's more than one billion poor. The most obscene manifestation of this failure is the 35,000 child deaths each day, two-thirds from causes now readily preventable at low financial cost.

The problem is not that we have tried to eradicate global poverty or even its worst symptoms and failed; it is that no serious and concerted attempt has ever been made! 

It is now actually possible to provide virtually every man, woman and child on earth with adequate food, clean water, safe sanitation, primary health care, family planning and basic education -- by the end of the century and at an affordable price.

We see this clearly demonstrated in the universal child immunization effort, which, since the mid-1980s, in the largest peacetime collaborative effort in world history, is saving the lives of some 10,000 children a day -- more than 3 million a year. A similar process is now underway with respect to oral rehydration therapy against the single greatest historical killer of children -- dehydration from diarrhea. Our arsenal is now well- stocked with new technologies and rediscovered practices that can be similarly put to scale with inspired leadership and modest additional financial resources.

But if we continue to turn our backs on the plight of the poor, or ask them to wait patiently for better days, we will reap a whirlwind for all humankind -- a political, economic and environmental whirlwind that will shake even the prosperous and long-time democracies to their foundations and condemn us to a new international order of permanent conflict and instability.

What can the United States do, right away, to help lead the

way? Many things, but I will list a few thoughts:

* Few actions would have more immediate impact or symbolic weight than the president's signing of the historic "Bill of Rights" for the world's young -- the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

* The United States' national program of action to implement commitments made at the 1990 World Summit for Children (outlined in a plan issued in November), which apply to children of developing and industrial countries alike, could provide a useful base for initiating bipartisan actions (for a) much-needed reordering of priorities for children, women and families.

* We need (to support) the call issued two years ago by the

United Nations Development Program: first, for developing countries to devote at least 20 percent of their budgets to directly meeting the priority human needs of their people; and second, for 20 percent of all international aid for development to directly support those priority areas of human need -- primary health care, nutrition, basic education, family planning, and safe water and sanitation. (Today, only about ten percent of domestic spending in poor countries and of overseas aid is devoted to such investments.)

* The new spirit of democratic change and economic reform moving in Africa today simply cannot long survive the financial hemorrhage of paying an average $1 billion in debt service to foreign creditors every month for over a decade. Here again, the United States could help lead the way to a solution to the African crisis. Why not have this summer's G-7 Summit (the meeting of the seven most-industrialized nations) definitively address African debt, with much of the local currency proceeds going to accelerate programs for children, women and the environment? n

This article is excerpted from an address by James P. Grant, executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef), to the International Development Conference in Washington, DC


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


MOROCCAN BEAUTIES


LENGTH: 160 words


 

For at least half a century, Morocco has exercised an exotic pull on American imaginations. Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman made the name Casablanca synonomous with romance and intrigue. Crosby, Stills and Nash took the Marrakesh Express, and young, hip travelers flocked there. Literary colonies flourished in Tangiers on the Mediterranean coast. And one of Club Med's most popular resorts is on the beach at Agadir.

Among the attractions is the country's imposing physical beauty. Ski trails snaking down the Atlas mountains. Undulating fields framed by blue hills. Secluded gardens behind intricately carved doors. Long, craggy coastlines. Vast expanses of desert. It's not surprising that visitors to Morocco begin plotting their returns even before they leave. n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


TRAVEL: WEST AFRICA EN FAMILLE A car trip with two children down Africa's democracy road.


BYLINE: Howard W. French for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 2160 words


DATELINE: Miami, FL


 

To renew my fond acquaintance with an area I had lived in for nearly seven years, I recently set out with my family on a drive from Cote d'Ivoire (formerly called the Ivory Coast) across Togo and back.

There are few experiences that offer as accurate a barometer of African life as a long road trip these days, and our jaunt fully lived up to our expectations.

It is one thing to read from afar about the transformation of a region from plodding and paternalistic authoritarianism to dynamic, if still uncertain, democracy.

It is quite another to see what only recently would have been unimaginable changes firsthand and yet to realize that so much more must be done before any of the countries of the region can be said to have laid a solid foundation for its future.

Abidjan, the glittering economic capital of Cote d'Ivoire, has

always captured the contradictions of the region: a fast-paced and modern metropolis in a country whose economy rests on the antiquated pillars of coffee and cocoa. With its ever-spreading network of expressways and overpasses, the city appears to defy the country's stark economic crisis. It remains something of a consumerist boom town in a country where villagers are still more than likely to be illiterate and without access to even basic modern health care. 

These days, the Pearl of the Lagoons, as Abidjan is called in tourist brochures has added another contradiction. There are few places on the continent where democracy is discussed with as much openness and vigor as here, and yet all of the hoopla seems to end abruptly at the gates of the city.

Maybe this is because the opposition newspapers that have sprung up like wild mushrooms have never really penetrated the rural world, where reading and the disposable income that helps create the newspaper habit are, if not rare, still marks of distinction.

The government, cleverly, has been much slower in relinquishing control over the airwaves, knowing that news transmitted orally is by far the most readily accessible. If Abidjan is the effervescent center of political contention, le pays profond, still belongs, by mostly dexterous coercion, to Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the aging president who sometimes likes to be called the country's "First Peasant," to signal his attachment to the rural world and it to him.

It isn't necessary to travel very far past Port-Bouet, at the edge of the city, to see that, beyond this fondness, what helps to hold the "deep country" in check is a system of almost feudal control over the lives of the peasants.

Whereas Abidjanais are now freer than ever to denounce, to complain, to critique and to challenge, the peasantry are subject to the near-absolute law of petty officials, from prefect to soldier to gendarme.

The road to Ghana, like roads in every region of the country, are cluttered with roadblocks where, under pretense of halting illegal immigration and looking for wanted criminals, officials have perfected an arbitrary tax system whose purpose is only to fill their pockets.

Corn or cassava, musical cassettes or cement, whatever the cargo, the official exacts his cut.

"These men have made our life impossible, "said Manzan, a 30-ish woman we passed going the other way as she returned from a bus trip to Nigeria to buy trading goods. "They have no heart for anyone but their own families. Face to face, they will tell me that how we feed ours is not their problem."

The trader, whose impressive entrepreneurship is the kind that -- constructively harnessed -- would make this region truly blossom, had just been levied half of her varied cargo.

We had our first personal run-in with this highway robbery at the frontier with Ghana. The Ivorian side, once a model of order in keeping with the country's official image of itself -- more modern, better structured, more French than its neighbors -- now is a picture of larcenous chaos.

Amid a cacophony of traders with their tins and small trays of wares, women with large cloth bundles of food and secreted goods, fixers who promised an easy crossing and police agents on the prowl for a good take (occasionally raising a whip to subdue the pressing crowds), we tried to stick to the letter of the law.

After presenting all of our papers, both personal and those for our borrowed vehicle, the red-eyed agent looked incredulous. "What? No bribe?" his expression seemed to say. An older policeman, a veteran of these things whispered in my ear to "make a gesture." I feigned not to understand.

For this incomprehension, we were not allowed passage until the next morning, when a fresh set of guards were manning the crossing, their nerves still unjangled by the heat and the din.

In the old days in this region, for me, anyway, crossing into Ghana from anywhere used to be considered one of the more arduous travel experiences. The muddle that infects the Ivorian side these days was typical of the Ghanaian side of the border on good days back then.

I like to imagine that the changes at the border in Ghana, where the proceedings had an almost otherworldly orderliness to them during our crossings, reflect the growing confidence of a country that is emerging from a long schizophrenic nightmare of alternating rounds of dictatorship and anarchy, which sometimes coincided. Ghana seems finally on the brink to fulfilling some of its considerable potential.

There is less strident talk of democracy in Ghana than in its showier neighbor, Cote d'Ivoire. One gets a feeling, instead, of a more mature realization of both the costs and benefits of the individual responsibility that a functioning democracy implies.

At the border crossing at Elubo, Mike Oppong, a veteran immigration officer spoke with pride of the way things are being straightened out in his administration. Asked if this meant that agents made less money in the past, when rules were invented on

the fly and bribery was brazenly open, he said: "We can live with our earnings better now because we have a clearer conscience. This is the only way Ghana will ever go forward."

All is not roses yet in Ghana, to be sure. In Noe, a sea- hugging village that lives from fishing and the harvesting of its graceful oil palms, a man in his mid 50s has recently returned, disillusioned from a lengthy career of journalism in the capital, to farm and to teach.

"What we practice in this country cannot yet be called journalism," said the farmer, who asked that his name not be used. "If you write what a politician said and he doesn't like it, he will deny he said it. If you contradict him in print, then you have problems. This is not yet what I would call freedom."

Down the road a ways, under a darkening sky and a shared meal of smoked fish and fried yams, a young engineer, sharp of mind, speaks wryly of the frustrations of trying to find decent work in the country.

"I cannot start a family now, although I am at an age where I would like to do so, " he says. "Jerry Rawlings (the Ghanaian president) has done a lot to lift the country up, but for ordinary people, life has only gotten harder."

Everywhere, in fact, as Ghana puts in new roads to replace the seemingly battle-scarred highways of old, and erects modern buildings to crowd out the colonial vintage architecture that still

dominates most towns, the story has this ring to it: yes, things have gotten better, but life has not gotten easier.

While Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana represent contrasting economic examples -- the first easing its way down from its once haughty plateau of imagined affluence, the other searching for a formula to continue its recent rise -- both are struggling with new democratic realities. But on the other side of Ghana, Togo stands, along with Liberia, as an example of the West African version of a descent into hell.

Having our small children along was not a cause for parental concern in most of the places we went, but to drive through Togo today is to run a gauntlet of nightmares.

In the wake of last year's violent suppression of a civilian administration by the army, in a struggle between military rule and a pro-democracy movement, there is little functioning government left. Little Togo, once considered by many to be one of the most charming countries on the continent, has become one of the most brutal and unpredictable.

Every few miles, at a rhythm far exceeding anything I've seen elsewhere since the last days of the notorious dictator Milton Obote in Uganda, anyone on the road is subject to a roadblock check that often amounts to armed holdup.

The border crossing between Ghana and the Togolese capital of Lome has a fevered buzz to it, the kind of nervous bustling feeling of a place where people are frantically stocking goods for an impending catastrophe.

Nothing particular was going on in the country while we were there, except the everyday anxieties that keep the streets mostly empty by day and completely barren by night.

We chose not to stop in Lome, a city I used to look forward to having an excuse to visit. Instead, we continued across Togo, figuring that on the way back we would take a route through the country's rural midlands. The idea was that by avoiding the ambient ill-ease of the capital, we could reduce the anxieties of the journey.

We were wrong. The way back was tortured and harrowing. The armed groups we encountered on the road, alternately pro- and anti- "government," were often drunk and almost always abusive. On several occasions, guns were pointed menacingly, bags ripped open and threats made. Only a practiced nonchalance, an understated compliance and, perhaps most importantly, the surprisingly good grace and humor of my wife and children got us through.

Toward the end of a day-long drive, however, as we neared the Ghana border in the cool mountainous hills west of Kpalime, the trying experience was capped by car failure.

With a night sky descending on us and a broken car stuck on an isolated mountain road, I silently prepared my mind for the worst.

Instead, in the kind of experience I have had over and over again that each time strengthens my faith in the people of the continent, a carload of men who were going the other direction finally showed up just at dark. They stopped, inquired about our difficulty, and took it upon themselves to go find the needed parts and then returned to help us fix the car and be on our way. n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


TRAVEL: "REALITY TOURS" OFFER A NEW WAY TO SEE THE WORLD A conversation with Kevin Danaher of Global Exchange, a San Francisco-based organization that promotes public education in global issues.


SECTION: CULTURE/LIFESTYLE


LENGTH: 2014 words


 

AfricaNews: Global Exchange runs tours with a difference. It's not an ordinary travel agency, but it also isn't alone in the field, is it? It's part of a growing phenomenon.

Danaher: There is a movement. It's usually referred to as socially responsible tourism. There's a whole branch that focuses on environmental tourism. It all comes out of '60s and '70s people who grew up and got educated, and we started traveling around and realized that other cultures have so much to teach us.

AN: Do you have a point of view -- a world view, if you will -- that you're trying to promote? 

Danaher: What we say to our people is, "Look, we don't have a dogma or an agenda that we want to convince you of. We just want to expose you and open you up to this experience and see how it affects you. Just be open minded, and we're so convinced that it will affect you that we don't have to ram it down your throat." We don't try to avoid unpleasantness or controversy or differing opinions among the people we meet on our trips. We have confidence in our own people's basic wisdom. I think one of the problems with mainstream education and the mass media is that it's overly filtered, and people are not exposed to a broad enough range of what's out there. So we try to immerse the members of our tours in all the complexity and rely on their innate wisdom to be able to sort it out.

AN: Describe your reality tours to Africa. What are they, what happens on them and what sort of people go?

Danaher: We try to do broad outreach, and we include in that a scholarship fund.

We're particularly interested in sending African Americans, community organizers and people who are going to use the experience well when they come home. We give them a good orientation so they know what to expect when they get there. And then on the trip, we're focused less on your standard tourism of seeing the sites -- the big waterfalls and the animals and that kind of Tarzan image of Africa -- and more on introducing people to the community groups, to the grass-roots organizations that we think

are the future of Africa: the women's groups, the community development organizations, the peasant organizations that are really transforming the face of Africa.

AN: What do you mean when you say you want to take people who will use the experience well when they come back home, and how do you encourage that process?

Danaher: We provide them with suggestions, based on our own experiences and the experiences of other people who have traveled and come back and done public education. We give them a list of ways in which they can share what they've learned. It's very effective if you've just come back from a trip to Senegal or South Africa and you see an article in the newspaper, to write a letter to the editor and say, "Well, I was just there, and I can tell you that what I saw did or did not match up with what was in your article."

Also, there are plenty of schools, colleges and radio stations around the country constantly looking for speakers with direct experience of the countries in question. So we try to give some ideas of how to address public audiences.

And, we try to share ideas about fund raising because one of the problems with doing nonprofit work, educational work, is where to find the money. For example, there is an inner-city high-school group in Seattle that takes 30 or 40 students to East Africa each summer. They fund it basically in one weekend of fund-raising activity. Each student gets a sponsor and the students gather one weekend and clean up the shoreline of Lake Washington. So they make the linkage between environmental cleanup work here in the United States -- which is something pretty much everybody can support -- and, on the other hand, something on the other side of the planet going on in Africa. These students really get changed by the experience of not just going to Africa, but of earning their own way.

AN: All these things sound wonderful, but what's wrong with just going to see beautiful waterfalls or rare animals?

Danaher: Well, I'm a nature lover myself, so there is a part of me that says, "Yeah, there's nothing wrong with going to see a waterfall and animals." And on our trips, we always make time for people to go off and do "touristy" things. But given the emergency situation in Africa, and given the ability of the United States to do something about it, and given our responsibility for the cold war manipulations that supported dictators and prevented democracy in so many countries, I think we really owe it to the African people to do a little pay-back work.

We're not suggesting taking the load of Africa on our backs, but just educating Americans so they understand what's going on; so they understand why you have anarchy in a country like Somalia or Zaire and how it's related to the history of U.S. foreign policy.

I think one thing good that we've seen about our reality tours is that once people go to Africa and meet Africans, and have sat down with them and shared meals with them, then it's very difficult to ignore the news reports about starving children and crisis and emergency. The experience pushes them in the direction of taking some responsibility for what's going on. Not responsibility for what Africans need to fix, but for what we need to fix in terms of our institutions and their involvement in Africa.

AN: What do your folks come back from their experiences thinking that Americans can do?

Danaher: Well, you get a broad range of reactions when people come back. For example, we had a minister on one of our trips. She came back and immediately got involved with her church, and with the larger associations that her church was part of, to try to educate them about what was going on in Africa. She had come across a lot of really good groups that wanted to have some kind of formal linkage with groups in the United States for ongoing activity. She pursued those quite successfully.

I think one of the problems is that we focus too much on government policy. It's good to try to change U.S. government policy, but I think we also need to work in schools and churches and professional associations and trade unions -- the organizations that are out here in each of our communities, where we can have a more direct impact.

That's one of the things that we at Global Exchange call

"grass-roots internationalism": trying to promote the direct linking of community-based organizations in Africa with community-based organizations in the U.S. -- a sister school or a sister church or some other kind of linkage.

AN: When you take people on reality tours, how does it affect the widespread perception of Americans that Africa is nothing but a disaster area?

Danaher: We try to ensure that people get a range of experience. On one trip to Mozambique, we visited a refugee transit center that was one of the most heartbreaking experiences you could ever imagine. There were people who were literally holding their children and watching them die from hunger and hunger- related diseases, because their homes had been attacked by guerrillas supported by South Africa. Leaving that place on the bus, the entire group was absolutely silent. We were struck dumb by the horror of it all.

Within a few days we were at a cooperative on the outskirts of Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. Before we even get off the bus, a group of singing and dancing women come out, take us into their co-op, show us lush fields that they have constructed out of nothing, buildings they have built, pig production operations they have set up, all sorts of educational projects going on. Things that they have done largely on their own -- with some foreign assistance and some guidance from non-governmental agencies but largely through their own efforts. Our group came away from that saying, "Wow! These people, given a chance, can make it. They can get organized and change their reality."

So I think visiting Americans need to realize that Africa is just as complex as the United States or any other society. Africa has everything from the horrible to the wonderful.

Our Western definition of development has always been that the quantity of things you have determines how high you are on the development ladder. You spend time in Africa, and you realize that development should not be measured in the quantity of things but in the quality of social relations. So people who get to know Africans and African communities learn that there are a lot of ways in which African cultures are more advanced than ours. They have things that we don't have, things that we've lost or that have been destroyed, that we need to regain.

AN: So do people come back from reality tours hopeful about Africa's future?

Danaher: I think they come back with very mixed emotions. On all of our tours, wherever we go, we always have a debriefing

session where we ask people specific questions: What was your greatest insight? What was your high point? What was your low point? What are you going to do to spread the messages that you've learned when you get back to the United States?

People say, "I was heartbroken and I was distressed, but I came away hopeful for the future because I saw people in conditions of great destitution still managing to hold their head up."

When you meet people who don't have shoes, they're so poor, and yet they stand up straight and they look you in the eye and they speak with dignity, you get Americans to realize it's not about what you own, it's about what you possess inside you. Most Americans know people in this country who own quite a lot of things but have lost their self-respect and dignity and, in fact, are very poor people. So it's good to force people to ask basic questions about what it really means to be a human being? What is the definition of development? And where are we going here in the United States? n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


ANGOLAN WAR SPAWNS COMPLEX WEB OF PROFITEERS Fierce, deadly conflict continues.


BYLINE: Victoria Brittain * INSIGHT/Guardian News Service


LENGTH: 1907 words


DATELINE: London/Johannesburg/Harare


 

For three decades, East/West rivalry fed warfare in Angola. During the colonial era, independence movements received backing from the Soviet Union and China, while Portugal remained allied with the West. Since independence in 1975, the United States and the Soviet Union lined up on opposite sides, providing the warring parties with sophisticated weaponry.

A peace pact signed in 1991 barred any further lethal support from the two superpowers and from South Africa, which has played an active military role in Angola since 1975. The accord led to elections in Angola last September, but disagreement over the results has plunged the country back into conflict. In one of the largest battles ever waged in Angola, government troops last month were forced to withdraw from Huambo, Angola's second largest city and headquarters for the opposition movement Unita. An estimated 15,000 people died during the battle, and thousands are now suffering from starvation and disease, unreachable by relief efforts.

The Angolan government, formerly backed by the Soviet Union and Cuba, says its adversary, Unita, is up to old tricks. A massive resupply operation is being staged from South Africa, the government claims. South Africa was Unita's largest supporter during the civil war, although U.S. covert assistance totaling over $300 million from 1985 to 1991 was a critical element in Unita's ability to wage effective war. 

Unita and South Africa deny the accusations, and Unita says it is the government that is employing South African mercenaries. The government-controlled oil company, Sonangol, has hired 100 former members of the South African military to protect oil installations from Unita attacks. Those soldiers reportedly played a key role in the recapture by government forces of the oil-producing town of Soyo early last month.

But the head of the South African security operation has denied his men are mercenaries, as they have been portrayed in the South African press. "It is totally untrue," Buks Buys said in an interview with Namibian television. "We have been hired by a legitimate oil company." Buys said he was dismayed by the actions of Unita forces in Soyo, who he accused of brutality against the civilian population. "This is not the Unita I knew," he said. "These are bandits."

Unita leader Jonas Savimbi, who rejected the results of the September voting as fraudulent, has now agreed to return to United Nations-sponsored peace talks. But no cease-fire has been agreed, and more fighting is expected. Unita has weapons and other materiel left over from the earlier phase of the war, but the movement needs fuel and other supplies to maintain its fighting strength.

An investigation by the British newspaper, the Guardian, has turned up clues that support the allegations that Unita's lifeline, once again, comes from the south.

* * * *

Three white South African mercenaries, wounded while fighting for Unita in Huambo, were flown out of Angola last month to a private clinic in Windhoek, the Namibian capital, south of Angola. From Windhoek, they were airlifted secretly to South Africa, according to officials in Angola and Namibia.

This new evidence of South African involvement in the symbolic centerpiece battle of the Angolan war confirms reports from Angolan military sources of a vast resupply and logistics support to Unita.

The three men were part of a 100-strong force of former South African soldiers who were recruited by a security consultant in Pretoria, South Africa, to guards oil installations in Angola.

Eeben Barlow, of Executive Outcomes, who organized the operation, confirmed in an interview that the men were part of his group. But he insisted that they were security guards, not mercenaries. However, senior Angolan sources said the men were picked up south of Huambo, hundreds of miles from the Angolan oil fields.

The war now threatens to spill over into a new theater where South African involvement would be even more embarrassing. Unita leader Jonas Savimbi has threatened to attack two dams on the southern border, striking a severe economic blow against Namibia, which won independence from South African rule in 1990.

The Angolan government says the mercenaries fighting for Unita in Angola are former members of South African units that fought in Angola during the 1980s and were officially demobilized earlier this year.

The three wounded men -- Nico Bosman, Hermanus Ferreira and Geoffrey Landsberg, accompanied by a South African doctor -- were flown out of Angola through Zaire in a plane that has been used recently on illegal night flights into Angola. The clinic where the three men were kept, Westair, the company that owns the plane, and Propilot, the company that leased it, all share the same lawyer, according to officials in Namibia.

Exemplary of the complex, sometimes contradictory relationships in the Angolan conflict is that Westair has made flights into Angola for the United Nations, and Propilot ferried the South African security attachment to Soyo for the government oil company.

An interlocking network of small companies that can be traced back to the Johannesburg-based SA Bias group has been acting as contractor for buying strategic relief supplies and airlifting them into Unita territory. This business group has defense industry connections.

A seven-year-old German relief agency, called Hilfe in Not, which has been active in Unita support activity, has mounted a public fundraising drive for Angola. After last year's elections, the agency produced a minority report for the German government, one of its funders, which rejected the view of the United Nations and other international observers that the voting was generally free and fair.

The German agency forms part of an extensive network of right-wing organizations linked to the South African government. A key part of the network has been a company called Strategy Network International, set up in the 1980s by Sean Cleary, a former South African diplomat who once served in Washington. Cleary's group spearheaded the 1989 election campaign in Namibia for pro- South African politicians running against the Namibian independence movement, Swapo.

Subsequent investigations in South Africa have revealed that the anti-Swapo effort was the first part of "Operation Agree," a complex secret strategy by South African military intelligence designed to preserve South African economic dominance of the southern African region. Support for Unita in Angola's elections was the second phase of "Operation Agree," according to a former intelligence officer, Nico Basson, who gave extensive testimony during the investigation.

Dietrich Kantel, head of Hilfe in Not, says his group is not involved in military backing and is supplying only humanitarian relief. He says an estimated 500,000 people in Cuando Cubango -- the heart of Unita territory -- are in danger of starvation.

From October to mid-February, Hilfe in Not has been sending freelance airlifts into southern Angola from the Namibian capital, Windhoek, using a private operator, Namibian Commercial Aviation. But the Angolan government asked the Namibian government to stop the flights because of suspicions that they are being used to ferry military equipment. Hilfe in Not's Kantel says that he is now using a contracting firm in the Zimbabwe capital to buy and ship corn.

Chris Schutte, the head of Namibian Commercial Aviation,

said in an interview: "The Angolans thought we were flying in weapons. That's all propaganda. We had an 18-month contract starting last April through Hilfe in Not, which we were trying to fulfill. We were taking in maize and seeds before the harvests."

Namibia, Zimbabwe and Botswana all have complained of violations of their airspace by planes flying into Angola from South Africa. South African Foreign Minister Roelof 'Pik' Botha has denied the allegations repeatedly, but South African Foreign Ministry sources have conceded that covert cargoes of food, medical supplies, fuel and weapons were "more than likely" finding their way to Unita.

One of the airports that South African officials acknowledge is not adequately secured to prevent unauthorized flights is Wonderboom, near Pretoria. The charter company Wonder Air has been named by the Angolan government as having flown supplies to Unita from Wonderboom on a nightly basis throughout November and December.

A South African connection with Schutte's company in Namibia has emerged from an invoice for a shipment of unidentified goods ferried by Namibian Commercial Aviation last December from Agra Mills, a white-run farming cooperative in northern Namibia, to the Angolan border town of Macusso.

The invoice shows that the contractor was Merchant International Trading, Inc. (MITI) of London. Company records show MITI shares offices, directors and shareholders with six other British-registered companies. A spokesman for MITI, who refused to give his name, confirmed that the companies were related. The principal one is Merchant Trade Finance, an investment arm of SA Bias, the South African conglomerate involved in the Unita relief operation. Christopher Seabrooke, who heads SA Bias, confirmed that his company has done business with Hilfe in Not. n

With files from David Pallister and David Beresford.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


SANDS OF TIME RUNNING OUT AS AFRICA'S DESERTS ADVANCE Current efforts to tackle the problem could ease poverty and slow global warming. London


BYLINE: Pratap Chatterjee * INSIGHT/Guardian News Service


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

A dozen experts have been meeting this month in Geneva, the nerve center of last year's Earth Summit preparations. The aim of the meeting, like all those who are organizing follow-up strategies and actions inspired by the summit, is vast. The group means to stop the spread of the world's deserts -- if not literally by holding back the sands, then by setting out the policy alternatives that would enable governments to cope with the problems of poverty that desertification brings.

For the few hundred inhabitants of Gidan Kaura, in the northern Nigerian state of Sokoto, the attention will be welcome. Six years ago they had to leave their homeland when the sands of the Sahara swept remorselessly into their houses. The Sokoto Environmental Protection Agency says that the Nigerian desert is advancing three miles (about five kilometers) a year. 

One of the first problems negotiators must face is that scientists are split about whether deserts are advancing at all. Ulf Helden and other researchers at the University of Lund in Sweden have examined thousands of satellite photographs which show, they say, that the desert is merely changing shape.

The man who will try to bridge the two viewpoints is also a Swede. Bo Kjellen, a diplomat who took part in the Earth Summit negotiations, was pitted against Helden in a debate in Lund last month. In the confrontation, he forced Helden to agree that scientific controversies about long-term geo-climatic trends are irrelevant to people facing famine. But Kjellen is not hopeful that the experts in Geneva will come up with much in the way of minimum agreements. He thinks that the most that can be expected from the sessions is that the planners will be in a position to offer government negotiators realistic options when world officials meet in Nairobi, Kenya, in May to start detailed work on a global environmental treaty. The United Nations wants a document ready for signing in Paris in June 1994.

"We are talking about the problems of land management for 900 million people," Kjellen says. "There are clear relationships between development and environment, with poverty right at the center."

One of the challenges, environmentalists say, is that poverty is more than a scientific issue that can be solved with new laboratory-designed programs. The issue of how to eradicate poverty extends to the question of who has control over land and financial resources. In many parts of Africa, for instance, most agricultural work is done by women, but government extension services, practical assistance and technical cooperation money is dispensed to men.

A second chance. This is not the first time the UN has tried to tackle the world's deserts. In 1977 it adopted a "plan of action" to stop desertification. After 15 years, the effort is acknowledged as a complete failure.

The Nairobi-based UN Environment Programme (Unep) says the plan failed because it tried to apply technical solutions to socio-economic and socio-political problems, it did not include local populations in drawing up solutions, and it failed to integrate environmental programs into other development strategies. Unep also cites the low priority given to desert areas by funding agencies.

Meanwhile, the global problems of land degradation and the dwindling of water supplies is worsening rapidly in Africa. Swedish hydrologist Malin Falkenmark, who is on Unep's scientific and technical advisory panel, says that one country, Tunisia, is now

beyond what she calls the "water barrier": it has less than the bare minimum of 500 cubic meters of water per person per year. By the end of the century, Falkenmark predicts, 11 African countries with a total population of 250 million people will share that status, and by 2025 the number of countries with water emergencies could rise to 1.1 billion people -- two-thirds of the continent's projected population. Already the movement of deserts threatens four-fifths of sub-Saharan Africa's dry lands and range lands -- about 5.8 million square miles.

The UN convention on desertification will try to tackle the fundamental causes of dwindling water supplies, such as the loss of plant cover, which means that less water is released into the atmosphere, reducing the chance of rain. The barren lands also reflect sunlight, heating up the atmosphere and dispersing rain clouds that do form. Dust storms may exacerbate this effect by causing sunlight to be reflected even more harshly off clouds of dust into the sky.

But the puzzle of how plant cover is lost has spawned another controversy. There are three theories about which is the major cause -- long-term global warming, short-term drought and human activity -- although everyone agrees that the answer is some combination of the three.

The debate over whether the planet is warming will not be settled by the experts meeting in Geneva, although their colleagues who are working on the Climate Change Convention that was signed in Rio have their own special panel to look at desertification. Short-term drought is an accepted fact of African life, however, and Saharan and other African herders have adapted to the phenomenon by developing a nomadic lifestyle.

The impact of human activity is more complicated to assess. Governments often accuse poor people who live on the margins of deserts of destroying their land by cutting down the area's last few trees for fuel. Others say the real problem is inappropriate government development plans that have forced poor people into situations where they have no options.

Political support needed. Experts are aware that the proposed Convention will not be enough, in itself, to halt desert

advance: Even if the proposed pact offers incentives for governments, it would be unlikely to offer direct benefits for many people in the Sahara.

For example, the Tuareg people who have led a nomadic life for centuries on marginal lands of Africa's Sahel region are now fighting for survival in the countries that were created by colonization -- Algeria, Burkina Faso, Libya, Mali and Niger. Many of the traditional grazing lands have been taken over for use in externally funded development projects, which plant the areas in crops like peanuts for export to European markets. As a result, nomads have been forced further into the desert itself. And bad farming techniques, which too often characterize the projects, slowly are destroying the old lands, turning them, too, into desert.

Kjellen says that the attempt to create a global coalition to tackle the problem of encroaching deserts is important in itself, but that it also could pave the way for cooperation on a whole range of issues important to every country's well being. "I see the effort as a genuine partnership," he says. "If, in doing this, African countries get the feeling that the international community is more responsive to their particular problems, it could have an impact on some other matters in the future. My reading of the African attitudes in the negotiations in Rio was that the question of desertification took on a symbolic value for them." n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


BRIEFING


SECTION: NEWS BRIEFS


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

FIRST VISIT

Nigeria last month became the first African nation to send a top-level delegation on an official visit to Washington since President Clinton took office. "It's appropriate for the first one to be from the continent's most populous country," said a senior State Department official after talks last month with the head of Nigeria's transitional council, Ernest E.A. Shonekan.

A prominent lawyer and business executive, Shonekan was tapped late last year to head a ruling interim administration, which will serve until an elected president is inaugurated in August. Shonekan, leading an entourage, which included the ministers of foreign affairs and petroleum and the attorney general, had meetings with Vice President Al Gore, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and Deputy Secretary of State Clifford Wharton. 

In the discussions, Shonekan briefed American officials on Nigeria's election process. He also emphasized the need for relief from the substantial debt burden the civilian administration will inherit.

QUICK SWITCH

President Bill Clinton, in a statement last week, said that J. Brian Atwood -- who was nominated earlier as undersecretary of State for management -- instead has been tapped to head the Agency for International Development (AID). Atwood, who has been on the job at State pending his confirmation, will give the Clinton administration a trusted ally at the aid agency. Clinton's announcement said that Atwood's "proven effectiveness and his commitment to democratic change make him an ideal choice."

There has been intense jockeying for position among potential candidates for the AID job, a level of interest that is reported to have surprised Clinton. In recent weeks, members of Congress have expressed frustration at the delay in appointing a leader for the agency, which is expected to figure prominently in the debate over foreign aid in the post-Cold War world.

Atwood, who was an influential member of the Clinton transition team, has been president of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs since 1985. He served in the State Department under Cyrus Vance and Edmund Muskie, was a dean at the Foreign Service Institute, and has been a foreign service officer, including a stint at the American Embassy in Cote d'Ivoire.

SCREENING

A feature film by Zimbabwe director Godwin Mawuru is in Washington, DC, for a one-week run at the Biograph Theatre beginning April 9. Called "Neria," the movie is a project of the Media for Development Trust. Before final editing, the film, made in Zimbabwe with a local cast, was screened in several African countries to judge audience reaction. Filmmakers say they wanted to see if the picture's strong women's rights message got through to the public. Director Mawuru says the theme is one that is close to his heart because his father died when he was a child, and laws that refused to recognize womens' inheritance rights left the family destitute.

In recent years, Mawuru's country has become a popular site for shooting films. The current Disney movie, "A Far Off Place," was made on location in Zimbabwe.

TRAILBLAZER

A woman from the West African nation of Sierra Leone has become the first United Methodist cleric outside the United States to be given the status of chaplain by the denomination's Division of Chaplains and Related Ministries.

The Rev. Muriel Alice Fitzjohn, who also is married to a United Methodist minister, is an educator and former youth worker who serves as a chaplain in health care facilities. Fitzjohn, who is 67, is thought to be the oldest woman to receive the chaplaincy endorsement.

AFRICA MAKES NEWS

A book on media images of Africa has won the 1992 Sigma Delta Chi award from the Society of Professional Journalists. Africa's Media Image, edited by Beverly Hawk and published by Greenwood Publishing Group, was honored for its "important contribution to research on American journalism." The judges said that Hawk's work in compiling the "wide-ranging collection of essays" illuminated the debate on media coverage of Africa and the effects of coverage on American views of the continent. (Africa News Service Executive Editor Tami Hultman contributed a chapter to the book.)

The journalism society, which has 16,000 members, has presented annual Sigma Delta Chi awards since 1932.

SISTERHOOD IS POWERFUL

Women representing over 25 organizations in the United States have signed a letter of support for the South African Women's Charter. The gesture, coordinated by the New York-based Africa Fund, follows the launch on March 8 of the Women's Charter Campaign -- an effort to ensure that the issue of rights for women be injected into debates on a new South African constitution and bill of rights.

Among the support letter's signers are Colorado congresswoman Patricia Schroeder; National Organization for Women President Patricia Ireland; Dorothy Height, president of the National Council of Negro Women; Joyce Miller, president of the Coalition of Labor Union Women; and Joan B. Campbell, general secretary of the National Council of Churches USA. The National Council of Jewish Women signed as a group.

The charter campaign is being waged by the Women's National Coalition, a group that draws from over 50 South African organizations including political parties, church groups, business and professional organizations, and non-governmental organizations. The coalition is thought to be the most broadly based organization working in South Africa today. In addition to the 50 national organizations the campaign members represent, the effort has drawn support from hundreds of local and regional groups.

Although the campaign's program is multifaceted, its slogan

is simple: South Africa will not be free until its women are free.
