53 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


THE 'OTHER SOMALIA' PURSUES INDEPENDENT TRAIL Berbera, Somalia


BYLINE: Jonathan Ewing for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Hussain Ibrahim is a livestock exporter who has lived in this dusty port city for nearly 20 years. After surviving the near total destruction of the bloody civil war, he is struggling to restart his business and resume sales of sheep, goats and cattle to nearby countries.

Berbera, where temperatures sometimes climb to 135 degrees Fahrenheit, was once a centerpiece in the hot East/West competition for this region of the world. The Soviet Union built a naval facility here, which the United States took over when the two superpowers swapped client states in the late 1970s. 

"The town is roofless," Ibrahim observes, looking out across the low, brown buildings that make up the area around the docks. Tin and almost anything else that was removable were looted during intense fighting against the dictatorship of Mohammed Siad Barre, who finally was ousted in late 1990.

"It hasn't been easy -- none of us here are rich, and we're all working hard to earn a living," says Ibrahim. "But we're doing a lot better than those people in the south."

During 1990, the north of Somalia declared independence from the rest of the country and assumed the name Somaliland. An assembly of political and clan leaders set up an interim government, headed by Abdurahman Ahmed Ali Tour, a leader of the campaign against Siad Barre. The fighting ended, and the territory escaped the ravages of war and clan fighting that has brought such destruction to the south, where an American-led intervention force has mounted a massive relief operation to save thousands of starving people.

Peace and Food Exports. Throughout Somaliland, popular support for independence seems widespread. The mood is optimistic. In Berbera and in Hargeisa, the capital, one can walk peacefully through kiosk-lined streets where vendors sell all manner of merchandise.

Agricultural and livestock production are in evidence. This year, Somaliland has grown sufficient rice, sorghum and wheat to export to neighboring Djibouti and Saudi Arabia. Meat is being sold to Yemen and Saudi Arabia.

Somaliland was not made as destitute by war and drought as was Somalia, says Mark Stirling, regional representative for Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund. A "semblance of social order" was retained, and agricultural reserves were not totally depleted in the north as they have been in the south, Stirling says.

People in both regions have been plagued by long-term poverty. Life expectancy was only about 47 years and literacy about 40 percent even before the war began. During the Siad Barre years, the ratio of government spending on military compared to social needs was a staggering 500-to-one.

Somaliland still feels the burdens of those military outlays. According to Interior Minister Saeed Mohamed Noor, some one million land mines were planted during Siad Barre's rule. Gen. Mohammed Siad Morgan, one of the warlords causing difficulties in the south, was military governor of the north when most of the mines were laid, Noor says.

Somaliland has its own ethnic rivalries and regional tensions, which the interim government is trying to resolve. Representatives from all clans have been meeting recently to draft a formal constitution and lay the groundwork for elections.

Development Aid, Not Relief. The United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) is assisting with the development of an agricultural plan that is compatible with local needs and resources. To promote efficient cultivation of fields for crops, the FAO this month imported 200 head of cattle for sale to merchants who, in turn, will sell them to farmers. Cows are a cheap alternative to tractors and don't require tough-to-find spare parts, UN officials say.

Care International is coordinating a food program designed to strengthen rather than compete with the local economy. Food is being sold on the open market -- not distributed for free -- in an effort to create a stable market price and combat inflation. "A goat, which traded for 60 kilograms (132 pounds) of wheat 18 months ago, now sells for 40 kilograms (88 pounds)," says John Buttery of Save the Children, United Kingdom.

Despite the progress, the interim government is still struggling to assert its authority and establish an economic program. Riots broke out last year in Berbera when authorities tried to collect taxes needed to finance government activities.

The government backed down, and merchants seem intent on resisting any further taxation effort. "I see no reason to give money that was hard-won by me," says Hussain Ibrahim. "If I must fight over this, I will. God willing, I will win." n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


CAMEROON POLICE KILL PROTESTERS Opposition coalition presses demand for national democracy conference. Yaounde, Cameroon


BYLINE: Derald Everhart for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

At the end of March, police opened fire on political opposition marchers in the city of Bamenda, killing two people and wounding at least 27 others.

The shootings came just two days after the Cameroon government announced "a grand debate" on constitutional reform, a key opposition demand. The demonstration was the second of three weekly protest marches called by opposition leader, Ni John Fru Ndi, to protest "the people's stolen victory of October 11."

Fru Ndi is the chairman of the Bamenda-based Social Democratic Front party and head of a coalition -- the Union for Change -- that is attempting to pressure the government of President Paul Biya to hold new presidential elections under international supervision. 

A bookseller from Bamenda, Fru Ndi maintains he won the October 11 presidential election, but that Biya supporters manipulated the vote totals to give the victory to Biya. Official government figures give Biya 39 percent of the 3 million votes cast and Fru Ndi second place with 36 percent.

The government scheduled the balloting after a two-year campaign by a growing pro-democracy movement, which called strikes and stay-at-homes that left streets and businesses deserted for weeks at a time in many cities and towns.

Eyewitness accounts of the recent shootings indicate that police opened fire after a crowd -- estimated by opposition sources as 10,000 strong -- sat down on one of the main city streets and refused to move after police barred their route. Observers say police used tear gas and concussion hand grenades before firing with rifles.

"They (the police) were still firing on people as I was running away," says Anthony Venyena, who was in the front ranks of the marchers.

Government officials in Bamenda reported the arrests of 20 women and 13 men following the march, but authorities say they will not discuss the circumstances of the shooting until after an investigation is completed.

According to reports from marches in five other provincial capitals on the same day, police were less deadly in dealing with demonstrators. In Yaounde, police chased demonstrators round the downtown area with an armored, twin-nozzled water cannon. The scene suggested a bizarre image of an elephant chasing ants. In Bertoua, five people were reported arrested, while in Bafoussam, a heavy police presence prevented a large gathering from materializing.

In a statement released late the night of March 25 to the government-run Cameroon Radio, Prime Minister Simon Achidi Achu said the government would investigate the circumstances of the shootings, and that it "condemns the acts of barbarism and those involved.

"The government again invites the population to be vigilant and confirms its determination to maintain order and peace within the spirit of respect for the freedom and rights of its citizens," the prime minister's statement said.

The statement also pointed a finger at Fru Ndi followers, saying the shootings happened within "a program of disorder initiated by certain political parties of the radical opposition."

The prime minister was referring to a two-part plan of action announced March 15 by Fru Ndi, which called for a boycott of all French-made goods and companies and a series of peaceful marches on three consecutive Thursdays, ending on April 1. The campaign, according to Fru Ndi, is to protest "the recolonization of Cameroon by France, the savage destruction of our forests and environment, and the people's stolen victory of October 11, 1993." He said the opposition Union for Change would give the government until April 5 to make a satisfactory response, warning that the opposition would be forced into drastic action unless it gets some satisfaction.

Two days before the violent Bamenda incident, Cameroon government spokesman and Minister of Communications Augustin Kontchou Kouomegni said during a televised press conference that the government would hold "a grand debate" on constitutional reform nationwide during April and May.

"Every Cameroonian and legal political party will have the opportunity to participate in the debate," Kontchou Kouomegni said, but he offered no specifics about how the country's 12 million people will be able to register their views.

"Those are small details," Kontchou Kouomegni told AfricaNews. "The details of the organization will be published as soon as possible."

President Paul Biya had promised a debate on a new constitution during the campaign. The Union for Change coalition has sought constitutional reform as the first step to a free and fair election, which the coalition contends the October 11 vote was not.

But Kontchou has rejected the union's demand that the debate take the form of a "national conference" with a broad representation from civic and religious groups as well as political parties -- a mechanism used as a transition to democracy in several French-speaking African countries. Biya supporters fear such a conference would serve as a platform for the opposition to expose excesses of past and present members of government.

Opposition sources say the government's announcement of a constitutional debate was too imprecise to merit a serious response.

"You cannot sort out exactly what they want to do," says Dorothee Kom, a Fru Ndi spokeswoman. "There is no content, and nothing is said clearly." n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


OPPOSITION BCP SWEEPS LESOTHO POLLS Africa's three-year-old democracy bandwagon is still rolling.


BYLINE: Tami Hultman * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Twenty-three years after Ntsu Mokhlehle won an election to be prime minister of Lesotho, he may finally have a chance to govern.

Last week, Mokhlehle's Basotholand Congress Party (BCP) was declared the winner of the first general election since 1970 in Lesotho (pronounced Lay soo' too), a Maryland-sized country completely surrounded by South Africa. Results showed the party winning all the country's 65 constituencies.

The BCP swept the 1970 vote as well, but the ruling Basotho National Party (BNP) canceled the election, killed hundreds of opponents, declared a state of emergency, and outlawed the BCP and arrested its leaders. The repressive measures, backed by South Africa, were little noticed outside Africa. 

This election has been different. An international group of 130 election observers, coordinated by the United Nations, gave the poll a vote of confidence. "We are satisfied that those who voted were able to freely and fairly exercise their views," said a statement by the Commonwealth Observer Group, one of 11 organizations and seven governments who participated in the observer mission.

That assessment has been disputed by the BNP, the only political party, other than the BCP, to put up a full field of candidates. The BNP ruled Lesotho with an iron fist until six years ago, when a military coup ousted BNP leader Leabua Jonathan, who died two years later.

A BNP statement last week said the conduct of the balloting violated "every tenet and every spirit of fairness and equity." The party complained that polling places had opened late and voting had extended into a second, unscheduled day.

In response, the observer team acknowledged some logistical problems and the extension of voting hours, but it said those realities did not reflect an attempt to rig the elections. "International observers have not found grounds to believe that there have been fraudulent activities or public disorders that would have invalidated the outcome of these elections," the observers said in a statement.

Although small in size, Lesotho is a nation of forbidding but majestic terrain and of isolated, hard-to-reach areas. Nicknamed "the magic mountain kingdom," it is a place where, even in mid- summer, blizzards can block access to higher elevations. In remote mountain areas, some voters arrived at polling places on horseback or had to be given lifts by helicopters.

Fear and Hope. Because of Lesotho's troubled history, the BNP's refusal to accept the results stirred fears that the BCP might be denied its victory once again.

After Jonathan's overthrow, a succession of military leaders has exercised power. Beginning in 1990, the country's rulers have been promising a free vote, but there have been widespread suspicions about those intentions.

"The people of Lesotho appear to welcome this transition with wary enthusiasm," said a pre-election assessment by the Washington, DC-based International Republican Institute (IRI), which sent 13 observers. "Many individuals, parties and organizations expressed strong concern -- not about the potential for fraud on election day, but about the post-election transition. No one wants a repeat of (the 1970) elections in which actual irregularities were reportedly few, but the election results were not respected by those who lost."

Jim Dunlap, an IRI observer who spent more than four weeks in Lesotho, says that for the country's people, "1970 is like yesterday. It's talked about all the time. The atmosphere now is compared to that in 1970, so naturally that makes people cautious."

Adding to the uncertainty was the fact that neither the election laws nor the text of a new constitution were released until ten days before the election. In addition, the constitutional document is vague about the role of the military in the new government. "We are worried," says one Lesotho voter whose job takes him around the country, "that the military will use the BNP's complaints to continue to wield effective power."

It has been clear to knowledgeable observers that the BCP would win any truly fair vote. BCP leader Mokhlehle, who studied with Nelson Mandela and other South African anti-apartheid leaders, was a famed campaigner against British colonial rule, and his win in 1970 -- the country's first post-independence election -- was no surprise at the time. After fleeing the country in 1974, Mokhlehle campaigned from exile for Lesotho democracy.

In 1979, when Lesotho authorities stepped up a terror campaign against opponents, Mokhlehle launched a guerrilla insurgency against the Jonathan government.

But internationally, the government held all the cards. After Jonathan began to criticize his powerful neighbor, South Africa, in 1977, foreign aid to Lesotho soared. Outside assistance rose still further when Lesotho blamed South Africa for the BCP's attacks. U.S. development assistance rose 13-fold from 1976 to 1980, not counting $34 million for food and road building.

The government was noticeably less successful, however, at persuading its own people that the threat came from abroad. A month-long reporting trip to every corner of Lesotho during 1980 confirmed Mokhlehle's claim that he had overwhelming support from the country's one million people. Even in the atmosphere of fear and intimidation that prevailed, it was difficult to find a critic of Mokhlehle outside the ruling elite.

Now, unlike 1970 or 1980, Lesotho is operating -- if not quite in the glare of international publicity -- at least in its dim glow. "Lesotho has the potential for being a model for the region," says Jim Dunlap. "It has the ability to give confidence about the transition process in other countries, including South Africa. We have every indication that things should go smoothly." As the strength of the BCP victory became known, a festival atmosphere began to spread in Maseru, the capital.

In interviews since the vote, Ntsu Mokhlehle, long called a dangerous radical by opponents, has been making conciliatory statements, thanking the military for paving the way to free elections and promising to take all opinions into account as he tackles such issues as relations with South Africa and the role of the country's traditional monarchy. He has promised the country's people an honest, effective government but says hard work is needed from every citizen.

The 74-year-old BCP head, who retains the acute mind and magnetic personality that propelled him to leadership, also says he is optimistic. "I'm old," he says, "but I've got energy."

In his victory speech, Mokhlehle said his administration will put into place "practical steps toward solving hunger, disease, ignorance and joblessness." n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


COUNTDOWN TO DEMOCRACY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Crystal ball gazing is a tricky exercise in any country, but particularly in South Africa, where 26 political parties begin meeting this week to hash out a process leading to elections. No firm dates or plans have been made, but based on the agreements to date between the African National Congress (ANC) and the National Party, AfricaNews has constructed this very tentative timetable for the countdown to democracy.

* April to June 1993: Twenty-six political parties meet in "multiparty negotiations" to establish a timetable for the process leading to elections. Major players are the National Party, the African National Congress (ANC), Inkatha, the Pan Africanist Party and the Conservative Party. The governing National Party and Inkatha are pressing for these multiparty negotiations to reach binding agreements on issues such as how much power will be concentrated in the national government and how much power regional governments will have over economic, social and political issues. The ANC believes that the multiparty talks should only discuss the transition period, and that all binding decisions for the long term, including the powers of the regions, should be decided by the elected constituent assembly. Decisions will be made on the basis of "sufficient consensus" among all the parties. 

* June to August 1993: The existing National Party- dominated parliament passes legislation to create a Transitional Executive Council (TEC), which will include representatives from all of the major political parties in the negotiations. The ANC insists that the TEC have executive control over the security forces, the media, finance/budget matters and the running of elections. The National Party says that the TEC should be advisory in nature and that the current parliament and F.W. de Klerk's cabinet should continue to rule the country during the interim period. Both parties

agree to establish:

* an independent electoral commission to organize and supervise the elections;

* an independent media commission to oversee the impartiality of the media.

* September to December 1993: Once the procedures for the elections and the functioning of the constituent assembly have been agreed upon, the present parliament will pass a new nonracial constitution for the interim administration of the country, providing for the elections and creation of a constituent assembly.

* January to April 1994: Voters elect a single 400-member constituent assembly, one-half of whom are elected on the basis of the nationwide results and the other half on the basis of each party's showing in specific geographic regions. Only parties polling more than five percent of the vote are included in the constituent assembly.

* 1994 to 1995: The constituent assembly appoints a cabinet to include all parties with more than five or ten percent of the seats in the assembly. The assembly rules the country while it draws up a new constitution. The ANC is suggesting that decisions should be made on the basis of a two-thirds majority, but that on matters concerning the powers of regions, a two-thirds majority of the regional delegates will be required. The National Party says key decisions should be made by consensus or by a three-quarters majority.

* 1995 to 1999: The Government of National Unity, which the ANC proposed earlier this year, will rule the country until the first elections are held under the new constitution no later than five years after the elections for the constituent assembly. The ANC proposal calls for a strong executive presidency, elected by a simple majority, to appoint a cabinet made up of representatives of all parties with more than five percent of the seats in the constituent assembly. The National Party wants a weaker presidency and decision making by consensus.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


VOTES, VIOLENCE AND LIFE


BYLINE: Charles E. Cobb, Jr.


LENGTH: 480 words


 

South African blacks -- 75 percent of the population -- still cannot vote. To draw up a new nonracial constitution that would give them that right, 19 organizations -- a dozen of them black -- sent some 200 delegates to the Convention for a Democratic South Africa in December 1991. Tense but hopeful from the beginning, the talks collapsed in June 1992, with everyone blaming everyone else for the bloody escalation of violence in the townships. The ANC accused President Frederik W. de Klerk's white National Party of allowing it. BY September terrible loss of life brought the parties together again. Everyone agreed that the talks had to resume and the fighting had to stop. But no one agreed on what was causing the violence. Tribalism is the easy answer. 

"That's a lie!" says Archbishop Desmond Tutu. "In Soweto we have lived harmoniously. I am Xhosa. I have a Zulu family on one side. A Swazi family there. A Mopedi over there. A Motswana there. If we quarrel, it is because you have a new suit and I am jealous. We have never quarreled in Soweto because of tribalism."

To the Reverend Allan Boesak, an ANC leader from Cape Town, "township violence is a legacy of apartheid -- a system that is violent in itself. But there was a dangerous glorification of the armed struggle; we romanticized it. Our kids grew up with the idea that you are only a hero in the struggle if you are willing to kill someone. It's destroying our soul."

Black South Africa is arguably the most complex

community in Africa: A population of 30 million people, half urban, half rural... definable in terms of the most oppressive legislation in Africa but just as definable in terms of resistance to oppression.

Despite dire headlines, black South Africans manage much normalcy in day-to-day living. Babies are born, families raised, weddings and birthdays celebrated. There is work and play, warmth and love.

"I am oppressed by this government, yes," a Soweto vendor told me, "but I am not oppressed. I have life; I have hope for better."

The subtlety of his distinction reflects what I saw across

South Africa: blacks refusing to be defined only as victims of apartheid. n

Excerpted from "The Twilight of Apartheid: Life in Black South Africa," National Geographic, Vol. 183, No. 2, February 1993. The author is a former contributing editor of Africa News Service.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 5, 1993


SOUTH AFRICAN ELECTIONEERING GAINS MOMENTUM Campaign for first democratic election gears up as negotiations on procedures continue.


BYLINE: Jim Cason for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 2507 words


 

Campaign for first democratic election gears up as negotiations on procedures continue.

Delegations from 26 political parties meet this week in South Africa to hammer out a process for nonracial elections, while small teams of lawyers and negotiators argue over every detail of the negotiations. Larger working groups in the African National Congress (ANC) and National Party are gearing up for the contest they hope will come a year from now when voters finally go to the polls.

At the ANC's National Headquarters in Johannesburg, Popo Molefe has a plan to set up 100 voter education offices around the country and launch a grass-roots, door-to-door effort to persuade voters to go to the polls. "You have to remember, 18 million of the 21 million people likely to take part have never voted before," says Molefe, who heads the ANC election committee. The ANC, which is campaigning with the slogan "Now is the Time," is concerned that most of its support will come from those first-time voters who may be kept from the polls by continuing violence. 

In March, the ruling National Party established an elections campaign committee based in Pretoria to run their effort. State President F.W. de Klerk helped launch the formal campaign at a rally on March 27 in the "Coloured" township of Goodwood near Cape Town. Heading up the party's effort is Olaus Van Zyl, who is beginning by reviving the National Party's campaign apparatus and making plans to establish local offices in black townships for the first time. Other issues to be decided in the next few weeks, Van Zyl says, include a new symbol for the party and finalizing major slogans.

One major unresolved issue is the actual date for elections. Both ANC and National Party officials say that they expect elections in March or April 1994, but predicting election dates in South Africa is a dangerous exercise. Last year, as negotiators prepared for the second round of multiparty Codesa (Convention for a Democratic South Africa) talks in May, top ANC advisors predicted that an interim executive including all of the parties would be ruling the country by October 1992, and elections would be held in April 1993. That seemingly solid agreement broke down in a dispute over the government's refusal to address continuing violence and over the percentage of votes necessary to make decisions in the constitution-making body.

What makes the two major parties optimistic that this round of talks will succeed is the agreement reached in bilateral negotiations on a timetable and outlines of a plan for a transition leading to elections (see "Countdown to Democracy" on page 3).

There are still major unresolved questions, including the precise boundaries and powers of the regional governments, the mechanics of the elections process, and the percentage of votes necessary to make decisions in the constituent assembly. But the ANC and the National Party both believe these issues can be resolved quickly. In the negotiations that begin this week, they will be seeking to draw other political organizations -- particularly Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party, the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC) and the Conservative Party -- into the negotiation process.

Could the ANC lose? Whatever the final election plan, many observers have assumed that the arithmetic of South Africa's population distribution should grant Nelson Mandela's ANC a substantial victory in an impartial election. Seventy-four percent of the population is black, and leaning heavily toward the ANC, while just 14 percent is white. The mixed race people, who under apartheid were categorized as "Coloureds" represent nine percent, while Indians account for another three percent.

But ANC national election coordinator, Popo Molefe, says that for inexperienced voters, violence or the threat of violence could discourage turnout in the black community. While Molefe believes the ANC will win, he notes that these problems will not affect white voters who form the core of the National Party's support.

South African political scientist Andrew Reynolds believes the ANC might lose to a coalition made up of the National Party and Inkatha. Writing in the Christian Science Monitor, Reynolds suggests that if the ANC wins slightly less than 50 percent of the national vote, the National Party might win 30 percent of the overall vote and strike a deal with Inkatha to form a coalition that could control a simple majority in the constituent assembly.

"What the international community must take note of," Reynolds writes, "is the totally uneven playing field on which the election campaign in South Africa is being fought." The National Party has considerable electoral experience and financial resources and, even under the most far-reaching transitional arrangement, will still effectively control administration of the state apparatus, he says.

Other pollsters such as Mark Orkin have put ANC support at 60 percent, the National Party at 17 percent, the PAC at eight percent, the Conservatives at six percent and Inkatha at five percent.

The Reynolds scenario may be a worst case, but ANC planners are taking the threat seriously. "A lot of people who have been interviewed in research surveys," says Molefe, "feel that it will be a major personal risk for them to take part in elections." In one recent poll, 16 percent of black South Africans said that they would not vote if faced with the threat of violence. As a result, the first stage of the ANC's campaign is focused on convincing people that the vote will be safe and secret.

The task is not easy. Molefe says the ANC has not been able to open an office or organize any public events for at least six months in the area known as Boputhatswana, which was declared an independent territory under apartheid. One rally planned for March 21 this year had to be moved after the Boputhatswana police erected road blocks to prevent it from happening. "Not even the churches are being allowed to do nonpartisan voter education in Boputhatswana at the moment," says Molefe.

Political violence in some areas of Northern Natal and in the Ciskei bantustan also has prevented the ANC branches there from organizing. The movement's leadership will be demanding access to these areas during the next round of negotiations, but Molefe warned that the ANC also may organize mass action campaigns to force more open political space.

Another major component of the ANC's early campaigning will be informing people that in order to vote they will need to get identification documents. The ANC estimates that between 4 million and 5 million eligible voters, many of whom are rural Africans and women, don't posses these documents. Voters without IDs will have to obtain special voter identification cards issued by an independent electoral commission.

The congress will be producing pamphlets and using radio and television advertising as well as mobile video units in its efforts. But with illiteracy rates running at about 30 percent in the black community, the ANC is also relying heavily on door-to-door campaigns. "We hope to have identified every single voter in the country by the end of May," Molefe says. "We've probably reached about five percent at the moment."

Black votes for the party of apartheid. While the ANC is just starting to establish its campaign offices, at National Party election headquarters, Olaus Van Zyl already has a basic network of local chapters that his party has used in whites-only elections for more than 40 years. Van Zyl says the National Party is just beginning to gear up for the next vote, with the first big push concentrated on a grass-roots effort to train local party activists, expand membership and open up new branches in black areas.

This is a process that actually started two years ago, when the previously all-white party opened up membership to all races. Although Van Zyl declined to provide figures for party membership, he said that recent opinion polls indicate it is doing extremely well, particularly in "Coloured" and Indian communities, a fact that the ANC's Molefe acknowledges.

"When it comes to the black communities, the ANC has got by far the majority of the support, and the National Party support varies between ten and 20 percent," Van Zyl says. "We realize of course that we would have to get more than double that support to win an election, so we are working very hard on getting more support in the black communities."

As part of this effort, the party has opened up its first campaign offices in Soweto and Kwathema townships. But they also face intimidation. "People join us and say please don't put our names on lists because we may be in danger if people know we are members," Van Zyl says.

These fears received an added boost earlier this year, when Moses Mayekiso, trade union leader closely allied to the ANC, was reported to have declared that white parties would not be welcome in the black townships. The ANC quickly disavowed the comment, which Mayekiso says was misunderstood. Nonetheless, Van Zyl says it has been particularly difficult for the National Party to campaign in Seboking township and other areas near Johannesburg.

As part of its effort to reach out to new voters, the National Party is relying more than in previous campaigns on radio advertising and door-to-door canvassing, social evenings and meetings, as well as larger campaign rallies.

Describing how the party that introduced apartheid will

make its pitch to black voters, Van Zyl says: "Yes, the National Party brought in a policy which they called apartheid. But the whole situation of black people not voting in South Africa existed since 1652 when the first white people landed. Separate race areas were first implemented by the English." In his view, the important thing for black voters to realize is that the party has changed, and that it now supports a democratic nonracial system. He also suggests that the National Party may be able to pick up support among more conservative rural black people in the Northern Transvaal or the Orange Free State where isolated communities lack trust in the ANC.

Noting that National Party policies differ little from those of Inkatha, the Christian Democratic Party in Boputhatswana or several other smaller parties, Van Zyl suggests the likelihood of working alliances with several of these groups during the campaign. Such an alliance, even if it did not win a majority, could cross the 33 percent threshold needed to block decisions in the constituent assembly.

At this point, Inkatha is concentrating its campaigning in the Natal region, where Chief Buthelezi's KwaZulu is located, although on March 21, Inkatha officials bussed in some 10,000 supporters for a rally in Vosloorus, near Johannesburg.

For its part, the ANC enters the election campaign with a strong alliance already in place that includes the trade union federation, Cosatu, and the South African Communist Party. The 1.5-million-member labor grouping is urging its affiliates to begin voter education drives on the factory floor. But, in an indication of the pressures the ANC is under even from its own supporters, Cosatu is tying its campaigning for the ANC to a specific "reconstruction accord" program that commits a future government to a comprehensive program of jobs creation, education and training.

"Another major problem," says Molefe, "is that we have been finding it very difficult to raise funds for the elections campaign." The ANC is trying to find $55 million for its campaign chest but so far has only managed to raise about $1 million. "People are saying they want to support the democratization process, and they will give money to nonpartisan activities but not to political activity," says Molefe. What the international community doesn't recognize, he argues, is that because it is not in the interests of the National Party to register more black voters, the burden of voter education is going to fall on the ANC.

The ANC is at a further disadvantage, says Molefe, because they are building their campaign from scratch while the National Party has many years of experience and is able to draw on the resources -- and budgets -- of its members of parliament and more affluent white voter base. The ANC also charges that the existing local government structures are being used to promote the National Party campaign. To support this charge, Molefe brandishes a pamphlet put out in the name of the National Party that was paid for with local government money.

The National Party's Van Zyl declines to release campaign budgets, but he says the party probably will spend less than what the ANC is spending. "We've got constituency boards. We have members of parliament. It's not that we have to set up a total structure from the start," he says. "Therefore we do not need as much money as the ANC to get structures going all over the country." n


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


POETRY: MUSINGS ON THE 13TH ANNIVERSARY OF ZIMBABWE'S INDEPENDENCE WHERE THE MAJORITY ARE THE MINORITY


BYLINE: Judith Mushipe


LENGTH: 227 words


 

In Zimbabwe the women are the majority. Politically and economically they are the minority. In every 100 people in Zimbabwe, 52 are women. For every 100 people queuing for bread, 60 are women. Out of every 100 people in line for mealie-meal, 80 are women. At a political rally of 1500 people, 1000 of them are women. It is the women who till 70% of the land, and yet they own no land. Women feed the nation and yet remain marginalized. It is the men who own the land and it is the men who decide what to do with the harvest. Women are the main consumers of goods and products, yet they do not make any fiscal or monetary decisions. They are the majority of the civil servants, and yet they do not make decisions in the Public Service. The majority of teachers are women, and yet they do not make decisions in the Ministry of Education. Women staff the Ministry of Health, and yet they are frustrated daily. Women in Zimbabwe, are marginalized, and with the passing away of Amai Sally Mugabe in January 1992, women have no representative at State functions and there is no mother figure at the State House. Judith Mushipe is a Lecturer in Business Administration at the University of Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


EUROPE MEETS AFRICA -- AMERICAN STYLE


BYLINE: Harry Amana


SECTION: CULTURE/LIFESTYLE: MUSIC


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

"Pieces of Africa"

(Elektra Nonesuch 79275-2)

(Kronos Quartet with Dumisani Maraire, ngoma, hosho, vocals, mbira; Foday Musa Suso, kora; Hamza El Din, tar; Obo Addy, donno, brekete, aketse, gidi, vocals; Radouane Laktib, oud, vocals; Said Hakmoun, bander, vocals; Dan Pauli, hosho; and the Oakland Interfaith Gospel Choir)

We've finally listened to Kronos Quartet's much-ballyhooed CD "Pieces of Africa," and it's a winner -- a good collection that mostly lives up to its reputation. It's a 67-minute collection of cross-cultural music by seven African composers from Zimbabwe, Sudan, Gambia, Uganda, Ghana and South Africa, some of whom accompany the quartet on five of the eight cuts.

It's strongest pieces, however, are seven compositions that take up just over two-thirds of the disc. Another 21 minutes is a five-movement suite, "White Man Sleeps," by exiled South African Kevin Volans, that is, at best, interesting, although its fourth and fifth movements are strong, intense compositions that seem to conclude just when they're getting started. 

For the still uninitiated: Kronos Quartet is the 20-year-old U.S. string quartet, much praised for its innovations with classical, jazz and "world" music, frequently driven by social commentary and protest. Its 1989 album, "Different Trains," received a Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Composition; "Pieces of Africa," released last February as its tenth album, was number one on Billboard's Top Classical and Top Adult Alternative charts last summer. Some Kronos enthusiasts say "Pieces of Africa" is the group's most innovative release to date. Listening to the seven pieces that occupy most of the disc, one can understand why.

Especially enticing is "Escalay" ("Waterwheel") by Sudanese composer Hamza El Din, who accompanies the quartet on the tar, a hand-held drum. This entrancing 12-minute piece -- the longest continuous composition on the disc -- has a distinctly Middle Eastern sound that ebbs and flows rhythmically over a brooding bass line that might remind old-time jazz lovers of the double bass line of John Coltrane's "Ole."

Equally lovely is "Kutambarara" ("Spreading") by Zimbabwean Dumisani Maraire, a seven-minute gospel song that includes Maraire on several instruments and vocals, along with Dan Pauli and the Oakland Interfaith Gospel Choir.

This is a call-response composition filled with percussion and counterpointed harmony. The male voice calls out over hand claps and the repeated, responding chant of the choir. Although the song's roots on this disc are among the Shona people of Zimbabwe, one can hear versions of this gospel form throughout South Africa, especially in the Methodist and Congregational churches, where the singing congregation keeps time with a heavy bass "thud" of bibles and prayer books hit mightily against their hands. That "thud" is missing on "Kutambarara," giving it a uniqueness that might remind gospel music listeners of the hand-clap time keeping of African American gospel.

It should be noted here that none of this music is purely grounded in Africa. Consistent throughout all of the compositions is the Kronos interpretation and interplay -- a "fusion," if you will, between indigenous African and U.S.-European classical music. Quartet members even abandon their strings sometimes for thumb pianos and percussion and sometimes thump the strings of the cello as if it were a jazz bass fiddle.

On "Ekitundu Ekisooka" ("First Movement"), a five-minute piece by Ugandan Justinian Tamusuza, for example, Kronos plays unaccompanied, but the sound is decidedly Middle Eastern. The violins, frequently used instruments in Middle Eastern music, drone over a thudding polyrhythmic beat (a drum, perhaps, or is it hands against the cello?) reminiscent of the music made popular in the United States by Ravi Shankar.

The other distinctly Middle Eastern piece, "Saade," (I'm Happy") is a four-minute song that includes the singing and sintir playing of its North African composer Hassan Hakmoun, along with Said Hakmoun on bander and vocals, and Radouane Laktib on oud and vocals. Again, the violins drone and whine over the polyrhythms, this time intensified by the innovative accents of the human voice.

On "Tilliboyo" ("Sunset"), another four-minute composition, Kronos is accompanied by the song's Gambian composer, Foday Musa Suso, on kora, a 21-string instrument. Here, the quartet's violins come in lightly in what might normally be a flute line, as the kora and thumb piano play lyrically underneath.

Completing this CD are "Wawshishijay" ("Our Beginning"), a five-minute song by Ghanaian Obo Addy, who sings and plays a variety of instruments, including the gidi, aketse and brekete; and "Mai Nozipo" ("Mother Nozipo"), the second composition by Zimbabwean Maraire in tribute to his mother. "Wawshishijay" is an intensive, percussion-filled song highlighted by a stirring harmony between voice and cello. It should have been longer.

"Mai Nozipo," an exuberant, seven-minute composition, features an unaccompanied Kronos, whose members play joyful fiddles and, again, discard some of their strings for inspired polyrhythmic percussion. One understands when listening to his piece that Maraire loves and is inspired by his mother. One also feels that Kronos understands this love.

For Kronos Quartet, this CD might be considered a good "beginning," in spite of the quartet's 20-year, ten-album history -- members have said that they have a score of other composers commissioned to write material for them -- and one looks forward to what their future work might hold.

Meanwhile, this disc is a good buy for those who love African music and who want to enter a cross-cultural world where Europe and Africa meet, American-style. n

(Note: For those who wish to catch Kronos live, the quartet is finishing up its 1992-93 U.S. tour with scheduled appearances at Herbst Theatre (San Francisco), April 29; Hult Center (Eugene, OR), April 30; University of Washington (Seattle), May 1; and the UCLA Center for the Arts (Los Angeles), May 8. Its Japanese tour is scheduled for May 10-22.)


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


VIEWPOINT MALAWI JOINS AFRICA'S DEMOCRACY MARCH


BYLINE: Ellen Drummond


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

The winds of democracy that are blowing across Africa have reached Malawi, a long-neglected backwater that for nearly 30 years has been held in the grip of one man.

Hastings Kamuza Banda, who has headed Malawi since its independence in 1964 and calls himself "life president," has been forced to yield to the forces of reform. After decades in which all dissent was suppressed and government opponents imprisoned and exiled, the country is preparing for a June 14 referendum on whether to end one-party rule.

In a largely successful attempt to isolate Malawi from the modern world, Banda has enforced quasi-Victorian dress codes and banning television as a pernicious influence. The government also has maintained strict control over the mass media and has barred foreign journalists from the country for decades. All private correspondence, both internal and external, has been systematically opened and censored, as have all publications. Telephones are routinely tapped, and the country has been honeycombed with a vast network of spies and informers. 

As has happened elsewhere in the world, the pro- democracy campaign in Malawi has gotten a boost from a modern technological tool, the facsimile machine.

Unlike previously available forms of communication, fax transmissions proved virtually invulnerable to government censorship. Large numbers of dissidents both inside and outside the country have capitalized on this fact to flood the country with anti-government circulars and documents. The material can be sent by fax from one area to another, and duplicates can be made for dissemination to the smallest villages. I once witnessed a stack of illicit handouts being wrapped inside a bolt of fabric, for distribution into the countryside.

While the aging Banda himself retains a measure of respect from many Malawians, those closest to him are the object of widespread loathing. John Temba, minister of state and Banda's heir apparent, and Temba's niece, Cecilia Tamanda Kadzamira, who is Banda's official hostess, are believed to be the real powers in the country and are regularly accused of misappropriating Malawi's assets and other crimes.

Other circulars extol the virtues of the opposition, particularly Chakufwa Chihana, the trade union leader who was jailed after returning to Malawi last year to campaign for change. One of the clandestine posters I saw referred to Chihana as the "Lion of Malawi," an appellation hitherto reserved exclusively for Banda.

International pressure and attention have provided important underpinning to the opposition drive. When major donor countries last year announced a suspension of aid to Malawi, the government was forced to make compromises. The referendum on multiparty rule is one; release of long-serving political prisoners is another.

The nation was stunned last June by the freeing of Machipisa Munthali, an early victim of Banda's purges who had been held for 27 years, roughly the same period as Nelson Mandela. While in prison, Munthali was fed only cornmeal porridge, pigeon peas and water and was denied access to all reading matter, including the Bible. He was not allowed visits from his children, and hardly anyone expected him to emerge alive.

"International pressure is working," one middle-aged man screamed upon hearing the news about Munthali. Turning to me,

he exclaimed: "You can't imagine how grateful we are."

World scrutiny also has seemed to influence the government's handling of Chihana. He was released after his first detention, although he was later rearrested and charged. Earlier this month, his two-year sentence was reduced to nine months, advancing his release date to June 14, the day of the referendum.

Increasing numbers of Malawians have joined in the democracy campaign. Not even the sentencing of Chihana to two years of hard labor last year seemed to impair opposition morale. People routinely refer to the labor leader as "president-in-waiting" and, risking arrest themselves, continue to shout his name and other anti-government slogans as official government vehicles pass by.

Elsewhere, such behavior might not be viewed as risky. But in a country where the predominant human emotion for more than a generation has been debilitating fear, this is an unprecedented upsurge of outspokenness.

It is hard to convey to those outside Malawi just how much foreign radio broadcasts mean to people whose only other source of information is rumor. The Voice of America is generally looked upon as worthless, but the BBC is virtually worshipped. Malawians with access to radios drop all activity to listen, and people excitedly discuss every report they hear that mentions their homeland.

Last year, after a steady stream of reporting on Malawi, news dried up as events in other places dominated the broadcasts. Malawians were hurt and bewildered to realize that the West's attention had shifted.

I once asked a young friend of mine who lives in a typical village if she had seen the pastoral letter written by Malawi's Roman Catholic bishops in early 1992. The letter, called "Living Our Faith," contains the most forthright, comprehensive and devastating indictment of Banda's regime ever openly published and disseminated inside the country.

"No," my friend replied. She had heard about it, as everybody had, but she had never seen it, she told me. I offered her a copy of the document, which in this devoutly Christian country had been declared illegal to possess. She took it with wariness and started laboriously plodding her way through the unfamiliar English phrases until, with dawning incredulity, she visibly began to grasp the meaning. "A growing gap between the rich and poor ... our people's experience of unfairness and injustice ... a climate of mistrust and fear ... the voiceless who live in situations of hopelessness."

With an expression of utter revelation, scarcely daring to believe what she was reading, the young woman looked up and

said: "They have written the truth!" *

Ellen Drummond is a pseudonym for a writer who has recently left Malawi after a lengthy stay.


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


VIEWPOINT RECOGNIZING ANGOLA WOULD SAVE LIVES


BYLINE: Vivian Lowery Derryck


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

While the United States is preoccupied with the power struggle in Russia and the fate of Srebrenicans in Bosnia, parts of Africa are facing similar death and destruction. In Angola, the heart of Africa, estimates of people killed since civil war resumed in October range as high as 30,000. While Bosnia seems to defy solution, the United States has the power to stem some of the slaughter in Angola by a simple act of recognition.

The Clinton administration should establish formal diplomatic relations with Angola. Recognition of the government of President Eduardo dos Santos by the United States would fulfill a promise, help to clarify the combat situation, signal U.S. commitment to the electoral process, and ultimately save lives. 

Angola has plunged back into civil war because Jonas Savimbi, the head of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita), refused to accept the outcome of September's elections. The United States should have acted quickly at the time, but in the tumult of our own election we did not. Through the Bicesse Accords of May 1991, which ended 16 years of Angolan conflict, the United States tacitly promised to recognize an Angolan government that emerged from free and fair elections. By virtually all accounts, the September elections were free and fair. Dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) won the legislature by an overwhelming 67 percent and could, therefore, choose a prime minister and form a government.

Dos Santos narrowly missed receiving a presidential majority, polling 49.57 percent, compared to 20.07 percent for Savimbi. The rebel leader cried foul, and civil war resumed. The second round of voting -- called for if no candidate won a simple majority -- never took place.

Six months later, the war-weary southern African nation is locked in bloody fighting that has touched virtually every family in the nation of 10 million. Major cities are yo-yos swinging back and forth between control by government and Unita forces, with appalling damage being inflicted by both sides.

Recognition of the dos Santos government would bring U.S. policy in line with that of its Western allies as well as with the desires of most African nations. France, Portugal, Britain and Germany all recognized Angola more than a decade ago. The Organization of African Unity (OAU) is urging the United States to speed recognition, and President Clinton has received letters to that effect from former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda and former Nigerian President Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo. Leading newspapers in the United States and Great Britain and a majority of the members of both houses of Congress have joined the call.

Given this overwhelming consensus, it is difficult to understand constraints preventing the new administration from acting.

Traditionally, the United States has based recognition on control of territory and a government's claim to represent the citizenry. While territorial control slips back and forth between Unita and the MPLA, the latter still holds much of the country, and the elections have legitimized its claim to represent the people. We should stand by our word and acknowledge the government's undisputed legislative victory.

By not recognizing Angola, the United States continues tacit support for Jonas Savimbi. Conversely, U.S. recognition would signal to the Unita leader that his former patron is just that -- a former backer who is now advocating an equitable resolution of a long-standing conflict. Without U.S. support, Savimbi would be left with only one ally, South Africa, and would be more likely to turn to negotiations.

There are other steps the United States should take after

recognition:

* First, the United States should demand that Savimbi attend United Nations-sponsored peace talks.

* Second, the U.S. government should pledge to oversee a new UN effort for the demobilization of the Unita and MPLA armies and the integration of both into a single fighting force. Although neither side demobilized their troops as promised in the peace accord, Savimbi complied less fully and therefore emerged initially stronger in the resumed fighting. Integrating the army is one key to peace.

* Third, we must demand an immediate cease-fire. In renewed fighting, Savimbi may have captured as much as 65 percent of the land mass of the country, but it is doubtful that he could capture all of Angola. Experts envision a bloody stalemate with continued high casualties. (Over 10,000 people have died already in the battle for the city of Huambo.)

* Fourth, we should commit the United States to lead a UN effort to monitor the runoff presidential election.

Not to act is to invite future problems. Angola is a bellwether for other African trouble spots that ache for resolution. A thousand miles to the north and west, Charles Taylor, the military strongman who invaded Liberia in December 1989, is toying with the notion of accepting a brokered cease-fire and agreeing to multiparty elections.

The tacit U.S. support for Savimbi says to Taylor that no decision or commitment is binding and that an election outcome does not have to be final. If it is not to your liking, refuse to accept it and restart the war.

On the other side of the continent in civil war-riven Somalia, failure to stand up to Savimbi will undermine UN and OAU efforts to deal forcefully with the clans and warlords. If there are no sanctions for failure to abide by the terms of international decrees and edicts, why waste time negotiating with the UN, and why honor any agreement that has been reached?

Also in East Africa, Mozambique is moving quietly toward UN-run elections. But resumed hostilities in Angola may suggest to Alphonse Dhlakama, leader of the anti-government Renamo movement, that he rethink the peace accord or up the ante. Already, elections planned for next October have been postponed because of the slow pace of demobilization. Every delay makes peace more fragile.

When Salim Salim, secretary-general of the OAU, visited the United States last month, he underscored the urgency of U.S. recognition of Angola. Africa is watching us closely on this one. Africans really do look at the United States as the world's leading democracy -- a role model that is expected to do the right thing.

This is a rare instance where an attractive policy option will also yield an important humanitarian result. But even more important, recognition is a clear signal that our government is ending a misbegotten, outdated Cold War policy of supporting Savimbi. The United States should seize upon this win/win situation and move to support reconciliation and rebuilding in Angola. *

Vivian Lowery Derryck is president of the New York- based African-American Institute.


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


PUSH FOR SPEEDIER SOUTH AFRICAN TRANSITION FOLLOWS HANI DEATH


BYLINE: Jim Cason for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1974 words


 

The assassination of South African leader Chris Hani has the potential to either propel the negotiations process forward or plunge the country into an explosive crisis, say analysts inside the country. What actually happens will depend on the skills of negotiators on all sides and, according to the African National Congress (ANC), on the government's willingness to set an early date for elections.

The immediate result of Hani's death was a week of street demonstrations and popular protests and new calls for government action against right-wing death squads. Shortly after the shooting, the ANC angrily noted that Hani had survived two previous assassination attempts and that they had made a written request for police protection several months ago. But the movement's leadership has also been at pains to avoid a backlash. "It may have been the hand of a white male that slaughtered him, but it was the eyes of a white woman who helped us catch this bastard," declared ANC Witwatersand Chair Tokyo Sexwale at one rally. He was referring to Hani's neighbor, Retha Harmse, whose report of a car license plate number led to the capture of the alleged assassin. And Nelson Mandela repeatedly appealed for calm in speeches that were shown on state-owned television in prime time. 

"(Hani's death) has created a new situation in the country," says ANC negotiator Mohammed Valli Moosa, "a completely new vibe. We need to have some sort of dramatic announcement within the next few weeks, if the situation isn't to become completely uncontrollable."

The ANC has moved quickly to channel popular anger at Hani's death into renewed pressure on the government to shut down right-wing death squads, set a date for elections and establish a transitional executive that has control over the armed forces. The movement announced plans for a series of demonstrations, marches and civil disobedience protests throughout the month of May to press these goals. "We think that there is a real possibility of it propelling the process forward, because the government is under a tremendous amount of pressure right now," says Valli, who is executive secretary of the ANC Negotiations Committee and a member of the South African Communist Party. He notes that ANC demands for an election date and joint control of the army have been echoed by several newspapers and by a growing number of political leaders.

Hani is not easily replaced. At the same time, Valli and others acknowledge that with the murder of Chris Hani, the ANC has lost one of its most popular township leaders at a time when activists are becoming increasingly disaffected by the compromises necessary for negotiations to proceed.

"Hani had a quality of knowing exactly how people are feeling on the ground," says Gabu Tugwana, deputy editor of the independent weekly newspaper New Nation.

For the ANC, the ability to know and articulate the frustrations and aspirations of township residents will be increasingly important. As the movement enters its fourth year of negotiations with the government, there are new hopes that elections will be held next year. Yet there have been no fundamental changes in the standard of living or in material conditions for the vast majority of black South Africans. "Mandela Released Three Years Ago, South Africa Still Not Free," read a sign carried at demonstrations after Hani's death.

"He knew our pain," declared Nelson Mandela before a crowd of some 80,000 at the funeral service for Hani in Soweto. And it was as a spokesman for the pain of the black majority that Hani played his most important role. A negotiated transfer of power inevitably requires compromise on all sides, as the ANC's recent agreement to a five-year period of coalition government indicates.

The concessions have provoked rebellion within the organization and strong criticism of its leadership. The idea of a five-year coalition government rather than unfettered elections is unpopular in many townships, and Mandela himself was booed at a memorial service for Hani in Soweto when he suggested the ANC would have to work with South African President F.W. de Klerk and the ruling National Party to construct a new South Africa.

In an interview with this reporter two years ago, Hani suggested that creating these divisions was part of de Klerk's strategy. "De Klerk wants to negotiate with a weakened ANC, and he is using violence to weaken the ANC. De Klerk also wants to negotiate with an ANC that is away from the masses."

It was building this link with the township base that Hani saw as his principal role. "Chris Hani was the umbilical cord between the African National Congress and the masses," says ANC youth league leader Peter Mokaba. When violence was plaguing the townships, Hani argued for the ANC to form self defense groups and then pressed for them to be closed down when they got out of hand. More recently he had been demanding that the government surrender control of the military and police and incorporate members of the ANC's military wing into the Defense Force. He also spoke out against the ANC's marginalization of returning exiles who, he charged, have returned to "stand in unemployment lines."

A man of peace as well as war. Although many press reports have portrayed Hani as recently evolved from a radical guerrilla leader to a moderate who favored negotiations, Hani never saw his militant image as incompatible with negotiations. "We are involved in the struggle for the liberation of our people," he said. "We have used a number of strategies to step up the struggle to eliminate apartheid from our society." But he made it clear that the goal always was to force de Klerk into negotiations.

Hani was a visible and leading presence at both the Codesa negotiations between the government and its opponents last year and, more recently, at the multiparty talks convened in early April. When theologian Charles Villa Vincencio asked him recently about his image as a radical, Hani replied that the ANC "must not lose that image. Should it do so, it will lose the support of many young people. That will be fatal in terms of our goal to build a nation in the future."

But both Hani's image and his leadership of the South African Communist Party were used by opponents to discredit him. He was the last of the returning ANC leadership to be granted immunity from prosecution and to be allowed to operate freely inside South Africa. The Communist Party charges that in the past few months there had been a concerted campaign of disinformation, including rumors that Hani wanted to start his own army with estranged ANC leader Winnie Mandela to force the government to give up power.

Hani's service as chief of staff of the ANC's military wing, Umkhonto weSizwe, during a time when the organization was detaining, torturing and killing some of its own members, led to the harshest criticism, even from some within the ANC organization. He responded that "there have been injustices and wrongful deeds committed in our name. The detention and torture camps are among them." While arguing that these actions should be placed in historical context, Hani also publicly called on the ANC leadership to continue its investigation of what happened in ANC camps and suggested that ANC members guilty of abuses should not be allowed to serve in a new security force. The same should also be true, he argued, for those guilty of abuses while working for the National Party government.

Whatever his critics thought, Hani was tremendously popular. When the ANC held elections for its ruling national executive in 1991, he received more votes than any other candidate (Mandela had already been elected president). And in several opinion polls in the last few months he has been second only to Mandela himself in popularity.

In the two weeks before he was killed, Hani had more than 20 speaking engagements in rural areas and squatter communities around the country. "The issue now is not armed struggle but elections," he told an audience at one of these rallies. "That needs a climate of peace and stability. We cannot afford to have the process delayed and disrupted by violent elements. Every ANC supporter should be a combatant, but a combatant now for peace."

The charismatic, 50-year-old leader, who studied Latin and classical literature and contemplated becoming either a priest or a lawyer, had the background to argue persuasively for peace, says the New Nation's Tugwana. "He is a person who fought on the ground in Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe), he knew the war in Angola. So when he talks about a war, and says the time for a war has come to an end, people feel he knows what he is talking about." It is perhaps because of this background that in the last few weeks Hani had been appealing to the Pan Africanist Congress's military wing, APLA, to end a series of recent armed attacks on whites.

While arguing for elections and pressing for popular support of negotiations, Hani also declared that in order to continue pressing for radical change, he would not join an ANC-led coalition government. "I don't want to be involved," he told the Sunday Times of Johannesburg. "I want the freedom to criticize from outside, to lead marches, to organize strikes, to pressure the new government into doing the right things." At that point, said Hani, he would devote his principal energies to pressing the social program of the South African Communist Party, which he headed.

It was that balance, or tension, that gave Hani his strength and legitimacy among his constituency. He both called for participation in elections and pressed for more radical change. Now, with Hani gone, it is even more in the interest of the government to respond to these demands, one of Hani's close friends, Tokyo Sexwale, declared at a recent rally. "It can't be business as usual," said Sexwale. "There is a new urgency. We need a transitional executive in place now. The youth are exasperated. People are feeling that they must take something from all this. It's not a case of saying the ANC should deliver -- we can't deliver what we don't have. The government has to deliver." *

With files from Jennifer Griffin in Johannesburg


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English
