Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


ERITREANS WELCOME STATUS AS AFRICA'S NEWEST NATION


BYLINE: Jonathan Ewing for Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1120 words


DATELINE: Asmara, Eritrea


 

This piece was filed just before the April 23-25 referendum on independence from Ethiopia.

An unmistakeable mood of optimism fills this city of 400,000 that hugs the Red Sea coast. Palm trees line many of the boulevards, and outdoor cafes are numerous along Victory Avenue, Asmara's main thoroughfare. One is reminded of a small city along the Mediterranean. With a 30-year war finally over, all kinds of small businesses have sprung up. Cobblers, butchers and tailors line the narrow streets near the center of the city. 

Skinder Abebe, a 30-year-old cobbler, runs a small shop along Victory Avenue. "The war is finished, and we are doing a good job of picking up the pieces," he says. "Still most of us are a bit sad about the past."

A robust and cheerful man, Abebe works until well past dark most nights. He is paid by those who patronize his tiny shop and receives a small food allowance from the provisional government.

In his quiet shop he repairs shoes and the occasional small harness. Like most Eritreans, Abebe has sacrificed much. His wife, a guerilla fighter with the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF), was killed in fierce fighting two weeks before the war's bloody conclusion, in May 1991.

"There are many like me in Asmara," says Abebe.

After 30 years of nonstop war with Ethiopia, initially against the government of Emperor Haile Selassie and, after 1974, against the Marxist regime of Mengistu Haile Mariam, Eritreans have been looking forward with both relief and uncertainty to the referendum that will make them legally independent.

Indeed, in the coffeehouses and restaurants of the capital, it is impossible to find anyone planning to vote "no." Of equal significance, the leadership ranks of Eritrea's provisional government are thick with former guerrillas of the Eritrean Peoples' Liberation Front (EPLF), and all are optimistic.

"We are hoping that the referendum will make us more attractive to foreign investors and help us to rid ourselves of (our) unemployment problem," says Deputy Minister of Labor Zeratzion Woldeghebriels. "We have had some valuable talks with the American Embassy in Addis Ababa, and we have very high expectations from the United Nations' groups in Geneva."

Woldeghebriels was imprisoned in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, from 1977 to 1983. He says that during those six years, he was tortured for his activities in EPLF.

A big job ahead. At times it seems that this poor but pleasant tree-lined city is running only on enthusiasm for an uncertain and difficult future. Problems abound. Unemployment is approximately 55 percent. Inflation threatens every family. And due to the flood of refugees from the countryside into Asmara, as well as the destruction of thousands of dwellings by Ethiopian artillery, the housing shortage is critical. Factories stand idle. The city's water supply is sporadic, and the infrastructure is in desperate need of repair. Eritrea doesn't even have it's own currency and still uses the Ethiopian Birr.

Outside of Asmara in the semi-desert lowlands, nearly half the population is on food assistance, and life expectancy is only 45 years.

Most of the region is inhabited by Muslims, who make up 50 percent of Eritrea's population, and the area's inhabitants account for the bulk of membership of the Eritrean Liberation Front (ELF), which once was the vanguard of resistance to Ethiopian rule. Many ELF members fear that the new government, dominated by the EPLF, many of whom are christians, does not have their best interests at heart. The ELF has accused authorities of delaying the return of 500,000 refugees being held in Sudan, out of a fear that the returnees will bring militant Islam with them.

The government denies allegations of unfair treatment. "We are trying to broaden the membership of the EPLF," said the group's leader, Issaias Afwerki, in a recent interview. "We have already lived for a long time together in peace, and we should continue to do so."

An Eritrean journalist, who preferred that his name not be used, says that "those who make up Afwerki's inner circle have more in common with cabinet members in Ethiopia than they do with the Muslim low-landers."

Perhaps in response to the dilemma, Afwerki recently suggested that the only way to deal with the conflict between the two popular fronts may be to abolish them and encourage the development of a new multipartyism with open and free elections.

To this end, technical assistance has been provided by both Norway and France. Non-EPLF supporters, however, are complaining that Afwerki's transitional government is not proceeding fairly. Specifically cited by the ELF is the fact that blue ballots are being used for "Yes" votes and red ballots for "No" votes, making a true secret ballot impossible.

But Eritreans have a strong national identity stemming from the 30-year war waged by the territory's nine ethnic groups, who fought alongside each other against Ethiopia.

The government will need to draw heavily upon that strength to build national unity now.

In the coastal city of Masawa, which was 90 percent destroyed by Ethiopian bombers in 1990, Suleiman Abdu Ali, 41, a soldier with the ELF during the war, warns that today's optimism is fragile and must be nourished by careful policies. "There will be problems later if we aren't treated fairly," he says. "We're all happy today, but I don't know if we will be tomorrow." *


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


REFUGEES RETURN AFTER HARROWING TREKS


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 694 words


DATELINE: Freetown, Sierra Leone


 

Mariama Kemokai, smiles as she lifts her gray sweater to wipe the sweat from her thin face, revealing a child-bearing belly as wrinkled and rippled as the ocean she is sailing on.

But her smile disappears as she considers her recent past. She is one of 226 refugees heading back to Sierra Leone on a boat chartered by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Lutheran World Service. Most have been through three wars in as many years. The fighting at home forced them and at least 350,000 others to escape across the eastern border to Guinea and to Liberia, a country where war and famine claimed more than 60,000 lives in 1990 alone. 

Liberia's wars often eclipse the problems of its neighbor, but Sierra Leone's troubles are devastating. A guerrilla invasion has wrecked the economy and displaced up to a quarter of the country's 4 million people. More than 120,000 face starvation in an area inaccessible to relief workers.

Turmoil in the region began in December 1989, when Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor and a band of his fighters invaded Liberia from Cote d'Ivoire to depose the brutal regime of Samuel Doe. The fighting ballooned into a civil war that left Doe dead and Liberia in ruins. It ended in November 1991 when West African troops sailed into the city and forced a cease-fire.

Angered that Sierra Leone had allowed the airport to be used to transport soldiers and weapons to Liberia, Taylor sent a group of rebels to invade Sierra Leone in April 1991.

Boakarie Kamara, a 65-year-old farmer, remembers. The cocoa and coffee harvest had just ended, and he was resting on the mattress of his iron bed in the southeastern village of Zimi. A group of teenagers with guns ordered him to his feet and threw him into jail with 300 other suspected spies.

In Sierra Leone and Liberia, your next breath often depends on how many amphetamines a young rebel has popped that day, how much booze he has swallowed, how much marijuana he has inhaled or how long it has been since he ate.

Kamara would think about this many times after he and his family fled to Liberia. So would Mariama Kemokai and her six young children, the strongest of whom carried his grandmother on his back to Liberia after the rebels invaded their home.

Many never made it out of Sierra Leone. Those who did not perish in the invasion faced further hardship once they crossed the Mano river into Liberia. The months of walking, scavenging for food and sleeping rough took their toll. Kemokai's old mother and two of her children fell ill and died. Boakarie Kamara lost a child to measles.

John Lissa, 43, is returning home for the second time. He has not seen his family since last summer when rebels of the United Liberation Movement of Democracy for Liberia attacked Liberia, from Sierra Leone, pursuing Taylor's National Patriotic Front fighters.

The attack left refugees little time. "When we were running I don't know which direction they went," says Musa Kamara of his three children, still missing. "They are living, they are not living, I don't know. I am living, I am not living, they don't know."

Most of the refuges who did not flee to Liberia went north to Lofa county to face disease and starvation. An estimated 120,000 Sierra Leoneans are still stranded there without adequate food or medical care. *


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SIERRA LEONE ON THE CUSP OF A REVOLUTION


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1694 words


DATELINE: Freetown, Sierra Leone


 

I had heard nothing but the worst about Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital. The picture I had was of buildings falling apart, piles of trash on every street corner, and roads that were a moonscape the color of Mars. But what I found on arrival was a city in bloom, bursting with the energy of a modern-day revolution.

My first view of Freetown, the capital, was from a Greek boat that was transporting Sierra Leonean refugees who were returning home through a voluntary repatriation program run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Lutheran World Service. From the deck of the Remvi, the afternoon sun revealed the dramatic coastline of a city huddled between mountains that plunge into the Atlantic. One story has it that the country was given its name by Portuguese explorers who, after hearing thunder tremble through the peaks, came up with Sierra Leone, meaning lion mountain.

The returning refugees were from the countryside, and most had never visited the capital. If they had, they would have hardly recognized the city they were about to enter. 

On nearly every block, groups of young people were digging ditches, painting curbstones, planting trees, filling potholes and painting and refurbishing buildings. One youth painted these

words to a Michael Jackson song along a street wall: "If you want to make the world a better place, take a look at yourself and make a change." The favorite paint colors appear to be green, white and blue, the colors of the government of 28-year-old president, Capt. Valentine Strasser, and it is his revolution they have joined.

Strasser ousted President Joseph Momoh one year ago, inheriting a guerrilla war that had spilled over from neighboring Liberia and a devastated economy, the result of decades of corruption. While people in nearly every other country in sub- Saharan Africa are pushing for democratic elections, the impoverished of Freetown say it is a luxury they can not yet afford.

One young man who helps organize a clean-up crew along the beach -- they call themselves the Beach Boys -- told me Freetown's youth are too preoccupied with other problems to worry about voting. "Right now they don't want anything democratic because we have a lot of problems to be solved before we can give power to any civilian."

Strasser has wasted no time in showing his military muscle. Last December the government executed 29 alleged coup plotters on a Freetown beach. People took to the streets afterward, not to protest the killings, but to praise the government for dealing harshly with anyone who might threaten their new-found hope that the corruption of the past is being cleared away as quickly as the sewage from the gutters.

The government has successfully used the clean-up campaign to symbolize a deeper transformation of Sierra Leone from a country where only an elite prospers to one that delivers services to the poor. Electricity and water, although still sporadic, have been restored to city neighborhoods. Soldiers inspect yards on the last Saturday of each month. Anyone found with dirty property has to dig ditches.

Only time will tell if the improvements to Freetown are merely a makeover to distract from the government's more pressing problems, like the war that has virtually halted diamond mining and severely cut agricultural production. My departure from Freetown showed me that Sierra Leoneans have more to be concerned about than they know, and that those who do know are afraid to talk.

While nursing a Coca-Cola at the port before boarding the ferry that shuttles passengers to the Lungi Airport, I entertained myself watching tourists (yes, Freetown even has tourists) take pictures and videos. I wondered how long they were going to get away with it. In most African countries with military governments, taking pictures at ports, airports or anywhere else considered strategic is prohibited.

I kept my eye on a couple of soldiers in a shiny new red Pajero with a big fat dent in it, accompanied by two decked-out girlfriends inspecting their fingernails in the back seats. The men ignored the tourists. But then one of their buddies in civilian clothes showed up. He wore dark sunglasses and a pair of binoculars hung around his muscular neck.

He began waving his finger and shouting at the tourists to put away their cameras, saying it was forbidden to take pictures

after 5 p.m. It was about 5:02, and nobody was aware of this "rule." By this time the soldiers had joined in harassing the tourists. Finally the man with the binoculars snatched a video camera, opened it and gave the tape to a soldier who tried to pry it apart. He threw it on the ground, crushed it with his foot and tossed it in the water. The tourist turned red and clasped his face with his hands. I wondered how many Sierra Leoneans suffered worse fates for violating "rules" they knew nothing about.

Once on the ferry, the man with the binoculars further exercised his authority, ordering everyone off the top deck where a little band was playing gospel music. He said it was "the VIP deck," aware or unaware that diplomats were among those clapping and singing along.

The ride from the ferry dock to the airport was a harrowing trip on a two-lane road. The soldiers and their buddy were in a big hurry and it was dusk, when many cars had not yet put on their headlights. After honking its horn and making several attempts to pass, the Pajero zipped into the lane of oncoming traffic and flew past the van I was riding in, forcing at least one approaching car onto the shoulder of the road.

But it was at the airport where I really began to think that Sierra Leoneans have something to worry about. I was on stand-by for a flight back to Abidjan, and I had to fight my way to the ticket counter through dozens of people who already had reservations. When I got there, they told me there was no more room. As I stood there contemplating my next move, I noticed soldier upon soldier, bejeweled girlfriend upon bejeweled girlfriend, breezing past the ticket counter, waving to customs officials and making their way to the plane.

My plane.

I thought it was time to take a peek at the passenger list. Of more than 100 names, only about six were checked off. All around me there were people whose names were on the list, and they were being told there was no room on the plane, although being on stand-by, I had nothing to complain about. "It's corruption," one man told the ticket counter assistant, who shrugged his shoulders. A woman burst into tears. Some sympathetic men, also vying for seats, urged someone to help her. I considered dredging up a tear or two myself.

But I had another dilemma. I knew it was likely there were still seats on that plane. All I had to do was fork over a few dollars to the ticket man, and I would be on my way. I have never gotten used to paying bribes, although as a reporter often trying to get into prohibited places quickly, it is a necessary evil.

This time, however, after seeing such hope and such determination for change in Freetown, I couldn't bring myself to do it. It was a small thing (made a little bigger by the fact that I would have had to spend another night or two or three in the Lungi Airport Hotel), but I felt a little proud of myself. It is not often that I feel proud in Africa, where reporters make their living off people's misery, writing pieces that invariably wind up at the bottom of an editor's story list.

But then, right there in the Lungi Airport, a little miracle happened. There was another plane.

The ticket man said, "Who's going to Abidjan?" My hand shot up like a rocket as I screamed, "Me!" along with a couple of others, including the woman in tears. The rest were trying to get to Accra, Ghana. Total confusion broke out. An official grabbed my passport, the ticket man grabbed my ticket, and I was being rushed to this and that booth to pay my "airport tax."

It was $12. I only had a $20. "I don't have change," the tax man said, obviously unaware that I had seen him take about 30 $1 bills from a group of Americans leaving the country. I had no time to argue. I was rushed to customs where a woman said to hand over a few dollars so I wouldn't waste time with a bag search and miss my plane.

So much for my resolve against corruption.

Hopefully Sierra Leoneans will have greater resolve and their revolution will turn out as good as those boys on the street made it look. *


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


RWANDA SECOND ONLY TO SOMALIA IN FOOD NEEDS, RED CROSS SAYS


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Rwanda could become another "major humanitarian catastrophe," according to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC). In an appeal for assistance, the Red Cross says some 900,000 refugees displaced by civil war are dependent on donated food, and a minimum of 13,000 tons is needed each month to feed them.

Civil war has necessitated an increase in the ICRC's budget for Rwanda from $10.5 million to $85.6 million, and Rwanda is now the organization's second largest operation in Africa, after Somalia.

"Famine is imminent, and severe malnutrition has been detected in children under five," the ICRC says in its statement this month. *


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


WAR ON WILDLIFE


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Along with the human suffering caused by Rwanda's civil war, the conflict has taken a toll on the gorilla population that inhabits the Virunga Volcano Mountains shared by Rwanda, Uganda and Zaire. Mountain gorillas are the most endangered of the three gorilla sub-species, and today they are only to be found in the Virunga.

It was here that naturalist Dian Fossie spent 18 years researching the rare animals until her still-unexplained murder in 1985. The mountains are also where much of the heaviest fighting in the war has occurred, and the sounds of war have frightened many of the gorillas away. 

Fighting in February also forced staff to flee the Karisoke Research Station, established by Fossey and supported by the U.S.- based Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund. Buildings were looted, and anti- poaching squads first introduced by Fossey in 1967 had to leave the area, according to the Associated Press.

The government accuses the rebel Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF) of using the Volcano National Park as a base and of responsibility for the Karisoke raid. The rebels say it was the work of government troops and locals. The RPF claims to have evidence that government forces last year killed a legendary gorilla named Titus.

Representatives of the Fossey Fund in the United States have appealed to both the government and the rebels to leave the animals unharmed and to keep the fighting out of the park.

Political turmoil has taken its toll on animals in this region before. During the brutal reign of Idi Amin in neighboring Uganda, soldiers moonlighting as poachers decimated the area's elephants. Uganda's elephant population dropped from about 30,000 in 1971, when Amin seized power, to less than 2,000 when he was ousted in 1979. The stock is now estimated to have increased to just over 3,000, thanks to a concerted effort by Uganda's current government. * (by Charles Onyango-Obbo


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


REBELLION ADDS MOMENTUM TO RWANDA REFORM


BYLINE: Charles Onyango-Obbo * Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1800 words


DATELINE: Inside rebel-controlled Rwanda


 

The last time I visited the Katuna border post on Uganda's frontier with Rwanda, in late 1990, an insurgency that was then two months old looked well on the way to defeat. Rwandan government troops had just retaken control of the area from the rebel Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF).

But a return trip to the Katuna area reveals a very different picture. The nearest government position is about 50 miles (81 kilometers) away, and the border post swarms with RPF soldiers dressed mostly in uniforms seized from overrun government positions.

Negotiations to end the 30-month-old civil war have produced a tentative settlement, and plans are underway for international observers to monitor a cease-fire and oversee elections. But the resumption of fighting in February, following earlier peace talks and a lull in the killing, has demonstrated the difficulty of resolving the country's long-standing differences. 

My journey with the RPF began with a drive from the Katuna border post to a reception center for journalists 15 miles (24 kilometers) inside northern Rwanda. The trip took us through the Mulindi Tea Estate, the largest in Rwanda, which according to the RPF produces 60 percent of the country's tea exports. Rebels say the loss of control over Mulindi, with its modern tea factory, is seriously straining the government economically. Tea is Rwanda's second largest foreign exchange earner after coffee.

Northern Rwanda has a beautiful but torturously hilly countryside. Finding a naturally flat space as large as a football field is rare. To reach the battle front to the south, we had to get out of our van several times so it could climb the steep hills. At times, we had to help by pushing.

All along the way, we saw young guerrillas weighed down with supplies walking the hills with apparent ease. "These kids are tough," says Frank Bamugambagye, the RPF's political commissar. "That's why we beat the government soldiers, who are used to a comfortable life."

Roots of Rebellion. The rebel invasion was launched on October 1, 1990, when about 7,000 Rwandan refugees who were soldiers in the Ugandan army deserted their posts and entered Rwanda.

The East African nation, southwest of Uganda, is about the size of Maryland with a population of more than 7 million. For most of the past two decades, Rwanda appeared politically stable and economically successful.

But the country's past has come back to haunt it. For centuries, the tall and elegant Tutsi people ruled Rwanda, even though they formed only about one-tenth of the populace. Their domination was deeply resented by the shorter, stocky Hutu.

Despite their differences, the Tutsi and Hutu speak the same language and share a common culture. Scholars tend to view them as sub-groups of the same ethnic stock. Liberal Rwandese intellectuals from both groups characterize the distinction as one of class, solidified into ethnic hostility by a divide-and-rule Belgian colonial policy that set Tutsi apart as superior to Hutu.

Belgium shifted its allegiances, however, when Tutsi leaders began to call for independence in the post-World War II years, and the colonial authorities stood by when the Hutu rebelled in 1959. Thousands of Tutsi were killed, and nearly 600,000 fled to Uganda, Tanzania and Zaire.

The majority of the Tutsi refugees settled in Uganda, where many found a political home in Uganda's National Resistance Army in the early 1980s. The army, led by Yoweri Museveni, seized power in Uganda in 1986, with thousands of Tutsi in senior military posts.

When many of those fighters joined the invasion of Rwanda in 1990, the Rwandan government -- and some outside observers as well -- believed that Museveni, now Uganda's president, should have taken steps to discourage or stop the attack. Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana accused Museveni of direct complicity in the rebel action. But Museveni, who was in New York attending a United Nations meeting at the time, denied any foreknowledge or responsibility.

Tutsi rebels say they launched the invasion to force the government to restore citizenship for 2 million exiled Rwandans and to press Habyarimana for an end to one-party rule.

The exact number of Rwandan refugees in surrounding countries is a matter of dispute, but Habyarimana's government has refused to allow them to come home, where population density is already the highest in Africa. Within Rwanda, Tutsi still face discrimination, although job and school entry quotas are defended by government authorities as affirmative action steps to correct past inequities against the Hutu.

A fight that won't die. The 1990 invasion by the RPF went well for a few days, then turned sour. Military chief Fred Rwigyema, who had been a general in the Ugandan Armed Forces, was killed by a sniper's bullet. The charismatic Rwigyema had gained a larger-than-life stature, and his death was a major blow for the front. Within weeks, another tier of commanders was killed in an ambush. By the time I visited Katuna at the end of November 1990, many RPF soldiers had been killed and thousands had been scattered by the counter assault of the Rwandan army.

But about this time, Maj. Paul Kagame took command of the RPF. As an officer of the Ugandan army, Kagame had been in the United States enrolled in a military training course when the invasion began. Tall and lanky, with oval-shaped spectacles sitting on a sharp nose, he looks more like an absent-minded professor than a soldier.

When he arrived on the scene, he pulled together about 2,000 men and holed up for several months in the cold, heavily forested Virunga mountains in northwest Rwanda. By the middle of 1991, he reportedly had rebuilt the RPF to a 15,000-strong force, and morale was high. By the end of that year, a guerrilla army that had been thought defeated began a series of successful raids on government positions. The assaults gave the RPF control of a strip of territory along the Uganda border stretching about 20 miles (32 kilometers) into Rwanda.

As a result, new efforts to find a negotiated solution were begun. After several months of haggling in the Tanzanian town of Arusha, the two sides agreed to a cease-fire, and the 51-member Organization of African Unity stepped in to monitor the peace.

Despite sporadic violations, the cease-fire held until this February, when guerrillas attacked government troops on three fronts. The renewed attacks came, the RPF says, after government- instigated violence left some 400 Tutsi dead in the northern Rwanda district of Gisenyi. The RPF accuses the district head of Habyarimana's ruling party of fomenting the trouble by appealing to old ethnic divisions and fears.

Rebel leader Kagame says the attacks were necessary "to send a strong signal that we shall not stand by and watch the murder of civilians."

By any measure, the scale of the RPF victories in the February fighting was phenomenal. In just a week of skirmishes, the rebels doubled the territory under their control. The Rwandan government, skeptical the RPF could advance so far without outside help, accused Uganda of sending ground troops, a charge the Ugandans have denied.

The RPF counters with its own charges that Rwanda is receiving help from French forces.

Paris says its 800 soldiers are in the country to protect French nationals and that it has begun withdrawing the troops as part of the peace process.

If the French did help in the February fighting, the Rwandan army gained little apparent benefit. John Bagire, the regional RPF commander, says his men easily overran ten government outposts. At several locations we visited, helmets still holding blood from fallen troops lay strewn around.

Amnesty International is investigating reports of killings of unarmed civilians and government opponents by government troops and of deliberate shootings of captured soldiers by the RPF.

In RPF-controlled areas of Rwanda, there is an eerie calm. The rebels have asked all civilians to leave, because they don't want the responsibility of caring for them and they fear infiltrators. Privately, some officers say they hope that as the number of displaced people swells, pressure will grow on Habyarimana to reach a settlement in the war.

A year ago, Habyarimana ended two decades of one-party control by agreeing to the establishment of a multiparty interim government. In mid-April, the mandate of the transitional government was extended for three months to allow conclusion of the peace talks, which are continuing in Arusha. The main sticking point seems to be the composition of a new 13,000-strong national army.

The rebels say they are confident a political settlement will be reached, although they seem ready to pursue the fighting if the government refuses to compromise. With a fighting force now approaching 40,000, the movement might well be able to continue the conflict if peace efforts fail. *


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


APRIL 26, 1993


AFRICA COVERAGE CONTINUES TO LAG


LENGTH: 440 words


 

An analysis of Africa, Asia and Latin America reporting broadcast by the "MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour" on public television last year and a comparison of National Public Radio's (NPR) coverage of Africa and the former Yugoslavia during January and February of this year show that Africa's 54 nations continue to get short shrift from news decision makers. Africa News Service compiled the information as part of our periodic survey of media treatment of Africa in the United States.

In the first half of 1992, the "NewsHour" carried more stories on Latin America and almost twice as many on Asia as on Africa. But after President George Bush announced a U.S. airlift to Somalia in August, the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Somalis found a more prominent place in U.S. news lineups generally. Coverage on "MacNeil/Lehrer" skyrocketed, with much of the reporting focusing on U.S. involvement and on American personnel. 

From January through June, the "NewsHour" did two reports on Somalia and seven on other African issues. From July through November, the program broadcast 16 reports on Somalia. In December, after U.S. troops were sent in, 19 Somalia stories were aired. Coverage of the rest of Africa dropped to three reports for the final six months of the year.

During the first two months of this year, NPR's morning and evening news programs carried 136 reports about the former Yugoslavia. In the same period, NPR did 54 stories on Africa, over half of them about the U.S.-led intervention in Somalia. Twenty- six stories were devoted to other countries on the continent.

Among the African stories receiving scant attention in the U.S. media are the crisis in Zaire, a mineral-rich nation the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, where a U.S.-installed dictator is resisting popular pressure for democratic change; the famine in southern Sudan, which threatens an estimated 3 million lives; the war in Angola, currently the world's most deadly armed conflict; the fragile peace accord in Mozambique, where United Nations observers are monitoring an end to decades of fighting; and the election campaign in Nigeria, which is one of the largest suppliers of oil to the United States. n


LOAD-DATE: April 23, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.

MAY 10, 1993


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 845 words


 

Businesses engaged in importing and exporting may be interested in a series of workshops offered by the Fritz Companies of San Francisco, CA. The workshops will be held through November in New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Seattle, San Diego, Minneapolis, Boston, Houston, Columbus and San Francisco. Fundamentals of Importing provides in-depth instruction in the different phases of importing, including U.S. Customs laws, documentation, classification, insurance, terms of sale and types of entries. Fundamentals of Exporting provides practical skills in the fine points of letters of credit, insurance, drawback, export licensing, boycott provisions, hazardous materials, and introductions to export regulations and classification principles. Principles of Drawback -- A Practical Approach to Recovering Your Import Duties provides a fundamental understanding of drawback regulations as applied to the administration of a drawback program. U.S. Customs Brokers Exam Preparation covers all areas of the broker exam given by U.S. Customs, including extensive instruction in Customs regulations, entry processing, ABI, accounting, and the 

requirements of the most recent exam. For more information, contact: Fritz companies, P.O. Box 7221, San Francisco, CA 94103; phone (415) 904-8360; fax (415) 541-7813. The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

paste, one ton of milk powder, and two tons of coconut powder. Importer: Wassim Mohey El Din, San Giovanni Company, 63 Horreya Avenue, P.O. Box 258,

Alexandria, Egypt; phone 203-546-7775; telex 54213 WASIM UN. Deadline: May 30.

* Surgical instruments. Purchaser: Assiut University, Sohag Branch, Management Headquarters, University Street, Madinat Naser, Sohag, Egypt. EDUCATION


LENGTH: 2320 words


 

The Ethiopian Research Council seeks abstracts for papers or panels for its 3rd annual convention to be held September 9-12 at Florida State University.

The theme of the convention is: Uniting Ethiopian World Scholars and Creative

Artists. Contact: Ashenafi Kebede, Center for African American Culture, Florida State University, 210 South Woodward Street B-105, Tallahassee, FL 32306.

Gender and Tropical Diseases: Facing the Challenge is the topic of a paper competition sponsored jointly by Canada's International Development Research Center and the Special Program for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR), a program of the United Nations Development Program, the World Bank and the World Health Organization. Papers should provide a basis for future research, should be submitted in English, French or Spanish (no longer than 30 typed, double-spaced pages) with a short summary in English, and may be authored by one or more persons. Papers may be based on original research or on secondary sources but must not have been published elsewhere. All submissions should offer a critical review of current knowledge about the chosen topic and focus on practical issues of disease control. Papers based on research conducted with the participation of women are encouraged. Deadline for intent 

to submit an entry is June 15. Deadline for submissions is August 15. Contact: Carol Vlassoff, TDR/World Health Organization, 1211 Geneva 27, Switzerland. Global Exchange seeks interns for summer and fall 1993. Opportunities are available for students who are self-motivated, creative and committed to building bridges between U.S. and Third World citizens. Interns work directly with staff members while taking on real responsibility in the organization. For

more information, contact: Global Exchange, 2017 Mission, San Francisco, CA 94110; phone (415) 255-7296. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to

$35,000 grants cover periods ranging from 12 to 24 months. Deadline: October 1.

Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, is sponsoring a study tour August 11 to September 4 to Senegal, Gambia and Mali. The tour is open to students only and will include lectures on the economic, political and educational systems of the three countries. Visits with local families and

trips to Goree Island, Juffure and Timbuktu are planned. Cost: $1,900 (includes

airfare, room and board, excursions, and tuition). Contact: Louis Sene, phone (909) 869-3397, fax (909) 869-3282. The Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security invites applications for the 1993 Visiting Scholar Fellowship Competition. These three-month fellowships are available to scholars from Africa and other regions outside of the United States who want to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. Applicants

may not be residents of the United States. Contact: SSRC, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax (212) 370-7896. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting

in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers International Fellowship Programs within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already

reside in the United States. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone (616) 968-1611. Rotary International's 25,000 clubs worldwide administer thousands of grants

yearly for study abroad to students from around the world. Contact: Rotary Headquarters, One Rotary Center, 1560 Sherman Avenue, Evanston, IL 60201; phone (708) 866-3000. The Johann Jacobs Foundation funds doctoral and independent research on the study of youth in a changing world. African researchers are encouraged to

apply. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland. The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African academicians and development professionals who have demonstrated commitment to grass-roots development through professional careers in research, teaching or public administration. Candidates must live and work in Africa and have the endorsement of a local institution or organization. The foundation does not require fellows to take a leave of absence from their positions. However, fellows are expected to devote sufficient time to complete the project within either the 12- or 24-month grant period. Grants range from $30,000 to $50,000.

Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone (202) 673-3916; fax (202) 673-3810; telex 6711367. Fellowships for journalists from developing countries are offered by the United Nations Correspondents Association's Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Scholarship Fund. The fellowships are awarded to enable journalists to report on the annual three-month UN General Assembly session for their news organizations. Applicants must be full-time professional journalists between the ages of 25 and 35, with a good working knowledge of English and employed by

recognized print or broadcast media organizations. Contact: Judy Aita, Room C-310, UN Secretariat Building, New York, NY 10017. Earthwatch supports research expeditions teaming volunteers with scientists and scholars working to preserve the world's endangered habitats and species and to promote health and international cooperation. Researchers interested in volunteer support may submit a two-page outline of the research subject and

design, dates, budget and plans for use of volunteers to: The Center of Field Research, Earthwatch Headquarters, 680 Mount Auburn Street, P.O. Box 403, Watertown, MA; phone (617) 926-8200. in pursuing a master's program for the 1993-94 academic year. Contact: International Graduate Program Coordinator, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, 113 Kasr El Aini Street, P.O. Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt. The African Studies Center and the Department of Teacher Education at Michigan State University are offering the course, "Education, Society and Learning in an African Context," from June 30 to August 1, 1993, in Zimbabwe. In addition to participation by undergraduates, the program's sponsors encourage practicing teachers to enroll in the program and earn either graduate credits or CEUs.

Contact: John Metzler, phone (517) 353-1700, or Anne Schneller, phone (517) 355-5522.

African Higher Education: A Bi-Annual Journal of Research and Practice seeks manuscripts on issues of general significance to the advancement of African higher education. Project descriptions, position papers and research articles

are acceptable. Manuscripts must not exceed 15 double-spaced pages. Contact: Toba Unuigbey, P.O. Box 10076, University of North Texas Station, Denton, TX 76203. The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a unit of the New York Public Library's Research Libraries, offers a Scholars-in-Residence Program to assist scholars and professionals whose research in the black experience can benefit from extended access to the center's collections. The program encompasses projects in African, African American, and African Caribbean history and culture. Fellowships allow recipients to spend six months to a year in residence with access to resources at the Schomburg Center and the New York Public Library. Persons seeking support for research leading to degrees are not eligible. Foreign nationals are also ineligible unless they have resided in the United States for three years immediately preceding the award date of the fellowship. Fellows receive stipends of $15,000 for six months and up to $30,000 for 12 months. They must work full time on their projects and may not

be employed during the period in residence. Contact: Arnold Rampersad and Hylan Lewis, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone (212) 491-2203. The Education Re-Entry Program of the Rockefeller Foundation is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies in the United States, Canada and Europe and who have an interest in issues related to education revitalization and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The program has been established to assist fellows who have been supported under the Rockefeller Foundation's African Dissertation Internship Program, as well as those trained under the auspices of other organizations. Proposals must include an explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined.

Contact: The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; or The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya. The Fulbright Scholar Program offers lecturing and research awards worldwide. Grant opportunities are available to U.S. citizens with a Ph.D. or equivalent professional degree. Language skills are needed for some lecturing assignments; most are in English. Many awards allow scholars to propose their own lecturing

or research projects. Deadline: August 1 for most programs. Contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Box GPOS, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone (202) 686-7877. The Joel Gregory Prize is awarded every two years for the best book on Africa in the area of the social sciences and humanities that has been written by a Canadian, a landed immigrant or an African who has studied in Canada. Books published between January 1, 1991, and December 31, 1992, are eligible for this year's prize. The prize is sponsored by the Canadian Association of African

Studies. Contact: Bogumil Jewsiewicki, Celat-Faculte des Lettres, Pavillon Charles De Koninck, Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada G1K 7P4.

VISITORS

Life and Culture. Trenton: Africa World Press, 1990. $19.95 (cloth). $14.95 (paper). 127 pp. Children's educational book.

E X H I B I T I O N S


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Washington, DC Through January 2, 1994

"Astonishment and Power: Kongo Minkisi & the Art of Rene Stout"

Contact: Smithsonian Institution, National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Avenue, S.W., Washington, DC 20560; phone (202) 357-4600, weekdays; (202) 357-2700, weekends. Durham, NC Through May 30

"Children's Photographs: Portraits and Dreams -- Durham and South Africa"

Contact: Hayti Heritage Center Gallery, 804 Old Fayetteville Street, Durham, NC 27701; phone (919) 683-1709. Atlanta, GA Through July 3

"African Reflections: Art From Northeastern Zaire"

MAY 10, 1993


AFRICAN WILDLIFE FOUNDATION GOES BIRD WATCHING
African Wildlife Foundation


LENGTH: 760 words


DATELINE: April 29, 1993 WASHINGTON, DC


 

The African Wildlife Foundation (AWF) is taking part in an eight-month survey of the Fischer's lovebird, endemic to Tanzania, beginning May 1993. With large numbers of the Fischer's lovebird having been traded internationally to supply the pet industry, there is concern that this exploitation has seriously depleted wild populations. Collaborating institutions for the study include the World Conservation Union's Species Survival Commission, the Tanzania Department of Wildlife and Tanzania National Parks. This is the first management-oriented field study in Tanzania of a bird species that is traded to a significant extent. 

"I don't think most people realize the FIscher's lovebird, a common pet in the United States and other industrialized countries, may actually be an endangered species in the wild," said AWF Executive Vice President Diana E. McMeekin. "This survey will give all parties concerned a better idea of the extent of the exploitation in trade that has occurred and a stronger foundation for continued conservation efforts."

The survey will initially focus on the Serengeti National Park in Tanzania where there are known, good and unexploited populations of Fischer's lovebird. The field work will coincide with the breeding season and the dry season. The survey will assess the current status of the bird in Tanzania and estimate a minimum and maximum population size. Researchers, led by ornithologist Dave Moyer, will interview bird trappers and traders in order to determine seasonal movements, aspects of the past trade, such as trapping methods and post trapping mortality levels and the significance of the trade to local economies. The study will also make recommendations for the management and conservation of the bird and establish the framework for a long-term monitoring system.

The Unites States, Japan, Belgium, the Netherlands, the Federal Republic of Germany and the United Kingdom have imported the Fischer's lovebird (Agapornis ficheri) in the past decade to supply the pet trade. The European community banned the import of the bird from Burundi and Rwanda in 1986 and from Tanzania in 1988. The United States banned the import of Fischer's lovebird in October 1992 under the Wild Bird Conservation Act. Tanzania began to regulate the trade under a quota system in 1988. In response to continued concerns raised by the Conventions on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), the government enacted a zero annual harvest quota in 1992. Unfortunately, it is probable that illegal trade of the birds continues.

The brightly colored Fischer's lovebird, measuring five and one-half inches in length, has a green body, orange forehead, cheeks and throat, and a yellow crown. Usually found in northern Tanzania and occasionally in southern Kenya, the bird travels in flocks in open grasslands, acacia woodland and dry bush country. The sound it makes is a high-pitched whistle.

Initial funding for the survey has been provided by two African Wildlife Foundation trustees, Henry P. McIntosh IV and George G. Matthews. Celebrating more than 30 years of service, the African Wildlife Foundation is the largest American conservation organization working solely in Africa. AWF assists African governments in their struggle to conserve natural resources by funding conservation projects, giving aid to parks and reserves and aiding in conservation education. AWF's newly created Planning and Assessment for Wildlife Management (PAWM) project works with the Tanzania Department of Wildlife on ways to achieve a sustainable, humane and economically sound bird trade. -30NW, Washington, DC 20036. Phone: 202-265-8394/8393, fax: 202-265-2361.

CONTACT: Shawn Sandor, African Wildlife Foundation, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue,


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


WORLD FOOD PROGRAMME PROVIDES EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE TO TOGOLESE REFUGEES IN BENIN
World Food Programme


LENGTH: 480 words


DATELINE: COTONOU, May 13, 1993


 

With the continuing influx of Togolese refugees into Benin, the World Food Programme today announced it will provide an additional 5,060 metric tons of food aid to meet the needs of an increased number of refugees requiring assistance.

In the last two months the number of refugees without adequate shelter and in need of food assistance has dramatically risen, from 40,000 in March to 100,000 todya, according to WFP and UNHCR.

Mounting civil unrest and growing insecurity in Togo, particluarly in the capital Lome, has forced an estimated 400,000 people to flee the country into neighboring Benin and Ghana, or escape up-country. Although many of these refugees and displaced persons are integrated into local families or living with relatives, others are living in churches and temporary shelters and are in dire need of relief assistance. 

A joint WPF/UNHCR assessment mission which visited Benin reports that more than 160,000 refugees have entered the country to seek asylum. About 100,000 of these refugees are in need of emergency assistance.

WFP -- the food aid organization of the United Nations -- last March approved the supply of 3,600 tons of emergency food aid for 40,000 refugees encamped in the capital, Cotonou, in Porto Novo, and in border cities such as Agoue, Grand-Popo, Lokossa, Athienne and Aplauhoue. The food was sufficient to meet the needs of the refugees for six months but, because of the increase in refugee numbers, the food is not enough and will run out by end of June.

The new tranche of food aid -- 4,800 tons of maize, 720 tons of pulses, 300 tons of vegetable oil, 180 tons of sugar and 60 tons of salt -- is enough to cover the needs of 100,000 refugees in Benin for an additional four-month period, from July to the end of October 1993.

WFP rations will be distributed to the refugees by Caritas and the Benenese Red Cross under the supervision of UNHCR.

In Ghanam the Programme is already providing 4,500 tons of emergency relief food to 50,000 Togolese refugees settled in the country's border towns between Ho and Kadjebi in the Volta region. -30Mitchell, Public Affairs, Rome, phones: 39-6-5797-5925, 5797-5593, 6-540-2313

CONTACT: J. Bagarishya, World Food Program, Cotonou; phone: 229-314892

(radio interviews); fax: 6-540-8306.


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

MAY 10, 1993


U.S./AFRICA POLICY: LETTER TO WARREN CHRISTOPHER, SECRETARY OF STATE


LENGTH: 587 words


 

May 6, 1993

The Honorable Warren Christopher

Secretary of State

Department of State

Washington, DC 20520

Dear Mr. Secretary,

We are deeply concerned that the Administration is considering the possibility of lowering financial aid financing for the Development Fund for Africa in order to pay for Russian aid. We are writing to you to express our strong support for maintaining, if not increasing, the funding level for development assistance to Africa.

We acknowledge that the U.S. must sacrifice to support the transition to democracy in Russia. But we insist that this sacrifice not come from the DFA, which is already at the minimum acceptable level. Sub-Saharan Africa is the poorest region in the world, and has been recognized as the principle development challenge facing the international community today. Some twenty-five nations in Africa are undertaking transitions to democracy and market economies, similar to the transition underway in Russia. Indeed, Africans share the same aspirations as Russians and look to the United States for support. Since 1988, the DFA has been an effective instrument for programming U.S. support for long-term development in Africa. In this era of political and economic reform, Africa needs DFA resources more than ever, and has greater capacity to use them effectively. 

We were extremely pleased that National Security Advisor Anthony Lake chose to make his first formal foreign policy address on Africa. He stated that the Clinton Administration is committed to a serious engagement in Africa. We believe that the credibility of this commitment will be seriously eroded if the funding levels for the DFA are not maintained or increased.

We would like to meet with you as soon as possible to discuss these issues.

Sincerely,

Paul Simon

Chairman, Subcommittee on African Affairs

Harry Johnston

Chairman, Subcommittee on Africa

Donald M. Payne

Member of Congress

James M. Jeffords

Ranking Minority Member, Subcommittee on African Affairs

Dan Burton

Ranking Minority Member, Subcommittee on Africa

CONTACT: Congress of the United States, Washington, DC 20515


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.

MAY 10, 1993


CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHTS PROJECT REPORTS ON SEVERE RESTRICTIONS FACING THE NIGERIAN PRESS


SECTION: DOSSIER. . .


LENGTH: 947 words


 

LAGOS, NIGERIA -- The Constitutional Rights Project, CRP, has decried the severe restrictions under which the press in Nigeria operate.

In a report entitled, "The Crisis of Press Freedom in Nigeria," the CRP observed that the press in Nigeria has been a victim of government high-handedness and arbitrariness, especially under military rule.

The CRP report, deriving from a year-long study of the practice of press freedom in Nigeria, listed several cases of harassment, arrest and detention of journalists, forced closure of media houses, promulgation of arbitrary decrees and laws, and the general uncertainty in the practice of journalism, which the CRP says underscores "The Crisis of Press Freedom in Nigeria."

From December 31, 1983, when the military again intervened in national politics up till the end of 1992 (a period of 7 years), the report cited more than 46 instances of the arrest and detention of journalists. 

The Report also cited instances of suspension and/or dismissal of journalists in government owned media houses for publishing embarrassing stories or news.

The CRP also cited the killing by parcel bomb in October 1986 of the founding editor of "Newswatch" Magazine, Dele Giwa, as a violent attack on the practice of journalism in Nigeria.

Further attacks on the press cited in the report include the closure of newspaper houses. In 1990 alone, more than five newspapers/magazines were shut down by the military government, while two media houses were closed in 1992.

Prominent among closed media houses listed in the report include "The Guardian," "Vanguard," "Punch," "Lagos News," "Champion," "Concord," "Newswatch" and "Newbreed Magazine."

The Report particularly criticized the trend under the military of curtailing press freedom. CRP investigations published in this report also showed that the statutory provisions relating to protection of press freedom are inadequate.

The Report examined the constitutional provisions on human rights and criticized the failure of the Nigerian Constitution to specifically guarantee press freedom, contrary to the recommendation of the Political Bureau set up by the military government to articulate popular opinion on Nigeria's future political direction.

On censorship, CRP's report observed that while there is no prior censorship of the press in Nigeria, the restriction on the activities of the press through the arrests and detention of journalists and the closure of media houses has induced a pattern of self-censorship, inimical to free reporting of events and news.

The CRP criticized the structure of ownership of the mass media in Nigeria, which it said is a limiting factor to the flow of information; particularly with government ownership of all the more than 80 electronic broadcasting stations in the country. The Report commended the plurality of print media in Nigeria, describing it as impressive.

The report called for the abrogation of restrictive laws on the press, naming specifically the Official Secrets Act of 1962, and the provision of the Criminal and Penal Codes on sedition.

While commending the liberalization of the ownership of electronic media, the Report called for an amendment to the Nigerian Broadcasting Commission Decree No. 38 of 1992, which authorizes the ownership of private broadcasting stations, with a view to expunging from its text the provision authorizing the minister of Information to give directives to the commission.

CRP's Report further called for specific constitutional restraint against government and security agencies forbidding the closure of media houses, while journalists accused of violating the law should be treated in accordance with the process which requires prompt and fair trial before competent courts.

As Nigeria seeks to achieve democracy for its people, there is the need to promote openness and deplore secrecy "in the conduct of all forms of official business," the report added.

Finally, CRP described the current state of press freedom in Nigeria, as falling very much below the standards set by the international bill of rights and the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights and stated that the need to redress this shortcoming is an urgent task for the government and people of Nigeria.

CONTACT: Clement Nwankwo or Basil Ugochukwu, Constitutional Rights Project, 21 James Robertson Street, P.O. Box 4447, Surulere, Lagos, Nigeria.

Phone: 234-1-843041.


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


83 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


INADEQUATE SHELTER: WHY A SPECIAL FOCUS ON URBAN WOMEN?


LENGTH: 1760 words


DATELINE: From ARISE (Uganda)


 

After all, the argument goes, inadequate shelter knows no gender. However, urban policy and management today has to incorporate a gender perspective in keeping with sociological and economic trends brought about by migration to urban areas.

There are two distinct facts about women and shelter that are important. First, it is estimated that women are de facto heads of nearly a third of households worldwide; secondly, women play an increasingly economic role in human settlements, though they are the lowest paid workers in the formal sector. What remains a constant, and forms the anchor for the two phenomena, is the traditional role of women as the pivot of the household.

In all these areas, and their accompanying roles and responsibilities, men and women experience and react differently -- with different priorities and needs. Significantly, women spend a greater proportion of their earnings on the family; so when women work, children enjoy better food health care and education. 

Furthermore, the improved income and education that results from shelter improvement can influence women in bringing down birth rates. In a nutshell, urban development needs to focus on women because the multiplicity of roles that women play in human settlements lends itself to the all-embracing concept of sustainability.

Despite their new roles, women still spend the greatest amount of time in the house. What, however, needs attention are the new kinds of economic activities that are now carried on in the house by women who are sole income earners.

House design and layout of settlements are of crucial importance to the multifarious roles that women play today. For example, in hot climates, women may want large verandas where they can combine an income-generating activity like sewing or retailing with child-minding activities. The provision of child-care facilities within the settlement also frequently determines the women's ability to work outside the home as opposed to being forced to accept exploitative subcontracting work. So also, they may prefer plots to be grouped around services so that domestic work can be socialized. The layout of settlements is especially important in societies where services inhibit the free movement of women.

Urban Services

It is in this traditional role of being concerned with the maintenance and running of the household and community, that women are in a position to offer advice and insights into the delivery of urban services.

At the micro level, this could include the choice and location of waterpumps. Waterpump handles have been broken because they had been designed for men. Women and children could not use them correctly. For example, the siting of toilets needs to be such that they meet the needs of women for privacy. Similarly, women are invariably in charge of the refuse disposal of the household and their involvement in garbage collection and disposal schemes can contribute immeasurable to a physically cleaner environment and to elimination of much wastage and inefficiency.

Women voluntarily come to the forefront where basic services (like water and sewerage) and social services are concerned. In Lima, Peru, though men were the main leaders of the BARRIO committee, women arranged special marches to claim the right to have water connections. The efficacy of women's committees, despite male dominance in matter of political participation, was greater for a variety of reasons.

For instance, while the women's committee was assigned health education, food and child welfare, the men concerned themselves with the "big problems" -- getting pipelines installed, electricity and the committee's political affiliations. As a study of the area notes, "There was a surprise for the men in this neatest of arrangements. The men's possibilities were almost nil, whereas the women, with less global problems assigned to their sphere, were in a good position to achieve results.

This division of labour by gender often leads to the most effective attempts being undertaken by women in sustainable local development.

Promoting Health

Women are important actors in the health arena, which has also been their responsibility. This thrust on women as the focus of health, education and awareness was tried out in the Orangi Pilot Project, in Karachi, Pakistan.

As the Director's Annual Report (1984/85) states: "In the success of the Low Cost Sanitation Programme, housewives had played an active role. Their participation provided us with a clue to the future direction of women's programmes. That women were very conscious of the problems of health and hygiene is borne out by the fact that they paid the sanitation cost from household expenses."

Women, however, by custom, stayed at home, which created problems of access. This was sought to be overcome by the "street vendor" approach composed of mobile training teams. They provided leaflets and training about prevention of diseases common in Orangi like diarrhea, malaria and scabies. They also offered immunization of children against diseases as well as further training about sanitation and hygiene. The results of this approach speak for themselves. Preliminary investigations in September 1986 revealed that many families had been totally free from disease during the preceding six months. Further, the incidence of serious diseases had been considerably reduced.

Generating Income

New policy initiatives have to consider women in their productive capacity despite their mostly unrecognized and low visibility role in the urban economy. In several export processing zones, women form over two-thirds of the work force. However, their participation in the formal sector is often marginalized because they are passive, or non-unionized or simply because they suffer from the traditional bias, being viewed by employers as second income earners.

The situation is likely to get more difficult. Growing urban populations are giving rise to increasing employment pressures. Governments that address this problem, however, now have the potential to create innovative and imaginative approaches to women that will have a crucial impact on long-term development.

As income generators, women need to have policies directed specifically towards them rather than the usual identification of employment opportunities with men. Entrepreneurship, or indeed any income-earning capacity, should be seen as a profit-making activity rather than a subsidiary poverty-alleviation programme within the framework of community welfare. Productivity should be as important a focus as poverty alleviation. For this, women need equal address to savings and credit facilities and training in management, marketing and pricing. Besides, there is evidence that credit schemes favouring women have a good cost-recovery record.

The Need for Change

In their societal and familiar roles the critical issue for women is the right to land tenure and property ownership. This has social, economic and cultural implications which allow women to lead independent lives befitting their status of being responsible for their families. Security of tenure gives women the ability to protect themselves against domestic violence; to shake off the tag of being the dependent of a man; to use it as collateral for gaining access to credit; and the choice to view land as a form of saving which appreciates over time.

From this starting point, women can come into their own and create the kind of lives that they have tried to achieve over many centuries.

Women should not be viewed as passive victims of society who need to be protected and sheltered by social welfare programmes. Rather, the necessary social and economic conditions should be created which encourage them to go out and become equal members of the urban workforce. The urban phenomenon has created a situation where the possibilities of change and progress are enormous. It has helped break some of the barriers keeping women from achieving their full potential as creators and sustainers of growth. This opportunity needs to be taken to develop policies that will build on this trend and take full advantage and capitalize on their unique role in society in the path to sustainable development. --United Nations Centre for Human Settlements (Habitat) -30

Reprinted from ARISE, Oct.-Dec. 1992.

ARISE is published four times a year by Action for Development (ACFODE).

CONTACT: Action for Development, ACFODE House, Bukoto, P.O. Box 16729,

Kampala, Uganda. Phone: 245936.


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


84 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


FIGHTING THE FOOD DEFICIT IN THE GAMBIA
DAILY OBSERVER, April 26, 1993


BYLINE: Abdou Karim Sanneh, DAILY OBSERVER (The Gambia)


LENGTH: 507 words


 

In this era of staggering debt imposed on The Gambia, there is no quick-fix solution to agricultural development.

The Government, since independence, has not centered its agricultural development policy on cash cropping, but on food crop production to meet the basic food needs of the cross section of the populace. Today The Gambia is nearly self-sufficient in food, but the country experiences an approximate 50% deficit in cereals. There is a need to increase food crop production, raise the nutritional status of Gambians and better meet the food requirements of the population. 

To combat food deficits, crops which are high-yielding varieties should be introduced into our husbandry practices. Provision of abundant food can be assured through the use of improved crop varieties and appropriate technology. The introduction of high-yielding varieties requires intensive application of agrochemicals such as fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides, pesticides, etc. Fertilizer promotion, distribution and credit assistance, would need to be accelerated to combat the food deficit. These efforts are necessary so that agricultural production and productivity can be increased and the national objective of attaining a high degree of self sufficiency in food can be achieved.

The green revolution, which has lead to the introduction of plant breeding and seed multiplication, has raised hopes that hunger can be combatted with the application of scientific know-how. High-yielding varieties, which are often early-maturing, will increase productivity when introduced and fully adopted as extension packages. Most of our traditional grains are adapted to our environment, but due to environmental degradation and population growth, our situation now calls for the cultivation of crops which are high-yielding varieties.

In The Gambia, the sahelian drought has lead to the introduction of many improved varieties of rice, maize, millet and sorghum, most of which are drought tolerant. Traditional grains, which are naturally selected for our ecosystem, should be maintained. They are more adapted to the environment and resist flooding and other unfavorable climactic conditions than most improved crop varieties. -30

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, April 26, 1993.

SOUTH is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.

131, Banjul, The Gambia. Phone: 220-96608, 96877; fax: 220-96878


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English
