Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


ANC COULD GET ELECTORAL SHOCK
SOUTH, May 1-5, 1993


BYLINE: Christelle Terreblanche, "SOUTH" (SOUTH AFRICA)


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Until now the National Party's (NP) opposition, especially the African National Congress (ANC), has been confident of ousting the ruling party in the first democratic elections in South Africa.

Most ANC members assume their organisation's popularity will carry them to certain victory.

"However, a closer reading of the mounting evidence, including opinion polls, registration issues and the mechanics of any electoral process, leave the observer with the growing impression that the ANC's march to victory in a one-person, one-vote election will certainly not be an effortless on," says Andrew Reynolds, who authored "Voting for a New South Africa" while teaching and studying for a year at UCT.

"It is in fact quite likely that President F.W. de Klerk of the National Party, with his allies, may well have the support and do the unthinkable and actually win a non-racial, democratic election in South Africa. 

"If my readings and estimates are even a close approximation of the actual state of play, then the party which designed and operated apartheid (the NP) could well form a majority government elected by many of the very people they systematically discriminated against for over 40 years."

Polling experts describe the scientific methods used by Reynolds to arrive at this conclusion on the outcome of the election as "very

sophisticated:.

"From the evidence I have found it seems clear that the NP under F.W. de Klerk will do much better electorally than many people have presumed, possibly even being in a position to lead a coalition government and hold the majority of seats in a constituent assembly," Reynolds argues.

"At the present time there is an uneven playing field, with virtually all the advantages of political organization -- financial strength, electoral experience and media control -- lying with the NP."

Reynolds also says the NP government itself has gone into the electoral process with the belief that while it hoped to win a substantial block in parliament, they would not "win" the election.

"However, the surprise may come from the fact that they will dramatically out-poll the expectations...

"De Klerk has largely managed to dissociate himself from former government architects if apartheid and many South Africans see him as a reformer and politician of the future.

Secondly, the propensity for electoral irregularities, subtle or overt, is high in South Africa and the country has a large, rural more conservative and less educated population."

Reynolds based his assessment of the factors influencing the election outcome on analysis of, among other things, identity documents and electoral registration, the effect of illiteracy on voter turnout, the effect of political violence and intimidation and the strength and abilities of the major parties.

He calculates that 28 percent of potentially eligible black South Africans will be disenfranchised due to lack of proof of age or citizenship and that might alter the electorate in favour of the "non-black" communities (white, coloureds and Indians).

While over 30 percent of South Africans -- at least 42 percent of blacks -- are illiterate, Reynolds argues that the turnout of the illiterate voters is usually 10 percent less.

He believes the levels of intimidation and violence will be higher in the TBVC states, particularly Ciskei and Bophuthatswana, "because they are areas containing millions of potential ANC voters controlled by regimes overtly hostile to the ANC."

His "guesstimate" is that up to 16 percent of black voters might fail to turn out if high levels of violence and intimidation manifest.

The variables are seen as favouring a high turnout of NP supporters.

Based on recent surveys and projections, Reynolds gave the ANC a 40.6 percent majority of support, the NP 30 percent (including 75 percent of coloureds), the Inkatha Freedom Party 11.5 percent (arguing that the party's support is undermeasured) and a right-wing alliance 5.7 percent.

The rest, including the DP, might not acquire the necessary five percent for parliamentary representation.

But he stresses that the 10 percent majority the ANC might get could be completely eroded by the above variables.

To arrive at the conclusion that the NP could win the next elections, Reynolds used scientific methods employed in other countries.

He employed constructions used by Samuel Huntington in his book, " The Third Wave", which might be too narrow for South Africa's complexity. However, Reynolds argues that they are appropriate.

Huntington said the first democratic election after a period of authoritarian rule almost always produces a result which surprises and stuns pundits.

Reynolds believes South Africa shows some distinct similarities to the variables which influenced Huntington's analysis.

Firstly, the new leaders distanced themselves from the former authoritarian rulers; secondly, coercion, fraud and electoral irregularities played a part in the former regime's victory.

Finally, the countries concerned were largely rural/peasant societies lacking a large urban middle class which is usually a prerequisite for opposition victory in such first democratic elections. -30

Reprinted from SOUTH, May 1-5, 1993.

SOUTH is published by SOUTH Press Service Services.

CONTACT: SOUTH, 6 Russell Street, Woodstock, South Africa 7295. Phone:

021-462-2012, fax: 021-461-5407.


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


86 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


A GREAT THINKER WHO LAID FERTILE GROUNDS
THE WEEKLY MAIL, April 30 - May 6, 1993


BYLINE: Anton Harber, The Weekly Mail (SOUTH AFRICA)


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Nelson Mandela had to visit and give pep talks to various African National Congress departments this week in order to boost morale. The combined effect of the deaths of two senior leaders, Oliver Tambo and Chris Hani, the violence of the past fortnight and the slowness of negotiations were taking their toll.

It was a tribute to the standing of ANC national chairman and former president Tambo that his death was still felt so acutely by the organization, despite his having been precluded by ill health from the hurly-burly of politics for four years.

This was partly because Tambo's death represented the end of an era. The gentlemanly, old-school arch-diplomat was the living embodiment of the ANC-in-exile. Tambo's personal style combined firm principle, unbending determination and an old-worldly grace that came to characterize the ANC as a whole -- and is inevitably changing as the ANC prepares to take part in government. 

The shock in the ANC can also be attributed to the man's popularity. From battle-seasoned Umkhonto weSizwe (MK) guerrillas, through jail-hardened cadres to the gray-suited negotiations team, one struggles to find ANC members who do not express heartfelt respect for the an who led the organization during 30 years of difficult and bitter exile.

This should come as a surprise, because he was better known as a diplomat than a military leader. It was in the field of diplomacy -- gaining international acceptance for the ANC and isolating the Pretoria government -- that his achievements were enormous. He will be remembered most of all for his meetings with world leaders, his protg Thabo Mbeki almost always at his side, slowly and graciously working to undermine Western resistance to the ANC's links with the Communist Party.

And it was this manner -- and his unquestioned integrity -- that won over arch-critics in white South Africa during the first contacts with the establishment in the critical years of 1985 to 1990.

However, MK leaders, like Ronnie Kasrils, say that Tambo was loved my MK cadres because he showed unwavering commitment to their role and skillfully managed the delicate balance between military and political struggle. He often visited the camps and kept track of the details of military strategy.

But it is his political leadership and strategic planning that stand out. He was the person who, when the black consciousness upsurge of the 1970s threatened the ANC, convinced the organization it must adapt and reach out to these people, rather than see them as political competitors.

And it was he who campaigned, in crucial meetings in the late 1980s with United States Secretary of State George Schultz and Soviet Premier Mikhail Gorbachev, to take the South African struggle outside the context of the Cold War, which had deadlocked talks over Namibia and Angola.

Tambo's greatest achievement was in ensuring that during the long and traumatic years of exile, when progress was hard to demonstrate, the ANC never suffered from the kinds of debilitating splits that characterized most other liberation movements.

There were periods in which his leadership, style and policy faced serious challenges from below. The first was in the late 1960s, after the failure of the Wankie campaign, the ANC's first major military push.

It was a mark of Tambo's hands-on style that he traveled to the Zambian border with his troops to bid them farewell as they crossed into the then-Rhodesia and headed south for home in 1967.

And when the campaign failed dismally, bringing to a head frustration and discontent within the ANC, he summoned the Morogoro conference of 1969 to try to keep the organization united. That conference led to the formation of the ANC's revolutionary council, which brought together political and military leadership to plan future strategy, and opened the doors of the ANC to non-blacks.

That was followed by the breakaway of what became known as the "group of eight," a core of nationalists that challenged the Morogoro decisions. Tambo summoned what became known as the "conference in the bush," which brought all the key ANC leaders together in the Zambian countryside to thrash out the problem and keep the organization in one piece.

At both these meetings, Tambo and his associates faced harsh criticism from below and direct challenged to their leadership. At both, he heard out his opponents, responded and held on to the reins of authority.

That was his style: to listen a lot, to seek conciliation, to understand his critics and to accommodate them.

It was also his weakness. He kept the organization together because of his consensus-seeking style of leadership, but it also meant he had enormous tolerance and seldom cracked the organizational whip.

"If someone misbehaved or broke the rules, Tambo would always try to talk them round and rehabilitate them. Sometimes we wondered why he never came down harder on them," one of his closest colleagues said this week.

That was why anyone who visited the ANC in Lusaka during the 1980s found an amiable and friendly organization, marred by elements of gross inefficiency.

And it accounts for the great black mark in Tambo's leadership

history: his failure to stop the abuses in ANC camps in Angola. There is now little doubt that even when he knew about the conditions in the camps, he did not use the authority he enjoyed to make sure that they came to an end and the culprits were punished -- a major error that is still plaguing the ANC.

He has also been criticized for the fact that Operation Vula, the major attempt to reestablish an ANC underground after the Nkomati Accord drove the organization out of neighboring states, came so late. In the end, it was his political work that counted, but a stronger military position and a stronger underground could have changed the balance of power before the 1990 un-banning of the ANC.

He was often slow to decide and was given to careful consideration, detailed planning and lengthy discussion rather than swift action. Mbeki, who was almost always at Tambo's side during the 1980s, described him spending many hours thinking through problems, making extensive notes and ensuring he came to meetings with carefully prepared positions and strategies.

"He was not that good at reading prepared speeches, but he was excellent when he spoke off the cuff. People often wondered how he was able to speak so fluently and so carefully when he cast aside his notes. But then they didn't know that he would have spent three days writing the speech, so he knew exactly what and how he wanted to say it," Mbeki says.

Tambo's style stands in marked contrast to Mandela's stronger, more direct leadership. Where Tambo sought consensus, Mandela seeks support for decisions he has already made.

Tambo was, Kasrils says, a workaholic and expected the same of those around him.

He also had an element of the purist. Tambo never drank -- except during a visit to Cuba in 1987, when Fidel Castro insisted he toast the

revolution with rum. He closed his eyes, threw it back and later remarked: "That was very nice."

He also often told a story of the first time he ever wore shoes, as a Transkei child. At the age of nine, he found a pair of shoes which he put on to walk the great distance to his home. He found it difficult, but put this down to inexperience. It was only when he got home, blistered and sore, that his mother pointed out they were high-heeled women's shoes.

The picture that emerges is of drive and determination that saw him through a difficult childhood and the many sacrifices of exile.

This came partly from a driving sense of mission: his closest friend, Mandela, had gone to prison for the cause and it was only luck that had Tambo selected as the organization's external representative, enabling him to avoid prison -- something that plagued him over all those years. Says close associate

Frene Ginwala: "He would often say in difficult times, 'I have been given a task and nothing is going to stop me from fulfilling it.'" Tambo died last week, aged 75, knowing that that task -- the achievement of nonracial democracy -- was nearly, but not quite, complete.

-30

Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL, April 30-May 6, 1993

THE WEEKLY MAIL is published by M&G Media, Pty, Ltd..

CONTACT: THE WEEKLY MAIL, P.O. Box 260425, Excom, 2023, South Africa.

Phone: 011-334-2400; fax: 011-334-2905


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


N2 BILLION SCANDAL:
Nigeria Airways management flies into a murky cloud of scandals--how did it spend N2 billion without the board's knowledge? Who owns or runs Air Nigeria?


BYLINE: Ulibe Ukim, NEWSWATCH


LENGTH: 4254 words


 

Mohammed Joji is probably having his roughest time since he became the managing director of Nigeria Airways January 1992. Although Joji has been battling a number of formidable outside forces, his first in-house battle came in February when the board gave him a query.

The board wanted to know how he spent a federal government loan of $64 million (about N2.1 billion on the autonomous market rate), which the government advanced the airline to bail it out. Formal application for the loan was made in April 1992 although Joji and his team of financial advisers had been talking to government officials about it much earlier. Details of the disbursements show that the money was released between January and December much earlier than eve when the formal application was made. Many board members did not seem to have been aware of when the money was collected and how it was spent. The board now asked for details of how the money was approved and spent. Joji and Afam Nwagboso, his director of finance, were asked to furnish the board with documents showing the amounts and dates the money was released, the sequence of disbursements, the beneficiaries and what the airline benefited from the payments. 

The concern of the board is to establish on whose authority Joji expended the money which is far in excess of the N500,000.00 limit of expenditure for the airline's managing director. He has since filed his reply to the board. In it, Joji documented the expenditure and said the money was disbursed, not by him, but by a subcommittee appointed by the government of which he was a member.

The money, he said, was given to the Ministry of Finance Incorporated, MOFI, which disbursed it directly to the airline's creditors through the

Central Bank. Said Joji: "The $64 million loan was given to MOFI. Government said that every kobi spent must be accounted for to MOFI even before the board. Everything was properly documented and I have given that to the board, to the federal government and to the TCPC."

When he applied for the load, Joji said the bail was "needed urgently to enable the part payment of Nigeria Airways' long overdue operating debts, together with the accomplishment of urgent heavy maintenance that is necessary to enable the airline's aircraft to resume or continue operation in an air worthy condition." The loan covers a period of five years with a 20 percent interest. The condition which Joji built into the request was that in event of privatisation of Airways the loan will either be repaid directly from the proceeds or from the dividend to be generated by the new airline.

Throughout the negotiation for the loan, Tony Momoh, Airways chairman and member of the disbursement subcommittee provided adequate support for Joji.

The account presented by Nwagboso to the board shows that the key beneficiaries of the loan included NICON, which got $10 million on April 1, 1992 to cover the insurance premium for the airline and another $2.94 million on December 17. Equator Bank, according to the statement, received a total of #3.02 million in three installments on January 21, September 13 and October 5. Equator leasing got $12.75 million in 15 installments between January 21 and November 26. Air Lingus, the Irish firm which maintains Airways' Boeing 737, got $8.34 million in three installments on November 11, 26 and December 3.

Other beneficiaries included Sabena Techniques, $109 million, Shire Fuel, $1.97 million; Varig, $7.3 million; Jet Aerospace $494,464.08 and Aviation Equipment, $304,000. Those who challenge Joji on these figures do so apparently because the board was not in the picture when the money was spent.

An official of Jet and Aerospace, a Miami-based firm said he doubted strongly this expenditure, because no serious effort was made to ascertain the debts in the first place. "Early last year, a foreign company offered to assist in verifying creditors claim on Nigerian Airways. The idea was to challenge some of those claims that were frivolous. One Saturday, we had a meeting where $7 million was ascertained as Nigeria Airways indebtedness to Sabena, although engines, rotables and parts valued at about $32 million were being held by Sabena."

He said that before the team which included Jet Aerospace officials, Keith Bolshaw and Joji reached Brussels the next Monday, the content of the meeting was leaked to Sabena. Airways debt jumped to $11 million. "Some rotables and engines were later released by Sabena to Nigeria Airways. Since then, Bolshaw took over the negotiations. One month after, Airways' indebtedness went up to $27 million."

Jet and Aerospace said it offered its services free. But it is also known that it had a major contract with Airways at the inception of Joji's management but fell out of favour with the airline.

What is happening, Joji says, is a calculated blackmail because he opted to play differently. "Supposing I received the $64 million loan and I say let me wash a few hands, let me take $10 million here and there, you will not hear any story. It is because there was ethics and morality attached to the expenditure of that money and that the people are doing all these. The people who gave it to me trusted me."

Momoh refuses to comment on the issue. "The thing is not whether the federal government gave Nigeria Airways a loan or whether the federal government guaranteed any loan for Nigeria Airways. I cannot discuss the loan the federal government gave to Nigeria Airways or guaranteed to Nigeria Airways. The loan profile of a company is the internal affairs of that company."

Joji has another problem, and this is his link with Air Nigeria, the airline he largely put together with the help of Bolshaw, a Briton, under the auspices of the Technical Committee on Privatisation and Commercialisation, TCPC.

Aviation officials have become very skeptical of the project and the rush with which it is being implemented, even without necessary government approvals. Joji has been fingered as the culprit. A top government official even spoke of "a hidden agenda" in the implementation process of Air Nigeria package. That point, the official said, is strongly buttressed by the fact that there has been a deliberate campaign of disinformation on what has become perhaps the most difficult job for TCPC.

Air Nigeria is planned for inauguration on May 21, to coincide with the commencement of summer and the high traffic season. At least, it makes good business sense that promoters of Nigeria's new continental carrier want to position their baby in the market at a time of immense traffic prospects.

But the problem which promoters of the new airline are beginning to realise is that plans, no matter the beauty, do not always translate into reality. From indications, Air Nigeria, for months a dream, may at best remain just a dream. The new airline is trapped in an intricate web of pre-natal complications which may prove fatal.

Among its promoters -- the Technical Committee on Privatisation and Commercialisation, TCPC, the sharp division which surfaced in January over modalities for implementing the privatisation programme has deepened. Hamza Zayyad, TCPC chairman and Omowale Kuye, the secretary who also heads TCPC's subcommittee on the privatisation of Nigeria Airways, have been at loggerheads

for most of the year. Their disagreement is over what should come first: government's approval or pre-emptive action.

Zayyad's anger is that Kuye and his team have since exceeded the brief. The team which included Tony Momoh, chairman of Nigeria Airways and Joji, as well as Keith Bolshaw, a Briton and consultant to TCPC on Airways privatisation, were mandated to negotiate with prospective investors and to select a core foreign investor for the project. But it went further by assembling a start-up team at a time when government had not approved the plan.

In fact, up-till last week, government's only approval to TCPC's plans had been on how to privatize the airways. Emeka why it chose Air Nigeria as better privatisation option. These are the debts problem of Nigeria Airways, the non-availability of audited accounts on which the capital market could determine the company's share price, the inefficient administrative and operational procedures which are not easily amenable to change and the need to develop an entirely new organization to provide efficient, reliable and profitable service. The other reason was the need to create an international airline of repute and by so doing, provide a conducive climate for aviators to fully develop their talents.

TCPC relied heavily on the report of the Presidential Task Force, PTF, which government set up to prepare the national carrier for privatisation. The PTF had recommended the Airways be privatized through asset deconsolidation. This was to involve the creation of two companies-Aircraft Operating Company and Aircraft Leasing Company. The first TCPC committee headed by Arthur Mbanefo studies this proposal and among the options it recommended was the liquidation of the company and the establishment of a brand new carrier.

It wasn't until Joji arrived the scene, that he, assisted by Bolshaw, worked with the TCPC to package the present arrangement. The privately run Air Nigeria would take charge of international operations while what remains of Nigeria Airways will be collapsed into a small airline to fly local and West African routes. It would be wholly owned by government.

Air Nigeria will lease three planes-one DC-10-30 and two Airbus A310 from Nigeria Airways. At the moment, two DC-10s and three A310 are serviceable in the fleet. The DC-10 will be leased at $400,000 per month while the Airbuses will attract a monthly lease of $300,000. Air Nigeria will also take over all of Nigeria Airways overseas assets in stations like London, New York, Rome, Jeddah and Amsterdam.

The proposal was a clear contradiction of the National Civil Aviation Policy which government approved and released in 1990. The policy states clearly that Nigeria Airways should be broken into two, one for domestic and the other for international operations. While the domestic carrier should be wholly government-owned. The essence, a member of the committee which drafted the policy said, was to ensure that the lucrative international operation was left to the government. He cited the example of Ethiopian Airline which is wholly-owned by government and is Ethiopia's number one foreign exchange earner. "Why the government turned around and did another thing, I cannot say," the member told NEWSWATCH.

Except for British Airways and American Airlines which are privately-owned, most foreign airlines are owned by governments and they become not only symbols of strength and vitality but a source of economic nourishment.

But only a few are really disturbed by this fact. The worry at the moment is that the privatisation process is moving at a pace which only a few can understand. Many are in the dark about what is happening, and those who have an inkling are challenging it. Wole Adeosun, secretary for transport is said to have challenged Kuye on the way the privatisation is going. Adeosun is said to be unhappy that a sick baby like Nigeria Airways is trying to give birth to a baby itself. According to NEWSWATCH sources, he also objects to the purported recruitment of staff going on in Air Nigeria. Adeosun's colleagues in the Transitional Council are equally unaware. A meeting of the council has been planned for next week to discuss the issue of

Air Nigeria. Said a member of the Transitional Council last week: "People behind Air Nigeria are moving faster than they can run. We really need to know more about what is happening."

NEWSWATCH gathered that officials of the transport and communications ministry are worried about what is happening in Nigeria Airways and Air Nigeria, and some have initiated moves to get the government to review the entire implementation process.

The ministry officials are concerned that the TCPC is milking Nigeria Airways to bring forth its baby. For instance, all the consultants and members of the start-up team are being sustained by Nigeria Airways. When the team arrived, they were initially lodged at Hotel Eko L'Meridien on which the airline spent more than N300,000. Later, it hired an official accommodation for the newly recruited personnel at about N4.5 million in Ikeja. Number 26 Glover Road, Ikoyi, which is officially the residence of the managing director of Airways, has been turned into a guest house where a number of the consultants are lodged.

Air Nigeria office, Eagle House, located within Nigeria Airways headquarters was originally build as the airline's catering block. Said a

ministry official: "Nigeria Airways facility is being used to run Air Nigeria. It is not with the approval of the ministry. We cannot use the assets of a sick baby to set up a new one."

Momoh's responses beclouds the real situation. Wen the board met in February, the members had noted that the Airways resources were being used to support Air Nigeria. Four committees were constituted to handle matters relating to the privatisation and commercialisation of Air Nigeria/Nigeria Airways. The key resolution of the board was to ascertain how much of Nigeria Airways facilities and resources were being used for Air Nigeria and identify those that would be needed, and thereafter work out the costs and modalities for meeting them.

In fact, until that meeting, most members of the board were in the dark on the developments that were bound to crush their organization. The board also queried the role of Bolshaw whom it hired in January on the recommendation of Joji as a consultant "on any aviation matter."

Momoh had, in the letter summoning the meeting, alleged that Airways was being killed to raise up Air Nigeria, and that Bolshaw's role as consultant to Air Nigeria was akin to hiring one's own killers. But by the time the meeting ended, the board noted that Bolshaw had been of immense help to the airline especially in debt negotiation and renegotiation of unfavorable contracts.

Still, members left the meeting unaware of what was really happening. With a board ignorant of what is happening and a management team that was equally ignorant, it was not surprising that staff of the airline were similarly in the dark. Although the start-up team took up positions in the airline since February, communication with the various sectors of the airline only came on April 23 when Kuye spend seven hours explaining the concept and implementation of the Air Nigeria program to the board, management and union representatives in the airline. Some senior Nigeria Airways official said Kuye's briefing is a panic measure. "In Nigeria, you know when somebody comes to brief you on a second thought, you know there is something wrong."

But is there something wrong with Air Nigeria? It seems so. It seems that the cart has been placed before the horse and a deliberate climate of disinformation has been created to keep the mix-up covered. First, there is at the moment, no known owner of Air Nigeria.

Neither the government, nor the foreign investors -- Swiss Air and Sabena -- nor private airline operators have subscribed to the airline. The TCPC document which will commit government to the deal is yet to be signed.

Similarly, the memorandum of understanding between Swiss Air and government has not been signed, and it seems unlikely that it well be, given the objections Zayyad has to its contents. The document is essentially a marketing alliance between Swiss Air and Air Nigeria reflecting "mutual desire to form a relationship of close cooperation between the two airlines for all services operated between Nigeria and Europe in the case of Air Nigeria, and between Switzerland and West Africa in the case of Swiss Air."

Although Swiss Air offers to provide "one or more individuals to liaise with the designated representative" of government on sourcing, interviewing and engagement of suitably qualified candidates, it shall be "acting solely on a goodwill basis and will incur no liability, expense or obligation."

A draft of the public announcement attached to the document says: "Although Swiss Air will not initially be an equity participant in Air Nigeria, the Federal Republic of Nigeria has accepted Swiss Air's request that the allocation of shares be arranged in a manner that will enable Swiss Air to participate in future on pre-agreed terms."

The announcement was billed to be made on January 18, but up till now, it has not, perhaps reflecting the lack of government's approval.

Similarly, the company which is planning to launch its maiden flight on May 21, is yet to secure its certificate of incorporation. At the Corporate Affairs commission last week, NEWSWATCH, was told that the registration paper of the airline was still being processed and the certificate is awaiting the signature of the registrar-general.

Also, application was only made last week for an air operating license, AOL. The request did not follow the laid down guidelines. The application, made on a Nigeria Airways letterhead, simply requested the Federal Civil Aviation Authority, FCAA, to issue an AOL for Air Nigeria. FCAA officials said they can only be issued a provisional license until formal request is made.

Necessary review in the relevant bilateral air services agreements, BASA, have not been made to legally designate the new airline as the operator of the BASA. Logistic arrangements have not been made on the routes where the new airline will operate. With these lapses, it seems only reasonable that the airline may be heading for a bumpy ride, it is manages to take off, May 21.

"It seems that the people have committed themselves to a timetable and they are doing everything to follow it," said a government official.

An aviation chief said last week that the best thing to do was to first resolve the issues of ownership and funding before the fake-off. Said a

British Airways official: "Honestly, we do not know the owners of Air Nigeria."

Another airline executive spoke similarly when he asked: "Who owns Air Nigeria? Is it the government? Is Swiss Air involved? Who brought these white people parading themselves as Swiss Air staff? Who is funding all that is going on now? Do not turn to Zayyad, for he probably has no answer. He would only answer on the source of funding."

Swiss Air had agreed to pay $12 million as advanced route royalty covering three to five years. Sabena on its part offered to pay the same amount. But its money would come by way of maintenance on Nigeria Airways Airbus fleet. So far, Swiss Air has paid the royalty and the money has not been received by TCPC. Zayyad told an official last week he wanted to know who received the money and who authorized the expenditures so far made for the start-up team. That is his other area of quarrel with Kuye and Joji whom he believes are the people running the show without his nor government's authorization.

Both Joji and Kuye insist that Swiss Air is involved in what is

happening at the moment. Said Joji: "If they (Swiss Air)_ tell you that they are not involved, why do they have Avicom here? What they have said is, 'let us come and set it (Air Nigeria) and monitor it to see of it is viable. Then we will be ready to pay at a higher price.'"

That is different from what he told senior pilots of the airline March 5. Then he said that Swiss Air as a company was not directly involved with the nucleus of Air Nigeria or with the formation of an interim management which is provided by a private consultancy firm. He also told them that Sabena and other interested investors had so far not taken up equity. Between the two foreign airlines and Air Nigeria, what exists is a mere technical agreement, which can be entered into with any reputable firm, but which has been given a different coloration.

Airways technical crew which met after Joji's March 5 address paint a rather sad picture of the situation at Air Nigeria. "The present situation is an administration devoid of checks and balances of either a limited or public liability company. No shareholders, no board, no established terms of reference of executives, no performance projections, no conditions of service. Just absolute power to hire and fire at will. That is indeed strange."

Joji has consistently said he does not take decisions for air Nigeria as that is the duty of TCPC. "Whatever TCPC wants to do, it has a right to do. I am not a member of TCPC and cannot decide for them."

Reported by Ray Ekpu, Godson Ukpevo and Emmaneul Uneke

-30

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, May 10, 1993

Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


FROM THE EDITORIAL SUITE NEWSWATCH COVER STORY, May 10, 1993


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nigeria Airways -- many years ago -- was a lone ranger in Nigeria's domestic routes. As the oil boom came and many Nigerians could afford to fly instead of drive, the richer ones bought themselves some sleek jets, but those of us who had to fly had to depend on Nigeria Airways.

At this time flying was often a tearful event. You had to crawl and beg to buy a boarding pass. Why? Because the aircraft were few but the passengers were many, too many for the aircraft available. Nigeria Airways was trying to service the domestic route of which it had near total monopoly and also to run a race against the foreign airlines that dominated the international route. It never quite achieved both aims successfully. It ended up not exploiting its strength on the domestic route and not priming itself sufficiently for the foreign route. 

But as the passengers cried out, complaining of the inefficiency of the national airline and the hardship it imposed on them, the sky opened up and we saw new airlines coming up, taking off and landing. Now Nigeria Airways began to have a competitor, then competitors and more competitors on the domestic route. The airline improved in its efficiency, which gave more room to the other airlines.

Then the structural adjustment programme came with the Babangida administration restructuring the economy and public institutions. Many of the government's water-in-a-basket parastatals had to be asked to brace up, to commercialise and privatise to meet the demands of a free market economy. The Nigeria Airways had to be broken up into several companies, one of which would do domestic operations while the other would test its wings in the foreign route. But there seems to be a pall of doubt arising from the paucity of information on how that exercise is going.

Is there Air Nigeria? Who owns it? Who runs it? How are the staff recruited and from where? Who is recruiting them? Is the government aware of what is going on? Is the Technical Committee on Privatisation and Commercialisation (TCPC) aware of what's happening? What is the role of the ministry of communications and transport? And the role of the managing director of Nigeria Airways? Is the MD of Nigeria Airways the super boss of Air Nigeria? What else is going on in Nigeria Airways? Questions, questions, questions.

Find out. It's a thorough piece of investigative journalism, involving several NEWSWATCH reporters, but the storytelling is done by Assistant Editor Utibe Ukim, who is our aviation expert.

Ray Ekpu, Editor-In-Chief

NEWSWATCH


LOAD-DATE: May 18, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MAY 10, 1993


CLINTON FOREIGN POLICY TO INCLUDE AFRICA EMPHASIS-- NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR ANTHONY LAKE


BYLINE: Reed Kramer, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS. . .


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Africa, traditionally a low priority region for American foreign policy makers, will not be overlooked by the Clinton administration, Anthony Lake, the president's national security advisor, said in his first foreign policy address.

The White House "is exploring means to assist Africa's economic reforms and economic growth" and to ease Africa's debt burden, Lake told African ambassadors at a Brookings Institution luncheon.

An inter-agency panel has approved a new debt relief initiative that would write-off official debts from about 18 countries, administration sources say, although details are being withheld pending consultations with Congress. Impoverished countries in good standing with the International Monetary Fund would be eligible for the forgiveness of Export Import Bank loans, debts on purchases of military hardware, and outstanding housing guarantees and credits, the officials say. 

Lake said the choice of Africa as the topic for his first speech since being named the president's chief foreign policy advisor was intentional. "There has been a sense that some administrations have taken years to figure out where Africa is on the map," he said. The Clinton team not only knows "where Africa is," he said, but wants to contribute to "where it is going" and to craft a "new relationship" built upon the rapid movement towards democracy on the continent.

Acknowledging that global changes in Europe and Asia capture more attention, Lake hailed the fact that more than a dozen African countries have held multi-party elections since 1989, while another fifteen are expected to vote before the year's end. Plans for elections in South Africa, he said, "provide real hope that we may soon see what once seemed so remote, the end of apartheid and the arrival of non-racial democracy."

The administration's interest in the movement towards democracy in Africa extends to the president himself, Lake said, citing a conversation he had with Clinton following the presentation of credentials by two African ambassadors last month. In response to a question, Lake said he will encourage Clinton to visit Africa while he is in office.

Lake emphasized the importance of tackling Africa's problems before they evolve into crises. "Looking back on the elections in Angola, we wish we had acted more aggressively to avoid the problems we face now," he said. Internationally supervised balloting in Angola last September resulted in a narrow victory for the government of President Eduardo dos Santos, but the results were disputed by Jonas Savimbi, leader of the rebel movement Unita, and fierce fighting resumed.

The war is a continuation of 16 years of conflict on a Cold War battle ground between government forces with Soviet backing and Unita, which received about $300 million in covert U.S. aid. Pressure has been building within the administration and from Congress to recognize dos Santos's government, but Lake said no decision on Angola policy steps has been made.

Lake cited several other areas where the administration hopes to chart a new course. He pledged an " activist approach to disasters in the making," to try to forestall future Somalia-type disasters. The administration is working on ways to resolve conflicts in Sudan and Liberia, he said, and to overcome the "resistance to democratic change" in Zaire and Togo.

Asked by one questioner why the administration has not been "bolder" in pressing Zaire leader Mobutu Sese Seko to agree to the demands of a pro-democracy movement in that country. Lake said Washington has "made clear to Mobutu that we support the democratic process" and is working with Belgium and France on a concerted effort to pressure Mobutu, who seized power in 1965 with CIA support.

Lake, whose Ph.D. dissertation topic was U.S. policy towards South Africa and who has lived and worked in Africa, is the first national security advisor with direct African experience. "Africa occupies a special place in my work and affections," he said in his speech. His decision to use the occasion of the luncheon hosted by the Africa Project at Brookings to deliver his maiden address was intended as a strong signal that Africa is an area of interest and concern, White House aides said.

Namibian Ambassador Tuliameni Kalomoh said he and other members of the African diplomatic corps in Washington "welcome this assurance of Clinton administration support for the democratic process and for development efforts" in Africa. "We were especially pleased that this was his first speech," Kalomoh said.

This article appeared in the Washington Post on May 4, 1993.

LANGUAGE: English

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1463 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

* Maintenance and Repair Shop Equipment.

Purchasing agent: Sheladia Associates, Inc. Specifications may be obtained by written request only from Sheladia Associates, Inc., 15825 Shady Grove Road, Suite 100, Rockville, MD 20850. (Request form RFQ 914-93-15 and enclose two return address labels and a $15 handling fee.) 

CLOSING DATE: June 14.

* Pellet mill system. Purchasing agent: Holding company for Rice Mills and Marketing. Specifications may be obtained by written request only from the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. (Enclose a nonrefundable payment of $20, payable to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt.)

* Laboratory equipment. Purchasing agent: Sugar Crops Research Center, Cairo, Egypt. Specifications may be obtained by written request only from the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. (Enclose a nonrefundable payment of $20, payable to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt.) Tender and procurement opportunities for companies doing business in Africa are available through the following

projects:

* Morocco -- Telecommunication and data processing equipment and consultative services. Financed

by the World Bank. Contact: M. Kaide, Chef de la Division, Office National des Postes et Telecommunications, Boulevard Mohamed V, Rabat, Morocco; fax 212-2-777- 416; telex 31998

* Ethiopia -- Road works. The Emergency Recovery and Reconstruction Project. Financed by the International Development Agency (IDA). Details on payment of $100.

Contact: General Manager, Ethiopian Roads Authority, P.O. Box 1770, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia; phone 251-1-152180 or -156603; fax 251-1-514866. Businesses engaged in importing and exporting may be interested in a series of workshops offered by the Fritz Companies of San Francisco, CA. The workshops will be held through November in New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Seattle, San Diego, Minneapolis, Boston, Houston, Columbus and San Francisco. Fundamentals of Importing provides in-depth instruction in the different phases of importing, including U.S. Customs laws, documentation, classification, insurance, terms of sale and types of entries. Fundamentals of Exporting provides practical skills in the fine points of letters of credit, insurance, drawback, export licensing, boycott provisions, hazardous materials, and introductions to export regulations and classification principles. Principles of Drawback -- A Practical Approach to Recovering Your Import Duties provides a fundamental understanding of drawback regulations as applied to the administration of a drawback program. U.S. Customs Brokers Exam Preparation covers all areas of the broker exam given by U.S. Customs, including extensive instruction in Customs regulations, entry processing, ABI, accounting, and the requirements of the most recent exam.

For more information, contact: Fritz Companies, P.O. Box 7221, San Francisco, CA 94103; phone (415) 904-8360; fax (415) 541-7813. African Debt Tables Emerging Markets Group from ANZ Grindlays Bank plc The table gives indications for Value Impaired Debt, quoted in US cents per SD1 nominal value. In all cases prices quoted are for Public Sector Debt except where otherwise stated. Prices change each Friday. . These rates have been compiled by ANZ Grindlays Bank plc for information only. ANZ Grindlays Bank plc accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For more information, contact the London office at 44-71-378-2986; fax 44-71-403-8668. In New York, 212-766-7646; fax: 212-755-1268.

Africa News


June 1, 1993


EDUCATION


LENGTH: 2800 words


 

The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and more. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points in North America.

APPLICATION DEADLINE: September 13. Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 731-21st Avenue 

South, Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. A Summer Social Studies Tour to Egypt for undergraduate and graduate students; administrators; and elementary, secondary and university educators of social studies, global education and Egyptian studies is sponsored by the Ohio State University. Contact M. Eugene Gilliom, College of Education Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210.

Phone: (614) 292-2575. The University of California is offering the opportunity to the general public to be a member of a university research team

this summer. Offered this summer is: ART IN MALI (August 1-13/August 15-27) where volunteers can live among the Dogon people near the picturesque cliff village of Bandiagara to interview the region's artists and discover the role that art plays in this ancient West African culture; ARCHAEOLOGY IN BENIN (July 12-25/August 2-15), where volunteers can join local archaeologists in Equatorial Africa to excavate the port city of Oudiah, home to a 17th century colonial slave trade fort in the former Kingdom of Dahomey; and KENYA'S ENERGY FUTURE (July 4-17/July 18-31) where volunteers help to find energy-saving techniques that will both protect the environment and help Kenya's struggling economy. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers and students.

Contact: University Research Expeditions Program, Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Phone (510) 642-6586. A Summer Institute for Intensive Amharic will be offered at Michigan State University from June 17-July 21. Classes wil be taught by Grover Hudson, director of the program, and native speakers of Amharic. For more information, contact Grover Hudson at (517) 355-8471. Requests for proposals for the 1993-1994 International Development Seminars. Reseachers and practitioners with recent experience in international development are invited to submit proposals for the following series. The Center fot Advanced Study of International Development (CASID), the Society for International Development Series (SID), and Women in International Development (WID) have international development series which are interdisciplinary and provide a forum for exploring development related issues and problems. Community residents, visiting scholars, faculty, staff and graduate students in all subjet and geographic interest areas are invited to apply. Joint presentations and panel discussions are welcome. For more information, contact Nancy Radtke, MSU Center for Advanced Study of International Development (CASID), 306

Berkey Hall, East Lansing, MI 48824-1111. Phone: (517)

353-5925; Fax: (517) 353-4840. 1993 Visiting Scholarship Fellowship Competition is being offered by the Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security, with the support of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. These three-month fellowships allow scholars, journalists, public servants, lawyers, and others to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. In 1993, fellowships are offered to African, Eastern European and Central European scholars. This competition is designed for junior scholars in the first seven years of their postdoctoral careers and other eligible applicants at an equivalent stage. Fellowships will cover roundtrip economy air fare, institutional fees, and a modest stipend. Following the awards of the fellowship the Council will negotiate the stipend. The typical duration of a Visiting Scholarship is three to six months and will not exceed one academic semester. Visiting Scholar Fellowships complement the SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Fellowships on Peace and Security in a Changing World, which are longer-term fellowships available to researchers from all regions. Visiting Scholar Fellowship awardees are encouraged to develop proposals for these longer-term awards. APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE COMPLETED AND RETURNED TO THE COUNCIL BY JULY 15, 1993.

Awards will be announced in November 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Committee on International Peace and Security, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY

10158. Phone: (212) 661-0280, fax: (212) 370-7896. The Education Re-Entry Program of the Rockefeller Foundation is designed to assist in the professional re- establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies in the United States, Canada and Europe and who have an interest in issues related to education revitalization and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The program has been established to assist fellows who have been supported under the Rockefeller Foundation's African Dissertation Internship Program, as well as those trained under the auspices of other organizations. Proposals must include an explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined. There is no deadline for

submission of proposals. Contact: The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; or The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya. The Ethiopian Research Council seeks abstracts for papers or panels for its 3rd annual convention to be held September 9-12 at Florida State University. The theme of

the convention is: Uniting Ethiopian World Scholars and

Creative Artists. Contact: Ashenafi Kebede, Center for African American Culture, Florida State University, 210 South Woodward Street B-105, Tallahassee, FL 32306. Global Exchange seeks interns for summer and fall 1993. Opportunities are available for students who are self- motivated, creative and committed to building bridges between U.S. and Third World citizens. Interns work directly with staff members while taking on real responsibility in the

organization. For more information, contact: Global Exchange, 2017 Mission, San Francisco, CA 94110; phone (415) 255-7296. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover

periods ranging from 12 to 24 months. Deadline: October 1.

Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, is sponsoring a study tour August 11 to September 4 to Senegal, Gambia and Mali. The tour is open to students only and will include lectures on the economic, political and educational systems of the three countries. Visits with local families and trips to Goree Island, Juffure and Timbuktu are

planned. Cost: $1,900 (includes airfare, room and board,

excursions, and tuition). Contact: Louis Sene, phone (909) 869-3397, fax (909) 869-3282. The Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security invites applications for the 1993 Visiting Scholar Fellowship Competition. These three- month fellowships are available to scholars from Africa and other regions outside of the United States who want to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. Applicants may not be

residents of the United States. Contact: SSRC, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax (212) 370-7896. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in

Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers International Fellowship Programs within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the

United States. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone (616) 968-1611. Rotary International's 25,000 clubs worldwide administer thousands of grants yearly for study abroad to students

from around the world. Contact: Rotary Headquarters, One Rotary Center, 1560 Sherman Avenue, Evanston, IL 60201; phone (708) 866-3000. The Johann Jacobs Foundation funds doctoral and independent research on the study of youth in a changing world. African researchers are encouraged to apply.

Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland. The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African academicians and development professionals who have demonstrated commitment to grass-roots development through professional careers in research, teaching or public administration. Candidates must live and work in Africa and have the endorsement of a local institution or organization. The foundation does not require fellows to take a leave of absence from their positions. However, fellows are expected to devote sufficient time to complete the project within either the 12- or 24-month grant period. Grants range from $30,000 to

$50,000. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone (202) 673-3916; fax (202) 673-3810; telex 6711367. Fellowships for journalists from developing countries are offered by the United Nations Correspondents Association's Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Scholarship Fund. The fellowships are awarded to enable journalists to report on the annual three-month UN General Assembly session for their news organizations. Applicants must be full-time professional journalists between the ages of 25 and 35, with a good working knowledge of English and employed by

recognized print or broadcast media organizations. Contact: Judy Aita, Room C-310, UN Secretariat Building, New York, NY 10017. Earthwatch supports research expeditions teaming volunteers with scientists and scholars working to preserve the world's endangered habitats and species and to promote health and international cooperation. Researchers interested in volunteer support may submit a two-page outline of the research subject and design, dates, budget

and plans for use of volunteers to: The Center of Field Research, Earthwatch Headquarters, 680 Mount Auburn Street, P.O. Box 403, Watertown, MA; phone (617) 926- 8200. The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships with free tuition for two years to bright, highly motivated African students interested in pursuing a master's

program for the 1993-94 academic year. Contact: International Graduate Program Coordinator, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, 113 Kasr El Aini Street, P.O. Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt. The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a unit of the New York Public Library's Research Libraries, offers a Scholars-in-Residence Program to assist scholars and professionals whose research in the black experience can benefit from extended access to the center's collections. The program encompasses projects in African, African American, and African Caribbean history and culture. Fellowships allow recipients to spend six months to a year in residence with access to resources at the Schomburg Center and the New York Public Library. Persons seeking support for research leading to degrees are not eligible. Foreign nationals are also ineligible unless they have resided in the United States for three years immediately preceding the award date of the fellowship. Fellows receive stipends of $15,000 for six months and up to $30,000 for 12 months. They must work full time on their projects and may not be employed during the period in

residence. Contact: Arnold Rampersad and Hylan Lewis, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone (212) 491-2203. The Fulbright Scholar Program offers lecturing and research awards worldwide. Grant opportunities are available to U.S. citizens with a Ph.D. or equivalent professional degree. Language skills are needed for some lecturing assignments; most are in English. Many awards allow scholars to propose

their own lecturing or research projects. Deadline: August 1

for most programs. Contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Box GPOS, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone (202) 686- 7877.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 960 words


 

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER OR ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. The position is responsible for the development, monitoring and evaluation of program activities to sustain continuing African efforts in democratization and economic liberalization.

QUALIFICATIONS: graduate training in the social sciences, a solid grounding in African governance and development issues and familiarity with current political, economic and constitutional changes in the region; sound judgment, demonstrated interpersonal, analytical and writing abilities; preferred qualification include previous working experience in Eastern and Southern African; knowledge of development

assistance program. Location: Nairobi. Salary, Program 

Officer: $54,300-68,800. Salary, Assistant Program Officer: $37,300-47,200. Send curriculum vitae and a brief writing

sample for Position #205 to: Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017. World Wildlife Fund seeks a HUMAN RESOURCES MANAGER to manage all human resource activities for a 300-member staff. The position is responsible for developing, implementing and managing all human

resource activities relating to: employee relations and legal issues; establishment and implementation of Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) and Affirmative Action Program; training and development activities; and preparation of personnel policy and procedures manuals.

QUALIFICATIONS: Candidates must possess a bachelor's degree in human resources management, industrial psychology, organizational management or a related field. A master's is preferred. Successful candidate will have at least five years of human resources management experience with demonstrated success in developing, implementing, and managing comparable personnel programs. Position requires excellent organizational skills with particular emphasis on the ability to set, manage, and meet a multitude of deadlines in a fast-paced environment, to work well under pressure, and to work effectively with a wide range of staff. Excellent oral and written skills and an aptitude for problem-solving, decision-making and details are critical. A working knowledge of appropriate laws and regulations is required. To apply, send cover letter and

resume to: World Wildlife Fund, Attention Human Resources Department, 303-M 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037 or by fax, 202-293-9211. The Institute for Food and Development Policy seeks an EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR to provide strong intellectual,

research and administrative leadership. QUALIFICATIONS: proven ability to do research and analysis in Food First's area of concern, with substantial record of publications; experience in public interest work, coalition work and grassroots organizing; proven ability to work with the media, write and communicate in a non-academic style and speak before diverse audiences; experience managing non-profit organization, with background in areas of progressive staff management and conservative financial management; proven ability to raise funds from diverse sources, both domestic and international; and ability to work creatively with an energetic Board of Trustees in setting the strategic

direction of the organization. Salary: $32,000-$40,000 annually, with full medical (Kaiser Permanente, plus dental and vision insurance. To apply, send resume, cover letter

and references to: Executive Search Committee, Institute for Food and Development Policy, 145 Ninth Street, San

Francisco, CA 94103, USA. DEADLINE: June 30. International Medical Corps (IMC), a non-profit medical relief organization, needs a SITE MANAGER for its Emergency Health and Nutrition Program in Sumbe,

Angola. QUALIFICATIONS: Experience supervising expatriate and local personnel required. Fluent Spanish/Portuguese required; six-month time commitment

needed. Salary: up to $2,200/month, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

IMC also seeks FINANCE/ACCOUNTING AND LOGISTICS personnel for its programs to Somalia.

QUALIFICATIONS: Six month time commitment required.

Salary: up to $2000/month, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

For either position, mail or fax resume/letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-014, 5933 West Century Blvd., Suite 310, Los Angeles, CA 90045

5460. Fax: (310) 670-0125.

VISITORS

Africa News


June 1, 1993


PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

The following books are part of the Junior African Writers Series published by Heinemann Educational Books. The series, divided into four levels of language difficulty, is written by Africans, or people who have lived in Africa and have experienced the continent's diversity. Many of the stories explore the challenges facing young people as they grow up in today's complex world. For more information contact Heinemann Educational Books, Inc., 361 Hanover Street, Portsmouth, NH 03801-3959; phone (800) 541- 2086; fax (603) 431-7840.

Level 1: 8-12 years

Amu DJOLETO, Twins in Trouble, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Lawo is on his way to play football. Suddenly he hears footsteps. There's a big man following him. Who is he? What does he want? 

Amu DJOLETO, The Frightened Thief, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Amanor must find money to give to the school bullies. They make fun of him, call him names and threaten to hurt them. He is very frightened. How can he pay them?

Jenny ROBSON, Winner's Magic, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

The winner of the cross-country race will fly to Kenya. Kenna wants to win, but he is not the best runner in the school. Can he find the winner's magic?

Patricia SEALEY, Caught in the Act, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Mpho's mother and father always give her anything she asks for. She wants to buy chocolate for her friend Neo and herself. But she only has enough money for one bar of chocolate.

Patricia SEALEY, Nothing Ever Happens Here, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Nothing exciting ever happens to Madume, a young Nigerian boy. Then, one day he hears shouting -- his friends are in trouble. He has to do something quickly to save them from a lioness.

Dianne STEWART, The Paper Chase , 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

On weekends, Jacob sells newspapers to make some extra money. But one Saturday everything goes wrong. He wakes up late, misses his bus and then forgets to weigh down his newspapers with a stone. Suddenly newspapers are blowing everywhere. What is Jacob going to do?

Level 2: 10-14 years

Akachi ADIMORA-EZEIGBO, The Buried Treasure, 1992. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

After the civil war in Nigeria, Ola and her family are very poor. Ola's father is dead and their money has disappeared. Is there anyone who can help them?

Cyprian EKWENSI, Masquerade Time, 1991. 32 pp.

When Andy, a black American boy, is invited by his Nigerian friend Ihanyi to go and see the local masquerade -- where the spirits of the dead come alive -- he is very excited. But the atmosphere is threatening and danger is in the air as the terror masquerade arrives.

Gaele MOGWE, The Magic Pool, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Was it true that no one ever came back from the Magic Pool? Did a dangerous python really live there. On the last day of school vacation, Boni, Lorato and Kagiso decide to go and see for themselves.

James NGUMY, The Boy Who Rode a Lion, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Kamau needs money to pay his school fees. He gets a job guarding sheep from a hungry lion. One day he falls asleep in a tree. When he wakes up he cannot believe where he is. Set in Kenya.

Keith WHITELEY, Kagiso's Mad Uncle, 1991. $2.50 (paper). 32 pp.

Kagiso completes primary school, but his father makes him look after the cattle instead of going on to secondary education. But Kagiso is unhappy.

Level 3: 12-16 years

Yaw Ababio BOATENG, Miss John, 1991. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

Joanna Tetteh is fourteen and loves adventures, but she's always getting into trouble. Everyone tells her she behaves too much like a boy. But why can't girls run in races or go on school trips? Joanna decides to prove she can do anything the boys can do.

Yaw Ababio BOATENG, The Young Detectives, 1992. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

Kakraba and Panyin can't believe it when they see the three jewel thieves. They hear them planning to hide the jewels. They can't tell their parents. The police do not listen to them. Can the twins catch the thieves all by themselves?

Gillian LEGGAT, The Artist and the Bully, 1992. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

Vusi loves to draw and paint. He wants to take art classes. Mandla is a bully. He thinks artists are sissies. Will Mandla stop Vusi from entering the art competition?

Tracey LLOYD, The Old Man and the Rabbit, 1991. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

Juma visits Pagonis, the baker, every day on his way to school to buy dried bread to eat. When he has no money to pay the baker, he does some odd jobs, but one day he cannot find any work. Then he finds a rabbit and has an ideaI

Eileen MOLVER, Lindiwi Finds a Way, 1992. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

The pupil want a football and a netball. The school needs books, and chalk. But where can they get the money? Can Lindiwi think of a good idea?

Kofi SEYKI, The Haunted Taxi Driver, 1991. $3.00 (paper). 64 pp.

On graduation night, Boba Oko hopes to make lots of money driving his taxi. He decides to have a few drinks to make him drive faster. Baba has an accident. It is a night he will not forget.

Level 4: 14-18 years

Hope DUBE, Love is a Challenge, 1992. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

Sarah loves her job and she loves her boss, John Luke. One day he gives her the most difficult assignment she has ever had. Sarah is determined to show John Luke how good she is.

Cyprian EKWENSI, King for Ever!, 1992. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

King Sinanda wanted to rule forever. But he was an evil man with many enemies. Nobody liked him. When he had destroyed his enemies, he began to worry about his friends. Who could he trust?

Kwasi KORANTENG, The Innocent Prisoner, 1991. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

Brakwa waits in line at the airport in Accra. He is about to fly to the United States to train as a doctor and is full of hope for the future. But suddenly a security man arrests him. Cocaine is found in his suitcase. Who put it there? How can Brakwa prove he is innocent?

Mike SADLER, The Lonely Stranger, 1991. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

One day, Fani, a herd boy, watched six horsemen ride into his mountain village. They promised friendship, but they brought danger to the villagers.

Mike SADLER, The Mystery of Mister E, 1992. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

Nani and Hammer live in Motsani Game Park in Botswana. When their cousin, Shakespeare, visits them from Soweto their adventures begin. Poachers are killing animals in the park. Can the boy from the city help to trap them?

John TEMBO, Dead Men Don't Talk, 1991. $4.00 (paper). 96 pp.

RMy name's John Tembo. I'm an honest man and a good detective. But like any good policeman I make enemies. Until now I've always been more clever than my enemies. Now I'm in trouble.S Tembo enjoys danger, but this time his life is threatened. Who is trying to kill him? Why?

Level 5:

mature young adults

Shirley BOJ , Cry Softly, Thule Nene, 1992. $5.00 (paper). 128 pp.

Thule Nene's world is turned upside down when her family is killed in a terrible blood bath. She is sent to a poor orphanage with little hope for the future. Then she is offered a new start with a wealthy family, if she will help look after a crippled white girl.

Barbara KIMENYE, The Money Game, 1992. $5.00 (paper). 128 pp.

Joshua makes some money by collecting illegally at a church meeting. Martha steals it from Joshua and Laban steals it from Martha. That's the beginning of the money Game. Join the fun as the money goes from hand to hand.

Kwasi KORANTENG, The Gold Diggers, 1992. $5.00 (paper). 128 pp.

Inspector Kanjaga is given the most difficult job of his career. He must stop a gang of gold thieves. Disguised, he joins the gang to uncover their operation. But will he succeed? Four of his colleagues have died trying.
