Africa News


June 1, 1993


NGO POLICY STATEMENT ON SUDAN


BYLINE: The Coalition for Peace in the Horn of Africa Sharon Pauling and John Prendergrast, coordinators


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

The NGO policy Statement on Sudan, signed by over sixty U.S.-based organizations and professionals concerned about the need for a stronger international response to the deepening humanitarian and human rights crisis in Sudan. ASSISTING VULNERABLE POPULATIONS

The diversion, obstruction and interruption of food production, trade and aid deliveries have become integral war strategies for all factions in Sudan. UN and NGO humanitarian efforts, both independent and through Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS), have repeatedly been held hostage by these tactics. Although it is important that the donor community continues to press for such steps as unrestricted access for NGOs, safe passage for civilians, and corridors of peace for the supply of relief food, diplomatic efforts to secure access must be fully integrated with broader peace initiatives and human rights pressure. Too often, multiple initiatives are uncoordinated and international efforts and resources are expended on getting limited humanitarian access to certain areas, leaving little energy for building broader conflict resolution processes, such as sustained pressure for and monitoring of cease- fires. 

While acknowledging the importance of continued emergency relief supplies, even more critical is the need to help restore subsistence economies, rebuild assets, and re- empower community structures in areas where this is possible. An important component of achieving these goals is to aggressively negotiate demilitarized zones. The concept of negotiated demilitarized zones has been widely confused with militarily-enforced safe havens. Negotiated demilitarized zones are productive areas where people can return to farming and herding. An expanded UN monitoring presence would report violations. One "carrot" which may help to induce agreement is to suggest that the continued provision of certain relief supplies to organizations under the control of warring parties could be conditioned on their agreement to, and respect of, these demilitarized zones. Food would not be discontinued to needy populations; rather, an effort would be made to find alternative conduits for relief supplies. The escalation to militarily-enforced havens is premature, and would serve only to attract or further entrench people away from their home areas in ever- expanding relief camps. Khartoum's recent "charm offensive" provides a window for voluntary agreements to resettle noncombatants in demilitarized zones where the restoration of self-reliance can be made a priority.

An important aspect of re-empowering community structures is the choice of vehicle for the delivery of relief and rehabilitative assistance. Local churches are possibly the only accessible, representative institution in SPA- controlled territory of southern Sudan, an area experiencing a significant religious revival. Many individual churches as well as consortia such as the New Sudan Council of Churches have been engaged in relief and rehabilitation activities with their local communities for years, with quite meager resources. The U.S. and UN should examine ways in which assistance can be channeled through the local church networks in order to build local capacity and provide a conduit not directly tied to any warring faction.

Finally, the London-based organization African Rights and other have continuously pointed out the vital importance which pubic health inputs have in complex humanitarian emergencies such as that which exists in southern Sudan. Epidemics are usually much bigger killers than outright starvation, and Kala Azar and visceral leishmaniasis have taken countless thousands of Sudanese lives. Efforts to combat killer diseases like these need to be vastly augmented. FOSTERING PEACE PROCESSES

It is becoming increasingly apparent that the quiet diplomacy approach inherent in the Abuja Process is deeply flawed and not taken seriously by the combatants except as an opportunity to be perceived as seeking peace without being held accountable to any timetable. The U.S. and UN must make the negotiation and monitoring of a comprehensive cease-fire the number one diplomatic priority in Sudan, and put the required energy and resources into building a legitimate peace process.

The process pursued in Somalia provides some lessons for Sudan. Conflict resolution efforts in Somalia over the last four months followed two parallel tracks. On one track, diplomats brought together warring factions and made the implementation of a cease-fire accord the top priority. On the other, a broad array of unarmed groups participated in local, regional and national discussions aimed at restoring non-military leadership and structures throughout that country. These two tracks were merged in March in an attempt to encourage a more broadly representative settlement.

A similar process should be modified for Sudan. In negotiations with the government and the SPLA factions, the implementation of a cease-fire accord should be paramount. But a parallel process could be initiated which includes elders, women's groups, teachers, and churches in the south. Local groups could be assisted and encouraged to hold local congresses and meeting in order to express their views both internally and to the international community. Encouragement could also be given to the setting up of independent forums for the expression of opinion by the large number of exiles who are aligned to no specific party in the conflict and are represented by no political group. International church leaders and NGO representatives might be encouraged to visit the south and support local community re-empowerment efforts.

NGOs, religious leaders, and democratic organizations in northern Sudan could be engaged in a similar process. The UN may not be the appropriate convener of such a process, but UN support and recognition for the initiative would be extremely important. DEFENDING HUMAN RIGHTS

International human rights diplomacy, which since 1990 has included aid and trade sanctions and harsh condemnations from bodies such as the UN General Assembly, the U.S. Senate, and the U.K. House of Lords, has potentially succeeded in creating space for more aggressive human rights monitoring. The UN Special Rapporteur provides a promising opening for further concrete actions. A Prerequisite for progress, though, is the necessity for a permanent presence of monitors in areas of persistent violations who would report regularly to the Rapporteur, who in turn report findings regularly to the Security Council. Senate Resolution 94 asks that the UN "place human rights monitors... in areas of Sudan affected by the fighting and human rights abuses," and we wholeheartedly endorse this recommendation. This would make the broad mandate of the Special Rapporteur -- which includes abuses based on politics, gender, religion, and ethnicity -- much more likely to be met.

There is specific urgency to the human rights crisis in the Nuba Mountains, where widespread ethnic cleansing and slave raiding have been reported. If the Rapporteur is denied free access to any areas of southern Kordofan, the U.S. should quickly press the issue in the UN Security Council and with the Sudan government.

The international community acted far too late in Somalia, after 300,000 people had already perished. The same mistake should not be repeated in Sudan. Replication of these kinds of missions will likely be cost-prohibitive. Limited interventions now will preclude massive intervention later. The international community still has a choice in Sudan.

-30802 Rhode Island Avenue, N.E., Washington, DC 20018;

CONTACT: Sharon Pauling, Bread for the World, phone (202) 269-0200. John Prendergrast, Center of Concern, 3700 13th Street, N.E., Washington, DC 20017;

phone: (202) 635-2757. Both are available for interviews and information concerning the issues raised in this statement.


LOAD-DATE: June 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


99 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1993


MALAWI: THE REFERENDUM AND BUILDING CIVIL SOCIETY by the Lawyers Committee on Human Rights


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

On June 13, 1993 Malawi will hold a national referendum on whether it should retain a single-party system or adopt and multi-party system. The decision to hold the referendum was the result of widespread demonstrations and domestic demands for political reform combined with financial and diplomatic pressure from the international community. For the first time in the 26 years since independence, the people of Malawi will have the opportunity to participate in deciding the nature of their political system. As important as this is, it is essential that the international community realize that it is only one of the issues at hand.

The government has imposed severe restrictions on political activity, which limit the freedoms of assembly, association and free expression. Juxtaposed with this trampling of guarantees essential to civil society was the creation of structure and mechanisms of governmental authority which remain beyond challenge by and accountable to the very people dismantling the system of repression created by President (Hastings Kamuzu) Banda and the Malawi Congress Party is the other critical issue for the June referendum. It is why any effort at identifying a responsible role for the international community must begin well before voting day, and continue well after the results are finalized. 

The civil and political rights affirmed in the International Bill of Human Rights are essential to any voting exercise that aspires to be free and fair(1) Moreover, it is clear that the observance and protection of these rights reflect the general state of human rights in a country and therefore have an importance beyond any single referendum. The choice before the international community is whether it wishes to have a quick vote and get on with business as usual or whether it wishes to help the Malawian people lay the foundation for a society that respects human rights.

The systemic, consistent human rights violations in Malawi are the result of government policies and practices which have continued for so long that they have defined the very nature of Malawian society itself. While changing the personnel involved in setting up such a system may be achieved by voting, changing the norms of 26 years of repressive governmental rule coupled with 26 years of fear and silence by the people of Malawi will not be so easily or quickly achieved. The continuing human rights violation detailed in this report have not been satisfactorily addressed, and will have an impact on both the conduct of the referendum and life after the referendum. Political reform must be accompanied by rebuilding civil society.

In too many African countries focusing on the week before and the week after a major vote has constituted the extent of efforts to create conditions for democracy. In some cases the seeds of failure sprouted long before monitoring teams even set foot in the countries in question. In others, the brief period of political activity was forgotten as old habits resumed. If democratic rule and respect for human rights are to take hold, then the international community must help the people of Malawi build a rights respecting society, where the right to vote will be one among many rights.

The Lawyers Committee calls on both the Government of Malawi and the international community to act to ensure an environment that respects the rights to freedom of speech, assembly, association and the right to due process prior to the upcoming referendum and to monitor closely the government's observance of these rights afterwards. To reiterate the thinking of the second "UN Technical Report," the Malawian government must appreciate that the process and procedures involved in staging a free and fair vote is what is critical to the international community.

The Lawyers Committee endorses the reports of the

UN Electoral Assistance Unit: "UN Technical Team on the Conduct off a Free and Fair Referendum on the Issue of a One-Party/Multiparty System in Malawi," and "Further Report on the Conduct off a Free and Fair Referendum on the Issue of a One-Party/Multiparty System in Malawi," and ardently reaffirms these reports' recommendations(2), in

particular:

* Creating an impartial referendum authority

* Guaranteeing freedom of association, assembly, expression and movement

* Creating an adequate atmosphere for a free, fair and peaceful campaign

* Ensuring the full participation of international observers

The Lawyers Committee urges the international community to play an active role in assisting the people of Malawi in implementing the recommendations of the UN Technical Team and to bring the force of international opinion to bear on the government of Malawi for any actions which divert the country from a free and fair vote. It is essential that international monitoring and involvement begin well before June 13, and continue for some time afterwards.

We also wish to reiterate the importance of continued international pressure in regard to the unfinished business of curbing human rights abuses in Malawi. The constitutionally "legal" structures and official procedures which the government uses to suppress freedom of expression, detain opponents without trial, and deny due process will still be in place the day after the referendum. As long as the remain in force the observance of human rights in Malawi will remain at best, precarious. Moreover, any potential transition to a multiparty system will quickly find itself crippled without sweeping legal reforms. The campaign to promote the respect of human rights must continue to be a priority before, during and after the referendum.

The upcoming referendum represents a pivotal moment for the Malawian people in their quest for basic human rights and a rare opportunity for donor governments like the United States to assist them. It would be a tragedy for all involved were the emphasis to be placed on holding a simple vote rather than promoting fundamental reforms to build a lasting environment that ensures respect for human rights, for all the rights essential for a fair vote and for the results of that vote to be respected and carried out. -30- (1) Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that "everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes the freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media regardless of frontiers." Art. 20 states that everyone has the right to peaceful assembly. (2) UN Report Nov. 1992, supra note 5 at 3-18; UN Report Jan 1993, supra note 6, at 3-11.

CONTACT: Adotei Akwei, Lawyers Committee on Human Rights, 330 Seventh Avenue, 10th Floor, New York,

NY 10001. Phone: (212) 629-6170; fax: (212) 967-0916.


LOAD-DATE: June 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1993


MK WILL BE TRAINED IN SOUTH AFRICA
NEW NATION (South Africa), May 7-13, 1993


LENGTH: 680 words


 

In a major about-turn, government this week requested that the ANC train its Umkhonto we Sizwe (MK) soldiers inside the country.

This emerged during negotiations between government and ANC officials on the establishment of the National Peacekeeping Force (NPKF) to deal with political violence.

While the ANC has agreed in principle to the training of MK cadres inside the country, such a move would be in direct contravention of the Groote Schuur Minute signed by the ANC and the National Party in 1990. 

Both parties, however, have agreed to work at eliminating the restrictions contained in the Groote Schuur agreement.

Delegations representing MK and the SA Defense Force (SADF) met at the Simon's Town Naval base recently to exchange views on how such a structure should function.

NEW NATION has reliably learnt that the government was positive about the move, but was a "bit" concerned that the NPKF would marginalize the SA Police.

In terms of the ANC's blueprint, the NPKF will consist of elements drawn from all parties taking part in negotiations. This means that the SADF, SAP, homeland armies and police forces, MK and Apla would second personnel to the peace force.

COMMANDER

The training and command of the NPKF would be carried out by international experts in peacekeeping operations. The United Nations would provide the commander of the NPKF in consultation with the Transitional Executive Council (TEC).

The NPKF will be accountable to the TEC and will also include personalities from the National Peace Accord and other organs of civil society.

After the establishment of the NPKF and SAP and the SADF will be confined to activities relating to the maintenance of law and order and the defense of the borders.

The NPKF will exist until a government of national unity is established.

Progress on the establishment of a joint peace- keeping force coincides with the emergence of a new military threat from the right with the coalescence of conservative forces under the leadership of former SADF and police generals.

The generals are confident of widespread support in the army and are certain that secessionist moves to establish a volkstaat will not be opposed by the SADF.

Spokesperson for the right wing Volksfront formed by the generals, Riaan van Rensburg, told NEW NATION that he did not believe the government has the necessary control over the army to order it to block a breakaway from South Africa by white conservatives.

-30

Reprinted from NEW NATION, May 7-13, 1993

NEW NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

CONTACT: NEW NATION, 1st Floor Darragh House,

13 Wanderers Street, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:

011-333-2721/2/3/4; fax: 011-333-2733; telex: 482226.

LANGUAGE: English

101 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1993


Environment at Risk


BYLINE: Abdou Karim Sanneh, DAILY OBSERVER (The Gambia)


LENGTH: 814 words


 

An untested substance being described as "fertilizer" made from household waste is being imported into The Gambia from Europe, in contravention of the Environmental Protection Act and without knowledge of the Environment Ministry, the Daily Observer has discovered.

Our farm correspondent was alerted to the unapproved product, known as A4 Compost, by concerned farmers. He discovered that the substance is being imported and distribute in 50 litre bags by Africa Organic Limited, a company based in Latrikunda Sabiji. Twenty-five 20-foot containers of the substance have so far entered The Gambia. The bags, which bear no label to determine the product's composition, are selling for D35 each. Our reporter contacted Will Lottin, the Dutch manager of Africa Organic, to find out more about the alleged fertilizer. Mr. Lottin showed him a phytosanitary service certification from the Plant Protection Service in Holland, which declares the product free from germs and seeds. The certificate, however, bears no countersignatory from the relevant Gambian authorities. 

Our reporter saw another document -- a note written by Sano Ceesay of the Food and Africulture Organization (FAO) of the UN which said the fertilizer should undergo proper testing. Mr. Lottin has confirmed that this has not been done. But he said his fertilizer is being distributed in many parts of the country. When asked by the reporter how farmers reacted to the substance, Mr. Lottin said some farmers found it useful and some did not like it.

Malang Barrow, a senior environment officer at the Ministry of Water Resources and the Environment, has expressed grave concern at the presence of this unscreened product in The Gambia. He explained that the importation of any kind of waste into the country is against the law and constitutes "dumping," according to the Environmental Protection (Prevention of Dumping) Act of 1988.

The Act interprets waste as "any form of industrial waste product or matter, whether known to be hazardous to human health or the natural environment or not."

"My office has just rejected the application of a company which was about to import waste into The Gambia to generate energy," said Mr. Barrow. "If a company wants to promote organic fertilizer they should use out local household waste. It is under the pretext of selling fertilizers that developed countries manage to dump their unwanted waste on developing countries," he pointed out.

He regretted that the Ports Authority and the Bureau of Customs allowed the A4 Compost into the country without the knowledge of his Ministry. Mr. Barrow declared that his office will do all in its power to bring an end to the illegal importation. "The Environmental Protection Act gives my office the mandate to do this," he declared.

Indeed, the Act proclaims that anyone found guilty of dumping in the country any waste produced from sources outside The Gambia "is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand dalasis or a term of imprisonment not exceeding five years or to both such fine and imprisonment.

The Act continues that "if the court finds that the waste dumped...contains any radioactive, toxic, or other substance hazardous to humans or the natural environment," it can impose a maximum fine of 50 million dalasis or a maximum prison sentence of 14 years.

The DAILY OBSERVER has learned that there is no suitable equipment in The Gambia to carry out the necessary tests, such as checking for the presence of nuclear wastes or for harmful heavy materials such as lead. The controversial fertilizer will therefore need to undergo thorough tests at a laboratory outside The Gambia to determine its exact contents. -30

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, May 7, 1993.

DAILY OBSERVER is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia.

Phone: 220-96608, 96877; fax: 220-96878


LOAD-DATE: June 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1993


WORLD BANK TO STRENGTHEN AFRICAN NATIONS' ROLE IN AID Official Urges End To 'Imposing' Expertise


BYLINE: Tami Hultman, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 974 words


 

The World Bank's top policymaker for Africa yesterday announced sweeping changes in the institution's approach to the continent's economic problems.

In a speech to the annual conference of the African- American Institute, Edward V. K. Jaycox, vice president for the Africa Region, said the Bank no longer will dictate development plans to African countries and will stop "imposing" foreign expertise on reluctant African governments.

Calling the current pattern of technical assistance to Africa "a systematic, destructive force," he said future programs will be aimed at building Africa's capacity to help itself.

"This is a big change -- brand new," Jaycox said. 

Most of the world's poorest countries are in Africa, the only region whose poverty has deepened in recent years. But the continent also has vast untapped wealth and already is a larger trading market for the United States than the countries of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe combined.

The speech was an off-the-record address to a closed plenary of the Institute's conference, but Jaycox agreed afterwards to release his remarks for publication.

The policy shift, if implemented, will have repercussions throughout Africa, because the Bank is the key economic player in a continent Jaycox described as having been in "economic free fall." For the last decade, the Bank has shaped the development agenda in Africa, formulating policies that have guided the practices of its sister institution, the international Monetary Fund, as well as the aid programs of the United States and other donor countries.

Acknowledging that the Bank has been unable to devise effective solutions to Africa's persistent economic problems, Jaycox said that in the future the Bank will help fund African governments to write their own development plans and will use the bulk of a $20 million economic research fund to support studies commissioned by Africans themselves, rather than to pay for studies by Bank economists.

In addition, development projects funded by the Bank "are now forbidden to have resident foreign management teams," and must recruit skilled Africans instead, Jaycox said.

"Four billion dollars a year goes into the salaries of expatriate advisors," he said, and has undercut African expertise. Critics of current development programs have estimated that over 100,000 foreign experts working in sub- Saharan Africa consume a major chunk of all foreign aid moneys to the continent.

In another action to support the goal of building Africa's own capabilities, Jaycox announced that universities in the United States and other western nations that have World Bank-funded contracts to train African economic managers must move their programs to Africa within three years and must collaborate with African universities.

The statement startled conference participants. "It's so dramatic a change that I wonder if I heard him correctly," said Dr. Robert S. Browne of Howard university, a former senior advisor on international economic policy to the Carter administration and Congressional committees.

Dr. Adebayo Adedeji, Executive Director of the African Center for Development and Strategic Studies in Nigeria, agreed that the speech represented a reversal of direction for the financial institution but stopped short of applauding the change.

"He admits failure, admits mistakes, admits that the Bank has been misled and has misled the countries it has been advising," he said. "But how many thousands of African children have died while those mistakes were being made?" Adedeji says the World Bank "must go beyond admitting mistakes and discard its faulty programs."

Several conference participants said they were concerned that Jaycox continued to defend the controversial policy of structural adjustment, an economic austerity program that critics say embodies necessary reforms but puts too much emphasis on economic growth statistics and too little on improvements in education, health and public welfare. "There were no alternatives (to structural adjustment) and there still aren't," Jaycox said in a question session after the speech.

But Robert Berg, president of the Washington, DC- based International Development Conference, said that the speech nevertheless represents a "sea change in World Bank thinking that will put Africa's own leadership at the center of the development process for the first time." Berg said that in an era of sweeping democracy in Africa, where more than a dozen countries have replaced authoritarian regimes with elected governments, it is appropriate that "Africa is finally having an influence on the policies of the World Bank." -30EUROPEAN WASTE SOLD AS FERTILIZER HERE


LOAD-DATE: June 1, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

and refer to RFQ 914-93-13). DEADLINE: JULY 13. Tender and procurement opportunities for companies doing business in Africa are available through the following

projects: Businesses engaged in importing and exporting may be interested in a series of workshops offered by the Fritz Companies of San Francisco, CA. The workshops will be held through November in New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Seattle, San Diego, Minneapolis, Boston, Houston, Columbus and San Francisco. Fundamentals of Importing provides in-depth instruction in the different phases of importing, including U.S. Customs laws, documentation, classification, insurance, terms of sale and types of entries. Fundamentals of Exporting provides practical skills in the fine points of letters of credit, insurance, drawback, export licensing, boycott provisions, hazardous materials, and introductions to export regulations and classification principles. Principles of Drawback -- A Practical Approach to Recovering Your Import Duties provides a fundamental understanding of drawback regulations as applied to the administration of a drawback program. U.S. Customs Brokers Exam Preparation covers all areas of the broker exam given by U.S. Customs, including extensive instruction in Customs regulations, entry processing, ABI, accounting, and the requirements of

the most recent exam. For more information, contact: Fritz Companies, P.O. Box 7221, San Francisco, CA 94103; phone (415) 904-8360; fax (415) 541-7813.

* EDUCATION


LENGTH: 3734 words


 

Technoserve, a non-profit international development agency, has released the last four teaching cases in its series of 12. The cases engage students in a variety of management dilemmas encountered by non-profit organizations developing

nations. The four are: "Problems in Monitoring and Evaluation--An Example of Palm Oil Processing in Ghana, West Africa," "The Role of the Small-Scale Farmer in NonAfrica," "The Co-Pro-Riz Cooperative: Negotiating Assistance

Traditional Export: Pineapple Export in Cocoa Coast West with Small-Scale Farmers, in Rwanda, East Africa," and

"Entry Strategies for New Country Programs: Defining Lines Then Crossing Them." Teacher's version, $22.50, student version $1.95 (10 or more $1.75), slide sets, $12.50. For more information and order forms, contact Andrea Luery at Technoserve, (203) 852-0377. Amnesty International has Fall internships available in its 

Mid-Atlantic Regional Office in several areas: CAMPAIGNS-- intern is responsible for coordinating regional activities, such as demonstrations at embassies, maintaining contacts with Congressional members and letter writing campaigns to raise local awareness and action. ABOLITION OF CAPITAL PUNISHMENT--death penalty intern will organize action in protest of scheduled executions and maintain relationships with AI anti-death penalty coordinators and related groups. MEMBERSHIP DEVELOPMENT--membership intern works to increase regional membership in AIUSA and assist in the development of new volunteer community groups and coordinate events, activities and projects for all area community groups. REGIONAL STUDENT PROGRAM--the student program intern is responsible for assisting the organization and development of new groups and the support and maintenance of existing groups. Working with student leadership, the intern will coordinate events, activities and projects for all area local groups. NATIONAL STUDENT PROGRAM (NSP)--the NSP intern will assist in all facets of production materials and educational programs, as well as the development of SAY, the educational human rights magazine for youth. WOMEN AND HUMAN RIGHTS CAMPAIGN--the women's campaign intern is responsible for assisting the task force on a regional level and organizing AI's women's symposium. SPECIAL PROJECTS/FUNDRAISING--the special projects intern will assist the Director in the planning and implementation of special outreach projects, major donor fundraising appeals, special fundraising events and human rights crisis response actions. HUMAN RIGHTS EDUCATION--the education intern is responsible for working with the AIUSA's Human Rights Educator's Network, where the intern will plan education workshops and conferences and coordinate the Annual Call for Posters contest. ADMINISTRATION--the administrative intern will be involved in the day-to-day operation of the office, including the accounting, information management (including computer systems), inter-office communication, contract negotiations and procurement departments. All internships are unpaid. Amnesty International has fall, winter, spring and summer internships, as well as one-month placements in January and May. To apply, submit cover letter, resume,

writing sample and two letters of reference to: Alfred Collie, Amnesty International USA, Mid-Atlantic Office, 1118 22nd Street NW, Washington, DC 20037; phone; (202) 775-5161.

DEADLINE: July 15 (for fall internships). Amnesty International offers a Ralphe J. Bunche Fellowship Program for people of color. The fellowship lasts one academic year and begins with a training period. Each Bunche fellow focuses on a special project in some area of Amnesty International's work, as determined by his or her skills and interest and the needs of the Regional Office. The Mid- Atlantic Fellow will be based at AIUSA's regional office in Washington, DC. A stipend of $1,500 per month is provided. Applicants for the fellowship can be college or graduate level students and/or youth activists. Experience in civil rights and/or human rights is desirable. Good oral and written communications skills and good organizational ability is essential. To apply, send a resume, two letters of recommendation and a statement explaining why a year-long

fellowship would be important to your development to: Amnesty International USA, Mid-Atlantic Office, 1118 22nd Street NW, Washington, DC 20037; phone; (202) 775-5161. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby

Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264. The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and more. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points in North America. APPLICATION

DEADLINE: September 13. Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 731-21st Avenue South,

Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. Contact M. Eugene Gilliom, College of Education

Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210. Phone: (614) 292- 2575. The University of California is offering the opportunity to the general public to be a member of a university research

team this summer. Offered this summer is: ART IN MALI (August 1-13/August 15-27) where volunteers can live among the Dogon people near the picturesque cliff village of Bandiagara to interview the region's artists and discover the role that art plays in this ancient West African culture; ARCHAEOLOGY IN BENIN (July 12-25/August 2-15), where volunteers can join local archaeologists in Equatorial Africa to excavate the port city of Oudiah, home to a 17th century colonial slave trade fort in the former Kingdom of Dahomey; and KENYA'S ENERGY FUTURE (July 4-17/July 18-31) where volunteers help to find energy-saving techniques that will both protect the environment and help Kenya's struggling economy. No experience necessary. Scholarships

are available for teachers and students. Contact: University Research Expeditions Program, Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Phone (510) 642-6586. Requests for proposals for the 1993-1994 International Development Seminars. Reseachers and practitioners with recent experience in international development are invited to submit proposals for the following series. The Center fot Advanced Study of International Development (CASID), the Society for International Development Series (SID), and Women in International Development (WID) have international development series which are interdisciplinary and provide a forum for exploring development related issues and problems. Community residents, visiting scholars, faculty, staff and graduate students in all subjet and geographic interest areas are invited to apply. Joint presentations and panel discussions are welcome. For more information, contact Nancy Radtke, MSU Center for Advanced Study of International Development (CASID), 306 Berkey Hall, East Lansing, MI

48824-1111. Phone: (517) 353-5925; Fax: (517) 353-4840. 1993 Visiting Scholarship Fellowship Competition is being offered by the Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security, with the support of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. These three- month fellowships allow scholars, journalists, public servants, lawyers, and others to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. In 1993, fellowships are offered to African, Eastern European and Central European scholars. This competition is designed for junior scholars in the first seven years of their postdoctoral careers and other eligible applicants at an equivalent stage. Fellowships will cover roundtrip economy air fare, institutional fees, and a modest stipend. Following the awards of the fellowship the Council will negotiate the stipend. The typical duration of a Visiting Scholarship is three to six months and will not exceed one academic semester. Visiting Scholar Fellowships complement the SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Fellowships on Peace and Security in a Changing World, which are longer- term fellowships available to researchers from all regions. Visiting Scholar Fellowship awardees are encouraged to develop proposals for these longer-term awards. APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE COMPLETED AND RETURNED TO THE COUNCIL BY JULY 15,

1993. Awards will be announced in November 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Committee on International Peace and Security, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605

Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Phone: (212) 661-0280,

fax: (212) 370-7896. The Education Re-Entry Program of the Rockefeller Foundation is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies in the United States, Canada and Europe and who have an interest in issues related to education revitalization and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The program has been established to assist fellows who have been supported under the Rockefeller Foundation's African Dissertation Internship Program, as well as those trained under the auspices of other organizations. Proposals must include an explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined. There is no deadline for

submission of proposals. Contact: The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; or The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya. The Ethiopian Research Council seeks abstracts for papers or panels for its 3rd annual convention to be held September 9- 12 at Florida State University. The theme of the convention

is: Uniting Ethiopian World Scholars and Creative Artists.

Contact: Ashenafi Kebede, Center for African American Culture, Florida State University, 210 South Woodward Street B-105, Tallahassee, FL 32306. Global Exchange seeks interns for summer and fall 1993. Opportunities are available for students who are self- motivated, creative and committed to building bridges between U.S. and Third World citizens. Interns work directly with staff members while taking on real responsibility in

the organization. For more information, contact: Global Exchange, 2017 Mission, San Francisco, CA 94110; phone (415) 255-7296. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover

periods ranging from 12 to 24 months. Deadline: October 1.

Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, is sponsoring a study tour August 11 to September 4 to Senegal, Gambia and Mali. The tour is open to students only and will include lectures on the economic, political and educational systems of the three countries. Visits with local families and trips to Goree Island, Juffure and Timbuktu are planned.

Cost: $1,900 (includes airfare, room and board, excursions,

and tuition). Contact: Louis Sene, phone (909) 869-3397, fax (909) 869-3282. The Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security invites applications for the 1993 Visiting Scholar Fellowship Competition. These three-month fellowships are available to scholars from Africa and other regions outside of the United States who want to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. Applicants may not be residents of the United States.

Contact: SSRC, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax (212) 370-7896. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers International Fellowship Programs within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the

United States. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone (616) 968-1611. Rotary International's 25,000 clubs worldwide administer thousands of grants yearly for study abroad to students from

around the world. Contact: Rotary Headquarters, One Rotary Center, 1560 Sherman Avenue, Evanston, IL 60201; phone (708) 866-3000. The Johann Jacobs Foundation funds doctoral and independent research on the study of youth in a changing world. African

researchers are encouraged to apply. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland. The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African academicians and development professionals who have demonstrated commitment to grass- roots development through professional careers in research, teaching or public administration. Candidates must live and work in Africa and have the endorsement of a local institution or organization. The foundation does not require fellows to take a leave of absence from their positions. However, fellows are expected to devote sufficient time to complete the project within either the 12- or 24-month grant

period. Grants range from $30,000 to $50,000. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone (202) 673-3916; fax (202) 673-3810; telex 6711367. Fellowships for journalists from developing countries are offered by the United Nations Correspondents Association's Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Scholarship Fund. The fellowships are awarded to enable journalists to report on the annual three-month UN General Assembly session for their news organizations. Applicants must be full-time professional journalists between the ages of 25 and 35, with a good working knowledge of English and employed by recognized

print or broadcast media organizations. Contact: Judy Aita, Room C-310, UN Secretariat Building, New York, NY 10017. Earthwatch supports research expeditions teaming volunteers with scientists and scholars working to preserve the world's endangered habitats and species and to promote health and international cooperation. Researchers interested in volunteer support may submit a two-page outline of the research subject and design, dates, budget and plans for use

of volunteers to: The Center of Field Research, Earthwatch Headquarters, 680 Mount Auburn Street, P.O. Box 403, Watertown, MA; phone (617) 926-8200. The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships with free tuition for two years to bright, highly motivated African students interested in pursuing a

master's program for the 1993-94 academic year. Contact: International Graduate Program Coordinator, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, 113 Kasr El Aini Street, P.O. Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt. The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a unit of the New York Public Library's Research Libraries, offers a Scholars-in-Residence Program to assist scholars and professionals whose research in the black experience can benefit from extended access to the center's collections. The program encompasses projects in African, African American, and African Caribbean history and culture. Fellowships allow recipients to spend six months to a year in residence with access to resources at the Schomburg Center and the New York Public Library. Persons seeking support for research leading to degrees are not eligible. Foreign nationals are also ineligible unless they have resided in the United States for three years immediately preceding the award date of the fellowship. Fellows receive stipends of $15,000 for six months and up to $30,000 for 12 months. They must work full time on their projects and may

not be employed during the period in residence. Contact: Arnold Rampersad and Hylan Lewis, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone (212) 491-2203. The Fulbright Scholar Program offers lecturing and research awards worldwide. Grant opportunities are available to U.S. citizens with a Ph.D. or equivalent professional degree. Language skills are needed for some lecturing assignments; most are in English. Many awards allow scholars to propose

their own lecturing or research projects. Deadline: August 1

for most programs. Contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Box GPOS, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone (202) 686-7877.

JUNE 14, 1993


* EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER OR ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. The position is responsible for the development, monitoring and evaluation of program activities to sustain continuing African efforts in democratization and

economic liberalization. QUALIFICATIONS: graduate training in the social sciences, a solid grounding in African governance and development issues and familiarity with current political, economic and constitutional changes in the region; sound judgment, demonstrated interpersonal, analytical and writing abilities; preferred qualification include previous working experience in Eastern and Southern African; knowledge of development assistance program.

Location: Nairobi. Salary, Program Officer: $54,300-68,800. 

Salary, Assistant Program Officer: $37,300-47,200. Send curriculum vitae and a brief writing sample for Position

#205 to: Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017. World Wildlife Fund seeks a HUMAN RESOURCES MANAGER to manage all human resource activities for a 300-member staff. The position is responsible for developing, implementing and

managing all human resource activities relating to: employee relations and legal issues; establishment and implementation of Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) and Affirmative Action Program; training and development activities; and preparation of personnel policy and procedures manuals.

QUALIFICATIONS: Candidates must possess a bachelor's degree in human resources management, industrial psychology, organizational management or a related field. A master's is preferred. Successful candidate will have at least five years of human resources management experience with demonstrated success in developing, implementing, and managing comparable personnel programs. Position requires excellent organizational skills with particular emphasis on the ability to set, manage, and meet a multitude of deadlines in a fast-paced environment, to work well under pressure, and to work effectively with a wide range of staff. Excellent oral and written skills and an aptitude for problem-solving, decision-making and details are critical. A working knowledge of appropriate laws and regulations is

required. To apply, send cover letter and resume to: World Wildlife Fund, Attention Human Resources Department, 303-M 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037 or by fax, 202- 293-9211. The School for Field Studies offers professionals two year contracts in the fields of Conservation Biology, Resource Management, Tropical/Wildlife Ecology, Applied Anthropology, International Development and Resource Economics. Faculty oversees 32 students, in semester and summer programs focusing on local environmental, conservation and management issues. A position is available in KENYA at the Center for

Wildlife Management. Requirements: PhD or equivalent, at least one year experience in the region, demonstrated commitment to conservation, 2 years teaching at the undergraduate level, applied research experience, and an ability to live in a remote setting for extended periods of

time. Send cv to: SFS/SS93, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915

or fax: (508) 927-5127. The Institute for Food and Development Policy seeks an EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR to provide strong intellectual, research

and administrative leadership. QUALIFICATIONS: proven ability to do research and analysis in Food First's area of concern, with substantial record of publications; experience in public interest work, coalition work and grassroots organizing; proven ability to work with the media, write and communicate in a non-academic style and speak before diverse audiences; experience managing non-profit organization, with background in areas of progressive staff management and conservative financial management; proven ability to raise funds from diverse sources, both domestic and international; and ability to work creatively with an energetic Board of Trustees in setting the strategic direction of the

organization. Salary: $32,000-$40,000 annually, with full medical (Kaiser Permanente, plus dental and vision insurance. To apply, send resume, cover letter and

references to: Executive Search Committee, Institute for Food and Development Policy, 145 Ninth Street, San

Francisco, CA 94103, USA. DEADLINE: June 30. International Medical Corps (IMC), a non-profit medical relief organization, needs a SITE MANAGER for its Emergency Health and Nutrition Program in Sumbe, Angola.

QUALIFICATIONS: Experience supervising expatriate and local personnel required. Fluent Spanish/Portuguese required; sixround-trip transportation and room and board provided.

month time commitment needed. Salary: up to $2,200/month,

IMC also seeks FINANCE/ACCOUNTING AND LOGISTICS

personnel for its programs to Somalia. QUALIFICATIONS: Six

month time commitment required. Salary: up to $2000/month, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

For either position, mail or fax resume/letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-014, 5933 West Century Blvd., Suite 310, Los Angeles, CA 90045-5460.

Fax: (310) 670-0125.

108 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 14, 1993


* PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

F. Scott BOBB, Historical Dictionary of Zaire.

Metuchen: Scarecrow Press, Inc. (P.O. Box 4167, 52 Liberty Street, Metuchen, NJ 08840), 1988. $37.50 (cloth). 385 pp.

Examines the historical roots of the nation, the numerous ethnic groups within it, European colonization and an extensive bibliography. 

Michael BARRETT-BROWN, Short-Changed: Africa and the

World Trade. Boulder: Westview Press (5500 Central Ave., Boulder, CO 80301), 1993. $59.95 (hardback). $18.95 (paper). 220 pp.

Critique of the economic strategies which the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have imposed on African countries.

Stanton H. BURNETT, Investing in Security: Economic

Aid for Noneconomic Purposes. Washington: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) (1800 K Street, NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20006), 1992. $6.95 (paper). 87 pp.

Examines the United States' post-Cold War economic policies toward developing nations and what new strategies must be employed.

Bruce C. DONALDSON, A Grammar of Afrikaans. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyer (Postfach 11 02 40, D-1000, Berlin 11, Germany), 1993. 497 pp.

An educational book of grammar and pronunciation.

Cary FOWLER and Pat MOONEY, Shattering -- Food,

Politics, and the Loss of Genetic Diversity. Tucson: The University of Arizona Press (1230 N. Park Avenue, Suite 102, Tucson, AZ 85719-4140), 1990. $29.95 (cloth). $14.95 (paper). 275 pp.

Examines the prospect of massive changes in the global food economy as a resulting from the genetic manipulation of seed varieties.

Kimberly A. HAMILTON, Lusophone Africa, Portugal and

the United States. Washington: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) (1800 K Street, NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20006), 1992. $6.95 (paper). 57 pp.

A look at the trilateral relationship and the possibilities of cooperative roles in Africa.

INVESTOR RESPONSIBILITY RESEARCH CENTER, How Institutions Voted On Social Policy Shareholder Resolutions

in the 1992 Proxy Season -- October 1992. Washington: Investor Responsibility Research Center, Inc. (Suite 600, 1755 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 10036), 1992. 154 pp.

Results of survey of institutional investors' votes on shareholder resolutions raising social issues.

Paul KENNEDY, Preparing for the Twenty-First Century.

New York: Random House (201 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022), 1993. $25.00 (cloth). 428 pp.

Looks at the growth and migration of world populations, environmental developments and new technologies and how it will affect live in the 21st century.

Geraldine KENNEDY, ed., From the Center of the Earth:

Stories Out of the Peace Corps. Santa Monica: Clover Park Press (PO Box 5067, Santa Monica, CA 90409-5067), 1991. $12.95 (paper). 223 pp.

Recollections of former Peace Corps field workers.

Norma J. KRIGER, Zimbabwe's Guerrilla War -- Peasant

Voices. New York: Cambridge University Press (40 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011), 1992. $59.95 (cloth). 303 pp.

Explores how peasants were mobilized during Zimbabwe's war of independence and how they fared after the revolution.

Wyatt MACGAFFEY and Michael D. HARRIS, Astonishment

and Power: The Eye of Understanding/The Art of Renee Stout.

Blue Ridge Summit: Smithsonian Institution Press (Department 900, Blue Ridge Summit, PA 17214), 1993. $34.95 (paper). 160 pp.

The work of a contemporary African-American artist, influenced by the African visual tradition.

Peter MATTHIESSEN and Mary FRANK, Shadows of Africa.

Newark: Harry N. Abrams, Inc. (P.O. Box 1213, Newark, NJ 07171), 1992. $34.95 (cloth). 120 pp.

A collection of words and images of African wildlife.

Karin MCQUILLAN, Elephants' Graveyard. New York: Ballantine Books (201 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022), 1993. $19.00 (cloth). 260 pp.

Mystery novel set in present-day Kenya.

Ann McKinstry MICOU and Birgit LINDSNAES, eds., The Role of Voluntary Organizations in Emerging Democracies.

New York: Institute of International Education (809 United Nations Plaza, New York, NY 10017-3580), 1993. 203 pp.

Examines the functions of voluntary organizations in fostering democratic development in several countries, including South Africa.

Clement NWANKWO, Frank AIGBOGUN, and Eluem Emeka IZEZE, et. al., The Crisis of Press Freedom in Nigeria.

Surulere: Constitutional Rights Project (21 James Robertson Street, P.O. Box 4447, Surulere, Lagos, Nigeria), 1993. 127 pp.

Covers the restrictions on the press and arrests and detention of journalists.

ORGANIZATION FOR ECONOMIC COOPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT, Geographical DIstribution of Financial Flows to Developing

Countries 1988/1991. Washington: OECD Publications and Information Center (2001 L Street N.W., Suite 700, Washington, DC 20036-4910), 1993. $68.00 (cloth). 328 pp.

Financial data on developing nations.

Walter F. PITTS, JR., Old Ship of Zion: The AfroUniversity Press (2001 Evans Road, Cary, NC 27513), 1993.

Baptist Ritual in the African Diaspora. Cary: Oxford $29.95 (cloth). 199 pp.

Study of the African origins of African-American forms of worship.

Michael RENNER, Critical Juncture: The Future of

Peacekeeping. Worldwatch Paper No. 114. Washington: Worldwatch Institute (1776 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20036), 1993. $5.00 (paper). 74 pp.

Evaluates the successes and shortcomings of traditional U.N. peacekeeping, and recommends changes in the post-Cold War era.

Edgar J. RIDLEY, An African Answer: The Key to Global

Productivity. Trenton: Africa World Press (P.O. Box 1892, Trenton, NJ 08607), 1992. $24.95 (cloth). $8.95 (paper). 64 pp.

Presents theory that the African decisionmaking process is based on mythological assumptions, symbols and symbolic behavior, and the consequences of the process.

UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME, Human

Development Report 1993. Cary: Oxford University Press, 1993. $17.95 (paper). 230 pp.

Presents comparative analysis of world regions and the quality of life of their populations.

Contact: David Killingray, Centre of African Studies, School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, Thornhaugh Street, Russell Square, London WC1H OXG, UK. 15-16 Oxford, UK -- Conference

"The Oxford Environment Conference: Climate Change and World Food Security"

Contact: Caroline Sumner, The Oxford Environment Conference, Meetings Management, Straight Mile House, Tilford Road, Rushmoor, Farnham, Surrey GU10 2EP, UK; phone 44-0-252- 795414; fax 44-0-252-792101. 15-18 Trenton, NJ -- Conference "Repatriation, Rehabilitation, Rebuilding, Healing and Moving Ahead" U.S.-based Liberian ministers.

Contact: The African United Methodist Church, 120 North Warren Street, P.O. Box 1642, Trenton, NJ 08605; phone (609) 599-9010. 20-August 28 Cape Coast, Ghana -- Seminar "The International Seminar on New Perspectives on the Transatlantic Slave Trade and Its Impact on African and Black American History"

Contact: International Seminar, Student and Youth Services,

P.O. Box 14337, Accra, Ghana; phone: 226878, telex 3033GH,

fax 233-21-669078 (ATTN: Sam Parry) or Council on International Education Exchange (CIEE), 205 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10017; phone (212) 972-3221. 23-25 Columbus, OH -- Conference "Annual Conference on African Linguistics"

Contact: David Odden, 24th ACAL, Department of Linguistics, Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210. August 1 Worcester, MA -- Deadline for Abstract

"The Somali Crisis: Relief, Reconciliation and Reconstruction"

Contact: Hussein Adam, Congress Coordinator, Political Science Department, College of Holy Cross, Worcester, MA

01610-2395; phone: (508) 793-3361; fax: (508) 793-3030. 1-4 Lagos, Nigeria -- Summit "7th Pan-African Congress"

Contact: 7PAC, International Secretariat, P.O. Box 610, Apapa, Lagos, Nigeria; phone 234-1-871-333 or -875-389; fax 234-1-524-000. 3-7 Harare, Zimbabwe -- Book Fair "Reading and Development"

Contact: Margaret Ling, Director, Zimbabwe International Book Fair, 25 Endymion Road, London, N4 1EE, United Kingdom; phone (081) 348-8463. 16-19 New York, NY -- Meeting "Second Meeting of the Preparatory Committee for the International Conference on Population and Development"

Contact: Population '94, ICPD Secretariat, United Nations Population Fund, 220 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10017; phone (212) 297-5222; fax (212) 297-4915. 18-20 Nairobi, Kenya -- Conference "African Capital Markets Conference"

Contact: Sam Mensah, African Capital Markets Conference, School of Management, University of Michigan-Flint, Flint, MI 48502; phone (313) 762-3318, fax (313) 762-3687.

LANGUAGE: English
