112 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 14, 1993


NUMBER OF SUDANESE REFUGEES IN UGANDA MAY EXCEED 100,000 World Food Programme


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 747 words


 

KAMPALA, June 10, 1993 -- The governing body of the World Food Progamme today approved an 18-month extension of a project supplying relief food to 92,000 Sudanese refugees in Uganda, and stated that this number could rise to 115,000 during the course of the year.

WFP -- the food aid organization of the United Nations -- will provide a total of 31,000 tonnes of food commodities for the period July 1993 to December 1994, as well as a cash subsidy of US$ 90 a ton for internal transport, storage and handling of these commodities. The total cost to WFP of this latest project will be nearly US$ 10 million.

Since September 1988, there has been a steady flow of refugees from southern Sudan into Uganda. The rate of influx reached a peak in 1989 when it was estimated that some 50,000 Sudanese had crossed the border. Due to the persistent insecurity in south Sudan, refugees continued to arrive throughout 1990, 1991, and 1992. The arrival rate during the second half of 1992 averaged 1000 a month. By January 1993, a joint WFP/UNHCR and government mission confirmed the total number of refugees at 92,000, of whom 84,000 are in Adjumani (East Moyo) and 8,000 in Kiryandongo (Masindi district). 

WFP has been providing food assistance to the refugees since May 1989, initially under an emergency operation, and then through three protracted refugee operations. In February 1993, the government of Uganda, observing the need to continue assisting the refugees and the likelihood that their numbers would increase, requested WFP to provide further aid for a projected number of 115,000 Sudanese refugees from July 1993 for 18 months.

Over the years, the government has maintained a policy of allowing entry to the refugees and, to the extent possible, of providing them with agricultural land. This is to enable the refugees to achieve a measure of self- sufficiency, pending their eventual voluntary repatriation to Sudan. There are no restrictions on refugees taking up employment or engaging in commercial trade alongside the indigenous population.

Of the 84,000 refugees in Adjumani, some 31,000 have been given land (over two hectares per family) and are settled in 12 villages in the area, while approximately 53,000 continue to live in two large camps at Ogujebe. The 31,000 settled refugees harvested some crops during 1992, especially cereals. They are also able to fish in the nearby Albert Nile and have some limited opportunities for agricultural employment. These activities have given them a degree of self-sufficiency, thus enabling a progressive reduction in the daily ration provided by WFP.

The refugees in the camps, on the other hand, are still entirely dependent on food aid. While efforts are continuing to find land for these refugees, this has been difficult, due to scarcity of available land and lack of government funds.

In Kiryandongo, about 2,350 hectares of land have been allocated for the settling on 951 families, who are presently constructing shelters and clearing the land for agriculture. They are being provided with seeds and agricultural tools and are expected to harvest some crops by August/September 1993. The Ranches Restructuring Board, through the Ministry of Local Government, is trying to identify more land to be used for resettling the remaining 1,410 families.

WFP has so far committed 52,000 tonnes of commodities to the refugee operation in Uganda, at a cost of US$ 10 million. The Programme also wants to expand the potential for expanding development activities among the refugee population, such as road clearing and maintenance, installation of culverts, construction of communal facilities such as schools and health centres and afforestation. -30phone: (256-41) 244010.

CONTACT: O.Owusu, World Food Programme, Kampala;


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 14, 1993


NEWSWATCH (Nigeria), May 31, 1993
STANDSTILL: Fuel scarcity, blackouts paralyse businesses,transportation; strikes paralyze education, banking services


BYLINE: Wale Akin Aina, NEWSWATCH


LENGTH: 5014 words


 

Gori Ogbara, co-ordinator of the Social Democratic Party, SDP, in Shomolu Local Government Area and a businessman is, as a Lagos resident, used to unusual situations. But the incident of the early evening of Thursday May 6 overwhelmed him. All through that day, he had searched for diesel fuel for his generator, to keep his dry cleaning outfit running. For days, his shop, located in the Fayedi area of Lagos mainland had been without regular electricity supply. Customers were harassing his staff. One of them told Ogbara he could buy at a petrol station at Akwonjo, along the Lagos Abeokuta expressway.

Ogbara headed for the place in his Mercedes Benz 200 saloon. Just after the Ikeja bus stop along the expressway, he ran into a horde of stranded commuters, who had taken over the road. Claiming to be on "Operation Solidarity for the Suffering Masses," they stopped and interrogated. He was forced to give "lift" to six people who were going to Alagbado, half way between Lagos and Ota in Ogun State. He

told NEWSWATCH: "The situation was tense. I could not believe such a thing could happen. Worse, I ended up not getting diesel." His business throughout that day remained at a standstill. 

For several weeks now, commuters and private car owners in Lagos were faced with the problem of fuel scarcity. The shortage which started with diesel oil and saw long haul commercial buses off the roads has since spread to include petrol and even kerosene. At the Bay Petrol station on Isheri road in the Ogudu area of Lagos, the last consignment of fuel was delivered on May 11. It ran out two days later on May 13.

Last week, the crisis worsened when workers of the Total Nigeria, Plc went on strike. All outlets of the oil company shut down operations since May 17. The strike no doubt, increased pressure on other filling stations. But Lagos is not alone.

In Akwa Iborn State, economic activities virtually came to a halt for lack of fuel at the filling stations. But the blackmarkets at the Ikot Ekpene road and the Barrack road in Uyo are doing good business. There, illegal outlets sell a litre of petrol for as much for as much as N15.

The story is the same in Calabar and Port Harcourt, where long queues of motorists keep vigil in petrol stations, waiting to buy fuel.

But if scarcity is an occasional thing in southern parts of the country, it has become a permanent feature in the north. In the federal capital, Abuja, signboards proclaiming "No fuel" are regular sights in the six fillings stations. Fuel scarcity was first noticed in Abuja just before the summit of the Organization of African Unity, OAU, in 1991. Since then the shortage of petrol has completely disappeared. Ironically, the fuel shortage in the city is no respecter of persons. NEWSWATCH learnt that officials of the presidency have sometimes had to alter the schedule of the president due to petrol scarcity. Although the presidency receives bulk allocation of fuel from the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC, the supplies have not been regular. This nearly affected the visit of Maryam Babangida, the First Lady, to Kwara State April 24. The advance party of vehicles that was to leave Abuja to Kwara by road nearly did not make it. The drivers had to sleep overnight from Thursday April 22 till Friday April 23 at the Agip filling station in the Wuse area. The vehicles did not leave the filling station until about 2 p.m. that day.

The persistent scarcity of fuel in the northern parts of the country is affecting the campaign schedule of Bashir Tofa, the National Republican Convention, NRC, presidential flag bearer and Moshood Abiola, his counterpart in SDP. NEWSWATCH gather last week that the "Hope '93" campaign train of Abiola which was in Kaduna, Katsina and Kebbi was halted by fuel scarcity. The politicians bought jerricans of 18 litres for N200. It used to cost N18. Indeed, in Yola and Jos, a tin of petrol costs as much as N1,000.00 A litre is now N100.00 The National Electoral Commission, NEC, has appealed to NNPC to make contingency plans to supply it with fuel for the June 12 election. The worsening situation of fuel is also crippling industries. For instance, on Wednesday May 12, the "Champion" newspaper, was not published because the company had no electricity and could not run its generating plant because there was no diesel oil. According to Henry Odukomaiya, editor-in-chief and managing director of the "Champion" newspaper group, the company had gone as far as Ibadan and Ijebu-Ode in search of diesel. No luck. He told NEWSWATCH that as a result of non- production the newspaper lost about N500,000.00 in sales and advertisements.

The story is no different in other companies operating in Lagos. Most industries are producing at less than 40 percent of their capacity due to lack of diesel to run generating plants. Odukomaiya lamented the situation. "Nigeria is in a fix; everything in Nigeria is not working. All the facilities have broken down. We do not know whether we are going forward or backward. I think the government has to do something about this."

In Lagos, two weeks ago the vice president, Augustus Aikhomu, explained that the scarcity of fuel was due to mechanical faults in the Kaduna refinery which produces 100,000 barrels per day. He said spares to rectify the fault would soon be purchased. Curiously, the NNPC had last month declared the refinery operational and had indeed invited Philip Asiodu, the secretary for petroleum resources, to commission the newly repaired refinery. On the very day the secretary appeared accompanied by media men, fire broke out in the area 2 of the refinery. The commissioning was postponed. Indications are that the turnaround maintenance of the refinery, that has been going on since 1991 may take a long time to be completed. Last week, Uche Chukwumerije, secretary for information and culture announced what he described as a three-pronged strategy to battle fuel shortage. He said a joint meeting of the transitional council and the National Defence and Security Council would take a comprehensive action on the border smuggling; the enforcement of high level of probity and self discipline among all the actors involved in the distribution network of petroleum and the temporary conversion of oil pipelines feeding crude oil to the Kaduna refinery. He added that the two refineries in Port Harcourt and Warri were producing at full capacity.

Obviously, the impact of these two refineries is not felt. Port Harcourt produces 120,000 barrels per day, while Warri produces 35,000 per day. The senate committee on petroleum and mineral resources last week described the scarcity of fuel in the country as "a national embarrassment." Lawan Gana Guba, chairman of the committee, said that as from this week, the senate would begin a public hearing into the reasons for the shortage that has "closed down our social and national activities."

Last week, Asiodu inaugurated a committee to search for solutions to the persistent problem. Comprising of Hassan Hadeja, secretary of state for the petroleum ministry, Edmond Dakoru, managing director of the NNPC, Sannia Bello, NNPC's group executive director for refineries and petrochemicals and the members of the board of the Kaduna refinery, Asiodu's committee is the second to be set up within the past week. Earlier, a committee had been set up by the 16 northern governors to unravel the mystery behind the shortage of petroleum. Even so, by the end of last week, there was little hope that the committees could find a solution for the fuel shortage. Long queues continued to feature at petrol stations around the country.

Ken Calebs Olumense, proprietor of Nite Shift, a nightclub in Ikeja, Lagos, tried last week to courageously hide his pain at his loss. His residence at 31, Allen Avenue was razed May 18. Not much of his property was saved. He told NEWSWATCH what happened; "you know, as usual, there was no light on Allen and that night (May 17) I switched on the generator, like I usually do, to allow it to rest and conserve diesel. NEPA had not brought back light then, but when they did a few minutes later, to my dismay I heard a large explosion. I suspect that NEPA fed high voltage into the house and caused the explosion. Before we could not do much to prevent the house from being razed. I will not blame anybody for the fire, it was an act of God."

The case of Olumense is definitely the height of agony Nigerians have been going through under the "no light" regime of the National Electric Power (NEP), Plc. In many parts of the country, prolonged darkness is the norm. Last month, Saleh Michika, governor of Adamawa State felt so frustrated that he gave NEP an ultimatum to restore power to Yola, the state capital or face his wrath. Michika had toured NEP facilities in the state and could not understand why there was no light since nothing was apparently wrong with NEP equipment. NEP apologized to Michika in a statement signed by W.A. Agbede, the general manager, transmission, for the Bauchi region. According to Agbede, the prolonged outage in the state was due to a fault in NEP equipment at the Gombe transmission sub-station which feeds Yola. He assured that the company was working round the clock to restore power supply.

In Ikeja area of Lagos, residents enjoy electricity for only about three hours in a day. Even some who stay in priority areas are not so lucky. For instance, at Isaac John Street, in the Ikeja GRA there are two priority lines. One goes to the Lagos state governor's residence on the street and the other goes to the Ikeja General Hospital. But both priority lines have no regular power supply either. Last week, residents of Ijora, in Lagos sent an SOS to NEP, requesting it to restore power to the thriving commercial area. Spokesman for the residents, Adesola Adebayo, a medical doctor who runs a private clinic, said that businesses in the area have suffered severe losses for lack of power supply.

Sometime last month, NEP announced that seven states would experience extended periods of blackout as it was carrying out repairs on its 330KV line along the Benin/Onitsha transmission line. The states were Delta, Edo, Anambra, Enugu, Benue, Cross Rivers, Kogi and Taraba. NEP has completed the repair work but the states still experience prolonged periods of blackout.

The worsening power cuts are said by NEP officials to be caused by the explosion at the Egbin thermal station which has a capacity of 3200 megawatts and supplies 50 percent of the country's power needs. The explosion, which occurred last December and put three of the six generating units of the thermal station out of service, was said to have been caused by the feeding of condensate, instead of dry gas, to the turbines by the Nigerian Gas Company. NGC, has since denied this. Adesola Macaulay, as assistant general manager said the federal government has been able to secure a $60 million (about N1.2 billion) loan from Exim Bank of Japan to overhaul the thermal station. The problems at Egbin, he explained necessitated the rationing of power in most parts of the country.

The Kainji, Afam and Sapele stations are in dire need of rehabilitation too. NEP officials told NEWSWATCH there are no spares in the stores at NEP headquarters in Lagos to overhaul those stations. The spares include transformers, cables, jointing equipment and equipment to support network

improvement. Said a NEP official: "The money is not just there to procure equipment." The official said that for the power company to be really efficient, it would need nothing less than five billion naira to improve its services.

That amount is by no means an exaggeration. According to officials, most transformers in the country are overloaded and the company is finding it difficult to buy new ones. Two years ago, a transformer costs N50,000. Now, the price is about N400,000. Red tape is also is a stumbling block to efficient performance of NEP, despite the fact that the company has been commercialised. Last year, the NEP board approved the creation of 8 zones, each to be headed by a general manager. Each zone is to be responsible for distribution and sale of electricity after receiving power in bulk from the national grid. The idea behind the creation of zones is to decentralize NEP along lines of a profit- oriented company. But the N1 million each zonal general manager needs as take-off grant has not been given to them. Also, the former executive director in charge of distribution who was retired about two weeks ago was said to be the only person who gives out equipment to the zones. The

situation is yet to change. Said a NEP staff: "You will discover that if GM in charge of the Maiduguri zone wants equipment or needs N20,000, he will have to come to Lagos and that trip alone, in terms of transport and accommodation will cost N10,000." Officials painted a bleak future for the NEP and the country. The system is collapsing and as a result, the country will continue to experience blackouts.

Said a NEP district officer: "There in nothing we can do about this and don't forget that it's also affecting our morale."

Augustine Ahiazu, a professor and vice-chancellor of the Rivers State University of Science and Technology, sits in his office trying to make sense out of what is happening to tertiary education in the country. It is just a couple of days into yet another strike by the Academic Staff of Nigeria Universities, ASNU and academic activities in his university are paralysed. In September, the teachers were promised better conditions of service and university autonomy by the government. They called off their strike. They went back on strike three weeks ago. These have been protracted strikes that have paralysed education. No one

knows when sessions will begin and end. Said Ahiazu: "Many universities are just running crash programmes; students come in, study for one week and again they are away. I must tell you that our universities are no longer ivory towers. Reason has been thrown overboard. The system lacks steady flow in planning and programme. We can't be sure again of the kind of degree and manpower we turn out. This is a sad development."

There seems to be no amicable settlement in sight between university lecturers and the government, a sure sign that for another extended period, education in higher institutions will be a standstill. Last week, students began to move out of university campuses as they became uncertain of when the universities would resume. ASNU had gone on strike, May 3 following the expiration of the ultimatum given to the government to reverse its decision of parity in remuneration between teachers and non-teaching staff of universities. The teachers had accused government and specifically Ben Nwabueze, a professor and secretary of education, of breaching the agreement reached with them last September. Matter got worse when Nwabueze insisted that the agreement was not binding on government and threatened that if the teachers went on strike they should consider themselves dismissed. Last week, lecturers of Nigeria's premier university, the University of Ibadan headed to an Ibadan high court seeking an interlocutory injunction restraining the university authorities from ejecting them from their official quarters. Justice Pius Aderemi granted the injunction. The leader of the banned Academic Staff Union of Universities, ASUU, Atahiru Jega had also gone to Lagos high court to challenge the right of government to sack academics. He prayed that the court declare such action null and void and illegal. Jega also wants the court to declare the essential services decree signed May 4 by the president which makes it illegal for teaching staff to go on industrial action; retroactive, selective, unjust, illegal and unconstitutional.

ASNU issued an eight-point guideline to its members as a pre-emptive measure against harassment by government. Part of it advised lecturers not to sign any register or reapply as government "would soon see the folly of its ways." It further stated that "even if you are deemed to have resigned your jobs, you have the legal right to your official residence until you have found alternative accommodation." The guidelines ended by urging ASNU members not to "panic as government is waging a psychological war. Government cannot replace us if we act uniformly."

As the strike enters its fourth week, it would appear that the issue of parity of pay with non-teaching staff is taking the back burner. Lecturers are insisting that the government should unban ASUU, fund universities and respect university autonomy. NEWSWATCH found that in many higher institutions, education has become almost impossible due to the lack of materials to write with. At the Niger road in the University of Ibadan, where many of its science laboratories are located, water has not run for the past 15 years, making laboratory work impossible. In some faculties, such as theater arts, teachers have no chalk. Said a

lecturer: "Students are so demoralised that they just scribble anything and hand it over to you."

The worsening system of Nigerian university education is made the more evident by new rules which now guide post- graduate admission to universities in Britain. Before a graduate of a Nigerian university is admitted for a post graduate course he must pass a written examination. Universities in America are also said to be seriously thinking of adopting the same method.

The Academic Staff Union of Polytechnics, ASUP, ignored the essential services decree and went on strike action last week. The polytechnic teachers claimed that the nation's education was grossly underfunded and neglected by the government. They also described the decree as retrogressive and a gross violation of human rights as enshrined in the constitution.

Academics and some concerned elder citizens were scheduled to meet in Ibadan last Saturday. A similar meeting between leaders of ASNU and the senate did not hold the previous week because ASNU members did not show up in Abuja. But Jega said ASNU received no invitation from the senate requesting it appear before it. Decisions reached at the Ibadan talks, hosted by Olumbe Bassir, a professor and former president of the National Association of University Teachers, a fore-runner of ASUU, will be passed on to government.

But even as peace moves are being made, ASNU has given indication that it will not back down on its demands. Jega said last week that the association remained committed to defending the university system by continuing the strike until "our demands are met." He added, however, that ASNU would continue to participate in peace discussions aimed at "a speedy resolution of the present crisis."

Joseph Nwaijie, secretary-general of the Nigerian Union of Railmen went home after work Friday, May 14, looking forward to a quiet weekend with his family. It was not meant to be. Soon after he got home about 300 railmen forced their way into his house, beat him up, harassed his family and even attacked his daughter with a knife. They then went ahead to vandalise his property before trooping out on the streets protesting their non-payment of salaries. On a television programme last week Nwaijie supported the action of the railmen who beat him up. "You know, a hungry man is an angry man." he said, explaining that the railway men who had been on strike for the past 26 days had the right to be angry because they have not been paid since July, last year. According to him, the federal government last December announced that it had released N1.7 billion to the Nigerian Railway Corporation, NRC, and the priority was that as long as the workers' salaries remain unsettled, rail transport and services in the country would remain at a standstill.

Rail services have been paralysed since the beginning of this year. Workers of the NRC have gone on strike about six times this year, protesting their deplorable conditions of service. Last week, Nwafor Maduekue, managing director of the NRC, explained that the 1991 minimum wage policy pushed up salaries in the corporation for N11 million to N16 million. Also, the 45 percent increment across the board, approved by the federal government for civil servants last year, increased the wage bills further to N29 million. Maduekwe said he did not know how the NRC, with only 30 engines, aging tracks and rickety coaches could afford such wage bills.

Over the years, the issue of urban road transportation has become an intractable problem. In 1988, the federal government initiated the Federal Urban Mass Transit Programme (FUMTP), with a budget of N700 million. Over the last four years, the FUMTP has received over N2 billion from government.

But sadly, all the money seems not to have made an impact on urban transportation. In Lagos, for instance, the veritable yardstick for the programme's success, about 6.4 million people commute per day in the metropolis. A breakdown shows that the private buses, generally referred to as "molue" carry about 2,080,000 passengers daily, minibuses also known as "Danfo" handle about 1,980,000 people per day, taxis take care of 120,000 passengers, while the state government owned Lagos State Transport Corporation can only carry about 150,000 persons per day.

Under the FUMTP, LSTC was allocated 188 buses. The corporation has about 603 buses but fewer that 100 are in operation. By the end of the year, the corporation owed N10 million. Michael Olawale Cole, Lagos state commissioner for works and transport, told NEWSWATCH that government realises less than 30 percent return on investment on the LSTC. He said the corporation was bogged down by mismanagement, fraud and theft, and an acute lack of responsibility on the part of management and workers. Cole said that the corporation is currently undergoing a "surgical operation to determine which is should survive or be allowed to die naturally."

The story is the same with all the state owned transport companies. The Ondo State-owned mass transit company, is in the habit of losing money. In 1991, it declared a loss of N2 million. Of the about 89 vehicles in its fleet, only a quarter are serviceable. The Bauchi State- owned Yankari Mass transit company's fleet of 42 vehicles, only 19 are road worthy. Last year, Auwala Gwadabe, its chairman, described employees of the company as "cheats and people of dubious character."

A 1990 survey of state owned transport companies showed that all of them operate at a loss because of mismanagement. Oyo State trancity transport lost N2.7 million; Benue transport, N6 million and Borno State transport N6.5 million.

Transporters, cashing in on the fuel scarcity have increased fares, sometimes by 250 percent. In Lagos, for instance, a ride from Ojuelegba to CMS which usually cost N4 was N10 last week. Molue buses charged N5 from Ojota to Idumota. It was normally N3. On Wednesday May 8, business activities in Enugu came to a standstill when bus drivers withdrew their services in protest against attacks from traders. The traders had demonstrated against fare hikes. They destroyed windscreens and damaged vehicles in the attempt to compel drivers to revert to the normal fare of two naira per drop, the bus operators refused.

Isaac Ukpong (not real name) a reporter with an Isolo- based newspaper house has developed a rather interesting banking habit. Every month, as his salary is paid into the Union Bank, Isolo branch, Ukpong withdraws every kobo from

his current account. He explains why: "Most times you go to the bank and discover that they are on strike, no warning, no nothing. You are left in a lurch with no money to spend." Now he feels it's better to withdraw all his salary at once and keep it in the house where a sudden strike action would not affect him.

Never has disruption in banking services in the

country been as frequent as in recent times: on Tuesday, April 11, a day after Easter celebration, many people went to their banks to withdraw money but found the gates shut. Junior workers of most of the old banks chose the day to go on a week-long strike to press home demands for a 57% across the board salary increase. Only a few banks rendered skeletal services.

The strike was called off after the management met their demand. The strike was spear-headed by the National Union of Banks, Insurance and Financial Institutions Employees, NUBIFIE.

Dayo Awobajo, senior secretary-general of NUBIFIE told NEWSWATCH that the industrial action was caused by a misunderstanding between the employers and the union over the review of an expired collective agreement. He said the disagreement had now been resolved.

But before the dust raised by the salary increment increase settled down, another round of industrial crises erupted. This time it was organised by the senior staff of banks. Their grouse bothers on the on-going face off between Owena Bank management and the staff. The management had sacked over 300 of its 700 staff force. The striking senior staff insisted that the management must reinstate the sacked workers. The junior staff who were not involved in the strike claimed there was no way the could work without the co-operation of the senior staff.

Although the strike has been suspended (it lasted for one week May 10-17) following the intervention of the ministry of finance, the problem is not over. If the ministry fails to resolve it, they may resume the strike.

No one knows where to turn any more. --Reported by Sam Olukoya, Olu Ojewale, Jonah Achema, Kayode Olaokun and Eme Bassey.

-30

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, May 31, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited.

CONTACT: LONDON: NEWSWATCH, Centre for International Operations, Suite 46, 8-14 Pancras Way, London, NW1 OQG

United Kingdom. Phone: 071-387-9291: fax 071-383-7576.

NIGERIA: No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate,

Oregun P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Phone: 960950;

fax: 962887; telex: 27874 NEWCOM NG.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 14, 1993


RETURNED WOMEN FACE NEW BATTLES NEW NATION (South Africa), May 21-27, 1993


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

"I was thinking it would be a success, but now I'm in a pool of confusion," says the recently returned 20-year-old Standard pupil Vivian Nahara.

Although she feels alone in her troubles, her feelings of disappointment and pain are shared by several other women who have returned from years in exile to find a South Africa far less rosy than they dreamt of.

In a series of interviews conducted in Durban, NEW NATION found several women battling to survive since their return to South Africa.

Many are women from southern African countries who had married South African exiles and returned with them. Others were simply South Africans who now have difficulty in finding employment. 

The women explained how they faced a host of cultural problems in adopting the South African lifestyle. In some cases, the new environment had added tensions to their marriages.

For 35-year-old MK soldier Amanda Masuku (not her real name), who spent 11 years in exile in Angola and Tanzania, her return home has meant having to cope with a new struggle -- to make ends meet.

She said that the difficulties she faced during her six years of training in Angola were not as severe as the depression she now faces. "There were times when I said to myself, I'm going to do it, because I'm here to learn and fight for my people," she said.

After completing military training, Masuku was trained as a dentistry assistant and worked at the Holland Solidarity Hospital in Tanzania. Yet she is unable to find recognition for her qualifications and secure a proper job as a health care worker in South Africa.

A former political activist, Masuku no longer attends ANC meetings in her home township, Chesterville. She said that her unemployment has made her lose self-confidence, so that she does not feel good about participating in meetings. "I want to work first. Then I can do other organisational activities."

Zambian-born Ruth Mwanza has also stayed away from the ANC since arriving in South Africa with her South African husband, whom she met in exile. Formerly with the ANC women's section tailoring department in Lusaka, Mwanza said she is afraid of the politics here. "I always hear of people being killed," she said.

Mwanza, who lives with her husband's family in Mpumalanga, near Hammarsdale. Her biggest problem has been to conform to the traditional role of 'makoti' (bride) in an extended family. After three months, her husband's family said they did not accept her because the couple had not been married according to Zulu custom.

"In Zambia, no labola is paid," explained Mwanza.

She said she felt constrained by the "passive" role that she, as the wife of the home, was supposed to play. "In Zambia, women are free. As long as we have done the housework, we can go anywhere." she said. "Even the gogo can drink beer, but I as the makoti, I must just sit quietly."

Nahara, who studied at the Solomon Mahlangu Freedom College in Tanzania before returning to South Africa a year ago, also said that she found the sexist "social rules" of South African society difficult to adjust to.

At the college, women were treated equal as men, she said. "But here I can see that men do most things, we even sit separately at school... It seems we are still backward."

She said she often feels ashamed because she can't speak fluent Zulu, having learned Swahili, Portuguese, Xhosa and Sotho while in exile. "If you can't speak proper Zulu, people treat you like you're not a real South African," she said.

On the other hand, 73-year-old Janice Dlamini, who spent the last 20 years in Tanzania, can still speak fluent Zulu. But this seems of little use to her. "I survived by selling fruit and vegetables in Tanzania. Then the government bought us a plane ticket to return to South Africa, so that I could see my home," said Dlamini.

She said she returned early this year and has no home, no food, and no way of sending her six children to school. She is staying at a friend's home in Chesterville, along with several other recently returned women who share the same plight.

Chesterville Youth Development Programme (CYDP) worker Sipho Nxumalo said that the CYDP is helping many returned exiles throughout Chesterville with food vouchers.

Citing one of the cases, he said there was a tough situation involving a Tanzanian woman who had married a South African in exile and returned with him and their three children.

"She no longer has good communication with her husband. He has started drinking, used up all the subsidy grants, and told her that she should go back," said Nxumalo.

United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) director for Natal, Prova Borges, said that foreign spouses encountered many problems upon returning to South Africa.

"The relationship comes under strain with the new dynamics of the man's family. Things get tense when he can't find a job. And many of them have gone back to their old girlfriends and abandoned the women they married in exile," said Borges.

For all returning exiles, the unemployment, violence and sometimes hostile attitudes of other South Africans struggling to make ends meet, has left many disillusioned. Some even wish to return to exile, if they could find the means.

The temporary closure of the National Co-ordinating Committee on Repatriation (NCCR) following corruption scandals last year has left many returnees with nowhere to turn to.

But, according to Borges, the UNHCR has committed itself to fund returnee programmes until the end of 1993. Once the NCCR re-opens, hopefully before the end of May, funds will once again be channeled to those in need through the NCCR, he said.

-30

Reprinted from NEW NATION, May 21-27, 1993

NEW NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

CONTACT: NEW NATION, 1st Floor Darragh House, 13

Wanderers Street, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone: 011

333-2721/2/3/4; fax: 011-333-2733; telex: 482226.

Emerging Markets Group from ANZ Grindlays Bank plc The table gives indications for Value Impaired Debt, quoted in US cents per SD1 nominal value. In all cases prices quoted are for Public Sector Debt except where otherwise stated. Prices change each Friday. These rates have been compiled by ANZ Grindlays Bank plc for information only. ANZ Grindlays Bank plc accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For more information, contact the London office at 44-71-378212-755-1268.  

2986; fax 44-71-403-8668. In New York, 212-766-7646; fax:

Commentary from Emerging Markets Group:

Fundamentals were most at work recently in Nigeria, where the annulment of elections by General Babangida brought Nigeria into a storm of protest from the U.S., which threatened to cut off vital financial assistance to the country. Nigeria par bonds fell about 200 bp as did the Promissory Notes. Despite the very high stripped yields on the Nigeria Brady Bonds, we urge caution at this time.

Contact John MacMahon or Jules Green, 071-378-2867 or 071-378-2950 for more details.

* BUSINESS

Air Afrique announces lower fares to five West Africa destinations effective June 15. All APEX fare requirements drop from 30-day advance to 14-day advance purchase. The

destinations are: Lagos, Nigeria; Accra, Ghana; Bamako, Mali; Banjul, Gambia and Conakry, Guinea. Contact Air Afrique for more information, (800) 456-9192 or (212) 586-5908/09. Agent: Sheladia Associates, Inc., 15825 Shady Grove Road,

Suite 100, Rockville, MD 20850. Attn: Mary Lou Cesar. Specifications may be obtained by written request. (Enclose $20 handling fee, 2 address labels and refer to IFB# 914-93

14.). DEADLINE: July 30.

$15 handling fee). DEADLINE: July 28.

BID OPENING DATE: July 25.

* Echo Cardiography Doppler Imaging Systems. Purchasing

agent: Institute of Cardio Thoracic Surgery, Midan Ibn El Nafis, Embaba, Giza. Specifications may be obtained by written request only from the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. (Enclose a nonrefundable payment of $20, payable to the

Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt.) BID OPENING DATE: July 29. Tender and procurement opportunities for companies doing business in Africa are available through the following

projects: Businesses engaged in importing and exporting may be interested in a series of workshops offered by the Fritz Companies of San Francisco, CA. The workshops will be held through November in New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Seattle, San Diego, Minneapolis, Boston, Houston, Columbus and San Francisco. Fundamentals of Importing provides in-depth instruction in the different phases of importing, including U.S. Customs laws, documentation, classification, insurance, terms of sale and types of entries. Fundamentals of Exporting provides practical skills in the fine points of letters of credit, insurance, drawback, export licensing, boycott provisions, hazardous materials, and introductions to export regulations and classification principles. Principles of Drawback -- A Practical Approach to Recovering Your Import Duties provides a fundamental understanding of drawback regulations as applied to the administration of a drawback program. U.S. Customs Brokers Exam Preparation covers all areas of the broker exam given by U.S. Customs, including extensive instruction in Customs regulations, entry processing, ABI, accounting, and the requirements of the most

recent exam. For more information, contact: Fritz Companies, P.O. Box 7221, San Francisco, CA 94103; phone (415) 904-8360; fax (415) 541-7813.

* EDUCATION


LENGTH: 4160 words


 

"Computers and Communications for Development in Africa" is the name of a conference to be held in Olympia, London on September 22-23. Delegates will look at hardware and software options for business, and focus on trends in the computer

industry and their impact on Africa. DEADLINE: September 13.

For more information, contact: African Information Technology Exhibitions and Conferences, 15 High Street, Graveley, Cambridgeshire PE18 9PL, United Kingdom; phone 44-480-830724, fax 44-480-831131. Boston University is offering a Language/Liberal Arts Program as well as Global Internships in Niamey, Niger. Both programs examine educational reform, development efforts and Sahelian 

life. Contact: Boston University, Office of International Programs, Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; phone (617) 353- 9888. Technoserve, a non-profit international development agency, has released the last four teaching cases in its series of 12. The cases engage students in a variety of management dilemmas encountered by non-profit organizations developing

nations. The four are: "Problems in Monitoring and Evaluation--An Example of Palm Oil Processing in Ghana, West Africa," "The Role of the Small-Scale Farmer in NonAfrica," "The Co-Pro-Riz Cooperative: Negotiating Assistance

Traditional Export: Pineapple Export in Cocoa Coast West with Small-Scale Farmers, in Rwanda, East Africa," and "Entry

Strategies for New Country Programs: Defining Lines Then Crossing Them." Teacher's version, $22.50, student version $1.95 (10 or more $1.75), slide sets, $12.50. For more information and order forms, contact Andrea Luery at Technoserve, (203) 852-0377. Amnesty International has Fall internships available in its

Mid-Atlantic Regional Office in several areas: CAMPAIGNS-- intern is responsible for coordinating regional activities, such as demonstrations at embassies, maintaining contacts with Congressional members and letter writing campaigns to raise local awareness and action. ABOLITION OF CAPITAL PUNISHMENT--death penalty intern will organize action in protest of scheduled executions and maintain relationships with AI anti-death penalty coordinators and related groups. MEMBERSHIP DEVELOPMENT--membership intern works to increase regional membership in AIUSA and assist in the development of new volunteer community groups and coordinate events, activities and projects for all area community groups. REGIONAL STUDENT PROGRAM--the student program intern is responsible for assisting the organization and development of new groups and the support and maintenance of existing groups. Working with student leadership, the intern will coordinate events, activities and projects for all area local groups. NATIONAL STUDENT PROGRAM (NSP)--the NSP intern will assist in all facets of production materials and educational programs, as well as the development of SAY, the educational human rights magazine for youth. WOMEN AND HUMAN RIGHTS CAMPAIGN--the women's campaign intern is responsible for assisting the task force on a regional level and organizing AI's women's symposium. SPECIAL PROJECTS/FUNDRAISING--the special projects intern will assist the Director in the planning and implementation of special outreach projects, major donor fundraising appeals, special fundraising events and human rights crisis response actions. HUMAN RIGHTS EDUCATION--the education intern is responsible for working with the AIUSA's Human Rights Educator's Network, where the intern will plan education workshops and conferences and coordinate the Annual Call for Posters contest. ADMINISTRATION--the administrative intern will be involved in the day-to-day operation of the office, including the accounting, information management (including computer systems), inter-office communication, contract negotiations and procurement departments. All internships are unpaid. Amnesty International has fall, winter, spring and summer internships, as well as one-month placements in January and May. To apply, submit cover letter, resume, writing sample

and two letters of reference to: Alfred Collie, Amnesty International USA, Mid-Atlantic Office, 1118 22nd Street NW,

Washington, DC 20037; phone; (202) 775-5161. DEADLINE: July 15 (for fall internships). Amnesty International offers a Ralphe J. Bunche Fellowship Program for people of color. The fellowship lasts one academic year and begins with a training period. Each Bunche fellow focuses on a special project in some area of Amnesty International's work, as determined by his or her skills and interest and the needs of the Regional Office. The Mid- Atlantic Fellow will be based at AIUSA's regional office in Washington, DC. A stipend of $1,500 per month is provided. Applicants for the fellowship can be college or graduate level students and/or youth activists. Experience in civil rights and/or human rights is desirable. Good oral and written communications skills and good organizational ability is essential. To apply, send a resume, two letters of recommendation and a statement explaining why a year-long

fellowship would be important to your development to: Amnesty International USA, Mid-Atlantic Office, 1118 22nd Street NW, Washington, DC 20037; phone; (202) 775-5161. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta,

GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264. The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and talk to people involved in preparing for democratic elections. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points in

North America. APPLICATION DEADLINE: September 13. Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 731-21st

Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. International Faculty Development Seminars in Egypt and Zimbabwe offer college-level faculty and administrators the opportunity to meet and exchange ideas with counterparts from prestigious institutions of higher learning overseas. Participants will also gain first-hand knowledge of globally important issues. The seminars, scheduled to take place during the 1993-94 academic year, were developed by the Council on International Educational Exchange. The seminar in Egypt will explore the history, significance and future of Islamic fundamentalism and provide participants with an understanding of radical Islam vis-!-vis Arab nationalism, democracy and pluralism, human rights and the role of women. More information will be available in September from Tracy Dobson, Assistant Dean, International Studies and Programs at

MSU, 207 International Center, 355-2350. Or, contact: Council on International Educational Exchange, 205 East 42nd

Street, New York, NY 10017. Phone: (212) 661-1414.

--Michigan State University, African Studies Dept. Bulletin Fulbright Graduate Grants are available for the 1994-95 academic year for graduate students and young professionals to study or do research for one academic year in African countries. Grants include maintenance for one academic year, round-trip international travel, health and accident insurance and a research allowance. Candidates may apply to only one country, and they are responsible for arranging their own affiliations within the host country. Applicants must hold a bachelor!s degree or its equivalent by the beginning date of the grant and must be U.S. citizens at the time of application. The campus deadline for receipt of applications is October 1. For more information, contact the

MSU Fulbright Program Adviser: Tracy Dobson, Assistant Dean, 207 International Center, 355-2350. Rockefeller Foundation Resident Fellowships at the University of Florida - Gainesville are available to study Afro-American Identity and Cultural Diversity in the Americas through the Center for African Studies and the Center for Latin American Studies at U of FL. The program provides support for scholars from Africa, the Caribbean, Latin America and the U.S. to participate in the study of the diaspora of African peoples in the New World, including cultural exchange, migration and new forms of cultural identity. For more information,

contact: Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, 319 Grinter Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611.

Bulletin The Population-Environment Fellows Program places fellows for two years with Master's degrees in local agencies that carry out intersectoral interventions addressing population- environment dimensions of development. This program is sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan. No formal deadline is set, but prospective applicants are encouraged to apply as soon as possible. For

more information, contact: Population-Environment Fellows Program. SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann

Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Phone: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

--Michigan State University, African Studies Dept. Bulletin The University of California is offering the opportunity to the general public to be a member of a university research

team this summer. Offered this summer is: ART IN MALI (August 1-13/August 15-27) where volunteers can live among the Dogon people near the picturesque cliff village of Bandiagara to interview the region's artists and discover the role that art plays in this ancient West African culture; ARCHAEOLOGY IN BENIN (July 12-25/August 2-15), where volunteers can join local archaeologists in Equatorial Africa to excavate the port city of Oudiah, home to a 17th century colonial slave trade fort in the former Kingdom of Dahomey; and KENYA'S ENERGY FUTURE (July 4-17/July 18-31) where volunteers help to find energy-saving techniques that will both protect the environment and help Kenya's struggling economy. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers

and students. Contact: University Research Expeditions Program, Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Phone (510) 642-6586. 1993 Visiting Scholarship Fellowship Competition is being offered by the Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security, with the support of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. These three- month fellowships allow scholars, journalists, public servants, lawyers, and others to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. In 1993, fellowships are offered to African, Eastern European and Central European scholars. This competition is designed for junior scholars in the first seven years of their postdoctoral careers and other eligible applicants at an equivalent stage. Fellowships will cover roundtrip economy air fare, institutional fees, and a modest stipend. Following the awards of the fellowship the Council will negotiate the stipend. The typical duration of a Visiting Scholarship is three to six months and will not exceed one academic semester. Visiting Scholar Fellowships complement the SSRC- MacArthur Foundation Fellowships on Peace and Security in a Changing World, which are longer-term fellowships available to researchers from all regions. Visiting Scholar Fellowship awardees are encouraged to develop proposals for these longer-term awards. APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE COMPLETED AND RETURNED TO THE COUNCIL BY JULY 15, 1993. Awards will be

announced in November 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Committee on International Peace and Security, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New

York, NY 10158. Phone: (212) 661-0280, fax: (212) 370-7896. The Education Re-Entry Program of the Rockefeller Foundation is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies in the United States, Canada and Europe and who have an interest in issues related to education revitalization and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The program has been established to assist fellows who have been supported under the Rockefeller Foundation's African Dissertation Internship Program, as well as those trained under the auspices of other organizations. Proposals must include an explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined. There is no deadline for

submission of proposals. Contact: The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; or The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya. Global Exchange seeks interns for fall 1993. Opportunities are available for students who are self-motivated, creative and committed to building bridges between U.S. and Third World citizens. Interns work directly with staff members while taking on real responsibility in the organization. For

more information, contact: Global Exchange, 2017 Mission, San Francisco, CA 94110; phone (415) 255-7296. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover periods ranging from 12 to 24 months.

DEADLINE: October 1. Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, is sponsoring a study tour August 11 to September 4 to Senegal, Gambia and Mali. The tour is open to students only and will include lectures on the economic, political and educational systems of the three countries. Visits with local families and trips to Goree Island, Juffure and Timbuktu are planned.

and tuition). Contact: Louis Sene, phone (909) 869-3397, fax (909) 869-3282. The Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security invites applications for the 1993 Visiting Scholar Fellowship Competition. These three- month fellowships are available to scholars from Africa and other regions outside of the United States who want to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. Applicants may not be residents

of the United States. Contact: SSRC, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax (212) 370-7896. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini- conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers International Fellowship Programs within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the United States.

Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017- 4058; phone (616) 968-1611. The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African academicians and development professionals who have demonstrated commitment to grass-roots development through professional careers in research, teaching or public administration. Candidates must live and work in Africa and have the endorsement of a local institution or organization. The foundation does not require fellows to take a leave of absence from their positions. However, fellows are expected to devote sufficient time to complete the project within either the 12- or 24-month grant

period. Grants range from $30,000 to $50,000. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone (202) 673-3916; fax (202) 673-3810; telex 6711367. Fellowships for journalists from developing countries are offered by the United Nations Correspondents Association's Dag Hammarskjold Memorial Scholarship Fund. The fellowships are awarded to enable journalists to report on the annual three-month UN General Assembly session for their news organizations. Applicants must be full-time professional journalists between the ages of 25 and 35, with a good working knowledge of English and employed by recognized print

or broadcast media organizations. Contact: Judy Aita, Room C- 310, UN Secretariat Building, New York, NY 10017. Earthwatch supports research expeditions teaming volunteers with scientists and scholars working to preserve the world's endangered habitats and species and to promote health and international cooperation. Researchers interested in volunteer support may submit a two-page outline of the research subject and design, dates, budget and plans for use

of volunteers to: The Center of Field Research, Earthwatch Headquarters, 680 Mount Auburn Street, P.O. Box 403, Watertown, MA; phone (617) 926-8200. The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships with free tuition for two years to bright, highly motivated African students interested in pursuing a master's

program for the 1993-94 academic year. Contact: International Graduate Program Coordinator, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, 113 Kasr El Aini Street, P.O. Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt. The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a unit of the New York Public Library's Research Libraries, offers a Scholars-in-Residence Program to assist scholars and professionals whose research in the black experience can benefit from extended access to the center's collections. The program encompasses projects in African, African American, and African Caribbean history and culture. Fellowships allow recipients to spend six months to a year in residence with access to resources at the Schomburg Center and the New York Public Library. Persons seeking support for research leading to degrees are not eligible. Foreign nationals are also ineligible unless they have resided in the United States for three years immediately preceding the award date of the fellowship. Fellows receive stipends of $15,000 for six months and up to $30,000 for 12 months. They must work full time on their projects and may not be employed during the

period in residence. Contact: Arnold Rampersad and Hylan Lewis, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone (212) 491-2203. The Fulbright Scholar Program offers lecturing and research awards worldwide. Grant opportunities are available to U.S. citizens with a Ph.D. or equivalent professional degree. Language skills are needed for some lecturing assignments; most are in English. Many awards allow scholars to propose

their own lecturing or research projects. DEADLINE: August 1

for most programs. Contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Box GPOS, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone (202) 686-7877.


LOAD-DATE: June 28, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


118 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 28, 1993


* EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

SENIOR POPULATION ADVISOR is needed by CARE for its Population Programming. Responsibilities include developing CARE's Population and Field Programs Strategy in coordination with corresponding field offices. Provide guidance and technical assistance; design, implement and evaluate projects. Represent CARE and collaborate with USAID and other

donors. Qualifications: MD, doctorate or equivalent academic experience in demography, repreductive health or maternal/child health. Excellent communications skills, 

ability to travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.
