Africa News


JUNE 28, 1993


REPORT ACHIEVING POST-SETTLEMENT PEACE IN MOZAMBIQUE: THE ROLE OF THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY United States Institute of Peace


LENGTH: 427 words


 

The civil war in Mozambique has left hundreds of thousands dead and caused five million Mozambicans to flee their homes, about one-third of whom found refuge in neighboring countries. This carnage and devastation was inflicted on a nation that was already desperately poor. Most observers doubted that a peace agreement could be reached with the unpredictable rebels. When the fifty page agreement was signed seven months ago, most Mozambicans and international experts doubted that the cease-fire would hold.

Almost miraculously, the guns on both sides fell silent and the cease-fire has been faithfully observed. But few of the other provisions of the agreement have yet been implemented and the whole agreement could collapse. There are grounds for concern that without action by the UN and key international actors, the failed peace process in Angola could be tragically repeated in Mozambique.

Steps need to be taken:

1. to renegotiate the overall timetable for implementation of the agreement;

2. to implement a comprehensive scheme of military demobilization and the reintegration of former combatants into the civilian economy and society;

3. to resettle the many displaced persons and refugees;

4. to build a more tolerant and participatory society, capitalizing on the stated commitments of both the government and Renamo to the principle of democratic pluralism;

5. to consider electoral systems and transitional forms of government which will promote conflict resolution;

6. to rehabilitate Mozambique's economy;

7. to draw appropriate positive and negative lessons for Mozambique from experiences of other states like Angola and Namibia, which have undergone similar transitions. -30Street, Suite 700, Washiington, DC 20005-1708; phone: (202)

Contact: United States Institute for Peace, 1550 M

457-1700; fax: (202) 429-6063.


LOAD-DATE: June 28, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 28, 1993


REPORT MASSACRE OF UP TO 400 DISPLACED LIBERIANS DEMANDS INTERNATIONAL RESPONSE The U.S. Committee for Refugees


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

June 9, 1993--The massacre Saturday night of 300-400 Liberian at a camp for displaced persons 35 miles from the Liberian capital, Monrovia, provides the latest gruesome evidence that LiberiaUs civil war, now in its fourth year and largely forgotten by the international community, is no closer to resolution and is, in many ways, regressing to levels of atrocities not seen since its first year.

The U.S. Committee for Refugees (USCR) strongly condemns the massacre of defenseless displaced persons last weekend and hopes that (the June 9, 1993) hearings on Liberia by the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Africa will build more international pressure for a final peaceful resolution to the Liberian civil war.

This press advisory provides additional facts and analysis of the massacre, and recommends steps to improve security and bring the war in Liberia closer to resolution. THE MASSACRE

Rebel soldiers of the National Patriotic Front (NPFL), under the command of rebel leader Charles Taylor, are accused of perpetuating the massacre that reportedly left as many as 300 dead and 700 wounded. Many of the 300-400 killed were reportedly dismembered and disemboweled. 

The slaughter occurred at Harbel, a large abandoned rubber plantation 35 miles from the capital, Monrovia, shortly after midnight Saturday night. Some 35,000 displaced Liberians had settles in a temporary camp there after fleeing battles two months ago between the NPFL and the West African peacekeeping force known as ECOMOG. ECOMOG had reportedly told the displaced persons that Harbel was safe. It is believed that NPFL troops slipped through ECOMOG lines to reach Harbel. The rebel troops reportedly entered the camp and identified themselves as government soldiers in need of food. The rebels began the massacre after receiving food from camp residents. ANALYSIS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

The massacre at Harbel bring the Liberian civil war full circle. It was the dead-of-night massacre of some 300 innocent men, women and children who had sought sanctuary at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Monrovia in July 1990 -- almost exactly three years ago -- which hastened the initial military intervention by ECOMOG peacekeeping troops in August 1990.

The latest atrocity indicated that the Liberian war remains far from a peaceful resolution and that the U.S. and the rest of the international community cannot continue to stand idly by waiting for the Liberian conflict to resolve itself. The war has killed an estimated 60,000 persons and uprooted some 1.2 million Liberians -- more than half the country's population. Mass graves recently found in proximity to Monrovia indicate that numerous other unreported massacres have occurred in the past year. The massacre at Harbel comes less than a month after unconfirmed charges that the NPFL slaughtered 100 civilians in the town of Fassama, near Liberia's border with Guinea.

Rebel leader Charles Taylor, whose military forces are weakened but far from defeated, has vowed that he will prolong Liberia's agony through guerrilla warfare and terrorist tactics. Liberia's forested terrain and the NPFL's familiarity with local languages make Taylor's threat credible. The Liberian conflict, moreover, has fractured into

no fewer that four armies: the NPFL, ECOMOG, former government troops known as the Armed Forces of Liberia, and former refugees and government soldiers known as the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (ULIMO). This makes peace more elusive.

The U.S. Committee for Refugees urges the following

steps: 1. Congress and the U.S. State Department should strongly condemn last weekend's massacre and insist on a rapid investigation by the United Nations. -------------------------------------------------

The U.S. should demand a full, immediate and rapid UN investigation into the massacre/ The UN investigative team now en route to Monrovia should conclude its probe before July 1 and make all findings public. The UN should also investigate other human rights atrocities, such as last October's murder of five American nuns, which has never been investigated. 2. ECOMOG must provide protection for Liberians displaced within Liberia. -------------------------------------------------

ECOMOG forces should routinely provide security patrols at camps for displaced persons, especially those near battle lines. Security should not be the responsibility of AFL troops, who themselves have a record of committing human rights abuses. If ECOMOG cannot provide adequate security, ECOMOG, should, at a minimum, refrain from assuring uprooted citizens that they are safe when in fact they are not. As a result of last weekend's massacre, UN refugee officials reportedly will transfer some 60,000 displaced Liberians into Monrovia for protection, where they will join several hundred thousand other uprooted Liberians already living there in crowded conditions. Tents and financial assistance from the international community are required. 3. Liberian refugees who have fled to neighboring Guinea and Ivory Coast should receive additional protection to guard against similar atrocities in their camps along the Liberian border. -------------------------------------------------

Some 385,000 Liberian refugees have taken refuge have taken in Guinea, and nearly 200,000 in Ivory Coast. Many of these refugee settlements are in remote areas. Rebel leader Taylor has threatened to extend the war into neighboring countries as punishment to ECOMOG member, and Liberian refugees are prime targets. The Harbel massacre could be repeated on a larger scale. International financial assistance from the U.S. and other Western nations may be necessary to make such security deployments possible. 4. Congress and the U.S. State Department should urge the UN to station human rights monitors in Liberia. The U.S. and the UN should exert renewed pressure for a return to the Yamoussoukro IV peace process and a final peaceful resolution to the conflict. -------------------------------------------------

All four armies operating in Liberia are guilty of abuses and should be monitored by international observers. In the long term, the Yamoussoukro IV accord, signed in 1991, continues to offer a process for peace. -301025 Vermont Avenue, NW, Suite 920, Washington, DC 20005;

Contact: Jeff Drumtra, U.S. Committee for Refugees,

phone: (202) 347-3507; fax: (202) 347-3418.


LOAD-DATE: June 28, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JUNE 28, 1993


U.S. SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE SUBCOMMITTEE ON AFRICA - POLICY OPTIONS FOR ZAIRE


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 3600 words


 

Testimony of Steve Askin June 9, 1993

Mr. Chairman, members of the committee, thank you for inviting me to testify today on the urgent issues facing the United States in its policy toward Zaire and toward that country's former president, Mobutu Sese Seko.

I refer to Mr. Mobutu as a former President because his term of office expired in December 1991, and because a full understanding of questions of sovereignty and legitimacy is absolutely critical if we are to promote peaceful change in Zaire.

Past hearings before this subcommittee have examined the terrible human rights abuses in Zaire, the impoverishment of its people and the destruction of its infrastructure and human service structures. Witnesses at your last full hearing on Zaire, in November 1991, convincingly explained why Mobutu's failure to relinquish power was already plunging Zaire into chaos and violence.

Conditions have grown immeasurably worse since then, and every day that Mobutu delays his departure makes it more likely that Zaire will become the next Liberia or the next Somalia. However, rather than offering a potentially endless account of the latest abuses, I will focus my testimony on 

the key question facing policymakers: what can our government do -- both unilaterally and in cooperation with others -- to help the people of Zaire speedily and peacefully complete their transition to democracy. Because economic pressures offer the last hope for peaceful transition, my testimony will draw on research I have conducted, as a journalist specializing in African economic affairs, on the Zairian economy under the Mobutu regime.

Without belaboring the point, I will also touch on the reasons our government has an especially strong obligation to help undo the great damage wrought by its past support for Mobutu and encouragement of some of his most corrupt practices. Secretary of State Christopher heralded a long overdue policy reversal at the African American Institute last month, when he declared that Africa's future lies "not with corrupt dictators like Mobutu, but with courageous democrats in every part of the continent." Yet these words will have little practical meaning unless they lead to swift and effective action.

THE ECONOMIC CONTEXT: MOBUTU'S SYSTEM

To act effectively, we need a sophisticated understanding Mobutu's system of rule, often referred to as "kleptocracy" or government by theft. For the past 28 years, Mobutu has carefully and thoughtfully refined this system for transforming the public resources of Zaire into private wealth, while using bribery, coercion and violence to thwart all movements for change. This system has transformed wealth which rightly belongs to Zaire's 40 million people into a personal business empire serving the private interests of one man and his tiny circle of supporters.

A vast body of evidence suggests that, through most of the past quarter century, Mobutu has misappropriated several hundred million dollars annually. In the years for which the most detailed evidence is available, Mobutu and his associates have mis-directed up to 20% of the Zairian government operating budget, up to 30% of mineral export revenues, up to 50% of the government capital budget. Mobutu uses these funds for luxury consumption, for personal investment abroad, for corrupt payments to political allies, and for other activities which fall completely outside the parameters of legitimate governance.

Past attempts to "reform" Mobutu ended in utter failure. Perhaps the most serious such effort came during the Carter administration when -- partly at the behest of the United States -- the International Monetary Fund sent a senior international banker to monitor the Zairian Central Bank and promote financial integrity. That banker, Erwin Blumenthal, soon left in frustration, declaring that "the corruptive system in Zaire with all its wicked and ugly manifestations, its mismanagement and fraud will destroy all endeavors" for change.

At least four types of financial flows have served to enrich Mobutu. In recent years, he has relied primarily upon funds taken from (1) Zaire's treasury, (2) Zaire's mineral export revenues and (3) foreign aid and investment funds. In the past, Mobutu also benefited significantly from covert payments by foreign governments, including the United States.

DIVERSION OF STATE FUNDS

The Zairian state treasury itself has provided Mobutu his most reliable and consistent source of funds. Unpublished studies prepared by the World Bank and the IMF show that direct government appropriations to Mobutu's presidential office have often consumed fifteen to twenty percent of the government's operating budget.

Yet these generous appropriations were not sufficient to satisfy Mobutu's demand for wealth. The same confidential financial studies also show that Mobutu has consistently overspent his "official" presidential appropriation, making up the deficit by taking funds designated for public services. Particularly detailed records are available for the 1986 fiscal year. In that year, Mobutu's parliament allocated about $60 million to the Presidency and Mobutu- controlled political organizations. However, the Presidency and government-funded political offices actually drew $172 million -- 16% of the year's total government operating expenditure -- from the Zairian treasury. Mobutu's additional expenditures were taken from the budgets of the Health Ministry, Education Ministry and other key ministries.

Further evidence exists of Mobutu-directed spending for which no meaningful records can be found. A 1989 World Bank memo showed, for example, that fully 18% of the year's state expenditures were spent for unexplained "other goods and services."

This massive mis-spending leaves almost no money for legitimate government functions. World Bank figures indicate that, among all developing nations for which data is available, Zaire devotes the smallest percentage of official spending to human services. In 1990, education received only 1.4% of Zairian government outlays; health, 0.7%; other social services, 1.5%.

EMBEZZLEMENT OF EXPORT PROCEEDS

Export revenues provide Mobutu his most important source of hard currency. Identifiable "leakages" often exceed $100 million per year. In 1988, for example, $400 million disappeared without explanation from Zaire's mineral export proceeds. This represented about 30% of the annual revenue of the company involved, the state-owned copper and cobalt mining firm, Gcamines.

Consistent reports of similar diversions date back to the founding of Zaire's state minerals marketing system in 1974. In some cases, the exact destination of diverted funds remains a mystery; in others, direct evidence exists that Mobutu or members of his family were the beneficiaries. These abuses have helped to drive Gcamines to the brink of collapse. Its output -- once the mainstay of Zaire's formal sector economy -- has dropped by two-thirds in recent years.

Despite ample evidence of past abuses, international institutions appear to have continued some lending to Gcamines. As recently as Monday of this week, the Mobutu- appointed President Director General of Gcamines reported that the company is the recipient of some continuing World Bank credits.

Mobutu may now be planning one final raid on Gcamines assets, through a recently announced plan to privatize major portions of the company. Whatever the ultimate merits of privatization, if carried out under present conditions it will merely provide Mobutu another opportunity for embezzlement.

Copper and cobalt are not the only sources of mineral revenue diversions. Over the past year, diamond smuggling appears to have replaced copper and cobalt exports as Mobutu's primary foreign exchange source. Some reports suggest that diamond exporters with close ties to Mobutu, his family, or his generals may have netted as much as $300 million last year. MISUSE OF FOREIGN AID, FOREIGN LOANS AND FOREIGN INVESTOR FUNDS

There is a long history of systematic Mobutist misappropriation of foreign aid grants and multilateral development loans. As early as 1975, during a hearing before this very subcommittee, former Senator Dick Clark raised questions about reports that $5 million worth of foreign aid was being annually diverted to "private officials of the Mobutu government."

Last year, a committee of Zaire's Sovereign National Conference (the predecessor to the High Council of the Republic) found -- during it investigation of "misacquired wealth" -- evidence that Mobutu received kickbacks totalling 7% of expenditures for the Inga-Shaba power line, the largest construction project in Zaire's history. The project was partly financed with guarantees from the U.S. Import-Export bank. If the full history of Zaire's foreign borrowing is ever reconstructed, it may show that most of the nation's foreign debt, which totals more than $10 billion, arises from loans whose proceeds were stolen or squandered. DIRECT FOREIGN GOVERNMENT BRIBES

We as Americans cannot ignore our own government's role in establishing Mobutu's patterns of corruption. Roger Morris, who handled African affairs for the National Security Council in the Johnson and Nixon administrations, has estimated that Mobutu received close to $150 million in bribes and secret payments from the Central Intelligence Agency during the first decade or so of his regime. In more recent years, there have been credible accusations which deserve further investigation involving financial flows in

the opposite direction: irregular funds transfers possibly made by Mobutu to U.S. and European business officials who have lobbied their governments on his behalf. POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS

With the arrival of a new administration, many Zairians hoped the U.S. would take leadership in organizing multilateral pressure for Mobutu's rapid departure. The Clinton Administration has sent some welcome signals. It has placed an appropriate stress on its opposition to Mobutu, its recognition of the High Council of the Republic and Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi as Zaire's legitimate transitional political authorities, and its support for anti- Mobutu sanctions.

Yet the administration's expressed support for international sanctions against Mobutu has not yet been translated into action. As we have seen elsewhere, most recently in the case of Haiti, sanctions delayed swiftly become sanctions evaded.

In the past, some officials have suggested that the U.S. must await the preparation of a comprehensive multilateral plan of action before imposing sanctions against Mobutu. While multilateral action is important, I believe the urgency of Zaire's crisis permits no further delays.

At least five potentially fruitful types of pressure

against Mobutu have been proposed:

1) Actions aimed directly at his personal fortune, including

a freeze on his foreign bank accounts and those of his

family and political associates;

2) Economic sanctions directed against the Mobutu

government, including formal suspension of Zaire from the

IMF and World Bank;

3) Sanctions aimed at Mobutu's sources of foreign currency

income, including an embargo on Zaire's copper, cobalt and

other exports.

4) An arms embargo designed to deprive Mobutu of weapons

used to suppress opposition;

5) Diplomatic action, including expulsion of Mobutu's ambassadors from Western capitals.

If well-designed, these and similar measures could isolate Mobutu and facilitate his departure before Zaire collapses into full-fledged civil war.

Yet the proposed sanctions must be creatively broadened if it is to have any real effect. Moreover, the isolation of Mobutu should be coupled with efforts to strengthen the HCR and the Tshisekedi cabinet which are, however imperfect, the only institutions in Zaire with a legitimate claim to represent the political will of the nation. In designing an effective sanctions package, the following factors must be

considered:

1) An assets freeze limited to bank accounts will have relatively little effect, because bank deposits probably represent only a small fraction of Mobutu's wealth. To be effective, a freeze must also encompass real estate holdings; equity interests in a variety of foreign business ventures; and all other identifiable assets purchased from the profits of kleptocracy. Moreover, a freeze should be explicitly designed as the first step toward the seizure of ill-gotten assets; the possible prosecution of Mobutu and his associates for any financial crimes they have committed; and the repatriation of illegally-obtained wealth to Zaire when a legitimate government assumes effective power in Kinshasa.

Since Mobutu appears to be haunted by the prospect of a Marcos-like exile in which he and his family will be hounded to their graves by a successor state bent on recovering ill- gotten wealth, there is a carrot which might be tied to this "stick." I suspect that, if Mobutu agreed to renounce power and accept permanent exile, Zairians would welcome a compromise which allowed him a safe haven abroad with some form of immunity from prosecution and assets seizure.

2) Economic pressures should be targeted against the Mobutu- Faustin Birindwa government which, despite its lack of legitimacy or international recognition, holds effective control over Zaire's government ministries. This government's suspension from the World Bank and IMF should be coupled with moves toward recognition of the HCR-Tshisekedi transitional government as the representative of Zaire in all multilateral bodies and negotiations. Some steps were taken in this direction last month, when senior officials at the IMF and World Bank met with Tshisekedi's widely-respected finance minister, Jules Sambwa. However, there are disturbing indications that the World Bank -- which alone among multilateral lending institutions continues to disburse funds to Zaire -- may still be cooperating with Gcamines, with the Office des Routes, and with other historically corrupt entities still under Mobutu's control.

Immediate action is also needed to isolate Zaire's Central Bank, which is operated by a Mobutu appointee in defiance of the HCR and currently serves partly to launder diamond smuggling proceeds. This rogue institution should be excluded from all international transactions and funds transfer systems until Mobutu relinquishes control. Mobutu's power could be further undermined through an embargo on the currency notes, printed abroad, which he uses to pay his security forces.

Increased public disclosure and transparency on the part of lenders and aid donors could also help speed Mobutu's departure and assist Zairian efforts to investigate the "misacquired wealth" of Mobutu and his associates. Lender and donor agencies -- including the World Bank, the IMF and the US Agency for International Development -- should be directed to provide investigators active assistance. Records held by these and other international agencies could prove invaluable in tracking misdirected funds. The mere threat of public disclosure might be a useful source of leverage encouraging Mobutu's retirement.

3) An arms embargo is symbolically important but may have only modest impact, since Mobutu has a monopoly on arms already in the country. However, a report last year by Africa Watch indicated that several countries -- including Egypt, Israel and South Africa -- may be providing advisors or other vital support to Mobutu's military. In addition to embargoing weapons, the U.S. should use all available means to press these and other governments to sever military links with Mobutu.

4) Because Mobutu's destructive regime has already driven the copper and cobalt mines to a virtual standstill, diamonds are the most important target for any export embargo.

Embargoing diamonds is virtually impossible since any smuggler can carry several hundred thousand dollars worth in his or her pocket. Nonetheless, authorities in Antwerp, Tel Aviv, New York and other major diamond cutting centers would -- if determined to do so -- have relatively little difficulty pinpointing the major buyers and sellers of Zairian precious stones. If an embargo were coupled with close observation of Mobutu's customers and harsh prosecution when violators are caught, they will quickly turn to other diamond sources. A ban on air links with Zaire would also help to greatly reduce the flow of smuggled mineral products.

So that these anti-theft measures won't rebound against Zaire's 40 million citizens, they should be coupled with a program of greatly increased humanitarian aid. Humanitarian assistance should be funnelled through non-government organizations, not through agencies controlled by the Mobutu- Birindwa government. The U.S. should support and encourage speedy completion of a planned UN assessment of humanitarian need and the broadest possible multilateral aid effort.

5) Expulsion of Mobutu's ambassadors and diplomats should be viewed as merely the first step toward international recognition of the transitional government. Though the U.S. and the European Community have repeatedly declared that they view the HCR as Zaire's highest legitimate authority, Mobutu-appointed ambassadors still occupy most Zairian embassies, including the embassy in Washington. In addition to according recognition only to representatives chosen by the transitional government, the U.S. should insist that U.S. corporations operating in Zaire pay taxes only to the legitimate authorities and halt any payments to the Mobutu-Birindwa government.

I realize that some of these recommendations lack precedent in the history of international economic sanctions. Yet nothing less will work if Zaire is to be afforded any chance of achieving peaceful political transition. -30(saskin@igc.apc.org.)

Comments may be sent to Steve Askin

EDUCATION


LENGTH: 2454 words


 

Limited space is available on a 16-day tour of Cameroon's rainforests and cultural sites. Held December 19, 1993- January 4, 1994, the tour indludes sightseeing expeditions with including hikes and canoeing. Total price with air fare, is approximately $4,000. Contact Afor, (312) 907-9759 or Etoke (205) 252-8353 for more information. "Computers and Communications for Development in Africa" is the name of a conference to be held in Olympia, London on September 22-23. Delegates will look at hardware and software options for business, and focus on trends in the

computer industry and their impact on Africa. DEADLINE:

September 13. For more information, contact: African Information Technology Exhibitions and Conferences, 15 High Street, Graveley, Cambridgeshire PE18 9PL, United Kingdom; phone 44-480-830724, fax 44-480-831131. Boston University is offering a Language/Liberal Arts Program as well as Global Internships in Niamey, Niger. Both programs examine educational reform, development efforts and

Sahelian life. Contact: Boston University, Office of International Programs, Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; phone (617) 353-9888. Technoserve, a non-profit international development agency, has released the last four teaching cases in its series of 12. The cases engage students in a variety of management dilemmas encountered by non-profit organizations developing 

nations. The four are: "Problems in Monitoring and Evaluation--An Example of Palm Oil Processing in Ghana, West Africa," "The Role of the Small-Scale Farmer in NonAfrica," "The Co-Pro-Riz Cooperative: Negotiating Assistance

Traditional Export: Pineapple Export in Cocoa Coast West with Small-Scale Farmers, in Rwanda, East Africa," and

"Entry Strategies for New Country Programs: Defining Lines Then Crossing Them." Teacher's version, $22.50, student version $1.95 (10 or more $1.75), slide sets, $12.50. For more information and order forms, contact Andrea Luery at Technoserve, (203) 852-0377. Amnesty International offers a Ralphe J. Bunche Fellowship Program for people of color. The fellowship lasts one academic year and begins with a training period. Each Bunche fellow focuses on a special project in some area of Amnesty International's work, as determined by his or her skills and interest and the needs of the Regional Office. The Mid- Atlantic Fellow will be based at AIUSA's regional office in Washington, DC. A stipend of $1,500 per month is provided. Applicants for the fellowship can be college or graduate level students and/or youth activists. Experience in civil rights and/or human rights is desirable. Good oral and written communications skills and good organizational ability is essential. To apply, send a resume, two letters of recommendation and a statement explaining why a year-long

fellowship would be important to your development to: Amnesty International USA, Mid-Atlantic Office, 1118 22nd Street NW, Washington, DC 20037; phone; (202) 775-5161. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby

Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264. The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and talk to people involved in preparing for democratic elections. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points in North America. APPLICATION

DEADLINE: September 13. Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 731-21st Avenue South,

Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. International Faculty Development Seminars in Egypt and Zimbabwe offer college-level faculty and administrators the opportunity to meet and exchange ideas with counterparts from prestigious institutions of higher learning overseas. Participants will also gain first-hand knowledge of globally important issues. The seminars, scheduled to take place during the 1993-94 academic year, were developed by the Council on International Educational Exchange. The seminar in Egypt will explore the history, significance and future of Islamic fundamentalism and provide participants with an understanding of radical Islam vis-!-vis Arab nationalism, democracy and pluralism, human rights and the role of women. More information will be available in September from Tracy Dobson, Assistant Dean, International Studies and Programs

at MSU, 207 International Center, 355-2350. Or, contact: Council on International Educational Exchange, 205 East 42nd

Street, New York, NY 10017. Phone: (212) 661-1414.

--Michigan State University, African Studies Dept. Bulletin Fulbright Graduate Grants are available for the 1994-95 academic year for graduate students and young professionals to study or do research for one academic year in African countries. Grants include maintenance for one academic year, round-trip international travel, health and accident insurance and a research allowance. Candidates may apply to only one country, and they are responsible for arranging their own affiliations within the host country. Applicants must hold a bachelor!s degree or its equivalent by the beginning date of the grant and must be U.S. citizens at the time of application. The campus deadline for receipt of applications is October 1. For more information, contact

the MSU Fulbright Program Adviser: Tracy Dobson, Assistant Dean, 207 International Center, 355-2350. Rockefeller Foundation Resident Fellowships at the University of Florida - Gainesville are available to study Afro-American Identity and Cultural Diversity in the Americas through the Center for African Studies and the Center for Latin American Studies at U of FL. The program provides support for scholars from Africa, the Caribbean, Latin America and the U.S. to participate in the study of the diaspora of African peoples in the New World, including cultural exchange, migration and new forms of cultural identity. For more

information, contact: Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, 319 Grinter Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611.

--Michigan State University, African Studies Dept. Bulletin The Population-Environment Fellows Program places fellows for two years with Master's degrees in local agencies that carry out intersectoral interventions addressing population- environment dimensions of development. This program is sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan. No formal deadline is set, but prospective applicants are encouraged to apply as soon as possible. For

more information, contact: Population-Environment Fellows Program. SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann

Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Phone: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

--Michigan State University, African Studies Dept. Bulletin The Education Re-Entry Program of the Rockefeller Foundation is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies in the United States, Canada and Europe and who have an interest in issues related to education revitalization and development in sub-Saharan Africa. The program has been established to assist fellows who have been supported under the Rockefeller Foundation's African Dissertation Internship Program, as well as those trained under the auspices of other organizations. Proposals must include an explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined. There is no deadline for

submission of proposals. Contact: The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; or The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya. Global Exchange seeks interns for fall 1993. Opportunities are available for students who are self-motivated, creative and committed to building bridges between U.S. and Third World citizens. Interns work directly with staff members while taking on real responsibility in the organization. For

more information, contact: Global Exchange, 2017 Mission, San Francisco, CA 94110; phone (415) 255-7296. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover

periods ranging from 12 to 24 months. DEADLINE: October 1.

Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, is sponsoring a study tour August 11 to September 4 to Senegal, Gambia and Mali. The tour is open to students only and will include lectures on the economic, political and educational systems of the three countries. Visits with local families and trips to Goree Island, Juffure and Timbuktu are planned.

Cost: $1,900 (includes airfare, room and board, excursions,

and tuition). Contact: Louis Sene, phone (909) 869-3397, fax (909) 869-3282. The Social Science Research Council's Committee on International Peace and Security invites applications for the 1993 Visiting Scholar Fellowship Competition. These three-month fellowships are available to scholars from Africa and other regions outside of the United States who want to pursue research on innovative topics in international peace and security studies at universities and major research centers outside their home regions. Applicants may not be residents of the United States.

Contact: SSRC, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax (212) 370-7896. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers International Fellowship Programs within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the

United States. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone (616) 968-1611.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

NYZS/The Wildlife Conservation Society seeks a BUFFER ZONE MANAGER to be stationed in Masoala Peninsula, Madagascar. It is a field-based position supervising sustainable development activities in buffer zone bordering proposed national park in remote rain forest region for USAID-funded intergrated conservation and development project. Work with national forester, national and international consultants

and extension/facilitation agents. QUALIFICATIONS: Advanced degree in forestry, agroforestry or related field; 3-5 years experience in tropical sustainable forestry and/or sustainable harvesting of forest products, familiarity with community organization, park management, ecotourism and ICDPs preferred. Fluency in French required. Salary commensurate with experience and qualifications; position subject to funding approval. POSITION STARTS OCTOBER 1993 

for 2-3 years. Send CV and 3 references to: Dr. Hilary Simons Morland, Africa Program Officer, NYZS/The Wildlife Conservation Society, 185th Street and Southern Boulevard,

Bronx, NY 10460; phone: (718) 220-5887; fax: (718) 364-4275. SENIOR POPULATION ADVISOR is needed by CARE for its Population Programming. Responsibilities include developing CARE's Population and Field Programs Strategy in coordination with corresponding field offices. Provide guidance and technical assistance; design, implement and evaluate projects. Represent CARE and collaborate with USAID

and other donors. Qualifications: MD, doctorate or equivalent academic experience in demography, repreductive health or maternal/child health. Excellent communications

skills, ability to travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016. For more information, contact Virginia Banks, Recruitment and Staff Development, 54 Wilton Road, Wesport, CT 06880; phone

(203) 221-4000. Fax resume and salary requirements to: (203) 221-4077. Candidates should be interested in the issues that surround democratization in Africa. Foreign language

ability is desirable. For further information, contact: Keith Klein, Director of Africa Programs, IFES, 1620 I

Street NW, Suite 611, Washington, D.C. 20006. Phone: (202) 828-8507. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER OR ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. The position is responsible for the development, monitoring and evaluation of program activities to sustain continuing African efforts in democratization and

economic liberalization. QUALIFICATIONS: graduate training in the social sciences, a solid grounding in African governance and development issues and familiarity with current political, economic and constitutional changes in the region; sound judgment, demonstrated interpersonal, analytical and writing abilities; preferred qualification include previous working experience in Eastern and Southern African; knowledge of development assistance program.

Location: Nairobi. Salary, Program Officer: $54,300-68,800.

#205 to: Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017. World Wildlife Fund seeks a HUMAN RESOURCES MANAGER to manage all human resource activities for a 300-member staff. The position is responsible for developing, implementing and

managing all human resource activities relating to: employee relations and legal issues; establishment and implementation of Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) and Affirmative Action Program; training and development activities; and preparation of personnel policy and procedures manuals.

QUALIFICATIONS: Candidates must possess a bachelor's degree in human resources management, industrial psychology, organizational management or a related field. A master's is preferred. Successful candidate will have at least five years of human resources management experience with demonstrated success in developing, implementing, and managing comparable personnel programs. Position requires excellent organizational skills with particular emphasis on the ability to set, manage, and meet a multitude of deadlines in a fast-paced environment, to work well under pressure, and to work effectively with a wide range of staff. Excellent oral and written skills and an aptitude for problem-solving, decision-making and details are critical. A working knowledge of appropriate laws and regulations is

required. To apply, send cover letter and resume to: World Wildlife Fund, Attention Human Resources Department, 303-M 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037 or by fax, 202- 293-9211. African-American Institute has two positions available. PROJECT MANAGER for the Nigeria Family Health Services

project in New York. Qualifications: AID project management experience, preferably in Africa; ability to handle Personnel, Administration and Finance (PAF); PAF support to the Combatting Childhood Communicable Diseases (CCCD) Project and other health-related projects in Nigeria. contracts and grants. Qualifications: BS degree and five years experience with federal accounting/reporting or auditing of federal contracts; experience with AIDARs and OMB Circulars A-110, A-122 and A-133; computer and communications skills. Africa experience a plus. Send resume

to: Human Resources Department (Position 13-93), 833 United Nations Plaza, New York, NY 10017.

Jonathan S. ADAMS and Thomas O. MCSHANE, The Myth of Wild

Africa -- Conservation WIthout Illusion. New York: W. W. Norton & Company (500 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10036), 1992. $21.95 (cloth). 266 pp.

A report on how Western conservation has affected the balance between wildlife and Africans. 

William BOYD, Brazzaville Beach. Newark: Avon Books (P.O. Box 19112, Newark, NJ 07195-0112), 1990. $4.95 (paper). 320 pp.

Novel. Jeremy BRECHER, John Brown CHILDS, and Jill CUTLER, eds.,

Essays from a symposium on the theme " New World Order vs. One-World Community."

Prose and color photo essay on Benin and Bahia (Salvador). Paul GIFFORD, Christianity and Politics in Doe's Liberia.

New York: Cambridge University Press (40 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011), 1993. $59.95 (cloth). 349 pp.

Discusses the branches of Christianity in Liberia and the effect of Samuel K. Doe's regime on the teachings within the church. Michael A. GOMEZ, Pragmatism in the Age of Jihad -- The PrePress (40 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011), 1993.

Colonial State of Bundu. New York: Cambridge University $59.95 (cloth). 252 pp.

Examines the pragmatic role of Islam in Bundu, among states with a fundamentalist, theocratic Muslim culture.

Marshall G.S. HODGSON, Rethinking World History. New York: Cambridge University Press, 1993. $49.95 (cloth). 328 pp.

Explores European and Islamic influences in world history. David KEEN, A Political Economy of Refugee Flows, From

Southwest Sudan, 1986-1988. Geneva: United Nations Research Institute (Palais des Nations, 1211, Geneva 10, Switzerland), 1992. 37 pp.

Analyzes the refugee flows and the factors that forced the Dinka people to abandon their homes.

Doris LESSING, African Laughter: Four Visits to Zimbabwe.

Scranton: Harper Collins (1000 Keystone Industrial Park, Scranton, PA 18512-4621), 1992. $25.00 (cloth). 442 pp.

A look at the author's visits to Zimbabwe in 1982, 1988, 1989 and 1992 after being in exile for opposition to the white minority government.

Peter MAGUBANE and Carol LAZAR, Women of South Africa: Their

Fight for Freedom. New York: Little, Brown & Company (205 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10016), 1993. $40.00 (cloth). $24.95 (paper). 128 pp.

Collection of photos, with text, covering 40 years of women and struggle in South Africa.

Wunyabari O. MALOBA, Mau Mau and Kenya: An Analysis of a

Peasant Revolt. Bloomington: Indiana University Press (Tenth and Morton Streets, Bloomington, IN 47405), 1993. $35.00 (cloth). 240 pp.

Study of the political economic and social systems of the Mau Mau. Dermot MCALEESE, Jacques BOURRINET, and Alan MATTHEWS, et. al., Africa and the European Community After 1992.

Philadelphia: World Bank (P.O. Box 7247-8619, Philadelphia, PA 19170-8619), 1993. $7.95 (paper). 93 pp.

Collection of papers exploring the European Community's creation of a single economic system and the ramifications it will have on Africa. Ann McKinstry MICOU, The U.S. Independent Sector As It

Relates to South African Initiatives: A Directory. New

York: Institute of International Education (809 United Nations Plaza, New York, NY 10017), 1993. 89 pp.

the Sahel. Washington: Panos Institute (1717 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, 3rd Floor, Washington, DC 20036), 1993. 114 pp.

Focuses on successes and failures of measures used to combat the insects, and the funding efforts to eradicate plagues. Nicholas VAN HEAR, Consequences of the Forced Mass

137 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 12, 1993


LETTERS TO AFRICA NEWS ON-LINE


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Observing the events in Somalia over the past 29 months, and after my years of residence in that country, it is eminently clear that Mohamed Farah Aideed is indeed a world class criminal! He is responsible for creating anarchy and chaos by giving American and Soviet arms to teens, thugs and other irresponsible elements in the society without being able or willing to exercise appropriate discipline or control. He calls these criminals his "followers!"

With Aideed's help and encouragement, these armed hoodlums ravaged and pillaged the country. They raped and murdered innocent civilians and they looted convoys and warehouses of the food and supplies intended for the starving population. They fired on relief ships in the harbor in an effort to discourage UN intervention and the distribution of humanitarian aid. With their guns, they held hostage an innocent, starving civilian population while Aideed supplied a barrage of propaganda. Aideed lusts for the power to loot the treasury and to control the country's commercial activities for his own benefit. He has proven that he can create anarchy and chaos but not that he can govern! Above all others, he is the reason armed UN intervention was needed! 

Aideed is an obvious criminal and not the head of a government so I see no reason for the UN not to offer a substantial reward, payable in U.S. dollars, for his capture. If this is coupled with an offer of safe-keeping in a country of his choice for the captor and his family, Aideed's prompt capture can be expected. Aideed is not popular outside Mogadishu except with a few clans of the Hawiye tribe. This would be cost effective! Further, this action taken quickly will induce respect for the UN and help stem the tide of anti-Americanism in Somalia and erosion of popular support in this country resulting from the civilian deaths.

Consideration sand discussion of the matter by the UN Security Council should be kept secret, if possible, until the UN military command is ready to announce the terms. In the meantime, UN troops should be equipped with tear gas and launchers to enable them to control crowds, and break up demonstrations, without civilian casualties.

Stewart Edwards

Falls Church, VA


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 12, 1993


POLICY UNITED STATES LIFTS ARMS EMBARGO TO ANGOLA U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DEPARTMENT OF STATE Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs 22 CFR Part 126

AGENCY: U.S. Department of State

ACTION: Public Notice

SUMMARY: The Department of State is amending the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) (22 C.F.R. Parts 120-130) to reflect the removal of the domestic arms embargo on Angola.

EFFECTIVE DATE: June 24, 1993

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT: David Shapiro, Office of Defense Trade Policy, Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs,

U.S. Department of State. Phone: (202) 647-4231.

SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION: The Department of State has terminated the domestic arms embargo against Angola. Section 126.1(a) of the ITAR is being amended to reflect this change in policy with respect to the commercial export of defense articles and services to Angola. Effective immediately, it is the policy of the U.S. Government to review all licenses and approvals authorizing the export or other transfer of defense services to Angola on a case-by-case basis, with a presumption of denial for lethal articles. Approvals for export of defense articles or defense services bound for Angola will be considered for non-lethal defense articles or services.

For the purposes of this policy, "nonlethal defense articles" means an article that is not a weapon, ammunition, or other equipment or material that is designed to inflict serious bodily harm or death. (See, e.g., 10 U.S.C. n 2547)


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 12, 1993


EDITORIAL "WHEN WILL THE WORLD INTERVENE IN SUDAN?"
Bona Malwal, "Sudan Democratic Gazette," July 1993


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Ever since the United Nations General Assembly voted in December last year to condemn the human rights violations by the Khartoum regime, the debate has continued about whether the international community has both the right and the will to intervene in Sudan. The Islamic Fundamentalist military regime has reacted negatively to such talk but that was only to be expected.

There appears to be a misconception amongst many that an intervention in Sudan would need to be a military one. That is not the case at all. Military intervention is only ever a last resort, and will usually happen only when one side or the other ceases to cooperate with a humanitarian or political intervention. Humanitarian intervention in Sudan has been a way of life since 1984 and political intervention has occurred sporadically in one form or another over the same period. Recent efforts to end the conflict, such as the talks at Abuja, Nigeria in April and May, have involved foreign mediation which is probably the commonest form of political intervention. 

It is difficult to understand why a great deal of fuss is being made about the prospect of intervention from certain Sudanese politicians who have no links with the Khartoum regime. While the regime's negative response is understandable, there is less so. It seems that they are

opposed to intervention on two grounds: firstly, that Sudan's state sovereignty question would be impinged upon and, secondly, that an intervention would impose unacceptable political conditions on a future Sudan. The sovereignty question is easily dealt with because it is based on the false belief that it is the land which is sovereign rather that the people. The second fear can only be allayed by providing more facts and information to this group about precisely what an intervention would hope to achieve.

In Khartoum, a minority grouping seized power in a coup d'etat in June 1989. In the years since, that minority grouping has systematically terrorised sections of the population. All forms of political dissent have been suppressed and famine has been used as a weapon of war. The Nuba people of Southern Kordofan have become the victims of an ethnic cleansing programme. International observers have been denied access to most parts of the country. The minority grouping has been accused of exporting terrorism to neighbouring countries. All manner of international diplomatic conventions have been abused and violated by the minority grouping and in December 1992 it was condemned for its abysmal human rights record by the International Commission for Human Rights in Geneva. All of the above activities by the Khartoum regime have been well documented and made known to the international community. The question ought not to be whether there should be an intervention but when it should be initiated and what form it should take.

It ought to be obvious that the Khartoum regime is opposed to intervention because it is desperate to cling on to power and wishes to cover up the crimes it has committed whilst in power. If human rights violations had not been committed in the first place, intervention would have never gotten on to the international agenda.

Those people around the world who will eventually make the decision to intervene or not in Sudan should not allow themselves to be persuaded into inaction by the arguments mentioned so far. There is a basis for an intervention both in international law and in the human rights covenants. The crimes committed against the Sudanese people by the Khartoum regime have been well documented and provide justification enough for an intervention. Perhaps the only question to remain unanswered is whether the international community has the will to intervene in Sudan. The GAZETTE hopes and prays that it does. The time has come for the world to unfold its arms and to confront this rogue regime head on. Bona Malwal Editor and Publisher Sudan Democratic Gazette

CONTACT: Sudan Democratic gazette, P.O. Box 2295, London,

W14 0ND, United Kingdom. Subscription Rate: US $60.


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1993


LANGUAGE: English
