140 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 12, 1993


JOINT UNDERTAKING BETWEEN NELSON MANDELA, PRESIDENT OF THE ANC AND INKOSI MANGOSUTHU BUTHELEZI, PRESIDENT OF IFP AND CHIEF MINISTER OF KWAZULU


LENGTH: 2627 words


 

I. BASIC PRINCIPLES

1. South Africa has reached a crucial stage on the path to democracy. After centuries of colonial domination and apartheid, our country is poised for a major breakthrough leading to the establishment of a united, non- racial, non-sexist and democratic order and a government based on the will of the people.

2. The achievements made thus far are a result of the efforts and sacrifices made by the people of our country and international support for a democratic settlement. The people's aspirations will find expression in democratic elections for a government of their choice, and measures aimed at reconstructing our country to the benefit of all and bringing about national reconciliation.

3. The ANC and the IFP recognise the historic importance of this moment. We jointly reaffirm our commitment to the speedy resolution of the problems that remain so that our society can at least find peace and occupy its rightful place among the world community of nations. 

4. Violence remains one of the most serious impediments in the endeavor to realise these objectives. The ANC and the IFP acknowledge that every life lost is a serious indictment on the system of apartheid, our own organisations as well as other political leaders; and that it behoves all peace-loving South Africans to engender within our communities the spirits of peace and tolerance.

5. On behalf of the ANC and the IFP, we hereby reaffirm our commitment to the agreements reached in previous bilateral meetings as well as the National Peace Accord. We jointly commit ourselves to reaching an agreement together with the other signatories to strengthen the National Peace Accord, and to abide by its strengthened provisons. We hereby commit ourselves to the peaceful resolution of the problems of our country, and to a constructive approach in dealing with matters under discussion in multi-party negotiations.

In order to help contribute to the atmosphere necessary for a peaceful transition to democracy, we commit

ourselves to the following principles:

II. ORGANISATIONAL RELATIONS

1. The IFP and the ANC are two independent organisation founded to pursue what each organisation perceives as the interest of the country and its people.

2. The two organisations share the common objective of ridding SA of the scourge of apardheid and its consequences. Insofar as we share these common perspectives, we are duty- bound to co-operate in their realisation.

3. Where the ANC and IFP differ on mechanisms to this end, we commit ourselves to discus these differences in a spirit of tolerance and mutual respect, taking into account that the interests of SA and its people trancend these differences.

4. It is therefore the responsibility of both organisations to ensure that our supporters, members and particularly leaders at all levels, promote a healthy relationship between them based on such mutual respect and tolerance.

III. NORMAL POLITICAL ACTIVITY

1. The common objectives that the two organisations as well as other parties share, require that there be an atmosphere of peace among all South Africans, freedom of association, assembly and other basic human rights.

2. We therefore commit ourselves to promote the creation of such an atmosphere, and to do all in our power to prevent violations of these principles by our members and supporters. In particular, urgent measures need to be undertaken to ensure free political activity throughout SA. This entails, inter alia;

2.1 The recognition by our members and supporters of the

right of all individuals to hold their own views, and

their right to express these views without intimidation

and violence; while at the same time echewing mutual

vilification.

2.2 Where either of our organisations are able to do so canvass their views and that they are afforded the

we shall ensure that other organisations are allowed to

necessary facilities to do so. This should apply to both

urban and rural areas.

2.3 Both the IFP and ANC recognise the right of people to

assemble and give expression to their grievances and the

parties they support provided that such manifestations

are in keeping with the letter and spirit of the National

Peace Accord. To this end the IFP and the ANC agree that

if and when either party convenes a demonstration,

protest or any other form of mass action, it will ensure

that;


                2.3.1 it has given priority to the need  to promote
           peace;
                2.3.2 the action will avoid deliberate  provocation
           of opponents, injury to persons or damage to
           property;
                2.3.3 the structures of the Peace Accord  will be
           kept fully and timeously informed and will be
           utilised to maximum effect;
                2.3.4 good faith negotiations will occur  with all
           relevant parties and the security forces regarding
           the proposed action;
                2.3.5 all agreements reached regarding the  proposed
           action  will be binding, and the convening party
           will comply with them and do everything reasonably
           possible to ensure its members are aware of the
           agreements;
                2.3.6 sufficient marshals will be provided  to ensure
           that the proposed action is peaceful and
           disciplined;
                2.3.7 all reasonable steps will be taken  to make
           sure that no weapons are carried with unlawful
           intent;
                2.3.8 in making its decision as to  whether the
           action would be embarked upon, the convening party
           will give due cognisance to thew political climate
           prevailing at the time and the appropriateness of
           the proposed action;
                2.3.9 the convening party will plan the  route of any
           demonstration so as to provide for a specific  place
           where it is to start, the route which is to be
           followed and a place where the march should end  and
           where and how marchers should disperse;
                2.3.10 provision will be made for  effective means of
           communications between the conveners of the action,
           marshals, peace committee monitors, the police and
           any other relevant party during the action and
           immediately thereafter.
3. Realising that the problem of violence and legitimate law enforcement should also be addressed in the context of the unfolding transitions, we commit ourselves to contribute constructively to the multilateral negotiaions on multiparty control of all armed formations. In particular, we agree that all proposals regarding armed formations in the country should be considered in the light of a single, over-riding objective; to establish impartial, accountable, effective and legitimate security forces for a democratic South Africa. To this end, we specifically endorse the proposals made in the Fourth Report of the Technical Committee on Violence at the Multi-Party Negotiating Process regarding the adoption of a series of phased, confidence building measures within a common framework to achieve this objective. We recognise that within this common framework a clear distinction will have to be drawn between statutory and non-statutory armies on the one hand and police forces on the other during the transition to democracy and thereafter. This distinction is consistent with our view that policing functions should be clearly distinguished from military functions and our view that the various armies should play no role in the election process which lies before us, while the various police forces and a multi-party peace-keeping force will be required to fulfil ongoing law and order functions.

4. Where there are disputes between us, including disputes regarding either party's freedom to canvass its views and be afforded the necessary facilities to do so or regarding the exercise of the right to freedom of assembly, we agree to attempt to resolve these disputes in a constructive manner. We agree that the primary mechanisms for dispute resolution between us are those contained in the National Peace Accord and direct meetings and liaison between our two organisations.

5. Realising that apartheid and the variety of struggles against it have had particularly serious consequences for South Africa's youth, and that there is a need to constructively channel the energies and hope of the youth, we commit ourselves to participate together in the development of a peace-corps/youth services under the auspices of the National Peace Accord.

IV JOINT MECHANISMS

1. In order to promote healthy and contructive interaction between our organisations, we commit ourselves to strengthen and expedite the work of the joint liaison structures between our two organisations. We call on these structures to speed up their work aimed at finalising detailed agreements on matters of mutual concern for ratification by the respective executives.

2. In order to obviate some of the problems that beset relations between the two organisations after previous bilateral meetings, we agree that such joint mechanisms should include measures aimed at monitoring progress in the implementation programmes agreed upon and dealing with such violations as may occur. Further, we pledge to ensure that problems that arise in this relationship will be handled first and foremost through the channels agreed upon rather through the media; and that such contact will not be broken off simply as a result of differences that might emerge.

3. In the endeavor to ensure that the relations between our organisations find expression among the people, we undertake to initiate and encourage activities among our

structures at all levels. this will include:

3.1 Joint mass rallies, meetings and marches by local as well as regional structures - which should be undertaken as a matter of urgency to relate to one another in this spirit of co-operation, mutual respect and tolerance.

4. None among us should see it necessary, no matter how serious the point of disagreement, to resort to violence. Those who seek to exploit whatever differences may exist between the two organisations for their own ends, will then stick out like a sore thumb.

5. Great possibilities exist for the final resolution of the political problems that have gripped our country for decades and even centuries. We owe it to ourselves, our children and generations to come, not to squander this historic opportunity.

6. The future of peace and democracy for which many have sacrificed their lives is within reach. Let us grasp it with both hands.

Department of Information and Publicity P O Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 23 June 1993

For more information, contact, William Bowles, African National Congress, Dept. of Information & Publicity. Email

comments to: bbowles@anc_dip.wn.apc.org Voice:2711-330

7083, Fax:2711-333-8870.


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 12, 1993


UNITED NATIONS SECRETARY-GENERAL BOUTROS-GHALI ADDRESS TO ORGANIZATION OF AFRICAN UNITY


LENGTH: 8280 words


 

CAIRO--Summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) A year ago I met with this distinguished assembly of African leaders in Dakar, and it is that meeting that we resume today in a spirit of love and friendship. I say "resume" because it is a meeting that has never ended.

Today, in Cairo, at the outset of my talk with you, I should like to extend my greetings to His Excellency President Abdou Diouf, and in so doing, I also express my sincere thanks and appreciation for the role played by President Diouf personally during Senegal's chairmanship of the Organization of African Unity, during which African issues were followed in depth and with genuine sincerity. This had an excellent effect on cooperation and coordination between the OAU and the United Nations at all levels.

I should like to take this opportunity to note with admiration and appreciation this active role. 

It is also a pleasure for me to draw particular attention to the positive, influential role played by the Secretary-General of the OAU, Salim Ahmed Salim, and to his solicitude in supporting cooperation among the various agencies of the two organizations and his endeavours to promote constant coordination on all African issues.

I am particularly pleased to extend special greetings to President Muhammad Hosni Mubarak, who is to assume the leadership of the Organization of African Unity for the coming year. Greetings to you, Mr. President, and through you to the people of Egypt, to whom I am proud to belong. Greetings to every Egyptian man and woman in this excellent land and greetings especially to Cairo, the immortal African city on the banks of whose river Nile the first African summit conference was held and which is today hosting the twenty-ninth such conference. Today's summit is not just another ordinary sessional meeting -- it marks the culmination of 30 years of existence of the Organization of African Unity, which was the dream, the goal and the labour of the early pioneers of the liberation movement and has become the springboard, forum and framework for joint African action.

The holding of these two summit conferences in Cairo is not due to mere coincidence or chance, for Egypt's historical record testifies to the African role played by Egypt in supporting African liberation movements, in fostering and assisting the process of independence on this continent, in fighting against colonialism and racial discrimination, in participating and playing an active role in the founding of the Organization of African Unity and in working constructively to promote development and progress for the peoples of Africa. Ahmad Hishmet Pasha Street, in the Zamalek district, where the headquarters of the African Society, Egypt, is located, will remain a symbol of independence, of struggle and of freedom in Africa, for Cairo has been a witness to the struggle of leaders who have gloriously led their nations to freedom and independence.

It is a pleasure for me today to congratulate, here in Egypt, the free State of Eritrea on joining the family of African nations after our celebration, this past 28 May, of its joining the international community and becoming the 182nd member of the United Nations. I should like on this occasion to salute President Issaias Afwerki and to extend to him and to the people of Eritrea heartfelt congratulations. That event in itself has special significance, confirming as it does the importance and soundness of the organization of African States and its ability to take up challenges and continue realizing the goals of its charter.

And so, just as the spark of the first summit conference was struck in Cairo, so will today's summit give new impetus towards a more brilliant future of greater growth.

More than any other region, Africa displays the vast range of United Nations activities for peace, democracy and development. Development assistance, humanitarian relief, regional cooperation, human rights, preventive diplomacy and peacemaking have all been important areas of United Nations activity in Africa during the past year.

I wish to begin this survey of United Nations activities in Africa with a few encouraging words on the increasingly important role that the United Nations is playing in assisting Africa's process of self- democratization. A sincere commitment to self- democratization must remain our common focus. While set- backs have occurred and progress cannot be taken for granted, the general trend towards self-democratization in Africa has been both positive and encouraging.

I am pleased to report to you that electoral assistance has been an area of substantial United Nations activity in Africa during the past year. Since the establishment of the United Nations Electoral Assistance Unit, the United Nations has provided electoral assistance to 46 Member States -- a majority of which are located in Africa. Requests for electoral assistance from African countries have included requests for technical and operational assistance, election monitoring and United Nations verification. Electoral assistance has now become a key feature of virtually every United Nations peacemaking initiative now under way -- including those taking place in Africa.

In Somalia, the United Nations is presently engaged in its most ambitious and comprehensive undertaking ever. Years of civil war and factional fighting had resulted in the widespread destruction of the country's infrastructure, and in the complete breakdown of all governmental authority. Famine, social upheaval and massive population displacement were the realities that the United Nations confronted in Somalia. In 1992 alone, between 300,000 and 500,000 Somalis died -- mostly young children.

The United Nations Operation in Somalia (UNOSOM II), the first stage of the United Nations effort in Somalia, responded directly to the immediate humanitarian crisis that the country faced. Unfortunately, due to the widespread anarchy, looting and conflict that then prevailed in Somalia, the delivery of humanitarian aid could not be secured and the situation continued to deteriorate.

In response, the Security Council in December 1992, by resolution 794 (1992), authorized the establishment of a unified command for Somalia -- UNITAF -- with a mandate to establish a secure environment for humanitarian relief operations throughout the country. In March 1993, the Council voted to authorize UNOSOM II -- resolution 814 (1993) -- giving it a mandate to continue disarmament and pacification, and to work towards fostering national reconciliation, dialogue and the strengthening of political institutions.

The UNOSOM II will include a force of 28,000 military and 2,800 civilian personnel from 32 countries, plus a Quick Reaction Force of 1,200 United States troops that can be deployed anywhere in Somalia within 24 hours. To date, six African countries have contributed troops for the Somalia operations -- Morocco, Nigeria, Egypt, Botswana, Zimbabwe and Tunisia. Contingents from Zambia and Uganda will be in place before the end of July. I want to express here my gratitude for these African contributions and for this concrete expression of African solidarity.

Despite the temporary disruption in activities that has occurred in recent weeks, UNOSOM II has now begun the process of restoring to the people of Somalia the sovereignty and integrity of their State. Throughout the country, the situation is very much improved. Food aid has reached the starving, violence has been curtailed, order is being restored and the process of reconstructing Somalia has begun. The close collaboration between the United Nations, the OAU, the Organization of the Islamic Conference and the Arab League, has greatly assisted all aspects of the United Nations operation in Somalia, and has ensured that the process of encouraging political reconciliation and development is conducted in a manner that is appropriately sensitive to local needs, issues and concerns.

None the less, the costs of intervention in Somalia have been extraordinarily high. In human terms, 30 United Nations peace-keepers and two United Nations personnel from the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) have lost their lives in the international effort to assist the people of Somalia. A further 90 United Nations peace-keepers have been wounded in this effort -- many seriously.

In addition to the human costs, the financial costs of intervening in Somalia have also been high. The cost of military operations during the first six months alone exceeded $600 million. The total military costs for the first 18 months will likely exceed $1.6 billion. In addition, the United Nations has now formulated a $160 million 1993 Programme for the Relief and Rehabilitation of Somalia, targeting the re-establishment of local administrative capacity, the creation of employment opportunities, the repatriation of refugees and displaced persons, the expansion of agriculture and livestock, and the re-establishment of primary education and vocational training. Pledges of $130 million have so far been made for the 1993 Programme.

Somalia is slowly beginning to recover. This recovery cannot, and will not be allowed to fail because of the reckless and irresponsible actions of a few anti-democratic elements. The calculated and deliberate attacks that have been directed by certain factions against United Nations personnel in Somalia must be condemned in the strongest possible terms. It is in the interests of the international community and of the people of Somalia that the perpetrators of these criminal acts be found and that they be held fully accountable for their actions.

Turning to the Sudan, the ongoing conflict in the south of the country has made an already difficult humanitarian situation much worse. The United Nations has intensified and expanded humanitarian relief programmes throughout the country in order to cope with the effects of drought and civil war. The United Nations has also maintained a broad range of basic development programmes in the Sudan targeting health, nutrition, water, sanitation and agriculture.

In 1992, approximately 5.5 million persons affected by drought in the Sudan required emergency food aid. It is expected that this number will be reduced to 1.1 million in 1993, if the expectation of a generally good harvest holds true. To address these needs, the United Nations has appealed for $205 million in humanitarian assistance to the Sudan, including $130 million for food aid requirements and $75 million for non-food rehabilitation assistance, such as health services and the provision of seeds and tools.

In order to focus greater international attention on the humanitarian crisis affecting the Sudan, I recently appointed a Special Envoy to the Sudan for humanitarian affairs. The Special Envoy has begun consultations with all concerned parties on ways and means to meet humanitarian needs, including enhanced access to affected regions and better security for the delivery of relief supplies. As part of this humanitarian effort, the United Nations also stands ready to support the current OAU-sponsored peace process in any capacity which the participants might deem useful.

In Eritrea, a United Nations mission -- the United Nations Observer Mission to Verify the Referendum in Eritrea (UNOVER) -- was given responsibility for verifying the agreed referendum on independence. A mission composed of 21 international staff and 100 observers was authorized by the General Assembly. The referendum achieved a 98 per cent turnout and a 99 per cent vote for independence. The results were verified by the United Nations, and the referendum was officially certified by United Nations monitors to have been free and fair.

Working with the newly-installed Government of Eritrea, United Nations agencies have produced an $81 million consolidated appeal for humanitarian assistance to Eritrea. Three quarters of Eritrea's population is at least partly dependent on food aid, and over 500,000 refugees must now be repatriated from neighbouring countries. These challenges, together with the task of reconstructing and rebuilding Eritrea will require the active cooperation and assistance of the United Nations and of the international community for years to come.

It is, therefore, particularly gratifying that one of the very first countries to recognize Eritrea's independence was Ethiopia. On 28 May, I had the privilege of seeing the Eritrean flag raised for the first time at the United Nations, and of welcoming Eritrea as the 182nd Member State of the United Nations. The determination of Ethiopia and Eritrea to work together in meeting the challenges of the future is a source of great encouragement and a bright omen for the region.

In Ethiopia itself, the number of people requiring assistance has dropped from 9 million in 1992 to 6.5 million in 1993, due primarily to increased food production and to intense health and nutrition activities. An integrated inter-agency appeal has been launched to cover the $300 million cost of meeting present 1993 needs.

In Rwanda, the United Nations has sought to lessen the risk of conflict breaking out between Rwanda and Uganda, while also working closely with the OAU to support the Arusha peace process between the Government of Rwanda and the Rwandese Patriotic Front.

In separate letters to the Security Council in February 1993, the Governments of Rwanda and Uganda called for the deployment of United Nations military observers along their common border. In April, I dispatched a technical mission to Uganda and Rwanda in order to gather relevant information. In May, I recommended the establishment of the United Nations Observer Mission Uganda- Rwanda (UNOMUR). Last week, the Security Council adopted a resolution establishing UNOMUR and authorizing the deployment of observers to the region.

In recommending the deployment of United Nations observers I noted that a decision to deploy observers to the Uganda/Rwanda border could also help to promote the negotiation process in Arusha and encourage the parties to actively pursue their efforts towards peace and national reconciliation in Rwanda.

To address the dire humanitarian consequences of the conflict in Rwanda, the United Nations has now launched an inter-agency appeal for $78 million in international assistance to meet the needs of the 900,000 displaced persons in Rwanda.

In Liberia, the United Nations has worked closely with the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the OAU to achieve a cease-fire and obtain adherence to the Yamoussoukro IV Agreement. The ECOWAS has provided strong military and diplomatic leadership, fully supported by both the Security Council and the various political and humanitarian organs of the United Nations.

Liberia is a good example of the type of cooperation between the United Nations and a regional organization that was envisaged in Chapter VIII of the Charter. At the initiative of the ECOWAS, the Security Council convened on 19 November 1992 to consider the conflict in Liberia. The Council adopted resolution 788 (1992) imposing an arms embargo on the country, urging the appointment of a special envoy for Liberia, and calling upon all parties to the conflict to respect and implement the cease-fire and other accords. Shortly afterwards I named Trevor Gordon-Somers as my Special Representative for Liberia and dispatched him to the region to assess the situation and help mediate the conflict.

Following continued military engagements between the ECOWAS and the forces of Charles Taylor, the Security Council met again to consider Liberia in March 1993. The Council expressed its continued support for the ECOWAS and for the Yamoussoukro IV Agreement, and declared its readiness to consider appropriate measures in support of the ECOWAS if any party was unwilling to cooperate in implementing the Agreement.

While a cease-fire has still not yet been agreed to, all sides have now agreed that upon the signing of such a cease-fire, the United Nations should be called upon to monitor implementation of the cease-fire and the Agreement. The parties have also agreed that the United Nations should subsequently be involved in monitoring the conduct of the election provided for under the Yamoussoukro IV Agreement.

Most recently, following the brutal massacre of women and children at Harbel, Liberia, I instructed my Special Representative to go to Liberia, and to conduct a thorough investigation of this crime. I wish again to express my extreme outrage at this incident and to make it clear to all concerned in the conflict in Liberia that such conduct cannot be tolerated.

Given the extent of the damage and destruction caused by the civil war in Liberia, it will be necessary for the United Nations and the entire international community to support a comprehensive programme for reconstruction and development once peace has returned to the country. To meet interim humanitarian needs, I have launched several appeals for humanitarian assistance to Liberia. Of the total of $161 million requested, $104 million has so far been pledged.

In Western Sahara, the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) has now been in operation for two and a half years. Although the Settlement Plan called for the referendum to be held in January 1992, a firm date for the referendum has still not yet been fixed. In March, the Security Council signalled its growing impatience with the slow pace of negotiations over the organization of the referendum, and set a deadline of the end of this year for the referendum to take place.

Preparations for the referendum are being speeded up. In response to the Security Council's action, my Special Representative Sahabzada Yaqub-Khan, travelled to the mission area at the end of March for talks with the parties. On his return to New York, Mr. Yaqub-Khan reported to me that both Morocco and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro (POLISARIO) had shown a desire to move towards an early referendum. Against this background, and in response to calls from the parties, I visited the mission area in the first week of June in order to help reach a compromise solution on the remaining issues, and also to underscore the importance of implementing the Settlement Plan without further delay.

I am pleased to report to you that as a result of these negotiations the differences between the parties have been substantially narrowed. I am optimistic that agreement on the terms of reference for the referendum will soon be reached, and that this will help to generate momentum for the holding of the referendum at an early date.

In the meantime, preparations are continuing. The initial deployment of civilian police officers to Western Sahara has now taken place, and the full deployment will proceed as required. A 10-member Identification Commission for the referendum has now been established, and after the completion of essential preparatory activities, the Commission will begin voter registration. Although it is now apparent that the budget of $143 million, which was approved by the General Assembly in May of 1991, will require additional support, I am hopeful that the concrete steps now under way will persuade the General Assembly to allocate the needed additional resources.

In Mozambique, I am happy to report that the United Nations operation there -- United Nations Operation in Mozambique (ONUMOZ II) -- has now become fully operational. The Security Council and General Assembly have approved a budget of more than $330 million for the operation, and a United Nations force of about 7,100 military troops and civilian police has now been deployed. This force includes contingents from six African countries -- Botswana, Cape Verde, Congo, Egypt, Guinea-Bissau and Zambia. I wish again to express my thanks and gratitude to these countries for their contributions and their solidarity, and also to express my appreciation to the Government of Zimbabwe for its transitional assistance prior to the arrival of United Nations forces.

Under the Rome Agreement, government and Mozambique National Resistance Movement (RENAMO) forces are to be demobilized and grouped into 49 United Nations-monitored assembly points. Following certain initial delays the demobilization process has now begun. Full demobilization in accordance with the terms of the Agreement will be completed prior to the holding of United Nations verified elections. It is expected that preparations for these elections will be completed by the middle of next year.

In a new departure, a United Nations Trust Fund has been established for implementation of the electoral aspects of the peace process. The Fund will assist political parties to organize and prepare for the electoral process, and covers costs associated with requirements such as transportation, office space, communication facilities and other essentials. Over $10 million has already been donated to the Fund.

The rehabilitation and recovery of Mozambique after more than a decade and a half of protracted civil war will be a daunting challenge. More than a million and a half Mozambicans have taken refuge in neighbouring countries, and between 4 and 5 million more remain displaced inside Mozambique in search of food and security. A consolidated humanitarian assistance programme has been developed for Mozambique to support emergency relief, repatriation, demobilization, the restoration of essential services and the country's balance of payments deficit. The programme will require $559.6 million for the 12-month period from May 1993 through April 1994, of which $450 million has already been pledged and committed to specific activities. During the recent donors meeting in Maputo, additional pledges amounting to some $70 million were announced. In South Africa, 60 United Nations observers are now working in close collaboration with counterparts from the OAU, the Commonwealth Secretariat and the European Community to facilitate South Africa's transition to majority rule. United Nations observers have provided support to community peace projects, assisted local development initiatives, worked to ease political tensions and monitored police conduct at political marches and rallies.

In addition to these efforts, I have myself undertaken several initiatives during the past year to try to curb the terrifying cycle of violence that has gripped South Africa. I have repeatedly urged all South African leaders and political parties to put an end to violence and to work together to reach agreement on interim arrangements for the establishment of a new political system. In this connection, my special representatives and envoys have met with all of the major political parties to discuss the implementation of United Nations resolutions calling for the establishment of a united, non-racial and democratic South Africa.

After many years of government opposition to the presence of international observers, these initiatives and activities mark a significant breakthrough for South Africa and for the United Nations.

With respect to Angola, there is less reason for optimism. The collapse of the Bicesse Accords following the refusal of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) to accept its defeat at the polls plunged Angola back into civil war. The small United Nations force authorized under the United Nations Angola Verification Mission (UNAVEM II) mandate was wholly unsuited to intervene in the fierce resumption of hostilities that followed.

The deteriorating political and military situation in Angola, the collapse of the joint monitoring and verification groups provided for under the Bicesse Accords, and the evacuation of most UNAVEM II sites have drastically reduced the observation and verification functions of the mission -- which formed the main part of its mandate. The UNAVEM II, therefore, is now concentrating its efforts on liaison activities and on assisting the delivery of humanitarian relief to the civilian population.

The humanitarian situation in Angola remains very grave. Health services, market structures and food production efforts have largely collapsed. It is now estimated that more than 2 million Angolans are suffering from hunger, drought and disease. Recent reports indicate that over 1,000 people a day are dying from malnutrition and other factors associated with the war.

In order to address these grave problems, the United Nations has launched a $226 million consolidated inter- agency appeal for Angola. This and other assistance will continue to be supervised and coordinated by my Special Representative for Angola.

None the less, providing humanitarian relief under present conditions remains a daunting challenge. Humanitarian assistance continues to be delivered to both government- and UNITA-controlled areas, albeit with great difficulty and often at significant risk to the United Nations personnel involved. United Nations flights have been fired upon by UNITA forces, and aid relief workers have been attacked throughout the country. Although the collapse of the Abidjan talks leaves little room for optimism, the United Nations will continue its efforts to provide humanitarian relief while working to achieve a cease-fire and a resumption of the peace process.

In view of the set-back suffered in Angola, it is especially heartening for me to be able to conclude this survey of United Nations activities with a genuine and remarkable success story from Africa. Quick and exemplary international cooperation to deal with the devastating drought in southern Africa averted a widely predicted catastrophe. Commentators had compared the southern African drought to the deadly drought that gripped Ethiopia and the Sudan in 1984-85, and it was predicted that hundreds of thousands of people would likely perish due to famine and disease.

Ten countries in southern Africa were involved, and approximately 20 million people spread over 2 million square miles were affected. Total food output throughout the region had dropped to less than half that of previous years, and 4 million tons of food aid was needed from donor countries. Emergency non-food needs were estimated to approach $200 million.

Led by the countries of the region, coordinated by the United Nations system and matched by a quick donor response, disaster was averted. The 10 Southern African Development Community (SADC) countries mobilized to battle the disaster with extraordinary speed. The SADC early warning units had alerted the world to the looming famine at a very early stage, and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Food Programme (WFP) jointly mounted multiple crop and food supply assessment missions confirming the enormity of the problem the region faced. The newly established Department of Humanitarian Affairs then prepared the United Nations system's first-ever famine relief appeal, issued jointly by the United Nations and a regional body, SADC.

Donors responded immediately with food aid pledges covering virtually all the assistance that was needed. The seriousness and commitment demonstrated by SADC, as well as donor satisfaction with the procedures initiated by the United Nations to keep donors abreast of developments in all sectors, encouraged the fast donor response and facilitated this impressive mobilization of resources and effort.

With the return of the rains to southern Africa, this remarkable effort in human cooperation has been fittingly rewarded.

It is also heartening for me to refer to one of the major areas of concern to the United Nations, which is human development.

The United Nations continues to give priority attention to human development goals in Africa, particularly as it relates to children. In this regard, UNICEF provided assistance to the OAU for the convening of the International Conference on Assistance to African Children, in Dakar last November. The Consensus of Dakar sets out important goals to be achieved in Africa by 1995 in furtherance of child survival, protection and development. I can ssure you that the United Nations system will support the efforts of African countries to achieve those goals.

In concluding this opening speech, I should like to invite you -- to invite us all -- to reflect and to demand more of ourselves. I should like all of us here to undertake the most difficult task there is, but one which

every man and woman on this continent expects of us: to consider Africa's future.

To consider the future of Africa is both to think in the long term and to think "here and now". It means being mindful of the broad economic forces and devoting one's attention to people's daily lives. It means constructing a general political context for future action and finding practical means to embody present reality.

To consider Africa's future is also to create new bonds at the national, regional and international levels. It is to mobilize energies and consciences on behalf of development. It is to place one's confidence in a rich continent -- yes, a continent which is very rich in people, in ideas and in raw materials. But it is also a continent in which intolerable inequalities prevail, and in which lavish expenditure exists side by side with unimaginable poverty.

To think about Africa's future is lastly to find means, models and projects which can rekindle our confidence. It is to believe in the capacity of Africans freely to invent their own history. It is to restore pride in itself to a continent which is essential for mankind.

For these intentions to be more than just pious hopes and become a plan of action, it is more necessary than ever before to reflect together and to allow our imaginations free rein, while at the same time placing them at the service of our common objectives.

These objectives are centred about a single word -- the word "development". But make no mistake, this word, which seems so simple, denotes a process of infinite complexity.

This process is complex because development is neither a model to be copied, nor a programme to be executed. It is an ongoing response to world developments. It is complex because development cannot be reduced to economic development alone. It has a political, social, cultural and psychological dimension as well. It is complex because development depends both on others and on oneself. It is complex because development embraces a common outlook and diverse ways of approaching it.

Lastly, it is complex because it is not an objective in and of itself, but is rather the transcendant expression of a number of other objectives. Among those objectives which both circumscribe and promote development are the imperative of peace and the duty of democracy.

The imperative of peace is essential for the controlled management of development in Africa.

When I read development projects, plans of action, medium-term adjustments, economic programmes, I am always struck by the fact that they all assume -- whether through naivete, excessive optimism, ignorance, lack of courage, I am not sure -- the existence of an idyllic state of peace. In these future-oriented analyses, war appears as nothing more than a random occurrence. Unfortunately, when it comes to Africa, one must admit that aggression, border conflicts, tribal strife, ethnic confrontation and civil war, far from being a passing phase in our history, appear to be serious and persistent trends.

Like you, I know that Africa is not solely responsible for these situations of conflict. Far from it. The arbitrary carving up of land, frontiers inherited from the period of colonization, rivalries stirred up from outside and the pressure of foreign interests have, alas, become quasi-permanent features of the African political landscape. Over the past 50 years it is Africa which has experienced the greatest number of armed conflicts, in spite of the commendable efforts of the OAU to settle disputes between African countries.

As Secretary-General of the United Nations, I have spoken, whenever I have had the opportunity, of the importance I attach to the role of regional organizations in the solution of conflicts. Indeed, I have had the opportunity to see how the OAU, together with the League of Arab States and the Organization of the Islamic Conference, played a leading role in Somalia.

Once again I invite the OAU to be completely faithful to the mission entrusted to it by its founding fathers -- peace. Peace as an element in the democratization of international life; peace as the victory of democracy.

The democratic imperative is in fact one of the fundamental tasks that Africa must take on. I see democracy as the missing link between peace and development -- because democracy safeguards peace, and because sound development is unimaginable without democracy.

But this concept of democracy must continually be given a new form -- and this OAU Conference is an ideal setting for giving thought to this. Yes, democracy is a concept that has to be constantly reinvented. By that I mean -- and I want to tell you this in the clearest possible way -- that in exhorting you thus to promote democracy, I have no wish to urge you to be imitative in any way or to call on you to borrow political forms from elsewhere, or still less to try to please certain Westerners. On the contrary, It has to be said firmly that democracy belongs to no one. It can and must be assimilated by all cultures. It can take myriad forms and is, thus, all the better geared to the situation of peoples all around the world. Democracy cannot be fashioned after the model provided by certain States; rather, it is a goal to be attained by all peoples. It is the manifestation of our common heritage. It is an asset that must be shared by all. Democracy also belongs to Africa.

In this grand democratic scheme of things, a contribution is required of all citizens -- both women and men -- and of associations and public opinion. But I believe that above all it is the noblest task that falls to States. Yes, I believe in the State, in its capacity to transform structures and to safeguard freedoms. I believe that both in Africa and elsewhere the State is a melting-pot for cultures, a favoured place for learning about civic responsibility. And I am filled with the most profound concern when I see some States -- more frequently in Africa than elsewhere -- sink into failure, into decay and into disorder, until they are nothing more than an abstract backcloth for true anarchy.

Where attaining the democratic ideal is concerned -- and I am saying this to you here in earnest -- I expect a great deal of the State.

The State, as I see it, is not merely a narrow circle of political leaders. I would even say, without contradicting myself, that the State is first and foremost an administration. An administration that is sound, honest, dedicated, educated and concerned about public service and the public interest. We know that Africa does not have any prerogative where corruption is concerned, and that corruption is the most evenly distributed evil in the world. In Africa, however, the administration often has to be

created, rebuilt or restored. This is an urgent task: without an administration, there can be no true democracy.

In my view, the State also serves the cause of fundamental freedoms. We know today that freedom cannot be promoted against the will of the State, but must be built in cooperation with the State. Africa has played an important role with regard to this change in thinking. It is Africa that has gone the furthest, in various international forums, in examining the relationships between domestic law, human rights and the law of nations.

None the less, we all know, international public opinion is often harsh with regard to human rights in Africa. Does this mean that we are more barbarous than people elsewhere? Do we have less respect for human nature? Are our diplomats not as well trained as those of other countries in projecting a positive image of our countries abroad? Or is the industrialized countries' aim to find an easy way of exonerating themselves of the grave injustices prevailing in their territories by focusing international public opinion on Africa? Today these are questions that we cannot avoid asking ourselves and to which I, for my part, have a number of partial answers.

One thing is certain in any event -- there can be no sustainable development without promotion of democracy and, consequently, without respect for human rights. We are all aware that undemocratic practices and authoritarian policies sometimes accompany the measures taken early on by some countries when they embark on the development process. However, we also know that if, once they have achieved initial economic results, these States do not undertake democratic reform, the final outcome will be merely insubstantial growth, which is a source of greater inequalities and social disruption in the future. I repeat, only democracy makes development meaningful.

Today, the question of Africa's development presents itself in terms that are both old and new.

They are old, sadly, for reasons which we can only

enumerate once again: the debt burden; the unfairness of the international economic system; Africa's trade and technological dependence; inadequate or non-existent infrastructure; and inadequate vocational and technical training, to mention a few.

But the question has a new dimension as well, for the rest of the world's perception of Africa has changed. And this is a source of great concern to me. With the end of the cold war, the West has lived through a period of euphoria in the past few years, and Europe -- Africa's traditional advocate -- is tempted to turn inwards and redirect its development assistance and investment towards its new, eastern "frontier".

In the wake of the new international economic order, the very concept of partnership is becoming a dim memory. Today, the industrialized countries are having a difficult time choosing between their business relations and their humanitarian impulses in their dealings with Africa. Concerted development is increasingly becoming an idea without substance.

Africa must learn everything that this situation has to teach. Far from giving up on the international community, Africa must show by its own actions that it is worthy of that community's confidence.

To this end, Africa must itself undertake a number of

urgent tasks: first of all, Africa must strengthen its regional structures so that progress can be achieved throughout the continent. How many economic, customs and administrative stumbling blocks, how many infrastructural and communications inadequacies could be overcome by more effective cooperation between African States. In this area, regional and subregional economic organizations should, at last, play a role consistent with their charters. Yet, paradoxically, there may actually be too many of these organizations. In any event, there are too few that function in a satisfactory manner.

Secondly, Africa must diversify its economy. Today, consensus has been achieved on one point -- the whole world agrees that national stabilization policies are imperative. Yet this raises many questions. Are there special steps that must be taken to promote such diversification? Should diversification be promoted through intervention and, if so, how should this be done? Or, is it better simply to let countries straighten out their macroeconomic policies, leaving diversification to the operations of the market? How can feasibility studies be encouraged in this area, and how can they be financed? Africa must find its own answers to all these questions.

Lastly, Africa must promote training. The region has a sizeable population, which is an invaluable resource. The people of Africa must be guaranteed food and health. More than ever, I believe in the capacity of African men and women for work, action, initiative, imagination and creativity. All the initiatives that I have witnessed or learned of fill me with confidence. In towns, Africa must control urban growth and adapt technological progress to specific needs of the African people. In the countryside, farmers must be given respect commensurate with the importance and dignity of their labour. And here I should like to emphasize and commend the exemplary role played by rural women.

Yet, it is common knowledge that such efforts on the part of Africa require a high level of support. In saying this I am appealing not to the generosity but to the conscience of the industrialized countries. I urge them to become aware of international linkages, to learn how the interests of our planet are interdependent and to acknowledge that Africa can be an element of peace and prosperity for the entire world if it at last receives that which is its due.

Obviously, this assumes the existence of a market that does not systematically favour the richest. It also assumes a mandatory reduction of the debt weighing on Africa's shoulder and encumbering its capacities for self-financing. In addition, the industrialized States must provide project- specific financing, promote the training of a skilled labour force and encourage long-term projects. The international community must invent new forms of cooperation, of assistance between States, of assistance between States and organizations and assistance between organizations. In short, the entire cycle of cooperation must be reconsidered.

This, then, ladies and gentlemen, is the message, the

cry that I would like to raise: No, Africa is not alone! No, Africa has not been abandoned! The eyes of the world are still on Africa!

As for myself, rest assured that from my current vantage point, I am devoting all my energy to mobilizing the international community and the United Nations on behalf of Africa so that they may encourage Africa's efforts, which I know to be considerable, and so that Africa, far from being a continent untouched by progress, may at last assume its rightful place as an integral part of mankind on the march.


LOAD-DATE: July 19, 1993

EDUCATION


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Limited space is available on a 16-day tour of Cameroon's rainforests and cultural sites. Held December 19, 1993-January 4, 1994, the tour indludes sightseeing expeditions with including hikes and canoeing. Total price with air fare, is approximately $4,000. Contact Afor, (312) 907-9759 or Etoke (205) 252-8353 for more information. "Computers and Communications for Development in Africa" is the name of a conference to be held in Olympia, London on September 22-23. Delegates will look at hardware and software options for business, and focus on trends in the computer industry and their impact on 

Africa. DEADLINE: September 13. For more information,

contact: African Information Technology Exhibitions and Conferences, 15 High Street, Graveley, Cambridgeshire PE18 9PL, United Kingdom; phone 44-480-830724, fax 44- 480-831131. Boston University is offering a Language/Liberal Arts Program as well as Global Internships in Niamey, Niger. Both programs examine educational reform, development

efforts and Sahelian life. Contact: Boston University, Office of International Programs, Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; phone (617) 353-9888. The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and talk to people involved in preparing for democratic elections. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points

in North America. APPLICATION DEADLINE: September 13.

Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College,

731-21st Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover periods ranging from 12 to 24

months. DEADLINE: October 1. Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies

7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

JULY 26, 1993


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

TechnoServe, a non-profit rural enterprise development organization seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa Division Headquarters in Norwalk, CT. Responsibilities include project management, evaluation, budgeting, financial management, training and fundraising

experience. QUALIFICATIONS: Five years resident overseas experience in business or agricultural development, seven years international development work, including at least two years in Africa; fluent French preferred; must be willing to travel internationally. Send letter and

resume to: TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or fax (203) 838-6717, c/o Terri Scofield, manager of human resources. A PROJECT MANAGER is needed by the American Friends of the AICF in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenace of property; liaison with donors, orther non- governmental organizations and authorities. 

QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiatins, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environemtn; knowledge of primary health care issues.

NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783- 5247. International Medical Corps (IMC) seeks a COUNTRY DIRECTOR to develop and implement its programs in

Somalia. Accounting skills desirable. Assignment is for six months minimum, starting SEPTEMBER 1, 1993. Position

#: Dept. 93-021.

sites in Somalia. QUALIFICATIONS: five years experience in nonprofit/government financial management; sound understanding of accounting/financial principles; excellent oral and written communications skills required. Assignment is for six months minimum,

IMMEDIATE OPENING. Position #: Dept. 93-022.

#280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622. NYZS/The Wildlife Conservation Society seeks a BUFFER ZONE MANAGER to be stationed in Masoala Peninsula, Madagascar. extension/facilitation agents. Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10460; phone: (718) 220

5887; fax: (718) 364-4275. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. liberalization. assistance program. Location: Nairobi. Salary, Program

brief writing sample for Position #205 to: Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017. travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016. Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in

the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and

December, 1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930. 

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and

December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in

physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December

1993 and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November

1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly

renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month

considered): September-December 1993): The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; September 1993, January-March 1994, May-June, 1994,

August-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157;

phone: (202) 296-0928. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404)

766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

AFRICA WATCH, Beyond the Rhetoric -- Continuing Human

Rights Abuses in Rwanda. New York: Human Rights Watch (485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017), 1993. $3.00 (paper). 29 pp.

Examination of treatment of political opponents and citizens by the Rwandan government.

AFRICA WATCH, Liberia -- Waging War to Keep the Peace:

The Ecomog Intervention and Human Rights. New York: Human Rights Watch, 1993. $3.00 (paper). 34 pp. 

Evaluation of human rights abuses by Ecomog forces since October 1992. AFRICA WATCH, Nigeria -- Threats to a New Democracy.

New York: Human Rights Watch, 1993. $3.00 (paper). 23 pp.

Background on the military government's actions against civil institutions and the handling of religious and ethnic conflicts prior to the elections held in June. AFRICA WATCH, Zambia -- Model for Democracy Declares

State of Emergency. New York: Human Rights Watch, 1993. $3.00 (paper). 7 pp.

Examines what forces contributed to the current declaration of state of emergency by President Frederick Chiluba. AMERICAN REFUGEE COMMITTEE, Refugees in the 1990s -- New

Strategies for a Restless World. Minneapolis: American Refugee Committee (2344 Nicollet Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404), 1993. $10.00 (paper). 60 pp.

Issue papers and proceedings derived from the 1992 international conference on refugee affairs. AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL, Amnesty International Report

1993. New York: Amnesty International, U.S.A. (322 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10001), 1993. $16.95 (paper). 254 pp.

Details human rights violations around the world; includes summaries on African countries. Biyi BANDELE-THOMAS, The Man Who Came in from the Back

of the Beyond. Portsmouth: Heinemann (361 Hanover Street, Portsmouth, NH 03801-3959), 1992. $9.95 (paper). 140 pp.

Fiction. Part of the publisher's African Writers Series. David BEVAN, Paul COLLIER, and Jan Willem GUNNING,

Agriculture and the Policy Environment: Tanzania and

Kenya. Washington: OECD Publications and Information Center (2001 L Street N.W., Washington, DC 20036-4910), 1993. $19.00 (paper). 103 pp.

Study of how the macroeconomic and trade policies are largely responsible for the different performances of the agricultural sectors in the two East African countries. A.S. BHALLA, ed., Environment, Employment and

Development. Albany: ILO Publications Center (49 Sheridan Avenue, Albany, NY 12210), 1992. $20.00 (paper). 177 pp.

Covers several environmental issues, including alternative approaches to economic development and employment promotion that incorporate environmental issues.

Laura BIGMAN, History and Hunger in West Africa: Food Production and Entitlement in Guinea-Bissau and Cape

Verde. Westport: Greenwood Publishing Group (88 Post Road West, Box 5007, Westport, CT 06881), 1993. $49.95 (cloth). 176 pp.

Comparison of the two countries' political and economic differences, environmental circumstances, and how they affect food production.

W.P.B. BOTHA, The Reluctant Playwright. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1993. $10.95 (paper). 233 pp.

Fiction. Part of publisher's African Writers Series. Charlotte BRUNER, ed., The Heinemann Book of African

Women's Writing. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1993. $10.95 (paper). 211 pp.

Collection of short stories, fiction and non- fiction, by African women. Michael DORRIS, Rooms in the House of Stone.

Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions (PO Box 3226, Minneapolis, MN 55403), 1993. $4.95 (paper). 66 pp.

Essay chronicling the author's 1991 visit to drought-worn Zimbabwe as a board member for Save the Children. INTERNATIONAL LABOR OFFICE, Poverty in Developing

Countries: A Bibliography of Publications by the ILO's

World Employment Programme 1975-91. Albany: ILO Publications Center, 1992. $16.00 (paper). 152 pp.

Bibliographic references of over 350 ILO publications and documents issued between 1975 and 1991.

Steve JACOBS, Under the Lion. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1993. $10.95 (paper). 230 pp.

Fiction. Part of publisher's African Writers Series. LAWYERS COMMITTEE FOR HUMAN RIGHTS, In Defense of

Rights: Attacks on Lawyers and Judges in 1992. New

York: Lawyers Committee for Human Rights (30 Seventh Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10001), 1993. 210 pp.

Documents mistreatment and persecution of judges and lawyers around the world.

John P. LEWIS, Pro-Poor Aid Conditionality. Washington: Overseas Development Council (1875 Connecticut Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20009), 1993. $9.95 (paper). 53 pp.

Explores the extent to which the development community has and can in the future apply conditionality for the goal of poverty alleviation.

Emmanuel MARTEY, African Theology: Inculturation and

Liberation. Maryknoll: Orbis Books (Maryknoll, NY 10545), 1993. $18.95 (paper). 176 pp.

Examination of the historical development of the two major strands of African theology in relation to political changes on the continent. R.S. O'FAHEY, Enigmatic Saint -- Ahmad Ibn Idris and the

Idrisi Tradition. Chicago: Northwestern University Press/The University of Chicago Press (11030 South Langley, Chicago, IL 60628), 1990. $17.95 (paper). 261 pp.

Biography of a noted 19th century Moroccan mystic and teacher.

Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


LETTER TO THE WORLD BANK: Inter-Church Coalition on Africa


LENGTH: 2334 words


 

The following letter was sent by the Inter-Church Coalition on Africa to the World Bank on the issue of health along with endorsements by over 70 groups and organizations around the world. 7 July, 1993 Mr. Lewis Preston President, World Bank 1818 H Street N.W. Washington, D.C. U.S.A. 20433

Dear Mr. Preston:

We are writing to you on the occasion of the

release of World Development Report 1993: Investing in Health. Our concern for the issue of health arises out of a moral and practical concern for both the physical and spiritual well-being of persons. Implicit in our concern is a recognition of the basic dignity and equality of all persons. This leads us to an interest not only in the health of individuals, but also the health of the collective body of communities.

Since the health and livelihood of citizens around the world are very closely linked to the policies which the World Bank promotes, we appreciate that the World Bank has chosen to focus on this important issue. 

We believe that access to health care is a basic human right. It marks the dignity of the human person. Health care must therefore be made available to all, regardless of race, class, ethnic origin or ability to pay. Health care cannot be efficiently allocated by market forces or promoted in a context of growing poverty and environmental degradation. Good health and health care policies can only emerge in an environment where health is accorded primacy, along with education.

We believe that the vision of health care outlined in the World Development Report 1993 falls far short of the most basic requirements for health. It promotes instead a two-tiered system of health care which is distorted by an undue emphasis on privatization. In essence, the report urges poorer countries to cede most health care to the private sector, leaving governments to provide a minimal package of primary health care for the poor and to try to regulate the private sector. What it ignores is the devastating impact of the debt crisis and the implementation of structural adjustment programmes on health care in developing countries.

In light of this we strongly urge the World Bank to undertake a critical re-examination of its health strategy and of the links between health and the broader issues of poverty, economic and political reform, and

international indebtedness. In particular we recommend: 1) That the World Bank promote health care policies which affirm the principles of universality and equal access both within and between countries.

The World Development Report 1993 promotes a system of health care for developing countries which encourages private sector involvement and user fees for health services beyond a minimum guaranteed package. This basic package, however, consists of little more than public education, immunization programmes, and only very basic coverage. Only those who can afford it will have access to even the most basic operations. In a context of high unemployment, soaring prices and growing poverty this strategy only increases inequities in access to health services and effectively closes off access to adequate health care for the poor. The transformation of health care into a privatized, user- pay system thus constitutes another assault on both the physical welfare and the basic human dignity of the poor. The argument that user fees would only be charged to those who can afford it have little meaning in a context where over 75% of the population lives below the poverty line as is the case in some African countries.

As an alternative to this approach we favour a community- based, comprehensive vision of health care where people are given the power and tools to reduce the problems of ill-health that are intimately related to the economic and social patterns of their society. Comprehensive health care must be part of an overall development strategy to combat poverty and promote self- reliance. The provision of adequate health care depends upon a commitment of the state's resources. This vision can be realized only if the governments, health services and aid donors all support this process of change. 2) That the World Bank officially end its support for orthodox structural adjustment programmes for Sub- Saharan Africa, and that the World Bank take a leadership role in debt reduction by, among other things, calling for a cancellation of multi-lateral debt to low-income countries and highly indebted middle income countries.

The proposals contained in the 1993 World Development Report do not address the single greatest factor contributing to the health care crisis in the South. Many countries have been compelled to adopt structural adjustment programmes, which have had a devastating impact on the health and livelihood of most of their citizens. We regard this consequence of the debt crisis to be the largest single threat to health currently facing the global community. Structural adjustment undermines the ability of states to allocate resources towards either health care or self-reliant development, and instead turns these resources towards the export sector and debt servicing. How can poor countries possibly give either resources or attention to health care when significant amounts of their scarce capital continue to be siphoned off by Northern banks, G-7 governments, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank?

During the 1980s, the World Bank took on the role of debt custodian, in effect bailing out commercial banks, Northern governments, the IMF and itself by using funds earmarked for development assistance for debt repayments. The servicing of the growing debts owed to the World Bank and the IMF are another problem they have directly contributed to the dismantling of health care systems.

As the world's largest development institution, the World Bank has enormous power over the lives of people around the world, many of whom succumb daily to the downward spiral of poverty and declining health. We believe that many of the conclusions of your report on health care will only exacerbate this crisis. We believe that the recommendations contained in this letter will help to alleviate their plight. We urge you to reconsider your approach in light of these comments. Yours sincerely, Charlotte Maxwell Co-Chair, Board Inter-Church Coalition on Africa Clarke Raymond Acting General Secretary Canadian Council of Churches

ENDORSEMENTS: Rev.
