153 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


COMMENTARY ON THE WORLD BANK'S WORLD DEVELOPMENT REPORT 1993: INVESTING IN HEALTH


BYLINE: Kenna Owoh


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 587 words


 

I have worked for many years in Africa as a nurse and mid-wife where I had to cope with a crumbling health care system.

Now the World Bank has offered up its own prescription for the health crisis in the Third World. It correctly draws attention to some of the underlying

causes: concentration of resources on curative, urban- based services; mismanagement and inefficiency of the public health sector; bureaucratic constraints; and extensive poverty. 

The World Bank offers some solutions such as the need to promote rural-based primary health care. However, it ignores the role it has played in contributing to the general decline in health and health care in countries where its economic policies have been adopted.

These policies have actually increased poverty in most African countries over the past decade. Fee-for- service, privatization, massive layoffs, cutbacks of social services have led to deepening malnutrition, hospital closures and worsening poverty.

The World Bank's proposals for improving health in the Third World obscure the basic fact that its primary goal is to ensure an orderly flow of debt repayments to banks and Western governments. The World Bank itself has amassed profits totaling over $13 billion (US) over the past decade through debt payments extracted from Third World countries. The interests of the poor in good health, clean water, education and employment are peripheral to the underlying design of World Bank programmes.

Zimbabwe, for example, showed a remarkable improvement in health care during the 1980s. In 1990 the country adopted one of the World Bank's so-called structural adjustment programmes which recommended, among other things, the introduction of health care user fees. Since then, the number of women dying in childbirth in the Harare, the capital city has doubled because mothers could not afford the fees imposed for maternity services.

Even World Bank officials are gradually admitting that their economic policies have broadly failed in economic terms. They have also failed the people whom they are supposed to serve. Yet, now the World Bank threatens to compound past mistakes by incorporating health and health care for the Third World into the market.

It is time to identify clearly the motives and agenda of the world's largest development agency.

The Bank must be called to account for its disturbing legacy of bad loans to corrupt leaders, failed projects and flawed development policies.

What African countries need now is a commitment from our governments and from development agencies like the World Bank to support their efforts to develop and implement their own comprehensive health care programmes where people not markets take priority. This commentary piece aired on the Canada's National Radio (C.B.C.) on Friday July 9, 1993.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


STATEMENT KOFI A. ANNAN, UNDERSECRETARY-GENERAL FOR PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS: UNITED NATIONS


LENGTH: 987 words


 

STATEMENT ON SOMALIA July 14, 1993 -- First, let me express my profound sorrow for the tragic deaths of four of your colleagues on 12 July in Mogadishu. As you know, they were not killed in cross-fire. They were deliberately targeted for murder in the performance of their duties. And that is the measure of the chaos that has descended upon Mogadishu. I deliberately say Mogadishu and not Somalia because it is easy to lose sight of the fact that the cast majority of the Somali people outside the capital city are working with the United Nations to ensure the provision of humanitarian assistance, reconstruction, disarmament and political reconciliation.

However bad the situation in Mogadishu now seems, let us not forget that a few short months ago, things were infinitely worse. There was a raging civil war, the likes of which we have very rarely seen in modern times and where, for the first time, humanitarian relief shipments were blocked and looted. In addition, those providing humanitarian relief actually became the targets of gangs and militias roaming the country and killing fellow Somalis. In this chaos, a number of international relief workers such as Dr. Pumpalova, Mr. Devereaux and Mr. Luftinberger were murdered. 350,000 Somalis died in 1992 in chaos perpetrated by such gangs in 1992, and at the height of the crisis 3,000 Somalis were dying every day of starvation. 

It is in this context that the Security Council authorized in December 1992 the first ever Chapter VII operation for humanitarian purposes. The goals of this

action were very clear: to establish a secure environment for the delivery of humanitarian relief and at the same time move forward the process of political reconciliation and reconstruction.

With this action by the Security Council, there was

immediate success: relief began to flow, death rates from starvation dropped dramatically, and famine now has virtually disappeared. The United Nations also brought together twice in Addis Ababa the various political factions who had been locked in violent disputes for two years and had refused to talk to each other. We should not forget that it was the Somalis themselves at those meetings who asked us to ensure a general disarmament of the country because they knew that this was an essential condition both for political reconciliation and reconstruction of their country.

Admittedly, we have had setbacks but let us not forget that it is only one of the factions which is behind the current violence in Mogadishu.

I think there is universal agreement that we simply cannot allow Somalia to slide back to the anarchy of the recent past. It is essential that we root out the criminal elements who, just in the past few weeks, have killed some 35 peace keepers, four journalists as well as Somali nationals working for international organizations. And this of course, in addition to the death and destruction, that these elements have once again wrought upon their own people in South Mogadishu.

We hope that this is only a parenthesis in the overall thrust of the operation and that this particular phase of instability will be concluded rapidly. We have no alternative but to make sure that Mogadishu is rid of all weaponry. As long as there is not full disarmament, even a cessation of hostilities could not provide the lasting confidence that the Somali people need to continue with the rebuilding of their country.

In saying all this I am not trying to minimize the problem that we face. All I am saying is that we must look at the current violence in Mogadishu in the context of our overall objective of restoring peace and bringing the country together once again.

So let me repeat, I do not want to minimize the problems that we face. You all know that there is some disagreement among certain countries participating in UNOSOM II about the best way to achieve our goals. I have in mind the question of command and control. But such disagreements are to be expected when you consider that we have peace-keepers from the most diverse group of nations, some participating for the very first time in peacekeeping operations. We are trying to mold them into one unified force, but teething problems are to be expected.

These disagreements are being discussed quite openly at the highest level and I am confident that we can sort them out. I would also like to deny reports that the Italian contingent is pulling out of Somalia. To the contrary, strong support for the United Nations operation in Somalia has been expressly by the Italian cabinet.

Let me also state that, contrary to reports, we are not opposed to negotiations with the factions involved. We are dealing with all factions, and have not cut off contact even with Aideed's group. However, these must be conducted through the channels set up by the Security Council and the Secretary-General. We must all be clear that there is one command under the Secretary-General, his Special Representative, Admiral Howe and the Force Commander, General Bir.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


STATEMENT THE MAKING OF THE ETHIOPIAN CONSTITUTION ADDRESS BY H.E. MELES ZENAWI


LENGTH: 2734 words


 

May 17, 1993 Before I begin, I would like to respond to Abdul Mohammed's expression of thanks for the freedom to organize this event without government interference or restrictions. In view of our history of authoritarian rule, I well understand that this newfound freedom is appreciated, but I want to take this opportunity to say that this freedom is not a privilege, but a right, an I look forward to the day when we can take such fundamental rights for granted.

The making of a constitution is an historic event of great significance for any country, but for the pursuit of democratic ideals and practice worldwide.

We are therefore privileged to welcome so many of you who have come from different parts of the world to share your experience, your views, your knowledge with us, in this symposium. We are confident that your contributions will be valuable, and I can assure you that we will use them, that we will learn from you. 

The making of a constitution is a complex process, encapsulating the basic principles and values of democracy, drawing on experience and lessons learnt elsewhere while establishing the frame work and mechanisms most appropriate for a given country. Ethiopia is a vast and complex land, a mosaic of many peoples, languages, cultures.

We are trying to draft a constitution which is relevant to all of our people, which addresses the fundamental issues in our society, the majority of whom are peasant farmers, pastoralists, who have in the past had little of no access to the structures of power which determined their fate.

This constitution is being drafted also in the context of rapid societal change. The past two years have been a time of transition for Ethiopia, with far- reaching effects for all our people.. We have seen the overthrow of the Derg regime, the establishment of the Transitional Government, coming from years of bitter struggle and enormous pain and sacrifice on the part of millions of ordinary men and women in Ethiopia.

During these two years we have been able to move forward and take steps within a process which will guarantee democracy and lasting peace for this long- suffering land of ours. This process has been instrumental in establishing numerous institutions which characterize the democratic nature of a state, such as an independent judicial system, an impartial police force, local democracy within decentralized regional administrations.

The people of Ethiopia have achieved democratic rights, the right to express themselves freely without fear, the right to organize, to demonstrate. A new democratic culture has begun to flower in our country. Through effecting democratic rights, our people are also learning to confront and overcome considerable hurdles.

This government is prepared to advance and advocate the cardinal principle of the supremacy of the constitution. This means that the charter "though we still uphold its ruling principles" and legislative measures enabled under the Charter, are all subordinate to the new constitution. In consequence, all those with misgivings about the charter are now free to make their case in the debates and deliberations over the new constitution.

The new constitution can therefore serve as fresh ground for settling past differences and for the creation of a deeper convergence and concord in the future. We hope that everyone, especially those dissatisfied or frustrated, will now accept the challenge.

Herein lies the importance of this symposium, not in outlining the details of what our constitution is to be, but in giving us an opportunity to tap the rich experience of other countries. This symposium can help us in identifying the fine points and key issues encountered in similar processes elsewhere, in anticipating and overcoming potential pitfalls and problems. It is then up to us to draw what we need from this and apply it to our own particular conditions and situations.

I do not believe this is the right time and place for me to present my views on the detail of what our new constitutions should include.

However, I believe it is appropriate for me to identify the main objectives and issues which I believe our constitution should address.

First and foremost, our constitution must be a constitution of the people. They must believe in it, they must call it their own. It must be conceptually accessible to and easily understood by all of our people, using clear, plain language without mystification or confusion. It must be directly relevant and applicable to their daily lives, not a remote instrument of a remote government.

We must ask ourselves what will this constitution mean for the people? To whom is it addressed? How will it be seen by grassroots communities in every corner of Ethiopia?

However perfectly crafted, however noble its ideals, a constitution which is not accessible to all, which does not belong to all, will at the end of the day be simply a piece of paper in the hand of an elite. Its fate will echo that of other African countries where short-lived efforts at democratization of society were never achieved.

When we say our constitution must be a constitution of the people, we mean first of all the Ethiopian people, men and women, throughout every town and village, must be actively involved from the beginning of the drafting process right through to the final ratification. It is through their active participation in all stages of the democratization process that the ordinary people of Ethiopia will make this process, this constitution, their own, theirs to use, theirs to defend.

This genuine participation of the people demands the kind of democracy which can only be accomplished when political power is not centralized in the hands of the few, when it is devolved down through every region, every town district, village, every household, in a way that genuinely empowers local communities to administer their own affairs, to determine the course of their own lives and futures.

We want to democratize, to empower, every sector and level of our society. Democracy cannot be partial, it must be for all, or it is not democracy. Power must be exercised from the bottom up, at every level, it must be a tool in the hands of the people, to safeguard their democracy and work for development. Our constitution must enable us to establish such democracy.

You know, there are those, and they are not few, who say that democracy and development are incompatible, who claim that poor countries like Ethiopia cannot afford the luxury of democracy. They also say that democracy fosters instability.

In any discussion on the compatibility of democracy and development, it is important to focus on what kind of democracy we need and its relation to social and economic development. If and when a constitution represents a democracy within which there is a genuine empowerment of the people, the people will use this constitution, will use their empowerment to engage in socioeconomic development, to improve their lives, to work in every way for their own future and that of their community.

In this way, democracy becomes an integral and indispensable instrument of, rather than a hindrance to development. Not only is democracy fully compatible with development, it is indispensable for development. A democracy which is deeply rooted among the people, which has a broad base throughout every village, every sector of the population, which is directed, protected, by a constitution designed not to create endless constitution crisis, but to promote stability, we believe such a democracy cannot foster instability. This is the type of democracy which we need, which we want to establish. Such a democracy is both an instrument of socio-economic development and lasting peace and stability.

Only such a broad based democratic system can foster stability, peace, and justice in our country, can create the climate and conditions essential for stable developments and economic prosperity.

As all of you know, Ethiopia as an entity encompasses many different nations and nationalities, an enormous variety of beliefs, culture, traditions. This reality has been a dominant feature in the political life of our country, it has been a trigger for bitter warfare.

It represents at one and the same time a multifaceted mosaic of rich diversity and cultural wealth for our country, and a potential source of instability and conflict.

There are those who, on the basis of experience and events in other countries as well as in our own, conclude that the very existence of so many different entities in Ethiopia represents a great weakness, and is inherently and inevitably disastrous.

However, we choose to see this aspect of Ethiopia, this diversity, as a source of great political and cultural strength. Throughout this transition period, we have been able to prove that what many see as a time bomb can be turned into an asset. We believe we have shown that in Ethiopia it is possible to change the potentially negative aspects of national diversity, to solve the problems in a positive and constructive way, and to transform this diversity into a source of strength rather than weakness.

Accomplishing this successfully depends on certain

key factors:

1. Diversity must not be wished away, camouflaged, suppressed. It must be embraced as it is, it must be allowed free expression. It must be manifested in the nature, in the mechanisms of democracy.

2. It must be possible for people to assert their own national and cultural identity, to respect and support each other's diversity, within the context of their common Ethiopian identity. We believe there is no incompatibility, no inherent conflict, in being at the same time an Amhara and an Ethiopian, an Oromo and an Ethiopian, a Tigrayan and an Ethiopian, a Guarage and an Ethiopian, and so on. All are distinct and diverse, while at the same time interwoven into the fabric of the entity we call Ethiopia.

3. Our constitution must embrace this diversity, while at the same time continuously promoting unity. It must promote the concept of unity based on diversity and equality. While encompassing and promoting the universal values and concepts of justice, human rights, freedom of expression and so on, for which our people have fought, it must also reflect and promote the particular values and characteristics of Ethiopian society, the tolerance, the solidarity, the perseverance, the sense of community, which unite the diverse entities within Ethiopia.

This new constitution will determine the future political direction an life of our country, Ethiopia. It must therefore be both universal and fully Ethiopian in its nature. I do not anticipate any argument on this point.

However, we also recognize that while the establishment of democracy may be a new phenomenon for Ethiopia, this is not true of many parts of the world. While the institutions and practices of democracy are new for Ethiopia, our people have struggled and paid a bitter price for the values and principles of democracy, for justice and equality and peace. These values and aspirations are universal, the achievements of those who fought for them, who have worked to establish democracy here and elsewhere, are shared by and belong to all of humanity.

So we have no need to reinvent the wheel here in Ethiopia. We are privileged in being able to draw on the vast treasure house of experience from all over the world in our quest for a democratic system. We can see this knowledge and experience within the context of our particular experience, needs, conditions, and thereby create a truly Ethiopian constitution for the Ethiopian people.

So, in short, our constitution must be both universal and Ethiopian in its nature. It must be relevant to the lives of our people. It must establish a framework which enables them to take power into their own hands, to play a decisive role in the affairs of their country. It must promote stability and progress as a prerequisite for genuine, sustainable, socioeconomic development.

We stand now at a historical turning point in Ethiopian history, ushering in a new era of peace and stability for our people. Despite all the problems, the divisions, and bitter conflicts in the past, we have much to be proud of, enormous cause for optimism. We have never bowed our heads to oppression, never allowed it to break us.

Our people have emerged from a dark period in our history, and have displayed a maturity, a wisdom, a civility, a spirit of reconciliation, in tackling both the divisions in our society which have torn us apart and caused so much suffering in the past, and the immense challenges of reconstruction and democratization.

The present peace and stability in our country, which enables us to embark on this process, has been brought about through the victory won by our people at enormous cost. This is their moment in history, it is for the people to seize this moment and determine the shape of their future, their country.

This they will do in creating their own constitution which is Ethiopian in essence, which promotes unity, stability, progress, development, which can consolidate and build on the democratic rights for which they have fought so long and so hard.

And so we look forward to the debates, discussions, the sharing of experience and ideas which your participation in this symposium during the week will bring, and you can be confident that you will be making a valuable contribution to this most important process in our country's history. Thank you.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


STATEMENT: ZAIRE'S POLITICAL SITUATION ADDRESS BY ARCHBISHOP MONSENGWO


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

JULY 7, 1993 THE ZAIRIAN POLITICAL SITUATION Declaration of the President of the High Council of the Republic

"Stop, stop causing suffering to the wounded people." That is the urgent appeal which we address today, to the Zairian political class as a whole and to those who hold power in particular.

In effect, the country has been at a standstill for ten months. The state is no longer governed and its democratic institutions are paralyzed. Moreover, for the last three months, by reason of partisan interests, all the efforts deployed to bring about a dialogue among the different parties have been in vain. Those efforts have either been diverted from their objectives or purely and simply nullified. 

But a solution is all the more urgent because the people live in complete insecurity, aggravated by the fact that acts have been taken either to deny the military their salaries and thereby incite them to revolution, looting, or extortion, or to pay them only to put them at odds with a starving people. Not to mention other sources of tension such as tribal conflict and violence, massacres, and forced movements of populations organized for political ends.

The social situation is catastrophic and our economy collapsed. Civil servants are hoping against hope for a salary which cannot satisfy their essential needs. Zairian diplomats abroad have not been paid for fifteen months and live in a state of penury unbecoming to the Zairian nation. The mechanisms of the banking system have come undone and no longer function.

Perhaps by the application of the rules of good governmental management established by the National Conference, with a minimum of good faith reinforced with the sense of the common good, and with concern for the greater interest of the nation and a spirit of dialogue, we would have surmounted this crisis.

But in the face of this crisis, the political authorities contented themselves instead with the terrorism of the state and the organization of a black market which serves nothing other than the interest of a financial oligarchy.

As concerns the political leaders, they are doing nothing. They seem to be at the end of inspiration and political strategies.

Everyone is inclined to believe that a large number of political actors are in favor of seeing this confused situation continue.

--For some, because it is to their advantage to acquire dishonest wealth, a regular functioning and rigorous management of public finance would not be in their interest.

-- For others, because they are afraid to take up the management of the state, preferring instead a conflictual situation which would bring them better chances at the next elections.

-- And for still others, because they are uneasy at the prospect of the implementation of the decisions and institutional order of the National Conference, or to put it otherwise, the prospect of the coming of democracy and of a state of laws and rights.

We denounce all these selfish and irresponsible attitudes, because they distract the people, holding them hostage and preventing them from realizing their true freedom.

The consequence of this situation is the indifference of the powers-that-be to the misery of the people. The state of laws and rights has in effect been murdered. The national consensus is broken. The relationship between the authorities and the people, which forms the basis for any democratic order, is gravely damaged.

The authority of the state no longer has dignified objectives. It has thus become purposeless. It has stopped being human.

But even so a solution would be possible, if there were a minimum of good faith and loyalty, of honesty and spirit of dialogue is this dialogue, recognized by all to be well-founded and of overriding necessity. But it has been blocked for six weeks for no good reason, to the great unhappiness of the Zairian people.

What has happened, therefore, to cause this dialogue not to be pursued? What prevents the much- awaited gestures of good faith from being met? What is it, objectively speaking, that could justify the closing of the People's Palace, official seat of the High Council of the Republic, head institution of transition and recognized as such by all the parties? What, in this period of transition and after the establishment of its institutional order by the National Conference, could justify the continued confiscation of the official media and the denial of access to them by certain sons and daughters of Zaire? What is it that legitimatize, in the eyes of the regime that calls itself respectful of human rights, the detention of some citizens for reasons of opinion?

Also, are we not convinced that this crisis is absurd and artificially created, without regard to the dishonor which it brings to our country?

That is why we say to the political class that it is imperative that it bring itself to understand that in a state based on the rule of law (as was the will of the National Conference), power does not come from the barrel of a gun or from the street and must be held in the hands of legitimate institutions.

We recall for the political class as well that democratic authority is not exercised by challenging a legitimate institution, and even less by defying the people by whose authority it is held, but by the happiness of the people and in harmony with them. The challenge of authority is that of the elevation and complete development of the people.

Also, we address a moving appeal to all members of the political class that they, without delay and once and for all, decide to resume the blocked dialogue, with the will this time to use it to its end and to respect its conclusions.

TO THE CHIEF OF STATE

We appeal to his sense of patriotism and implore in the name of heaven, for the love of our people, and in virtue of his high function of symbol and guarantor of the nation conferred upon him by the National Conference, to squarely take up his responsibility.

To this end, we invite him to eliminate, as far as it concerns him, all the reasons which make this crisis persist, to neglect nothing which could strengthen the confidence and the impartiality pertaining to his function as symbol and guarantor of the nation, and to be forever attentive to the legitimate aspirations of the people -- and of all the people -- for change.

TO THE ZAIRIAN PEOPLE

We invite them to be aware of the fact that security, harmony and peace will not be with them if they oppose it with determination and fierceness, by developing love and solidarity amongst themselves.

This is because our nation cannot be built other than by harmony, peace and solidarity and without hate, selfishness and divisiveness.

Also we ask of them to continue to support firmly the legitimate institutions of the Republic in their efforts toward restoration of peace and harmony, without which there can be neither democratic change nor development.

God bless Zaire and give her peace.

Contact: AFJN (Africa Faith and Justice Network),

Washington DC; phone: (202) 832-2412; fax (202) 832-9051


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


STATEMENT ZAIRE: VISIT OF PRESIDENTIAL ENVOY: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE, MICHAEL MCCURRY, spokesman


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 307 words


 

We deplore the continuing crisis in Zaire and hold President Mobutu responsible for a situation which puts at risk the lives and welfare of millions of his countrymen, and the stability of an entire region. Assistant Secretary (George) Moose made our views clear to an envoy from President Mobutu of Zaire, Mr. Ngbanda Nzambo-ko-Atumba, during meetings on July 19 and 21. The purpose of the visit was to deliver Mobutu's response to a letter from Secretary (Warren) Christopher, and to hear our reaction. In his response, President Mobutu blamed the opposition and the High Council of the Republic for the continuing stalemate in Zaire and the resulting human suffering, including severe unrest in Shava and Kivu provinces.

Assistant Secretary Moose informed Mr. Ngbanda that the United States finds this response to the Secretary's letter totally inadequate. He stressed that U.S. policy toward Zaire has not changed and that it remains clear to us that the only solution to Zaire's crisis is a transition government accepted by all major parties in accordance with the rules laid down by the National Conference. The primary objective of the transition must be agreement on a constitution followed by free and fair elections on terms acceptable to all major parties. It is also abundantly clear to objective observers that President Mobutu bears responsibility for the continuing political impasse, economic deterioration, and human suffering. We call on him once again to allow the transition to proceed or bear full responsibility for the consequences.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


UPDATE ON AFRICATREK -- SUMMER 1993


LENGTH: 867 words


 

In November 1992, Americans Dan and Steve Buettner and Dr. Chip Thomas, along with Nigerian Mobolaji Oduyoye set off across Africa, to bike 11,000 miles on the continent of Africa. While attempting to set a world record, the expedition is conducting scientific research for NASA and is providing the backdrop for a youth education program reaching 50,000 classrooms worldwide. The team has reached Zimbabwe on its way to South Africa. The following is an excerpt from the journal of the team leader on their experience in Zaire. ON THE ROAD IN ZAIRE From HABARI, the official journal of the AfricaTrek Expedition by Dan Buettner, expedition leader

True adventure began in Zaire, the central African country (as big as the United States east of the Mississippi) where Joseph Conrad set "Heart of Darkness." Zaire is covered with mountains, huge volcanoes, abundant wildlife and endless rain forests which shelter the Pygmies. It also has one of the most corrupt governments on earth, massive food shortages, potholed roads that could swallow a semi-truck and an over-armed, underpaid army famous for drinking hard liquor and confiscating tourists' possessions. 

We shared the first two hundred miles of roads with merchants who travel up to 400 miles every week on one speed bicycles, buying kerosene, batteries and soap in Central African Republic to sell in their home villages. The road, just parallel tracks separated by a patch of vegetation, took us through bamboo forest -- lit sublimely by pencils of sunlight that shone through the branches -- across numerous bridgeless rivers and through dozens of tiny villages where life proceeds exactly as it has for centuries. Zaire's economy is so bad that most people have reverted to subsistence farming, or a hunting and gathering existence. It took us three days to travel the first 200 miles in Zaire -- considerably slower that our 100-mile a day goal but faster than a party that took seven days by Land Rovers.

We fell into a routine during the 18 days it took us to cross Zaire. We woke to a breakfast of cold rice,

packed our bags and started pedaling by 8:00 a.m. Though we took an hour break around noon, we rarely found lunch -- mostly we ate bananas, which people sold out of their huts -- 70 per cyclist per day. Every other day or so, we'd find a market and buy rice and beans. At night we stopped in mud huts and asked for permission to pitch our tent. To find water, we were led to a river or through the forest to a cloudy puddle known as "a source." After we purified the water with our Penta Pure filters, we'd wash, boil rice and beans, talk to our

hosts and retire by 8:00 p.m.

Our Zairian adventure culminated the last night in the country when eight heavily armed paratroopers stopped us near the Ruwenzori Mountains. They wore jaunty red berets, camouflage uniforms, yellow thongs and AK-47 machine guns slung over their shoulders. They warned us we were in a war zone and if we proceeded, we ran the risk of being attacked by Zairian rebels. I knew that the bridge these soldiers were guarding was obviously a rebel target and staying there for the night was not a safe option either. "What do you recommend?" I asked the commanding officer. "It's your choice," he said. Then waving his hand toward an arsenal that included grenades, a rocket launcher and a 50 mm anti- aircraft gun, said, "But at least here you have protection."

In other circumstances, that campsite might have been the most beautiful in all of Africa. A full moon had risen over the bluish peaks of the Ruwenzori Mountains, illuminating the misty, jungle-lined river and the yawning gray blobs which were the hippopotami swimming down below. We pitched our tents between the paratrooper's grass-hut barracks and settled in for an uneasy night's sleep.

Morning arrived without incident. A cacophony of birds clucking and whining along with chattering monkeys filled the humid jungle air. We ate breakfast with the soldiers, took Polaroids of them and bid them a happy farewell. I felt kind of silly for having been so afraid the previous night. But before I pedaled a quarter mile away from the bridge, the birds fell abruptly silent with the loud crackle of machine gun fire. I didn't go back to investigate. That afternoon we crossed the border into Uganda.

For further information, contact AFRICATREK, 529 South 7th Street, #310, Minneapolis, MN 55415; phone (612) 349-6606.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


WHAT IS THE TRUTH?


BYLINE: Moffat Ekoriko


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

NEWSWATCH, July 19, 1993 Frank Ockiya, A Port Harcourt-based oil industry worker, was confused. In less than 12 hours he had two conflicting reports on the position of the Nigerian Labour Congress (NLC) in the current political crisis. The NTA and FRCN network reported the Congress as cautioning workers not to protest the cancellation of the June 12 elections, the CHAMPION and PUNCH newspapers the following day reported the Congress as giving a 48 hour ultimatum to the federal government to release the results or face a general strike.

He was still trying to make sane sense out of this when NTA again came up with a story that Pascal Bafyau, NLC president had denied giving the federal government an ultimatum. Speaking during a visit to the presidential villa to present the resolution of the Central Working Committee of the Congress on the 

political impasse, Bafyau said: "I don't know where they (newspapers) got their story."

A few days later, according to the PUNCH , the NLC leader called for the release of the June election results. The paper quoted him as saying that the NLC position was that the president should go ahead and declare the remaining results and this was made known to the president during the Aso Rock visit.

The NLC/Bafyau affair is typical of the confusion in the news media in the wake of the current political crisis. People don't know who or what to believe because of conflicting reports. Okunade Sijuwade, the Ooni of Ife at the end of a meeting of traditional rulers with the president the other week said they were satisfied with the government's new political agenda. NTA showed him on screen saying, "we have to agree at a point because he was talking sense." That night, the Ooni, the CONCORD claimed, denied the story ion a telephone

interview with it. But the DAILY TIMES headline was: "We're satisfied with new political agenda--Ooni" and

CONCORD: "I didn't agree with IBB... Ooni." Most readers did not know what to take, the traditional ruler's words on television or his denial in CONCORD.

A few days later, Sijuwade issued a full statement on his position on the outcome of the Abuja meeting. The statement signed by Funmilola Olorunnisola, his press secretary and reported by the GUARDIAN quoted the Ooni as saying that his position was misconstrued by the generality of the people because he was quoted out of context by a section of the media to satisfy the wishes of the government.

John Odigie-Oyegun who on television implied the 30 state governors accepted the federal government position on the elections had to address another press conference in Benin to "clarify" his position. The governor's case was rather dramatic. Odigie-Oyegun said on NTA they agreed to commit themselves to the emergence of a viable and permanent democratic system. This was also what CHAMPION reported. But the PUNCH and the CONCORD reported that the governors rejected the new agenda.

Tanko Abdullah, a Lagos trader said last week he was "not sure of what was happening in the country any more. The confusion is too much."

He is not alone in this. The newspapers have taken implacable stands and report all developments to suit themselves. The NATIONAL CONCORD owned by Moshood Abiola, refers to his as "president elect" although he was not so declared by the then National Electoral Commission, NEC, while President Ibrahim Babangida is the "outgoing president." The PUNCH and VANGUARD refer to him so too.

THE NEWS reported that Abubakar Umar a colonel, was one of the moving forces behind the so-called hidden agenda. But the NATIONAL CONCORD was the first to publish Umar's letter resigning from the military in protest against the cancellation of the election result.

The news media themselves have also become victims of the confusion. Nendo Gawa, editor of the NIGERIAN TIDE, the Rivers State government -owned newspaper, was reportedly sent on compulsory leave for allegedly publishing the verdict of a Benin court ordering the National Electoral Commission to release the results of the June 12 presidential elections. Last week in Port Harcourt, the management of the paper denied ever sending the editor on forced leave. Dan Obinna, secretary/legal adviser of the company told NEWSWATCH the editor is on his "normal annual leave." Gawa himself confirmed. "I am on my annual leave and would resume at the end of the period."

The PUNCH first reported THE NEWS was proscribed. Femi Falana, the magazine's lawyer came out to deny the alleged proscription in the GUARDIAN although he admitted the police distributed an undated proscription order. The magazine was still on sale at the news-stand in Lagos but another report said the police in Minna had arrested three vendors for selling it. Last week Bayo Onanuga editor-in-chief of THE NEWS announced the suspension of the publication of the magazine.

THE HERALD in the June 26 edition published an imaginary letter from the president's daughter Halimat to her father on the current political impasse. A few days later the paper apologized over what was a mere fiction. Despite the apology, Abdul Razaki El Alawa, editor and two other management staff of the paper were arrested by security agents. THE HERALD is owned by Kwara State.

In the STANDARD, owned by Plateau State government, an editorial was carried on the political crisis only to be retracted a few days later. Six editors of the paper resigned in protest. They alleged the counter editorial was forced on them. The same allegation was made by Yakubu Andulazeez editor of the NEW NIGERIAN who resigned over the paper's editorial of June 16 titled "OUR NATION, OUR DESTINY." He alleged the editorial was faxed from Abuja. His company replied that his resignation was a "politically orchestrated blackmail" against it.

The confusion is not even helped by the principal actors in the crisis. The CONCORD claimed the federal government had apologized to Abiola through Uche Chukwumerije, information secretary on a BBC interview. Chukwumerije denied it promptly. Last week, Babangida himself said he owed nobody any apology over his stewardship because his belief in the greatness of the country was solid.

Despite the number of people killed during the riot last wee, in Lagos, Chukwumerije in a statement said nobody died. But other news media reported that more than 50 people were killed. As Ockiya put it, few readers now know what to make of media reports. "NTA tells you one thing and CONCORD tells you another." Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, July 19, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited.

CONTACT: LONDON: NEWSWATCH, Centre for International Operations, Suite 46, 8-14 Pancras Way,

London, NW1 OQG United Kingdom. Phone: 071-387-9291: fax

071-383-7576. NIGERIA: No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos,

Nigeria. Phone: 960950; fax: 962887; telex: 27874 NEWCOM NG.


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


JULY 26, 1993


NATAL PEACE PRIZE WINNER: THE WEEKLY MAIL, July 2-8, 1993


BYLINE: Farouk Chothia


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Forget about Nelson Mandela, Mangosuthu Buthelezi and F.W. de Klerk. It's time to meet South Africa's most successful grassroots peace-maker. He is, incidentally a foreigner -- Ghanaian-born Moses Anafu.

In the eight months that he headed the Commonwealth Observer Mission (CoM) in Durban, the genial 45-year old Anafu succeeded where local peace

mediators had tried and failed: brokering peace between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party. 

In the strife-torn district of kwaNdwalane, near Port Shepstone, both the ANC and the Local Dispute Resolution Committee made overtures to chief Aaron Ndwalane. Facing murder charges, and with the reputation of being a "warlord", Ndwalane spurned their olive branch.

Yet Anafu had success -- not only in kwaNdwalane, but also in the districts of kwaMavundla, Ezingolweni, Ndwedwe and Umbumbulu.

Explaining the reason behind his success Anafu

said: "I come from a chiefly family (his father was a chief) so I was quite familiar with the protocol. When I arrived here, I noticed that the chiefs were conspicuously absent from the peace process -- and you could not bring peace to rural Natal without their whole-hearted involvement. We therefore put chiefs at the heart of the whole process".

After urging Ndwalane to adopt a neutral stance, Anafu gave him the role of peacemaker in the community and helped him to restore his authority over his subjects. Ndwalane called peace meetings between the ANC and IFP earning the respect of both sides.

This was a far cry from the days when the chief, under fierce attack from ANC-supporting youth was forced to flee his territory. Ndwalane returned later with his warriors and ruled with an iron fist, driving ANC youth away.

At the height of the violence in the 1980s, about 50 people were dying each month in his area. Violence has now declined sharply, with fedw deaths recorded.

Elaborating on his methods, Anafu said: "I told the chiefs what they already knew. that not matter what misgivings, anxieties and fears they may have ofg the future, as fathers of the community they need to take the lead -- and not only to support the peace process. When two of their sons fight, they need to mediate -- not take sides."

He has also tried to allay the fears of chiefs, citing the case of pre-independence Ghana, where the chiefs earned the ire of Nkrumah for cooperating with the British colonial rulers. "Nkrumah had said that chiefs would either have to side with the people, or one day they would have to run and leave their sandals behind.

"But far from aboloshing the chieftaincy, chiefs prospered under the national government. The present king of the Ashanti tribe, for instance, is a barrister and was once Ghana's ambassador to Rome," said Anafu.

He takes a sympathetic approach to the chiefs, believing their "cooperation" with the British in Ghana and with the National Part government in South Africa must be seen in a historial context. "in Ghana the Ashantis fought the British intermittently between 1800 and 1900, when the British finally put down the last Ashanti uprising. The Ashanti king was exiled to the Seychelles with his senior chiefs until 1925. The minor chiefs, seeing what had happened to the bigger chiefs, caved in. It was a humiliating experience for their chiefs. They may have conformed outwardly, but in their hearts of hearts thet could never have loved colonial rule.

"In South Africa, the defeat of the Zulu kingdom couldn't have been a badge of honour for the Zulu monarchs either. I won't be surprised if they feel the same (as the Ghanaian chiefs of pre-independence)," said Anafu.

He hopes that South Africa's political parties will not turn chiefs into a "political football" in an election campaign.

"They would be more useful playing a healing role.. Throughout Africa, their role has been a standard

one: to represent the spiritual well-beng of communities",.

He does not believe chiefs should join either the ANC or the IFP. "If their are divisions, the cheifs should bring the two sides together -- every other thing is of secondary importance."

He believes South Africa should look at other West African countries when it maps out the future of chiefs under a new constiution.

"In Ghana we have a National House of Chiefs and we have Regional Houses in the ten regions. But they do not have a political role, nor do they seek one. They are part of our cultural heritage -- and we treasure them as such," said Anafu.

Even though he has convinced chiefs -- who provide the IFP with support at grassroots levels -- to accommodate the ANC, Anafu has not had any confrontation with IFP leader chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi. "In every meeting I have had with him, he has promised me his whole-hearted support. He told me that if I encounter any problems, I should approach him," said Anafu.

Much to the anger of local peace mediators, Anafu has left Durban to take up a new post in Johannesburg.

Sources close to him say the was reluctant to move -- but that he had to give into pressur from Commonwealth secretary general Chief Emeka Anyoukou. This, sources say, reflects the COmmonwealth's new focus on upcoming elections, and downscaling its peace role.

"As the secretary general's special representative in South Africa, i have to be close to where the poltician's are," said Anafu.

This has sparked concern that the various initiatives he has spearheaded in Natal could flounder -- though Anafu brushed the fears aside. "my heart will always be in Natal. What we have built we will not allow to fall apart. I will keep my ear to the ground and assist wherever I can . When necessary I will come to Natal", said Anafu.

He added that an earlier decision to close the

Durban office of the CoM has been overturned: new monitors will be stationed there.

Anafu -- who boasts a doctorate in history -- confirmed the Commonwealth intended playing a more prominent role in South Africa in the run-up to elections. "We intend playing a more prominent role in South Africa in the run-up to elections. "We intend adding new dimensions to the evolving situation", he said.

This would include sending in "election experts" to assist the Independent Electoral Commission, to send in "media experts" to ensure that media coverage is fair to all the political parties and to run training programmes in mediation and negotiation skills for grassroots activsits involved in peace initiatives. Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL, July 2-8, 1993

THE WEEKLY MAIL is published by M&G Media, Pty, Ltd.

CONTACT: THE WEEKLY MAIL, P.O. Box 260425, Excom,

2023, South Africa. Phone: 011-334-2400; fax: 011-334- 2905


LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 9, 1993


EDUCATION


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may

be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing,

MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply. 

DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL

FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in

the first ten years of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE:

December 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third

Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896. Internship opportunities are available at the Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on

assisting the rural areas of South Africa. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa. The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years' study towards an AUC Masters' degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to

apply. Contact: International Graduate Program Coordinator, Office of the Provost, AUC P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo Egypt. Fulbright Graduate Grants are available for the 1994-1995 academic year for graduate students and young professionals for study and/or research for one year in thirty African countries. Fifty grants are available, and all include maintenance for one academic year, roundtrip international travel, health and accident insurance and a research allowance. Candidates may apply to only one country. Candidates must be U.S. citizens and hold a bachelors degree or its equivalent by the beginning of the grant. For more information, call 415-723-0856. The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions compete in two

separate categories for funding: (1) Non-research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category. The application deadline is November 1. To request guidelines and proposal

forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008-3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. It is recommended that all institutions contact the appropriate CIES program officer for the scholar-in-residence program for advice, referral and assistance before preparing proposals. For Sub-Saharan Africa, contact Linda Rhoad at (202) 686-6230. For North Africa, contact Gary Garrison at (202) 686-4019. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University "Computers and Communications for Development in Africa" is the name of a conference to be held in Olympia, London on September 22-23. Delegates will look at hardware and software options for business, and focus on trends in the computer

industry and their impact on Africa. DEADLINE: September 13.

For more information, contact: African Information Technology Exhibitions and Conferences, 15 High Street, Graveley, Cambridgeshire PE18 9PL, United Kingdom; phone 44-480-830724, fax 44-480-831131. Boston University is offering a Language/Liberal Arts Program as well as Global Internships in Niamey, Niger. Both programs examine educational reform, development efforts and Sahelian

life. Contact: Boston University, Office of International Programs, Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; phone (617) 353- 9888. The Center for Global Education is coordinating and sponsoring a tour entitled "The Struggle to Dismantle

Apartheid: A Travel Seminar to South Africa." From November 3-17, 1993, participant will look at the causes and effects of violence that plagues urban townships and rural communities; explore the changes taking place today in South Africa, as well as the barriers to achieving genuine democracy free of racial discrimination; examine the past and present struggle against apartheid, including the political and economic dynamics underlying current negotiations; and talk to people involved in preparing for democratic elections. The tour visits the Johannesburg/Soweto/Pretoria area, Natal and Cape Town. Cost is $3,650, including air fare from New York. Air far can be arranged from other points in

North America. APPLICATION DEADLINE: September 13. Contact: Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 731-21st

Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55454; phone: (612) 330-1159. The African Development Foundation offers Ba Applied Research Grants to individual African development professionals, scientists, scholars, technicians and researchers who wish to study issues of direct significance to self-reliant development. Candidates must hold a bachelor's degree or equivalent technical training or professional experience and should be affiliated with and formally endorsed by an organization that deals with development issues. The $10,000 to $35,000 grants cover periods ranging from 12 to 24 months.

DEADLINE: October 1. Contact: African Development Foundation, Office of Learning and Dissemination, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini- conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a FISHERY PLANNING OFFICER for its Rome Office.

Responsibilities for the one year position include: collection, analysis and advising on socio-economic aspects of small-scale fisehries management and development issues, primarily for the Mediterrean, Near East and East Africa. Also, participate in sectoral studies of fisheries in developing countries, identifying management needs and formulating appropriate strategies and plans to assist Member Governments in policy decisions concerning fisheries alolocations as related to improving fishing communities.

QUALIFICATIONS: university degree in economics or sociology with specialization in socio-economics. Seven years of progressively responsible professional experience in quantitative analysis of development and management, including applied field research in socio-economics of smallOfficer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the

scale fisheries. DEADLINE: AUGUST 17, 1993. Contact Executive United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a FISHERY INDUSTRY OFFICER for its Rome Office. 

Responsibilities for the one year position include: coordination of fish in nutrition projects, primarily in Africa and Asia; provide technical inputs relating to the production, distribution, storage and acceptability of fish products to increase their use in nutrition; to promote fish consumption and implement training programmes related to the use of fish; to promote efforts to increase earnings from fish production at a community level to result in better

nutrition of the family. QUALIFICATIONS: university degree in food science and technology, human nutrition or a closely related field. Seven years of progressively responsible professional experience in development assistance, particularly related to household food security. Working knowledge (level C) of English or French and limited

knowledge (level B) of another official language. DEADLINE: SEPTEMBER 1, 1993. Contact Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437. The University of California, Santa Cruz is accepting applications for the ANTHROPOLOGY pool. Several part-time, temporary teaching positions are available for one or more quarters. The university seeks outstanding candidates able to

teach one or more of the following courses: Anthropology of Religion, Peoples and Cultures of Africa, Culture and Colonialism or Medical Anthropology. Send letter of application, three letters of recommendation and syllabi for proposed courses to Carolyn Martin Shaw, Chair, Search Committee, Anthropology Board of Studies, Clark Kerr Hall, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064. The University of Georgia is accepting letters of interest for a tenure-track faculty historian of the AFRICAN DIASPORA.

Contact: Robert Pratt, Department of History, LeConte Hall, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602. Responsibilities include project management, evaluation, budgeting, financial management,

training and fundraising experience. QUALIFICATIONS: Five years resident overseas experience in business or agricultural development, seven years international development work, including at least two years in Africa; fluent French preferred; must be willing to travel

internationally. Send letter and resume to: TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or fax (203) 838-6717, c/o Terri Scofield, manager of human resources. organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiatins, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environemtn; knowledge of primary health care

Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783- 5247. International Medical Corps (IMC) seeks a COUNTRY DIRECTOR to develop and implement its programs in Somalia.

CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622. NYZS/The Wildlife Conservation Society seeks a BUFFER ZONE MANAGER to be stationed in Masoala Peninsula, Madagascar. Work with national forester, national and international consultants and

extension/facilitation agents. QUALIFICATIONS: Advanced degree in forestry, agroforestry or related field; 3-5 years experience in tropical sustainable forestry and/or sustainable harvesting of forest products, familiarity with community organization, park management, ecotourism and ICDPs preferred. Fluency in French required. Salary commensurate with experience and qualifications; position subject to funding approval. POSITION STARTS OCTOBER 1993 for 2-3 years.

10460; phone: (718) 220-5887; fax: (718) 364-4275. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. Africa News


August 9, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently;y recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to- Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone

(501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following 

nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and December,

1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December

1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general

surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December 1993

and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly

renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered):

September-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; September 1993, January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, Augustof 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers

December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352- 0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box

65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta,

GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Africa News


August 9, 1993


PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Tony ALLAN and Andrew WARREN, eds., Deserts: The Encroaching

Wilderness -- A World Conservation Atlas. Cary: Oxford University Press (2001 Evans Road, Cary, NC 27513), 1993. $35.00 (cloth). 176 pp.

A colorful volume of maps, photographs and artwork is a reference guide and atlas to the world's desert regions. Lester R. BROWN, Hal KANE, and Ed AYERS, Vital Signs 1993 -- 

The Trends That Are Shaping Our Future. Washington: Worldwatch Institute (1776 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20036-1904), 1993. $10.95 (paper). 150 pp.

Research project tracks 42 key indicators of the planet's economic, environmental and social health. Cristovam BUARQUE, The End of Economics? -- Ethics and the

Disorder of Progress. Atlantic Highlands: Zed Press (171 First Avenue, Atlantic Highlands, NJ 07716), 1993. $19.95 (paper). 172 pp.

Contends that economic theory must incorporate an ethical standard in order to continue to command respect as a discipline. Kevin M. CLEAVER, A Strategy to Develop Agriculture in Sub- Saharan Africa and a Focus for the World Bank -- World Bank

Technical Paper No. 203. Philadelphia: World Bank (P.O. Box 7247-8619, Philadelphia, PA 19170-8619), 1993. $9.95 (paper). 140 pp.

Assessment of government and donor policies and investments in agriculture which have worked, and those which have not.

John L. ESPOSITO, The Islamic Threat: Myth or Reality?.

Cary: Oxford University Press (2001 Evans Road, Cary, NC 27513), 1992. $19.95 (cloth). 243 pp.

Examination of Islam's vitality as a global force and its relation to the western world. Christopher D. GERRARD, Greg D. POSEHN, and Granville ANSONG,

Africa News


August 9, 1993


FEMALE GENITAL MUTILATION: WORLD HEALTH ASSEMBLY CALLS FOR THE ELIMINATION OF HARMFUL TRADITIONAL PRACTICES


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

The Forty-Sixth World Health Assembly adopted, by acclamation, a resolution on Maternal Child Health and Family Planning for Health that highlights the importance of eliminating harmful traditional practices and other social and behavioural obstacles affecting the health of women, children and adolescents. The resolution. underlines that the persistence of practices ''such as child marriage, dietary limitations during pregnancy and female genital mutilation, . . . . restrict the attainment of the goals of health, development and human rights for all members of society. The resolution was sponsored by a group of African countries - Guinea, Kenya, Nigeria, Togo and Zambia, and Lebanon.

The World Health Assembly, in discussing the resolution and recognizing the progress made in maternal and child health and family planning, expressed confidence that WHO's strategy for the health of women and children would reduce by half the 500 000 deaths of women during pregnancy and childbirth and 4 million deaths of newborns that occur each year. 

It is believed that over 80 million female infants, adolescents and women in over 3O countries of the world have been subject to female genital mutilation. However, because of the limited information that is available, the Assembly requested that the Director-General provide additional information on the scope and health implications of such traditional practices. Female genital mutilation is mainly practiced ln Eastern and Western Africa. In a number of countries such as Djibouti, Mali, Sierra Leone, Somalia and large areas of Ethiopia and Sudan, nearly all women are affected; in others, such as Burkina Faso, Guinea Bissau and Kenya, the practice is common, affecting one-quarter to one- half of women. In other countries such as Mauritania, Togo, Uganda and the United Republic of Tanzania, the practice affects at least 5% of the population. Female genital mutilation is now found in countries such as Australia, Europe and North America among migrant groups. ''This traditional practice magnifies the inequity suffered by women in the communities where it is performed and must seriously be addressed if the health, social and economic development needs of women are to be met'', said Dr. Gabi Williams of the Delegation of Nigeria, when presenting the resolution on Maternal and Child Health and Family Planning for Health.

Female genital mutilation can lead to death or infertility. Among other complications, immediate risks include hemorrhage, tetanus, infection, and vesiculo-vaginal fistula. HIV infection can be contracted from the tools or instruments used. Long-term effects include problems of reproductive and general health such as urinary tract infections and coital difficulty, cysts and abscesses, keloid and severe scar formation, and difficulty when voiding and during menstruation. During childbirth, the risk of maternal death is doubled and the risk of a stillbirth increased several-fold. Moreover, during childbirth, the risk of hemorrhage and infection is greatly increased, and long-term morbidity becomes cumulative and chronic.

The origins of female genital mutilation are difficult to trace. While it is believed that it was originally an attempt to ensure chaste or monogamous behaviours or as a means of suppressing female sexuality, others believe that it served to protect adolescent girls against rape. Significantly, this practice is closely associated with poverty, illiteracy, and low status of women. In such settings, an uncircumcised woman is stigmatized, and not sought in marriage, which helps explain the paradox that the victims of the practice are among its strongest proponents, along with traditional midwives who perform the act. All these reasons point to the continuing cultural and traditional pressures which perpetuate the practice.

A number of indirect consequences on the health of women and newborn infants also exist. Women are aware of the difficulty that they will have in childbirth in the presence of genital mutilation. As a consequence they will not eat enough during pregnancy in order not to gain too much weight and often exacerbate an already existing anemia, thus increasing the risk of hemorrhage and infection, as well as long-term morbidity, and increase the risk of low birth weight and pre-term delivery. This practice of limiting dietary intake during pregnancy is widespread among many other populations of women who also fear complications during childbirth. These fears are translated into restrictions or prohibitions against certain foods, particularly animal proteins and some vegetables. Furthermore, the custom of drinking large amounts of tea with meals inhibits the absorption of iron and thus aggravates anemia, which affects over 6O% of women in the developing world. The custom of women being fed last, and therefore least, further reduces women's access to adequate food intake .

Research carried out in developing countries, such as Ethiopia, Guinea and Nigeria have shown that when adolescent girls under 17 years of age become pregnant and do not receive proper care, between 3% and 5% will die. These deaths occur because the girls are usually not fully developed physically, are frequently anemic and underweight, they have greater risks of complications during pregnancy and require specialized care during delivery. If care is available and ''used'', these risks can be reduced significantly. Unfortunately, because of such cultural obstacles as health care being provided by men, many women are inhibited from using these services.

WHO has assured governments of its readiness to support national efforts against the perpetuation of harmful traditional practices, and to continue collaboration in research and dissemination of information. WHO has played a role that has included the provision of technical and financial support for national surveys, for the relevant training of traditional birth attendants, midwives and other health workers and for grassroots initiatives. Moreover, WHO's programme areas of Women, Health and Development and Safe Motherhood, Adolescent Health and Nutrition collaborate very closely with other United Nations organizations and bodies involved in this field and have closely collaborated with the non governmental organizations working towards the elimination of these harmful traditional practices.

CONTACT: Dr Mark Belsey, Programme Manager, Maternal and Child Health and Family Planning, WHO, Geneva, Switzerland, telephone 4l 22 79l 3359. -30* DIRECTORY


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.
