Africa News


August 9, 1993


REPORT OF THE UNITED NATIONS SECRETARY-GENERAL ON THE SITUATION CONCERNING WESTERN SAHARA


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

July 28, 1993

1. In a status report submitted to the Security Council on 21 May 1993 (S/25818), I had informed the Council of my decision to visit the mission area in the first week of June, in pursuance of paragraph 2 of resolution 809 (1993), which called for an intensification of efforts in order to resolve outstanding issues, particularly those relating to the interpretation and application of the criteria for voter eligibility.

2. I visited the mission area from 31 May to 4 June 1993, accompanied by my Special Representative, Sahabzada Yaqub-Khan. The present document contains a report on my mission and on further efforts in pursuance of resolution 809 (1993). 

3. At Rabat I was received by His Majesty King Hassan II of Morocco. I also held meetings with the Prime Minister, Mr. Mohamed Karim Lamrani, the Minister of State, Mr. Moulay Ahmed Alaoui, the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, Mr. Abdellatif Filali, and the Minister of the Interior and Information, Mr. Driss Basri, and other senior officials. In the area of Tindouf I met with the Secretary- General of the Frente Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro (POLISARIO), Mr. Mohammed Abdelaziz. Senior Frente POLISARIO officials were also present. At Algiers I was received by the President of the Haut Comiti d'Etat, Mr. Ali Kafi. Meetings were also held with the Head of Government, Mr. Belaid Abdeslam, and other members of the Haut Comiti d'Etat, Mr. Redha Malek, Minister for Foreign Affairs, and General Khaled Nazzar, Minister of Defence. While on a subsequent mission at Vienna from 10 to 17 June, I held further consultations with the Permanent Representative of Morocco to the United Nations, Mr. Ahmed Snoussi, the POLISARIO Coordinator with the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO), Mr. Mustafa Bachir Sayed, and the Foreign Minister of Algeria, as well as the Permanent Representative of Mauritania to the United Nations, Mr. Mohamedou Ould Mohamed Mahmoud.

4. Additionally, the current Chairman and the Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) were kept regularly informed of ongoing efforts in pursuance of Security Council resolution 809 (1993). Other senior government officials from States members of the Security Council were briefed by me on the Western Sahara question during my visits to Paris and Vienna.

5. The aim of my visit to the mission area was to urge the parties to accept a compromise solution with regard to the interpretation and application of the criteria for voter eligibility. To this effect I presented to the parties a comprehensive text (see annex I) based on talks with the parties in August and September 1992 and on their comments regarding the outline of a possible compromise which my Special Representative had proposed during a visit to the mission area in March 1993. I invited the parties to convey to me as early as possible their views regarding the acceptability of my compromise proposals, to enable me to submit recommendations to the Security Council in a full report in pursuance of resolution 809 (1993).

6. To follow up my discussions with the authorities concerned, my Special Representative held another round of meetings in the mission area from 5 to 20 June 1993. During these and subsequent consultations, both parties reaffirmed their commitment to the implementation of the peace plan in its entirety and their determination to move towards an early referendum. Both parties stressed that they did not reject the proposed compromise but expressed reservations on certain provisions of the text. Reservations expressed by the authorities at Rabat centred on specific provisions concerning tribal links with the Territory which, in their view, were unduly restrictive. In spite of these concerns, Morocco has since acquiesced in the compromise in its present form.

7. For its part the Frente POLISARIO conveyed to the Special Representative its acceptance of all the criteria for voter eligibility enunciated by my predecessor in the annex to his report of 19 December 1991 (S/23299), thus signifying a favourable change in the earlier position of the Frente POLISARIO which had consistently objected to several of these criteria. With regard to the proposed compromise on the interpretation and application of the criteria for voter eligibility, the Frente POLISARIO also conveyed its acceptance of oral testimony in support of individual applications for participation in the referendum, which indicates another favourable change in its earlier position. However, in expressing substantial reservations on the compromise, the POLISARIO authorities proposed several amendments to the text. Their reservations and proposed amendments concern primarily provisions relating to tribal links with the Territory and to the composition of the tribal chiefs (shiukhs) invited to testify, which they consider unduly permissive.

8. As is well known, we have consistently sought to encourage direct talks between the parties as a way of facilitating the implementation of the peace plan. It was therefore gratifying to learn that, shortly after my visit to the mission area, both parties finally agreed to initiate direct talks in mid-July at Laayoune and to ask for the assistance of the United Nations in holding this meeting. Notwithstanding difficulties in the preparation and organization of the talks and other problems, mostly of a procedural nature, the delegations of Morocco and the Frente POLISARIO met from 17 to 19 July 1993 at Laayoune, in the presence of my Special Representative as United Nations observer. While it would have been unrealistic to expect a major breakthrough on substantial issues - nor was this the primary aim of the talks - it was an encouraging sign that this exploratory dialogue was held in a positive spirit, marked by restraint and mutual respect. Neither party has excluded the possibility of resuming the talks for wider discussions on issues of mutual concern. It is my earnest hope that such talks will soon be resumed as a follow-up to the Laayoune initiative.

9. In paragraph 3 of its resolution 809 (1993), the Security Council further asked for preparations for the holding of the referendum and urged that voter registration commence promptly, starting with the updated lists of persons included in the 1974 census. Pursuant to this request, Mr. Erik Jensen was appointed Chairman of the Identification Commission in May 1993 and immediately travelled to Rabat, Laayoune, Tindouf, Algiers and Nouakchott with a view to initiating the process of identification and registration of voters. He also assembled the members of the Commission and a team of registration officers. The former group arrived in Laayoune in June. On the basis of the mandate (see annex II) promulgated on 26 April 1993 in conformity with the relevant provisions of the settlement plan and article 11 of the general regulations of 8 November 1991 (see annex III), the Identification Commission began work on establishing with the authorities of both parties the detailed procedures for identification and registration, starting in the Laayoune and Tindouf areas.

10. Proposals regarding specific measures to initiate the above process were at first agreed, but reservations expressed subsequently made it necessary to modify certain aspects. Further discussions, which were facilitated by the presence of both parties at the direct talks in Laayoune, have since led to revised proposals for the organization of work, which should now make it possible for the actual identification and registration of potential voters to start. Meanwhile, the complicated but essential practical and logistical arrangements have been proceeding, registration materials are being prepared and most of the specialized technical equipment is expected to arrive shortly. One Identification Commission team has been deployed to Tindouf to begin preliminary work in that area.

11. The Police Commissioner, Colonel Jurgen Friedrich Reimann (Germany), who assumed his functions in May 1993 as Head of the Security Unit of MINURSO, arrived in the mission area, with a small contingent of 19 civilian police officers from Belgium (5), Germany (4), Malaysia (5) and Togo (5). This first contingent will accompany the registration teams to provide security and order at the various sites for registering voters.

12. The above report outlines factual developments related to my visit to the mission area and events that followed it. The intensification of efforts to overcome existing difficulties has contributed to the holding of direct talks between the parties which, if sustained, will hopefully facilitate the implementation of the settlement plan. The progress towards the registration of voters, which is gathering momentum, is another concrete step. The exchange of views has sharpened focus on outstanding issues. Foremost among these is the urgency of the acceptance of the compromise on the interpretation and application of the eligibility criteria.

13. I intend to submit in due course a full report to the Security Council in pursuance of resolution 809 (1993). -30NEWS RELEASE


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


CONGRESSIONAL LETTER TO U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE ON LIBERIA


LENGTH: 880 words


 

One Hundred Third Congress

Congress Of The United States

Committee on Foreign Affairs

House of Representatives

Washington, DC 20515

The Honorable George Moose

Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs

Department of State

Washington, DC 20520

Dear Mr. Secretary:

We are delighted, as we know you are, that the warring factions in Liberia reached agreement last week on a cease- fire and new transitional political arrangements. This breakthrough creates a real opportunity for ending the three and a half year old civil war which has devastated Liberia. Relief organizations estimate that nearly 150,000 lives have been lost in the conflict. 

 

Because of the long historical ties between the United States and Liberia, and because of the unwitting support that U.S. provided to the Doe regime during the 1980's, the United States has a special responsibility to do all in our power to ensure that this opportunity for peace is not lost. Our interest in ensuring that the settlement holds is heightened given the current political instability in Nigeria, which has provided the bulk of the ECOMOG peacekeeping forces in Liberia. This may be our last and best chance to restore political order in that troubled land.

In the past, Charles Taylor, head of the NPFL faction, has not implemented agreements that have been reached with his opponents. There is a real risk of this happening again. Taylor is convinced that the Nigerians are not a neutral force, but are committed to the Sawyer regime, and pose a direct physical threat to him and his forces. To respond to this concern, the peace plan proposes to expand the U.N. observer mission in Liberia and bring in non-West African forces (from Tanzania, Zimbabwe and Egypt) to supplement existing ECOMOG troops. This is primarily an African solution to an African problem, and should be encouraged.

We believe that the viability of the current agreement will depend upon the rapid deployment of additional U.N. personnel and non-West African troops. Without these confidence-building measures, there is little reason to believe that Taylor will not return to hostilities.

We urge you to do all in your power to assure that these confidence-buildingmeasures are undertaken. We realize that the problem here is money, and that resources for peacekeeping initiatives are almost completely exhausted. But we believe that the United States, in the past, has not been active enough in working to avoid Liberia's descent into anarchy. We now have the opportunity to make amends for this failing. We are willing and eager to work with the Administration to address the financial problem.

Thank you for your consideration. We look forward to hearing from you on this issue.

With best wishes, we are

Sincerely,

Dan Burton

Ranking Republican Member

Subcommittee on Africa

Harry Johnston

Chairman

Subcommittee on Africa


LOAD-DATE: August 10. 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


U.S. WELCOMES SIGNING OF LIBERIA PEACE AGREEMENT


LENGTH: 294 words


 

The White House, Office of the Press Secretary 7/28/93 The United States welcomes the recent signing of the Liberia peace agreement. This accord holds the promise of finally ending a destructive conflict that has racked Liberia, killed over one hundred thousand people and created over half a million refugees. We have provided over $250 million in humanitarian assistance to victims of the conflict and believe the new accord can put Liberia back on a path toward political reconciliation, national elections and civil reconstruction.

The U.S. commends and continues to support the sustained peace effort in Liberia by the United Nations, the Economic Community of West African States, and the Organization for African Unity. Their joint effort has succeeded in bringing the Liberation parties closer together and sets a model for conflict resolution in Africa and elsewhere.

The U.S. urges the parties to the agreement to adhere strictly to the commitments they have made. The accord will only succeed if they work in good faith with one another and with the international community. The parties can provide an early signal of their commitment to the accord by cooperating fully with the international relief agencies in the delivery of humanitarian assistance, and we urge them to do so.

CONGRESSIONAL LETTER TO U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE ON LIBERIA


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


EXCERPTS FROM: STATEMENT OF REP. WILLIAM J. JEFFERSON (D-LA) BEFORE THE COMMITTEE ON AFRICA


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 467 words


 

August 4, 1993 On June 12, 1993, the people of Nigeria elected M.K.O. Abiola as Nigeria's new President-Elect. Mr. Abiola was the leader of a democracy movement that was taking place in Nigeria that was comparable to the recent celebrated democratization movements in Poland, Germany, and Russia. On June 12, Nigeria was well on its way of becoming a member of the community of democratic nations.

But, the military dictator, General Ibrahim Babangida, annulled the election of Mr. Abiola on untenable grounds. Although this election was judged fair and free by international observed nations including Great Britain, General Babangida acted against the wishes of the 14 million people that voted in the June 12th election. The democratization of Nigeria now has been halted by the actions of General Babangida. 

I would hope that this committee would take a strong stand in support of the August 27th date as the date that Mr. Abiola is to assume office and the date of significant consequences for the relationship between Nigeria and the United States. The nearly 100 million people of Nigeria who make up nearly a quarter of the population of Africa deserve democracy.

Unless Mr. Abiola is allowed to take office, it may be necessary for our country to take severe action against General Babangida including withdrawals of pending debt relief, cancellation of cooperative agreements, freezing of official bank accounts, denial of entry to the U.S. by certain Nigerian officials, refusing to honor letters of credit or to allow export guarantees, and a reduction in diplomatic relations, among other possible actions.

Boris Yeltsin became a symbol of democracy around the world when he stood atop the tanks of the Soviet military to demand an end to military backed political rule. Mr. Abiola is showing the same courage and heroism that Mr. Yeltsin showed, except it is being done in relative obscurity out of sight of CNN cameras and therefore out of mind of most of the people in the west, indeed in the world.

Just as our nation rallied to Yeltsin and his countrymen as they faced down tanks, let us now give our national commitment to Mr. Abiola and the people of Nigeria as they confront the guns of military rule and seek to take the reins of their government.


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


BASKET CASE -- YINKA DARE OF NIGERIA


BYLINE: Scott Stearns BBC - FOCUS ON AFRICA, July-September 1993, Volume 4 Number 3


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Yinka Dare is the talk of American college basketball.

The 20-year-old Nigerian centre took the George Washington University Colonials to their first National Collegiate Championship in 32 years.

The team eventually lost to the University of Michigan. But along the way a nationwide television audience saw why Dare is the best first-year player in America. At 2.15 metres, the 125 kilo Dare led the league in rebounding and averaged 12.6 points a game. His 56.3 percent field goal shooting was the team's best. His 109 blocked shots set a single season school record. All from a young man who first picked up a basketball just four years ago. 

Born in Kabba, mid-west Nigeria, Yinka moved to Kano, with his family where his father, Jaiye is a civil engineer and avid tennis player.

Though most young Nigerians are more interested in football, Dare says his size and the fast inside play of basketball attracted him to the game in an informal street league at Kano Pillars Park.

"At first I didn't like it too much because I was struggling," he remembers. "I wasn't good at all and everybody was getting at me. It was tough for me. But then as I started getting good I saw the improvement I was making gradually. It became a challenge to me to make myself to be better than anybody I played with."

Within six months, he was. Another six months on the Kano Pillars state team and Dare tries out for Nigeria's national squad. There he faced older, more experienced players who showed him he still had much to learn about the game.

In February 1991, George Washington University assistant basketball coach Ed Meyers saw Dare play in Lagos. He looked awkward taking jump shots from the top of the key, but when Dare drove the lane and took the ball to the hoop with a one-step dunk, Meyers was a believer.

Rules governing American collegiate recruitment of young players forbade Meyers from speaking with Dare. But Meyers befriended a Nigerian air force lieutenant who knew the family and Dare was soon on his way to the Milford Academy in Connecticut to finish high school. At Milford, training improved his bench press weight from 55 kilos to 140 kilos. An honours student, Dare's powerful overhead dunk once shattered a backboard.

On his arrival at George Washington, he roomed with Gambian fourth year centre Adama Kah. A Graduate of St. Augustine's High School in Banjul, Kah helped Dare open a bank account and introduced him to American fast food. Care says he prefers pounded yam.

"When I first got here, I think he was the perfect roommate for me because he knew where I was coming from and it was easy to relate to him," Dare said. "Adama helped me get used to what I was coming to."

Having demonstrated he can play with the best in Division I college ball, scouts saw how far he goes from here is largely up to him.

"When he learns the game he's going to be a monster," assistant coach Meyers said. "He's come a long way and he's got a long way to go. If he's patient in his development and works hard, the sky's the limit."

There have already been flashes of brilliance. With less than two seconds left and down 79-77 to Rutgers, Dare caught a full-court pass and converted a layup at the buzzer to send the game into overtime. George Washington won 106- 100. Dare finished with a career high 26 points.

Colonial's head coach Mike Jarvis thinks Dare could be as good as Patrick Ewing, the starting centre for the New York Knicks, who coached Jarvis in high school. The U.S. press often compare Dare to another Nigerian, Hakeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets, or the most dominant first professional this season, Shaquille O'Neal of the Orlando Magic.

Dare is the first to admit he must become a more complete player. He's working on a ten-foot jump shot and a jump hook to spread out tight defenses under the basket. Treatment for exercise-induced asthma has helped his endurance on the floor. He needs to foul less.

"Right now, my parents are not even concerned about basketball as much as my education," he said. "They don't know how big it is here. I can't explain it to them. I didn't think basketball was this big."

Dare is pursuing a degree in business administration and says he enjoys living in the nation's capital. But more and more college players are leaving school early to turn pro, and Dare admits he may consider leaving George Washington before his senior year.

"If I can turn pro, I'll go, but I don't know when," he said. "I have to consider everything. I can't honestly say I'm going to say here four years. I can't see that far ahead yet."

The Nigerian community here herald Dare as an example of soft-spoken excellence in an American culture which they complain unduly portrays Nigeria as a country of drug dealers and military repression.

"I can only carry myself in a good way to reflect good on my country," he says. "Right now I can't afford to do anything that would damage the name of Nigerians here, and you know I wouldn't even think of doing anything like that."

He thinks often of his family at home on a quiet, tree- lined street in Kano. Brother Mike and sister Christine write of their new two-year-old sister Tobi.

"They know me, because I never write," he says apologetically. "I know they're getting mad right now. I'll write soon enough. Tell them I'm doing good right here." Scott Stearns reports for FOCUS ON AFRICA from Washington. -30T. Brew, 2400 Cleveland Street, Portsmouth, VA 23707.

Contact (agent in U.S): BBC FOCUS ON AFRICA MAGAZINE, James

Editorial: BBC African Service, Bush House, PO Box 76 Strand,

London, WC2B 4PH, England; phone: 071-257-2906; fax: 071-379- 0519.


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


COTE D'IVOIRE'S HOUPHOUET-BOIGNY: SO OLD, SO WISE?


BYLINE: BBC - FOCUS ON AFRICA, July-September 1993, Volume 4, Number 3


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Normally stable Cote d'Ivoire was rocked in March when the elite Republican Guard took to the streets. Ofeibea Quist-Arcton reports on the country's increasingly uncertain future.

Soldiers have mutinied before in Cote d'Ivoire, but to seize control of the presidential palace in the heart of Abidjan in a protest over pay was unprecedented. It was also a measure of the increasing desperation and generalized malaise in a country that was once the envy of its neighbors. 

During the 1960's and 1970s, Cote d'Ivoire's cocoa and coffee driven economy was the pride of West Africa; but the collapse in the value of both commodities in recent years has had serious consequences.

It took the personal intervention of octogenarian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny to calm the jumpy, volatile soldiers. But the incident shocked Ivorians. For the first time, Houphouet's hallowed portals had been invaded. It was seen as a slap in the face for the president, a deliberate, defiant gesture of disrespect, and he was said to be furious. A worrying sign of things to come?

The 'hands on' approach to sensitive national issues has always been very much the style of the veteran Ivorian leader; the 'Grand Old Man' of African politics, 'Le Vieux, Le Doyen.' His official age is put at 87, though Houphouet- watchers say a few years appear to have gone missing. After

the mutiny, there were the inevitable questions: is he losing his touch?

But for the moment, President Houphouet-Boigny remains, at least at his home, master of the situation. Within the region though, his prestige has recently taken a battering. There has been the failure first of peace talks on Liberia and then Angola, both conducted under the auspices of 'Le Vieux.' The self-styled peace broker often looks uncomfortably meddlesome and partisan; a man who cannot resist the temptation to take sides in regional conflicts, backing first the Biafrans, then Unita's Jonas Savimbi and latterly Charles Taylor.

On the domestic front, Houphouet's succession remains the great unanswered question. But 'Le Vieux' is keeping his cards close to his chest. The Ivorian president does not appear to have made any preparations for the event, nor has he openly groomed a successor - despite the presence of many hopefuls waiting in the wings.

Take Henry Konan Bedie, 58, President of the National Assembly, who, in accordance with the constitution, ought to take over from the president if he dies or is unfit to govern. Cote d'Ivoire's ambassador to the United States when he was only 27, Bedie is a chubby-faced southerner, a Catholic and a Baoule from the same ethnic group as Houphouet-Boigny, and is considered quietly ambitious. He is seen very much as Houphouet's spiritual son.

Bedie's main rival is the prime minister, the 51 year- old Alassane Dramane Ouattara, a former International Monetary Fund economist and technocrat, from the predominantly Muslim north. He was brought in by the president in late 1990 to rescue Cote d'Ivoire's ailing economy. If Ouattara has a weakness, it could be his lack of political experience and absence of an established powerbase.

Those with presidential ambitions are jockeying for power. But they do so gingerly. No one - except the opposition - talks openly about succession. However, the rivalry is palpable between Ouattara - determined to push through his unpopular privatization program - and Bedie, who has taken delight in challenging it. Their conflict has become public; but the president took his time before reacting.

Houphouet finally called together the members of his ruling PDCI party - the Democratic Party of Ivory Coast - and sharply reminded them, "I'm still here." He then proceeded to call both Bedie and Ouattara good men, renewing his confidence in both and consequently giving nothing away.

Outside the party which has ruled the country since independence, but also with presidential ambitions, is Laurent Gbagbo of the FPI, the Ivorian Popular Front Party. Not perhaps the threat he appeared to be a couple of years ago, Gbagbo remains very popular in the towns and cities. But like everything else, Gbagbo's political agenda remains set by the president.

It's two years before Ivorians will be called upon to vote for a new leader. But already Houphouet's PDCI party appears to have embarked on its election campaign. Earlier this year a 'peace caravan' in honor of the president toured the country. But back in Abidjan, 'Le Vieux' refuses to pronounce on whether he will be seeking a eighth term in office.

Meanwhile, the president's most visible foible and ultimate indulgence - the huge multi-million dollar basilica built in splended isolation in his hometown, Yamoussoukro has led to cheeky conjecture that politics aside, Felix Houphouet- Boigny is preparing his place in heaven.

Ofeibea Quist-Arcton is the BBC's West Africa correspondent. -30T. Brew, 2400 Cleveland Street, Portsmouth, VA 23707.

Contact (agent in U.S): BBC FOCUS ON AFRICA MAGAZINE, James

Editorial: BBC African Service, Bush House, PO Box 76 Strand,

London, WC2B 4PH, England; phone: 071-257-2906; fax: 071-379- 0519.


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 9, 1993


CLINTON ASKED TO BACK PEACE IN LIBERIA


BYLINE: Reed Kramer, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Members of Congress are pressing the Clinton administration to step up support for a new peace accord in the west African nation of Liberia, devastated by three and a half years of civil war. A cease-fire went into effect on August 1, a week after Liberia's warring factions signed an agreement that calls for disarming and demobilizing all combatants and holding national elections under United Nations supervision early next year.

The conflict has killed 150,000 people and uprooted nearly half the population of 2.5 million, many of whom are in refugee camps in neighboring countries.

Calls for diplomatic and financial commitment to the peace plan have come from both the Senate and House and from both sides of the aisle. Citing "a special responsibility to Liberia," which was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves, Sen. Paul Simon (D-IL) said U.S. action to support "this tenuous peace accord" is urgent. 

As many as 500 Liberian children a week are still dying from war-related causes, according to the United Nations Children's Fund. Recent fighting has blocked relief efforts in parts of the country, leaving more than 200,000 Liberians at risk from starvation and in need of immediate aid.

"Members of the United Nations are looking to us to take the lead," said Rep. Harry Johnston (D-FL), chairman of the House Africa subcommittee. "This may be our last and best chance to restore political order in that troubled land," Johnston said last week in an appeal to the State Department co-signed by the subcommittee's ranking Republican, Dan Burton (R-IN).

The peace pact, signed on July 25 by the interim Liberian government, the rebel movement known as the Patriotic Front and a militia of former Liberian soldiers called Ulimo, was sponsored by the United Nations, the Economic Community of West African States, and the Organization of African Unity.

Under the accord, a West African peacekeeping force of 11,000 that has been in Liberia since 1990 will be strengthened by four or five battalions from African nations outside the region. About 300 United Nations observers are scheduled to monitor the cease-fire process.

Administration officials have voiced support for the peace effort, which a White House statement called "a model for conflict resolution in Africa and elsewhere." But the officials concede that with so many issues vying for attention and resources, Liberia faces stiff competition. An interagency task force has been created to examine how U.S. assistance might be directed to back the international effort.

In a recent Senate hearing, Simon called upon the administration to abandon the "excessive caution" of past Liberian policy. Johnston and Burton said the U.S. government had not been "active enough in working to avoid Liberia's descent into anarchy" and now needs to "make amends for this failing."

Congressional critics say the Bush administration erred by refusing to respond when the Liberian civil war began in late 1989.

The outbreak of fighting followed a century of close ties between the two countries, and a decade of U.S. backing for an unpopular regime that made Liberia the largest per capita recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa. But as the government disintegrated and rebellion spread in the countryside during 1990, Bush adopted a severely limited diplomatic posture. According to officials who were in the State Department and Pentagon at the time, the White House vetoed several proposals to facilitate peace efforts, including using U.S. Marines stationed on four naval ships offshore to keep order in the capital, Monrovia, before it degenerated into Somalia-like anarchy.

The Marines did intervene when fighting overran Monrovia in August of 1990, but only to evacuate American personnel from the embassy and two CIA communications facilities. The United States also supplied about $300 million in humanitarian aid.

With deaths mounting, the 16-nation West African Community stepped into the breach, sending 7,000 troops who separated the warring sides, stopped the wholesale slaughter and brokered a series of fragile cease-fires.

Capitol Hill's Africa specialists say the White House response to the latest peace plan will be a test of administration support for Africa's recent moves towards democracy. Although senior Clinton strategists, including National Security Advisor Anthony Lake, have said Africa is a priority concern, Simon, who chairs the Senate Africa subcommittee, said the continent remains "more on the back burner than is desirable."

A similar view is expressed in the House by Congressional Black Caucus members and others who want to see a more active Africa policy. The House Africa subcommittee, with Republican backing, has asked administration officials to give greater attention to the humanitarian crises in Angola, Sudan and Zaire that are legacies of superpower competition.

Giving added urgency to the concern for Liberia is the fear that the peace accord could unravel if support operations are not established rapidly. "Funding must be found to get this started right away or we could see Liberia plunged back into full-scale war," said Richard Joseph, Africa specialist at the Carter Center in Atlanta, which has played a behind-the-scenes role in the negotiating process.

UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is expected to ask for a U.S. airlift of the new African battalions, slated to come from Zimbabwe, Egypt, and perhaps Tanzania, and to seek American funding and gear to equip the peace keepers for a multifaceted mission that includes cease-fire monitoring, weapons collection and warehousing, border control, and the encampment and demobilization of former soldiers from all sides.

The timing couldn't be worse. Peacekeeping budgets in both New York and Washington are overstretched, Congress is on summer recess, and several key UN and U.S. officials are on vacation.

Nevertheless, Liberians from all sides appear more optimistic than at any time since the war started. Amos Sawyer, a former university professor who has headed the interim government since its formation under West African auspices, said in a telephone interview from Monrovia that the current agreement differs in two important respects from previous failed accords. "We learned from sad experience that leaving things to good faith did not work out well, so we bargained hard for these terms," Sawyer said.

The strong disarmament provisions give West African troops the authority to seize weapons and "warlike materials" that are not handed over voluntarily and to search for lost or hidden guns. And where previous peace plans left Liberia a divided state under the control of rival administrations, the new accord unifies the country under a single authority prior to elections.

Both Sawyer's administration and the rival Patriotic Front government established by rebel leader Charles Taylor are to be dissolved by the end of this month, replaced by a five- member transitional council and a 35-member legislative assembly. All three Liberian factions have named a representative to the Council, which will chose its own chairperson and select two additional members from three nominees submitted by each group. The interim government and Taylor's Patriotic Front will name 13 members each to the assembly, with Ulimo choosing the other nine. None of the participants in the transitional government will be allowed to seek office in the elections.

This month's cease-fire ends a new military offensive launched by Taylor last October after two years of precarious peace. The rebel leader, who denounced the West African intervention as a Nigerian-led effort to keep him from taking power, vowed to force the peacekeepers out of Liberia.

But Taylor's army, which had controlled much of Liberia's territory, suffered a series of defeats when West African troops captured the large Firestone rubber plantation and the U.S.-built international airport in February, and seized the port city of Buchanan in May. Loss of the port ended profitable rebel exports of iron ore, timber, rubber and diamonds used to finance imports of arms and other supplies. A regional economic embargo further squeezed Taylor's once- ample coffers.

Grace Minor, a Taylor spokesperson in the United States, acknowledged that the Patriotic Front has suffered economically. But she said financial pressures were not the reason Taylor agreed to the latest peace plan. The new agreement is a "good solution" that should end the fighting because it was drawn up by all the Liberian parties and was not "imposed by outsiders," she said.

Although the peace agreement calls for opening all roads to relief convoys, free movement exists only on paper. Military officers on both sides appear intent on awaiting the arrival of UN observers to verify that aid shipments contain no weapons.

In a report to the Security Council last Tuesday, Boutros- Ghali promised to dispatch an advance team of observers "as soon as possible." A UN technical team has arrived in Monrovia to identify ways to speed up emergency relief and to draft plans for establishing an observer mission in the country.

Several American organizations including the Carter Center and National Democratic Institute have drawn up plans to provide monitors for the elections. -30COTE D'IVOIRE'S HOUPHOUET-BOIGNY: SO OLD, SO WISE?


LOAD-DATE: August 10, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

* EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

An 18-day "Reality Tour" of Zimbabwe and Malawi is offered by Robyn Michaels, a former Peace Corps volunteer in conjunction with Classic Tours International. Urban areas and markets, development projects and the planning office in Blantyre, Malawi are on the itinerary; and in Zimbabwe, tourist will visit, Bulawayo, Hwange National Park and Victoria Falls. For an additional charge of $550, Nairobi and Mombasa in Kenya may be added. Travelers will need shots, anti-malarial prophylaxsis and a sleeping bag. An initial deposit of $1,000 is required by OCTOBER 15, 1993 for the tour, which is scheduled for January 19, 1994. Final payment is required by December 15, 1993. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply.

FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Fifty grants are available, and all include maintenance for one academic year, roundtrip international travel, health and accident insurance and a research allowance. Candidates may apply to only one country. Candidates must be U.S. citizens and hold a bachelors degree or its equivalent by the beginning of the grant. For more information, call 415-723-0856. The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions

compete in two separate categories for funding: (1) Non- research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category. The application deadline is November 1. To request guidelines

and proposal forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008-3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. LENGTH: 1614 words


 

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a FISHERY INDUSTRY OFFICER for its Rome Office.

Responsibilities for the one year position include: coordination of fish in nutrition projects, primarily in Africa and Asia; provide technical inputs relating to the production, distribution, storage and acceptability of fish products to increase their use in nutrition; to promote fish consumption and implement training programmes related to the use of fish; to promote efforts to increase earnings from fish production at a community level to result in better

nutrition of the family. QUALIFICATIONS: university degree in food science and technology, human nutrition or a closely related field. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER (Africa and Middle East Programs) to be posted to Nairobi. The position is responsible for the development, monitoring and evaluation of program activities to sustain continuing African efforts in democratization and

economic liberalization. QUALIFICATIONS: graduate training in the social sciences, a solid grounding in African governance and development issues and familiarity with current political, economic and constitutional changes in the region; sound judgment, demonstrated interpersonal, analytical and writing abilities; preferred qualification include previous working experience in Eastern and Southern African; knowledge of development assistance program.

Location: Nairobi. Salary, Program Officer: $54,300-68,800.

Salary, Assistant Program Officer: $37,300-47,200. Send curriculum vitae and a brief writing sample for Position

#205 to: Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017. SENIOR POPULATION ADVISOR is needed by CARE for its Population Programming. Responsibilities include developing CARE's Population and Field Programs Strategy in coordination with corresponding field offices. Provide guidance and technical assistance; design, implement and evaluate projects. Represent CARE and collaborate with USAID

and other donors. Qualifications: MD, doctorate or equivalent academic experience in demography, repreductive health or maternal/child health. Excellent communications

skills, ability to travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016. Save the Children seeks a SOUTHERN AFRICAN PROGRAM DIRECTOR and has several other openings in its Africa division. For more information, contact Virginia Banks, Recruitment and Staff Development, 54 Wilton Road, Wesport, CT 06880; phone

(203) 221-4000. Fax resume and salary requirements to: (203) 221-4077. The International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES) has an Africa Programs division which periodically offers internship opportunities in the Foundation's Washington, D.C. office. Candidates should be interested in the issues that surround democratization in Africa. Foreign language

ability is desirable. For further information, contact: Keith Klein, Director of Africa Programs, IFES, 1620 I

Street NW, Suite 611, Washington, D.C. 20006; phone: (202) 828-8507.

LANGUAGE: English

181 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


* VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently;y recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison,

AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following 

nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and December,

1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December

1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general

surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December

1993 and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House.

Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered):

September-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472- 1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; September 1993, January-March 1994, May-June, 1994,

September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box

65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby

Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

* PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

George B.N. AYITTEY, Africa Betrayed. New York: St. Martin's Press (175 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10010), 1992. $35.00 (cloth). 412 pp.

A critical look at the single-party and dictatorial governments of African countries. Elliot J. BERG, ed., Rethinking Technical Cooperation -- 

Reforms for Capacity Building in Africa. New York: United Nations Publications (Room DC2-853, Dept. 600, New York, NY 10017), 1993. $17.50 (paper). 336 pp.

An assessment of recent reform proposals and projects along with alternative plans to promote greater self- reliance in developing nations. John Henrik CLARKE, African People in World History.

Baltimore: Black Classic Press (P.O. Box 13414, Baltimore, MD 21203), 1993. $8.95 (paper). 92 pp.

A narrative on the significant people and events that shaped African, African-American and world history. Dan CONNELL, Against All Odds -- A Chronicle of the Eritrean

Revolution. Trenton: The Red Sea Press (556 Bellevue Avenue, Trenton, NJ 06818), 1993. $24.95 (cloth). 309 pp.

An eyewitness account of the movement and a historical study of the struggle for liberation. Joseph E. HARRIS, ed., Global Dimensions of the African

Diaspora. Washington: Howard University Press (2900 Van Ness Street, NW, Washington, DC 20008), 1993. $24.95 (paper). 532 pp.

Collection of essays from the First and Second African Diaspora Institutes and other works.

Diane Victoria HORN, African Nomad Designs. Owings Mills: Stemmer House Publishers (2627 Caves Road, Owings Mills, MD 21117), 1992. $5.95 (paper). 48 pp.

Presentation of patterns and designs, along with explanations of their sources, materials and symbolism in the nomad population. Doris LESSING, African Laughter -- Four Visits to Zimbabwe.

Scranton: Harper Collins (1000 Keystone Industrial Park, Scranton, PA 18512-4621), 1992. $25.00 (cloth). 442 pp.

Experiences of the author's return to her homeland, after years of exile.

Ann McKinstry MICOU, The Donor Community in South Africa: A

Directory (Working Paper No. 26). New York: Institute of International Education (809 United Nations Plaza, New York, NY 10017-3580), 1993. 81 pp.

Reference guide to the activity of donor organizations in South Africa. Tibamanya mwene MUSHANGA, ed., Criminology in Africa. New

York: United Nations Publications, 1992. $45.00 (paper). 272 pp.

Focuses on the problems of crime and the criminal justice system facing African countries and how it affects sustainable development. PANOS INSTITUTE, Grasshoppers & Locusts -- The Plague of the

Sahel. London: Panos Institute (9 White Lion Street, London N1 9PD, United Kingdom), 1993. $12.95 (paper). 114 pp.

Examines past methods of dealing with locusts and grasshoppers and presents possible ways to combat recurring plagues. Mamphela RAMPHELE and Chris MCDOWELL, eds., Restoring the Land -- Environment and Change in Post-Apartheid South

Africa. London: Panos Institute, 1991. $12.95 (paper). 216 pp.

A look at South Africa's environmental problems and its industrial, agricultural and conservation policies.

Abdi SHEIK-ABDI, Divine Madness: Mohammed Abdulle Hassan

(1856-1920). Atlantic Highlands: Humanities Press International, Inc. (171 First Avenue, Atlantic Highlands, NJ 07716), 1993. $55.00 (cloth). $22.50 (paper). 226 pp.

Biography of the leader of the Somali resistance movement against British and Ethiopian colonisers in the early 1900s. Elliott P. SKINNER, African Americans and U.S. Policy Toward

Africa, 1850-1924: In Defense of Black Nationality.

Washington: Howard University Press (2900 Van Ness Street, NW, Washington, DC 20008), 1992. $34.95 (cloth). $24.95 (paper). 555 pp.

Historical study of U.S.-Africa policy, including first African-American diplomats and the relationship between Liberia and the U.S.

THE WORLD BANK, Uganda: Agriculture -- A World Bank Country

Study. Philadelphia: World Bank (P.O. Box 7247-8619, Philadelphia, PA 19170-8619), 1993. $13.95 (paper). 207 pp.

Examines work of previous studies and projects on the agricultural sector and stimulation of growth, making general policy recommendations.

THE WORLD BANK, Uganda: Growing Out of Poverty -- A World

Bank Country Study. Philadelphia: World Bank, 1993. $12.95 (paper). 197 pp.

Analyzes the economic policy changes in Uganda and tracks the progress of anti-poverty policies. Gillies TURLE, The Art of the Maasai -- 300 Newly Discovered

Objects and Works of Art. New York: Alfred A. Knopf (201 East 50th, New York, NY 10022), 1992. $50.00 (cloth). 160 pp.

Description and history of Maasai art with color photography (by Peter Beard).

186 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


THE SAHARA EQUATORIAL AFRICA EASTERN AND SOUTHERN AFRICA


SECTION: CALENDAR OF EVENTS;DIRECTORY;MINNEAPOLIS, MN


LENGTH: 1840 words


The AFRICATREK Cycling Expedition, led by Dan Buettner, is about to complete its unprecedented bicycle journey across Africa. On August 17, after cycling 11,500 miles across grueling terrain, including the Sahara Desert and the jungles of Zaire, the team set a world record when they arrived at Cape Agulhas, located at the southernmost tip of South Africa. The team dipped the front wheels of their Cannondale mountain bikes in the ocean to symbolize the end of the expedition. The three American team members will return home to the United States via KLM Royal Dutch Airlines on August 28. On November 24, 1992, Dan Buettner, along with his team consisting of two black and two white men, set out to capture a world record for bicycling from the north to the south of Africa. During the 10 month expedition, the team experienced incredible obstacles, including military skirmishes in Algeria and Zaire, being arrested twice, surviving five bouts of malaria, and enduring a three week period where they each ate about 70 bananas a day to survive! The team cycled 1200 miles through the Sahara on the classic trans-Saharan highway (Route du Hoggar). They encountered roads ranging from well-paved to boulder-laden to deep sand. In order to survive from oasis to oasis, the team carried condensed milk and dates, and used a 20 liter water bag developed by WTC Industries Inc. The bag which fits into the bike frame, automatically purifies water with PentaPure Water Purifier technology. Dan Buettner commented, "With all the challenges we encountered, at least with the PentaPure system we were able to count on clean water throughout Africa." When the team reached Tamanrasset, the last major oasis town in the Sahara, they were informed that the border was closed on their proposed route between Niger and Algeria. The team then traveled another 150 miles sough through virgin desert in quest of a seldom used border crossing, but unfortunately got caught and separated in a blinding sandstorm. After reuniting, the team returned to Tamanrasset where they traveled back to Algiers and caught a plane to Niamey, Niger. From Niamey to Lagos, the team cycled through a region called the Sahel, which is sandwiched between the desert and the tropics. The conditions were hot and hazy with barren, charred landscape caused by "slash and burn" agricultural practices. The roads in Nigeria were some of the best the team encountered, but the traffic was "unbelievably bad." Daily, the team passed overturned and abandoned trucks on the roadside. They were also shocked to pass two dead bodies that appeared to have been hit by cars and left for months on the side of the road. To ensure their personal safety, the team wore 3M Scotchlite Reflective Material on their clothes to make them more visible. The most challenging part of the expedition was a three week stretch through the rainforest of Zaire. To avoid military and rebel forces, the cyclists stayed on little- used mud-paths through the rainforest. For three weeks the team cycled about 60 miles per day with little food and under harsh conditions. Team members emerged from Zaire about 20 pounds lighter. As the team cycled through eastern Africa, food became more plentiful and the roads smoother. In Dar Es Salaam, the team helped distribute over 500 bicycles which had been gathered by Burnsville, Minnesota Rotary Club in Conjunction with trek. The donated bicycles were given to schools and medical clinics in Tanzania and Kenya. In South Africa, the AFRICATREK team met with Walter Sisulu, the Vice President of the ANC, and President F.W. de Klerk, who hailed AFRICATREK as "a courageous effort to help break down barriers between the peoples of Africa and the rest of the world." President de Klerk also added that he would like to take up biking himself, but would need six extra bikes for his body guards! Back in the United States, the expedition was followed by close to a million students who used a study guide produced by Land O'Lakes and Nystrom, studied the weekly updates and read about the team's adventures in "Weekly Reader", "Junior Scholastic" and "Sports Illustrated for Kids". Many of these supporters will attend the AFRICATREK homecoming event sponsored by Target Stores at the Hubert Humphrey Terminal at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport on August 28th at 4:45 p.m. St. Paul native Dan Buettner, 33, a published author and charismatic speaker, has led bicycle trips around the world through the former Soviet Union, and from Alaska to Argentina for which he and his brother Steve hold a world record. Dan Buettner is also a recent winner of the Polartec Performance Challenge award. He has appeared on the Today Show, Late Night with David Letterman, CNN, and Bill Cosby's To Tell the Truth. Other team members include: Steve Buettner, 28, the team's mechanic and James (Chip) Thomas, MD, 35, of Arizona, the team's doctor. Nigerian, Mobolaji Oduyoye, 30 served as the team's language expert for the first half of the expedition and was replaced by Ugandan, Michael Mpyangu, 29, for the second leg. When asked about the team's greatest accomplishment, Dan Buettner commented, "We pulled together five people from vastly different backgrounds to cross perhaps the most difficult continent on earth -- and emerged as friends." NOTE: Interviews with Dan Buettner and the other team members are available in the United States at a press conference at the Humphrey Terminal at the Minneapolis/St. Paul airport at 4:45 PM on August 28. B-roll footage, photographs, and slides from the expedition are also available. The public is invited to meet Dan Buettner on August 29th from 1:00-2:30 PM at the Woodbury, MN, Target store. CONTACT: Jocelyn Hale or Susan Erling at 612-349-6606. AFRICATREK, 529 South Street, Suite 310, Minneapolis, MN 55415; phone: 612-349-6606; fax: 612-349-6584.

August 28 Cleveland, OH -- Symposium "Slavery and Genocide in Sudan"

Contact: Augustine Lado or Betty Hinds, Pax Sudani Network,

P.O. Box 15118, Cleveland OH, 44115-0118; phone: (216) 861

1539; fax: (216) 687-9354; E-Mail: R0926.vmcms.csu.edu. September 4-6 Los Angeles, CA -- Festival "Pan-African Folk Festival"

Westview Street, Los Angeles, CA 90016; phone: (213) 237

Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


UNITED STATES PEACE-KEEPERS IN SOMALIA


LENGTH: 294 words


 

9 August 1993 -- The following statement was issued by the

Spokesman for Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali:

The Secretary-General deplores the incident on 8 August in which four United States army soldiers serving with the United Nations Operation in Somalia (UNOSOM II) were killed when their vehicle, while on a routine patrol in south Mogadishu, was hit by a large explosive device, probably detonated by remote control.

The Secretary-General expresses his condolences and deepest sympathies to the families of the brave peace- keepers who lost their lives in the service of the United Nations. 

At the Secretary-General's instructions, UNOSOM II is investigating the incident.

This cowardly attack on United Nations peace-keepers in Somalia demonstrates the urgent need to accomplish the total disarmament of the factions and militias still holding weapons in Mogadishu and the rest of Somalia. The perpetrators of the attacks will not succeed in thwarting the objectives of UNOSOM II mandated by the Security Council. Those objectives are the provision of humanitarian assistance; political reconciliation; and re-establishment of Somali political institutions. The maintenance of a secure environment throughout Somalia is indispensable for the achievement of those objectives. -30AFRICATREK TEAM RETURNS


LOAD-DATE: August 24, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


ON BEHALF OF THE SOUTHERN SUDANESE AND NUBA MOUNTAINS PEOPLE


LENGTH: 534 words


 

August 9, 1993 NAIROBI -- Since July 26th, many innocent civilians that live in the villages between Yei and Morobo (Southern Sudan) have become daily victims of heavy bombing from the Government of Khartoum. This air bombing has greatly intensified - morning, noon and evening - since August 3rd. This is not only a breach of the cease-fire, but a most atrocious genocide of hundreds of innocent people in the vicinity of Kaya. Begining on August 5th, this bombing has caused about 100,000 people to flee Kaya and its vicinity into northern Uganda, Zaire, and other areas inside Sudan. These people are without shelter, blankets, utensils, food,and medicines at the very peak of the rainy season. 

In view of this situation we are calling on the international community to take immediate and appropriate measures to stop Khartoum's continuous and brutal killing of innocent Southern Sudanese civilians.

We request the UN Secretary General, Boutros Boutros 1. To urge all combatants to observe a cease-fire and

Ghali, to take action of the following: to stop the killing of innocent civilians.

2. To stop the Khartoum Government from bombing civilian population in villages and re-settlement camps.

3. To impose a military air exclusion zone over the southern Sudan and Nuba mountains with immediate effect from 12 GMT, 10 August, 1993.

4. To create safe-havens in Western and Eastern Equatoria, Bahr-el Ghazal, the Nuba Mountains and Upper Nile.

5. To enforce the adherence of all warring parties in the south and Nuba Mountains to respect the peace of the demilitarized zones and safe-havens.

6. To monitor the situation on the ground with UN security personnel.

The Church has raised her voice on numerous other occasions. Once more the Church raises her voice on behalf of the desperate civilians, suffering in Southern Sudan and the Nuba Mountains. These people continue to undergo inhumane treatment and the most serious violation of human rights. We encourage not only the effort to supply essential humanitarian materials but also the effort of the UN, NGOs and the international community to impede the Khartoum Government's indiscriminate attacks on civilians.

The world's powerful nations through the offices of the UN should address the issue of human suffering in the Sudan and particularly in the South and Nuba Mountains. Please stop the war! Protect innocent civilians. New Sudan Council of Churches Executive Committee -30SECRETARY-GENERAL DEPLORES KILLING OF FOUR


LOAD-DATE: August 24, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


CHAD: MORE THAN 30 CIVILIANS KILLED BY MEMBERS OF THE SECURITY FORCES, MANY OF THEM EXTRAJUDICIALLY


BYLINE: Amnesty International


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Amnesty International is concerned about the killing of more than 30 civilians and the injuring of over 150 others during clashes on 8 August 1993 between demonstrators and security forces in the northern district (quartier nordiste) of the capital, N'Djamena. The security forces reportedly used automatic weapons and rockets to disperse the demonstrators. The authorities have announced that four gendarmes and three policemen were killed.

The demonstration was organized by the Ouaddai community in N'Djamena to protest against the apparent failure by the government to protect people in eastern Chad's Ouaddai prefecture from killings and other abuses. About 80 unarmed civilians were massacred on 6 August 1993 in Chokoyan village, about 100 kilometres east of Ouaddai's capital, Abeche, when an armed gang, thought by some to be members of former minister Abbas Koty, surrounded a market there and opened fire indiscriminately. The authorities have announced that government troops broke up the gang and arrested its leader. 

Members of the Gendarmerie were reportedly sent to prevent the demonstration, which the authorities have said was unauthorized, and were stoned by some in the crowd. The authorities have claimed some of the demonstrators shot at the gendarmes. The Republican Guard, a unit of the Chadian army directly responsible to President Idriss Deby, was subsequently deployed to support the gendarmes and they used automatic weapons and bazooka rockets against the crowd, resulting in the heavy death toll. There have been reports that several wounded civilians were removed from ambulances and shot at point blank range by members of the security forces.

The authorities have announced that 203 civilians have been detained for interrogation in connection with the violence. It is unclear whether an independent inquiry will be ordered to establish whether the use of automatic weapons and bazooka rockets was legitimate and whether the deaths and injuries could have been prevented or minimized.

BACKGROUND INFORMATION

More than 800 people, many of them unarmed civilians have been executed extrajudicially since President Idriss Deby came to power in December 1990. Many of them have been killed in custody or during attacks by members of the security forces on known or suspected government opponents or members of their ethnic groups. Members of the Ouaddai community appear to have been among those particularly targeted on a number of occasions. (For example, see UA 254/92, AFR 20/09/92, 5 August 1992).

Amnesty International is investigating reports of killings, looting and other human rights violations in recent months by members of the security forces in Ouaddai prefecture. The authorities are not known to have taken any action to investigate the reports and bring those responsible to justice. The violations have been exacerbated by attacks on civilians by unidentified armed gangs, some of them thought to be rebels. Lack of government action and the apparent impunity enjoyed by members of the security forces have left the population unable to distinguish between abuses by government troops and by other armed gangs.

RECOMMENDED ACTION: Please send telegrams/telexes/faxes and airmail letters either in

French, Arabic or in your own language:

- expressing concern at the killing of more than 30 civilians by members of the security forces, observing that the security forces appear to have shot to kill, including the use of bazooka rockets;

- expressing particular concern at reports that some of those killed had been injured and were removed from ambulances and deliberately shot at point blank range;

- expressing concern that the recent killings in N'Djamena show that the authorities have not taken sufficient measures to restrict and regulate the use of lethal force and to prevent arbitrary or deliberate killings in circumstances which violate internationally recognized standards;

- recommending that standing orders on the use of force and firearms be urgently prepared and introduced, based on the United Nations Basic Principles on the Use of Force and Firearms by Law Enforcement Officials (adopted by the Eighth UN Congress of the UN General Assembly in Resolution 45/121 on 14 December 1990).

- calling for an independent and impartial public inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the killings in N'Djamena, and the wounding of more than 150 others, and urging that those found responsible for deliberate and unlawful killings, be brought to justice;

- inquiring whether there has been an investigation into recent reports of extrajudicial executions and other human rights violations by the security forces and killings by other armed gangs in Ouaddai and, if so, asking to be informed of the results of such an investigation and what steps have been taken to prevent their recurrence;

APPEALS TO

President: Colonel Idriss DEBY

(Salutation: Monsieur le President de la Republique/Dear President) President de la Republique Presidence de la Republique N'Djamena Republique du Tchad

Telegrams: President Deby, N'Djamena, Chad

Telegrams: President Deby, N'Djamena, Chad

Telexes: 5201 PRESIREP KD; 5307 PRESIREP KD

Telegrams: Ministre Interieur, N'Djamena, Chad

Telexes: c/o 5328 MINAFFET KD

PLEASE SEND COPIES OF YOUR APPEALS TO: Embassy of Chad, Boulevard Lambermont 52, 1030 Brussels, Belgium (Please see the responses to this topic for the addresses of diplomatic representatives in other countries)

190 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


(sh At least 35 members of the Ogoni ethnic group from the town of Kaa in Rivers State, including Mr Nwiku and three young children


BYLINE: Amnesty International


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

August 10, 1993 -- Amnesty International is gravely concerned by reports that at least 35 people in Kaa town in Rivers State have been extrajudicially executed by armed men, some of whom are believed to have been in navy and police uniforms, on 4 August 1993. The victims, who are from the Ogoni ethnic group, are believed to include at least three young children and the husband of Maria Nwiku, who was herself injured in the attack.

Local government officials maintain that the attack was part of an ethnic clash between the Ogoni people and the neighbouring Adoni people, from whose lands the attackers came. However, the removal of all Ogoni policemen from the region three weeks prior to the attack and the military's failure to restore order in Kaa strongly suggest that the attack had the support of the military. 

Amnesty International deplores the apparently deliberate extrajudicial execution of members of the Ogoni ethnic group. It is calling on the Nigerian government to halt these killings and to conduct an immediate, thorough and impartial investigation to determine whether the security forces were involved, and with a view to bringing all those responsible for the killings to justice. Amnesty International also calls on the Nigerian authorities to safeguard the security of all Ogoni people, including those who have fled the area.

BACKGROUND INFORMATION

The Ogoni community has been campaigning against the environmental damage to their homeland in Rivers State and the destruction of their land and crops caused by the extraction of petrochemicals by oil companies, including Shell and the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), for which they have received no compensation. The Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP) has been active in defending the rights of the Ogoni community and in raising awareness of their plight.

Ken Saro-Wiwa, spokesperson for MOSOP, was arrested on two separate occasions in April 1993 and again on 21 June 1993 with N.G. Dube and Kobari Nwile, both active members of MOSOP. All three were charged on 13 July 1993 under the Criminal code of Eastern Nigeria in connection with their activities on behalf of the Ogoni community (see UA 238/93, AFR 44/07/93, 20 July 1993). Ken Saro-Wiwa was released on bail because of a heart condition in the week beginning 26 July 1993 and is believed to still be in hospital. The other two are believed to still be in detention.

RECOMMENDED ACTION: Please send telegrams/telexes/express and airmail letters either in

English or in your own language:

- expressing grave concern at reports that at least 35 members of the Ogoni ethnic group, including the above- mentioned individuals have been extrajudicially executed by armed men, some of whom are believed to have been in navy and police uniforms, on 4 August 1993;

- calling on the Nigerian authorities to halt these killings and to conduct an immediate, thorough and impartial investigation, with a view to bringing those responsible to justice;

- calling on the Nigerian authorities to ensure that the safety of all members of the Ogoni ethnic group is guaranteed.

APPEALS TO:

General Ibrahim Babangida (Salutation: Dear President) President and Chairman of the National Defence and Security Council State House Abuja Federal Capital Territory Nigeria

Telegrams: President Babangida, Abuja, Nigeria

Telexes: (0905) 91529 or

91530 EXTNAL NG (via Ministry of Foreign Affairs)

General Sani ABACHA (Salutation: Dear General Abacha) Chief of Defence Staff and Minister of Defence Defence Headquarters Ministry of Defence Abuja Federal Capital Territory Nigeria

Telegrams: General Abacha, Ministry of Defence, Abuja, Nigeria

Mr Rufus Ada George (Salutation: Dear Governor) State Governor Government House 91000 Port Harcourt Rivers State, Nigeria

Telegrams: State Governor Rufus Ada George, Port Harcourt, Nigeria

Alhaji Aliyu I. ATTAH (Salutation: Dear Inspector- General) Inspector-General of Police Ministry of Police Affairs Defence Headquarters Moloney Street, Lagos, Nigeria

Telegrams: Inspector-General Attah, Ministry of Police Affairs, Lagos, Nigeria

PLEASE SEND COPIES OF YOUR APPEALS TO: His Excellency Alhaji Abubakar Alhaji, K.B.E., High Commission of Nigeria, Nigeria

House, 9 Northumberland Ave, London WC2 5BX. Fax: 071 839 8746 (Please see the responses to this topic for the addresses of diplomatic representatives in other countries)

AND, IF POSSIBLE, TO THE FOLLOWING:

newspapers: Nigerian Star PMB 73, 97 Aggrey Road Port Harcourt, Rivers State Nigeria Daily Times PMB 21340, Ikeja Lagos, Nigeria National Concord POB 4483, Ikeja Lagos, Nigeria The Guardian PMB 1217, Oshodi Lagos, Nigeria Newswatch PMB 21499, Ikeja Lagos, Nigeria PLEASE SEND APPEALS IMMEDIATELY. Please do not send appeals after 21 September 1993.

Section, 99 - 119 Rosebery Avenue, London EC1R 4RE; email:
