LOAD-DATE: August 24, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


OBSERVERS TO LIBERIA TO MONITOR CEASE-FIRE AS CALLED FOR IN 25 JULY COTONOU AGREEMENT


BYLINE: United Nations Information Centre


LENGTH: 5547 words


 

Security Council SC/5683, 3263rd Meeting 10 August 1993 -- The Security Council this afternoon approved the dispatch to Liberia of an advance team of 30 military observers to monitor, investigate and report cease- fire violations, as called for in the Cotonou Agreement signed on 25 July by the parties to the conflict in that country.

The mandate of the advance team would expire within three months, according to resolution 856 (1993) which was adopted unanimously by the Council. Also by that text, the Council welcomed the Secretary-General's decision to send a technical team to Liberia to evaluate the proposed establishment of a United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL).

The Council called upon all parties to the conflict to respect and implement the cease-fire, to cooperate fully with the advance mission and to ensure the safety of all United Nations staff as well as all other peace-keeping and humanitarian personnel within Liberia. It commended the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) for its efforts to restore peace, security and stability in Liberia. 

Liberia's Minister for Foreign Affairs, G. Baccus Matthews, said the successful implementation of the Cotonou Agreement would herald a new chapter in international cooperation for peace between the United Nations and a regional and subregional organization. The cease-fire was being fully observed. The parties were taking steps to transform themselves into a Liberian National Transitional Government, but their efforts would depend on the help of the United Nations within the next 30 days, at the same time that the disarmament process must start. He appealed to the Council to support the people of Liberia, who were ready to march together to a peaceful and democratic future.

Statements were also made by the representatives of Benin, Nigeria, Djibouti, Morocco, Venezuela, China, Cape Verde, United Kingdom, France, Brazil, Russian Federation, Japan, Spain and the United States.

The Security Council meets this afternoon to consider the situation in Liberia.

Before the Council is a further report from the Secretary-General regarding the United Nations role in implementing the Agreement signed by the Liberian parties in Cotonou, Benin, on 25 July, following peace talks held at Geneva from 10 to 17 July. In the report (document S/26200), the Secretary-General states his intention to commence planning for the dispatch to Liberia as soon as possible of an advance team of United Nations observers to monitor and verify provisions of the Agreement related to a cease-fire and the cessation of hostilities. He also intends immediately to send a technical team to draw up detailed plans for the establishment of a United Nations observer mission there.

The Agreement provides that a cease-fire and the cessation of hostilities would take effect seven days from the date on which the Agreement was signed, that is on 1 August, says the report. The Cease-fire Monitoring Group (ECOMOG) of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) would supervise and carry out the implementation of the Agreement, while monitoring and verification would be effected by the United Nations. To ensure against any violation of the cease-fire between 1 August and the arrival of the additional ECOMOG troops and the main body of United Nations observers, the parties agreed to establish a Joint Cease-fire Monitoring Committee, comprising representatives of the three Liberian parties -- the Interim Government of National Unity (IGNU), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the United Liberation Movement for Democracy in Liberia (ULIMO) -- as well as ECOMOG and the United Nations, which would also chair the Committee. The report adds that during the initial period, the United Nations has undertaken to consider dispatching 30 military observers to Liberia to participate in the work of the Joint Committee.

The parties also agreed that there should be a single Liberian National Transition Government with legislative, executive and judicial branches, says the report. General and presidential elections are to take place within seven months from the signing of the Agreement. In response to a request by ECOWAS, the United Nations now stands ready to assist a reconstituted Electoral Commission in the organization and conduct of free and fair elections. The report stresses that the rapid expansion of humanitarian assistance activities throughout the country would be an essential component in implementing the Agreement, and states that a consolidated inter-agency appeal will be issued shortly outlining estimated requirements for Liberia.

According to the report, while it would be less than prudent to underestimate the remaining difficulties, the Agreement offers the hope that the violent and destructive civil war which has afflicted Liberia may at last be brought to an end.

Also before the Council was a draft resolution

(document S/26259), the text of which reads as follows:

"The Security Council,

"Recalling its resolution 813 (1993) of 26 March 1993,

"Welcoming the signing under the auspices of ECOWAS, on 25 July 1993, at Cotonou, Benin, of a Peace Agreement between the Interim Government of National Unity of Liberia (IGNU), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), and the United Liberation Movement for Democracy (ULIMO) (S/26272),

"Considering that the signing of the Peace Agreement constitutes a major achievement and an important contribution to the restoration of peace and security in Liberia and in this region of West Africa, and creates the opportunity to bring an end to the conflict,

"Taking note of the report of the Secretary-General dated 3 August 1993 (S/26200),

"1. Welcomes the decision of the Secretary-General to send a technical team to Liberia to gather and evaluate information relevant to the proposed establishment of a United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL);

"2. Approves the dispatch to Liberia as soon as possible of an advance team of thirty military observers to participate in the work of the Joint Cease-fire Monitoring Committee, including in particular to monitor, investigate and report cease-fire violations in conjunction with the said Committee, the mandate of said team to expire within three months;

"3. Looks forward to the report of the Secretary- General on the proposed establishment of UNOMIL, including in particular a detailed estimate of the cost and scope of this operation, a time-frame for its implementation, the projected conclusion of this operation, how to ensure coordination between UNOMIL and the peace-keeping forces of ECOWAS and their respective roles and responsibilities;

"4. Calls upon all parties to the conflict to respect and implement the cease-fire provided for in the Peace Agreement and to cooperate fully with the advance mission and ensure the safety of all United Nations personnel and all other peace-keeping and humanitarian personnel within Liberia;

"5. Urges the conclusion at the earliest possible stage of a status of mission agreement;

"6. Commends ECOWAS for its efforts to restore peace, security and stability in Liberia;

"7. Commends the Organization of African Unity (OAU) for its efforts in support of the peace process in Liberia;

"8. Decides to remain actively seized of this matter."

The President of the Council, MADELEINE K. ALBRIGHT

(United States), called the meeting to order at 4:40 p.m.

The PRESIDENT said she had received letters from the representatives of Benin, Egypt, Liberia and Nigeria requesting to be invited to participate in the discussion. There being no objection she invited the representative of Liberia to take a seat at the Council table and the representatives of Benin, Egypt and Nigeria to take seat's at the side of the Council chamber.

The PRESIDENT drew attention to the following

documents: further report of the Secretary-General on Liberia (document S/26200); text of a draft resolution (document S/26259); and letter dated 4 August from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Council (document S/26265). A letter dated 6 August from the Charge d'affaires ad interim of Benin addressed to the Secretary- General would be issued as (document S/26272).

G. BACCUS MATTHEWS, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Liberia, said the Cotonou Agreement was a victory for the Liberian people. By agreeing on a process beginning with the cessation of hostilities and leading to disarmament and free and fair elections, Liberians had decided on how political change would be brought about in their country. The Agreement was also a victory for the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and the United Nations. The successful implementation of the Cotonou Agreement would herald a new chapter in international cooperation for peace between the United Nations and a regional and sub-regional organization.

Since the signing of the Agreement, he said, the cease-fire was being fully observed. The parties were taking the steps to transform themselves into a Liberian National Transitional Government.

The adoption of the draft resolution before the Council, and its implementation, would prove a significant milestone on the road to peace, he said. A crucial concern was whether the United Nations would help Liberia to install the Transitional Government within the next 30 days concomitant, as the Agreement required, with the beginning of the comprehensive disarmament of combatants. The ECOWAS had requested funds to enable some African countries to provide reinforcement for ECOMOG. Those additional troops were urgently needed for the disarmament process. He appealed to the Council to consider that request from ECOWAS so that those countries which had declared a willingness to commit troops could secure the necessary funding.

The peace process in Liberia was at a delicate stage, he went on. For three and a half years, war, death and desolation had been visited upon the Liberian people. Today, peace was within reach, and every effort must be exerted to implement the Cotonou Agreement without delays. He appealed to the Council to support the people of Liberia, who, with one accord, were ready to march together to a peaceful and democratic future.

GEORGES A. WHANNOU (Benin) said the signing of the Agreement had resulted from the cooperation of the parties which had been fostered by the efforts of the United Nations. The cease-fire and the holding of elections were critical elements of the Agreement. Its humanitarian aspects, including the return of displaced persons, was also crucial.

Implementation of the Agreement would exemplify cooperation between the United Nations and regional organizations. The integration of Liberia into the ECOWAS through the establishment of peace and security there would benefit the region as a whole.

IBRAHIM A. GAMBARI (Nigeria) said that not since the Yamoussokro IV Accord had there been any settlement as comprehensive and crucial to the search for final peace in Liberia as the Cotonou Agreement. It clearly deserved the support of all interested parties in Liberia, as well as the international community. The draft resolution should be adopted unanimously as it represented a significant step in the efforts to achieve a peaceful resolution of the conflict which had persisted for several years. The draft resolution sought the implementation of the provisions of the Yamoussokro Accord which the ECOWAS countries and the parties to the conflict had long acknowledged as the best possible basis for creating lasting peace in Liberia. The setting up of a Joint Cease-Fire Monitoring Committee to be replaced subsequently by a United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) would go a long way in strengthening the peace process for which the States of the sub-region had an abiding commitment.

Despite the signing of the Cotonou agreement by all parties, Nigeria had no illusions that peace had dawned in Liberia, he cautioned. The international community must continue to exert its utmost efforts until peace was fully assured. With the active cooperation lately demonstrated between the United Nations, ECOWAS and the OAU, it had been possible to maintain close contact with all the parties involved in the crisis. In that situation, and with the determination of the Liberian people, there was hope for an end to the crisis. The international community and relevant agencies must not relent in their efforts to deliver humanitarian assistance to the needy and displaced people in Liberia who continued to suffer from the ravages of the civil war. The international community had a duty to continue to assist those people to rebuild their lives.

ROBLE OLHAYE (Djibouti) said he attached great significance to the draft resolution before the Council and supported wholeheartedly the dispatch of the advance team of military observers called for, signaling the inception of formal United Nations involvement in the resolution of the bloody and tragic conflict in Liberia.

The presence of the United Nations in Liberia would serve to lend acutely needed assurance to all the parties of the willingness of the international community to become involved in a fair and equitable resolution. The agreement was framed as a cooperative exercise by ECOWAS/ECOMOG and the United Nations, mirroring the complementary role each had played thus far under the lead of ECOWAS. It would serve as a shining example of regional and international division of labour in the maintenance of international peace and security.

The war had exacted a terrible toll on the Liberian people, he said, and, in addition to establishing peace, every effort needed to be made to quickly raise the follow of humanitarian assistance. Conditions must also be set which would allow the thousands of refugees and displaced people to return to their homes. That would not effectively take place until there was a lifting of the tight economic sanctions imposed by ECOWAS. For that to happen, the United Nations observer mission needed to be in place, and the cease-fire and disarmament processes begun without obstruction. "Clearly there is every incentive to move quickly", he said.

He welcomed the further enlargement of ECOMOG by drawing on new troops from ECOWAS and other OAU countries outside the West African region, he said. The United Nations observer force would provide critically needed credibility and transparency not only in cease-fire verification, but in the implementation of the encampment, disarmament and demobilization provisions of the Agreement. While ECOWAS and the United Nations had been instrumental in bringing the warring parties to the table, neither the United Nations nor ECOWAS had imposed a set of agreements on the parties. The peace plan was the product of the Liberians themselves, reflecting their earnest desire to halt the fighting. "It would be a cynical shame, a tragedy, if it were the intention of anyone to use this accord as a distraction to buy time to consolidate or re-equip", he said. By removing the weapons, demobilizing the troops, and sealing the borders, Liberia should be in a position to begin preparations for voter registration, elections and a truly representative government. The United Nations needed to be on hand to assist in that worthy venture, which would begin with 30 military observers, which might perhaps act as a pace-setter for an international effort to assist the reconstruction of Liberia.

MOHAMMED NACER BENJELLOUN-TOUIMI (Morocco) welcomed the signing of the Cotonou Agreement as a great contribution to resolving the conflict which had ravaged Liberia. He said the ECOWAS and United Nations efforts which had led to the Agreement's successful conclusion exemplified the principles embodied in Chapter VIII of the Charter. Such cooperation must continue to ensure successful implementation of the Agreement's provisions.

He further welcomed the Secretary-General's initiatives, including the dispatch of a technical team to Liberia and the establishment of a fund in support of countries contributing to the plan's implementation. Morocco fully supported the terms of the draft resolution and would vote in favour of it.

DIEGO ARRIA (Venezuela) said only time would reveal the will of the Liberian parties to follow up the Cotonou Agreement, which had been a great international achievement. Reviewing the Agreement's provisions, he noted the political aspects including provisions for elections. Liberia's situation was promising, he said, but violations of human rights should not be disregarded, as they had reached a monstrous dimension.

He praised the role of ECOWAS and ECOMOG in Liberia. The modalities used in El Salvador regarding the Truth Commission could also be used in Liberia, he said.

LI ZHAOXING (China) welcomed the signing of the Cotonou Agreement as a major contribution to the restoration of peace in Liberia and the sub-region of western Africa. The cease-fire achieved with the help of ECOWAS and the OAU and the beginning of the Agreement's implementation marked a good beginning in the peace process, he said.

He went on to stress that the achievement of genuine and lasting peace in Liberia depended on the cooperation of the conflicting parties with the United Nations and ECOWAS. They must adopt practical and effective measures to fulfill their commitments and must strictly observe the peace Agreement, so as to ensure a successful general election and create conditions for national reconciliation. China would vote in favour of the draft resolution.

It was hoped that the Secretary-General would send the advance group of 30 military observers as soon as possible to facilitate the peace process.

Africa and its people had great potential, he said. The people, after endless suffering caused by war, were striving to establish a peaceful environment, rebuild their homeland and develop their economy. Solving the conflict in Liberia would promote peace and stability in the subregion and in Africa as a whole.

JOSE LUIS JESUS (Cape Verde) said the conflict in liberia had been a major concern for the countries of the subregion. It had caused thousands of deaths, destroyed the economy of the country and spawned a serious humanitarian and refugee situation. All those involved must now work decisively towards achieving peace and stability in the country.

The Cotonou Agreement was a turning-point in the process of finding a lasting peaceful solution, he said. The Council had created the conditions for a meaningful United Nations contribution to a negotiated solution of the Liberian conflict. The future role of the United Nations would be crucial to the effective implementation of the Liberian peace Agreement.

The proposed UNOMIL seemed to be a sine qua non condition for the successful implementation of the Cotonou Agreement, he went on to say. The UNOMIL must be deployed in a timely manner. The timely dispatch of an advance team of 30 military observers to participate in the work of the Joint Cease-fire Monitoring Committee was also important. The Secretary-General should set up a trust fund to assist ECOMOG contributing countries and potential contributing countries to cope with expenses resulting from their peace- keeping role. All those in a position to do so should contribute to that fund.

Concern arose, he said, over the humanitarian situation in Liberia. Every effort should be made to guarantee that all those in need had access to humanitarian assistance. He commended ECOWAS and the Secretary-General's Special Representative for their vital contribution to the successful conclusion of the Agreement.

The draft resolution was adopted unanimously as Council resolution 856 (1993)

TOM RICHARDSON (United Kingdom), speaking after the vote, welcomed the Agreement reached at Cotonou on 25 July, and said the resolution just adopted was testimony to the efforts of ECOWAS to resolve a conflict that had claimed 150,000 lives, wrought terrible damage on Liberia and brought instability to its neighbours, such as Sierra Leone. He recalled, however, that previous agreements had failed to last. The new ingredients introduced this time were a clear determination of the parties to the conflict to end the tragedy inside Liberia and the willingness of the international community to provide active support to the peace process.

The signature of the Cotonou Agreement was only the beginning, not the end, of the peace process, he said. All parties should seize the opportunity for peace and cooperate fully in its implementation. As a first step, it was vital that the cease-fire should hold. The United Kingdom was therefore pleased to support the dispatch of a group of 30 observers for the Cease-fire Committee.

For that process to move further forward and proceed to elections, and a new government, he said, it was evident that the ECOWAS regional force, ECOMOG, would have a continued crucial role in maintaining internal security. He strongly supported ECOMOG's efforts so far in very difficult circumstances. The proposals put forward at Cotonou to widen the circle of contributors, and to supplement ECOMOG with United Nations observers, were a valuable opportunity to build confidence. He looked forward to a report from the Secretary-General on how UNOMIL might best be deployed.

The ending of the conflict would reveal the full extent of the damage caused to Liberia, he said. However, it was already clear that the need for humanitarian relief and, in the longer term, for reconstruction, would be considerable. The United Kingdom would continue to provide humanitarian relief -- both bilaterally and through the European Community -- and looked forward to consulting with Community partners on Liberia's other needs.

JEAN-BERNARD MERIMEE (France) welcomed the signing of the Agreement which put an end to a deadly conflict and commended the ECOWAS, the OAU and the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for their efforts. Such cooperation, he said, was the realization of the principles embodied in Chapter VIII of the Charter. The UNOMIL would be the first peace-keeping operation made up of troops of both the United Nations and a regional organization. The tasks and budgets of the two organizations must be strictly divided appropriately. The United Nations troops must be funded through assessed contributions, while the others must be supported by voluntary contributions.

He expressed concern over obstacles to the delivery of humanitarian aid, especially the blockages occurring at the border between Liberia and Cote d'Ivoire, despite the call of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) for free access. Access must be restored and a process must be established for verifying the humanitarian nature of the convoys, he said.

Welcoming the Council's action, he said commensurate attention should be paid to an equally critical conflict -- the one in Rwanda.

RONALDO MOTA SARDENBERG (Brazil) said the signing of the Cotonou Agreement constituted a major achievement and strengthened hopes for the complete end of the tragic civil strife afflicting that country. It was encouraging that the efforts made both by ECOWAS and by the Special Representative of the Secretary-General had met with a commitment of the warring factions to reach a settlement conducive to national conciliation and to the reconstruction of Liberia. The international community should cooperate with the humanitarian assistance efforts to be carried out by the United Nations and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), with a view to creating conditions for the smooth implementation of the peace Agreement.

He commended ECOWAS for its untiring efforts under extremely difficult conditions towards the restoration of peace and stability in Liberia. He looked forward to receiving the report of the Secretary-General, in particular with regard to the parameters for the future cooperation between ECOWAS and the proposed United Nations military observer operation in Liberia. By ensuring greater efficiency in the implementation of the Cotonou Agreement, such cooperation would serve as an example for future undertakings between the United Nations and other regional organizations, in accordance with Chapter VIII of the Charter.

YULIY M. VORONTSOV (Russian Federation) welcomed the signing of the Agreement and called on the parties to adhere to its provisions. The contribution of ECOWAS to the peaceful settlement of the conflict demonstrated the ability of Africa to resolve its own problems. Dialogue was the most important element in achieving peace. His country stood ready to support the Agreement as well as future initiatives aimed at restoring peace in Africa.

YOSHIO HATANO (Japan) stressed that the advance team of military observers must be dispatched as soon as possible. It would be critical to ensure close coordination between ECOWAS and the United Nations. The provision of humanitarian aid was a primary concern at the present stage. Japan had made a recent contribution to relieving the plight of refugees from the Liberian conflict. It had done so in the firm belief that the achievement of lasting peace would depend on the restoration of the economic and social stability of Liberia.

ANTONIO PEDAUYE (Spain) welcomed the signing of the Cotonou Agreement and the example provided of cooperation between regional organizations and the United Nations. He supported the dispatch of military observers as well as of a technical team to Liberia.

He went on to say that the Council should remain vigilant as the situation in Liberia was delicate, and he appealed to all parties to contribute to a successful outcome of the process which had started in Cotonou.

Speaking as her country's representative, Ms. ALBRIGHT (United States) welcomed the Council's decision to dispatch an advance team of monitors to Liberia to participate in the monitoring of the cease-fire. She noted that the cease-fire had taken effect on 1 August and urged that the advance team be sent as quickly as possible to reinforce the cease-fire and increase the confidence of the Liberian parties in the international monitoring effort.

She appealed to the Liberian parties, and especially to the NPFL, to honour the commitment they had made in the Agreement to allow humanitarian relief deliveries to reach all areas of Liberia via the most direct route, including from Monrovia. According to international relief organizations, delays in the delivery of much-needed relief put thousands of displaced persons, especially in lower Bong county, at risk of starvation. In view of the deteriorating humanitarian situation in the interior of the country, she also urged the United Nations, on an urgent basis, to find some mechanism to allow cross-border relief shipments from Cote d'Ivoire and Guinea to resume until such time as the full observer contingent referred to in the peace agreement might arrive. She noted that the Secretary-General's report mentioned an ECOWAS request for the establishment of a United Nations trust fund in support of the expanded ECOMOG peace-keeping force needed to implement the peace agreement. She encouraged the Secretary-General to seriously consider setting up such a trust fund to facilitate the collection of international contributions to the ECOWAS/ECOMOG peace- keeping effort.

The United States, she went on, had provided over $28 million to ECOWAS and its member States in the last three years in support of the ECOMOG peace-keeping operation in Liberia. It would continue to assist ECOMOG as it stepped up its activities to implement the Agreement and encouraged other members of the international community to do so as well. She appealed to the signatories to the Agreement to stand by the commitments made in it and to work with ECOWAS and the United Nations to implement it fairly and expeditiously so that the suffering of the Liberian people would end and reconciliation would begin.

The meeting was adjourned at 5:47 p.m. --30EXTRAJUDICIAL EXECUTIONS IN NIGERIA


LOAD-DATE: August 24, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

192 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


AUGUST 23, 1993


UNITED NATIONS OBSERVER MISSION UGANDA-RWANDA


BYLINE: United Nations Information Centre


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

BACKGROUND Aug 11, 1993 -- Fighting between the Armed Forces of the Government of Rwanda and the Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) first broke out in October 1990 across the border between Rwanda and its northern neighbour, Uganda. Despite a number of cease-fire agreements thereafter, hostilities resumed in the northern part of the country in early February 1993. These interrupted comprehensive negotiations between the Government of Rwanda and RPF, supported by the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and facilitated by the United Republic of Tanzania. In support of resumption of the negotiations, Rwanda and Uganda, in separate letters to the President of the Security Council on 22 February 1993, called for the deployment of United Nations military observers along the 150-kilometre common border in order to prevent the military use of the area, especially the transportation of military supplies. RPF control of the border has been extensive.

Following consultations in the Security Council on 24 February concerning these letters, the Secretary-General decided to send a goodwill mission to Rwanda and Uganda. He instructed it to examine all major aspects of the peace process including the possibility of deploying military observers along the border. The goodwill mission carried out this mandate during 4-18 March 1993. 

Meanwhile, efforts by OAU and Tanzania led to a meeting between the Government of Rwanda and RPF from 5 to 7 March at Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania. In a closing joint communique, the Government of Rwanda and RPF pledged their commitment to a negotiated settlement and agreed to reinstate the cease-fire on 9 March and to the resumption of peace talks in Arusha, Tanzania. They also committed themselves to providing adequate security and protection to displaced persons. On 12 March 1993, the Security Council, by its resolution 812 (1993), called on the Government of Rwanda and RPF to respect the renewed cease- fire, to resume negotiations, to allow the delivery of humanitarian supplies and the return of displaced persons, and to fulfil the obligations and commitments the parties had made in the past. The Council also welcomed the goodwill mission the Secretary-General had sent to Rwanda and Uganda. Finally, it asked him to examine the requests of those two countries for the deployment of observers along their common border. Following the adoption of the Council resolution, the Secretary-General sent a technical mission to assess the concept of military observers. It visited Uganda from 2 to 5 April and Rwanda on 6 April. The mission reported that it would be possible to deploy United Nations military observers to monitor the border between Uganda and Rwanda and verify that no military assistance --lethal weapons, ammunition and other material of possible military use -- was being provided across it. It was decided that deployment of the observers would be on the Uganda side of the border only.

SECURITY COUNCIL AUTHORIZES ESTABLISHMENT OF OBSERVER MISSION

On 22 June 1993, the Security Council, by its resolution 846 (1993), authorized the establishment of the United Nations Observer Mission Uganda-Rwanda (UNOMUR) on the Uganda side of the common border, for an initial period of up to six months. The duration of the mission is subject to review, following the conclusion of the Arusha talks (see peace talks in arusha below). The Council decided that the verification would focus primarily on transit or transport, by roads or tracks which could accommodate vehicles, of lethal weapons and ammunition across the border, as well as any other material which could be of military use.

The Council requested the Secretary-General to conclude a status of mission agreement with the Government of Uganda which would include assurance of safety, cooperation and support of the Mission by Uganda. The authorized strength of UNOMUR is 81 military observers, 17 international and seven local civilian support staff.

UNOMUR is to be headed by Brigadier-General Romeo A. Dallaire of Canada as Chief Military Observer, reporting to the Secretary-General. All matters affecting the nature or the continued effective functioning of the mission would be referred to the Security Council for its decision. The Council also welcomed the Secretary-General's decision to support the peace efforts of OAU by putting two military experts at its disposal to help expedite the deployment of OAU's neutral military observer group to Rwanda. The Secretary-General was requested to report on the contribution the United Nations could make to assist OAU in implementing the peace agreement and to begin contingency planning in the event that the Council decided that such a contribution was needed. The Secretary-General estimates that the cost of the Observer Mission would amount to some $8,500,000 for an initial six-month period. The costs of the Mission are to be met by the assessed contributions of United Nations Member States.

PEACE TALKS IN ARUSHA

In a related development, Mr. Macaire Pedanou, head of the United Nations goodwill mission remained in Tanzania to observe, on behalf of the Secretary-General, the Arusha talks on a comprehensive peace agreement between the Government of Rwanda and RPF. These had reconvened on 16 March 1993. The talks cover military issues, refugees and displaced persons, and outstanding political matters, including the amendment of the constitution, as well as the duration of the transitional period. Early in the talks the parties also began to discuss an international neutral force to oversee the implementation of key aspects of the peace agreement and to create confidence during the transition period.

In a joint request to the Security Council from Arusha on 11 June, the two parties called on the United Nations to send a reconnaissance mission to Rwanda as speedily as possible. This mission would prepare for the quick deployment of a neutral international force as soon as the peace agreement under negotiation was signed. The request welcomed the decision made in consultations between the United Nations and OAU that the United Nations should assume responsibility for and command of such a force. The parties asked that the force should guarantee public security, especially for the delivery of humanitarian aid. It would also assist in searches for weapons caches, neutralization of armed bands, demining, civilian disarmament and the cessation of hostilities. The parties also requested that the international force oversee the demobilization of existing armed forces and of all aspects of the formation of the new National Army and National Gendarmerie. On 4 August 1993, the Government of Rwanda and RPF signed the peace agreement.

HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE

On 15 April 1993, the United Nations launched an inter-agency appeal for international assistance covering a period from April to December 1993 amounting to $78 million to meet the needs of over 900,000 war-displaced people, or approximately 13 per cent of the nation's population. The appeal was the result of a request by the President of Rwanda to the Secretary-General earlier in 1993 following a three-fold increase in the number of the displaced persons whose emergency needs had overwhelmed the local capacity to supply them. Most of the displaced were living in and around 30 camps where serious malnutrition and disease were prevalent. The situation was exacerbated by Rwanda's already precarious economic condition, overpopulation and rapidly declining agricultural production. An inter-agency mission, led by the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA), was fielded between 18 and 25 March to prepare a consolidated appeal with all concerned United Nations agencies. The appeal presents priority emergency relief projects focusing on food, nutrition, health, water and sanitation, shelter and household items and education. The projects would be undertaken singly or jointly by the World Food Programme, the United Nations Children's Fund, the World Health Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, the United Nations Development Programme and DHA, in close collaboration with Governments, the International Committee of the Red Cross and non-governmental organizations. Following the signing of the Kinihira agreement of 30 May 1993 between the Government of Rwanda and RPF on the return and the resettlement of the displaced persons to the demilitarized zone in northern Rwanda, an estimated 500,000 displaced people have returned home. These movements have led to the closing of several camps for the displaced and the emphasis of the humanitarian assistance efforts has shifted to meeting the needs of displaced returning home.

Published by the United Nations Department of Public Information United Nations Information Centre -30SECURITY COUNCIL APPROVES DISPATCH OF ADVANCE MILITARY

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. Africa News


September 9, 1993


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 480 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

* High voltage lab. A.I.D. CIP Grant # 263-K-620/627.

Purchaser: Menoufia University, Faculty of Engineering, Shebeen El Koum, Cairo, Egypt. Fax and phone offers will not 

be accepted. BID OPENING DATE: October 20. A single copy of the IFB, including all terms and specifications may be obtained by written request. Enclose a check or money order for US $20, payable to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

* Laboratory Instruments and Supplies. A.I.D. CIP Grant

# 263-0176. RFQ. #: 263-035PP3 (2). Purchasing Agent:

EduSystems, Inc. Attn: Cyndy Christian, 2P.O. Box 1030,

Walworth, WI 53184-1030; phone: (414) 275-5761. Fax and phone

offers will not be accepted. BID OPENING DATE: October 5. A single copy of the IFB, including all terms and specifications may be obtained by written request. Enclose a check or money order for US $15, payable to EduSystems at the above address. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

* Air Filters. CIP Grant # 263-K-624; IFB #EEA/17Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts

93/ARE. Purchasing Agent: Egyptian Electric Authority, c/o Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. Fax and phone offers will

not be accepted. BID OPENING DATE: October 4. A single copy of the IFB, including all terms and specifications may be obtained by written request. Enclose a check or money order for US $20, payable to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt.

* Overhead Conductor Accessories. AID Grant # 263-0194;

IFB #217841-05. Purchasing Agent: Black & Veatch

International, P.O. Box 8405, Kansas City, MO 64116; phone: (913) 339-7475; fax (913) 339-2288. Fax and phone offers will

not be accepted. DEADLINE: September 15. A single copy of the IFB, including all terms and specifications may be obtained by written request. Enclose a check or money order for US $50, payable to Black & Veatch International, Inc.

Africa News


September 9, 1993


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

An 18-day "Reality Tour" of Zimbabwe and Malawi is offered by Robyn Michaels, a former Peace Corps volunteer in conjunction with Classic Tours International. Urban areas and markets, development projects and the planning office in Blantyre, Malawi are on the itinerary; and in Zimbabwe, tourist will visit, Bulawayo, Hwange National Park and Victoria Falls. For an additional charge of $550, Nairobi and Mombasa in Kenya may be added. Travelers will need shots, anti-malarial prophylaxsis and a sleeping bag. An initial deposit of $1,000 is required by OCTOBER 15, 1993 for the tour, which is scheduled for January 19, 1994. Final payment is required by December 15, 1993. For more information, contact Paul Carpenter, Classic Tours International, 520 N. Michigan

Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611; phone: (312) 329-1234 or (800) 828Wayne, Chicago, IL 60626; phone; (312) 973-3663 

8222; fax: (312) 642-8418; or call Robyn Michaels, 6916 N. MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may

be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI

48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply.

DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the

dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first ten years

of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE: December 1, 1993.

Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York,

NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896. The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions compete in two separate

categories for funding: (1) Non-research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category. The application deadline is

November 1. To request guidelines and proposal forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008-3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. It is recommended that all institutions contact the appropriate CIES program officer for the scholar-in-residence program for advice, referral and assistance before preparing proposals. For Sub- Saharan Africa, contact Linda Rhoad at (202) 686-6230. For North Africa, contact Gary Garrison at (202) 686-4019. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini- conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more

information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Food for the Hungry seeks a CHIEF LOGISTICS MANAGER to be based in Beira, Mozambique. The position is responsible for the receipt, storage accounting, transport and monitoring of all FHI commodities and is also responsible for all international procurement and local procurement when in bulk.

QUALIFICATIONS: 1-2 years of relief development experience, preferably in Africa. Some degree of proficiency in Portuguese or Spanish. Must be willing to apply biblical principals to development work and be in agreement with Food for the 

Hungry's Christian philosophy and practice. DEADLINE:

SEPTEMBER 30, 1993. Contact: Scott Allen, recruitment coordinator, Food for the Hungry, 7729 East Greenway Road,

Scottsdale AZ, 85260; phone: (800) 2-HUNGER.

Peace Corps of the United States has the following

positions available:

TRAINING DIRECTORS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as training director for pre-service training in various countries. Contract are to

begin in April, May or June 1994. QUALIFICATIONS: extensive Peace Corps training experience coordinating pre-service training activities, although similar experience in an international development organization will be considered; organizational and management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; crisis management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledge about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. For more information, contact Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W.,

Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

HEALTH TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Health Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in

Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in primary health care or maternal and child health education in West Africa; prior experience designing primary health care training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MPH or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter- cultural team of trainers; knowledgable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess

and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region,

1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Africa. and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region,

197 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer- to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376,

Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following 

nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and December,

1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December

1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery.

Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December 1993

and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated

Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered):

October-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered;

January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box

65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA

30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Taoufik BEN ABDALLAH and Philippe ENGELHARD, The Urgency of

Fighting Poverty for Democracy and the Environment. Geneva: United Nations Non-Governmental Liaison Service (Palais des Nations, 1211, Geneva 10, Switzerland), 1993. 23 pp.

Examines the interlinkages between poverty, democracy and the environment and how the dynamics affect international relations. (In English and French.) Cynthia CROSBY, Historical Dictionary of Malawi, Second 

Edition. Metuchen: Scarecrow Press, Inc. (P.O. Box 4167, 52 Liberty Street, Metuchen, NJ 08840), 1993. $30.00 (cloth). 243 pp.

Reference guide to the economics, politics, social order and history of Malawi.

Hans D'ORVILLE, The Search for Global Order. New York: InterAction Council (821 UN Plaza, Room 701, New York, NY 10017), 1993. 362 pp.

Proceeds of a 1991 InterAction meeting on the global challenges of population, poverty, the environment, mass migrations and arms proliferation. Robert GOODLAND, Herman DALY, and Salah El SERAFY et. al.,

eds., Environmentally Sustainable Development: Building on

Brundtland. Lanham: UNIPUB (4611-F Assembly Drive, Lanham, MD 20706-4391), 1991. $13.00 (paper). 100 pp.

Presents theories on how future economic trends and development will affect the North-South relationship. Tony HODGES, Angola to 2000 -- Prospect for Recovery. New

York: The Economist Intelligence Unit (215 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10003), 1993. $450.00 (paper). 170 pp.

Comprehensive examination of the country's recent history of war, political activity and economic circumstances.

Gordon S. JACKSON, Breaking Story: The South African Press.

Boulder: Westview Press (5500 Central Ave., Boulder, CO 80301), 1993. $34.95 (cloth). 308 pp.

A look at the role of the South African press and its influence on apartheid since the 1976 Soweto uprising.

Carol J. LANCASTER, United States and Africa: Into the TwentyConnecticut Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20009), 1993. $9.95

First Century. Washington: Overseas Development Council (1875 (paper). 61 pp.

A review of the major economic and political trends in the region and what role the U.S. might play in the continent's future.

Olusegun OBASANJO and Felix G.N. MOSHA, eds., Africa: Rise to the Challenge -- Towards a Conference on Security, Stability,

Development and Cooperation in Africa (CSSDCA). New York: Africa Leadership Forum (821 UN Plaza, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10017), 1992. 433. pp.

Collection of background papers, issue papers and speeches from OAU summit participants.

Rakiya OMAAR and Alex DE WAAL, Somalia: Human Rights Abuses by

the United Nations Forces. London: African Rights (11 Marshalsea Road, London SE1 1EP, United Kingdom), 1993. 35 pp.

Report on human rights violations in Somalia, including Mogadishu, Kismayo and Belet Weyn. John RAPLEY, Ivorien Capitalism -- African Entrepeneurs in

Cote d'Ivoire. Boulder: Lynne Rienner Publishers, Inc. (1800 30th Street, Suite 314, Boulder, CO 80301), 1993. $35.00 (cloth). 197 pp.

A study of the development of capitalism in Cote d'Ivoire. Jasjit SINGH and Thomas BERNAUER, Security of Third World

Countries. Brookfield: Ashgate Publishing Company (Old Post Road, Brookfield, VT 05036-9704), 1993. $56.95 (cloth). 168 pp.

A study of the conflicts and pressure in the developing world that contribute to global instability in terms of security risks.

Alex VINES, One Hand Tied: Angola and the UN. London: Catholic Institute for International Relations (Unit 3, Canonbury Yard, 190a New North Road, London N1 7BJ, United Kingdom), 1993. 46 pp.

Analysis of the current political players, the recent elections and the emergency situation in Angola.

PLANNING AHEAD


LENGTH: 387 words


 

February 3-5, 1994 Miami, FL -- Conference "The Eleventh Annual Intercultural/International Communication Conference" Deadline for papers and panel abstracts is October 1, 1993.

Contact: Dr. Mitchell E. Shapiro, conference director or Susanne Miller, conference coordinator, University of Miami School of Communication, Graduate Studies Office, P.O. Box

248127, Coral Gables, FL 33124; phone: (305) 284-5236; fax: (305) 284-3648. April, 21-24, 1994 Providence, RI -- Meeting

"The Sudan: History, Politi, and Identity in a Time of Crisis" Deadline for papers and panel abstracts is November 30, 1993.
