Africa News


September 9, 1993


EMERGENCY TRUCK FLEET RE-DEPLOYED TO RWANDA


LENGTH: 814 words


 

World Food Programme NAIROBI, AUGUST 31, 1993 -- The World Food Programme today re- deployed the major part of its trucking fleet in Somalia to its emergency programme in Rwanda. The fleet, jointly operated by WFP and the governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea, has completed most of its work in Somalia and is urgently needed in Rwanda.

Thirty-two long-haul trucks and 25 trailers which arrived in Mombasa from Mogadishu on 16 August left Mombasa for Rwanda today with 564 metric tonnes of sugar and vegetable oil. They will be used to ferry some 6,000 tonnes of relief food per month from Kampala directly to people in displaced camps in Rwanda, including those in the demilitarized zone. 

The WFP fleet will provide greater flexibility and cost efficiency. To date, WFP has been using private trucks to deliver relief food from Kampala, but security constraints have prevented truckers from delivering relief food directly to areas like Ruhengeri. Instead, cargo has had to be transported to Kigali, where private Rwandan trucks hired by ICRC as well as ICRC's own trucks have taken over the delivery to regional centers.

WFP recently reached an agreement with the Government of Rwanda to allow trucks arriving from Uganda and Tanzania to clear customs at two regional centers, instead of first stopping in Kigali. This agreement applies to both WFP's fleet and private trucks hired by the Programme.

According to the WFP, using its own trucks will result in net savings in transport of about USD 150,000 per month. Extra handling and storage costs will also be saved by eliminating the need to stop in Kigali. Direct delivery to displaced people camps will ensure that beneficiaries receive emergency food supplies much quicker.

This component of the WFP trucking fleet was originally re-deployed to Mogadishu in December 1992 from WFP's operations in Ethiopia and Eritrea, where for the last eight years, the Programme has run the largest UN relief transport fleet in the world, delivering more than 2.4 million tonnes of food.

The decision to bring the trucks to Somalia in December 1992 was based on the urgent need for a reliable fleet for long-haul trucking of relief food to towns like Baidoa, Berdera and Huddour in the interior of Somalia. As part of the international humanitarian effort, the governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea consented to moving the trucks to Somalia.

Now that the situation in Somalia had shifted from emergency to rehabilitation and reconstruction, once more the government of Ethiopia met WFP's request to temporarily re- deploy the fleet to Rwanda as a sign of solidarity for the current international relief effort.

The remainder of the WFP fleet in Somalia, 17 trucks, will return to Eritrea in the near future.

Although the food pipeline to Rwanda has greatly improved in recent months, the food security of the estimated 900,000 displaced people remains of utmost concern. NGOs in some of the displaced people camps are reporting high rates of death caused by malaria, diarrhea and malnutrition.

While WFP -- the food aid organization of the United Nations System -- has been taking extraordinary measures to deliver large amounts of relief food into Rwanda, the last few months have seen persistent problems in ensuring proper food distribution at the camp level. WFP, together with ICRC -- the agency responsible for the distribution of relief food -- continues to work closely with the government of Rwanda to resolve the issue of inflated beneficiary lists and diversion of food aid.

During the height of the Rwanda emergency, which began in February 1993, WFP launched a massive airlift out of Entebbe, delivering more than 26,000 tonnes of food to Kigali. This helped avert a major catastrophe. This airlift was terminated in July when WFP negotiated the re-opening and use of the Katuna border crossing from Uganda, a faster and more direct route than the one that crossed through Tanzania. -30- For more information, contact Brenda Barton, regional

information officer; phone: 264-2-230-807 or Joseph Kabore,

director of operations, WFP Kigali; phone: 250-763-68.


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


WFP DISCONTINUES TWO MORE AIRLIFTS AS ROADS TO CAIA AND MARINGUE ARE OPENED


LENGTH: 960 words


 

World Food Programme

MAPUTO, SEPTEMBER 1 --As the roads to Caia and Maringue in Sofala province have finally been opened to overland convoys, the World Food Programme has replaced two more costly airlifts in Mozambique. Peace means that the country's network of roads is being used again; not only food aid, but also traders and peasants who are resettling move along the rutted dirt roads.

Last week, WFP sent three convoys from Beira to Caia carrying a total of 170 tonnes of food while the previous week another convoy took 65 tonnes of food from Beira to Maringue via Macossa.

WFP is now doing only one airlift in Mozambique, delivering a monthly 15 tonnes for 1,000 people in isolated Casa Banana, at a cost of slightly under US$400 per tonne. Because road transport can cut delivery costs by at least two thirds, WFP is funding the repairs on the road from Gorongosa to Casa Banana. The airlift will be discontinued as soon as the road is opened. 

"Sending food by road is a much cheaper alternative and allows us to use money for other purposes, such as rebuilding bridges and repairing roads." said Philip Clarke, WFP Director of Operations in Mozambique. "The country's shattered infrastructure certainly needs all the help it can get."

Road access in Nampula and Niassa provinces is also improving, allowing more efficient food deliveries. In Zambezia province, WFP opened many roads that had been out of use since the mid-1980s. To deliver food, WFP has gotten trenches filled, bush cleared, logs removed and wooden bridges built, often with the spontaneous help of local people who wanted the food to get through.

The road to Caia winds its way through Dondo and Inhaminga, a formerly important railway junction that was cut off from the outside world since 1986. The Dondo-Inhaminga leg was opened by WFP in January 1992, although the first WFP convoy found several unexploded antitank mines along this route. WFP has been using the road Beira-Dondo-Inhaminga regularly while airlifting food supplies to Caia and waiting for the Inhaminga-Caia leg to be demined.

WFP is now exploring the possibility of using Caia as a depot and starting point for food deliveries to localities along the Zambezi river. With the rainy season approaching and roads becoming impassable, sending food upriver by boats and barges makes sense. To do this, the Zambezi must first be sounded and its river ports re-equipped.

From 2-29 August, the WFP Logistics Unit (UNILOG) delivered nearly 6,000 tonnes of food, mainly to other aid agencies or organizations that carry out the final distribution to needy people. These include the Mozambican Red Cross, World Vision, Food for the Hungry, UNHCR, DPCCN and Renamo.

At the height of the relief effort, in March 1993, before the good harvest came in, UNILOG was delivering 19,000 tonnes a month and five localities were served by airlifts.

Thanks to the combination of peace and good rains, there has been a dramatic drop in the amount of food aid needed in Mozambique. In 1992/93, because of drought and war, WFP was providing food for 3.8 million people. This year, WFP estimates that 1.1 million displaced Mozambicans need food aid --and many only until the next harvest.

All over the country, hundreds of thousands of peasants are resettling, opening "machambas" or plots, clearing bush, preparing the land, building mud-and-poles huts and growing their own food.

To the 1.1 million displaced should be added the 300,000 refugees who so far have returned spontaneously from Malawi and who also need food aid until they become self-sufficient.

It is expected that more refugees will return from neighbouring countries as the planting season (October/November) approaches, with an estimated 700,000 returnees back in the country by April 1994. To provide these people with food, WFP has signed agreements with UNHCR, the Mozambican Red Cross and World Vision, who will distribute WFP food in eight of Mozambique's ten provinces, where returnees are expected to arrive.

Because of the influx of returnees and because rural household food stocks are being consumed and the hungry season is setting in, the monthly emergency food needs are increasing in certain areas. WFP estimates that the monthly requirement will increase slowly from the current 28,000 tonnes up to a maximum of 34,000 tonnes during April 1994, just before the harvest, and then drop again, in comparison, monthly requirements were 45,000 tonnes in 1992 -30Director of Operations, Maputo; phone (258-1) 49 3217/18 - 49

For more information, please contact: Philip Clarke, WFP 4080/81 or Mercedes Sayagues, WFP Regional Information Officer, Harare, phone (263-4) 739984


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


HUNGER, SUFFERING AND DEATH IN ANGOLA


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

World Food Programme August 25, 1993 -- As the tide has changed in Angola, so has the situation for its civilian population -- for the worse. War is hurting badly not only people displaced by war and those in besieged towns; it is also hurting the population in secure Government-held cities. Poor residents of Luanda, Lobito and Benguela are feeling the brunt of the war as very little food is available and only at painfully high prices. Malnutrition rates are increasing alarmingly, especially among children, to the point that Unicef is declaring a nutritional emergency (more than 10 percent of children with serious or acute malnutrition) in many areas of these towns.

Interprovincial trade has collapsed; there is minimal commercial activity and very little food available in city markets. What is available is not accessible. With the kwanza worth NK 45,000 = US$1, a low-level government employee earns NK300,000 kwanzas a month, or about US$7. The official minimum monthly salary is NK120,000. A 50 kg bag of maize costs more than one million kwanzas; a 50kg bag of potatoes costs two million kwanzas.

It is not surprising to find in the "bairros" (neighborhoods) of Lobito extremely thin and hungry children, their bones sticking out underneath their rags. Paradoxically, displaced people in camps in major cities are better off than poor residents because a lot of NGOs and aid agencies are active in the camps. 

This is why WFP has redirected its policy of giving priority to food deliveries in rural areas, besieged towns and displaced people who are directly affected by war. It was thought that residents of the larger cities would have access to food in the markets. But inflation and the collapse of the marketing system have put food out of the reach of the poor and even of those earning salaries.

For this reason, in Lobito and Benguela, WPF is now supporting soup kitchens for residents (see Lobito/Benguela for more information). In Luanda, WPF provides food for the operation of many NGOs and the Ministry of Social Affairs (MINARS) (see Luanda/Sumbe section).

The worsening situation is not confined to cities. Although information from rural areas is sketchy and there are large "grey zones" of which little is known, reports are filtering in. There are pockets of critical malnutrition along the border with Zambia. Brazzaville reports that refugees escaping from Cabinda suffer from severe malaria and serious malnutrition. In Mavinga and Jamba, local authorities report they have no chloroquine to treat malaria patients. Lack of vitamin A is most severs among children under five in peri- urban areas and in camps for displaced people. The lack of salt is severe all over Angola, except in the coastal areas. Salt is precious in the central highlands or "planalto" and not only for cooking -- lack of iodine causes goitre and mental retardation.

Unicef has estimated that 4,000 children die every month -- a conservative estimate, said its head in Luanda last week. Of these deaths, 25 percent would be directly attributable to fighting. Also, according to Unicef, the mortality of under fives has jumped to 292 per live births -- the highest in the world. That rate had decreased to 173 per 1,000 live births during the time of peace up to the elections. It is estimated that some 250,000 children have become orphans or have lost contact with their parents. The number of street children has risen dramatically.

FOOD DELIVERIES

Although official WFP relief flight to inland destinations have not resumed, WFP is able to move a significant volume of food for needy people in municipalities along the coast.

It should be noted that, although the Government controls thin slices of territory, those areas have the largest concentrations of people -- and they keep arriving into towns. Aid officials in Luanda estimate that the capital's population may well top 2.5 million by now; the overcrowding is obvious, with the attending unsanitary conditions in a city that has poor sewage and lacks water and electricity daily. A figure of 25 people per household is not unusual. The triad of Lobito, Benguela and Katumbela may have two million people, as tens of thousands have fled from Huambo, Gana and Cubal and from the northern road to Huambo.

In August, WFP is distributing nearly 8,000 tonnes, enough to feed more than half a million people. Most of it is delivered by land but, since NGOs and MINARS began flying to inland destinations last week, more deliveries have been made by air. This allows for a substantial increase in deliveries to isolated cities. In just one week (23-27 August), WFP has provided 761 tonnes of food for the relief flights carried out by the Lutheran World Federation and MINARS to Luena, Saurimo and Malange. In the week of 16-21 August, Caritas and LWF flew WPF food to Luena, Saurimo, Dundo and Cabinda. Caritas is now undertaking an initial 12 flights to Uige, a city under Unita control. According to the bishop of Uige, his town receives

requests for food from three neighboring provinces: Uige, Bengo and Malange. To meet these needs, food will be trucked from Uige to N'dalatando, Negage and the west of Malange province.

Although information about the Unita-held countryside in the North is poor, it seems safe to assume that the combination of land mines and no access to markets means rural people are surviving on subsistence agriculture -- with the hungry season setting in.

Renewed fighting in the "planalto" is causing and will cause an influx of newly displaced people who will need assistance. WFP is considering several ways of doing this. One way is using the railway to Ganda, which is a much cheaper way of delivering food and could bring it at least halfway to Huambo. That entails repairing the railway and clearing it of mines. WFP plans to increase its monthly deliveries to 10,000 tonnes in September. Total stocks in-country as of 15 August are 22,040 tonnes. The Programme is replenishing its stocks and will have received an additional 63,000 tonnes by the end of September. Nine ships are calling on Lobito and Namibe until mid-September (when the hungry season is on), bringing food mostly donated by the U.S. and the EEC.

LUANDA/SUMBE/LUENA

In Luanda, WFP provides food for MINARS and several NGOs, reaching nearly 29,000 beneficiaries every fortnight. These include orphans and street children, patients in hospitals, (including cholera patients), amputees and displaced persons.

In Bengo province, WFP assistance includes, among others, food for the Caxito hospital and for and for two agricultural and tree-planting projects implemented by ADPP. WFP is providing food for 20,000 displaced in Dondo, distributed by World Vision, and for 14,200 displaced people from Cacuso who are assisted by Caritas and MINARS.

The WPF base in Sumbe reports fortnightly distributions of 434 tonnes of food through MINARS, Caritas and APN, reaching nearly 30,000 people.

Luana is looking much better than in May. Unita forces have been pushed some 50K away from the city. People have been assigned land. LWF has provided seeds and agricultural tools, and both residents and displaced are planting. LWF has opened a centre to treat scabies and the government has sent two doctors for the hospital.

LOBITO/BENGUELA

Both cities are swollen by tens of thousands of displaced people. Katumbela airfield is closed to relief flights so WFP is using the airport at Lobito. There is little food available; if there are surpluses of food from the few plots around Lobito, traders prefer to send it to Luanda where food fetches higher prices.

Through MINARS and NGOs such as Catholic Relief Services, Save the Children, ORA, AAA and Caritas, WFP is providing food for nearly 100,000 people. This includes about 46,000 persons displaced by war (32,000 are scattered through the cities, the rest live in camps); nearly 10,000 disabled persons and amputees, 500 orphans, elderly people and patients live in hospitals.

In addition, the soup kitchens recently opened in the poorest "bairros" of Lobito and Benguela reach 22,400 people. The kitchens are managed by NGOs and parishes or churches, and WFP requires some form of community involvement in their operation.

More kitchens are expected to open soon, reaching an additional 11,000 people in Lobito; 9,000 in Benguela, 3,000 in Catumbela; 4,350 in Anha do Norte and 4,400 in Biopio. The last two areas were recently visited by WFP Lobito, by land, for a needs assessment.

This week, WFP will conduct an assessment mission to Cubal to evaluate needs and ways of delivering food to Caimbambo, Cubal and neighboring areas. Since the government retook positions and towns all the way to Altos de Katumbela, lots of people who had fled to Caimbambo and Cubal are returning home spontaneously, without waiting for an organized move or for the areas to be declared safe. These people will need assistance, not only in food, but also in seeds and tools to prepare for the next planting season (October/November).

WFP is also planning deliveries along the northern road to Huambo but first will run assessment missions to Boccio and neighboring areas. Already WFP has agreed with the NGO Accao Agraria Alemaa to distribute 336 tonnes of food every month to 24,000 displaced people from Bocoio and Balombo municipalities.

THE SOUTHWEST

Lubango (pop. about 300,000) shelters 90,000 people displaced by war from northern Huila province. More are settled in a camp for displaced people about one hour away from Lubango. The displaced in town live with friends or relatives or have settled in the safe countryside around Lubango. -30Italy; phone: (6) 57971; telex: 626675 WFPI; fax: (6)

CONTACT: World Food Programme, Via C Colombo 426, 00145 Rome, 5127400/5133537.


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


STATEMENT AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS -- MISSION TO THE UNITED STATES NATIONAL EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

AUGUST 30, 1993 -- The National Executive Committee of the African National Congress met in full plenary over the weekend commencing Friday 27th until Sunday 29th August, 1993. The meeting, chaired by our President, Comrade Nelson Mandela, received reports from the Negotiations Commission, a report on Preparations for the ANCUs Conference on Reconstruction and reviewed the Report of the Motsuenyane Commission, established by the ANC to investigate instances of human rights violations committed against persons detained by the ANCUs security organs while in exile. The vacancies on the National Executive Committee, created by the deaths of Comrades O.R. Tambo and Chris Hani were also filled and two additional members were co-opted onto the National Executive Committee.

The report of the NECUs Negotiations Commission provided an overview of the various facets of the unfolding negotiations process at the World Trade Centre at Kempton Park, as well as the negotiations occurring at the local and regional level. The NEC once again endorsed the agreed on election date of April 27, 1994, underscoring the need to ensure the continued inclusivity of the process and that the agreed election date was adhered to. 

The meeting examined the draft interim constitution as well as draft legislation for the Independent Broadcasting Authority and the Transitional Executive Council. The NEC expressed its satisfaction with the progress made.

The emergence of a bloc of ultra right wing parties and groups, clustered around COSAG, and the role they have chosen to play in the negotiations was noted with concern by the meeting. Despite the ANCUs efforts to accommodate and address the concerns of the Inkatha Freedom Party and its COSAG allies on the issue of regional boundaries and the powers of regional governments, the NEC noted that our efforts have not elicited a positive response.

In its review of violence, the NEC, while recognizing the multiple origins of such violence, nonetheless remains convinced that its primary source is a well-orchestrated conspiracy on the part of forces opposed to democratic change, assisted by elements in the organs of state security. The NEC approved the ongoing and other initiatives being undertaken to secure a dialogue between the supporters of the ANC and the IFP at grassroots and undertook to extend its engagement with White ultra-right because of apprehensions about their future in a democratic political order.

The NEC undertook an extensive review of the ANC's own preparations for the election campaign noting that despite the uneven performance among its fourteen regions, the plans were largely on track. The ANC's campaign will begin in earnest on the 8th January 1994, the eighty-second anniversary of the ANC, on which date the movement will unveil its manifesto. Preparations have now entered their second phase, during which campaigning structures will seek to contact every potential voter at least once in order to gauge our current electoral support. A number of regions have already begun applying new and creative forms of popularizing the elections and engaging in voter education such as the mock elections conducted in Port Elizabeth over the past weekend.

The NEC received reports on the initiative to bring peace to Angola. Given the historic responsibility of the Pretoria regime for the escalation of this conflict and the assistance Angola had given to the struggle for freedom in the sub-continent, it was resolved that the ANC do all in its power to bring an end to the fighting that has resulted in extensive loss of life.

The threat of violence and its potential for disrupting democratic elections was identified as the gravest danger facing the country. The NEC committed the ANC to devote its energies to the pursuance of peace, both as a worthy end in itself an to ensure the greatest participation by all South African in our country's first ever democratic elections.

The NEC reviewed the report of the Motsuenyane Commission and has expressed its considered view on the matters therein in a separate statement which we are distributing today. Briefly stated, the NEC accepts collective moral and political responsibility for the transgressions identified by the Commission and reservedly apologizes for each and every one of these.

A report on preparations for the ANC Special Conference on Reconstruction, scheduled for December 1993, was also reviewed from the conference preparatory committee. The preparations are being spearheaded by the ANC's Policy Committee Departments and the NEC commended the sub-committee for the work it has completed. The planned Conference on Reconstruction will be the culmination of an extensive process that will involve the ANC, its tripartite allies, the Mass Democratic Movement, the religious communities and the Patriotic Front parties and governments.

The untimely deaths of Comrades O.R. Tambo and Chris Hani during the course of this year, created vacancies on the NEC. In an election held by secret ballot among its members, Comrades Charles Ngqakula, Penuel Maduna and Josiah Jele were elected to fill these.

Exercising the powers given to it by Conference, the NEC co-opted Comrades Sankis Nkondo and Nkosazana onto the NEC. The vacant post of National Chairperson was filled by the election of Comrade Thabo Mbeki to that position. -3061884, Marshalltown 2107, Johannesburg.

Contact: The Department of Information and Publicity, P.O. Box


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


THE UNITED STATES AND DEMOCRACY IN AFRICA


BYLINE: Richard Joseph


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

AFRICA DEMOS, Volume 3, No.2, July-August 1993 In previous issues of AFRICA DEMOS, as well as in other publications, I have complained about the lack of a bold and comprehensive commitment of the United States government to the cause of democracy, human rights and civil liberties in Africa. As recently as April 22 during a hearing of the Subcommittee on Africa of the U.S. House of Representatives, I called the group's attention to the major commitments, in word and deed, already made to democratization in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe compared to the inadequacy of what was being said and done for Africa.

It must now be acknowledged that senior spokespersons of the U.S. government have clearly demonstrated that this double standard is over. In his prepared statement for the same hearings, the U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, George Moose, announced his government's determination "to help Africans build stable, honest, and democratic governments which respect fully human rights." He acknowledged the increasing number of countries that had conducted multiparty elections in recent years and those that were preparing them. "Elections by themselves do not democracies make. The process leading to elections must allow for freedom of speech, of the press, and of assembly, with full access to the media for all participants." 

I therefore was pleased to acknowledge, when it became my turn to testify, that I never heard such forthright and unambiguous support for democratization in Africa by any senior U.S. official. I delighted in repeating to the

committee the words of Assistant Secretary Moose: "We will not allow our assistance to be used for the support of dictators, and we will use the full weight of our influence to end dictatorial practices." Less than two weeks later, another senior official articulated the Africa policies of the Clinton administration. At a luncheon forum at the Brookings Institution, Washington, DC, National Security Adviser Anthony Lake declared that "the most important change for Africa's long-term prospects is the continent's new progress toward democracy." He also acknowledged the number of African countries that had conducted multiparty elections. Yet, he

counseled: "Africa's democratic institutions will not always look like our own, nor should they." From his remarks it was

clear that the time of coddling African autocrats was over: "The African people have been saying that any ruling elite that puts its interests before those of the vast majority is no longer acceptable."

Later in May, at the annual meeting of the African- American Institute (AAI), also in Washington, the depth and breadth of the new U.S. commitment to democracy, human rights and sustainable development in Africa were reflected in the presentations of Ambassador Moose, Administrator J. Brian Atwood of the United States Agency for International Development, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher. Mr. Atwood is well known to African democratic activists, and also to autocratic leaders, from his years of service as president of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs (NDI). NDI has played a pioneering role in helping lay the basis for democratic polities in many African countries through its work in civic education, institution building, and election monitoring. Mr. Atwood brings a level of understanding about the democratic challenge in Africa to policy-making in the U.S. government that is unique. He acknowledged that "there was a conspiracy of silence with the respect to what was going on in Africa. There was no one who really wanted to talk about human rights abuses in Africa." Some of Mr. Atwood's reflections deserve full citation, such as the following offered in response to individuals "who

suggest that democracy cannot take place in Africa":

I would suggest that democracy took root in Africa long before it took in Europe. When people would go into those polling places at a national level, as opposed to conducting their democracy at the village level as they had done for centuries, they expected that their vote would count. They did not want, nor did they have any right to expect, that their government would steal their vote from them. So the outrage that people have felt in places like Kenya and Cameroon and Senegal most recently is very real outrage."

Just days before the conference, the U.S. government announced its recognition of the government of Angola, acknowledging the good faith of the Dos Santos regime in conducting multiparty elections last September. In a sweeping statement in which he indicated U.S. concerns for the mediation of conflicts, the promotion of human rights, public health and debt reduction in Africa, Secretary of State Christopher admitted a point that critics of U.S. foreign

policy had long made: "During the Cold War period, policies toward Africa were often determined not by how they affected Africa but by whether they brought advantage or disadvantage to Washington or Moscow." In several policy domains, he promised that "the Clinton administration will make Africa a high priority and give it the attention it deserves." Moreover, as a symbol of the new policy, President Sam Nujoma of a democratic Namibia was invited to be the first African head of state to be received in the Clinton White House. Unfortunately, some African leaders do not appear to have taken seriously this "wind of change" in American foreign policy. When Gen. Ibrahim Babangida unfolded the latest series of judicial and administrative actions intended to confuse and delay the democratic transition in Nigeria, he provoked an

immediate rebuke from the State Department: "The United States deplores the outrageous decision of Nigeria's military regime to annul the results of the June 12 presidential election and cancel the transition to elected civilian rule." The June 22 statement went on to condemn "the continuing repression of the press and democratic forces" in Nigeria and "the failure on the part of the military regime to respect the will of the Nigerian people and transition to democracy." Despite the U.S. government's reliance on imports of Nigerian crude oil, and its carefully nurtured improvements in relations since the chill of the mid-1970s, the Clinton administration was not prepared to disguise its profound disappointment.

Each of the previous statements by U.S. officials recognizes that more than the introduction of formal institutions of constitutional democracy is needed in Africa. Almost every African country must rebuild weakened economies permit civil society to flourish anew, and allow democratic norms and practices to become established. A genuine commitment to assist democracies in Africa is a long-term one and comes with a pricetag. In recognizing its responsibilities, the United States is taking the first step to acknowledge its deep and historic ties to the African people and their continent. It also poses a challenge to other major powers who have been content to proffer mere rhetoric, or adopt the old "conspiracy of silence," when confronted by the struggle between the democratic renewal and autocratic resistance in Africa. -30- AFRICA DEMOS is published by the African Governance Program at The Carter Center of Emory University (CCEU), One Copenhill, Atlanta, GA 30307 USA; (404) 420-5151.


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


I'LL BE PRESIDENT -- Interview with Nigeria's M.K.O. Abiola NEWSWATCH


LENGTH: 800 words


 

M.K.O. Abiola reacts to President Ibrahim BabangidaUs address to the National Assembly, August 17, at an interview

with NEWSWATCH London bureau chief, Kayode Soyinka:

NEWSWATCH: In his speech to the National Assembly, President Babangida did not give a clear indication on the political future of the country. Are you disappointed?

ABIOLA: He is playing the waiting game. He wished he could hang on. He wished because he is that type of a person. He is a gambler. He gambles with the hopes and aspirations and the future of the Nigerian people. 

NEWSWATCH What is he up to?

ABIOLA: He is bribing the National Assembly legislators so that they could come and beg him. That was what he called Anenih & Co. for, to come and beg him and he would then turn round and tell Nigerians that he had made up his mind to relinquish power, that he had said he was going, but that the legislators and politicians like Anenih were the ones who appealed to him not to go, that he should stay on as president.

NEWSWATCH: What do you think will now happen?

ABIOLA: He is counting on the legislators to now debate his speech, after which, he hopes, they would now vote to ask him to stay in power.

NEWSWATCH: What should Nigerians who voted for you in the June 12 election do?

ABIOLA: Nigerians should just stay calm and stay the course of democracy and the election of June 12. Babangida has not been able to convince the world that there was anything wrong with that election.

NEWSWATCH: Could you still be president?

ABIOLA: Oh yes.

NEWSWATCH: Why are you so sure?

ABIOLA: Because I know the Nigerian army. The Nigerian army is not loyal to one man. Nigerian army is loyal to the nation. Their oath of office is to the country. And theyUve told him that his term expires on August 27. He is like a child dancing round the well, he dares not jump inside the well.

NEWSWATCH: But Babangida is bent on installing an interim government.

ABIOLA: Whoever he likes he can hand over to. He is wasting time.

NEWSWATCH: Your critics said you should have taken part in the three-day strike called by the Campaign for Democracy last week instead of travelling abroad canvassing international support?

ABIOLA: That is their own judgment. Nobody claps with one hand, not even in Nigeria. I succeeded in the elections. And in my success I had only one vote, the other millions of votes were contributed by fellow Nigerians. I am not the only custodian of liberty and democracy in Nigeria, there are others. I decided to come and tell my own story to the world in the name of the African people, in the name of the Nigerian people. And that is more important really.

NEWSWATCH: Are you not worried that while you are outside your support in Nigeria might be weakening?

ABIOLA: My support in Nigeria was not built overnight. It cannot disappear overnight either. It is not a building built with my saliva that will disappear under the morning dew, no. I have been a true Nigerian for the last 25 years, giving scholarships, giving employment, developing various areas far flung away from my own locality. That is not done overnight. I have 235 traditional titles throughout Nigeria. All that cannot be withdrawn in any case. Democracy is not a one manUs cup of tea. -END -30- Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, August 30, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited.

CONTACT: LONDON: NEWSWATCH, Centre for International Operations, Suite 46, 8-14 Pancras Way, London, NW1 OQG United

Kingdom. Phone: 071-387-9291: fax 071-383-7576. NIGERIA: No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun P.M.B. 21499,

Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Phone: 960950; fax: 962887; telex: 27874 NEWCOM NG.


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

209 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


M.K.O. Abiola vows to assume office August 27 but interim national government arrangement may have pulled the rug from under his feet.


BYLINE: Utibe Ukim, NEWSWATCH, August 30, 1993


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

"A major feature of your life so far is the doggedness and determination with which you pursue any venture embarked upon."

-- President Ibrahim Babangida in a birthday message to Abiola in 1992.

Moshood Kashimawo Olawale Abiola is no stranger to battles. His life is a story of personal battles that have turned the impoverished boy who roamed the streets of Abeokuta into a man of immense wealth and global influence. But since June 23, Abiola seems to be locked in the fiercest battle of his life. President Ibrahim Babangida's annulment of the June 12 presidential election which Abiola is believed to have won, has brought out the warrior in him. Abiola has consistently maintained his rejection of the annulment and his determination to keep faith with August 27, the date the military promised to relinquish power. 

He sounded his battle cry June 24 when he declared himself the "custodian of a sacred mandate," which he would not relinquish. "on that date (August 27), the people of Nigeria through their democratic expressions of June 12, 1993 expect me to assume the reigns of government. I fully intend to keep that date with history."

How Abiola intends to do that, no one can say. However, his declaration has pitched him against Babangida, his bosom friend and his military regime and even a number of politicians across the country. Within his party, the SDP, a deep crack has surfaced. Support for him is no longer total. Abiola, abroad since August 4, to canvass international support for his campaign to get the Babangida regime to uphold the result of June 12 election, plans to return home this week. He will certainly meet a party in rancour and torment. His publications, the Concord newspapers and magazines and other sympathetic papers have been proscribed.

In the government news media, he is portrayed as the unpatriotic one who has been abroad campaigning against his country; the rich politician who has refused to play by the rule and who has promoted selfish interest above nationalist interest. When government officials speak of the "rich persons who are not necessarily the philosopher kings," the meaning is not lost on Nigerians.

His trip abroad has been branded as illegal and a violation of the country's civil aviation laws, an offense which attracts severe penalty. No doubt, the odds are against Abiola. But Abiola is a man at home with the odds.

When he entered the race for the presidency in January, he stood no chance of clinching the party's ticket. He was a stranger to the fold. A co-contender at the time described him as "not only a stranger but inexperienced in party politics." Ten years earlier, these same reasons forced him to quit the banned National Party of Nigeria, NPN. First, when he contested the party's national chairmanship against Adisa Akinloye in 1980, he was outschemed by the more experienced politicians. He lost.

Then on June 12, 1982, Abiola set his eyes on succeeding Shehu Shagari as the NPN flag bearer. He could not obtain the nomination form because the party secretariat's doors were shut against him. In frustration, he resigned from the party.

Umaru Dikko, Shagari's powerful transport minister, told him: "The presidency is not for sale to the highest bidder."

June 12 must have a mystical power over Abiola. On June 12, 1982, he could not even run the race. On June 12, 1993, he ran but was stopped before breaking the tape.

He feels cheated. He has declared that the road to peace in the country lies in a recourse by Babangida to the path of natural justice. His last press statement issued before he took off for London stated this much. "As the direct beneficiary of the (June 12) mandate, I stand firm and resolute in upholding and defending that mandate. I shall never compromise or betray the trust reposed in me by the Nigerian people." That statement, like previous ones, reflect the combative nature of the man. In an interview with NEWSWATCH in 1988, Abiola explained this attitude by saying, "we do everything we have to do with all the means at our command."

Since he arrived London without a formal visa, Abiola has become some kind of a folk hero. He has enjoyed extensive coverage by the western media. He is a constant guest of the British Broadcasting Corporation, BBC. He has appeared twice on the American Cable News Network, CNN. His first appearance, which took place in Washington, DC was heavily promoted and Abiola was introduced as "the man who will be president in Nigeria." He held consultation with key political leaders in the United States Congress and government including Al Gore, the vice-president whom he met within 24 hours of his arrival in the US. The 90 minutes meeting is believed to have been attended briefly by Bill Clinton's chief of staff.

In the United Kingdom, Abiola has met with parliamentary, opposition and key government officials. His

message: Tougher action against Nigeria to force Babangida to respect the people's mandate. In the days ahead, the success or failure of his campaign will be seen in the country.

For Abiola, the road to the present has been tough and bumpy. Only last November, he had declared his aversion for partisan politics. "Why should I join any of the two political parties? If I join the SDP, I will be estranging my numerous friends in the NRC. That is the problem with being partisan. Count me out of any partisan arrangement like joining any political party."

Six weeks later he changed his mind and registered with the SDP, declaring himself a social democrat. The day after, he obtained the party's presidential nomination form. He was able to beat formidable forces like Baba Gana Kingibe, his running mate, to clinch the tickets. Abiola relishes controversy the way he loves proverbs. His campaign was marked by a few, especially his choice of Kingibe, a muslim as his running mate. It angered not only members of the Yar'Adua group whose support led to the defeat of Kingibe but a number of sympathetic Christians. Kingibe had even referred to him as "one of those sitting on the fence while we labored to build the party but has now come to reap from our sweat."

The interim national government announced by Babangida last week may have pulled the rug from under Abiola's feet. His party supports the new arrangement. The new government takes over from the transitional council on August 25, two days before the August 27 date originally fixed for the disengagement of the military from government.

He told NEWSWATCH in London August 18 that he will still take over as president August 27. It remains to be seen how he will accomplish this. -30- Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, August 30, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited.

CONTACT: LONDON: NEWSWATCH, Centre for International Operations, Suite 46, 8-14 Pancras Way, London, NW1 OQG United

Kingdom. Phone: 071-387-9291: fax 071-383-7576. NIGERIA: No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun P.M.B. 21499,

Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Phone: 960950; fax: 962887; telex: 27874 NEWCOM NG.

210 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


Nigeria plans to withdraw from peace-keeping force in Liberia


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner AFRICA NEWS SERVICE


LENGTH: 734 words


 

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast -- Nigeria's new interim civilian government says it plans to withdraw its troops from the West African peace-keeping force in Liberia because it can no longer afford to keep them there.

The plan comes at a critical time in Liberia, where a cease-fire has held for a month but disarmament of the country's young and undisciplined fighters has yet to begin. Three and a half years of fighting has left more than 150,000 people dead. 

Nigerian forces and ammunition drive the six-nation West African peace-keeping operation in Liberia. The peace-keepers were drawn into the war last October when rebels attacked the capital Monrovia.

Nigeria's new head of state, Ernest Shonekan, said in a national address Tuesday that it was ''time to bring the boys home'' and they should all return to Nigeria by the time he leaves office next March. He said he would discuss the plan with fellow members of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) that created the peace-keeping force and sent it to Liberia in August 1990.

Shonekan, a businessman and political newcomer, was appointed last week by outgoing military president Ibrahim Babangida and is commander-in-chief of the armed forces. He is Nigeria's first civilian leader in a decade.

Africans have long looked to Nigeria as the giant of the sub-Saharan region because of its vast oil wealth and record for assisting its less fortunate neighbors. But now it is struggling under a $30-billion foreign debt.

''There is no doubt that our economy has suffered because of our peace-keeping and peace-enforcing operations,'' said Shonekan. The United States has helped finance Nigeria's involvement in Liberia, a nation settled by freed American slaves in 1847, by contributing $28 million to ECOWAS.

Shonekan said Liberia no longer needed Nigerian troops and put the burden on the United Nations, which has its own financial problems, and the international community to see disarmament through. Up to 4,000 additional non-West African peace-keeping troops from Tanzania, Zambia, Egypt and Zimbabwe are expected to arrive in Liberia within the next two months to assist with disarmament.

Liberia's three warring factions signed a peace accord in July that led to the formation of a new transitional government. Its first meeting has already been boycotted by rebel leader Charles Taylor's representative because of a dispute over when the new government would take office.

Taylor, who began the war when he invaded from the Ivory Coast on Christmas Eve 1989, has persistently accused the West African troops, especially the Nigerians, of siding against him and of trying to take over Liberia. Babangida was friends with Samuel Doe, the Liberian president who was abducted from West African troops by a splinter rebel group and killed in September 1990.

Foreign observers had speculated that Taylor decided to give up fighting the 11,000-strong West African force when it appeared as if the military would remain in power in Nigeria after Babangida annulled June's presidential elections. He appointed Shonekan following intense pressure at home and abroad to install a democratically elected president.

The pressure has not eased. A strike by Nigeria's largest labor union has held for six days to press for the appointment of Moshood Abiola as president. He is widely believed to have won the June 12 polls that Babangida annulled because of alleged fraud. International monitors judged the vote fair.


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 9, 1993


FORMER CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT FREED


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner AFRICA NEWS SERVICE


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast - The Central African Republic's military leader Andre Kolingba has lost presidential primaries, ending his 12-year-rule, and set free a former president imprisoned for murder.

Kolingba freed Jean-Bedel Bokassa on Wednesday along with the rest of the nation's prisoners to commemorate his 12th anniversary in power. Bokassa was jailed in 1987 on charges of embezzlement, murder and cannibalism. 

He is barred from entering politics, but told the French daily LE FIGARO in an interview published Thursday that he would return to power if he had popular support.

''I will do everything I can to help my country,'' Bokassa told the newspaper. ''If I am asked to return to politics, I will see. If the people want it, I will return.'' He has moved to an apartment in the presidential palace, a big change from solitary confinement. ''This is my place. I am emperor,'' he said.

Several hundred of his supporters in the capital Bangui on Wednesday cheered his release. Some reports said they were trying raise $20,000 for a registration fee to put Bokassa up as a candidate in the second round of presidential elections scheduled for Sept. 12.

Kolingba finished fourth in the first round of voting on Aug. 22 with 12 percent. The first woman to have participated in a presidential election in sub-Saharan Africa, Ruth Rolland, came in last with one percent.

Kolingba tried to change the electoral law after it became apparent that he was losing. But France, the nation's former colonial ruler, immediately condemned the move and suspended all bilateral aid. Kolingba quickly backed down.

The top two finishers, Agne-Felix Patasse and Abel Goumba will compete in the runoff. They won 37 percent and 22 percent respectively.

Patasse was a prime minister under Bokassa before the self-declared emperor was deposed with French assistance in 1979. Bokassa, 72, seized power in a coup in 1965 and his 14- year rule was often compared to the brutal regime of Uganda's Idi Amin.

Bokassa was sentenced to death in 1987 after he returned from exile in France and Cote d'Ivoire. Kolingba commuted his sentence to 20 years and later to 10 years. -30NIGERIA TO PULL OUT OF PEACEKEEPING FORCE IN LIBERIA


LOAD-DATE: September 6, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Algeria Dinar (AD)         0.1837     3.4835       13.8920

Angola Kwanza (AK)        36.5381   692.8622    2763.0775

Botswana Pula (BP)         0.0237     0.4502        1.7955

Burundi Franc (BF          1.8081    34.2860      136.7297

Cape Verde Escudo (CVE)    0.7024    13.320       53.121

CFA Franc (CFA)*           2.6367    50.000       199.396

Djibouti Franc (DF)        1.6436    31.168      124.295

Egypt Pound (LE)           0.0316     0.5991        2.3892

Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993- 1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in th U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and

qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: OCTOBER 1, 1993 and MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications 

and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA. An 18-day "Reality Tour" of Zimbabwe and Malawi is offered by Robyn Michaels, a former Peace Corps volunteer in conjunction with Classic Tours International. Urban areas and markets, development projects and the planning office in Blantyre, Malawi are on the itinerary; and in Zimbabwe, tourist will visit, Bulawayo, Hwange National Park and Victoria Falls. For an additional charge of $550, Nairobi and Mombasa in Kenya may be added. Travelers will need shots, anti-malarial prophylaxsis and a sleeping bag. An initial deposit of $1,000 is required by OCTOBER 15, 1993 for the tour, which is scheduled for January 19, 1994. Final payment is required by December 15, 1993. For more information, contact Paul Carpenter, Classic Tours International, 520 N. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611;

phone: (312) 329-1234 or (800) 828-8222; fax: (312) 642- 8418; or call Robyn Michaels, 6916 N. Wayne, Chicago, IL 60626; phone; (312) 973-3663 MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible

publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI

48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting

are welcome to apply. DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring

of 1994. POST DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first

ten years of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE:

DECEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280;

fax: (212) 370-7896. The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions compete in two separate

categories for funding: (1) Non-research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category. The application deadline is November 1. To request guidelines and proposal

forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008-3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. It is recommended that all institutions contact the appropriate CIES program officer for the scholar-in-residence program for advice, referral and assistance before preparing proposals. For Sub-Saharan Africa, contact Linda Rhoad at (202) 686-6230. For North Africa, contact Gary Garrison at (202) 686-4019. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 3067 words


 

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID

Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activites of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in

French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006. CUSO, a Canadian International Development Organization is recruiting for a two-and-a-half year contract for a MANAGER OF HYDROGEOLOGY AND CONSTRUCTION for its "Water for Life" project in rural Ondo State, Nigeria. The project aims to strengthen village and government institutions to enable 50,000 rural inhabitants to better 

meet theri water and sanitation needs. QUALIFICATIONS: an appropriate university degree, several years management level experience in the design, field implementation and evaluation of community-based sustainable handpump maintenance and repair programs; strong hands-on experience with a) master contract, subcontractor administration field supervision, b) mnitoring techniques, c) the proven ability to control drilling contractor operations in the field d) design/implementation of computerized operations monitoring; demonstratied strong leadership, comminucations and multicultural team work experience. The position salary starts at C$40,197October 18. For detailed information or to apply, send

C$42,561, with an immediate starting date. DEADLINE: resume, three references and a short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in this

particular area, contact: Position NIG/93/09C, CUSO Human Resources, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, K1N

9K7; fax: (613) 563-8068.

CUSO also seeks a MANAGER OF ACCOUNTING AND CONTROL for its "Water for Life" project. The selected candidate will serve as the project financial, accounting, and operational controller and principal advisor on all fiscal matters, with primary management responsibility for the portection of and adequate accounting for all project assets and for all assets of project-wide

compueterization. QUALIFICATIONS: accounting degree, possibly MBA, with CA, CMA or CGA designation; a wide range of hands-on experience in all areas of accounting and control; field experience on large-scaleaverseas development projects; very strong multi-component budgeting, analysis and control skills; ability to devise and implement a computerized management, control and reporting systems; stong communications skills; good knowledge of donor financial reporting requirements and practices (prefereably CIDA); ability to teach fundamental of financial management to non-financial managers, present meaningfulreports to host governments and donor agencies. The position salary start at C$36,503-C$38,411, with an

immediate starting date. DEADLINE: October 15. For detailed information or to apply, send resume, three references and a short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in this particular

area, contact: Position NIG/93/10C, CUSO Human Resources,

135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 563-8068. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (Rome office) seeks a SENIOR OFFICER IN LAND CONSERVATION AND REHABILITATION to manage the ongoing International Scheme for the Conservation and Rehabilitation of African Lands and the development and implementation of similar schemes for the Asia and Pacific

and Latin America and Caribbean regions. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in soil science, agriculture, agricultural engineering or closely related subject. Ten years of progressively responsible experience in the field of soil and water conservation and land reclamation, including experience in developing countries. Working

knowledge of English, French or Spanish. SALARY: US$ 64,570-$76,232 (without dependents), US$69,680-$82,781

(with dependents). DEADLINE: October 7. Contact: Executive Officer LNOR, Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437. Food for the Hungry seeks a CHIEF LOGISTICS MANAGER to be based in Beira, Mozambique. The position is responsible for the receipt, storage accounting, transport and monitoring of all FHI commodities and is also responsible for all international procurement and local procurement

when in bulk. QUALIFICATIONS: 1-2 years of relief development experience, preferably in Africa. Some degree of proficiency in Portuguese or Spanish. Must be willing to apply biblical principals to development work and be in agreement with Food for the Hungry's Christian philosophy

and practice. DEADLINE: SEPTEMBER 30, 1993. Contact: Scott Allen, recruitment coordinator, Food for the Hungry, 7729

East Greenway Road, Scottsdale AZ, 85260; phone: (800) 2- HUNGER.

positions available:

counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526.

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

216 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253;

Internet: tomb@winrock.org. Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the

following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and 

December, 1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and

December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and

general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December

1993 and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the

newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897- 4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered):

October-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December

1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington

Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928. The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404)

766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

218 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Bernard ABEILLE and Jean-Marie LANTRAN, Social Infrastructure Construction in the Sahel -- Options for

Improving Current Practices. Philadelphia: World Bank (P.O. Box 7247-8619, Philadelphia, PA 19170-8619), 1993. $6.95 (paper). 39 pp.

Study of the experience with construction programs in the education and helath sectors in the Sahel, with recommendations for cost-effective solutions. 

 

Nassau A. ADAMS, Worlds Apart: The North-South Divide and

the International System. Atlantic Highlands: Zed Press (171 First Avenue, Atlantic Highlands, NJ 07716), 1993. $22.00 (cloth). $19.95 (paper). 261 pp.

An economic and political history of North/South divisions since 1945 and an examination of the current impasse between hemispheres.

Tunde AKINGBADE, Nigeria: On the Trail of the Environment.

Surulere: Babtex Productions (57, Akintan Street, Surulere, Nigeria), 1991. 155 pp.

A look at decisions and trends in regulations on environmental protection and economic considerations.

Robin W. ALPINE and James PICKETT, Agriculture, Liberalisation and Economic Growth in Ghana and Cote

d'Ivoire, 1960-1990. Washington: OECD Publications and Information Center (2001 L Street N.W., Washington, DC 20036-4910), 1993. $27.00 (paper). 140 pp.

Study of reform options and experiences of the two West African countries, which faced similar economic problems at independence.

Stan BURKEY, People First: A Guide. Atlantic Highlands: Zed Press (171 First Avenue, Atlantic Highlands, NJ 07716), 1993. $55.00 (cloth). $19.95 (paper). 244 pp.

Presents a methodology for achieving development based on principles of local control, cooperation and self-reliance.

Stephen J. CARR, Improving Cash Crops in Africa -- Factors Influencing the Productivity of Cotton, Coffee and Tea Grown by Smallholders (World Bank Technical Paper No.

216). Philadelphia: World Bank, 1993. $6.95 (paper). 58 pp.

Study of technology available to small-scale farmers in Africa and presents the varied yields of the crops and differences in productivity.

FREEDOM HOUSE, Freedom in the World: The Annual Survey of

Political Rights and Civil Liberties, 1992-1993. Lanham: National Book Network (4720 Boston Way, Lanham, MD 20706), 1993. 637 pp.

A review of political and civil liberties around the globe in the past year.

Amitav GHOSH, In An Antique Land. New York: Alfred A. Knopf (201 East 50th, New York, NY 10022), 1992. $23.00 (cloth). 393 pp.

The author traces the life of a 12th century Indian slave in Egypt.

Bessie HEAD, Collector of Treasurers and Other Botswana

Village Tales. Portsmouth: Heinemann (361 Hanover Street, Portsmouth, NH 03801-3959), 1992. $9.95 (paper). 109 pp.

Compilation of short stories drawing on the rich oral tradition of Southern Africa, focusing on village people from Botswana, and the status and position of women on the continent.

Chenjerai HOVE, Shadows. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1991. $9.95 (paper). 111 pp.

Extended prose poem follows the life of a Zimbabwean farming family during the war for liberation.

Anthony LAKE, et. al., After the Wars: Reconstruction in Afghanistan, Indochina, Central America, Southern Africa and the Horn of Africa. New Brunswick: Transaction Publishers (Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ 08903), 1990. $15.95 (paper). 196 pp.

Analysis of the differing problems of polity and economy confronting the governments of the war-torn countries and ideas to stimulate redevelopment efforts.

Robert ROSS, Beyond the Pale: Essays on the History of

Colonial South Africa. Hanover: University Press of New England (23 South Main Street, Hanover, NH 03755-2048), 1993. $50.00 (cloth). 270 pp.

Essays examines the development of South African society, the origins of its white ruling classes, in interpretive accounts of the colonial history of the Cape.

THE SOUTH CENTRE, ed., Facing the Challenge: Responses to

the Report of the South Commission. Atlantic Highlands: Zed Press, 1993. $60.00 (cloth). $22.50 (paper). 319 pp.

Collection of analyses by political and intellectual figures on the challeges facing countries of the South in domestic and development policies.

Alphonse TIEROU, Doople -- The Eternal Law of African

Dance. New York: Harwood Academic Publications (P.O. Box 786, Cooper Station, New York, NY 10276), 1992. $32.00 (paper). 88 pp.

Volume two of the "Choreography and Dance Studies" series explores the movements, codes and meaning of traditional Africa dance.

Ivor WILKS, Forests of Gold: Essays on the Akan and the

Kingdom of Asante. Athens: Ohio University Press/Swallow Press (Scott Quadrangle, Athens, OH 45701-2979), 1993. $50.00 (cloth). 388 pp.

Essays on the Akan peoples of Ghana, exploring the various aspects of Asante culture including conceptions of wealth, time and motion and of the relationship between the unborn, the living and the dead.
