LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


ZWELAKHE SISULU ON THE CUTTING EDGE


BYLINE: Zwelakhe Sisulu, SUNDAY NATION, August 29, 1993


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

There is a mood bordering on euphoria around the prospects of the elections scheduled for next April in the ranks of the democracy movement.

Throughout the country people are working feverishly in garnering support for their parties and will soon see a dramatic reversal of roles; when former prisoners and political activists assume important positions in government.

If this is a scene that is full of hope, it also has the makings of a potential tragedy if the key components of the movement are not vigilant.

For a start there may be the danger of the ANC collapsing into becoming an election machine when the times call for a strong organisation for the task of changing the conditions that affect the majority, which is poor. 

Too often in Africa, the reversal of political roles has tended to end at leadership level and never filtered down to the mass of the people. And thus the lot of the people's lives was not affected by the changes whereas that of the elite did change and rather dramatically.

This chasm between the elite and the mass of the people then creates conditions of great tension and that invariably leads to terrible suppression by the new rulers.

This denial of civil liberties against the majority then creates conditions wherein the elite plunder the country's resources at will and by the time a creditable, leadership emerges, the economy is already in ruins.

This is the cycle that has led to the interventions of institutions such as the IMF in many developing countries and often such interventions unravel in tandem with a political agenda.

Now while it is true that having the vote will be an important advance in the path to democracy the vote in itself is quite worthless if it does not lead to the establishment of new and better conditions.

The vote can be an important tool in the hands of the majority in bringing about social change.

The question that needs to be asked is what should be done to ensure that our vote counts -- not simply in putting our preferred political formation in power, but in ensuring that those who are in power are accountable to the people who elected them?

Conditions in South Africa are going to get worse before they get better. The majority will have the vote but will not have employment or housing. DILEMMA OF ELECTION

The challenges that confront the country cannot be resolved by a new government alone, but will require the active participation of all organs of civil society. This is why building organisation will help bring about accountability, but will also mean that the structures and energies from the communities are used constructively.

People's expectations are high -- so high in fact that if they are not met the country could be thrown into a cataclysm of violence.

This is the unenviable task of government of national unity that will be elected next year.

The dilemma of democracies in modern time is that the exercise of the highest democratic right, that of voting, is periodic through the holding of elections and is followed by a lull until the next elections.

This has tended to reduce political parties into election machines that splutter to life every other four or five years.

In the context of the South African experience the building of strong organisation is going to be the key to sustaining our democratic rights. It is only through strong collective power that the majority can help democracy prosper.

It may be that we have already fallen into the first trap of allowing the mood of optimism to demobilise the democratic forces.

At a time when the new conditions demands vision, self examination and rigorous debate, intellectual paralysis has set in.

Yet this is understandable if one considers that many of our leading intellectuals and activists are suffering from a "war weariness" of the past couple of years. But if we say negotiations are site of struggle, we have to recognise that rebuilding the country is an even higher stage of struggle that requires our collective energy.

The mass media could be a powerful instrument in empowering people in their first experience of democracy and in acting as a collective mobiliser and a transporter of experience.

But to be able to perform its function properly, South African mass media needs a new framework from within which to work.

And a key element in the development of the new framework must be a commitment by media owners that under these circumstances the interests of democracy are more important than the interests of shareholders.

Certainly the fact that a new Independent Broadcasting Authority will soon be in place means that the airwaves can be used more effectively in building democratic culture. Reprinted from SUNDAY NATION, August 29, 1993 SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Company (South Africa)

CONTACT: Editorial Offices, P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg

2000. Tel: (011) 333-2711, Fax: (011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


PHONE LINES FOR ALL


BYLINE: Annabel Dunn, AFRICA SOUTH AND EAST:NEWS MAGAZINE OF THE SUBCONTINENT, July 1993


LENGTH: 960 words


 

While many African nations are still floundering with antiquated and unreliable telecommunication systems, Botswana is on schedule to complete its country-wide digital microwave link late this year. Diamond-rich Botswana's huge foreign currency reserves have enabled it to fund a modern telecommunications network.

The service, is the most modern in Africa, has been developed over the past six years by UK firm Cable and Wireless with the Botswana Telecommunications Corporation (BTC). Cable and Wireless has also been involved in telecommunications in Nigeria and Cameroon. 

When construction is completed on the final digital microwave links between Ghanzi on the western edge of the Kalahari Desert and Jwaneng in the south ; and Maun in the north and Orapa on the eastern side of the Kalahari; the backbone telecommunications infrastructure for Botswana will have been completed, providing basic telephone services to the major population centres. Along the way, many villages have been provided with their first-ever telephones. BTC aims to provide services (at least one payphone and a limited number of lines for police, medical clinic and other essential services) to all villages with populations over 500.

The majority of the telecommunications development work during the early years from 1986 was concentrated on the major population centres along the eastern side of Botswana. This provided the economic base to finance expansion into remote areas. BTC commercial manager Richard Doyle said the vastness of the country and low population densities coupled with the wide spacing of settlements had presented the major hurdles.

The digital microwave backbone, which circles the country, is solar powered. It is by far the largest in Africa (and one of the largest in the world) with a total transmission distance of more than 2000 kilometres. The microwave towers are being installed by Norwegian firm ABB Nera. One tower is erected every 40 kilometres along the route to provide line-of-side communications. The solar power panels provide the main power source and have the capacity to take 2000 simultaneous calls.

The speed at which the new system installed has forced user costs up, although Doyle claimed Botswana's telecommunication charges were not the most expensive in Africa and were cheaper than some European countries.

"We have n trying to link up the whole country in two years and at t same time have had to run the operation a sound commercial basis," said Doyle.

"In six years we have gone from having between 5000 and 6000 lines on a manual exchange to having the digital microwave link around the country almost completed, as well as installing 400 circuits into South Africa and satellite communications for international calls." A local call costs 21 thebe for six minutes." With the backbone links near completion BTC is now looking to enhance its services to meet the expanding needs of the business community. In June last year a new data communications service was introduced - the Botspac Packet Switched Data Service. Users have a wide choice of speeds at which they can access the networks and they do not need to know the access speed of the destination terminal as the system will authomatically convert the original speed of a call to the speed of the receiving terminal. Access to Botspac PSS is by standard direct circuit or by a dial-up telephone line. The data links are direct, permanently- available connections to the network and subscribers have a choice of either synchronous (packet mode) or asynchronous (character mode) connections. They are available at transmission speeds ranging from 1200 bps to 65,000 bps.

The dial-up connection is through the public switched telephone network and is normally used for direct data transmission from a terminal to a host commuter. A modem and accompanying software are required.

The service has 20 corporate subscribers to date. The quality of the data exchange, the cost and the ability to network have been the major selling points. Barclays Bank uses Botspac for its business master services for corporate clients. The clients can call in and access their own data base in the Barclays network. In May, 1992, the country's first paging service came on line in Gaborone providing coverage within 35 kilometre radius of the capital. The service has been extended to Francistown and BTC is now looking offering the service to other towns. Cellular mobile telephones, carphones and pocket phones are still waiting government approval. Doyle said the government had put the idea of mobile phones on hold while it looked at the possibility of liberalising the market.; at the moment the BTC has a monopoly. Providing satellite links for mobile phones is not considered economically viable yet because of the size of the country and the limited number of potential customers. Reprinted from AFRICA SOUTH AND EAST, July 1993.

CONTACT:ASE Publications, 1 Mayo Centre,Fortesque Road,Yeoville


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


TELL THE WORLD ABOUT OUR PLIGHT


BYLINE: Raymond Mashao, SUNDAY NATION, August 15-21, 1993


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Sunday Nation travels to the refugee camps of Gazankulu to speak to Mozambican refugees who are still fleeing their country, even though the war between the Renamo rebels and the Frelimo government is over.

Thick smoke hangs in the air over the Hluphekani village east of Gazankulu's capital, Giyani. Small traditional huts are crammed together on bare dusty earth. Radios blare out songs in Shangaan and Portuguese.

Hluphekani, which means suffering in Shangaan, is home to hundreds of refugees who have fled war-torn Mozambique to a better life in South Africa. Now, hunger and starvation have added to the exodus. 

All the refugees share a common dream of going back home once they feel it is safe.

A Sunday Nation team, which visited the village to find out how the refugees were faring, called at the only relief centre for the 2,000 inhabitants.

The centre is run jointly by Gazankulu homeland and the South African Red Cross, which provides blankets and soap. It has five workers, including clerks and security guards. On the floor is a heap of mealie meal to meet the needs of new arrivals.

Other donors include Operation Hunger, which provides soup, mealie meal and bread. Next to the centre is a clinic which was built by Gazankulu's Department of Social Welfare. The clinic is staffed by three qualified nurses and a welfare worker.

As we drove through the village, we saw men and women erecting makeshift huts to accommodate fresh refugees fleeing poverty in Mozambique.

Despite the ceasefire agreement signed between Renamo and the ruling Frelimo government, refugees are still pouring into Gazankulu.

Lacio Sambo, a teenager, and an elderly man, Samson Sithole, are new arrivals at the camp. Neither knows what the future holds for them.

They left war-ravaged Mozambique knowing that the South African sponsored Renamo rebels and the Frelimo government had smoked a peace pipe.

But Sithole and Sambo said life was still extremely difficult in the rural areas of Mozambique.

Sambo, wearing a thick khaki jacket and matching shorts, does not know his age but remembers vividly that poverty forced him to leave his village.

He struggled to control tears rolling down his face

and said:"All I want is to start a new life here. I left Mozambique and walked through the forest for many days.

"I'm glad the war is over, but there's nothing to live for in Mozambique. I'm hungry and looking for a job. I'm prepared to do any work because I'm suffering."

Communications between Sambo's village of Khombomuni in the Gaza district and the capital, Maputo, are completely cut off.

Government lorries, which used to deliver food rations, cannot travel because the roads are still not safe. Sambo said when the sun rose each morning, the villagers would look for the trucks - but their hopes would turn to despair when the sun set.

Livestock like goats and cattle were confiscated by the rebels - drought killed off the rest.

"The rebels would come to our village and kill people without saying anything. Those of us who were lucky would run into the bush and hide until they had left," he said.

"Sometimes we would stay in the bush for many days, eating wild berries, roots and tree leaves. The elders would send a young boy back to the village to see if it was safe to go back."

Sithole still cannot believe he survived the war. Although he does not know his age, he looks old enough to be a pensioner. His weary legs carried him through the rough countryside between Maputo and Gazankulu.

He risked his life crossing the paths of lions, elephants, hyenas and jackals and found his way to "safe" South Africa without interference from the police.

HUNGER

"I came here because of hunger. I'm old but I think I can still work for a year or two. There's not much left for me in this world because I've seen enough horror in my life," Sithole said.

"Back home, there's nothing to live for. The rebels would come to our village and take all the food and livestock.

"Most of us are fortunate just to be alive today. We were left with nothing and there was nothing we could do because the rebels were always ready to kill those who opposed them. The situation was bad and I decided to walk all the way to Gazankulu," he said.

The refugees spend the day wandering around the village, waiting for Good Samaritans from Giyani township and white farmers from Mooeketsi and adjoining farms to give them work.

Johannes Mashava, 40, is among the few refugees fortunate enough to be employed at the camp. He is a security guard earning R160 a month. BURNED

"The rebels came to our village one night and shot at people. They burned down our huts, raped women and took our cattle," he said.

Mashava is looking forward to the day when peace is restored in Mozambique so that he can go back home with his family. He doubts, however that it is safe to return at this stage.

"I've heard that the war is over and I'm longing to go back. I'm always thinking about that because people who go home also tell us that the war is over."

We found George Khoza sipping traditional beer brewed by one of his four wives, who managed to escape with him. A sobbing Khoza refused to be photographed but talked openly about his experiences.

"Don't ask me about my children because most of them were killed by the rebels," he said.

"Those people (Renamo) would attack at night and everyone would run for their lives and hide in the mountains until the next morning. But we also want to go home."

Barefooted Zephania Sambo said he could not remember his age only that he was "very old" and had known better times in Mozambique.

Sambo's village was also attacked by the rebels. "They frog-marched us to a mountain and tied us to trees, promising to kill us the following day. But they fell asleep that night and we managed to free ourselves and run away," he said.

"As we drove out of the camp on the way to another refugee village west of Giyani, the refugees waved at us

and shouted:"Tell the world about our plight." MOTHERS OF MERCY

Working in a rehabilitation centre for Mozambican refugees has become a way of life for dedicated welfare worker Alice Maphophe and nurses Josephine Maluleke, Julia Mutshekwana and Alice Sithole.

They are "mothers" to the 2,000 refugees at Hluphekani camp, dispensing help and advice on a variety of subjects.

Refugee camps are normally breeding grounds for diseases such as kwashiorkor, diarrhoea and the effects of malnutrition - but hard work by the four has helped to end many ailments.

Sister Sithole said:"We conduct health education for women when they come to the clinic with emphasis on family planning and how to breast-feed children."

Maphophe, who is responsible for the refugees'

welfare, said:"They (the refugees) keep coming every week, but not in large numbers like before. It seems the war is really over because it is men and boys who are arriving now," she said.

"They say there's nothing but poverty and starvation back there." Reprinted from SUNDAY NATION, Aug. 15-21, 1993.

Contact: SUNDAY NATION, P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


THE PANA RECOVERY PLAN: PRIVATISATION OR BUST


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Plans are underway transform the moribund Pan-African News Agency (PANA) into a "truly independent and professional news organisation, to become the leading source of information in Africa".

So says the recovery plan which intends to make PANA a privately-owned news and communication business run by media professionals, and using satellite technology to link Africa with both itself and the rest of the world.

PANA's new management, headed by Co-ordinator General Babacar Fall, has three years to make the plan work. Mr. Fall believes the plan will cost around US$6 million to implement, US$750,000 of which has already been pledged by UNESCO. 

Founded in 1979 by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), PANA had all-but collapsed by 1992, having swallowed US$18 million of member state funding in the process.

As the revival plan -- approved by the OAU last year -- points out, the agency failed because of unwieldy bureaucracy and editorial constraints imposed upon the agency by the governments whose interests it was supposed to serve.

The recovery plan intends to do away with the bureaucracy and rigid state control in order to make the PANA an economically viable concern run by a variety of shareholders.

"We want to transform PANA into something which is not only for the governments, but also for all parties of society involved in communication," says Mr. Fall. "We don't think that communication is just something for one group of society. It must benefit all groups."

Objectives outlined in the recovery plan certainly

have a post-Cold War feel to them, and they include:

* Enabling private investment in a restructured shareholding shareholding system, with "equitable participation of private investors such as financial institutions, publishers, press organisations, non- governmental organisations and individual shareholders".

* Developing a "truly independent and highly professional" news agency "capable of ensuring the free flow of information among African countries, and between Africa and the rest of the world".

* Hiring staff capable of reporting freely on "both the successes and failures" of the authorities to improve life for "disadvantaged groups, the youth, the minorities, African women and children".

* Installing a satellite system owned by PANA and capable of distributing "news products" continent-wide, quickly and efficiently.

* Building-up "an international market for PANA products". Products will include not only news reports, but also "specialised services" determined by the requirements of "an international clientele".

Perhaps most importantly, PANA's direction will no longer be decided by the Information Ministers of OAU member states, but by the PANA Foundation, made-up of representatives of national news agencies, media associations (such as MISA, which Mr. Fall believes could have a an important role to play in PANA's future), publishers, private investors, and the telecommunications industry.

The Foundation, in turn, will support the setting up of two PANA companies; PANA Press, which will run the news agency, and PANA Communications, which will be responsible for the mechanics of distributing PANA Press's information.

PANA's bureaucracy is currently being trimmed; political appointments are being ousted, correspondents are being hired, and regional bureaus are being restructured. Reprinted from MISA FREE PRESS August 1993. MISA FREE PRESS is published by the Media Institute of Southern Africa (Namibia)

CONTACT: MISA Head Office, P.O. Box 20783, Windhoek, Namibia, Tel/Fax (26461) 32975


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


IT'S A POLITICAL DECISION


BYLINE: Utibe Ukim, NEWSWATCH, September 13, 1993


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

The United States Department of Transport on August 11 suspended air services between Lagos and America, alleging that the Murtala Muhammed Airport, Lagos, "does not maintain and administer effective security procedure." IBRAHIM MAMMAN, managing director of the Nigeria Airport Authority, NAA, which manages Murtala Muhammed Airport, in an interview with NEWSWATCH assistant editor, UTIBE UKIM, speaks on the US action and the state of MMA.

NEWSWATCH: How would you describe the action of the United States government banning flights from and into Murtala Muhammed Airport? 

MAMMAN: As you must have heard from the secretary for information, the action of the American government is political rather than objective. I am saying this because of certain developments that led to that. For quite some time, we have been discussing the security issue with American Federal Aviation Authority, FAA, officials. They came, we held meetings with them about the airport. They listed some shortcomings, which were corrected. They even drew up a certain manual which was signed by the then minister of aviation, transport and communication, Engineer Olawale Ige, after which they even conducted training, at their own auspices, for our men. Towards the end of July, they came, held meetings with the secretary of transport, communication and aviation, and expressed satisfaction at the progress that has been made since their last visit. Of course, the major issue that was outstanding then was the issue of photo I.D. card. That is, the identity card should carry the photograph of each individual. We do not have the machine here so we have placed order from the manufacturers in Germany, but we have not been able to take delivery. However, in the interim, we came up with something which they saw and approved. In fact, after the inspection of the airport, they went back to the ministry to express satisfaction at the progress made. To now say that the security system at the airport is not up to standard and they have suspended flight... so , on all accounts, it is more of a political decision than anything else.

NEWSWATCH: You talked about some shortcomings which were noted by...

MAMMAN: Those shortcomings had to do with access control and security identification display area which if you go to the airport now, you will see some points marked in red which means, within such boundaries only accredited people would be allowed to pass beyond that point. They were quite happy with that. And then there are some toll gates too. You notice that it is quite difficult to go into the airside because their control base are from the airport airside. All these have been put in place. So with photo I.D. card, every airport worker or anybody who has legitimate duty to do at the airport would carry a color coded photo ID card. Which means if you carry a photo I.D. card, it would only authorize you to go to certain areas. We only restrict you to some part of the airport, depending on the color of the I.D. card. This is to enhance effective control on the movement of people within the terminal area.

NEWSWATCH: But don't you think the US action may have been due to the recent development, for instance the airport robbery case?

MAMMAN: It has nothing to do with the armed robbery. The armed robbers followed the bureau de change van carrying money from the town. It was not as if they just came to the airport and started vandalizing and shooting. they followed this man to his point of destination at the airport. It was unfortunate that it took place. You see, their own write up does not even mention the robbery incident.

NEWSWATCH: Do you think that if the aviation security men were allowed to carry firearms, the incident of that robbery would have been averted?

MAMMAN: I believe you are perfectly right. Over the years we have been writing to government to allow a category of NAA security officers to carry arms. Definitely if the armed robbers know that the security agents are well armed, they would think twice before they break into that area to carry out an operation. But we are still pursuing this, and we believe that government may concede to allow just a section of the security officers to carry arms.

NEWSWATCH: There is this other problem of multiplicity of security agencies at the airport. You have the police, the army, and NAA. Have they been streamlined now?

MAMMAN: I want to confirm that this has been done. In fact, following the meeting in the vice-president's office, last year, the number of security agencies has been reduced from over thirty to just six or seven. So that is what is subsisting at the moment.

NEWSWATCH: Since this ban by the American government, what efforts have you made to put your objections across to the department of transport?

MAMMAN: We have written our own report to the secretary of transport and aviation. He too is already discussing it at the government level. And they are doing other things to make sure that everything is in place.

NEWSWATCH: How much have we lost in the course of this ban?

MAMMAN: Well I can't talk on the Nigerian economy. That is very global. Definitely NAA would lose in the sense that what we can derive in the form of passengers service charge, landing and parking, we would definitely lose. On the national economy, that is unqantifiable. You should also weigh the American government action against the background that so many foreign airlines have been coming here for more than 10 years. Nothing embarrassing has ever happened. Even as we are talking now, it is not that any hijacking has taken place or that terrorist activity or something close to that has taken place. That is not the background. So you would see that their action definitely is more political rather than anything to do with aviation security. The British Airways comes daily, Lufthansa comes regularly, Air France comes regularly, and so do other airlines.

NEWSWATCH: In a letter the department of transport wrote, they mentioned that the warning they issued last October on the Lagos airport was the longest they have ever issued. Why, between then and now, weren't you able to come into an agreement?

MAMMAN: That was precisely why I said the action was a surprise because after their visit, the very last visit, they came prior to the announcement, they expressed satisfaction. That was July 22 when we met at the secretary's office. And the following week, they made their assessment and departed, only for them to issue a statement that the security situation was not adequate, just one week later.

NEWSWATCH: Murtala Muhammed Airport, is Nigeria's busiest airport and the first contact that many foreigners make with the country. The airport has a very bad image with report of touting and theft of passenger's luggage. How have you been able to address this?

MAMMAN: The issue of touting and luggage poaching has been drastically reduced at the airport. For the past three years, we have not heard of luggage being poached. this is due to the fact that we have now reduced the distance which luggage has to go through on the conveyor belt to the baggage hall. You would see that as soon as your luggage arrives, you can even see it discharged to the conveyor desk. So there isn't any room for anybody to poach on the luggage. That one has been virtually eliminated. And touting has been greatly reduced, to the barest minimum. We have the standing presidential task force, we have the security of NAA, and we have other agencies that are constantly at the gate and parading and inspecting all nooks and corners of the airport. But I want to add that there is definitely an environmental problem, a culture problem that people who have nothing to do find themselves at the airports. In any case, once this photo ID card comes into operation, that would be virtually eliminated, because if you don't carry an identity card, you have no business being found at the airport.

NEWSWATCH: How soon is the photo ID coming up?

MAMMAN: We are using a temporary one at the moment. The other one that we had to import will come by next month.

NEWSWATCH: And with that you would have satisfied all the conditions.

MAMMAN: We have virtually satisfied all of them with this temporary one, but with that we shall satisfy completely the FAA requirements. Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, September 13, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited.

CONTACT: LONDON: NEWSWATCH, Centre for International Operations, Suite 46, 8-14 Pancras Way, London, NW1 OQG

United Kingdom. Phone: 071-387-9291: fax 071-383-7576.

NIGERIA: No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate,

Oregun P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Phone: 960950;

fax: 962887; telex: 27874 NEWCOM NG.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


THE KILLING THAT TURNED GUGULETU TO PEACE


BYLINE: Gaye Davis, THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN (South Africa)


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Guguletu, early on a Wednesday afternoon. Potholed streets full of cars and taxis, pavements busy with hawkers and strollers. Banners up on the corner of the street where Amy Biehl was murdered, advertising for the forthcoming

events: a concert, a dance.

I don't drive down NY1 (the NY stands for Native Yard), where Biehl's car came under a hail of stones, because my meeting is in Section Three, along another route which winds among cramped houses along crooked, rutted roads. 

After the meeting, its business concluded, talk turns to Biehl's killing. "It was a very, very bad thing that happened," says Kelly Langs, a street committee member for NY 141. "It should never have happened. It mustn't happen again. Not in Guguletu."

Two street committee members accompany me to Guguletu Day Hospital. This is more a courtesy than a necessity, for there are today no youth-led protests underway against a government whose policies -- and their legacy -- have accounted for an untold number of essentially racist killings, as indiscriminate as that of Amy Biehl's.

Instead, schoolchildren are gathered in a Guguletu church, attending a service dedicated to her memory. "We did it to pay respect and to show that our organisation distances itself from her killing and is committed to non- racialism," says Congress of South African Students (Cosas) regional organiser JJ Tyhalisisu.

The memorial service is just one of many initiatives launched to mark people's rejection of racially motivated attacks and halt a burgeoning perception that Guguletu -- and by extension other townships -- have become no-go

zones for whites. The concerns are real: violence has compounded staffing problems at health and other township facilities.

At the Guguletu Day Hospital, strain etched on her face. Dr. Carol Cragg tells of the haemorrhage of trained staff since January. There should be at least 10 full-time

doctors serving the clinic, she says: now there are only two. Instead of being treated, patients at township primary health care centres are now being turned away virtually on a daily basis, sometimes in their hundreds.

Cragg expects Biehl's death to fuel more resignations by doctors too exhausted to continue struggling against odds that threaten to become too great -- and that the chances of vacant posts being filled will become even more remote.

And yet, she says, it has been members of the community who have rallied to remedy the problem of health workers' safety to and from the townships, while their employer, the Cape Provincial Administration, which should be ensuring their protection, appears unable to find a solution.

"It was the community which came forward and which, together with the Peace Committee, helped arrange for us to have escorts and marshals. There have been meetings with the CPA about our safety but no decisions yet. We're here because the community needs us but we're also doing the CPA a favour by keeping the service going, yet it doesn't seem to care.

"Things are basically just running into the ground," she says, "I'm not supposed to talk to the press, but they can fire me if they like and this place will close."

Confronted with racist violence endured by black South Africans for hundreds of years, whites are tending to stay away. Only a handful respond to Father Basil van Rensburg's call to come and worship at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Guguletu last Sunday, in itself a poignant comment on his open invitation, which asks the

question: "How on earth are we supposed to build our future together when we are so polarised that we can't even pray together?"

Tomorrow a peace march has been planned for Guguletu at 10 am. Announcing it at an African National Congress- convened summit on violence on Monday night, Zieila Dubase urged "our comrades from outside the townships to join us in demonstrating non-racialism and to undermine the notion of no-go areas".

Reflecting on Biehl's death in a letter to a local newspaper, Mbulelo Teddy writes how it has "brought shame to the peace-loving people of South Africa and in particular of Guguletu".

Suggesting that NY1, the street in which she lost her life and Guguletu's longest, should be renamed in her

memory, Teddy says: "The people of Guguletu need to demonstrate their commitment to the ideals for which Amy fought. By naming NY1 in her memory we would be showing our respect for the ideals of democracy, non-sexism, non- racism and peace in which she strongly believed."

Perhaps tomorrow's march will see white people living in Cape Town demonstrating a similar commitment to the same ideals." Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, September 3-9, 1993

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Publications.

CONTACT: THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg or The Guardian Weekly, Abney Hall, Manchester Road, Cheadle, Cheshire SK8 2PD,

United Kingdom.. Phone: 011-403-7111; fax: 011-403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


SEPTEMBER 20, 1993


HOW THE ANC WOULD HANDLE FOREIGN AFFAIRS


BYLINE: Chris Louw, THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Some of South Africa's ambassadors may be replaced before the country goes to the polls next year, the African National Congress' new national chairman, Thabo Mbeki, has disclosed.

Decisions about the appointment of new diplomatic personnel would be taken by the subcouncil of the transitional executive council (TEC) dealing with foreign affairs, he said.

Giving the basic outlines of the foreign policies at a working breakfast in Johannesburg this week, Mbeki promised a "complete revamping" of the Foreign Affairs Department as soon as the TEC is in place later this month. 

The foreign affairs sub-council, he said, would be in a position to decide diplomatic appointments as part of its brief of "levelling the playing fields." As the ANC was seen as the government in waiting, he believed its representatives abroad would have "a better impact than the ambassadors currently representing the De Klerk government.

Mbeki gave some important pointers on the ANC's

foreign policies in the next few years:

* Normal diplomatic relations would be established with Cuba, Libya and mainland China.

* The ANC would retain its "close contact" with the Palestinian Liberation Organisation and would back negotiations with Israel on Palestinian rights.

* A "balanced regional economic policy" would be followed to ensure South Africa did not dominate its neighbours.

* South Africa's military capacity would be scaled down so that it posed no threat to its neighbours.

* The fate of South Africa's armaments industry would be decided in conjunction with neighboring countries. It might be developed for the benefit of the region, or closed down.

* The structures of both the South African Development Co-ordination Conference and those of the Frontline states would be maintained after being "broadened" to include a democratic South Africa.

On diplomatic appointments by the TEC Mbeki said criteria would first have to be decided -- in particular, whether political appointments were acceptable and whether professional diplomats should be given ambassadorial posts.

The creation of a new foreign service would have to be addressed before next year's elections, with an eye on the long term. Although there was already a sprinkling of blacks in the diplomatic service, the department "needs some revamping". Some existing diplomatic personnel might be put on pension. Mbeki said, but no one would be sacked.

Although a democratic South Africa had no wish to dominate the region, ANC president Nelson Mandela was already involved in efforts to influence regional politics, he added.

He disclosed that Mandela had signed a letter to both President Eduardo dos Santos and Unita leader Jonas Savimbi in Angola, proposing a summit meeting to find a solution to that country's armed conflict. Other African countries involved in the peace mission were the Ivory Coast, Morocco and Gabon.

Mbeki insisted that South African mercenaries had to be stopped from involving themselves in the Angolan war.

He also disclosed that Nigeria's outgoing president, General Ibrahim Babangida, had had contact with Mandela, in a bid to involve South Africa as "a significant future role player" in making peace on the continent. Babangida was planing a consultancy, with the blessing of the Organisation of African Unity, which would "try to find mechanisms to resolve conflicts". -30- Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, September 3-9, 1993

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Publications.

CONTACT: THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg or The Guardian Weekly, Abney Hall, Manchester Road, Cheadle, Cheshire SK8 2PD,

United Kingdom.. Phone: 011-403-7111; fax: 011-403-1025.

EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in th U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA. 

 

An 18-day "Reality Tour" of Zimbabwe and Malawi is offered by Robyn Michaels, a former Peace Corps volunteer in conjunction with Classic Tours International. Urban areas and markets, development projects and the planning office in Blantyre, Malawi are on the itinerary; and in Zimbabwe, tourist will visit, Bulawayo, Hwange National Park and Victoria Falls. For an additional charge of $550, Nairobi and Mombasa in Kenya may be added. Travelers will need shots, anti-malarial prophylaxsis and a sleeping bag. An initial deposit of $1,000 is required by OCTOBER 15, 1993 for the tour, which is scheduled for January 19, 1994. Final payment is required by December 15, 1993. For more information, contact Paul Carpenter, Classic Tours International, 520 N. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611; phone: (312) 329-1234 or (800) 8286916 N. Wayne, Chicago, IL 60626; phone; (312) 9733663 8222; fax: (312) 642-8418; or call Robyn Michaels, MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply. DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first ten years of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE: December 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions compete in two separate categories for funding: (1) Non-research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. To request guidelines and proposal forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008- 3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. It is recommended that all institutions contact the appropriate CIES program officer for the scholar-in-residence program for advice, referral and assistance before preparing proposals. For Sub-Saharan Africa, contact Linda Rhoad at (202) 686-6230. For North Africa, contact Gary Garrison at (202) 686-4019.

-- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

The American Research Center in Egypt announces the

following fellowships in Egypt for 1994-1995: two National Endowment for the Humanities Fellowships for postdoctoral, senior scholars; the Kress Predoctoral Fellowship in Egyptian Art and Architecture; five Egyptian Development Fellowships, earmarked for Egyptian predoctoral candidates enrolled in North American universities; and fellowships from the United States Information Agency. For the Egyptian Development Fellowships, Egyptian candidates must have J1 student status and be engaged in research relating to Egyptian development. Allowances include international airfare, a living stipend, and an allowance for research expenses. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. For application, write The American Research Center in Egypt, New York University, 30 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. Phone: (212) 998 8890. Fax: (212) 995-4144.

EMPLOYMENT

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities

to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activites of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006. 

 

CUSO, a Canadian International Development Organization is recruiting for a two-and-a-half year contract for a MANAGER OF HYDROGEOLOGY AND CONSTRUCTION for its "Water for Life" project in rural Ondo State, Nigeria. The project aims to strengthen village and government institutions to enable 50,000 rural inhabitants to better meet theri water and sanitation needs. QUALIFICATIONS: an appropriate university degree, several years management level experience in the design, field implementation and evaluation of community-based sustainable handpump maintenance and repair programs; strong hands-on experience with a) master contract, subcontractor administration field supervision, b) mnitoring techniques, c) the proven ability to control drilling contractor operations in the field d) design/implementation of computerized operations monitoring; demonstratied strong leadership, comminucations and multicultural team work experience. The position salary starts at C$40,197-C$42,561, with an immediate starting date. DEADLINE: October 18. For detailed information or to apply, send resume, three references and a short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in this particular area, contact: Position NIG/93/09C, CUSO Human Resources, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 563-8068.

CUSO also seeks a MANAGER OF ACCOUNTING AND CONTROL for its "Water for Life" project. The selected candidate will serve as the project financial, accounting, and operational controller and principal advisor on all fiscal matters, with primary management responsibility for the portection of and adequate accounting for all project assets and for all assets of project-wide compueterization. QUALIFICATIONS: accounting degree, possibly MBA, with CA, CMA or CGA designation; a wide range of hands-on experience in all areas of accounting and control; field experience on large-scaleaverseas development projects; very strong multi-component budgeting, analysis and control skills; ability to devise and implement a computerized management, control and reporting systems; stong communications skills; good knowledge of donor financial reporting requirements and practices (prefereably CIDA); ability to teach fundamental of financial management to non-financial managers, present meaningfulreports to host governments and donor agencies. The position salary start at C$36,503October 15. For detailed information or to apply, send C$38,411, with an immediate starting date. DEADLINE: resume, three references and a short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in this particular area, contact: Position NIG/93/10C, CUSO Human Resources, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 563-8068.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (Rome office) seeks a SENIOR OFFICER IN LAND CONSERVATION AND REHABILITATION to manage the ongoing International Scheme for the Conservation and Rehabilitation of African Lands and the development and implementation of similar schemes for the Asia and Pacific and Latin America and Caribbean regions.

QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in soil science, agriculture, agricultural engineering or closely related subject. Ten years of progressively responsible experience in the field of soil and water conservation and land reclamation, including experience in developing countries. Working knowledge of English, French or Spanish. SALARY: US$ 64,570- $76,232 (without dependents), US$69,680-$82,781 (with dependents). DEADLINE: October 7. Contact: Executive Officer LNOR, Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437.

Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a Program Officer or Assistant Program Officer for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38- 700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an accountant for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

Qualifications: previous management experience in a developing country; fluency in English and Swahili. US$1,200 a month. One-year commitment. Immediate opening.

Requires: proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment. EPI COORDINATOR, RN to coordinate Expanded Immunization program including a selection of mobile team, training of team and field supervision of implementation. Supervise establishment and operation of cold chain facilities. Requires: experience in developing country, preferably in rural setting; extensive experience in training. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment. Requires: experience in training; and strong primary health care background. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment. ARC provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Responsibilities include: providing leadership in setting project staff goals and strategies; managing project staff, budget and other resources; and insuring appropriate services are being provided to the clients' satisfaction. VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise.

For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer- to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and

December, 1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and

December 1993 and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered): October-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.
