Africa News


October 4, 1993


EXCERPTS OF THE STATEMENT BY H.E. MR. ISAIAS AFWERKI PRESIDENT OF THE STATE OF ERITREA AT THE 48TH SESSION OF THE UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY NEW YORK, SEPTEMBER 30, 1993


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

As I speak here today, I cannot help but remember the appeals that we sent year in and year out to this Assembly and the member countries of the United Nations, describing the plight of our people and asking for legitimate sympathy, support and recognition. We appealed to the United Nations not only in its capacity as a representative of the international community, but also because of its special responsibility to Eritrea. For it was the United Nations that decided in 1950, at the beginning of the Cold War, to deny the colonized people of Eritrea their right to self-determination, thereby sacrificing their national and human rights on the altar of the strategic interests of the superpowers. 

In passing that resolution, the UN affirmed that it "remained an international instrument" which the General Assembly "could be seized of" at anytime. But for the next 41 years, as a brutal war of aggression was conducted against the Eritrean people, initially with the active support of the United States and later with a much worse and massive involvement of the Soviet Union, and despite the repeated appeals of the Eritrean people, the United Nations refused to raise its voice in the defense of a people whose future it had unjustly decided and whom it had pledged to protect. Not once in 41 years did Eritrea, scene of the longest war in Africa, and victim of some of the grossest violations of human rights, figure in the agenda of the United Nations.

At this critical juncture of our history, Eritrea needs and deserves international support and assistance, not only because the United Nations and the international community bear special responsibility for Eritrea, but also because the United Nations and the international community bear special responsibility for Eritrea, but also because it is a test case for the United Nations Agenda for Peace and the whole concept of peace-building. Eritrea has not only secured peace and stability, it has made the rare achievement of establishing warm relations of cooperation with its former enemy, Ethiopia. And it is tackling the task of reconstruction with popular support and participation, with commitment and determination, with sound and flexible policies, with prudent and efficient utilization of limited resources, with a demonstrated readiness to promote regional understanding and cooperation. Unfortunately, the response of the United Nations and the international community so far has not been encouraging.

One of the most disquieting features of the present international situation is the marginalization of the entire continent of Africa. Every indicator shows that Africa is sliding back and being left behind, resulting in intolerable poverty, suffering and desperation for millions of its people. There is no denying that the onus of the responsibility for these problems falls first and foremost on us Africans. But, I believe, the international community must squarely face the fact that it also bears responsibility for Africa's plight. Many of the dictators who have sown so much havoc and suffering were in fact brought to power and sustained during the years of the cold war by sections of the international community. Perhaps more significant, the now discredited economic policies and the failed projects, were generally designed, and approved of, by international donors and implemented under the direction of an army of foreign experts and advisors.

In view of the developments in the Horn of Africa, the tragedy that has gripped Somalia has been profoundly disturbing. As the bloodletting among our Somali brothers assumed harrowing proportions, and at a time when many were hesitating, we strongly advocated the constructive intervention of the international community, under the umbrella of the United Nations, to save lives and help extricate Somalia from the destruction it was heading for. Despite our opposition, in principle, to external military intervention, we realized early on that the extraordinary situation in Somalia demanded extraordinary measures.

It was, therefore with great relief that we welcomed the decision of the United States Administration to intervene in Somalia. Encouraged, we sought individually and in conjunction with our regional partners to ensure that the intervention be guided by clear and comprehensive security, humanitarian and political objectives. And we did not hesitate to share our views on the size, type and stay of the intervention force needed for the success of the mission. But unfortunately, our views were not heeded, although we were, and still are, better placed to understand and work in the realities of neighboring Somalia.

Be that as it may, we do recognize and appreciate the achievements of the international intervention in Somalia. The improvement of the humanitarian situation and the March 1993 Addis Ababa Accords on national reconciliation are major steps forward. At the same time, the worsening security situation in Mogadishu and the increasing toll in civilian lives, including women and children, have cast a long shadow on the Somali intervention. Repeated mistakes in handling the situation have led some people to openly call for an immediate end to the intervention.

It is our conviction that a precipitate withdrawal of United States troops -- which we strongly warned against from the beginning -- will not only signal a lack of U.S. commitment to the intervention, but it will eventually make the position of UNOSOM untenable. This will plunge Somalia into a catastrophe much worse than the anarchy that prompted the intervention in the first place.


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 4, 1993


ANC ELECTION LIST: "MEMBERS WILL DECIDE"


BYLINE: Rehana Rossouw, SOUTH


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Rehana Rossouw spoke to ANC elections commission deputy head Patrick "Terror" Lekota(right) about the list: of candidates the organisation will compile for the election:

South Africa's next president will almost certainly head the list the ANC compiles of its candidates for government.

But the organisation is in no hurry to begin drafting the list. It is promising members full participation in deciding who represents them in the national assembly.

Because the election will be held on a proportional representation basis, voters will make their crosses for political parties, not candidates. 

Each party will compile a list of 400 names.

"The national executive committee recently endorsed a process which ensures that our list will be drafted by every branch and structure of the ANC," said ANC elections commission deputy head Patrick "Terror" Lekota.

The final list will include the names of ANC members as well as alliance partners -- organisations in the tripartite alliance (ANC/South African Communist Party/Cosatu) and the Patriotic Front.

The ANC will have to juggle the nominees carefully to ensure the list meets members' expectations, that it is inclusive and gender sensitive.

ANC branches throughout the country will nominate candidates for regional lists in the next two months as well as recommend names for the national list.

"Parallel to the nominations, branches also have to begin the process of drawing up a manifesto for the elections," Lekota said.

After all the regions have nominated choices for the list, the ANC will call a national conference.

Unlike previous national conferences, participation will be scaled down, but "without compromising representivity," Lekota said.

"The purpose of the conference will be to finalise the national list and adopt the manifesto."

Once names have been forwarded, the order in which they appear will have to be finalised. Some names on the list will be of people who will not go to parliament.

"We will be asking people with credibility to endorse the list and the ANC's campaign by adding their names," Lekota said.

"These will be put at the bottom of the list, in the lower 300's, where there is little likelihood of them being asked to go to parliament."

But not all the ANC membership's candidates will make the national list. The organisation will have to retain some of their leaders to represent the ANC at regional and local government level.

Yet another consideration is leaving behind a core of leadership to continue the ANC's organisational work, although the operations will be scaled down considerably.

"We have to keep in mind that we have to reserve some people for the other important structures of government," Lekota said.

"Regional government, for instance, is going to be an important theatre of struggle for survival and the best way of interacting with people closely. So we cannot take all our best people to serve the country at a national level."

Lekota said that while drafting the list will be as democratic as possible, the nominees would have to be rationalised by another body.

"Because this is a very sensitive and complicated procedure, we will establish a national list committee comprised of people with credibility to perform this task.

"The committee will be dealing with a red hot poker, and they will have to be seen to be neutral. We are giving them the responsibility of running the process in every region. They will explain to branches how the process will work and develop criteria for the nominations."

The ANC embarked on this process after attempts by the national executive committee to draft a list for members; ratification collapsed.

There will be some room for individuals nominated to decide their fate and the list committee could rule against popular decisions.

"Obviously we cannot force someone who does not want to go to parliament to do so just because the members decided," Lekota said.

Deadlines for the process have been set. The national conference will be held at the end of November or early December, as well as conferences of the ANC's Womens' and Youth Leagues.

The manifesto and list will then be presented to voters to decide whether they have enough confidence in the ANC to make their crosses on the ballot paper next to the ANC's logo.

Reprinted from SOUTH, September 17-21, 1993. SOUTH is published by SOUTH Press Services(Pty) Ltd.

CONTACT: SOUTH, 6 Russell St, Woodstock,7925, Phone:021-462-2012, Fax:021-461-5407


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 4, 1993


PRESS RELEASE THE NIGHTMARE CONTINUES... ABUSES AGAINST SOMALI REFUGEES IN KENYA AFRICAN RIGHTS


LENGTH: 2147 words


 

September 21, 1993--The 300,000 Somali refugees in Kenya are the forgotten part of Somalia's tragedy. This report details the extraordinary level of human rights abuses that these refugees are subjected to, at the hands of bandits and the Kenyan police and army.

The abuses include rape, killing, torture, detention, extortion, robbery, deportation and forced repatriation. This is not merely a reflection of violent crime in the north-east province, nor of the actions of a few undisciplined policemen acting on their own. Responsibility for the abuses reaches to the highest levels of the Kenyan government. Kenya has a long-standing policy of keeping down its refugee population by preventing would-be refugees from crossing the border, forcibly repatriating refugees, and forcing others out by making conditions so intolerable that few can bear to stay. Members of the security forces are allowed, and even encouraged, to engage in campaigns of systematic extortion against Somali refugees. The police can rape, torture, and kill refugees safe in the knowledge that they will never be called to account.

The report contains details of more than forty instances of murder in custody by the police and army (in many cases the bodies are then burned), five cases of "disappearance" in police custody, two cases of death following severe beating, four people killed by the police opening fire indiscriminately, and one killing by bandits. It describes beating and torture carried out by the police, and arbitrary arrest and detention. 

The refugees have no recourse. Not a single policeman or soldier has been prosecuted for crimes committed against refugees. Most refugees do not even report the abuses they suffer, for fear of retaliation and because they have no confidence in the police and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). The UNHCR is failing in its duty to protect refugees. It has not provided any legal representation for refugees detained by the police, nor brought charges against any security officers guilty of crimes against refugees.

There is an epidemic of rape in the refugee camps. In the five nights spent by Alex de Waal in three camps, 22 women reported having been raped. Most were gang rapes; often the women were severely beaten

as well. This is just the tip of the iceberg: the majority of rapes go unreported, because the bandits and policemen responsible threaten retaliation against a woman who even goes to hospital for a medical examination, and because of the deep shame and lasting stigma associated with rape. Contrary to Kenyan government claims, policemen are responsible for many of the rapes.

The report documents 15 cases of rape. One is Hibo (not her real name), a 21-year old mother, raped (by three policemen in May 1993. She told African Rights how the policemen caught her in the camp marketplace:

"The policemen drove close to the people, with the headlights turned off. Everybody scattered and ran away. I didn't run, I was too afraid. I just stood there. They came down from the car and started hitting me, slapping my face. First one came and grabbed my waist and picked me from the ground and pulled me towards the car. I can recognize the face of this one. His face was very close to mine. The other two, each took one leg and pushed me into the car. When they put me inside, they were holding a fist under my chin, pushing my head up so I had to look at the roof. I was screaming. They hit me on the chest: my chest was hurting for a long time. They drove to the police compound.

"You know the police compound Ifo -- there is the residence of the police inspector, which has a small veranda, and there are two tents. They took me through the veranda, they took me to the tent. The tent was completely dark. Inside the tent there was a sponge mattress. They forced me to lie down. Because I was screaming one of them sat on my face -- I stopped screaming, I didn't have enough air to breathe.

"There was a strong alcohol smell from the men. The first one who had attacked me earlier was the one who first started raping me. It was totally dark but I could recognize his voice.

"The one who was sitting on my face, he then got up and started holding my mouth to keep me silent. Then he also started holding my nose -- I found it difficult to breathe. I felt his hands on my face for a while; then I felt weak and he stopped holding me. Then he raped me. After he raped me he started beating me with his hands; he was suffocating me again. He hit me on the head and neck. I was crying but when I started being quiet he stopped beating me.

"Then another one came and raped me. A third man -- I could recognize a different smell, and a different weight from his body. But I couldn't see his face.

"Every time they raped me, they got a cloth and rubbed my body before the other one raped me. The force they were using and the harsh material was scratching my body.

"Then, after a while, another one came. I don't know his identity. He apologized. He started speaking in Swahili, I didn't understand but he was speaking gently and I felt he was apologizing. I was still lying down. He patted my thigh and said, 'Sorry, lady, sorry.' Then he sat at the corner of the tent and lit a cigarette -- this was the first light I had seen. Then I got up, stood up. He accompanied me to the front gate of the compound.

"I left empty-handed. I had left all my things, the basket and thermos, in the market. I started walking towards the market. I saw a lamp lit in a kiosk. Men were chewing khat and talking about me and the incident. They recognized me, made me sit down, and said my mother had been there looking for me, but had been too scared to go to the inspector's house, and had gone back to her tent instead. They could see my bruises. They could see what had happened but they didn't ask. They gave me some water to wash and drink. I rested for a few minutes. Then, seven men accompanied me back to my tent.

"My mother was there. The oldest man stayed a little while, talking about repatriation. I didn't want to say anything. When all the men had left, I told my mother everything. My mother started making a fire to warm some water so I could clean my body. We made a decision that we should repatriate to Somalia as soon as possible. I felt, it's better for the shiftas (bandits) in my own country to do this to me, so I don't have to blame any government that is hosting me.

"Any time I remember this story I feel anger, hopelessness, because I am a Moslem, and I believe that God has meant me to go through this hard life and only God can help me forget this problem."

After she was raped, Hibo went to hospital for a medical examination. When the police learned this, they started searching for her, presumably intending to ensure her silence by intimidating her or even killing her. Since that time, Hibo and her daughter (aged six) have been living as fugitives, running from place to place. The UNHCR has declined to offer her any special protection. Hibo is currently trying to obtain resettlement to a third country as she is no longer safe in Kenya.

The Kenyan government and police have repeatedly dismissed evidence of widespread rape by the security forces, saying that women allege rape in order to try to obtain third country resettlement or other assistance. UNHCR has appointed a specialist rape consultant, but it has failed to provide any protection for women vulnerable to rape or for rape victims. There are no specialist gynaecologists available to refugees. It has not brought charges against any security officers guilty of rape. UNHCR is not treating the rape crisis with the seriousness it warrants.

The threat of forced repatriation hangs over the refugees. Many were sent back to Somalia in 1991 -- in one incident, 37 refugees drowned when the Kenyan navy tried to force them back to Somalia in an unseaworthy boat. The government refused to allow adequate relief supplies and services in the refugee camps, creating an unnecessary disaster in which tens of thousands of refugees died in 1991 and 1992. There have been several mass round-ups of supposed refugees in the major towns, for deportation to the camps. Kenyan Somalis and Somalis with European passports and travel documents have been rounded up by policemen who refuse to recognize any documents and are just determined to remove anyone who physically resembles a Somali. Now the government is insisting on a rapid programme of return to Somalia, arguing that Operation Restore Hope has removed the refugees' reasons for wanting to leave Somalia. However, few preparations have been made for their arrival and most refugees have little confidence that they will be able to go back in safety.

The UNHCR is failing in its duty to protect refugees. It merely passes reports of police abuses on to the police -- who ignore them or threaten the victims. It has not taken out a single court case on behalf of a refugee, and has refused to cooperate with refugees who have tried to bring private prosecutions. Although refugees are arbitrarily arrested and detained every day, it provides no legal assistance to refugees to prevent them from being illegally repatriated, detained on spurious charges, extorted of money or valuables, beaten or raped. Although UNHCR field staff have expressed grave concern about theses violations, UNHCR headquarters in Geneva has displayed little interest. Its staff scarcely ever even visits the camps. UNHCR headquarters has failed to make any public condemnation of the security forces abuses. On the contrary its policy is to placate the Kenyan government.

The refugees are also victims of a very high level of crime in north-east Kenya. Banditry has been endemic in the area for thirty years, partly as a consequence of a long history of neglect and repression. Refugees are easy targets for bandits. The police are outgunned and justifiably afraid of the bandits; as a result they do very little to protect the refugees from armed robbery and rape by the bandits. Greater police protection is needed -- but when the government does send reinforcements the bandits merely scatter and the security forces take out reprisals on the refugees.

The report concludes with a series of recommendations for the government and UNHCR. African Rights calls upon the government to investigate abuses committed by the security forces and prosecute those responsible. A few convictions for murder and rape would dramatically change the attitude of the security forces towards the refugees, and would encourage the refugees to report abuses. We call for special assistance to the victims of rape, and for improving the protection of refugees form bandits.

Reprinted from AFRICAN RIGHTS, September 21,1993

Contact: AFRICAN RIGHTS, 11 Marshalsea Road, London, Tel: 071 403 3383, Fax: 071 403 4023. -30SOUTH, September 17-21, 1993


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 4, 1993


MOVE FAST ON ECOWAS CURRENCY: TO SAVE SUB-REGIONAL TRADE


BYLINE: SIR DAWDA, DAILY OBSERVER, Friday, September 3, 1993


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

The President, Sir Dawda K. Jawara, has hinted that the time may at last have come when the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) should expedite its search for a common currency for the sub- region.

The serious and expeditious search for a common West African currency will be a matter of urgent priority, he said, unless the current crisis surrounding the CFA franc is resolved soon. A delay in the resolution of the CFA crisis, he warned, could have "serious repercussions for sub-regional trade, unless ECOWAS comes forward with a common currency".

President Jawara made those remarks in an interview with the Brussels-based Courier magazine published by the European Community's African- Caribbean-Pacific (ACP) bureau. 

He said the CFA franc was the currency of sub- regional trade and its restriction will affect countries in the entire subregion, whether they are members or non-members of the franc zone.

It was the President's first public statement on the issue since the decision on August 2 by the West African Monetary Union (UMOA) to suspend the repurchase of CFA bank notes circulating outside the franc zone.

Making the sudden and dramatic announcement a month ago, the Governor of the Banque Centrale Des Etats d'Afrique Occidentale (BCEAO), Mr. Charles Konan Bany, said the objective of the measure was to arrest what he called "the large-scale and fraudulent exportation of notes", especially by business people in the informal sector, who used the CFA franc as a means of payment and transaction.

Though Mr. Bany chose not to mention it, the real reason for the plunge in the CFA was the temporary losses sustained by the French franc in late July, following the raising by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, of its interest rate. As an immediate and direct reaction, the French franc was devalued; and although it regained its position, the jolt to the French economic, financial and political establishment was enough for the government to take some immediate and drastic measures.

One of the first such measures was to drop the CFA, so to speak, like hot potato. This meant the Bank of France was no longer in a position to guarantee the CFA franc, thus retreating from the policy which they pursued for over nearly a quarter century. This policy was one of the pillars of the French hegemony in West Africa.

If the plunge of the CFA hit Banjul and other Anglophone capitals like a thunderbolt, it sent even more devastating shockwaves throughout Francophone Africa, the repercussions of which are evident in the current crisis in our sister Republic of Senegal.

In his press interview, Sir Dawda noted that trade is the main pillar of sub-regional integration and the currency crisis was directly hitting at that pillar.

Until the CFA franc returns to convertability, business people both within and outside UMOA will have to look for alternative convertible currencies to lubricate trade within the subregion, he said. "But," he added, "we have to wait and see how the situation evolves."

Asked to comment on the slow progress towards West African integration since the founding of ECOWAS 18 years ago, Sir Dawda said he believed that economic difficulties and political instability within member states were responsible.

President Jawara was Chairman of ECOWAS in 1990 when the most serious case of instability in West Africa in recent years erupted namely, the civil war in Liberia. Thanks to his astute leadership and the forthrightness and determination of President Babangida of Nigeria and then Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings of Ghana, other ECOWAS leaders, and their brave men who comprise the peace-keeping force ECOMOG, the hostilities have ceased and peace seems to be taking hold in that war-ravaged country.

Turning to the domestic political scene, Sir Dawda said he had no fears of instability in the country when he was no longer president. He declared, "We have a long tradition of democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and tolerance, and I am optimistic that this country will remain stable when I am no longer in charge."

Commenting on the professed aim to make The Gambia "the Singapore of West Africa", the President said this was a dream but no wild one. The country's economic adjustment measures (the ERP and PSD) have gone so well that we have created a conducive atmosphere for investment.

All the necessary legislative framework for such investments has also been laid, he added.

The Courier asked Sir Dawda what he thought of the LOME Conventions as the framework for cooperation between the European Community and ACP member states. The President said he thought LOME was a good format but after nearly 20 years, it needed to be revised and improved upon. He was, however, critical of the slow disbursement of funds under the Stabilisation of Export scheme (STABEX).

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, Friday, September 3, 1993. DAILY OBSERVER is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd.

Contact: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131, The Gambia. Phone:(220) 496608, 496877, 496878; Fax: (220) 96878


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 4, 1993


TRANSITION IN BURUNDI: THE CONTEXT FOR A HOMECOMING


BYLINE: from NEWS, September 16, 1993 The U.S. Committee For Refugees


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

September 15,1993--More than 240,000 Burundian refugees remain in exile in Tanzania, Rwanda, and Zaire. Most fled Burundi following recurrent outbreaks of inter-ethnic conflict that killed nearly 200,000 people during the past thirty years. While members of the ruling Tutsi elite and the Tutsi-dominated army consolidated power and influence, many of Burundi's majority Hutu sought protection outside Burundi's borders. In many cases, the land and homes they left behind were taken over by Tutsi.

Now, however, fair and peaceful elections have taken place in Burundi, enabled by a forward thinking government led by (now former) President Pierre Buyoya. For Burundians in exile, the peaceful transition of power to Frodebu, a largely Hutu political party, brought their homecoming closer. According to a report released today by the U.S. Committee for Refugees, "Today is the most positive political moment Burundi has experienced since independence. The refugees are welcome home." Having successfully navigated these treacherous political waters, Burundi must now continue its transition to a state in which members of all ethnic groups are treated as equals. 

The report, TRANSITION IN BURUNDI: THE CONTEXT FOR A HOMECOMING, was written by Catherine Watson, an internationally recognized expert on the modern history of Rwanda and Burundi. Watson is also author of a 1991 USCR publication, EXILE FROM RWANDA: BACKGROUND TO AN INVASION.

The new USCR report chronicles Burundi's little- known but traumatic post-independence history. It examines the very real fear of the Tutsi that they will be swamped, dispossessed, exiled, and killed by the Hutu, and the equally real fear and pain of the Hutu, who for decades had their self-respect and modest aspirations crushed and lived in dread of massacres. It looks at why Burundi generated hundreds of thousands of refugees in the last thirty years.

The report then looks at Burundi's refugee problem: the politics of Burundi's exile community, past attempts to bring the refugees home, and what the remaining refugees say they want before they will feel it safe to return.

Today, Burundian refugees wait to see what future lies in store for them, should they return. Only a few thousand have returned so far in 1993. But now that Frodebu is in power, it is likely that many refugees will come flooding home. The paper considers the question: Is the country ready to receive them, or will this threaten the delicate political dynamic, risking the creation of more violence and another exodus?

In order to make possible the return of Burundian refugees, and to ensure continued positive developments inside Burundi, the U.S. Committee for Refugees makes the following recommendations:

* Burundi's new government should deal with the Tutsi community with great sensitivity, building confidence and bridges of understanding. The Tutsi community will need to be self-critical and honest, and accept that it has enjoyed privileges in the past.

* Reforms in Burundi's army are imperative. Many Burundian refugees say they will not return home until there are Hutu soldiers.

* A human rights commission should be formed to help Burundians sort out the tragedies of their past, and to move toward peace with one another.

* The new government must seek out and work with leaders of the exile community to ensure that refugees have realistic expectations for when they return. * A new commission must determine what happened to Hutu properties that have been misappropriated. If returning land to its rightful owner is not handled seriously and with fairness, violence could result. The land issue is key to the successful repatriation of the refugees. * The international community should carefully monitor equity and human rights issues, and press the new government of Burundi to institute a culture of transparency and accountability. * Refugees from Burundi will need assistance from asylum countries and from the international community as they return home. It is critically important that the UN system and donor governments make available the resources that are needed to make repatriation successful and reconciliation possible. The governments of Tanzania, Rwanda, and Zaire should ensure that refugees are not pressured to repatriate prematurely under unsafe conditions. * The international community must support and foster national reconciliation in neighboring Rwanda and, when safety is assured, the repatriation of Rwandan refugees in Burundi. Unsettled conditions in Rwanda could destroy the progress being made in Burundi.

The U.S. Committee for Refugees, a private, nonprofit organization, accepts no government funds, and is supported by foundations and individual contributions. NEWS is published by the U.S. Committee for Refugees.

Contact: Virginia Hamilton (202) 347-3507


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.

EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3094 words


 

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accomodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Mali Senegal, October 30-November 12, 1993; Cameroon, November 15-29, 1993; Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July

10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF-Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919;

phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628- 9314.

foreign service staff employee salary. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1,

1993. Applications available from: The Center for African Studies, University of Illinois, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820;

phone: (217) 333-6335.

Hotline." Applications available from: The Center for African Studies, University of Illinois, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL

61820; phone: (217) 333-6335; or through Kristen Lee,

Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and qualifying exams prior to

receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain

applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities offers African Humanities Fellowships to support postdoctoral scholars and students in the final stages of their dissertation write-up. Scholars will participate in a residential seminar on "Powers of Expression and Expression

of Power." Contact: African Humanities Institute, SSRC, 605

The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program provides support for post graduate research in areas of economic development. Proposals for 1994 should relate to either privatisation or

education for women. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005;

roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation,

The Humanities Research Centre of the Australian National University offers Visiting Fellowships for scholars to conduct research relating to Africa. The center will also be

organizing three conferences on Africa. DEADLINE: OCTOBER

31, 1993. Contact: Centre Administrator, Humanities Research Centre, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT 0200,

Australia; fax: (06) 248-0054.

MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this

series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science,

MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590.

Fax: (517) 336-1091. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University

The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply.

DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL

FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first ten years of their postdoctoral

careers. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212)

661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Fulbright Scholar-in-Residence Program assists U.S. colleges and universities in hosting visiting scholars from abroad for one or both terms of the 1994-95 academic year. The program is designed to initiate or develop international programs or strengthen and enrich existing international or area studies programs. The resident scholar may teach regular courses or develop new ones, team teach or participate in special seminars and serve as a resource to faculty, students and the community at large. Preference is given to proposals in the humanities or social sciences, and in 1994-95, proposals related to Islamic societies and civilization are of special interest. U.S. institutions

compete in two separate categories for funding: (1) Non- research institutions devoted primarily to undergraduate education, or (2) Research institutions that have both graduate and undergraduate programs. Institutional proposals for Africa are limited solely to the first category.

DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. To request guidelines and

proposal forms, contact: Scholar-in-Residence Program, Council for International Exchange of Scholars (CIES), 3007 Tilden Street, NW, Suite 5M, Washington, D.C. 20008-3009. Scholars from abroad may not apply directly to CIES for these awards. It is recommended that all institutions contact the appropriate CIES program officer for the scholar-in-residence program for advice, referral and assistance before preparing proposals. For Sub-Saharan Africa, contact Linda Rhoad at (202) 686-6230. For North Africa, contact Gary Garrison at (202) 686-4019. -- Tuesday Bulletin, Michigan State University

The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA,

December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250.

The American Research Center in Egypt announces the

following fellowships in Egypt for 1994-1995: two National Endowment for the Humanities Fellowships for postdoctoral, senior scholars; the Kress Predoctoral Fellowship in Egyptian Art and Architecture; five Egyptian Development Fellowships, earmarked for Egyptian predoctoral candidates enrolled in North American universities; and fellowships from the United States Information Agency. For the Egyptian Development Fellowships, Egyptian candidates must have J1 student status and be engaged in research relating to Egyptian development. Allowances include international airfare, a living stipend, and an allowance for research

expenses. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. For application, write The American Research Center in Egypt, New York University,

30 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. Phone: (212)

998-8890. Fax: (212) 995-4144.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to

December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State

University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353- 1700.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey,

Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA

02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with

Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910

South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333- 6335.

Northwestern University announces the 1994-1995 competition for a residency fellowship with the Program of African Studies. Candidates must be black South Africans who want to take part in the activities of the Program of African

Studies. They also must be either: engaged in the study of Africa in any field of the humanities or social sciences and are at least at the post-MA level; or, writers or artists engage in creative projects. Fellowship of US$12,000 will for one half-year (four and a half months) and will also include one round-trip economy airfare between place of

residence and Chicago. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: South African Fellowship Program, Progam of African Studies, Northwestern University, 620 Library Place, Evanston, IL

60208; phone: (708) 491-7323; fax: (708) 491-3739.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 3907 words


 

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a REGIONAL INFORMATION AND P-4 COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER in Cairo, Egypt. Qualifications required include a university degree in aggriculture or social sciences or communication/journalism or other related field. Seven years of progressively responsible professional experience in the field of information and development support communication, production and use of audio-visual materials, and training in communication. Experience in press, radio and TV management. Working knowledge of Arabic, English and French.

Salary ranges: US$52,797 to $66,205 (without dependents) and

US$56,770 to $71,560 (with dependents). CLOSING DATE:

NOVEMBER 23, 1993. Contact: Executive Director, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20437. 

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to

Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activites of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable.

Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

CUSO, a Canadian International Development Organization is recruiting for a two-and-a-half year contract for a MANAGER OF HYDROGEOLOGY AND CONSTRUCTION for its "Water for Life" project in rural Ondo State, Nigeria. The project aims to strengthen village and government institutions to enable 50,000 rural inhabitants to better meet theri water and

sanitation needs. QUALIFICATIONS: an appropriate university degree, several years management level experience in the design, field implementation and evaluation of community- based sustainable handpump maintenance and repair programs; strong hands-on experience with a) master contract, subcontractor administration field supervision, b) mnitoring techniques, c) the proven ability to control drilling contractor operations in the field d) design/implementation of computerized operations monitoring; demonstratied strong leadership, comminucations and multicultural team work experience. The position salary starts at C$40,197-C$42,561,

with an immediate starting date. DEADLINE: October 18. For detailed information or to apply, send resume, three references and a short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in this particular area,

contact: Position NIG/93/09C, CUSO Human Resources, 135

Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 563-8068.

positions available:

DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Africa. assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC

20526. DEADLINE: Open.

assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC

20526. DEADLINE: Open.

QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps training experience competency-based language training; coordinating pre-service training activities; demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledgable about issues of international development; proven flexibility and

leadership. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region,

1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs., to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status.

Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary

hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100;

Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff.

Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and

salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv

International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

245 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison,

AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following

nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; October and December,

1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December

1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general

surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; October and December 1993

and May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House.

Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one-month considered):

October-December 1993: The school of Health Sciences in Lilongwe will serve as the training site for a program providing education support in the area of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472- 1288.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December

1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box

65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby

Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

LANGUAGE: English

University of Benin. Contact: Jacqueline Samuda at Phelps Stokes Fund (202) 862-2613.

Munini Martine Nole, president, Rassemblement des nationalistes democrates (political party); member, Executive Council and Strategies Commission of the Holy Union Opposition; member, High Council of the Republic.

Contact: Jacqueline Samuda at Phelps Stokes Fund (202) 862- 2613.

250 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1993


CGF OUTRUNS MARKET LEADERS


BYLINE: SOUTH (South Africa), October 1-5, 1993


LENGTH: 854 words


 

A study of South Africa's first socially responsible investment fund revealed it would have performed better than market leaders in the industry over a five year period.

Commissioned by the National Union of Mineworkers, the study coincides with the maiden annual results of the Community Growth Fund (CGF).

The CGF gave investors a return of 16,3 percent, well above the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) All Share Index and inflation.

The Fund has 17 criteria for investment, including companies placing a high priority on job creation, good industrial relations which include recognition of centralised bargaining, training offered, opportunities for women and affirmative action. 

The fund attracted R44,8 million since starting in June last year, and continues to attract new investors which include retirement funds, savings groups and individuals.

The National Union of Mineworkers, a large investor in CGF, compared their approved shares with various market leaders over three and five years. This notional CGF portfolio beat all the market leaders over three years, and all but one over five years.

The CGF is only a year old -- too young for concrete comparisons.

However, a theoretical portfolio was constructed and tracked back to 1988. The returns of this portfolio were then compared to two other unit trusts -- the market leader in terms of performance and the market leader in terms of size.

The results startled researchers at the Labour

Research Service, which carried out the study: the notional Community Growth Fund portfolio beat the top performing fund over three years, and came close over five years. And the portfolio beat the unit trust industry's largest fund every year over five years.

The notional CGF portfolio also beat the JSE (JSE) Overall Index and the JSE Industrial Index, as well as inflation over three and five years.

The researchers also compared shares approved by the CGF with those rejected by participating unions. Again, the socially responsible portfolio won easily. The unions controlling the CGF have approved 21 shares -- used to construct the national portfolio -- and rejected 10.

Over five years, the approved shares would have returned 32,9 percent a year, while rejected shares achieved 26,6 percent.

Socially responsible investing pays, said NUM's General Secretary, Mr. Kgalena Motlanthe.

He said the five-year study should comfort investors. "We always believed that it was possible to combine good performance with social responsibility .

The unions participating in the CGF have been tough on companies that have failed to meet their standards. But they have been responsible enough to select a good range of well- managed companies that satisfy CGF requirements. And now we know that these companies are also top performers on the JSE."

Motlanthe added that there was a perception that the unions would go for companies with "soft" managements. And some critics believed profitable companies were those which squeezed workers hardest.

"The study has proved these perceptions wrong. Good management today must also mean good industrial relations and good relations with the union.

"Companies that adopt a hostile attitude to their workers are obviously getting lower productivity and industrial strife. CGF is selecting companies with good management all round, including social issues."

The CGF is managed by Syfrets Managed Assets. While Motlanthe agreed that Syfrets has to get credit for selecting the initial portfolio, he added that the performance study showed that the union's involvement had actually added value to the portfolio -- the approved shares performed better than the rejected shares proposed by Syfrets.

"The union's role has been vindicated," he said.

SOUTH, October 1-5, 1993.

SOUTH is published by SOUTH Press Services (Pty) Ltd.

Contact: SOUTH Newspaper, 6 Russell St., Woodstock, 7925,

South Africa. Phone: (27-21) 462-2012, Fax: (27-21) 461- 5407.


LOAD-DATE: October 20, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1993


WHO GIVES AN OSLOBODENJE ABOUT ANGOLA?


BYLINE: MISA FREE PRESS (Namibia), October '93


LENGTH: 787 words


 

The Gallant independent Sarajevo newspaper Oslobodenje has become a household name around the world. But few people have heard of the Sindicato dos Jornalistas Angolanos (SJA).

And yet, like the journalists of Oslobodenje, the 250 or so members of the SJA, Angola's only independent media organisation, are battling to keep press freedom alive in their country.

Only, unlike Oslobodenje, which has been publishing for 50 years, the SJA is starting its campaign from scratch in a country where the media has never been free. 

Members of the SJA have nothing, not even typewriters, with which to realise their dream of starting an independent newspaper and radio station midst the rubble of their war- shattered country.

Like the country's journalists, the war in Angola is also largely ignored by the outside world. Claiming the lives of more than 1000 people a day, and having caused the displacement of millions of others, the Angolan war must surely be as devastating as the Bosnian conflict.

But there is no saturation satellite TV coverage for Angola -- only a handful of reports buried in the foreign pages. Even in the southern African media, little is seen and heard about our brothers and sisters in Angola.

Of course, the war in 'Angola has also taken its toll on the media, just as the fighting has made journalism a highly treacherous profession in Bosnia.

Angolan television reporter Elipidio Inacio was at least the fifth journalist to be killed in less than a year when he was caught in crossfire while covering the battle for Cuito on August 23.

Three months previously, two radio journalists -- Jose Maria Santos and Jose Manuel -- were murdered by as-yet unknown assassins in the coastal town of Lobito. The police said they had identified suspects for the killings, but as yet no arrests have been made.

On December 4, doctor and editor of the political and cultural weekly Jango, David Barnardino, was gunned down in his Huambo surgery.

Six weeks previously he had witnessed the murder of his writer-friend Fernando Marcelino, who was killed with his wife and sister when gunmen burst into Bernardino's home and opened fire as the four ate dinner together.

Meanwhile, Bela Malaquias a radio journalist with UNITA's Radio Vorgan has been held under house arrest by the rebel movement since June 1992.

These are the most outstanding cases illustrating the perils facing journalists in Angola, although countless other cases of intimidation and assault have been reported.

In a bid to investigate the Angolan media situation, and to expose the country's unfolding tragedy to the outside world, MISA is to send a "task force" to Angola as a matter of utmost urgency.

"One is forced to single out Angola as a country which has received scant attention," says MISA Chairperson, Gwen Lister. "And yet it is a tragi c situation where the death toll is more than the number of deaths in Bosnia and Somalia combined.

The SJA is appealing to anyone disposing of old but working typewriters to donate them to the union. This goes for any equipment which can be used by the SJA in its bid to launch an independent newspaper and radio station.

Meanwhile, the SJA is looking for funds to carry out a feasibility study into its proposed newspaper, and would also like to hear from funders who might be willing to support their newspaper and radio venture further.

The SJA can be contacted either direct on Tel.+2442334060/Fax.392216/PO Box 6375, Launda, Angola (ask for Avelino Miguel or Antonio Gouveia), or via MISA Head Quarters (Tel./Fax. +264 61 32975, PO Box 20783, Windhoek, Namibia.)

Reprinted from MISA Free Press-October '93

MISA FREE PRESS is published by MISA (Namibia).

CONTACT: MISA HEAD OFFICE, P.O. Box 20783, Windhoek,

Namibia, phone/fax: (264 61) 32975.


LOAD-DATE: October 20, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1993


DREAMS, SHATTERED DREAMS: A SPECIAL REPORT ON NIGERIA'S ECONOMY


BYLINE: Ray Ekpu, NEWSWATCH (Nigeria), October 4, 1993


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 2774 words


 

In The Closing Days of The Independence campaign, Nigerian leaders must have looked forward to a great future for the country. Why not? Independence was at hand and they didn't have to fire a shot or spill an ounce of blood, either of the colonialist of the native or of the soldier of fortune. Things seemed to have been all arranged in heaven, and heaven is where things are done perfectly. So Nigerians started slapping each other's backs, why not, after all, independence was about to be delivered on a platter of gold. The flag of the oppressors would be down, our own flag would be up; we would sing our anthem merrily and our own men, our own black men from amongst us, would be in charge. 

Besides, we had quite a lot going for us. Our people are energetic and hardworking and could work in the factories and farms from sun-up to sun-down. The weather is generally good just as the land is a lush, green velvet carpet in most parts of the country and all of these would guarantee a rich harvest. Once you sink your fingers into the soil, it would smile at you with a bumper harvest. Of course, 80 percent of the population was engaged in farming- -feeding their families and feeding the country's export market. By 1960, 85 percent of the country's foreign exchange earnings came from the export of agricultural produce--palm oil and kernels, cocoa, groundnuts, rubber, timber, and livestock.

As a bonus point, we found oil under our feet, which made the story even sweeter and our future even more rosy. We knew we had gold in Ilesha, precious stones in Jos, uranium in Gombe but of course oil was the king of them all. By 1958, just two years shy independence, the petro-dollars had started trickling in and by the time the civil war broke out in 1967 oil had assumed a position of eminence. It is by its grace that Nigeria was able to conduct the civil war without knocking at the money lender's abroad. But the First National Development Plan (1962-68) had to be extended to 1970 on account of the war. The war over, the federal government launched a new plan, the 2nd (1970-74) which was largely expected to be a reconstruction and rehabilitation plan.

The rise in the importance of oil occasioned by the rise in its price brought about a fall in the attention that the nation paid to agriculture. People made a cityward swing, abandoning their villages and farms and poverty in search of the holy grail of cash and employment and enjoyment in the cities. The farms suffered, food supply shrank, the cities swelled, they became more congested, but the hopes and dreams of the invaders remained just what they

were: hope and dreams. the government looked into its vaults, found them brimming with petro-dollars, and went crazy. The Third National Development Plan (1975-80) originally designed to cost N33 billion was now revised to N43 billion because of the whopping revenue from oil. The government found the windfall overwhelming and bothered about how it could exhaust these jumbo finances in double

quick times so it went in search of grandiosities: it built airports where no plane lands; steel parts that produce no steel; a national theatre that works like an oven; roads and flyovers that sprawl like a spaghetti; we also shopped around for handicapped countries that we could help and rounded off our big-ticket projects with a grand-ballroom called FESTAC77, a feast whose exact cost no one knows till this day.

As the government showed this way, the people, the rich ones among them, followed. Even the not-s0-rich having been blessed with the Udoji awards bonanza went into town to show off their wealth. Bicycles were changed to motorcycles, and motorcycles to cars. Stereo, television and radio sets, cookers, washing machines and other electronic devices were snapped up in the shops and markets. The rich Nigerians, God bless them, who are perpetually in search of outlets for self-expression seized the chance with both hands. They imported everything from toothpick to tooth-brush. The car lovers sped for customised Mercedes, or Maserati or Bentley or Lexus or Rolls or Lamborghini or if they were greedy enough, they went for all of them. Those who cared for champagne ensured it was vintage and customised--with their names on it, of course. So the imports rolled in and we had our armadas--our rice armada, our cement armada and other armadas that choked our ports and our purses. We used pens from Korea, T-shirts from America, telephone sets from Japan, chewing gum from Britain, toothpaste from Italy. By the close of the 70s crude oil had become our golden gateway to goodies and by the dawn of the 80s it became our pernicious path to perdition.

With the barrels of oil money came profligacy of the unabashed kind, and corruption of the over-the-table kind. Contracts were awarded and executed on paper while the money found its way into coded accounts abroad. Where the contracts executed at all the cost was mind-boggling when compared with costs in other developing countries. According to the Report of the Ministerial Committee on the Causes of the Excessively High cost of Government Contracts in Nigeria (1981) the cost of complete irrigation schemes per hectare in Liberia was N250, Cote d'Ivoire N500, Ghana N1,068, Nigeria (average)N2,470. Nigeria (Bakalori) N7,540.

Also, in 1979 the cost of one tonne of cement in Nigeria was N72, Kenya N50.82 and Algeria N35.40 while the aggregate unit cost of building and road projects in Nigeria in the same year was at least, 130 percent higher than in Algeria and 200 percent higher than in Kenya. Some commentators have characterised this boom-spend period as party time, a time when Nigeria had a ball, a great feast, got drunk on it and broke the bottles and glasses and left behind a mammoth mess. The oil-bust period of the 80s has also been characterised as the day after the hangover, the day for clearing and cleaning the mess, for picking the pieces, for wondering what hit you.

So despite our various development plans, various policies and laws (Indigenisation Decree, Land Use Decree) and vast oil sales Nigeria wound up at the beginning of the 80s as a nation that exported oil the sales with which it imported food, as a nation that had substantially squandered its patrimony and was ready for the debt penalty. Olusegun Obasanjo, head of state 1976-79) imposed a set of austerity measures in 1978 in the effort to curb the country's gluttonous appetite for imports. It was too little too late. It would probably have brought some measure of sanity into the economy if the new civilian president, Shehu Shagari had not bowed to the pressures of political expediency and swung open all the doors. Once more it was business as usual.

When Awolowo, leader of the UPN, pointed at the red light and the fact that we might soon run out of gas and get stuck in the night he was shouted down. The government's apologists said we were in no danger at all, but were clearly coasting home. We soon found out that home was hell, it was high bills and low revenue, it was the IMF's door, it was high prices and low wages, it was a job-today-none- tomorrow.

Muhammadu Buhari, The new head of state who took over from Shagari, attempted an iron-fisted discipline of lousy Nigerians, killing drug merchants, jailing currency offenders and regulating the economy to the point of asphyxiation. For him the way out of the currency crunch was oil swap otherwise called counter trade. But Buhari didn't sit around long enough for the full fruits of this measure to be realised before he was chucked out by Ibrahim Babangida.

Babangida made a few opening salvos that indicated he meant to deregulate and unshackle the economy. He abolished the notorious import license system, declared open a national debate on whether or not we should do business with the IMF and when Nigerians returned a resounding No he said we'd do it our own way. It turned out to be not our own way, but the IMF's way plus. The IMF and World Bank brought their desks into the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, and told us they wanted a structural adjustment programme, a massive devaluation of the naira, a 100 percent deregulation of the economy, privatisation of government enterprises and the removal of all forms of subsidy including the one n petroleum products. We tried hard to please the boss in the hope that they would put in a kind word for us on our debts- -or forgive us our sins of profligacy.

We introduced SFEM, then FEM and IFEM -- all in the effort to find a realistic rate of the naira. The aim was to let the currency float and find its level. Being a currency that has no lifebouy the naira sank, sank from 58 kobo to the dollar in 1980 to N1.52 to the dollar in 1986 and all the way down to N40 to the dollar in 1993. That's how far the naira has travelled on the road to ruin. Can you name 10 things you can buy with naira today? That's a quiz you can hardly win.

Since SAP, inflation has risen like a meteor from 51 percent in June 1989 to 95 percent in 1993. Interest rates have shot through the roof-from 10 percent in 1987 to anything-goes percent in 1993. There has been an explosion in the banking and finance industry from less than 40 banks in 1980 to more than 180 banks, mortgage banks and dozens of road-side finance houses which have managed in the last two years to send some of their creditors to their early graves

by default in payment. However, some currency speculators have also made a killing.

The cumulative effect of most of these measures has been, on the positive side, to liberate the creative energy of the people and to excite innovativeness. The negative aspects have been a massive loss of jobs by private and public sector employees, closures, takeovers and mergers of companies and extremely low capacity utilisation by surviving companies. Of course, the big multi-nationals have, like the whale swallowed their "neighbors."

The CBN report 1992 indicates that Nigerian Newsprint Manufacturing Company's capacity utilisation rate was 13.3 percent, Nigerian Machine Tools 8 percent, a few have been higher, most lower. This low production puts a strain on the employment situation and this is not substantially salvaged by the establishment of the National Directorate of Employment NDE, or the National Apprenticeship Scheme or even by the envisaged efficiency and therefore expansion that privatisation was supposed to bring about.

Certainly, we're in the dark, stark woods. The Manufacturing Association of Nigeria, MAN, says that 700 of its 1500 members have closed shop since 1987. There are many more companies which have gone under but are not in the elite roll book of the MAN. They've therefore died unsung-- no wreaths, no funeral oration.

Today, the economy is in a pathetic shape, made even more pathetic by the massive deficit and the political crisis. The budget surplus for 1992 was forecast to be N2 billion but we recorded a rumbling N44 billion deficit. The 1993 deficit was expected to be N28 billion but by June we had already gone into a hole with a N41 billion deficit. These cold statistics may not make sense to the layman but all they need to know is that they spell trouble for everyone except the very, very rich who have a cushion to sit on.

But there's even more to worry about. In 1980/81 oil was sold for $40 a barrel, today it's gone down to $14, meaning that the 1993 budget which was based on $17 a barrel is catching cold fast. The various strikes we've had this year have also affected production making the industry a very vulnerable though vital artery. The refineries in Port Harcourt, Warri and Kaduna have not been able to meet the consumption needs of the country and the situation would probably have been tragic but for the 4th refinery in Port Harcourt. But even with massive importation of petroleum products there are still gross shortages nation-wide and this has given rise to a resurrection by the petroleum ministry of the controversial subsidy debate.

Nigeria has 100 years reserve of gas, which may be the reason we are pussy-footing over the Liquefied Natural Gas, LNG, a project that should produce four million tonnes per year. While we've been dragging our feet, Indonesia which started at about the same time as Nigeria has built five plants. The same slow pace of development has affected the development of the petrochemical plants. Although the first phase has been completed -- and carbon black produced -- the next and more advantageous phase is yet to be completed.

But then even as we struggle to complete these projects we have existing debts to worry about. Currently, we spend about 1/3 of our export earnings to service $28 billion debt. The result is that we have only peanuts left for development projects. Real income has plummeted 10 times since 1985 while wages are crawling behind it. Amenities have deteriorated though their charges have gone up. Agriculture is in a state of abject neglect, imports are increasing while exports are nothing to write home about. The source-economic triangle is getting narrower at the apex, denoting a small, fabulously rich minority, and broader at the base denoting a greater pauperisation of the masses and the systematic elimination of the middle class, the engine room of any nation's development. According to the

World Bank report in 1988: Nigerians who lived in 1968 were better off than those who lived in 1988." That is not a great testimonial for SAP.

Nigeria is good at talking about diversification. Indonesia is better at practising it. An oil-producing country like Nigeria, Indonesia's non-oil export was only 20 percent in 1983, today it is 60 percent. In 1983 Nigeria's non-oil exports were less than 10 percent; today it is still less than 10 percent or something like that. I say something like that because it is not fashionable to have correct statistics in Nigeria.

If you disagree answer this quiz: How much has Nigeria spent on ECOMOG so far?

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, September 27, 1993

NEWSWATCH is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited,

CONTACT: NEWSWATCH, No. 3 Billings Way (off Secretarial Road), Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B/ 21499,

Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Phone:(234-1) 496-0950; fax: (234-1) 220-96878.

LENGTH: 2205 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell StampUs Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

*CFA Franc Q Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo. ** commercial rate

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 134 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development. 

* Video Equipment. A.I.D. Grant # 263-0132. IFB # 8059-55. Purchaser: Morrison Knudsen Engineers, Procurement and Transportation, P.O. Box 7808, Boise, ID 83729, Attn: Pete Bailey; phone: (208) 386-5403. Fax and phone offers will not be accepted. BID OPENING DATE: NOVEMBER 8. Send a check for US$15 to the above address to obtain a copy of this IFB. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.
