LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


255 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3120 words


 

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, phone: (202) 673-3916.

The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. 

The American Research Center in Egypt announces the following fellowships in Egypt for 1994-1995: two National Endowment for the Humanities Fellowships for postdoctoral, senior scholars; the Kress Predoctoral Fellowship in Egyptian Art and Architecture; five Egyptian Development Fellowships, earmarked for Egyptian predoctoral candidates enrolled in North American universities; and fellowships from the United States Information Agency. For the Egyptian Development Fellowships, Egyptian candidates must have J1 student status and be engaged in research relating to Egyptian development. Allowances include international airfare, a living stipend, and an allowance for research expenses. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. For application, write The American Research Center in Egypt, New York University, 30 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. Phone: (212) 998-8890. Fax: (212) 995-4144.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Progams, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as the sending areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities offers African Humanities Fellowships to support postdoctoral scholars and students in the final stages of their dissertation write-up. Scholars will participate in a residential seminar on "Powers of Expression and Expression of Power." DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF ALL APPLICATIONS: DECEMBER 17, 1993. Contact: African Humanities Institute, SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accomodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Cameroon, November 15-29, 1993; Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF-Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The Johann Jacobs Foundation encourages African scholars to apply for support of doctoral research concerning youth in a changing world. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites applications for grants for women from developing countries who are studying in the United States and have a demonstrated interest in the problems and needs of women and children in their countries. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. For application forms contact: Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund, 1818 H Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20433.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353- 1700.

Michigan State University Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

Northwestern University announces the 1994-1995 competition for a residency fellowship with the Program of African Studies. Candidates must be black South Africans who want to take part in the activities of the Program of African Studies. They also must be either: engaged in the study of Africa in any field of the humanities or social sciences and are at least at the post-MA level; or, writers or artists engage in creative projects. Fellowship of US$12,000 will for one half-year (four and a half months) and will also include one round-trip economy airfare between place of residence and Chicago. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: South African Fellowship Program, Progam of African Studies, Northwestern University, 620 Library Place, Evanston, IL 60208; phone: (708) 491-7323; fax: (708) 491-3739.

The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program provides support for post graduate research in areas of economic development. Proposals for 1994 should relate to either privatisation or education for women. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993. Applications available from: The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program, Room M-4029, World Bank, 1818 H Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub-Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764- 3468.

The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply. DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first ten years of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) announces its International Predissertation Fellowship Program. Full-time students working towards a Ph.D. are invited to apply for a 12-month training fellowship to study the culture in Africa or some other developing region. Candidates should be early in their training and seek language and area studies to complement disciplinary work. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 10, 1993. Contact: SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10058; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The SSRC also offers Predissertation Research Fellowships of US$2,000 to support preliminary fieldwork in Africa. Applicants should be scholars from disciplines that are underrepresented in African studies (economics, humanities, sociology, psychology), and students planning research on issues concerning African agriculture, health, or environment. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The SSRC African Dissertation Fellowships are designed to support doctoral dissertation research in the social sciences and humanities for periods of 9 to 18 months. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. Contact: SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10058; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333- 6335.

The 1994 United States Department of State Summer Work/Study Intern Program offers an opportunity for graduate students to spend the summer working in an American embassy or consulate in Africa. Students receive free housing and a foreign service staff employee salary. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 1, 1993. Applications available from: The Center for African Studies, University of Illinois, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1993

256 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5440 words


 

The African Governance Program of the Carter Center of Emory University seeks an ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR. The program specializes in problems of governance in both the English- and French-speaking countries of Africa and expects to provide election-monitoring services in Liberia and other countries. The Associate Director will conduct research, initiate and implement program strategies, administer special projects and plan budgets. The A.D. will also maintain links with national and international communities of persons and groups associated with Africa, including authorities and specialists in non-governmental organizations, academic institutions, private voluntary organizations, embassies and other governmental offices.

Requirements: exceptional analytic abilities, strong adminstrative skills, be able to respond to multiple demands, and have an academic background in Africa or related fields. In-country experience preferred. Master's degree preferred, Bachelors degree required. CLOSING DATE: NOVEMBER 30, 1993. Send resume and names of three references to: Dr. Richard Joseph, African Governance Program, The Carter Center, One Copenhill Avenue, Atlanta, GA 30307.

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an ACCOUNTANT for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. 

Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenace of property; liaison with donors, orther non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiatins, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available for its operations in Southern Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide surgical skills/emergency relief to displaced persons Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

NURSE to provide relief/acute care to displaced persons. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

FIELD COORDINATOR to coordinate program activities, participate in program development, supervise activities, including hiring of local staff; commodity management; liaison with local elders, authorities, and other agencies; maintain daily communication with Nairobi office; assist in budget development and management; assist with establishment of policies and procedures for ARC field staff regarding illness and security. Qualifications: management experience in a developing country, preferably in a rural setting; education; background in health management or related field. One-year commitment. US$1,500 a month. Immediate opening.

MCH COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities in selecting MCH care workers; conduct a one-month training to qualify them to work as TBAs; offer one-on-one counseling for traumatized women; supervise MT care workers; assist in clinical operations and conduct community education. Qualifications: RN with MCH and counseling background. Previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

HOME VISITOR COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial one-month training course and provide continuing education for workers; supervise daily activities and participate in clinical operations. Qualification: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

LOGISTICS COORDINATOR to procure all supplies needed for field activities; solicit proforma invoices in accordance with grant regulations; inventory all supplies; arrange transportation and monitor supply usage. Qualifications: previous management experience in a developing country; fluency in English and Swahili. US$1,200 a month. One-year commitment. Immediate opening.

For its operations in Somalia, American Refugee Committee seeks:

COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS TRAINER, RN, NP, or PA with public health background and training experience to: implement CHW training program for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; also interact with other agencies. Requires: proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

EPI COORDINATOR, RN to coordinate Expanded Immunization program including a selection of mobile team, training of team and field supervision of implementation. Supervise establishment and operation of cold chain facilities.

Requires: experience in developing country, preferably in rural setting; extensive experience in training. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

TBA COORDINATOR, an experienced nurse or midwife to coordinate a traditional birth attendant program including selection of participants, training and follow up supervision and support. Requires: experience in training; and strong primary health care background. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

ARC also has a variety of positions available for Portuguese-speaking professionals for projects in Mozambique. These include MD, MPH, PA, RN, CONSTRUCTION MANAGER, WATER/SANITATION MANAGER, OPERATIONS MANAGERS, and FINANCIAL MANAGER. Provide both hands-on and training of counterparts. Requires experience in developing countries. One-year contracts.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

CARE seeks a SENIOR POPULATION ADVISOR for its Population Programming. Responsibilities include developing CARE's Population and Field Programs Strategy in coordination with corresponding field offices. Provide guidance and technical assistance; design, implement and evaluate projects. Represent CARE and collaborate with USAID and other donors.

Qualifications: MD, doctorate or equivalent academic experience in demography, repreductive health or maternal/child health. Excellent communications skills, ability to travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID- funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable.

To apply for these positions, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a REGIONAL INFORMATION AND P-4 COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER in Cairo, Egypt. Qualifications required include a university degree in aggriculture or social sciences or communication/journalism or other related field. Seven years of progressively responsible professional experience in the field of information and development support communication, production and use of audio-visual materials, and training in communication. Experience in press, radio and TV management. Working knowledge of Arabic, English and French. Salary ranges: US$52,797 to $66,205 (without dependents) and US$56,770 to $71,560 (with dependents). CLOSING DATE: NOVEMBER 23, 1993. Contact: Executive Director, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20437.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs., to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status.

Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salaryhiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100;

Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

International Medical Corps has an opening for a COUNTRY DIRECTOR to plan, develop and implement its programs in Somalia. Five years experience managing international health care or humanitarian relief projects, leadership experience; strong supervisory, administrative and communications skills; accounting skills desirable. Prefer M.D. withknowledge of tropical medicine, EPI and maternal/child. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Assignment is for minimum of one year. Immediate opening. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-021, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442- 6622.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in Southern Sudan:

COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER/EPI COORDINATOR: Five years experience with immunization in developing countries; familiarity with cold chain techniques; excellent oral and written communications skills required. Must have M.P.H. OPENING: November 1. One year contract. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93-025.

MATERNAL HEALTH PROGRAM COORDINATOR: Three years experience in developing countries; community health, nurse practitioner with midwifery skills; traditional birthing training experience. Minimum one-year contract to begin December 1. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93- 028.

PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT or NURSE PRACTITIONER: Three years experience in developing countries; graduate of an accredited PA program; stron clinical skills; previous teaching experience; extremeley flexible; good oral and written ommunications skills. OPENING: November 1. Minimum six-month contract. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93-027.

Roundtrip transportation, room and board provided for each of these positions. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #2809, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442-6622.

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activites of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

Operation Crossroads Africa seeks individuals to serve as LEADERS/FACILITATORS during the summer months for work projects in Africa. Crossroads is a U.S.-based international, private volontary organization involved in cross-cultural exchanges and small-scale development projects for college students. Applicants should be at least 26 years of age and have knowledge about Africa. Previous travel experience and demonstrated group leadership is also required. Leaders/facilitators are provided with transportation and living expenses while in Africa and a small honorarium. Crossroads also seeks specialized experienced applicants for projects in Africa in preventive medicine and health education. DEADLINE: JANUARY 19, 1994. Contact: Operation Crossroads Africa, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 242, New York, NY 10115.

Peace Corps of the United States has the following positions available:

TRAINING DIRECTORS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as training director for pre-service training in various countries. Contract are to begin in April, May or June 1994.

QUALIFICATIONS: extensive Peace Corps training experience coordinating pre-service training activities, although similar experience in an international development organization will be considered; organizational and management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; crisis management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledge about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. For more information, contact Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in primary health care or maternal and child health education in West Africa; prior experience designing primary health care training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MPH or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter- cultural team of trainers; knowledgable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

EDUCATION TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Education Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in education in Africa; prior experience designing teacher training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MEd or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter- cultural team of trainers; knowledgable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

LANGUAGE COORDINATOR-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Language Coordinators for pre-service training in Africa.

QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps training experience competency-based language training; coordinating pre-service training activities; demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledgable about issues of international development; proven flexibility and

leadership. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region,

1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Swarthmore College seeks an ASSISTANT PROFESSOR, principal field in sub-Saharan Africa. Comparative and interdisciplinary interests, as well as teaching experience, highly desirable. PhD, or nearly completed PhD, required. Tenure-track position to begin fall 1994. Send letter and dossier to Robert S. DuPlessis, Acting Chair, Swarthmore

College, Swarthmore, PA 19081-1397. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 15, 1993. Interviews will be held at African Studies Association annual convention in Boston, December 4-7, 1993.

TechnoServe, a non-profit rural enterprise development organization seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa Division Headquarters in Norwalk, CT. Responsibilities include project management, evaluation, budgeting, financial management, training and fundraising experience.

QUALIFICATIONS: Five years resident overseas experience in business or agricultural development, seven years international development work, including at least two years in Africa; fluent French preferred; must be willing to

travel internationally. Send letter and resume to: TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or fax (203) 838-6717, c/o Terri Scofield, manager of human resources.

The University of California, Santa Cruz is accepting applications for the ANTHROPOLOGY pool. Several part-time, temporary teaching positions are available for one or more quarters. The university seeks candidates able to teach one

or more of the following courses: Anthropology of Religion, Peoples and Cultures of Africa, Culture and Colonialism or Medical Anthropology. Send letter of application, three letters of recommendation and syllabi for proposed courses to Carolyn Martin Shaw, Chair, Search Committee, Anthropology Board of Studies, Clark Kerr Hall, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064.

Gainesville, FL 32611. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 24, 1993. Interviews will be held at African Studies Association annual convention in Boston, December 4-7, 1993.

The University of Florida Center for African Studies seeks an assistant/associate in African Studies to serve as OUTREACH DIRECTOR of the 1994/1995 academic year. This is a nine-month, non-tenure accruing, renewable appointment and begins on or about August 13, 1994. Responsibilities include development of existing program to K-12, regional colleges and universities; planning/directing workshops/seminars; developing curriculum materials; preparing grant proposals, and representing the Center to the public. Requirements include an advanced degree in a field related to African studies, preferably with African field work; experience in public relations or program development desirable. Send curriculum vitae, letter detailing relevant background, pertinent interests and publications, and three letters of recommendation to Director, Outreach Search Committee, Center for African Studies, 427 Grinter Hall, University of

Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611; phone: (904) 392-2183.

DEADLINE: DECEMBER 1, 1993.

DIASPORA. Contact: Robert Pratt, Department of History, LeConte Hall, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602.

PhD at time of appointment and strong commitment to scholarship required. Teaching experience and teaching breadth desirable. Send curriculum vitae, a letter describing research and teaching interests, samples of publications and written work, and three letters of recommendation to Quintard Taylor, Chair, Africa Search, Department of History, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR

97403. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 24, 1993.

Virginia Commonwealth University seeks a DIRECTOR OF AFRO- AMERICAN STUDIES. Qualifications include earned doctorate and record of teaching, research, scholarship, and professional service that will merit rank of professor with tenure in a discipline within the College of Humanities and Sciences. Prior administrative experience is desirable. Evaluation of applicants will begin immediately and continue until candidate is selected. Send letter of interest, curriculum vitae, and names and phone numbers of three references to Dr. Susan Estabrook Kennedy, Associate Dean, College of Humanities and Sciences, Box 2019, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA 23284-2019.

Washington-based international development agency has immediate openings for experienced professionals with expertise in health, population, and development economics to play key roles in expanding health and family planning service delivery programs in Washington and in selected countries in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Positions require Master's, M.D. or PhD level knowledge of development economics, health, child survival and family planning, population dynamics, health policy and/or extensive experience in overseas development. Postings will require security clearances. Fax resume with salary history to (202) 332-4496 or mail to Cindy Emory,.CEDPA, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20036. NO PHONE CALLS.

Winrock International seeks ASSOCIATE PROGRAM MANAGER to handle overall administration of global farmer to farmer program component. Involves identification and mobilization of volunteer experts to 13 countries, development of volunteer experts to 13 countries, development of volunteer database and network, and liaison activities with volunteer sources, client farmer groups and agribusiness in target countries. Requirements: Bachelor's degree, preferably in agriculture, ag communications or extension, or agribusiness; five-plus years relevant experience, preferably with experience in developing country and management of USAID project. Master's desired. Good writing/verbal skills, basic computer, organization, and excellent interpersonal skills essential. Spanish or French fluency strongly desired. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 15. Send cover letter, resume, and references to: HRM Department, AP Manager, Winrock International, Route 3, Box, 376, Morrilton, AR 72110; fax: (501) 727-5242.

Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org.

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

 

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; December, 1993 and

April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians- in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; December 1993 and Mayanesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

NOVEMBER 1, 1993


VISITORS


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Our list of African visitors to the United States is compiled from the "Arrival List of International Visitors," published by the United States Information Agency (phone 202-619-5219), and other sources. Programming agencies: AAI: African-American Institute, Washington, DC; (202) 667-5636. TDI: Delphi International, Washington, DC; (202) 466-7951. FTUI: Free Trade Union Institute, Washington, DC; (202) 637DC; (202) 898-0600. MIC: Meridian International Center, 5279. IIE: Institute of International Education, Washington, Washington, DC; (202) 667-6670. USDA: United States Department of Agriculture, Washington, DC; (202) 619-5237. 

 

ALGERIA. . .

Cherif Rezki; chief editor, Arabic daily newspaper, "El Khabar." Scheduled: October 16-November 13. Interests: journalism, communications. Sponsoring agency: DI. Contact: (202) 619-5237.

Abdellaziz Lahiouel; U.S. desk officer, the Algerian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Scheduled: October 30-November 29. Interests: security issues. Sponsoring agency: MIC. Contact: (202) 619-6285.

EGYPT. . .

Mahmed Mounir Ahmed B. El-Missiri; desk editor, Crime and Legal Affairs. Scheduled: October 16-November 13. Interests: journalism, communications. Sponsoring agency: DI. Contact: (202) 619-5237.

Azza El-Nashar; presenter/newscaster, English programs, Channel 5 (Alexandria). Scheduled: October 17-November 16. Interests: TV broadcasting. Sponsoring agency: AED. Contact: (202) 619-6285.

Mamdouh M. M. Mansour; assistant professor, department of political science, Faculty of Commerce, Alexandria University. Scheduled: October 30-November 29. Interests: security issues. Sponsoring agency: MIC. Contact: (202) 619- 6285.

KENYA. . .

Eulalia Catherine Namai; production manager, KBC Radio/TV. Scheduled: October 16-November 13. Interests: journalism, communications. Sponsoring agency: DI. Contact: (202) 619- 5237.

MALI. . .

Bintou Sanankoua, teacher, Ecole Normale Superieure. Scheduled: October 12-November 5. Contact: Jacqueline Samuda at Phelps Stokes Fund (202) 862-2613.

Maurice Vulingqondo Madlala, principal, Zondela C.P. School. Scheduled: October 24-November 21. Interests: conflict resolution and mediation, observation of U.S. government. Sponsoring agency: AAI. Contact: (202) 619-5243.

Wilfred Sipho Mlaba; leader, Inkatha Freedom Party, Mpumalanga Township. Scheduled: October 24-November 21. Interests: conflict resolution and mediation, observation of U.S. government. Sponsoring agency: AAI. Contact: (202) 619- 5243.

Archibald Jacob Gumede; member of executive committee of the Southern Natal Region of the ANC. Scheduled: October 24observation of U.S. government. Sponsoring agency: AAI. November 21. Interests: conflict resolution and mediation, Contact: (202) 619-5243.

Wellington Mhlabunzima Hlengwa; chief, Thoyana Tribal Authority. Scheduled: October 24-November 21. Interests: conflict resolution and mediation, observation of U.S. government. Sponsoring agency: AAI. Contact: (202) 619-5243.

Bonginkozi Meshack Radabe; chairperson, ANC, Ndel Ntsele Branch. Scheduled: October 24-November 21. Interests: conflict resolution and mediation, observation of U.S. government. Sponsoring agency: AAI. Contact: (202) 619-5243.

TUNISIA. . .

Mohamed Ben Salah, president of the Tunisian Journalist Association. Scheduled: October 16-November 13. Interests: journalism, communications. Sponsoring agency: DI. Contact: (202) 619-5237.

ZIMBABWE. . .

Oriah Anthony Gara, member of parliament. Scheduled: October 17-November 15. Interest: U.S. political system. Sponsoring

agency: AAI. Contact: (202) 619-5243.
