262 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


TOKYO DECLARATION ON AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT: "TOWARDS THE 21ST CENTURY"


LENGTH: 3787 words


 

Tokyo International Conference on African Development, October 5-6, 1993

We, the participants of the Tokyo International Conference on African Development (TICAD), consisting of African countries and Africa's development partners, declare with one voice our continued dedication to the development of Africa towards a new era of prosperity. We, therefore, solemnly adopt the present Declaration, in the firm belief that it will serve to strengthen an emerging new partnership for sustainable development of Africa based on self-reliance of African countries and the support of Africa's development partners.

Background

1. Africa's economic and social crises of the 1980s highlighted the development challenges faced by this Continent. To address these challenges, many African countries have embarked on far-reaching political and economic reforms. We, the participants of TICAD, are encouraged by signs in recent years of both positive macro- economic performance and political development resulting from those reforms. In so doing, we nevertheless recognize the continued fragility and vulnerability of Africa's political and economic structures and situations that inhibit the achievement of sustainable development. TICAD intends to give further impetus to these reforms, taking into account the United Nations New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s (UN-NADAF). 

2. With the end of the Cold War, African countries and the international community now have an opportunity to share a broader common understanding of the need for dynamic development cooperation. The development of the Continent has emerged as an imperative in our search for a better future.

3. While special consideration should be given to obstacles confronting Africa, we are determined to strengthen our collective forward-looking efforts for the development of the Continent. This has been the spirit in which we have conducted our deliberations on the issues central to sustainable development in Africa.

4. These issues include the on-going process of simultaneous political and economic reforms, the necessity of increased private sector participation in domestic economic activity, the promotion of regional cooperation and integration, and the detrimental effects of humanitarian emergencies on Africa's socio-economic development. We recognize that the Asian experience of economic development and the catalytic role of international cooperation offer hope and provide a challenge for African economic transformation.

Political and Economic Reforms

5. Convinced of the advent of a new international era, we, the African participants, reaffirm our commitment to pursue and further strengthen political and economic reforms, in particular democratization, respect for human rights, good governance, human and social development, and economic diversification and liberalization. To achieve sustainable, broad-based economic growth, we, the participants of TICAD, believe that more open, accountable and participatory political systems are vital, including a stronger role for civil society. We recognize that political, economic and social reform must be initiated and carried out by African countries themselves, based on their visions, values and individual socio-economic background. Africa's development partners should therefore support African initiatives in these areas.

6. We, the participants of TICAD, recognize that simultaneous implementation of political and economic reforms, while conducive to development, may often entail painful transition processes. The interaction between political and economic reforms, which over time should be mutually reinforcing, is a complicated process which requires support to bring about progress. We, Africa's development partners, reaffirm our commitment to providing priority support to countries undertaking effective and efficient political and economic reforms. We, the participants of TICAD, also reaffirm our commitment to enhancing constructive dialogue to facilitate the reform processes.

7. We, the African participants, reaffirm our commitment to improving the quality of governance, in particular, transparency and accountability in public administration. We recognize that criteria for public expenditure should aim at enhancing overall socio-economic development and reducing non-productive expenditures. The building of human and institutional capacities for sustainable development is essential for all of these objectives. We commit ourselves to creating the enabling environment for training, retaining and effective utilization of human resources and improving institutional capacities. We, Africa's development partners, will enhance our support for African capacity building including improved technical assistance.

8. We, the participants of TICAD, reaffirm that structural adjustment programmes should take more actively into consideration the specific conditions and requirements of individual countries. We reiterate that political and economic reforms should ultimately lead to the alleviation of poverty and enhanced welfare of the entire population. To that effect, structural adjustment programmes should contain, more than in the past, measures to improve the access of the poor in particular to income earning opportunities and to effective social services, while seeking to shield them as far as possible from adverse social consequences. Increased priority should be given to investment in human capital through nutrition, health and education programmes, especially to improve the situation of women and children. Additionally, noting that the overall economic development in Africa has not kept pace with Africa's rapid population growth, we recognize the importance of sound population policies and call upon African Governments and the international community to address this issue within the socio-economic development process.

Economic Development through Activities of the Private Sector

9. The private sector is vital as an engine for sustainable development. We, the participants of TICAD, agree that though foreign aid has an impact on development, its role is only supplementary in magnitude and catalytic in nature. We recognize that a workable and practical cooperation between government and the private sector is a key factor for development. A climate of trust between these two actors should be encouraged and interaction promoted. We realize that political and economic stability is a prerequisite to commitments for long-term investments.

10. We, the African participants, are determined to continue policies which foster a greater role for the private sector and which encourage entrepreneurship. While stepping up deregulation measures, we will provide and maintain, in cooperation with our development partners, physical infrastructure and viable administrative, legal and financial institutions. We consider in general the informal sector as a source of vitality for African economies which deserves support in order to mobilize entrepreneurial capacity, generate employment, and to facilitate the transition into the formal economy.

11. We, the participants of TICAD, are convinced that further improvements in financial systems and practices are needed to stimulate domestic savings and investment, and to prevent and reverse capital flight.

12. In support of these efforts, we, Africa's development partners, shall continue to provide assistance in order to improve the enabling environment which requires economic reforms and privatization, the building of human and institutional capacities, and the development of financial intermediation. We recognize the importance of appropriate insurance and guarantee schemes to protect private enterprises investing in Africa from political and economic risks.

13. We, the African participants, affirm the central importance of international trade to our future development prospect. We, Africa's development partners, will work to facilitate market access for African products globally and to assist in up-grading and diversifying African exports. We, the participants of TICAD, support the vital role of private associations such as the African Business Round- Table and confirm the usefulness of investment- and trade- promotion initiatives within Africa and between Africa and the rest of the world.

Regional Cooperation and Integration

14. We, the African participants, reaffirm our vision and aspiration for ultimate regional integration and cooperation goals as embodied in the Abuja Treaty establishing the African Economic Community. We, the participants of TICAD, realize that although these goals have been, since the early years of independence, a logical development strategy for African countries, most of which have small national markets, greater efforts must now be made in promoting intra-regional trade and investment.

15. We, the African participants, will ensure that our commitments to regional schemes are fully incorporated in our national development plans, policies and programmes.

16. We, Africa's development partners, welcome and support the renewed commitment to regional cooperation and integration as has been recently demonstrated by African countries. These regional arrangements should continue to be consistent with the multilateral open trading system, and contribute to trade expansion. We will continue to extend our support to African countries' efforts aimed at reducing obstacles to integration through measures such as reduction of trade and investment barriers and policy harmonization, and to viable regional endeavours particularly in the area of infrastructure development and capacity building. We, the participants of TICAD, believe that regional integration should also be pursued by encouraging private sector initiatives, adopting consistent and gradual approaches for broadening exchanges and rationalizing existing schemes.

Emergency Relief and Development

17. We, the participants of TICAD, note with great concern that over the last two decades, and particularly in recent years, that a large number of African countries have suffered and are still suffering from natural and man-made disasters. The international community has responded generously to these situations since the early crises in the 1970s.

18. These disasters have constrained development in many African countries, destroyed the very basis for development, increased the number of refugees, and diverted human and financial resources that otherwise could have served development purposes.

19. We, the participants of TICAD, realize that man- made disasters are the result of a complex interplay of political, economic and social factors. In this context, lack of democratization and respect for human rights and the rights of minorities are among the root causes of these disasters.

20. We, the participants of TICAD, accept that responsibility for disaster prevention and management rests primarily with Africans themselves. We, the African participants, are therefore determined to devote our efforts to addressing the root causes of these disasters. We also confirm the critical role of regional cooperation as demonstrated in the past. We, the participants of TICAD, underscore the need to establish effective mechanisms for prevention , preparedness and management of man-made and natural disasters in general, and to strengthen food security schemes in particular. We, therefore, welcome the decision of the Organization of African Unity to establish the Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management, and Resolution and pledge our support to strengthen the effective functioning of this mechanism. We also reaffirm our willingness to assist victims of disasters, and urge the removal of all hindrances to effective distribution of relief supplies.

21. We, Africa's development partners, having recognized that there is a continuum between emergency relief and development, will ensure that the humanitarian assistance for the affected communities continue to be provided for resettlement, rehabilitation and reconstruction.

Asian Experience and African Development

22. Over the past 30 years, in contrast to Africa, the countries of East and South-East Asia have achieved high rates of growth in per capita income. We, the participants of TICAD, are mindful that in view of the differing international and internal conditions no one model of development can be simply transferred from one region to another. Nevertheless, we acknowledge some relevance of the Asian experience for African development. The very diversity of successful Asian countries gives hope that lessons can be drawn for African development.

23. We, the participants of TICAD, have noted that as demonstrated by the successful examples of the Asian development experience, the backdrop of development success lies in the combination of a strong commitment by the leadership and the people to economic prosperity, appropriate long-term development strategies and functional government administration to pursue these strategies coherently.

24. We have also noted that the policy factors which contributed to the remarkable performance of East and South- East Asia have included (1) the rational application of macro-economic policies and maintenance of political stability, (2) the promotion of agricultural production through technological research and innovations as solid basis for socio-economic development, (3) long-term investment in education and human resources development as priority of development strategy, (4) market-friendly and export-led policies to advance and adapt modes of production in order to increase opportunities for trade and economic growth, (5) measures to stimulate domestic savings and capital formation by developing financial intermediation and by expansion of banking services at the community level, (6) policy emphasis on the private sector as an engine of growth and development, and (7) early implementation of land reform.

25. We, the participants of TICAD, recognize that development achievements in East and South-East Asia have enhanced opportunities for South-South cooperation with Africa. We welcome the interest shown by some Asian and African countries in promoting this cooperation.

International Cooperation

26. We, the participants of TICAD, have concluded that the current situation in Africa calls for increased solidarity among us to act in full partnership to address this situation. This new partnership should be based on Africa's objective to achieve self-reliance on the one hand and responsive support by Africa's development partners on the other.

27. We, the participants of TICAD, agree that stability and security are prerequisites to sustainable development, and that it is essential to make efficient use of scarce resources and to minimize military and other unproductive expenditures.

28. We, the participants of TICAD, realize that development calls for full participation by the people at all levels, who should be galvanized toward action as agents for progress. In this regard, we acknowledge the dynamic and diversified role of African women in various sectors of the economy and recommend that special measures be taken to promote their rights and roles in order to enhance gender equity and to remove all legal, social and cultural barriers for advancement of women. Furthermore, we recognize the need to enhance cooperative efforts with local NGOs and other institutions of civil society which play constructive roles for African development.

29. We, Africa's development partners, will make all efforts to enhance development assistance to Africa, despite current global economic difficulties. This assistance will be increasingly oriented toward the priorities set by African countries. In making commitments to continued and enhanced cooperation, we will take into account the expectation of our constituencies that resources be spent where they are most efficiently utilized for the greatest development impact.

30. As African countries are at various stages of development, and have different cultural and historical backgrounds, we, Africa's development partners, may take differentiated approaches as we plan and implement our development cooperation, with due regard to aid coordination.

31. We, Africa's development partners, will apply a comprehensive approach covering aid, trade, debt strategy and investments. We, the participants of TICAD, reaffirm that debt and debt service still pose serious difficulties to many African countries. We emphasize the necessity to urgently address the debt issue within the overall context of debt relief and flows of new financial resources for development. We confirm the validity of the international debt strategy and invite the Paris Club to continue reviewing the question of debt relief for the poorest highly-indebted countries, especially with regard to earlier reductions in the stock of debt on a case by case basis. We urge creditor countries to take into account the difficulties that heavily indebted African countries are now facing.

32. We, the participants of TICAD, reiterate the importance of a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations and will make all efforts to remove trade barriers and other trade practices that prevent the expansion of African exports including exports to other African countries. We underscore the importance of primary commodities for many African countries' export earning and the need for diversification to reduce the volatility of these earnings.

33. We, the participants of TICAD, confirm that United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) agreements should be steadfastly implemented with a special emphasis on balanced relationships among agriculture, population and environment policies, particularly drought and desertification.

34. We also recognize that many of the gains made in Africa are threatened by the HIV/AIDS pandemic and related diseases which are already of a disastrous proportion in some countries. There is a need for a much stronger response by Africa and its development partners, for preventing and controlling these diseases including caring facilities as well as measures addressing its socio-economic impacts.

Follow-up

35. We, the participants of TICAD, pledge to take, in our respective spheres of responsibility, measures aimed at advancing the spirit of this Declaration through effective policies and actions. We have entrusted the three co-organizers of TICAD with evaluating and reviewing progress made towards the implementation of this Declaration. Ultimately, we intend to hold a conference of a similar magnitude and membership at the latest before the turn of the century.

* * * * *

By virtue of the deliberations, guidance and consensus of the conference we believe that prospects for significant development of Africa have been greatly enhanced.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


WE MUST END THE WAR: A Soul-Searching Quest for Peace in the Sudan


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Excerpts from a Statement by Francis M. Deng (Senior Fellow Foreign Policy Studies Program, The Brookings Institution) to asymposium on the Sudan sponsored by the U.S. Institute of Peace and the Subcommittee on Africa of the House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Affairs, Washington, D.C., 20 October 1993 Options for Conflict Resolution

In the North-South conflict, several possible options recommend themselves. One which now seems most unlikely would be a major transformation of the present regime to allow the formulation of an accommodating national framework that would remove religion from the public arena and make all the Sudanese feel a sense of equitable belonging to the nation, and participate as equal citizens without any racial, cultural, or religious discrimination. The other which is more likely would be for this regime to agree with the SPLM/SPLA (in whatever configuration) to coexist in a loose unity, whether confederal or federal. A genuine federal arrangement would allow the two parts of the country, as well as other regions, to coexist and pursue their respective social, cultural, and religious logics, with sufficient room for free interaction and mutual assimilation among ethnicities, cultures, and religions as a matter of individual choice. 

The third option which is winning increasing support in the South and internationally is to recognize that unity is not an end in itself, that the Sudanese have not only suffered for far too long in the name of unity, that the conflict is preventing both sides from realizing their aspirations and potential, and that partition might be the best way of releasing the resources and energies of the people to be invested in a more constructive process of well-grounded development and nationbuilding.

There is a fourth option which some people believe is quite possible but which most observers dismiss as neither desirable nor feasible, and that is military imposition of a model by one party against the will of the other party. In the present circumstances, the party strong enough to contemplate such a victory is the government, but so deeply- rooted are the animosities and so entrenched are the positions that the effect of such a victory would only be to reduce the SPLA to a guerrilla army still capable of pursuing a protracted war with sustainable impact on the security of the South and the economy of the country.

The fifth option which could generically come from within or emanate from the dynamic changes outlined under option four is a change in government that would allow any one of the first three options to be realized, in case the present regime chooses to pursue military victory and refuses to compromise along the lines of the postulated alternatives.

The scenarios for the resolution of the secondary layer of conflicts can be summarized in terms of the need for internal resolution as a prior or subsequent condition to a comprehensive settlement. Most of the major Northern factions share the Arab-Islamic agenda to one degree or another, and virtually all the Southern factions agree on the main elements of the Southern demands and differ only on tactics or strategies. Although differences within the South have generated much violence, they do not compare in scale to the differences between the North and the South, despite the fact that tactical alliances may induce the factions to cooperate across the North-South dividing line. Involving the International Community

The quest for peace requires third party mediation. This is why Sudanese on all sides are busy lobbying the international community to their point of view. The mere fact that we are assembled in this symposium is testimony to the significance we attach to the role of the international community.

Despite the reluctant attitude of the international community over Bosnia and the current ambivalence in the United States about involvement in Somalia, the now dominant forces of the market economy and the conscience of the human rights constituency combined with the watchful eye of the international media cannot in the long run allow democracies to stand by and watch countries brutalize themselves in genocidal conflicts without some form of involvement, humanitarian, diplomatic, political, or even military. What is important, as this meeting shows, is that there are a wide variety of ways by which the international community could assist the Sudanese in their search for domestic solutions, which, in the long run, are the only means of achieving sustainable peace in the country.

The Sudanese conflict, by virtue of its structure, is a reflection of regional and international identities and their interests. It is indeed an irony of history that the civil war in the Sudan should be the result of the country's greatest promise as a microcosm of Africa and a bridge or cross-roads between the continent and the Middle East. But the Sudan has lived under this illusion for far too long without translating it into tangible rewards. On the contrary, this aspiration has been a major factor in tearing the country apart. The Imperative of Peace

The tragedy of the war and its humanitarian challenges dictate an order of priority which the international

community is called upon to demand and support:

First, hostilities must stop immediately with the declaration of a cease-fire based on an open admission by all sides that only through a political solution will a lasting peace be achieved in the Sudan.

Second, the delivery of humanitarian relief supplies must be declared by all the factions as an overriding objective to which they will render their unreserved cooperation with the international community.

Third, pending a final resolution of the conflict and with a commitment to a non-violent search for peace, the parties need to agree on an interim administration of the South that will maintain basic social order and facilitate the delivery of essential services.

Fourth, with the help of the international community, Southerners and Northerners must be encouraged to unify their internal fronts and at the earliest possible opportunity organize a truly national peace conference of all the political forces with international observers to address the major constitutional issues pertaining to North- South relations and the form of governance appropriate to the country. In this connection, there is an urgent need for all third parties involved in the search for peace to coordinate their efforts in order to reinforce one another and increase their effectiveness.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 1, 1993


AFRICA FACES CRISIS OVER AID AS WORLD BANK LENDING FALLS


BYLINE: Roy Laishley, AFRICA RECOVERY, United Nations Vol. 7 No. 2 October 1993


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 2267 words


 

Evidence is mounting that the international strategy to boost aid flows to Africa is in serious crisis. New lending commitments by the World Bank to sub-Saharan Africa fell a dramatic 30 per cent -- or $1.2 bn -- in its last financial year, even though its overall lending increased by 9 percent. Last year, Western aid to all developing countries rose by only 1.1 per cent in real terms, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). Although a regional breakdown is not yet available, OECD officials say they do not expect flows to Africa to be above this trend and, for bilateral aid, could well be lower. Forthcoming analysis from the UN is expected to further confirm this picture.

"We fear that the upward trend in aid to Africa of the 1980s may have come to an end," one OECD official told AFRICA RECOVERY. Figures for 1990 already show a worrying stagnation in net aid flows to Africa. This contrasts sharply with the 1991 call in the UN New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s (NADAF) for real growth in annual aid flows of at least 4 per cent. 

Other officials express more optimism that aid flows to Africa can be maintained, pointing to Japan's recent announcement of a 50 per cent increase in its overall aid over the next five years, as one source of new funds for the continent. The real test for African aid will come at the end of this year, they argue, when the World Bank is expected to seek pledges for its third Special Programme of Assistance (SPA) for Africa. The Bank raised some $7 bn in additional pledges for SPA II, which is now coming to and end, and a similar amount is being sought for the 1994-1996 programme.

However, "alarm bells are already ringing" over the trend in aid flows to Africa, Ghana's Ambassador to the US Joe Abbey told AFRICA RECOVERY. A number of major bilateral donors have either cut back on aid plans or signalled their intent to make existing funds stretch further. From multilateral agencies, African borrowing is increasingly concentrated on their soft-loan affiliates, a reflection of the inability of a growing number of countries to afford the cost of borrowing from the main lending arms. But it is the voluntary bilateral funding of these soft-loan facilities, including the UN, which is now under the most acute pressure.

For the World Bank, commitments to sub-Saharan Africa in 1993 from its soft-loan International Development Association (IDA), held up much better than from its main lending arm. IDA credits, at $2.77 bn, were only some 14 per cent down on the previous year's level of $3.23 bn. New commitment from the more expensive International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), however, all but disappeared from the sub-continent, totalling only $47 mn in FY 1993 compared with $738 mn the previous year. Explaining this trend, the Bank's Chief Economist for Africa Ishrat Husain argues that the IBRD's hard terms should not be extended to most African countries as they will only add to their already considerable debt burden.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) also reports a downturn in lending to Africa in its latest financial year. Disbursements totalled some $525 mn in the year to 30 April 1993, compared with just over $1 bn for the previous year, a fall of close to 50 per cent. Zimbabwe was the only new African borrower from the Fund's regular accounts.

World Bank officials argue that not too much should be read into a single year, pointing out that the $4 bn level in commitments achieved in 1992 was significantly up on the previous year. Bank gross disbursements in 1993, at $2.62 bn, were actually up on 1992. When all repayments are taken into account, Bank net transfers to sub-Saharan Africa in 1993 were sharply up at $874 mn, compared with $794 mn the previous year.

Overall Bank lending to Africa since 1990 has shown a worrying volatility at a time when it is seen as the lead agency for mobilizing increased resources for the continent. But Mr. Husain says this is explained largely by the ups and downs of IBRD lending to countries such as Cote d'Ivoire and Nigeria. The trend line for IDA commitments since 1989 is holding at a relatively healthy $2.7 bn a year, he says, well up on the $1.4 bn average for 1984-1988.

To explain the 1993 downturn, the Bank cites a shift from adjustment lending, with its fast-disbursing element, to slower project-based lending. Non-project lending to sub- Saharan Africa virtually halved in 1993 to $455 mn and from $895 mn the previous year.

The Bank also stresses the role of political factors, specifically "administrative delays resulting from the political transitions in a number of countries." Turmoil in once large borrowers such as Zaire have influenced overall lending levels, as has less dramatic events in countries as such Kenya, Malawi, Nigeria and Togo. OECD officials also quote Africa's political problems as a significant factor in stalling the aid push for the continent.

Even favoured clients have not been immune, Mr. Abbey points out, with his own country Ghana seeing the disbursement of some $170 mn in credits halted last year as the Bank questioned extra spending prior to the elections. While reserving judgment until more detailed figures are available, Mr. Abbey questioned whether increasing conditionality in Bank lending, including the difficult issue of good governance, was causing a significant slowdown in the administration of aid. Recent Consultative Group meetings for Ghana, Uganda and others, however, have shown that donors are still prepared to pledge significant funds for selected countries. Growing aid competition

OECD officials point to the growing competition with politically "more important" regions as another explanation for the slowdown in aid to Africa. The fall in Bank lending to Africa coincided with a large surge in commitments to Eastern Europe -- up $1.7 bn to $3.8 bn. Bank officials strongly deny any linkage with the decline in commitments to Africa, stressing that this is IBRD funding not IDA, but the trend does nothing to ease Africa's long-voiced fears that it is being marginalized.

The latest plans for a $3 bn development fund for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, following the signing of a peace accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, has added a new competitor to the lists. The European Community is promising to be a major source of money for the new fund. With pressure in the Community to also commit more resources to Eastern Europe, its recently unveiled plans to seek a revision of the Lome Convention with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries is seen as confirmation of a significant shift in aid priorities.

Even where Africa is securing official funding, an increasing proportion is going on humanitarian and peace- keeping operations rather than on development programmes. Pointing to the expected $2 bn cost of UN operations in Somalia, Mr. Abbey voiced his regret that "such resources do not seem to be available for more positive things."

Most concern is now centred on the growing competition for the limited funding available for boosting the concessional facilities of multilateral agencies. OECD figures show that while bilateral aid to all countries fell by 6 per cent in real terms in 1992, multilateral aid rose 16 per cent. US Congress aid cuts

But the latest replenishment of the World Bank's IDA keeps overall funding barely stable in real terms and for far more recipients, although Africa's informal 48 per cent share of the total has been retained. Even then, the US Congress is discussing a 25 per cent cutback in this year's US IDA appropriation. IDA could face significant US arrears by the end of its three year cycle in mid-1996, according to aid officials. This could have major implications for negotiations on IDA XI, which will fund African development programmes in the second half of the 1990s.

Other institutions are also seeking extra funds for concessional lending. The IMF is hoping for agreement from finance ministers at the end-September annual meeting of the Fund and Bank in Washington for a replacement to its enhanced structural adjustment facility, which expires in November. Its executive board has proposed a new facility of $8 bn.

The African Development Bank (ADB), which claims to make higher net transfers to Africa than the World Bank, is currently seeking a 50 per cent increase to its soft-loan African Development Fund, in large part to compensate for tighter lending conditions on its main arm. Already, lending from this arm is restricted to just 17 countries, with the five North African economies taking over half the volume of these loans.

UN agencies, while retaining their priority concern for Africa, are also feeling the effect of increased competition for funds. In its 1992-1996 programme cycle, UN Development Programme funds are 25-30 per cent down on the previous five-year period, a fact which drew strong protest from African delegates to its June Governing Council. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees and UNICEF both report pressures on their funding, despite renewed US commitment for the latter.

Overall, bilateral aid remains stable, with its share of OECD gross national product (GNP) in 1992 at 0.33 per cent, according to the OECD's Development Assistance Committee. Denmark and Sweden have joined Norway in committing more than 1 per cent of their GNP to aid. Finnish aid, however, has slipped below the UN target of 0.7 per cent, following a near 24 per cent cut in real aid.

In total, eight of DAC's 21 members showed a decline in real aid flows in 1992, including Japan, which competes with the US as the world's largest aid donor. As well as Finland and Japan, aid from Austria, Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Luxembourg and the UK fell in real terms in 1992, with possible impact on Africa. Recently, a US Congress committee made a $55 mn cut in the $800 mn request from the Clinton Administration which would have kept funding stable in nominal terms for the US' main African aid arm. Japan aid boost

Japan, however, has pledged to substantially increase official flows, making up to $120 bn available over the next five years. This commitment is expected to remain despite the change of government in August, officials say. The Tokyo International Conference on African Development in October has underlined the Japanese commitment to Africa.

In many countries, the traditional concept of development aid is now being questioned. New proposals to the Clinton Administration would radically change the concept of US aid and how it is administered, with at present unknown consequences for the overall level of official support. Dutch Development Minister Jan Pronk recently argued that global political changes had consequences for the definition and function of aid.

OECD officials warn that Japan's increased aid alone cannot reverse the threatening downturn in official flows to Africa and that further resources are needed from other donors. But the World Bank's Mr. Husain also argues that simply seeking increased aid flows will not necessarily encourage development and, by creating increased dependency, could actually stall recovery efforts. "What is really needed is a mix of adequate debt relief, sustainable new money and increased domestic resources mobilization," he says.

AFRICA RECOVERY, United Nations, Vol. 7, No. 2, October 1993.

Published by the Promotion and External Relations Division of the United Nations Department of Public Information, with support from UNDP and UNICEF.

Contact: The Editor, AFRICA RECOVERY, Secretariat Room 931,

United Nations, New York 10017 USA. Telephone: 212-963-6857;

Fax: 212-963-4556.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 814 words

Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3320 words


 

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, phone: (202) 673-3916.

The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. 

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Progams, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as the sending areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities offers African Humanities Fellowships to support postdoctoral scholars and students in the final stages of their dissertation write-up. Scholars will participate in a residential seminar on "Powers of Expression and Expression of Power." DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF ALL APPLICATIONS: DECEMBER 17, 1993. Contact: African Humanities Institute, SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities seeks applicants for one-year residencies at the Institute on the campus of Northwestern University. Humanists and social scientists are encouraged to apply as are writers, artists, musicians, performers and cultural specialists. Theme for 1994-95 seminar: "Power of Words/Words of Power." DEADLINE: DECEMBER 17, 1993. The international competition is administered by the Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accomodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Cameroon, November 15-29, 1993; Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF-Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The Johann Jacobs Foundation encourages African scholars to apply for support of doctoral research concerning youth in a changing world. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland.

The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers international fellowships within its Iniatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the U.S. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017 4058; phone: (616) 968-1611.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites applications for grants for women from developing countries who are studying in the United States and have a demonstrated interest in the problems and needs of women and children in their countries. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. For application forms contact: Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund, 1818 H Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20433.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353- 1700.

Michigan State University Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population- Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747 0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program provides support for post graduate research in areas of economic development. Proposals for 1994 should relate to either privatisation or education for women. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993. Applications available from: The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program, Room M-4029, World Bank, 1818 H Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub-Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764- 3468.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post-doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Social Science Research Council Committee on International Peace and Security announces dissertation and postdoctoral fellowships for training and research on peace and security in a changing world. There are no citizenship, residency, or nationality requirements. The competition is open to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences, the humanities and the physical and biological sciences. Researchers in non-academic setting are welcome to apply.

DISSERTATION FELLOWSHIPS: These are open to researchers who are finishing course work, examinations, or similar requirements for the Ph.D. or its equivalent. Applicants must complete all requirements for the doctoral degree except the dissertation by the Spring of 1994. POST DOCTORAL

FELLOWSHIPS: IN most cases, successful applicants will hold the Ph.D. or its equivalent. However, possession of that degree is not a requirement for lawyers, public servants, journalists or others who can demonstrate comparable research experience and an ability to contribute to the research literature. This competition is designed for researchers in the first ten years of their postdoctoral careers. DEADLINE: December 1, 1993. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone (212) 661-0280; fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) announces its International Predissertation Fellowship Program. Full-time students working towards a Ph.D. are invited to apply for a 12-month training fellowship to study the culture in Africa or some other developing region. Candidates should be early in their training and seek language and area studies to complement disciplinary work. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 10, 1993. Contact: SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10058; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333- 6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

Wells College will sponsor a course on "Senegalese Society, Culture, and Politics" in Dakar, Senegal, January 2-21, 1994. Most lectures will be held at the Universite Cheikh Anta Diop. The $2,200 cost of this course includes flight, ground transporation, room and board, and other cultural events. Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O. Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; phone: (315) 463-3220.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12- month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

268 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 6787 words


 

The African Governance Program of the Carter Center of Emory University seeks an ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR. The program specializes in problems of governance in both the English- and French-speaking countries of Africa and expects to provide election-monitoring services in Liberia and other countries. The Associate Director will conduct research, initiate and implement program strategies, administer special projects and plan budgets. The A.D. will also maintain links with national and international communities of persons and groups associated with Africa, including authorities and specialists in non-governmental organizations, academic institutions, private voluntary organizations, embassies and other governmental offices.

Requirements: exceptional analytic abilities, strong adminstrative skills, be able to respond to multiple demands, and have an academic background in Africa or related fields. In-country experience preferred. Master's degree preferred, Bachelors degree required. CLOSING DATE: NOVEMBER 30, 1993. Send resume and names of three references to: Dr. Richard Joseph, African Governance Program, The Carter Center, One Copenhill Avenue, Atlanta, GA 30307. 

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an accountant for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenace of property; liaison with donors, orther non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiatins, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available for its operations in Southern Sudan: MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide surgical skills/emergency relief to displaced persons Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

NURSE to provide relief/acute care to displaced persons. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

FIELD COORDINATOR to coordinate program activities, participate in program development, supervise activities, including hiring of local staff; commodity management; liaison with local elders, authorities, and other agencies; maintain daily communication with Nairobi office; assist in budget development and management; assist with establishment of policies and procedures for ARC field staff regarding

illness and security. Qualifications: management experience in a developing country, preferably in a rural setting; education; background in health management or related field. One-year commitment. US$1,500 a month. Immediate opening.

MCH COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities in selecting MCH care workers; conduct a one-month training to qualify them to work as TBAs; offer one-on-one counseling for traumatized women; supervise MT care workers; assist in clinical operations and conduct community education. Qualifications: RN with MCH and counseling background. Previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

HOME VISITOR COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial one-month training course and provide continuing education for workers; supervise daily activities and participate in clinical operations. Qualification: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

LOGISTICS COORDINATOR to procure all supplies needed for field activities; solicit proforma invoices in accordance with grant regulations; inventory all supplies; arrange transportation and monitor supply usage. Qualifications: previous management experience in a developing country; fluency in English and Swahili. US$1,200 a month. One-year commitment. Immediate opening. For its operations in Somalia, American Refugee Committee seeks:

COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS TRAINER, RN, NP, or PA with public

health background and training experience to: implement CHW training program for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; also interact with other agencies. Requires: proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

EPI COORDINATOR, RN to coordinate Expanded Immunization program including a selection of mobile team, training of team and field supervision of implementation. Supervise establishment and operation of cold chain facilities. Requires: experience in developing country, preferably in rural setting; extensive experience in training. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

TBA COORDINATOR, an experienced nurse or midwife to coordinate a traditional birth attendant program including selection of participants, training and follow up supervision and support. Requires: experience in training; and strong primary health care background. US$1,200 a month. Six-month-plus commitment.

ARC also has a variety of positions available for Portuguese-speaking professionals for projects in Mozambique. These include MD, MPH, PA, RN, CONSTRUCTION MANAGER, WATER/SANITATION MANAGER, OPERATIONS MANAGERS, and FINANCIAL MANAGER. Provide both hands-on and training of counterparts. Requires experience in developing countries. One-year contracts.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

CARE seeks a SENIOR POPULATION ADVISOR for its Population Programming. Responsibilities include developing CARE's Population and Field Programs Strategy in coordination with corresponding field offices. Provide guidance and technical assistance; design, implement and evaluate projects. Represent CARE and collaborate with USAID and other donors. Qualifications: MD, doctorate or equivalent academic experience in demography, repreductive health or maternal/child health. Excellent communications skills, ability to travel and relocate to Atlanta. Contact: Rachael Cogan, CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student-directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevent skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID- funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations seeks a REGIONAL INFORMATION AND P-4 COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER in Cairo, Egypt. Qualifications required include a university degree in aggriculture or social sciences or communication/journalism or other related field. Seven years of progressively responsible professional experience in the field of information and development support communication, production and use of audio-visual materials, and training in communication. Experience in press, radio and TV management. Working knowledge of Arabic, English and French. Salary ranges: US$52,797 to $66,205 (without dependents) and US$56,770 to $71,560 (with dependents). CLOSING DATE: NOVEMBER 23, 1993. Contact: Executive Director, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20437.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a Program Officer or Assistant Program Officer for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs., to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The Ford Foundation seeks an Assistant Representative/Program Officer for Africa and Middle East Programs to be based in Harare, Zimbabwe. The position will include developing, monitoring and evaluating program activities in Zimbabwe. The staff member will also oversee all Foundation grant-making activities in Zimbabwe and manage the Harare sub-office. Graduate training in social science or related fields required. Salary starts at $54,300. Send curriculum vitae and a brief writing sample for Position # 291 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African- American Studies at the University of Rochester is calling for applications for its 1994-1995 Residential Fellowships. Available are one postdoctoral fellowship, one predoctoral dissertation fellowship, and two four-year fellowships for graduate study. Welcome projects include historical and contemporary topics onthe economy, society, and culture of Africa and its diaspora, as well as projects on human and technological aspects of energy development and agriculture in Africa. DEADLINE: JANUARY 31, 1994. Contact: Associate Director for Research and Curriculum, Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies, University of Rochester, 302 Morey Hall, Rochester, NY 14627; phone: (716) 275-7235.

The International Catholic Migration Commission seeks a PROGRAM DIRECTOR to work in Bassikounou, southeastern Mauritania. IMC, an implementing partner for the UNHCR, manages a primary education program, in French and Arabic, for 2300 Tuareg and Moor children from Mali at three sites. The program also has adult education and income generation components. Candidates should be aware that temperatures can reach 50 degrees Centigrade in Bassikounou during April- June. Excellent health and tolerance for extreme heat are essential. ASSIGNMENT STARTING DECEMBER 1, would be initially for 13 months. Fluency in spoken French an absolute prerequisite; knowledge of Arabic and Tamashek, as well as prior African experience, highly desirable. Contact: Ms. Mitzi Schroeder, ICMC, 1319 F Street, N.W., 8th Floor, Suite 820, Washington, DC 20004.

The International Eye Foundation seeks a PROJECT DIRECTOR for its Onchocerciasis Control Project in South Cameroon. Responsibilities include: all managerial, administrative, and financial aspects of the project; reporting to headquarters; assuring close collaboration with MOH staff; and monitoring, implementing and supervising all project activities, with emphasis on fully integrating them into the PHC system. Requirements: two-plus years of experience managing a health services delivery project; background in Public Health (MPH preferred); fluency in French. Previous work in Cameroon and familiarity with NGOs and AID regulations highly desired. IMMEDIATE OPENING for initial period of seven months, perhaps longer. Send resume, including salary requirements to IEF, Attn: Dr. Christine Witte, Onchocerciasis Program Coordinator, 7801 Norwalk Avenue, Bethesda, MD 20814; fax: (301) 986-1876.

International Medical Corps has an opening for a COUNTRY DIRECTOR to plan, develop and implement its programs in Somalia. Five years experience managing international health care or humanitarian relief projects, leadership experience; strong supervisory, administrative and communications skills; accounting skills desirable. Prefer M.D. withknowledge of tropical medicine, EPI and maternal/child. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Assignment is for minimum of one year. Immediate opening. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-021, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax (310) 442- 6622.

An MSN, RN or NP. OB/GYN skills, 2-3 years in developing countries. One-year contract. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-032, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los

Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

FAMILY PRACTICE PHYSICIAN. Prefer tropical medicine background; two to three years in developing countries. One- year contract. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

IMC seeks a DIRECTOR OF FINANCE/ADMINISTRATION to oversee all financial activities in Windhoek, Namibia for program sites in Namibia and Angola. Five years experience in non- profit/government financial management; sound understanding of accounting/financial principles; excellent oral and written communication skills required. One-year contract. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-035, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442- 6622. COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER/EPI COORDINATOR: Five years experience with immunization in developing countries; familiarity with cold chain techniques; excellent oral and written communications skills required. Must have M.P.H. One year contract. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93-025.

MATERNAL HEALTH PROGRAM COORDINATOR: Three years experience in developing countries; community health, nurse practitioner with midwifery skills; traditional birthing training experience. Minimum one-year contract to begin DECEMBER 1. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93- 028.

PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT or NURSE PRACTITIONER: Three years experience in developing countries; graduate of an accredited PA program; stron clinical skills; previous teaching experience; extremeley flexible; good oral and written ommunications skills. OPENING: November 1. Minimum six-month contract. Mail or fax letter of interest to IMC, Dept. 93-027.

Roundtrip transportation, room and board provided for each of these positions. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #2809, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442-6622.

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activites of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

Khanya College, Cape Town, is accepting applications for a DIRECTOR. The candidate must have a minimum academic qualification at master's degree level and a demonstrable comprehension of the context in which Khanya College operates. The candidate will need to communicate effectively with a wide range of external players in the fields of funding, reserach, and policy formation. Send curriculum vitae and three references to S. Isaacs, Chairperson, Khanya Board of Trustees, c/o Peninsula Technikon, P.O. Box 1906, Bellville 7535, South Africa.
