Northwestern University seeks a DIRECTOR OF PROGRAM OF AFRICAN STUDIES. Send nominations or letters of application accompanied by curriculum vitae to PAS Search Committee, Office of the Provost, 633 Clark Street, Evanston, IL 60208.

Operation Crossroads Africa seeks individuals to serve as LEADERS/FACILITATORS during the summer months for work projects in Africa. Crossroads is a U.S.-based international, private volontary organization involved in cross-cultural exchanges and small-scale development projects for college students. Applicants should be at least 26 years of age and have knowledge about Africa. Previous travel experience and demonstrated group leadership is also required. Leaders/facilitators are provided with transportation and living expenses while in Africa and a small honorarium. Crossroads also seeks specialized experienced applicants for projects in Africa in preventive medicine and health education. DEADLINE: JANUARY 19, 1994.

Contact: Operation Crossroads Africa, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 242, New York, NY 10115.

Oxfam America seeks a Boston-based REGIONAL COORDIATOR for southern Africa. Coordinate, administer, and communicate the agency's regional programs. Requires demonstrated involvement with grassroots development, relevent academic training or equivalent work experience, administrative abilities and a familiarity with the region. Send resume and letter of interest to OA, Recruitment Committee-SAC, 26 West Street, Boston, MA 02111-1206. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 30.

Peace Corps of the United States has the following positions available:

TRAINING DIRECTORS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as training director for pre-service training in various countries. Contract are to begin in April, May or June 1994. QUALIFICATIONS: extensive Peace Corps training experience coordinating pre-service training activities, although similar experience in an international development organization will be considered; organizational and management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; crisis management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledge about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. For more information, contact Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

HEALTH TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Health Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in primary health care or maternal and child health education in West Africa; prior experience designing primary health care training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MPH or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter- cultural team of trainers; knowledgable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

EDUCATION TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Education Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in education in Africa; prior experience designing teacher training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MEd or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter- cultural team of trainers; knowledgable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

LANGUAGE COORDINATOR-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Language Coordinators for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps training experience competency-based language training; coordinating pre-service training activities; demonstated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledgable about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Private Agencies Collaborating Together (PACT), a US-based international development organization, seeks a DEPUTY DIRECTOR experience in the small and micro-enterprise (SME) field for its South Africa office. Candidate must be a South African with relevent education, good communication skills, and a commitment to empowering blacks to establish successful SMEs. Send letter with CV and contact address/telephone/fax to PACT, P.O. Box 32286, Braamfontein 2017, South Africa.

Save the Children seeks an ACCOUNTING TECHNICAL SPECIALIST to be responsible for installation and testing of an accounting software package to be installed in field offices in 30-plus countries. Approximately 60 percent travel required. Additional responsibilities include on-going technical support. Excellent technical and communications skills required; fluency in French or Spanish and previous non-profit experience desired. Send resume with salary requirements to Victoria Banks, Recruitment and Staff Development Specialist, Save the Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT 06880.

The Save the Children Fund seeks a HEALTH AND NUTRITION COORDINATOR in Darfur, Sudan and a RELIEF NURSE to help run a feeding program in the southern Sudan. The Health and Nutrition Coordinator must have experience with nutrition surveys, data analysis and health planning. For the Relief Nurse position, experience in feeding and working at the government level are needed, as well as an ability to work in an isolated and difficult area. For more information, contact: Richard Young, Save the Children Fund, 17 Grove Lane, London SE5 8RD; phone: 071-703-5400; fax: 071-703- 2278.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture of the New York Public Library announces its 1994-1995 Scholars-in- Residence Program. The program is designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, and encompasses projects in African, Afro-American, and AfroContact: Scholars-in-Residence Program, Schomburg Center for Caribbean history and culture. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone: (212) 491-2203.

TechnoServe, a non-profit rural enterprise development organization seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa Division Headquarters in Norwalk, CT. Responsibilities include project management, evaluation, budgeting, financial management, training and fundraising experience. QUALIFICATIONS: Five years resident overseas experience in business or agricultural development, seven years international development work, including at least two years in Africa; fluent French preferred; must be willing to travel internationally. Send letter and resume to: TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or fax (203) 838-6717, c/o Terri Scofield, manager of human resources.

The University of California, Santa Cruz is accepting applications for the ANTHROPOLOGY pool. Several part-time, temporary teaching positions are available for one or more quarters. The university seeks candidates able to teach one or more of the following courses: Anthropology of Religion, Peoples and Cultures of Africa, Culture and Colonialism or Medical Anthropology. Send letter of application, three letters of recommendation and syllabi for proposed courses to Carolyn Martin Shaw, Chair, Search Committee, Anthropology Board of Studies, Clark Kerr Hall, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064.

The University of Cape Town seeks a LECTURER OR SENIOR LECTURER in Experimental Physics. Preference given to applicants with active research interest in solid state physics or modern optics. The successful candidate will lecture at all levels, including large first-year classes, and run undergraduate, as well as senior laboratories. Send curriculum vitae with list of publications and three references to Appointments officer: University of Cape Town, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa; phone: (27 021) 650-2138; fax: (27 021) 650-2192.

The University of Florida is accepting applications for an ASSISTANT PROFESSOR opening in west or western equatorial African history. Applicants must have PhD by time of appointment; teaching experience is welcome. Tenure-track position to begin August 1994. Send letter of interest, curriculum vitae, three letters of recommendation, and supporting materials to Steven Feierman, University of Florida, Department of History, 4131 Turlington Hall, Gainesville, FL 32611. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 24, 1993. Interviews will be held at African Studies Association annual convention in Boston, December 4-7, 1993.

The University of Florida Center for African Studies seeks an assistant/associate in African Studies to serve as OUTREACH DIRECTOR of the 1994/1995 academic year. This is a nine-month, non-tenure accruing, renewable appointment and begins on or about August 13, 1994. Responsibilities include development of existing program to K-12, regional colleges and universities; planning/directing workshops/seminars; developing curriculum materials; preparing grant proposals, and representing the Center to the public. Requirements include an advanced degree in a field related to African studies, preferably with African field work; experience in public relations or program development desirable. Send curriculum vitae, letter detailing relevant background, pertinent interests and publications, and three letters of recommendation to Director, Outreach Search Committee, Center for African Studies, 427 Grinter Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611; phone: (904) 392-2183. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 1, 1993.

The University of Georgia is accepting letters of interest for a tenure-track faculty historian of the AFRICAN DIASPORA. Contact: Robert Pratt, Department of History, LeConte Hall, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602.

The University of Oregon seeks an ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF AFRICAN HISTORY. Tenure-track position with appointment to begin September 1994. Applicants may specialize in any region or period. PhD at time of appointment and strong commitment to scholarship required. Teaching experience and teaching breadth desirable. Send curriculum vitae, a letter describing research and teaching interests, samples of publications and written work, and three letters of recommendation to Quintard Taylor, Chair, Africa Search, Department of History, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403. DEADLINE: NOVEMBER 24, 1993.

Virginia Commonwealth University seeks a DIRECTOR OF AFRO- AMERICAN STUDIES. Qualifications include earned doctorate and record of teaching, research, scholarship, and professional service that will merit rank of professor with tenure in a discipline within the College of Humanities and Sciences. Prior administrative experience is desirable. Evaluation of applicants will begin immediately and continue until candidate is selected. Send letter of interest, curriculum vitae, and names and phone numbers of three references to Dr. Susan Estabrook Kennedy, Associate Dean, College of Humanities and Sciences, Box 2019, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA 23284-2019.

Washington-based international development agency has immediate openings for experienced professionals with expertise in health, population, and development economics to play key roles in expanding health and family planning service delivery programs in Washington and in selected countries in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Positions require Master's, M.D. or PhD level knowledge of development economics, health, child survival and family planning, population dynamics, health policy and/or extensive experience in overseas development. Postings will require security clearances. Fax resume with salary history to (202) 332-4496 or mail to Cindy Emory,.CEDPA, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20036. NO PHONE CALLS.

269 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; December, 1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians- in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; December 1993 and Mayanesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House.

Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

VISITORS


LENGTH: 1040 words

Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


RESOLUTION TO REMOVE UNITED STATES ARMED FORCES FROM SOMALIA BY JANUARY 31, 1994.


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Introduction

The House of Representative on November 10 approved a resolution supporting President Clinton's plan to withdraw U.S. troops from Somalia by March 31, 1994. The approval was contained in a $240.6 billion defense appropriation bill. 

The vote on the pullout date effectively amended a resolution sponsored by New York Republican Benjamin Gilman that called for all troops to be removed from the east African nation by the end of January.

The text of Gilman's non-binding measure is reproduced below.

U.S. House of Representatives

H. CON. RES. 170

103D CONGRESS

1ST SESSION

Directing the President pursuant to section 5(c) of the War Powers Resolution to remove United States Armed Forces from Somalia by January 31, 1994.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

October 22, 1993

Mr. Gilman (for himself and Mr. Spence) submitted the following concurrent resolution which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs

CONCURRENT RESOLUTION

Directing the President pursuant to section 5(c) of the War Powers Resolution to remove United States Armed Forces From Somalia by January 31, 1994. Resolved by the House of Representatives (The Senate concurring),

Section 1.

FINDING THAT THE UNITED STATES ARMED FORCES IN SOMALIA ARE ENGAGED IN HOSTILITIES.

For purposes of sections 5(c) and 7 of the War Powers Resolution (50 U.S.C. 1544(c) and 1546), the Congress finds that the United States Armed Forces in Somalia are engaged in hostilities without a declaration of war or specific statutory authorization.

Sec. 2. REMOVAL OF ARMED FORCES FROM SOMALIA.

Pursuant to section 5(c) of the War Powers Resolution (50 U.S.C. 1544 (c)), the Congress hereby directs the President to remove the United States Armed Forces from Somalia by January 31, 1994.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


THE BATTLE FOR SOUTH AFRICA'S WAR-MACHINE


BYLINE: Stephen Laufer (South Africa), THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, October 28 to November 4, 1993


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Armscor is up for grabs. The pacifists don't want to reap the spoils of war, the profiteers want to sell its services and products, and the pragmatists want its know-how to upgrade civilian industries, writes Stephen Laufer

High-explosive shells leave the muzzle of Armscor's G- 5 cannon at over 3 200km/h. Unlike the days of black powder and shot, when all that counted was hitting the enemy with something hard, modern warfare requires precise information on the shell's behaviour during flight, and what happens when it reaches its target.

The answer is telemetry, a sophisticated measurement system which tells the generals what the shells are doing. Crammed into the nose-cone, high-tech electronics radio thousands of pieces of data back to specialists at a test site.

Armscor considers itself an international leader in telemetry, and it would like to sell its boffins' services worldwide, in much the same way as it would like to export the other products of South Africa's military high-tech base -- armoured vehicles, attack helicopters and other lethal equipment. 

But as the country emerges from the international ban on arms trading -- which led to a major strengthening of the domestic capacity for the research, development and manufacture of sophisticated weapons systems -- the debate on the future of the industry is taking shape.

Pacifists and profiteers are pitted against one another. The arms lobby argues the time has come to reap the financial benefits of years and billions spent perfecting the South African Defenc e Force's war machines. Their opponents counter with the biblical demand for swords to be turned into ploughshares.

For the peaceniks, the issue is clearcut. "Seeing the suffering war has brought to Angola and Mozambique, I don't believe weapons exports can be good for us or for Africa," said Catholic Bishop's Conference secretary general Brother Jude Pieterse. "There is no way the bishops want to see the country's economy built on arm sales."

"We recognise that jobs and skills are tied to the arms industry," said David Bruce of the End Conscription Campaign, "so it won't be able to shut tomorrow. But the objective must be that South Africa no longer be a promoter of war. The industry should be scaled down."

Keeping the industry at present levels could prove seductive. With 70000 jobs, the arms industry is a major employer, despite having shed 30000 positions from its peak. Exports accounted for sales worth R419-million in the last financial year.

So it is likely to be the pragmatists in the middle who prevail, because of the technical skills and resources invested in the arms sector. Centred on the labour unions and military researchers close to the African National Congress, this school of thought wants to see the industry's know-how converted into a booster rocket for the civilian economy.

Their task will be to get away from the beguiling logic of the international arms industry, which has its subscribers across the political spectrum, including members of Umkhonto weSizwe.

For the skills and technological advantages built up over a generation to survive and continue competing internationally -- so goes the militarists' argument -- manufacturers need to be at the cutting edge of a range of relevant technologies. Maintaining that position is dependent in large part on the domestic consumer, the national defence force, paying for research and development and demonstrating confidence in the finished product by buying it.

Which may explain the air force's latest purchase of four Rooivalk attack helicopters at R8-million a piece, for testing and evaluation purposes. Like the new tank Defence Minister Kobie Coetsee praised last week as proof that South Africa is a world player in the development of high-tech military systems, the killer choppers were conceived in a period of conflict with South Africa's neighbours.

Unsuited to internal law-and-order use, they are obsolete -- unless doctrines are developed to justify their acquisition. These in turn require a scenario under which South Africa faces a conventional military threat which, by its nature, is most likely to be external. Such doctrines become powerful arguments in the sale pitch to foreign defences forces.

Even if the doctrines can be developed, making the international sales will be difficult. The world market is saturated.

Nevertheless, the air force generals are unlikely to disappoint the salesmen, unless the eternal circle is broken. The allusions of old to the civilian spin-offs -- the most famous example being the development of teflon frying pans as a byproduct of the United States space programme -- are unlikely to suffice, say those who want to see the defences industry take a different course.

"We would like to see a public debate on the need for weapons upgrading, coupled with a conversion council whose task it will be to examine ways of using the defence industry's resources to upgrade civilian industries," says Bernard Fanaroff, of the National Union of Metalworkers.

"The fact is that Armscor and the private arms manufacturers, because of the resource available to them for years, have captured the country's top class scientists and technicians. They are a national asset with high skills levels, top training facilities, and very sophisticated manufacturing equipment, all of which are in short supply in the civilian sector."

Armscor, Denel and the private sector arms maker are also streets ahead of the rest of industry when it comes to project management and technology acquisition, skills developed under the adverse conditions of the United Nations and other boycotts against South Africa

The challenge, says Fanaroff, will be to upgrade local industry using the know-how and tools already available in the country, but until now narrowly focused on arms production. Joint ventures should use the resources and facilities of the arms and manufacturers to improve the international competitiveness of civilian industry in such areas as computer technologies, optics, communications, fibre textiles, ceramics and propellants.

Using the arms industry's resources to improve the international competitiveness of industry as a whole, believe the pragmatists, will aid the process of moving away from weapons manufacturing. "We don't believe that relying on arms exports is a viable long-term option, because the domestic base must shrink as demands for state resources increase from other areas," says Fanaroff.

The key to change, say the pragmatists, will be greater transparency and accountability within the arms industry. "We believe that the boards of Armscor and Denel should democratised, in much the same way as is happening with other parastatals like Escom," he says, "and that an independent regulatory body be formed to oversee the arms industry, with a similar makeup to the National Economic Forum."

Armscor's regulatory role is growing, says its new representative, Abba Omar, a former MK cadre who stressed that he was still speaking in his personal capacity. "A tighter regime on arms exports should be the aim for the next four or five years. We must stick to UN embargos, and aim for a higher degree of public transparency on who is getting what from South Africa. We should also be giving some thought to limiting exports to areas of heightened tension."

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, Vol. 9, No. 43, October 29 to November 4, 1993.

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa. Phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


275 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


ANC WANTS GOOD CORPORATE CITIZENS


BYLINE: Reg Rumney


LENGTH: 920 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, October 28 to November 4, 1993

African National Congress economics spokesman Trevor Manuel distanced himself last week from attempts to incorporate into US legislation codes of conduct for businesses reinvesting in South Africa.

Manuel was speaking at a Weekly Mail and Guardian breakfast function to honour the winner of the newspaper's Investing in the Future Award, the Premier Group, and runners-up Mercedes Benz SA and Standard Bank.

Manuel noted corporate conscience was sorely needed in South Africa, and how the ANC was grateful to the WM&G Investing in the Future Review for focusing on the issue with the award.

He had just returned from a trip to the US, said Manuel, where he had had a difference of opinion with what he called good friends of the ANC on the attempt to incorporate into legislation a code of conduct for US companies reinvesting in South Africa. 

"It took some explaining to tell them we in the colony would be OK" and that there was some corporate conscience in South Africa, he said.

Manuel spoke about the rating of social responsibility, and contrasted the experience of a plant in Atlantis where workers were deeply involved in the running of the company but which probably did not have a big corporate social responsibility budget with that of a mining house which had a big CSR budget but which had retrenched 164,000 workers between 1987 and 1992.

How would one compare the social responsibility of this mining house with the Atlantis factory? he asked. Could a company like Thor Chemicals, he continued, even if it had a large chairman's fund, lifelong employment and worker participation ever make the grade?

It was apparent relative weight of factors would shift with time and circumstances.

A question he posed was what kind of model should South Africa follow?

Should it follow the example of the United States with its myriad of foundations? Or Japanese companies and lifelong employment? Of the South Korean model, where government-aided winning companies contribute to the national advantage?

Does one fall closer to compliance with agreed norms, or reward innovation? Another question was how social responsibility was measured and by whom?

Manuel said that notwithstanding the perception of the ANC as an omnipotent organisation with policies covering everything, it did not have a defined policy on corporate social responsibility. He outlined some continuing considerations revisited from time to time.

On the external environment, there were easily measured factors such as investing in deprived communities, separating social investment from normal marketing, and involving the community in decision-making about such investment.

Environmental concerns included the potential shift of hazardous industries to the underdeveloped world.

Referring to what he said were South Africa's stultified markets, he said the challenge of taking on the oligopolies, expanding non-primary exports, and ensuring lower prices to combat inflation and give access to essential goods and services to the poor should be rewarded.

Internal issues included industrial relations, enlarging employment and training and retraining.

National objectives were adding value non-primary exports, investment in research and development, affirmative action and expansion of employment opportunities.

The key question was how good a citizen was a particular corporation?

And the key challenge will be to "give content to democracy".

"A democratic government government cannot do it alone. We need partnerships with long-term vision that take account of the legacy and constraints a new government will face." Such partnerships would ensure South Africa's international competitiveness and the country's reintegration into the world economy.

Social responsibility programmes were an important part of such partnerships, he said.

From THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, October 28 to November 4, 1993

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa. Phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


ANGOLAN DEATH TOLLS RISES DEPITE MOVES TOWARD PEACE


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner, Africa News Service


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Menongue, Angola -- This small outdoor market is one of the growing signs of life in this city in Angola's southeastern highlands. The town has been under siege since the beginning of the year, and only in recent weeks has outside aid reached the beleaguered inhabitants.

Children run and play, vendors sell vegetables and small tins of cooking oil. One booth is named the Pharmacy of Hope. It has everything from a broken IV to amoxycillin and vitamins. 

But few people can afford the prices here. A handful of peanuts cost more thanan average day's pay. A soldier looking for extra cash at the market surreptitiously offers to sell uranium and mercury to foreigners.

The national government is trying to help rehabilitate Menongue. The town's bank has reopened with newly arrived cash, and school is scheduled to begin on November 15th. But, as the city comes back to life, people here are still struggling against death.

"Our first visit was to the hospital to get some sort of idea what sort of condition people were in," says Peter Middlemass, from the aid group Care International, which is helping provide assistance to Menongue. "Since my days in Somalia and on the border of Thailand, I hadn't seen people in such bad condition -- andthat included both young children and adults, and all the wasted suffering fromsome form of malnutrition.

Most of the nearly 400 patients here sleep on the hospital floors. About half are children. Many show the telltale signs of malnutrition, such as swollen bellies and tuftsof reddish hair on their heads. Among the adults are victims of land mines, other war injuries, and hunger.

Typical among the patients is one 23-year-old woman who is lying on a hospital balcony. As she sheltered her two starving babies under a blanket, she explainsthat until she recently began receiving food aid she had gone for four months, eating nothing but leaves.

Dr. Agular Vicente is the hospital's only physician. He says not only is food ihort supply but medicine also has been scarce during the siege. He has had to perform many amputations without anesthetics, he says.

An energetic man with a nervous laugh, Dr. Vicente says thousands of injured and malnourished people have come through the hospital in the past nine month. Some 500 of them have died.

"This time the conditions are much worse -- two, three, or four times worse than before," says Dr. Vicente. More people have died in the last nine months of fighting than during the sixteen years of war that followed Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975, he says.

That conflict was halted by a United Nations-brokered peace accord in 1991 between the formerly oviet-backed government led by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and the rebel movement known as UNITA, headed by Jonas Savimbi, which had beensupported by the United States. The country's first democratic elections were held just over a year ago, but fighting resumed after UNITA charged fraud and refused to accept defeat.

The United Nations estimates that at least 1,000 people are dyingdaily in Angola, but nobody knows for sure. Menongue is only one of a number of towns that have been under attack since the renewed outbreak of hostilities one year ago.

In the run-up to the elections, the government left only 26 soldiers to guard the city. When UNITA attacked, civilians -- some of them over 70 years old -- took up arms to help defend the town until government reinforcements arrived. Still, Menongue was completely cut off for nine months, until fighting subsided enough for international aid flights to resume here last month.

The guns are mostly silent now. One recent night, when journalists were visiting, a group of teenage boys held evening prayer services in the local Roman Catholic church.

Hope has returned with the arrival of food aid and outside help. But, nobody knows how long the food deliveries will continue. UNITA still has the city surrounded, and peace talks have yet to produce a definitive end to the fighting.

UN negotiators plan to hold another round of talks this month in an effort to forge an agreement that can lead to lasting peace.


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

277 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


NOVEMBER 15, 1993


South Africa Sanctions Bill Stuck in the U.S. Congress


BYLINE: Reed Kramer, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Washington, D.C. -- Unless an unexpected Congressional roadblock is removed this week, the United States could be left as the only country maintaining economic sanctions against South Africa.

In the wake of Nelson Mandela's Sept. 24 speech to the United Nations calling for the international embargo to be lifted, restrictions on trade and investment have been removed by the European Community, the 50-member Commonwealth, the 51-nation Organization of African Unity, and the largest Asian economic powers, including China and Japan. The two biggest American cities, New York and Los Angeles, have repealed sanctions measures, as have several other local governments and state legislatures in Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Michigan.

But lack of action by the House of Representatives on a bipartisan measure passed by the Senate over six weeks ago threatens to keep U.S. anti-apartheid legislation in force until next year. Supporters of sanctions repeal say that could stymie American assistance to South Africa during the crucial run-up to next April's elections and could damage U.S. competitiveness in one of the world's top 25 emerging markets. 

"With South Africa preparing for its first ever democratic vote but threatened with continuing violence, this is not a time for inaction," Harry Johnson, a Florida Democrat who chairs the Africa subcommittee warned last week. A compromise is in the works, but legislative time is running out, with Congress moving rapidly towards adjournment before Thanksgiving.

Although President Bush in 1991 lifted most of the sanctions enacted by the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act that Congress adopted over President Reagan's veto in 1986, current law still bars U.S. support for International Monetary Fund and World Bank lending to South Africa and limits the activities of the U.S. Agency for International Development and the U.S. Export Import Bank in South Africa.

On the day of Mandela's UN speech, a quick U.S. response to his appeal seemed likely as the Senate moved immediately to adopt sanction repeal legislation entitled the "South African Democratic Transition Act of 1993." The Public Works, Banking and Foreign Affairs Committees in the House subsequently endorsed H.R. 3225. the House version of the bill.

But the fourth and final House panel with jurisdiction over the matter, the powerful Ways and Means Committee, chaired by Dan Rostenkowski, has not acted -- for reasons having nothing to do with South Africa or the sanctions issue. According to Congressional aides, the Illinois Democrat does not want to send any bill to the Senate containing revenue-related provisions for fear it cld become what one Capitol Hill source termed "a Christmas tree to which all kinds of unrelated measures could be attached." House and Senate parliamentarians have advised that a few sections of the sanctions bill could have potential revenue implications.

The delay in passage of what had been expected to be non-controversial legislation has alarmed Capitol Hill supporters of the legislation who believe this could signal American disinterest in South Africa at a critical political juncture and might discourage, at least temporarily, some of the American companies now considering post-apartheid investment and trade deals.

A number of American firms are now poised for a move into South Africa, following a decade of withdrawals in response to escalating political confrontation in South Africa and domestic pressures in the United States. "South Africa is twice the size of our next largest market in Africa, Nigeria," Carl Ware, president of Coca-Cola's Africa Group, said in a recent interview. ""We are ready for reentry as soon as conditions are suitable."

With so few days left before the Congressional session ends, supporters of sanctions repeal are worried. "If the bill does not pass during this session," one frustrated Congressional staff member said, "we will be debating it again in February or March when we should be focusing on support for the elections, not the old issue of sanctions."

To meet Rostenkowski's concerns, sections of the Senate-passed measure dealing with taxes and empowering the president to extend trade preferences to South Africa likely will be removed, the aides said. This may clear the way for House passage later this month.

The proposed compromise resulted from several days of campaigning by interested members from both Houses and lobbying by White House officials. "This is a real priority for us," one senior administration official said. "We didn't expect to encounter any problem since no one actually opposes passage."

To try to insure the bill's adoption this year, Senator Nancy Kassebaum, the leading Republican sponsor of the legislation, telephone Rostenkowski and her Democratic co-sor, Paul Simon from Illinois, who chairs the Senate Africa subcommittee, asked thedministration to intervene and make its interest in adoption known. In the House, Johnston appealed for help from a Florida colleague and friend, Sam Gibbons, who chairs the Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee, which endorsed the bill during a mark-up session on November 9.

Although long-time sanctions advocates like the Congressional Black Caucus have joined in pressing for passage of the repeal measure, following the lead of the African National Congress, anti-apartheid forces have had mixed feelings about the wisdom of relinquishing economic leverage gained over years of legislative battles. Until recently, the ANC indicated an interest in linking the removal of sanctions to the adoption of a new "code of conduct" for foreign companies investing in South Africa but now opposes attaching any conditions to repeal.

Jennifer Davis, executive director of the New York- based American Committee on Africa, the oldest U.S. anti- apartheid organization, says her group favors language like that adopted by the Washington, D.C. Council in a non- binding resolution calling for "reasonable efforts" to invest in companies that adhere to a set of ANC "guiding principles" in their dealings with South Africa. "This provides a form of pressure that may be useful when a company is mistreating its worrce or otherwise behaving very badly," she says. But few other municipalities or states have passage such a provision, and the bill before Congress would end the Code of Conduct requirements contained in the 1986 Anti-Apartheid Act, as soon as the president certifies that a nonracial, democratically elected government has taken office in South Africa.

While visiting the United States last month, Mandela put the emphasis on attracting foreign capital rather than regulating business activity. "We have issued a code to protect investment," he told a conference of institutional investors in Washington, echoing earlier remarks before a gathering a corporate executives in New York. "There will be no confiscation of property, " he said, and the ANC is not going to adopt "reckless" policies that might drive business away."


LOAD-DATE: November 15, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 851 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. BUSINESS


LENGTH: 667 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

* Training Department Equipment. A.I.D. Grant # 263- 0173.01 IFB # 93-04. Purchaser: Operations Management International, Procurement Department, a subsidiarty of CH2M Hill Ltd., 700 Clearwater Lane, Boise, ID 83712, Attn: Kelly Kurdy; phone: (208) 386-9186. Phone offers will not be accepted. BID DEADLINE: DECEMBER 20. Write to the above address to obtain a copy of this RFQ. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request. 

* Instruments and Laboratory Supplies. A.I.D. Project # 263-0152. RFQ # 263-0152.04 SEED/93-03. Purchaser: EduSystems Inc., P.O. Box 1030, Walworth, WI 53184-1030, Attn: Cyndy Christian; phone: (414) 275-5761. Phone offers will not be accepted. BID DEADLINE: DECEMBER 6. Write to the above address to obtain a copy of this RFQ. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

* Test Equipment and Spare Parts. A.I.D. Grant # 263- 0194.01. IFB # 17841-04A. Purchaser: Black & Veatch International, P.O. Box 8405, Kansas City, MO 65114, Attn: Donald Disbrow; phone: (913) 339-7475; fax: (913) 329-2888. Fax and phone offers will not be accepted. BID DEADLINE: DECEMBER 20. Send a check for US$50 to the above address to obtain a copy of this IFB. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

* Microprocessor Development System for the Maintenance of Microprocessor-Based Radioactive Monitoring Remote Stations. C.I.P. Grant #263-K-620. IFB # AEA/2-94/ARE. Purchaser: Atomic Energy Authority, National Center of Nuclear Safety and Radiation Control. Fax and phone offers will not be accepted. BID OPENING DATE: DECEMBER 14. To obtain a copy of this IFB, send a check for US$20 to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

To obtain a copy of this IFB, write to the above address. Please include address and telephone number and telex, cable or fax number with your request.

280 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3920 words


 

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962- 1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, phone: (202) 673-3916.

The African Studies Association of Young Scholars (ASAYS) has been formed to promote scholarship and professionalism among young Africanist scholars; to provide an opportunity and a forum for the exchange of thoughts and ideas related to Africa; and to provide a bridge between students, academics and professionals. ASAYS intends to promote and sponsor mini-conferences and to create and disseminate a national data base on the current activities and interests of young Africanist scholars. The group plans to develop a constitution and affiliation with the African Studies Association (ASA). A meeting to explore that relationship will be held during the ASA annual meeting in Boston, MA, December 4-7. For more information, contact: Laura Hendricks or Karl Fickenscher, James S. Coleman African Studies Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024; fax (310) 206-2250. 

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Progams, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro- American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies at the University of Rochester is calling for applications for its 1994-1995 Residential Fellowships. Available are one postdoctoral fellowship, one predoctoral dissertation fellowship, and two four-year fellowships for graduate study. Welcome projects include historical and contemporary topics onthe economy, society, and culture of Africa and its diaspora, as well as projects on human and technological aspects of energy development and agriculture in Africa. DEADLINE: JANUARY 31, 1994. Contact: Associate Director for Research and Curriculum, Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African- American Studies, University of Rochester, 302 Morey Hall, Rochester, NY 14627; phone: (716) 275-7235.

The Fulbright Scholar Program offers a Fulbright Research Grant in conjunction with a ten-month position as Director of the West African Research Center in Dakar, Senegal. The WARC serves as a focal point of US-West African academic exchange. The grantee will manage the WARC as well as pursue independent research. Field experience in West Africa and/or experience administering overseas programs preferred. Fluent French and US citizenship required. The award will begin in October 1994. APPLICATION DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Contact Christine Djondo, Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone: (202) 686-4028 or 686-4029; fax: (202) 362-3442.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806 7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities offers African Humanities Fellowships to support postdoctoral scholars and students in the final stages of their dissertation write-up. Scholars will participate in a residential seminar on "Powers of Expression and Expression of Power." DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF ALL APPLICATIONS: DECEMBER 17, 1993. Contact: African Humanities Institute, SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The Institute for Advanced Study and Research in the African Humanities seeks applicants for one-year residencies at the Institute on the campus of Northwestern University. Humanists and social scientists are encouraged to apply as are writers, artists, musicians, performers and cultural specialists. Theme for 1994-95 seminar: "Power of

Words/Words of Power." DEADLINE: DECEMBER 17, 1993. The international competition is administered by the Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two- week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accomodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF-Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The International Foundation for Education and Self- Help's International Fellows Program encourages minority graduate students, as well as others, to participate in nine-month internships with self-help, economic development programs. Tuskegee University in Alabama implements the International Fellows Program through its office of International Programs. IFESH pays the cost of orientation, travel, health insurance and an overseas living allowance.

APPLICATION DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 10, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254 4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The IFESH is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round-trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Johann Jacobs Foundation encourages African scholars to apply for support of doctoral research concerning youth in a changing world. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland.

The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers international fellowships within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the

U.S. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone: (616) 968-1611.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites applications for grants for women from developing countries who are studying in the United States and have a demonstrated interest in the problems and needs of women and children in their countries. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. For application forms contact: Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund, 1818 H Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20433.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353- 1700.

Michigan State University Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Museum for African Art's "Discovering Africa" travel series continues this winter with trips to Mali (January 3- 16, 1994), Cote d'Ivoire (January 17-28), Ghana/Benin (January 17-28), and Nigeria (February 15-March 2). Participants travel in small groups and focus intensely on the culture and people of Africa, meeting Africans who are leaders in the continent's art and politics. Contact: Jerry Vogel, The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012; phone: (212) 966-1313; fax: (212) 966-1432.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population- Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747 0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program provides support for post graduate research in areas of economic development. Proposals for 1994 should relate to either privatisation or education for women. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993. Applications available from: The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program, Room M-4029, World Bank, 1818 H Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have ompleted all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub- Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post-doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re- Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture of the New York Public Library announces its 1994-1995 Scholars-in-Residence Program. The program is designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, and encompasses projects in African, AfroJANUARY 15, 1994. Contact: Scholars-in-Residence Program, American, and Afro-Caribbean history and culture. DEADLINE: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone: (212) 491- 2203.

The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) announces its International Predissertation Fellowship Program. Full-time students working towards a Ph.D. are invited to apply for a 12-month training fellowship to study the culture in Africa or some other developing region. Candidates should be early in their training and seek language and area studies to complement disciplinary work. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 10, 1993. Contact: SSRC, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10058; phone: (212) 661-0280.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

Wells College will sponsor a course on "Senegalese Society, Culture, and Politics" in Dakar, Senegal, January 2-21, 1994. Most lectures will be held at the Universite Cheikh Anta Diop. The $2,200 cost of this course includes flight, ground transporation, room and board, and other cultural events. Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O. Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; phone: (315) 463-3220.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12- month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

281 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5374 words


 

Africare seeks a FUNDRAISER to manage the $20 million, five-year endowment campaign. This new position reports to the Director of Resource Development and requires the capabilty to organize the campaign from ground zero. Also requires developing rating system, donor tracking, starting planned giving, establishing volunteer committees, cultivating and stewarding donors. Travel required. Persuasive oral and written communication skills required. Strong interpersonal skills and computer literacy are a must. Send resume and cover letter by DECEMBER 6 to: Major Gifts Position, Africare, P.O. Box 26386, Washington, DC 20001. No phone calls.

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an ACCOUNTANT for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226. 

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiatins, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783- 5247.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Malawi:

CLINICAL POSITION, based in the Chikwawa District. Requires: MD, RN, PA, or NP; cholera and developing countries experience; self-starter. Position will be from two-to-four months. JANUARY OPENING.

In Mozambique:

A COUNTRY DIRECTOR to manage and direct the Mozambique program, which includes water/sanitation, construction and health programs; represent ARC to the government of Mozambique, donors and other NGOs; manage professional expatriate and national staff; prepare reports; and monitor field projects. Qualifications include experience in managing development of relief programs in developing countries; fluency in Portuguese, French or Spanish; strong, written, oral and interpersonal skills; and experience in budget monitoring and reporting. FEBRUARY OPENING. US$2,000 a month.

A PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL to develop public health program in coordination with the water and sewer projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH; proven success in implementing new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. One-year contract. JANUARY OPENING. US$1,500 a month.

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training andUS supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

TBA COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the TBAs; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. Qualifications: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. Six-month commitment, US$1,500 a month. MARCH OPENING.

CHW COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to implement CHW training programs for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; interact with other agencies. Requires: RN, NP, PA, or MPH; proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,500 a month. Nine-month commitment.

MOBILE CLINIC SUPERVISOR, based in Afmadou, to communicate with local elders and authorities in the selection of mobile medical assistants; conduct a two-week training to prepare assistant for activities to be implemented by the local clinic; and develop and implement mobile medical activities to all accessible villages inthe Afmadou district. Qualifications: RN or NP; experience in developing country, preferably in rural setting; training experience; and ability to work effectively with people from different cultures. Six-month contract, US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

In Southern Sudan:

FIELD COORDINATOR based in Kajo Keji County to coordinate program activities, participate in program development, supervise activities, including hiring of local staff; commodity management; liaison with local elders, authorities, and other agencies; maintain daily communication with Nairobi office; assist in budget development and management; assist with establishment of policies and procedures for ARC field staff regarding illness and security. Qualifications: management experience in a developing country, preferably in a rural setting; education; background in health management or related field. One-year commitment. US$1,500 a month. Immediate opening.

HOME VISITOR COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial one-month training course and provide continuing education for workers; supervise daily activities and participate in clinical operations. Qualification: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

MCH COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities in selecting MCH care workers; conduct a one-month training to qualify them to work as TBAs; offer one-on-one counseling for traumatized women; supervise MT care workers; assist in clinical operations and conduct community education. Qualifications: RN with MCH and counseling background. Previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide surgical skills/emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening. NURSE to provide relief/acute care to displaced persons. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening. American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

The Center for Arabic Study Abroad seeks an Executive Director for the period June 1994 to June 1996. CASA offers intensive summer and full-year programs in spoken and advanced literary Arabic for American college and high- school students and faculty. It is operated at the American University in Cairo under the governance of 22 American universities. Contact: Gerald E. Lampe, Director, CASA, SAIS/Johns Hopkins University, 1619 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; phone: (202) 663-5751.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student- directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevent skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID- funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

Qualifications required include a university degree in agriculture or social sciences or communication/journalism or other related field. Ten years of progressively responsible professional experience in the field of information and development support communication, production and use of audio-visual materials, and training in communication. Experience in press, radio and TV management. Working knowledge of Arabic, English and French. Salary ranges: US$62,685 to $73,535 (without dependents) and US$67,214 to $79,852 (with dependents). CLOSING DATE: DECEMBER 22, 1993. Contact: Executive Director, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20437.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.
