The Administrative Assistant will report directly to the Administrative Coordinator and be responsible for the following: administrative support; and drafting correspondance and overheads in Arabic. Required qualifications include: minimum 50 word-per-minute typing speed, word processing experience (WordPerfect 5.1 or Microsoft Word); three years of previous administrative/secretarial experience; occasional overtime required; proficiency in Arabic. Pay range: $10.50 to $12 an hour. Send resume to: University Research Corporation, 7200 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 600, Bethesda, MD 20814; phone: (301) 654-8338.

Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

282 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management.

Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to- Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the

following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; December, 1993 and April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians- in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI (assignment length open; November and December 1993, April-December 1994): Umtata Hospital and Transkei Medical School will host volunteers for teaching and care giving for orthopedic needs. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton, (704) 692-5781 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; December 1993 and Mayanesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296- 0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmeceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

"Democracy: Popular Precedents, Popular Practice and Popular Culture"

Send proposed paper titles to: The Administrative Secretary, History Workshop, University of Witwatersrand, P.O. Wits, Johannesburg 2050, South Africa.

"Texts and Images of People, Politics and Power: Representing the Bushman People of Southern Africa."

Deadline for papers is June 1994.

Africa News


December 6, 1993


BOTSWANA GETS A BAD CASE OF THE BLUES


BYLINE: AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, September 1993


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

For almost three decades a very nice little runner in the political and economic stakes, the dry, sprawling, diamond-rich social democracy is hitting a rough patch, and checking out its next step. Methaetsile Leepile tracks the political infights and the major players. Annabel Dunn looks at the economic options.

Things are not well within the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), the sacred cow of the country's politics. In power since independence 27 years ago, the party is paralyzed by power struggles between older members accustomed to the trappings of power, and the so-called newcomers. 

Trouble in the BDP started early last year when a commission set up by the President, Sir Ketumile Masire, to investigate illegal land deals in Gaborone's hinterland exposed widespread corruption and abuse by people in high places. Two implicated by the Kgabo report were then Vice President, Local Government and Housing Minister and party chairman Peter Simako Mmusi, and Agriculture Minister and party secretary general Daniel Kwelagobe. Under pressure from colleagues and the press, they resigned both their party and cabinet positions. But they insisted they had done nothing wrong -- they were leaving the party "to cleanse their names."

Both were in fact later absolved by a second enquiry, the Christie commission, led by a former Rhodesian high court judge, which investigated the Botswana Housing Corporation, a parastatal which fell under Mmusi. However, the judge did say Mmusi should take political responsibility for the entire mess. They took the government to court, a move that precipitated their resignations from cabinet, and hardened the division within the party.

Kwelagobe spent time mobilising support within national and local party structures throughout the country. He attacked his detractors -- led by archrival Major General Mompati Merafhe, Minister of Public Service -- as a bunch of power-hungry upstarts intent on destroying him and Mmusi. The BDP, he said in one of his famous diatribes, "shall not be controlled as though it were a private company, by small bands of people..." It later turned out that the cabal, dubbed "The Big Five," wanted to prevent Kwelagobe and Mmusi from standing for central committee elections.

The rest is history. At the July congress in Kanye, Kwelagobe and his faction swept up all but two of the ten available places and he and Mmusi were re-elected to their old positions. The other two places went to "neutrals" -- Vice President and Finance and Planning Minister Festus Mogae, and Commerce and Industry Minister Ponatshego Kedikilwe.

The Merafhe faction, fearing a witchhunt, reportedly trooped to State House to prevail on the President to nominate their number to the remaining five slots. He did -- much to the chagrin of the Kwelagobe faction.

In the last Parliamentary sitting, the war of words between the two factions continued unabated. For the first time in many years the House, which is dominated by ruling party politicians, was split down the middle between supporters of Merafhe and Kwelagobe. Predictably, Kwelagobe tried to block a bill which seeks to make it possible for any Botswana, whether a citizen by birth or naturalisation, to acquire land anywhere in the country. The Tribal Land (Amendment) Bill, which is a response to the Kgabo and Chrisitie reports, also seeks to eliminate the word "tribe" from the Act.

Merafhe argues that while the government is trying to attract investors from other nationalities, some people want them to be denied citizenship. "Those who advocate the retention of the word 'tribesman'' have their own motives...," he said. He was referring to the so-called North-South divide inside the party which Kwelagobe exploited to the full at the congress. Many of the people elected in Kanye are from the south, while those rejected were by and large from the north. Merafhe seems convinced that Kwelagobe is fanning the tribal flames for purely political ends.

Though basically cosmetic, both factions exploit the divide when it suits their egos. For instance in the runup to congress, BDP strongman Kwelagobe quoted from speeches by founding President Sir Sereste Khama, a northerner, when addressing committees from the north. This went down well -- even in death Sereste remains immensely popular. But Kwelagobe doesn't hesitate to label Merafhe and others in cabinet who control government as "Sereste's appointees," because a number of ex-ministers in cahoots with him, including southerners Mmusi and former Assistant Local Government Minister Ronald Sebego, are no longer in government. Could Kwelagobe be implying that Sir Ketumile, a southerner, who succeeded Sir Seretse, is a "northern boy"? The north-south divide has suddenly turned into a power struggle between government and party in Parliament.

The Merafhe group's fear is that the Kwelagobe faction will try to marginalise them in the coming elections. Kwelagobe, who didn't go very far in education (he did matric) is suspected of fearing the party newcomers, many of whom are affluent and educated. He likes to make the point that he was raised in the party, with nearly three decades as a party worker, building it into the powerful machine it is today. But as one of the "newcomers," Local Government Minister Chapston Butale said, he's been a party member since 1969, when Kwelagobe was in his early teens.

Kwelagobe, critics argue, thinks he was born to lead the BDP -- "he treats the party as if it were his backyard," confided one insider. "He has flooded party structures with his lackeys. Now they control the central committee. The next thing they will rig primary elections." (The central committee has the final say on people elected in the primaries).

It is said that for a long time Mmusi and Kwelagobe -- and even Masire -- surrounded themselves with "praise singers." In the runup to congress a pro-Merafhe source told the writer, "No one dared challenge the trio, their word was law. But that is no more." He feared Kwelagobe. "He is good with the people... He would be alright as Minister of Agriculture... but I shudder to think of that man becoming president."

Kwelagobe has become so confident that he now publicly criticises government policies, and the President. It was widely believed that after congress the duo would withdraw their case. It was postponed but not withdrawn. The President told delegates at Kanye that he "begged and pleaded with them" to withdraw, but they refused. Observers have interpreted this as implying that the President was tacitly admitting that the party and government had wronged Kwelagobe and Mmusi in suspending them. The party has since given the two a vote of confidence. Clearly, Kwelagobe is out to erode Masire's power, and if Masire still has any pretensions to State House, he would be better off taking the fight to Kwelagobe than to keep begging to him.

Reprinted from AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, September 1993.


LOAD-DATE: December 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


287 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


A RIGHT TO CHALLENGE THE BUREAUCRATIC MONOLITH


BYLINE: Anton Harber, THE WEEKLY MAIL AND GUARDIAN, November 12 to November 18,1993


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

The interim Bill of Rights finalised this week will open up exciting new opportunities for all sorts of social and environmental activities, argues Anton Harber.

When you are arrested in the future South Africa, a policeman will be obliged to read you your rights -- much as we see in American soap-operas and sitcoms.

And no longer will state officials, from passport issuers to stamp sellers, be able to make decisions that affect your life without giving you reasons -- and good ones too.

These are just two of the hidden elements in the draft Fundamental Rights chapter of the new constitution due to be finalised at the World Trade Centre this week. Most South Africans are not even aware of it, but the Bill creates a whole range of new rights that will fundamentally affect many lives. 

For example, the Bill gives every citizen the right to be furnished with reasons for administrative action which affects them (a passport refusal, a detention order, refusal of a military camp call-up ...) and those reasons have to be justified.

This gives ordinary people enormous scope to challenge actions by faceless and previously unaccountable bureaucrats.

The Bill is wide-ranging, covering everything from gender equality and the rights of detainees to the rights of children. It opens up whole new areas of activism for South Africans. As one small example, it includes the right not to be unfairly discriminated against on the basis of one's sexual preferences. This clause will empower gay activists far more than most constitutions do.

It also gives "every person ... the right to an environment which is not detrimental to his or her health or well-being," giving new clout to environmental lobbyists.

And, for the first time, South African law will allow for class or group actions, the basis on which activist and lobby groups have been able to use the courts in countries like the USA.

Our Bill has little of the clear and ringing language of its international equivalents. Now in its 11th draft, it is the result of complex and lengthy negotiation and is therefore often messy, convoluted and opaque.

So, the sanctity of private property was qualified by the African National Congress' desire to allow for restitution to people who were deprived of their property under apartheid, and that has in turn been qualified by others who fear the abuse of such redistributive rights. The result is a jurisprudential nightmare, a cocktail of ideas and equivocation that makes no one happy.

Nevertheless, the Bill of Rights will protect and empower all sorts of individuals and institutions previously attacked by the state. Universities will have their academic freedom entrenched; detainees will be protected against abuse; minority language groups will enjoy the right to their choice of language and cultural life; everyone will have freedom of movement, association and expression; no one can be deprived of their citizenship; education becomes a universal right, not a privilege.

In other instances, the negotiators have ducked difficult policy issues. The Bill guarantees an unequivocal right to life, but is silent on whether this prevents abortion or capital punishment.

Lawyers are divided on what this means. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Nic Corbett, has said he believes this precludes abortion. Others, such as Professor Dennis Davis of Wits University and Tony Leon of the Democratic Party, says it will not stop the aborting of an unviable foetus, such as in the first trimester of a pregnancy.

We will be caught into the same debate as the US Supreme Court, in which our constitutional court will have to determine what constitutes "life" and when a foetus is "living."

Other issues remain unclear. To what extent does the freedom of expression clause allow censorship of, say, pornography? Legal experts say it will allow the Publications Control Board to continue to work, but with significantly fewer powers and greater accountability.

All of these, however, are matters of interpretation, so the critical issue is who will do the interpreting; in other words, how will the extremely powerful constitutional court judges be chosen?

This remains a subject of controversy. The latest proposal is that, unlike ordinary judges who will be chosen by a special judicial commission made up of their peers and experts, the judges in the highest court of the land will be chosen by the multi-party cabinet.

Some experts argue that this leaves this decision in the hands of horse-trading politicians, it weakens the court as a counterbalance to parliament and it will favour bland and mediocre judges.

Others, however, say that this will give the court greater credibility. To leave it to a judicial commission will mean white, male judges will make the choice -- and they will inevitably lean toward white, male judges.

It is a critical issue, for issues as important as capital punishment, abortion and censorship will depend on how wise, just, fair, legally competent and credible these individuals are.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, November 12 to November 18, 1993.

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: December 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


Botswana Gets A Bad Case of the Blues


BYLINE: AFRICA SOUTH & EAST


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

For almost three decades a very nice little runner in the political and economic stakes, the dry, sprawling, diamond-rich social democracy is hitting a rough patch, and checking out its next step. Methaetsile Leepile tracks the political infights and the major players. Annabel Dunn looks at the economic options.

Things are not well within the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), the sacred cow of the country's politics. In power since independence 27 years ago, the party is paralyzed by power struggles between older members accustomed to the trappings of power, and the so-called newcomers. 

Trouble in the BDP started early last year when a commission set up by the President, Sir Ketumile Masire, to investigate illegal land deals in Gaborone's hinterland exposed widespread corruption and abuse by people in high places. Two implicated by the Kgabo report were then Vice President, Local Government and Housing Minister and party chairman Peter Simako Mmusi, and Agriculture Minister and party secretary general Daniel Kwelagobe. Under pressure from colleagues and the press, they resigned both their party and cabinet positions. But they insisted they had done nothing wrong -- they were leaving the party "to cleanse their names."

Both were in fact later absolved by a second enquiry, the Christie commission, led by a former Rhodesian high court judge, which investigated the Botswana Housing Corporation, a parastatal which fell under Mmusi. He attacked his detractors -- led by archrival Major General Mompati Merafhe, Minister of Public Service -- as a bunch of power-hungry upstarts intent on destroying him and Mmusi. The BDP, he said in one of his famous diatribes, "shall not be controlled as though it were a private company, by small bands of people..." The other two places went to "neutrals" -- Vice President and Finance and Planning Minister Festus Mogae, and Commerce and Industry Minister Ponatshego Kedikilwe.

The Merafhe faction, fearing a witchhunt, reportedly trooped to State House to prevail on the President to nominate their number to the remaining five slots. He did -- much to the chagrin of the Kwelagobe faction.

The Tribal Land (Amendment) Bill, which is a response to the Kgabo and Chrisitie reports, also seeks to eliminate the word "tribe" from the Act.

Merafhe argues that while the government is trying to attract investors from other nationalities, some people want them to be denied citizenship. "Those who advocate the retention of the word 'tribesman'' have their own motives...," he said. He was referring to the so-called North-South divide inside the party which Kwelagobe exploited to the full at the congress. Many of the people elected in Kanye are from the south, while those rejected were by and large from the north. Merafhe seems convinced that Kwelagobe is fanning the tribal flames for purely political ends.

Though basically cosmetic, both factions exploit the divide when it suits their egos. For instance in the runup to congress, BDP strongman Kwelagobe quoted from speeches by founding President Sir Sereste Khama, a northerner, when addressing committees from the north. This went down well -- even in death Sereste remains immensely popular. But Kwelagobe doesn't hesitate to label Merafhe and others in cabinet who control government as "Sereste's appointees," because a number of ex-ministers in cahoots with him, including southerners Mmusi and former Assistant Local Government Minister Ronald Sebego, are no longer in government. Kwelagobe, who didn't go very far in education (he did matric) is suspected of fearing the party newcomers, many of whom are affluent and educated. He likes to make the point that he was raised in the party, with nearly three decades as a party worker, building it into the powerful machine it is today. But as one of the "newcomers," Local Government Minister Chapston Butale said, he's been a party member since 1969, when Kwelagobe was in his early teens.

Kwelagobe, critics argue, thinks he was born to lead the BDP -- "he treats the party as if it were his backyard," confided one insider. "He has flooded party structures with his lackeys. Now they control the central committee. The next thing they will rig primary elections." (The central committee has the final say on people elected in the primaries).

It is said that for a long time Mmusi and Kwelagobe -- and even Masire -- surrounded themselves with "praise singers." In the runup to congress a pro-Merafhe source told the writer, "No one dared challenge the trio, their word was law. But that is no more." He feared Kwelagobe. "He is good with the people... He would be alright as Minister of Agriculture... but I shudder to think of that man becoming president."

Kwelagobe has become so confident that he now publicly criticises government policies, and the President. It was widely believed that after congress the duo would withdraw their case. It was postponed but not withdrawn. The President told delegates at Kanye that he "begged and pleaded with them" to withdraw, but they refused. Observers have interpreted this as implying that the President was tacitly admitting that the party and government had wronged Kwelagobe and Mmusi in suspending them. The party has since given the two a vote of confidence. Clearly, Kwelagobe is out to erode Masire's power, and if Masire still has any pretensions to State House, he would be better off taking the fight to Kwelagobe than to keep begging to him.

Reprinted from AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, September 1993.

LANGUAGE: English

289 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


Angolans Battle Unnoticed Hunger


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner, Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Luanda, Angola - Joao Batista, hungry for the grains of rice falling from bags of food aid onto the tarmac, threw himself under the white belly of the cargo plane with uncanny grace for someone who was drunk and has only one leg.

He was taking care not to shatter wine bottle he had tied inside the bottom of his empty pant leg to free his hands for stuffing rice into his oily pockets.

Batista, 30, is a former foot soldier for the Angolan army. His leg was blown off by a land mine and now he wanders the streets of the capital in his frayed military fatigues, a ghost of Angola's seemingly endless war. He and thousands like him are the mirror image of this teeming city that has become a filthy haven for lost, hungry and crippled souls since fighting resumed one year ago. 

The population of Luanda -- a seaside city once known as the Rio de Janeiro of Africa -- has increased by 40 percent in the past year as people flee fighting and famine in the interior.

But the estimated 600,000 refugees find little respite here, where inflation has hit 1,300 percent. As a result, the number of severely malnourished people in the city has doubled what it was five months ago, says Manuel da Silva, who heads the United Nations relief operation in Angola.

''We are getting concerned that this is increasing very fast,'' he says. ''It's very significant. The different aid agencies are getting very worried, including the World Bank, and people are trying to find means and plans of action to address this situation.''

International aid groups working in Angola have focused most of their attention on besieged cities in the interior where tens of thousands of people have died since fighting broke out in October last year after UNITA rebels rejected losing the southern African country's first democratic elections.

The health care of Luandans has not been a priority with the government. It dedicated only 0.3 percent of its budget this year to health, according to Ana Liria-Franch with the UN. High Commissioner for Refugees in Luanda.

The government's communications minister, Pedro Vall Neto, denies the government is not carrying out economic reforms that could help the impoverished and says it is trying to develop ''a liberal type of economy.''

''In England, America, in France -- all over the world it is like that. If you have your money you buy it, luxury or not, you buy it because you have the money to do it. If you don't have the money to do it you don't buy it because you can't,'' he says. ''If we start controlling that type of buying, how is the Western world going to react? They will be saying that we are going back to controlling the people again.''

Joao Bondo, his wife and six children are typical among those in Luanda with little buying power. He was a civil servant in the northern town of Uige with a comfortable life until fighting broke out. Here, he has no job and the family relies on the income of his wife who sells small items such as beer and biscuits on the street.

''When we have enough we eat three meals a day, breakfast, lunch and supper,'' says Bondo, 40. ''When we don't have enough we try to conserve by only eating supper. We didn't have this situation in Uige.''

Luanda's infrastructure was built to support about 400,000 people, not the 2.8 million who live here now. Those who do have jobs can hardly make a living.

At the Textang fabric mill, workers earn an average of 450,000 kwanzas per month, which is about $8 at the current black market rate. But even they could be out of a job within the next year. ''We are at 10 percent of production capacity,'' says Humberto Domingos da Costa, general director of Angola's industries. ''But we are still a bit satisfied because there aren't many factories in Angola that still function. But we do.''

Da Costa says he often trades kwanzas on the black market to obtain the dollars he needs to buy spare parts for his machines. ''We are a state company, but we don't depend on the state to function,'' he says.

Some of the massive green textile machines look as though workers went on their lunch break and never returned. Bolts of cloth are in mid-thread and a fuzzy, gray dust covers the machinery in a cotton cocoon, as if preserving them for the day when Luanda comes back to life.

Aid workers say the situation in Luanda will likely get worse before it gets better.

The rainy season is about to begin and is expected to bring a cholera epidemic with it that health workers fear will infect more than 1,000 people per week by next spring. Cholera exists in the city's piped water system, which is often unchlorinated, as well as in open sewers and streams that cut through the shantytowns.

''It's just going to be horrific in January, February and March'' as the epidemic peaks, says Peter Hawkins, who represents the British-based aid group Save the Children Fund in Angola. ''You have a very fit child in the morning who would be dead by the evening.''


LOAD-DATE: December 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1993


Africa's New Entrepreneurs Bring Dynamism to Faltering Economies, Woo Investors


BYLINE: Tami Hultman, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 2187 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe - Charles Msipa is bullish on Africa.

At a time when many outsiders view the continent's prospects as dismal, the 28-year-old businessman typifies a new breed of African entrepreneurs who expect an economic boom in the wake of widespread political reforms. Trained in international law, Msipa left a promising career in a London bank to become external affairs manager in southern Africa for Coca-Cola, which has created a new Africa division and is aggressively expanding in African countries.

"There really is a sense of revitalization and of empowerment of people going on all around Africa," Msipa said. "There's an air that things are changing and changing for the better, and people are feeling that they can participate more actively and contribute more." 

Since 1989, democracy movements have forced multiparty elections or limits to executive power in more than two dozen African countries. Along with political pluralism have come economic reforms that are making African countries more hospitable to private enterprise.

An additional element of the buoyant mood is the widespread belief that post-apartheid South Africa will become the engine that drives the continent's economic recovery.

Earlier this month, 20 eastern and southern African countries signed an agreement to establish a common market by the year 2000, in an area with a population of 270 million people and a gross domestic product of as much as $200 billion. South Africa, participating for the first time in an African summit, said it will join the group after establishing a transitional government in elections scheduled for next April.

Kenyan publisher Evelyn Mungai, who is vice chair of the fledgling African Business Roundtable, a forum of African business leaders, applauded the treaty as a boost for economic expansion throughout the region. "There is now a larger market for all of us," she said. "There is enormous opportunity for intra-regional trade and enterprise development."

But despite their optimism, some business leaders predict that stereotypes about Africa may limit the role American companies play in Africa's renewal, and they fear that the growth of African economies will be slowed as a result. The emerging markets of Asia, Latin America and eastern Europe may edge out Africa in the competition for investment dollars, they say.

Easom Alintah, a Nigerian who is secretary general of the Roundtable, believes that the export needs of American industry ought to be fueling a rush towards Africa's new markets. "There is money to be made in Africa," Alintah said during one of his trips to promote the Roundtable's agenda of policy reforms and international partnerships. "There is absolutely no reason why a U.S. business that approaches Africa with the same diligence with which it operates domestically shouldn't make a profit."

Alintah argued that Africa already is more important commercially to the United States than is commonly recognized. His country, Nigeria, supplies more than twice as much crude oil to the United States as Kuwait and Iraq combined prior to Desert Storm. "And you went to war for that," he said. By contrast, he noted, Nigeria's current political crisis is barely noticed in the United States.

U.S. Commerce Department statistics show that the volume of trade with Africa is more than three times as large as trade with all of eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. Although U.S. exports to sub-Saharan Africa grew 12% last year, some analysts say that is only a fraction of the potential increase.

"There is less interest in Africa around here than is warranted by the opportunities," said a Commerce Department aide who didn't want to be identified. "You don't hear the kind of talk about African countries that you do about Hungary or Poland, for example."

That may be changing. In remarks at the formal opening of the African Business Roundtable's Washington office in September, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown said he intends to play a part in "breaking the shackles of cynicism" about Africa's future. "As Secretary of Commerce," he said, "I am absolutely committed to making sure that Africa is ignored no more."

Brown leaves for South Africa on Friday with a delegation of two dozen business leaders. Department officials said the trip reflects growing awareness of Africa among U.S. firms. Last month in Washington, nearly 500 people, twice as many as predicted, paid $500 each to attend a one-day conference on investing in South Africa sponsored by Global Business Access, a private group.

Among those traveling with Brown will be Equitable Senior Vice President Frank Savage, who chairs the company's investment firm, Alliance Capital Management, which has launched a southern Africa capital fund that aims to put hundreds of millions of dollars into the region.

Savage recently visited Zimbabwe, where he said he has found the openness of government officials encouraging. "The serious capital pool for development in Africa is private, not government," he said, "and I don't think there's any question that Africans recognize that. They're also aware that it's crunch time for Africa, and that they either have to make further changes or be locked into the world's economic basement."

Savage is one of a growing group of African American business executives who are promoting Africa as a field of expansion for U.S. companies.

Justin Beckett of New Africa Ventures, an assets management firm headquartered in Durham, North Carolina, said investors who make the move into Africa now will be positioned to reap the largest profits from the continent's newly unfettered economies. New Africa is forming institutional and retail funds to invest in small, black-owned enterprises in South Africa as well as in companies listed on the Johannesburg stock exchange.

"The real opportunities are in countries of the world that are still developing," Beckett said. "And Africans are ready to be a part of that process. When I went to Russia recently, I found a lot of people who didn't even know what a check was. In west Africa, there were people who would take my check on the street. I saw sophisticated financial transactions by people who can't afford an office but who have the education and the energy to succeed. What they need is capital."

Beckett said New Africa intends to use South Africa, with its developed infrastructure and lively stock market, as a springboard to the rest of the continent, and he predicts other investors will do the same.

Not everyone is as sanguine about the impact of South Africa's new status on its neighbors. Earlier this month James Rawlings, a former U.S. ambassador to Zimbabwe and chairman of the Zimbabwe/U.S. Business Council, told the Zimbabwe Financial Gazette that the group will suspend its activities in the face of competition from South Africa for investor interest.

But Msipa, like other Africans interviewed, welcomes South Africa's integration into continental affairs. "Certainly South Africa's economy is much bigger and the industrial capacity much higher," he said, "but I think companies and businesses in the region will learn to be competitive and will find gaps where they can complement what is done by South African companies."

According to a recent report by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, that trend is already apparent. The study of southern African economies cited Zimbabwe's private sector for efficient management and forward-looking investment schemes tied to market demand. It also noted that, unlike the public sector, which has suffered a brain drain of skilled labor through emigration, the business community is becoming a model for utilizing indigenous skills and for technological development.

Msipa said another significant development is the changing African attitude towards foreign investment. He said the once-prevalent view that foreign companies are undesirable exploiters is being edged out by the recognition that investment generates the jobs that are essential to prosperity.

Citing Coca-Cola Africa as an example, Msipa said the company employs 40,000 people directly, but that its investments create hundreds of thousands of additional jobs through nationwide networks of suppliers and vendors, from glass manufacturers and graphic artists to sidewalk entrepreneurs and rural traders. More than 500,000 pieces of advertising, such as billboards, need to be updated or repainted every year.

Msipa said his own country is representative of the problems facing African governments, which, since independence, have done better at providing schooling than at stimulating economic growth. Zimbabwe has been described as having the world's most educated, unemployed work force.

"The single biggest factor that has brought this government to implementing reform programs," said Msipa, "is the dilemma of how to meet the aspirations that have been created by providing education for these young people." Zimbabwe recently reduced capital gains taxes and introduced full repatriation of capital and dividends, with further reforms scheduled to take effect in January.

But Msipa concedes that bureaucratic and regulatory barriers still discourage investment, in Zimbabwe and elsewhere. "Most African countries are trying to reduce the role of government and increase the participation of the private sector," he said, "but there is a gap between acceptance in theory and actually putting into place the policies that will attract the required level of investment." He said countries with the most favorable investment policies, like Namibia, will be the greatest beneficiaries of the growing interest in Africa.

Alintah agrees, arguing that too many African rulers continue to resist demands for accountable, efficient government. "Politicians think the public is more naive than it really is," he said, predicting that Nigeria faces serious social unrest as well as economic decline unless its military rulers proceed with democratic reforms that were suspended in June. "The only thing that has rescued the country up to this point is the strength of the private sector," he said. "But we can't provide the stable climate investors want without political order."

Still, Alintah argues, foreign firms who seek out knowledgeable African partners can do well, even in difficult conditions, just as Nigerian businesses have done. It is the growing number of Africans who are willing to invest in their own countries rather than sending their money abroad, he said, that will persuade foreign investors of Africa's potential.

Evelyn Mungai shares that view. "The private sector is the key to a very bright future," she said, arguing that African attitudes about pursuing careers in business are undergoing a fundamental change. "In the past," she said, "people sought security in the public sector. They saw business as something you do when you retire. Now the reverse is becoming true, and the dynamism of private enterprise is going to transform Africa."


LOAD-DATE: December 14, 1993


LANGUAGE: English

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell StampUs Head Office in London; phone 44- 71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

 

*CFA Franc = Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3774 words


 

Wells College will sponsor a course,"Senegalese Society, Culture and Politics", which will introduce students to the complexity of Senegalese society, culture and politics. Most lectures will be held at the Universite Cheikh Ahta Diop in Dakar.

Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O.

Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; phone: (315) 463-3220.

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part- time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and

information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The 

Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grassFoundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington,

roots development. Contact: African Development

DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916.

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on

the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to

apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in

Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State

Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro- American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530,

Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to

that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies at the University of Rochester is calling for applications for its 1994-1995 Residential Fellowships. Available are one postdoctoral fellowship, one predoctoral dissertation fellowship, and two four-year fellowships for graduate study. Welcome projects include historical and contemporary topics on the economy, society, and culture of Africa and its diaspora, as well as projects on human and technological aspects of energy

development and agriculture in Africa. DEADLINE: JANUARY

31, 1994. Contact: Associate Director for Research and Curriculum, Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies, University of Rochester, 302

Morey Hall, Rochester, NY 14627; phone: (716) 275-7235.

The Fulbright Scholar Program offers a Fulbright Research Grant in conjunction with a ten-month position as Director of the West African Research Center in Dakar, Senegal. The WARC serves as a focal point of US-West African academic exchange. The grantee will manage the WARC as well as pursue independent research. Field experience in West Africa and/or experience administering overseas programs preferred. Fluent French and US citizenship required. The award will begin in October

1994. APPLICATION DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Contact Christine Djondo, Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Washington,

DC 20008-3009; phone: (202) 686-4028 or 686-4029; fax: (202) 362-3442.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL

SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University,

Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accommodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July

10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF- Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA

98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually

activated): (206) 628-9314.

The International Foundation for Education and Self- Help's International Fellows Program encourages minority graduate students, as well as others, to participate in nine-month internships with self-help, economic development programs. Tuskegee University in Alabama implements the International Fellows Program through its office of International Programs. IFESH pays the cost of orientation, travel, health insurance and an overseas

living allowance. APPLICATION DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 10, 1994.

Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260,

Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The IFESH is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round- trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance

while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254 The Johann Jacobs Foundation encourages African

4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824. scholars to apply for support of doctoral research

concerning youth in a changing world. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland.

The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers international fellowships within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already

reside in the U.S. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue

East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone: (616) 968-1611.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites applications for grants for women from developing countries who are studying in the United States and have a demonstrated interest in the problems and needs of women

and children in their countries. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15,

1994. For application forms contact: Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund, 1818 H Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20433.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to

December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State

University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353- 1700.

Michigan State University Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in

this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032.

Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons

and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management

Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Museum for African Art's "Discovering Africa" travel series continues this winter with trips to Mali (January 3-16, 1994), Cote d'Ivoire (January 17-28), Ghana/Benin (January 17-28), and Nigeria (February 15- March 2). Participants travel in small groups and focus intensely on the culture and people of Africa, meeting Africans who are leaders in the continent's art and

politics. Contact: Jerry Vogel, The Museum for African

Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012; phone: (212) 966 National ScienceFoundation Dissertation Improvement

1313; fax: (212) 966-1432. Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses.

DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis

Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered.

Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029;

phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program provides support for post graduate research in areas of economic development. Proposals for 1994 should relate to either

privatisation or education for women. DEADLINE: DECEMBER

31, 1993. Applications available from: The Robert McNamara Fellowships Program, Room M-4029, World Bank, 1818 H Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have completed all course work and qualifying exams prior

to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain

applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub- Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked

previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for

candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the

Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post- doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African

research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133

Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212)

869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture of the New York Public Library announces its 1994-1995 Scholars-in-Residence Program. The program is designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, and encompasses projects in African, Afro- American, and Afro-Caribbean history and culture.

DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Contact: Scholars-in-Residence Program, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture,

515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone: (212) 491-2203.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and

live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820;

phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and

maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at

Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

Wells College will sponsor a course on "Senegalese Society, Culture, and Politics" in Dakar, Senegal, January 2-21, 1994. Most lectures will be held at the Universite Cheikh Anta Diop. The $2,200 cost of this course includes flight, ground transportation, room and board, and other

cultural events. Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O. Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY

13026; phone: (315) 463-3220.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12- month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate

research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994.

Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3;

phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The Center for Afro-American and African Studies at the University of Michigan offers a residency fellowship focusing on the them "African Peoples in the Industrial

Age." Details are available through that center at: 200 West Engineering Building, The University of Michigan, Ann

Arbor, MI 48109-1092. DEADLINE: JANUARY 5, 1994.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5200 words


 

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an ACCOUNTANT for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national

staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Malawi: CLINICAL POSITION, based in the Chikwawa District. 

Requires: MD, RN, PA, or NP; cholera and developing countries experience; self-starter. Position will be from two-to-four months. JANUARY OPENING.

In Mozambique: A COUNTRY DIRECTOR to manage and direct the Mozambique program, which includes water/sanitation, construction and health programs; represent ARC to the government of Mozambique, donors and other NGOs; manage professional expatriate and national staff; prepare reports; and monitor field projects. Qualifications include experience in managing development of relief programs in developing countries; fluency in Portuguese, French or Spanish; strong, written, oral and interpersonal skills; and experience in budget monitoring and reporting. FEBRUARY OPENING. US$2,000 a month.

A PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL to develop public health program in coordination with the water and sewer projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH; proven success in implementing new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. One-year contract. JANUARY OPENING. US$1,500 a month.

In Somalia: MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

TBA COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the TBAs; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. Qualifications: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. Six-month commitment, US$1,500 a month. MARCH OPENING.

CHW COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to implement CHW training programs for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; interact with other agencies. Requires: RN, NP, PA, or MPH; proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,500 a month. Nine-month commitment.

MOBILE CLINIC SUPERVISOR, based in Afmadou, to communicate with local elders and authorities in the selection of mobile medical assistants; conduct a two-week training to prepare assistant for activities to be implemented by the local clinic; and develop and implement mobile medical activities to all accessible villages in the Afmadou

district. Qualifications: RN or NP; experience in developing country, preferably in rural setting; training experience; and ability to work effectively with people from different cultures. Six-month contract, US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

In Southern Sudan:

FIELD COORDINATOR based in Kajo Keji County to coordinate program activities, participate in program development, supervise activities, including hiring of local staff; commodity management; liaison with local elders, authorities, and other agencies; maintain daily communication with Nairobi office; assist in budget development and management; assist with establishment of policies and procedures for ARC field staff regarding

illness and security. Qualifications: management experience in a developing country, preferably in a rural setting; education; background in health management or related field. One-year commitment. US$1,500 a month. Immediate opening.

HOME VISITOR COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial one-month training course and provide continuing education for workers; supervise daily activities and

participate in clinical operations. Qualification: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

MCH COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities in selecting MCH care workers; conduct a one-month training to qualify them to work as TBAs; offer one-on-one counseling for traumatized women; supervise MT care workers; assist in clinical operations and conduct community education. Qualifications: RN with MCH and counseling background. Previous experience in a developing country. One-year commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide surgical skills/emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening.

NURSE to provide relief/acute care to displaced persons. Six-month commitment. US$1,200 a month. Immediate opening. American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health

insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

The Center for Arabic Study Abroad seeks an Executive Director for the period June 1994 to June 1996. CASA offers intensive summer and full-year programs in spoken and advanced literary Arabic for American college and high-school students and faculty. It is operated at the American University in Cairo under the governance of 22 American universities. Contact: Gerald E. Lampe, Director, CASA, SAIS/Johns Hopkins University, 1619 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; phone: (202) 663-5751.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student- directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID- funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university-based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The International Development Group in Bethesda, Maryland seeks a BILINGUAL (ENGLISH/ARABIC) ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT for a part-time (20-to-24-hour-a-week) position. The Administrative Assistant will report directly to the Administrative Coordinator and be responsible for the following: administrative support; and drafting correspondence and overheads in Arabic. Required qualifications include: minimum 50 word-per-minute typing speed, word processing experience (WordPerfect 5.1 or Microsoft Word); three years of previous administrative/secretarial experience; occasional overtime required; proficiency in Arabic. Pay range: $10.50 to $12 an hour. Send resume to: University Research Corporation, 7200 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 600, Bethesda, MD 20814; phone: (301) 654-8338.

International Medical Corps has an opening for a COUNTRY DIRECTOR to plan, develop and implement its programs in Somalia. Five years experience managing international health care or humanitarian relief projects, leadership experience; strong supervisory, administrative and communications skills; accounting skills desirable. Prefer M.D. with knowledge of tropical medicine, EPI and maternal/child. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Assignment is for minimum of one year. Immediate opening. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-021, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax (310) 442- 6622.

For its operations in Somalia, IMC also seeks:

FAMILY PRACTICE PHYSICIAN. Prefer tropical medicine background; two to three years in developing countries. One- year contract. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in Southern Sudan:

HEALTH WORKER TRAINERS with experience in community development and education in developing countries, MPH preferred;

PHYSICIANS with background in tropical medicine and immunization programs;

VACCINATORS/TRAINERS with experience in EPI implementation, MPH preferred.

Roundtrip transportation, room and board provided for each of these positions. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #2809, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442-6622.

the AID Mission to Kenya. Operation Crossroads Africa seeks individuals to serve as LEADERS/FACILITATORS during the summer months for work projects in Africa. Crossroads is a U.S.-based international, private voluntary organization involved in cross-cultural exchanges and small-scale development projects for college students. Applicants should be at least 26 years of age and have knowledge about Africa. Previous travel experience and demonstrated group leadership is also required. Leaders/facilitators are provided with transportation and living expenses while in Africa and a small honorarium. Crossroads also seeks specialized experienced applicants for projects in Africa in preventive medicine and health education. DEADLINE: JANUARY 19, 1994. Contact: Operation Crossroads Africa, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 242, New York, NY 10115.

Peace Corps of the United States has the following positions available:

Contract are to begin in April, May or June 1994. QUALIFICATIONS: extensive Peace Corps training experience coordinating pre-service training activities, although similar experience in an international development organization will be considered; organizational and management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; crisis management skills; demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledge about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. training in Africa. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Candidate must be a South African with relevant education, good communication skills, and a commitment to empowering blacks to establish successful SMEs. The Health and Nutrition Coordinator must have experience with nutrition surveys, data analysis and health planning. For the Relief Nurse position, experience in feeding and working at the government level are needed, as well as an ability to work in an isolated and difficult area. They recruit medical personnel for specific posts in response to requests from governments and organizations in the countries. HOUSE OFFICER for Swaziland. Contact: Craig Brown, Skillshare Africa, 3 Belvoir Street, Leicester LE1 6SL, UK; 24-hour phone: 0533 540517; fax: 0533 542614.

Town, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa; phone: (27 021) 650 2138; fax: (27 021) 650-2192.
