LOAD-DATE: January 10, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management.

Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to- Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the

following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897- 4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296- 0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

301 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


SOME SERIOUS REGIONAL INITIATIVES ON SUDAN


BYLINE: Bona Malwal, SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, December 1993


LENGTH: 907 words


 

One of the most talked of failures in African politics is the dismal record that the continent's political leadership has when it comes to conflict resolution and peace making. One could be forgiven for thinking that Africa has lost its way, or somehow lacks leadership and statesmen, when considering that half the world's conflicts are happening on that continent. Where is the political machinery for dealing with Africa's conflicts?

The Organisation for African Unity (OAU), Africa's political club of governments, behaves rather strangely when it comes to conflicts. Towards the end of 1993, two years after regional conflict resolution and regional intervention had become the norm and not the exception, 

the OAU Charter's cardinal chapter is still: the infallibility of colonial borders and non-interference in the internal affairs of member states. These are the OAU's guiding principles which now look severely outdated.

The OAU is a casual spectator in Angola, Mozambique, Liberia and Somalia. The international community has seen fit to intervene in these countries, but not the OAU. Other conflicts where the world has yet to intervene, such as that in Sudan, are untouchable for the OAU. This is surprising, considering that Sudan's civil war is now Africa's oldest conflict and a recent study said that 1.3 million Southern Sudanese civilians had died war-related deaths over the past ten years.

Now it does, at last, seem as if there is an African regional organisation prepared to take the lead in conflict resolution. The Inter-Governmental Authority for Desertification and Development (IGADD), which links together Djibouti, Somalia, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and Sudan, has established a committee to mediate an end to the civil war in Sudan. The committee comprises of the heads of state of Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda, and is being chaired by the Kenyan president, Daniel arap Moi.

So far the four leaders have taken their task seriously and have set about fact finding amongst the belligerents. Both factions of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) were invited during November to meet the committee in Kampala, Uganda, during the summit meeting of the Preferential Trade Area (PTA), held between the 4th and 6th of November. Lieutenant General El Beshir attended the PTA meeting in his own right as head of the Khartoum regime and a member state. Meeting separately with the committee, all parties to the conflict reaffirmed their wish to co-operate with it in the search for peace.

It is difficult to raise too much hope of success in a conflict as intractable as that of Sudan, especially when both the credibility and the sincerity of many of the Sudanese players is in serious doubt. However, the fact that the four African leaders have found it important to publicly commit themselves to a peace effort in Sudan is a helpful sign for the long suffering people of the country and is also an encouraging development for Africa.

It is noteworthy that the presidents of Eritrea and Ethiopia, who have only recently seen the liberation of their own countries, should get involved in conflict resolution in Sudan. They have immense domestic problems to deal with as they set about building democracy and democratic institutions at home, without the need to burden themselves with the problems of Sudan. However, there are undoubtedly many lessons that all parties to the Sudanese conflict can learn from these young and energetic leaders.

The Gazette also wishes to acknowledge and applaud the efforts of friends of Sudan who have recently kept the people's plight high on the international political agenda. A list of all these people, humanitarian organisations and governments would take up the whole newsletter, but two in particular need to be singled out for special mention. They are Congressman Harry Johnston, Chairperson of the US House of Representative Subcommittee on Africa, and Congressman Frank Wolf. Their tireless campaign on behalf of the poor of Sudan is only matched by the vehemence with which they have been denounced and pilloried by the repressive Islamic Fundamentalist military regime in Khartoum.

Now that an African regional peace initiative has been launched by the IGADD committee, we hope that all those who are concerned and active in the interests of peace in Sudan will co-operate and co-ordinate with and assist this new peace effort, so that a swift resolution can be achieved.

Reprinted from SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, December 1993

Contact: SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, PO Box 2295, London W14 OND, UK


LOAD-DATE: January 10, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


THE PRESS AND THE TRANSITION


BYLINE: Zwelakhe Sislu, SUNDAY NATION, November 21, 1993


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

There has been, in recent weeks, a series of articles that have appeared in a Johannesburg daily newspaper under the anonymous authorship of "Johannesburg journalist".

In sum the articles have distilled the major problems confronting the diversification, and by extension, the democratisation of the press in South Africa.

I am not quite sure why "Johannesburg journalist" has decided to write anonymously because the points the author makes are valid and even critical to the transformation process we are going through.

The kernel of the argument contained in the articles is that the control of newspapers, which is in the hands of a few, makes nonsense of the argument of freedom of the press because it raises the trenchant question -- what freedom? and for whom? 

The country's print media has over the past three years dispensed generous doses of advice on the demerits of the liberation movements' different policy formulations.

By far the most memorable being the hysteria over the prospect of a policy of nationalisation by an ANC government.

It is true of course that it is the function of media to mirror the social reality and to highlight the hopes and fears of ordinary people.

Yet, the South African press, as a mirror of society, has looked at everything else, but itself.

Recently numerous seminars have been held to reflect on the question of freedom of the press, and often the focus of such talks is to get political guarantees that a new government will not temper with freedom of the press.

This assumes that indeed such freedom exists, in the first place, and that by the very nature of freedom, it is enjoyed by all equally. Freedom of the press is irrevocably linked to ownership.

In this country press ownership is exclusively white, in a market that is dominated by black consumers.

The most critical question about media freedom must therefore surely centre around ownership because it is the final repository of power and policy.

The attempt to depoliticise what is probably the most politicised institution is rather a fuss.

There is the argument that party-owned newspapers are limited in scope because they advance a narrow party political line. Which is true.

That line of logic should then be extended to say that similarly , a press that is exclusively owned by a minority white elite will likewise propagate the values of that class.

Politics, in other words, is not the sole preserve of political organisations and politicians. On the contrary, some of the most significant political agents in the country are major business companies.

And it is particularly true for the rest of the Western world that those who shape political policy are not themselves politicians but business people.

In South Africa, the two biggest conglomerates, Anglo American and Sanlam have respectively been tied to the Progressive Party (in all its phases of gestation) and to the National Party. These two companies together own 95 percent of all print media in this country.

By far the biggest consumers of newspapers are black people, yet this is not reflected in the ownership relations. One is not arguing that black ownership will in itself reflect the democratisation of media, but it will at the very least reflect accessibility to ownership.

In spite of the English press' long history of opposing the excesses of apartheid rule, it has been most resistant to change.

The National Party, which it has attacked with missionary zeal over the past four decades, has been rapidly conceding power, authority and privilege. And the plenary session at the World Trade Centre this week formalised the beginning of the orderly transfer of power from a white minority to the black majority.

This symbolised, in a sense, the strategic move by Afrikaners to commit group suicide in order to retain some influence, and not an entirely insignificant one, in a government of national unity.

Their perspective is informed by a sharp instinct of survival. It lies in the recognition that there has been a fundamental and irreversible shift from voting for the tribe to voting for the common good.

Afrikaners have had to come to terms with the reality of their Africanness in a way that the more privileged English have never had to.

The practice that attempted to shut out possibilities of Afrikaners having a meaningful control of media, and a significant stake in the economy when the National Party came to power in 1948 -- has once more arisen in the current situation.

The resistance to opening up media ownership, thus guaranteeing a genuine voice for the majority, may lead to intervention by a new government that believes it needs its own voice.

Government or party owned newspapers are to be avoided at all costs, since they tend to servily glorify party leadership instead of informing the mass of the people what the major debates of the day are.

But in a situation where all major media is owned, if you like, by hostile forces, there is every justification for government intervention.

The owners of these media understand how critically important they are in influencing society, and it is for this reason that the control of these newspapers is retained for political objectives.

This monopoly of the press thus means that there is less, and not more press freedom. Ownership of media cannot be divorced from the practice of a free press.

The press is not value neutral, it absorbs information from society and decides how best to disseminate it. In our experience, the interests of media owners have generally informed how much people know.

The press is a collective mobiliser as well as being a vehicle that enables different communities to exchange experiences. In this respect the press can become a critical tool for transformation.

The most effective way of securing freedom of the press is not through seeking political guarantees, but through the diversification of media -- in terms of views and of ownership.

Reprinted from SUNDAY NATION, November 21, 1993. SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: January 10, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1993 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


NOT FOR LOVE OF SOLDIERS


BYLINE: Ray Ekpu, NEWSWATCH, December 6, 1993


SECTION: VIEWPOINTS


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

There was no dawn broadcast. No dusk-to-dawn curfew. No martial music. No take-over of radio stations. No closure of airports and seaports. No shut-down of telephone lines. No tanks rolling in the streets. No tell- tale signs of a coup. But that was what it was. The generals had on Wednesday, November 17, imposed themselves, once again, on this unhappy country.

But the people are not breaking into song and dance, for this coup was totally uncalled for although some wrong-headed fellows had, in their desperation, called for it. True, there had been a general uncertainty in the land since June 23 when former President Ibrahim Babangida peremptorily scratched off the June 12 presidential election which, by popular admission, was free, fair and peaceful. But the country still had a fighting chance of keeping the generals at bay if Ernest Shonekan, the man who stepped in as Babangida stepped aside, had been given the chance to tackle the problems. 

For Shonekan, there was not even a day's honeymoon, as he was pounded from all sides, sometimes below the belt, by the press, his tribesmen and his detractors. All of these body blows had the cumulative effect of diminishing his ability to govern, reducing his government to a lame duck. Shonekan himself apparently believed in turning the other cheek, and not in counter-punching, a somewhat naive policy of appeasement. Perhaps in some distant date, Shonekan will stand at the podium and receive a medal as the most tolerant ruler in history but for now he can be dismissed as an 82-day wonder, as the man who had power dropped on his laps but who did not know what to do with it. And he is hereby dismissed.

However, Moshood Abiola, the man who won the annulled election, cannot be so dismissed. Apart from a few gaffes ("Nigeria will be turned into something more bloody than Bosnia and Somalia rolled into one;" "I'm larger than the party"), Abiola scores full marks for fighting a good fight. In the campaign for the restoration

of the election, he tried every trick in the book: confrontation ("Shonekan's government is a bastard"); conciliation (meetings with Tony Anenih, Arthur Nzeribe and Shehu Yar'Adua); and flattery (Abacha's "common sense, experience, tact and intellect"). He apparently bowed to the popular saying that "flattery will get you anywhere," but it did not get him anywhere.

The fight that Abiola conducted was, at a personal level, his fight, the fight to be the president of Nigeria; but at a higher level, it was our own fight. The fight for the just sharing of political and economic power in Nigeria, the fight for the soul of Nigeria. Abiola must have paid a high price in waging this war but he succeeded in raising our consciousness, in bringing our problems into bold relief. I dare say that in future no one will be able to casually wipe off the will of the people without a thought for the repercussions. To Abiola, this may be cold comfort but it can be said that be accomplished that for Nigeria.

And what have those who requested for a coup accomplished for Nigeria? A coup. The man in dark glasses has done them the favour. It's the height of naivety for these pro-coup democratic activists, is that not a contradiction in terms, to have thought that if June 12 was the question a coup was the answer.

What the coup lobbyists didn't realise is that if sugar is sweet, and money is sweeter, power is sweetest. As Henry Kissinger put it, "power is the ultimate aphrodisiac."

It ought to have occurred to them that anyone who decided to put his life on the line and execute a coup would most likely keep the power acquired rather than hand it over to someone else. Abacha has proved it. He has not

handed it to :Abiola. As things are now, the only post that Abiola can hold; in the Abacha government is FHS (Friend of the Head of State), which is still many notches

away from the one he coveted: president.

And with the assimilation by osmosis of Baba Gana Kingibe, Abiola's running mate in the election, into the military government as the minister of external affairs, June 12 has come to a sorry end. In fact, in Abacha 's brief-as-a-mini-skirt speech on taking over, June 12 appeared only once in a parenthetical reference to the problems that provided him with the excuse to intrude on our consciousness.

Although there has been no articulate and ground- shaking opposition to the return of the military, Abacha must not misjudge the mood of the nation. It is not for the love of the military that there has been this sold sound of silence. It is simply evidence that the flaccidity of Shonekan's government and the interminable uncertainty may have driven them to the point of exasperation and resignation. It is a situation of interim numbness from which they will soon recover to reclaim their right to democracy.

Abacha has given himself a tall agenda. He wants to reorganise and reform all the wayward institutions. He may be a tough soldier but I can swear that all the problems of those institutions cannot be swept away with the wave of his swagger stick during the very brief period that he must stay at Aso Rock. All he should do is do what he can and quit. Those problems will outlast him.

Also, he talked about a constitutional conference to determine the future constitutional structure of Nigeria.

The fault, I dare say, is not within the leaves of the constitution. Britain doesn't even have a written constitution but the system works. We tried the parliamentary system in the 1960s and failed. America's presidential constitution works only because they want it to work. How can ours work when soldiers are always at the door waving a smoking gun?

We are sick and tired of "military messiahs."

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, December 6, 1993.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications Limited

Contact: Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria; phone:(011) 496-0950. Fax:(011) 962-887.


LOAD-DATE: January 10, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

304 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


EXPERIENCED TRIO LEAD SHREWD ANC CAMPAIGN


BYLINE: Anton Harber, THE WEEKLY MAIL AND GUARDIAN, November 26 to December 2, 1993


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Watch this trio: Popo Molefe, Terror Lekota and Ketso Gordhan. All former mass democratic movement activists, they are now running the African National Congress Elections Commission.

This department, which will essentially run the ANC show in the buildup to the April ballot, has become an enclave of former United Democratic Front activists who are bringing to bear their old mobilising and organising abilities.

These three are old hands at UDF campaigns to get people to boycott the ballot, and they know how to get picketers to the voting stations. They have never tried the same with voters. But if the first two elements of their campaign for the April election are anything to go (by, they are men to watch. 

The first phase of their campaign centres on "people's forums". Nelson Mandela and other tripartite alliance leaders travel to public meetings around the country to invite communities to raise their concerns and to listen to them. It is foremost a listening -- and not a speaking -- tour.

This approach builds on two ANC strengths: Mandela's personal stature, and the traditional image of the ANC as a "parliament of the people", a broadly-based organisation that represents a diverse mass constituency.

The negotiations process has damaged the latter image, with many traditional ANC supporters feeling that the organisation has neglected basic voter demands in the rush for a settlement. For some, the initials "ANC" have become associated more with cocktail parties than with people's parties.

The ANC's strategy recognises this alienation. It acknowledges that there are many potential ANC voters who are disgruntled for some or other reason (because Winnie Mandela was booted out of office, or because she wasn't booted out of all of them; because of ANC policy on land, or because of a lack of ANC policy on land...). The forums are intended to allow individuals to express their gripes and feel a part of the organisation again.

The key to the election result may be which party most successfully projects itself as the party of democracy, and the ANC is trying to jump the queue by demonstrating internal democracy at work.

At the same time, this process gives ANC leaders a chance to get a feel for the issues that matter most to people.; It has the added advantage of allowing the ANC to start its campaign early without running the danger of exhausting the speech-making potential of its leaders before the climax.

By all accounts, the meetings have so far been highly successful. The ANC took a risk by starting off in

Natal a fortnight ago, but the gamble has paid off: in many cases there have been too many people attending with too many issues they want to raise with the leadership -- a problem every politician would like to have.

Having had 14 such meetings in Natal -- with attendance ranging between 200 and 10,000 -- they now plan five or six in the PWV area, two in the Northern Transvaal and one in the OFS. Others will be held without Mandela.

It is a significant sign of ANC priorities that the election strategists made maximum use of Mandela in Natal (eight meetings in one weekend) and are not taking him to the Western Cape at this stage of the campaign.

The ANC is using its process of drawing up nomination lists and a manifesto as the second phase of the campaign.

Normally, such documents are prepared before the campaign and presented as vote-catching tools; the ANC, however, is using the process of drawing up these documents to secure its basic support base.

At first glance, the elaborate process created to draw up the ANC's election lists over a three-month period seems excessively complex and arcane. But it is a shrewd way of mobilising internal support, involving members and potential members in the process and demonstrating a commitment to democracy.

The ANC was presented with a potential nightmare in selecting the 1,050 names it needs for the elections (200 on the national list for the national assembly; 200 on the regional lists for the assembly; about 470 for regional government; and 90 for the senate). It has to balance the conflicting needs of a diverse constituency, including its alliance partners, Cosatu and the Communist Party, and other members of the Patriotic Front, and find a balance of gender, age, race and region. It has to accommodate former guerrillas, exiles, former political prisoners and an old guard in search of pensions -- all of this in a situation where there are hundreds of people competing for what would be well-paid and influential jobs.

The Elections Commission is trying to turn this into a weapon of potential advantage.

It has opened up the process to non-members, by inviting all "mass democratic movement" structures to make nominations, drawing into its ranks potential sources of dissidence and dissatisfaction. So even some Azapo members have been nominated, ensuring that people who may otherwise be drawn away by far left organisations are kept within the fold.

Anyone can be nominated, and some surprises are expected, though those nominated will be obliged, if elected, to join the ANC and sub;it to caucus discipline.

The names that come forward will be sorted by a special committee to ensure that the list is properly representative, all the candidates meet the legal requirements and the 30 percent quota of women is fulfilled. These names will then be put to regional votes which will determine the order of the list. The final say rests with the National Executive Committee, but it may only change the order of names; it may not add or remove candidates.

The regional meetings will also debate the manifesto being drafted by the Elections Commission.

This elaborate process ensure that while there is wide participation, there is also a measure of control over the outcome. But, because the powers of the special committee and the NEC are carefully proscribed, the potential for conflict is limited.

The whole procedure is begin overseen by the Independent Mediation Services of South Africa. It climaxes with the national congress on January 7, the ANC's 82nd birthday, when the list, the manifesto and the reconstruction accord will be finalised. -30- Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, November 26 to December 2, 1993. WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.

305 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 20, 1993-January 16, 1994


IFP MAY FIGHT ELECTION WITHOUT BUTHELEZI


BYLINE: Farouk Chothia, THE WEEKLY MAIL AND GUARDIAN, November 26 to December 2, 1993


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Leading figures in the Inkatha Freedom Party are thinking the unthinkable. They are not ruling out the possibility of contesting next April's election without Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi.

But they insist this eventuality -- the political equivalent of Hamlet without the prince -- is unlikely to happen.

Speculation has been fueled by two developments this week. At an IFP rally in Durban on Monday, Buthelezi warned he would resign as president if a planned special IFP conference voted down his rejectionist stance on elections. It was the third time he has made this threat this year. 

And in Washington, Buthelezi's former close associate and past Inkatha general secretary Oscar Dhlomo said he thought the IFP leader might soon retire from public life and leave his party to fight elections without him.

Dhlomo, who quit his Inkatha post in 1990 and now heads the Institute for Multiparty Democracy, reportedly said it was not in Buthelezi's nature to participate in a process he had so vehemently opposed. At the same time, many rising IFP leaders were keen to fight the elections, and tensions were simmering in the organisation.

In an interview, IFP national spokesman Ziba Jiyane said he expected the IFP to survive even if Buthelezi stepped down as its leader at a special general conference to be help either next month or early next year. However, for this to happen, Buthelezi would have to give the party his blessing.

Jiyane said that while he respected Dhlomo's view, as he had "knowledge" of Buthelezi, he did not agree with his assessment.

It was unlikely that the special general conference of the IFP would go against Buthelezi's wish to boycott the April poll.

"Chief Buthelezi is very popular in the IFP. Nobody can conceivably challenge his leadership," Jiyane added.

Observers believe that IFP moderates, who want the IFP to fight the election, may attempt to strengthen their hand through internal elections for a new central committee. Jiyane said that the IFP planned to hold elections for its leadership structures at branch and provincial level.

And although only the IFP annual general conference can elect a new central committee in terms of the constitution, the organisation will "consider" holding elections for the central committee at the special general conference.

Observers point out that the IFP has not help central committee elections for the last five years.

Buthelezi appointed his closest confidant, Walter Felgate, to the central committee. If elections are held, IFP moderates could try to oust him, paving the way for then to increase their influence over the IFP president.

Dhlomo -- a former right-hand man of the IFP chief -- said he believed Buthelezi would consider retirement more seriously if he was given assurances that he would be left in peace and given recognition for his role in the liberation struggle.

"For Buthelezi to participate in the transitional executive council and government of national unity after his determined opposition to every aspect of the transitional arrangements would be a humiliating climbdown which, as I know him, he would find hard to swallow.

"Through his consistent stand, he may be preparing quietly to make his exit from political life," said Dhlomo.

There is little prospect, however, of IFP moderates seeking to oust Buthelezi. Besides his overwhelming personal hold on the party machine, the IFP's support among both rural blacks and whites in Natal largely depends on him.

Observers believe that possible successors to Buthelezi are IFP national chairman Frank Mdlalose, or kwaZulu government chief negotiator Ben Ngubane. Jiyane -- a former exiled leader of the Pan Africanist Congress -- stands an outside chance.

Since he joined the party early this year, he has had a meteoric rise in the IFP, begin its constitutional adviser at the World Trade Center Talks and later appointed as its media spokesman and national political director.

He also serves on the IFP election commission.

IFP moderates are keeping their options open with some even considering the possibility of breaking away from the IFP to form a new party with disaffected Nats.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, November 26 to December 2, 1993. WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: January 10, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

306 of 306 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


MARCH 8, 1993


SOMALIA PRESS INVASION BECOMES PART OF THE STORY Hordes of reporters brought their own reality to the Horn of Africa -- and took it away when they left.


BYLINE: Storer H. Rowley * Chicago Tribune Company


LENGTH: 1707 words


DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia


 

On Marine patrol in the streets of Mogadishu, the radio crackled to

life inside the column's command vehicle: "Downtown Six! Downtown Six!"

Capt. Bob Castellvi diverted his armored convoy to a private house where an American had just received death threats and needed protection. "It's probably some (spy) or a State Department type," mused Castellvi, 30, as he wheeled his light armored vehicle into action near the U.S. Embassy.

The mystery house turned out to be a compound rented by ABC-TV. The complaint was made by "Nightline" host Ted Koppel. The man in danger was Said Samatar, a Somali-born professor of African history from Rutgers University, whom ABC had hired as a consultant. 

Samatar, Koppel and a camera crew piled into Castellvi's armored vehicle, which was getting crowded. It might have been a metaphor for the media offensive in Somalia.

"Who are you?" demanded Koppel, when he saw another passenger taking notes, wedged in among the Marines in the crew.

"I'm from the Chicago Tribune. I'm spending the day with these Marines. Some of them are from Chicago. I can't believe this. Media people are falling all over each other on this story. You can't even go on a secret rescue mission without stumbling into other reporters."

Koppel smiled in agreement. Then he interviewed the Chicago reporter to that effect on camera. Then the reporter interviewed Koppel about his endangered consultant, who sat sheepishly on an ammunition crate as the windowless vehicle rumbled along en route to Mogadishu International Airport and a secure flight home to the Rutgers campus in Newark, NJ.

"A high-level source in Somalia, someone whose word we trust, told us this man's life had been threatened, and we are taking it seriously," Koppel said. So ABC had called the Marines.

In this civil-war-ravaged country, where more than 300,000 people have starved to death, hundreds of reporters were on hand to cover the mercy mission of thousands of foreign soldiers trying to provide security and food relief in Operation Restore Hope.

A Study in Excess. After the first month, the bulk of the reporters gave up on the story and moved on. Most pulled out after President George Bush's New Year's visit, but only after astonishing a starved and strapped Somalia with excess.

They shone TV lights in the camouflage-streaked faces of Marines hitting the beaches. They brought noisy electrical generators and erected a forest of satellite dishes on the roof of a makeshift hotel. They rented houses, chartered airplanes, sent in their most senior anchors and spent millions of dollars on coverage as sporadic gunfire rattled the nation.

Koppel, Dan Rather of CBS and Christiane Amanpour of CNN were among those doing standups from the roof of the Mogadishu airport terminal as Marines splashed ashore in the background.

Tom Brokaw and NBC had taken over much of the space at the only functioning hotel in Mogadishu, a three-story building with 58 rooms dubbed the Sahafi ("journalist" in Arabic) Hotel by its enterprising Somali owner, Mohamed Jirdeh Hussein.

From its rooftop, wide microwave dishes yawned skyward toward satellites over the Indian Ocean. Primitive refugee huts covered with green plastic climbed a nearby hillside, forming a poignant backdrop for TV reports, along with the gunfire.

The distinctive stench of the dead, buried in shallow graves that marched sadly down the slope, wafted daily over the dusty road toward the hotel, suspended in the searing equatorial air.

Up the street, inside a walled compound, CBS had the rarest of

things in Somalia: an air-conditioned suite of offices. It was converted to a bureau and packed with food, fruit, supplies and equipment. CBS reportedly put down a $17,000 deposit for the house. The New York Times paid $12,000 for one month's rent for another house.

Farther on was the spacious ABC operation, another group of buildings in a compound guarded by a retinue of local Somali employees, not far from the U.S. Embassy. CNN also set up a private, well-stocked, impromptu bureau.

What Famine? This media assault on Somalia was among the most bizarre spectacles of the television age, but covering Somalia has generally been an odd experience for journalists for a host of reasons, ranging from the availability of food and supplies in a country with seemingly little of both, to the red-carpet treatment given the press by the U.S. military, to the constant dangers of looting and robbery, leading journalists to hire armed bodyguards to protect them.

Despite widespread famine, the Sahafi provided meals of all kinds for paying guests, ranging from pasta and salad to rice and meat dishes for lunch or dinner. There were eggs, bread with butter and jam, or rolls with mangoes and coffee at breakfast.

Because the famine in Mogadishu was created by warlords hoarding food and controlling its flow to the city's markets, there was plenty of food for those few who had money.

The media grew to depend on resourceful people like hotelier Hussein, who charged by the bed ($85 a night). He could always change dollars quickly into Somali shillings and tell guests where to buy things or get their laundry done in a day -- even in chaotic, war-blasted Mogadishu, where there are no banks or cleaners.

In this powerless capital he kept gasoline-powered electrical generators running around the clock to light the hotel. This kept journalists, their laptop computers and their satellite telephones in business when darkness fell everywhere else.

Military, media team up. The media and the military have enjoyed unusually good relations during Operation Restore Hope, especially compared with relations during other recent U.S. combat operations, from Grenada to Panama to the Persian Gulf.

The U.S. military in Somalia was so helpful, harried journalists grew to depend on U.S. troops for occasional rides, rations, and refills of canteens and water bottles. Navy medics advised news gatherers on everything from sunblock and heat exhaustion to diarrhea and drug-resistant forms of malaria in East Africa. And members of the U.S.-led military contingent occasionally came to the aid of journalists when gangs tried to rob them or, in one instance in Bardera, surrounded their compound.

American forces even allowed journalists to check their guards' guns at the gates when entering a secured base or airport. Upon leaving,

exchanges like this were common:

"Hello, staff sergeant, could I please have the Chicago Tribune's gun? It's a Soviet 7.62 mm pistol with 'CCCP' on the handle. Here's my card."

"Here you go, sir," a Marine would respond, emerging from a guardhouse with the weapon and the removed ammunition clip. "Please wait until you're outside the perimeter before putting the clip back in."

Normally, any media use of guards with guns would be a topic of hot debate and ethical soul-searching. Most professional foreign correspondents are adamant about never taking sides or carrying weapons. Packing a pistol can give the wrong appearance, as if one has become a combatant.

But such discussions were short-lived in Somalia, where private relief agencies, and even the United Nations, have been operating for months by hiring armed Somali guards. Tribune photographer Chris Walker realized that need when he was accosted one day by two men brandishing AK-47 assault rifles and motioning for him to turn over his cameras. The Tribune's interpreter, Abdul Rahman Abukar, 27, leapt from the paper's car, pulled out his small pistol and made the would-be robbers back down.

But even as Abukar covered the two men with his pistol, another man reached into the car and stole Walker's camera bag. Out sprang the Tribune's driver, Aden Hassan Ali, 20, another honest Somali tired of the looters ruling his country, who struggled with the thief, retrieved the bag and returned it to Walker.

Not everyone survived such acts of bravery. Ali Ibrahim Mursal, 37, chief driver for the Associated Press, was killed January 5 defending three AP staff members in Mogadishu's main market.

When a robber tried to rip a gold chain off the neck of one of the three AP staff members, Mursal jumped on the thief's back. But another thug put the muzzle of an AK-47 in Mursal's back and pulled the trigger. He died in surgery hours later at Digfer Hospital. *


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1993
